Personal records: (also Abramsperg; Abramszperg; Cyrillic: Абрамсберг Антоний) (1743-11-16 – 1809-05-29, Polatsk, Vitebsk Governorate). Religion: Catholic.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; French; Latin rhetoric and poetics; mathematics; moral theology.
Career: Priest. Abramsberg was a French and German teacher (1776–1777), a moral theology teacher (1796–1797), a novice master and a preacher (1797–1809) at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. At the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium, Abramsberg was head of the student hostel, a German and French teacher and a mathematics teacher first in 1783–1784, later in 1787–1790. Abramsberg was head of the student hostel at the Vitebsk Jesuit Collegium in 1784–1785. He taught French (1785–1787, 1792–1795), German (1785–1786, 1792–1796), Latin rhetoric and poetics (1786–1787) and worked as head of the student hostel (1794–1795) at the Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit Collegium. He was a German teacher and head of the student hostel at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium in 1791–1792.
Teaching institutions and families: Polatsk Jesuit Collegium; Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium; Vitebsk Jesuit Collegium; Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit Collegium; Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium.

Personal records: (also Adodurow, Adoduroff; Cyrillic: Адодуров, Ададуров, Атадуров, Одадуров, Ододуров / Basilius (?); Василий Евдокимович) (1709-03-15/26, village of Bugreevo, Novgorod Governorate – 1780-11-05/16, Saint Petersburg; buried in Lazarevskoye Cemetery, Saint Alexander Nevsky Lavra). Married to: 1) Kleopatra Alekseevna (1717–?); 2) Elizaveta Dmitrievna Muravieva (1740?–1770). Children: Tatiana (1749–?); Dmitry (1760-?), Vasily (1765–1845). Religion: Orthodox Christian.
Education: Adodurov received his basic education at the Novgorod Greek-Slavic school. From the spring of 1723 to December 1725, he likely studied at the Moscow Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy. Beginning in 1726, he continued his studies at the Saint Petersburg Academy School. In February 1727, he was enrolled as a student at the Saint Petersburg Academy University.
Languages and other subjects taught by t:
Church Slavonic; Latin; Russian; German (grammar).
Rhetoric; mathematics (arithmetic, geometry).
Career: Translator. From 1728 to 1733, Vasily Adodurov worked as a translator at the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences. During this period, he translated Primechaniia k Vedomostiam (Notes to the Journal), Kratkoe opisanie Kommentariev Akademii nauk (A Brief Description of the Comments of the Academy of Sciences) and other documents for the Academy’s chancellery. After 1731, he also served as a German teacher. On 26 October 1733, he was appointed adjunct professor in the Department of Higher Mathematics at the Academy of Sciences. In 1735, he became a member of the Academic Assembly, a research center for the Russian language. From July 1736 onwards, he taught Slavonic grammar and Latin twice a week at the Junker Senate School. In 1738, he began teaching the «rules of Russian grammar» and rhetoric at the Academy of Sciences. From 1740 onwards, he also taught arithmetic and geometry. After 1739, Adodurov served as a translator for cabinet minister Artemy Petrovich Volynsky. In 1742, he oversaw the work of the Moscow branch of the Academy’s printing house. Around the same time, he became secretary to Count Aleksei Grigorievich Razumovsky, who supported his appointment as a Russian tutor to Princess Sophie of Anhalt-Zerbst (the future Empress Catherine II) in March 1744. In March 1741, Adodurov left the Academy of Sciences to join the Heroldmeister Office, initially as an Assessor. He was promoted to Collegiate Councillor in July 1744 and to Heroldmeister in March 1753. In 1759, he was elevated to the rank of State Councillor. In 1761, he was appointed Vice-Governor of the Orenburg Governorate. In 1762, he became a Privy Councillor and President of the College of Manufacturing. In October 1762, he was appointed Curator of Imperial Moscow University, a position he held until 1778. In 1779, he was elected an Honorary Member of the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences. Adodurov was awarded the Order of Saint Alexander Nevsky and the Order of Saint Anna.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School (1731–1741); Academy University (1731–1741); Junker school of Senate (1736 onwards), all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status: Sophie Friederike Auguste of Anhalt-Zerbst-Dornburg, princess, later Russian Empress Catherine II. From 1744, Adodurov was her Russian tutor.

Personal records: (or Agentoff) (ar. 1740, Russian Empire – after 1769-06 and before 1769-09-09, Moscow). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Agentov was one of the first students at Moscow University, founded in 1755. Around 1760, he was sent to the university of Königsberg in order to improve his knowledge of German.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German reading and writing; German morphology, declension and conjugation; German syntax; Latin reading and writing.
Career: Agentov became known as the first Russian author of a German grammar. As early as 1757, still a student at Moscow University, he became an instructor at the grammar school (gimnaziia), which was attached to the university and taught “the rudiments of German” (first German class) and Latin reading and writing. After his short one-term stay at the university of Königsberg in 1760, he returned to Moscow University and the grammar school in 1761, where he became teacher of the second German class (the so-called “etymological” class, which meant in fact “morphological"). In summer 1762, Agentov took over the third German class (“syntax class”) from his colleague Fischer. His successor in the second German class was Ivan Kalinovskiy. In the third class, Agentov remained as teacher until his death. He was replaced by his colleague Johann Bernhard Pfundheller. In 1761, the conference of professors of Moscow University commissioned Agentov to compose a German grammar, since there was a huge lack of such textbooks. Agentov completed this order very quickly, publishing his grammar only a year later in 1762. In fact, this grammar was nothing more, for the most part, than a literal plagiarism of two other German grammars published in Russia in 1745 and 1760 (German grammar by M. Schwanwitz, 3rd edition, 1745 and German grammar by J.E. Gretsch, 1760). It is interesting to note how J.G. Reichel, Agentov’s German colleague and professor of German language and literature at Moscow University since 1761, commented on Agentov’s commission to compose a German grammar. Reichel attributed it to the fact that his own [Reichel’s] reputation had been harmed by his opponents at the university. Thus, he wrote to a German colleague in Saint Petersburg, professor Johann Joachim Rost, in his letter of 12 March 1761: “You do know that my abilities were misjudged and people did not want to make use of my services. I received the order to compose a primer [ABC-book]. Agentov is to compose the German grammar. Prof. Müller [...] will be quite amused that the composition of a German grammar is treated so lightly and that people gamble with the reputation of the university for all world to see.” [Reichel, quoted from Lehmann, 1966, p. 144]. According to the minutes of the conference of professors from 26 January 1762, Agentov also worked on the translation of a book of syntax by J.B. Basedow, which he had received from Reichel, but this work was not completed (Пенчко, 1960, p. 237). Agentov’s professional skills as a teacher, apparently, were not always faultless. Due to the fact that Agentov turned up in his classes “very rarely”, in 1764, the university management even thought about releasing him from his duties. But instead, Agentov received quite a big salary increase, which was subject to the condition that he should improve his behaviour so that students could learn not only from his instruction but also from his positive example. (Пенчко, 1962, p. 282, 292). After 1762, Agentov was also among the group of translators at Moscow University and published several works. His book «Открытие сокровенных художеств, служащее для фабрикантов, мануфактуристов, художников, мастеровых людей и для экономии» [Discovery of secret arts for fabricants, manufacturers, artists, craftsmen and for economy] is deemed to be his most important work. It was the first book in the Russian language about chemical engineering and was published in three editions.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school (gimnaziia) attached to Moscow University (1757–1769).
Students and their social status: Nobles; non-nobles. The grammar school (gimnaziia) at Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative with the intention of educating students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: One department for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a governmental scholarship and self-funding pupils. At the beginning, there were 50 scholarship students (among them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students was achieved in 1787, when the school counted 1010 pupils (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials: Apparently, there were problems in the teaching of languages at the grammar school of Moscow University, so much so that the professors of the Moscow University felt compelled to draw attention to this issue in their conference in May 1767. They made the following decision: “It has been observed that students at the grammar school, especially in the lower classes, are very tired because of studying grammar rules that they do not understand and that are not explained in practice; whereby the Conference demands: 1) That teachers, writing on the blackboard examples subject to grammar analysis, should immediately translate them into Russian or from Russian into French, German (or Latin and Italian) and that they should do it daily. This is particularly important for practising conversation (dialogues). Dialogues, words and phrases explained in such a way should be learned by heart. Grammar rules, that have been explained in detail during the analysis and been read about in grammar books, and thus understood without much difficulty, should be studied in advance. One day a week should be used entirely to practise free conversation consisting of questions and answers. 2) That they force their students to do exercises given in the classroom and for homework three times a week, and that on the following morning teachers should sign the revised work and note the day when the work was given and corrected. Similar exercises should be introduced by teachers in other classes, too, for example, in the mathematics, as well as in the geography and history classes. These exercises, showing the diligence of both teachers and students, should be observed by the inspector and the rector, they should be the first to be paid attention to by the examiners on the public examinations.” (Minutes of the conference of the professors of Moscow University from 12 May 1767, published in Пенчко, 1963, p. 41). Thus, the main focus was on the translation of typical sentences. Contrary to prior practice, the student’s mother tongue, Russian, was now incorporated into the process of instruction in order to increase the student’s understanding. Oral skills were to be built up by memorizing sample dialogues, which were presented in the so called “dialogue books”. After the grammar books, these dialogue books represented the main basis for language instruction. The first years at the grammar school attached to Moscow University were characterized by a significant lack of textbooks for language tuition. There were only a few standard works, which had been printed at the Academic University in Saint Petersburg and which were used at the Academic grammar school as well. One of these books was Joachim Lange’s book “School dialogues”, published in 1738, which was used in the lower German classes according to the regulations of the Moscow grammar school of 1755 (see: Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). Another standard work was M. Schwanwitz’s German grammar, printed in a fourth edition at the Academic University in Saint Petersburg in 1745. Most likely, it was used at the very beginning of the Moscow grammar school, too. Still in 1758, Moscow University ordered 40 copies for the grammar school pupils (Пенчко, 1960, p. 140). Agentov’s colleague, J.G. Reichel, introduced J.Ch. Gottsched’s grammar books to Moscow University. These were Gottsched’s “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ and “ Kern der Deutschen Sprachkunst“, which were used by Reichel in his classes (see letter from Ch.G. Köllner to G.F. Müller dated 17 October 1757, cit. in Lehmann, 1966, p. 119). In 1758, Gottsched’s “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst” was introduced officially by Mikhail Lomonosov’s school regulations (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459). Possibly, Agentov also used the first complete Russian translation of Gottsched’s “Grundlegung” in his classes. This book was Gretsch’s Немецкая Грамматика, published in 1760 at the First Noble Cadet Corps in St Petersburg, which was copied by Agentov for his own grammar in 1761/1762. Gottsched’s works were used in the upper German classes (syntax and style). They are listed in a catalogue of the “school library”, attached to the minutes of the professors’ conference of 15 January 1765 [“Catalogus Librorum pro stipendiariis studiosis et discipulis universitatis et gymnasii moscuensis” (Пенчко, 1962, p. 29)]. Moreover, pupils were rewarded with Gottsched’s works at the yearly public exams, for example pupils of Agentov’s class in July 1765 with Gottsched’s “Vorübungen der Beredsamkeit” (Пенчко, 1962, p. 129, 131). In general, grammar books constituted the main basis for language instruction in the 18th century. The grammar covered all the important aspects of a language, not only the grammar rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology”, which meant morphology, syntax and prosody. Hölterhof’s “Немецкой Целлариус” was used intensively in the grammar school. Only one year after its publication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and officially imposed it for use in German classes (Пенчко, 1962, p. 255).

Personal records: Born in Paris Father: Charles Agée († Paris, 1775-06-05) Mother: Anne Hebour Brother: Jean Agée Married to: C. Agée
Career:
Wigmaker who arrived in Russia in 1766.
He was employed in the service of Baroness Stroganov. He was later engaged as a tutor at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. He went to Paris during Grand Duke Paul's European tour. He resided on Sennaya Street in Saint Petersburg in 1775. By an act drawn up at the consulate's chancery on February 1, 1779, he established a partnership with Alexandre Beaulard, which was dissolved as early as September 11 of the same year. In 1792, he was a moneylender in Saint Petersburg, associated with a certain Chef (he lent on pledges at 8%). At that time, he lived on the Moika, in the Glebov house, next to that of Marshal Orlov. He mingled with the court's maître d'hôtel Bertin (J.-J. Bertin?), and the wigmaker Noëlles (?).
He was denounced in April 1792 by the governor of the pages, Chevalier de Mullot de Villenaut, for having uttered, during a boozy evening at Ballu's, in the presence of many Frenchmen, "injurious words against crowned heads, saying that they were tyrants and that the people were foolish for allowing themselves to be governed by them, being men like them, and finally that if the entire royal family and opposing nobility had been slaughtered, affairs would have soon been resolved". Interrogated about his political views and his activities as a usurer, he was ultimately expelled from Russia by an order signed by Catherine II on April 25, 1792.

(or Maurice Nikolayevich) (*1779-03-13, Paris – †1847-01-06/18, Moscow; buried in the heterodox cemetery on the Vvedensky Hills in Moscow). Married to: Larmée (*Moscow, bapt. Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul, 1782-11-02 – †1850-03-13/25). Children:

  • Allart (*1808-11-05/17 – †1862), a student at Moscow University, then a surgeon, college assessor, chief physician of the Postal Hospital in 1845, and tate ouncillor in 1853e married Varvara Petrovna Beklemisheva, daughter of Court Councillor Piotr Petrovich Beklemishev.
Education: Land Noble Cadet Corps
Career: Bookseller. He was said to have been a lawyer in France, a military man, then a professor. He at the Land Noble Cadet Corps and served until 1819. Alongside his military career, he purchased, in 1807, from André Lemoine, the former bookstore of Dominique Bugnet in Moscow. At that time, it included a "Library for sale and subscription" consisting of 13,000 volumes, divided into 22 sections. He relocated it to Bolshaya Lubianka Street, in the house of Prince Nikolay Alexeyevich Golitsyn. He published a new catalog containing more than 15,000 volumes. Allart made the theatrical section the specialty of his bookstore, which earned him the title of "Bookseller to Her Imperial Majesty's Theatre." In 1808, Allart opened a "depot" of books in the Great Arbat Theatre. His catalogs and the organization of his bookstore were well ahead of everything else in this field. The bookstore was permanently closed after the War of 1812, and Allart turned to teaching. He donated 500 rubles to the Russian army in 1812, as the Napoleonic troops approached. He was among those French nationals who were exiled in 1812 on the orders of Count Fiodor Rostopchin, the governor-general of Moscow, to the Nizhny Novgorod province. One of the reasons for his arrest in 1812 was, as Count Rostopchin explained after the war, his membership in the "Illuminati" sect, a Masonic branch. Auguste Semen, a future famous typographer and Russian publisher, was arrested at the same time for the same reasons. Allart was indeed a convinced Freemason: he was a member of the Moscow lodges, Neptune (1816–1821, supervisor and master of ceremonies) and Le Phoenix (1818–1821, master and master of ceremonies), as well as a lodge in St. Petersburg, Les Amis réunis (honorary member). Allart returned to Moscow in 1814. He taught French at the St. Catherine of Alexandria Institute in 1819 and also at the Noble Boarding School of Moscow University starting in 1822. That same year, the governing Senate ratified the decision to take him into state service; he was promoted to titular councillor in 1827 (effective 1825). In 1826 he was awarded a gold snuffbox for presenting a French grammar to the emperor. In 1828, he was decorated with the Order of Saint Anne, 3rd class, on the proposal of the Council of the St. Catherine of Alexandria Institute. In 1830, he was appointed on a probationary basis to the Noble Cadet Corps No. 1 in Moscow as a French teacher. In 1831, he was dismissed from the Noble Boarding School during its transformation but was re-hired in 1832. He served as a professor in this institution without compensation until 1838 (however, in 1834 he was awarded a ring set with diamonds). That same year, he took an examination at Moscow University that confirmed his knowledge of French "in all its fullness." In 1836, he was confirmed in the Cadet Corps as a supervisor and French teacher and received a diamond ring for his service. He also taught at the House of Education in Moscow and was awarded 400 rubles for his efforts. That same year, the upper class of the Noble Boarding School at the university closed; Allart was dismissed but, in 1838, he was awarded 1,500 rubles. Appointed as a ollege ssessor (1838) and ourt ounselor (1841 or 1843), he had already received insignia for impeccable service over fifteen years by 1839. The Allart family had been inscribed in the first part of the nobility register for the Moscow government in 1829, but Eugène Allart was only registered in 1834.

Personal records: (*Pisarevka sloboda (Pisarevka settlement) of Sloboda Ukraine Governorate). Son of a priest of the Church of the Intercession at Pisarevka sloboda. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1759 onwards, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including the theological class (he graduated after a four-year course).
Career: It is only known that, after graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium in 1771, Antonovich became a Latin grammar teacher in the Grammar Class of the same school.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium.
Students and their social status:
In the 1770s, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class taught by Antonovich.
Most of the students at Kharkov Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the Grammar Class taught by Antonovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. During Antonovich’s tenure as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on ‘How to Teach and What to Teach’, issued in 1769 by Bishop Samuil Mislavsky of Belgorod and addressed to the rector, prefect, and teachers, were in use at the Collegium. The document gives a sufficiently complete idea of teaching basic school disciplines, including foreign languages. The instructions indicated the need for Latin grammar teaching according to the book by Christoph Cellarius in Johann Matthias Gesner’s version published at Moscow University in 1762 instead of the book by Alvarez, which was used at the Kharkiv Collegium in the first half of the 18th century. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also pointed out that grammar rules were necessarily supposed to be consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” Samuil Mislavsky recommended this book’s Russian edition as well as the original one. The instructions contained detailed recommendations on the organization of classroom and homework exercises for students. It listed sections and paragraphs of the books that the teacher was supposed to be guided by at various stages of teaching. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also focused on methods that would allow students to retain “entertainment words, intelligent designs, prompt responses and pleasant adventures of eminent men”. For this purpose, he advised teachers to use the book “Reasonable Comrade” by P. Semionov (П. Семенов, Товарищ разумный и замысловатый, или Собрание хороших слов, разумных замыслов, скорых ответов, учтивых насмешек и приятных приключений знатных мужей древняго и нынешняго веков, Moscow, 1787). In addition, the author of the Instructions advised teachers not to bother their students with learning rules and exceptions by heart, in order to keep them studying with interest. He drew the attention of teachers to the fact that a child could learn all the grammar rules, but it would not help him understand or write, if he or she did not use them constantly in their own translations. It is important to note that all of the books were available at the library of Kharkiv Collegium (they were bought on purpose; quite a few books were donated by Samuil Mislavsky). According to the library catalogue of 1769, the Collegium had several different books by Cellarius and Lange. Their number exceeded ten at the time. Besides that, the library had a few modern dictionaries, lexicons by different authors, published in Halle and other centres (unfortunately, the book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately). Personal records: (also Azum; Cyrillic: Азум, Франциск-Ксаверий) (1784-07-19 – 1847-04-14, Linz). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Asum arrived in the Russian Empire in 1803 and joined the Society of Jesus on July 17th of the same year. He immediately became a novice at the Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit Collegium. He spent one year in Dünaburg (now Daugavpils), then he continued his studies in the rhetoric class at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium in 1804–1805. After studying philosophy (1805–1807) at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium, Asum studied theology for four years (1807–1811) and taught German to laypeople at the same collegium.
Career:
Priest.
After studying at the Polatsk Collegium, Asum was sent to Saint Petersburg Collegium Nobilium, where he also taught German from 1811 until the closure of the institution in December 1815. After that he left the capital for Mahilyow, where he spent a year and a half as the rector of the Collegium church. In 1817 he moved to Mstsislaw, where he taught German to students of the local Collegium for two years. In 1819, he was sent to the Saratov mission of the Order, in the village of Kamenka, where in 1820 he heard of the dissolution of the Society of Jesus in the Russian Empire.
After the dissolution of the Society of Jesus in Russia, Asum went to Galicia, where for nine years (from 1820 to 1829) he taught Latin at the Ternopil Jesuit Collegium. During the year 1829 to 1830, he was novice master at the house of the first and second probation in Gleisdorf (Styria, now Austria). After the move of the Jesuit house to Graz, Asum worked as its head from 1831 to 1844.

Career: Governor. In service of Prussia until 1791, he was invited by Alexander Vasilievich Suvorov (1730-1800, prince and count, generalissimo, a famous military chief) as the tutor of his only son Arkadi (future general, who died in 1811). Audé de Sion arrived in Russia coming from Switzerland. He acquired Russian nationality and was admitted to military service with the rank of captain. From 1799 he was a teacher of fortifications at the 1st Corps. In 1802 he was appointed inspector (with the rank of major) of the classes the Page Corps, directed by a Gogel. In 1810 he was promoted to lieutenant colonel (podpolkovnik), in 1811 to colonel, in 1827 to major general, and resigned from the inspector position. He was criticized both by the pages themselves and by historians of the Page Corps for his lack of initiative and "idleness": he allegedly limited himself to submitting lists of "negligent and diligent" students to the director, always written in French; he enjoyed good wine and fine food and hastened to leave for his Masonic lodge meetings. A prominent Freemason, he was indeed an honorary member of several Masonic lodges in Saint Petersburg, a founding member and master in the chair of the lodge Les Amis réunis from 1816 to 1821. This lodge was one of the most important in Saint Petersburg, gathering over five hundred members, many of whom were Russians, including , as well as several Frenchmen. He was a member or visitor of several foreign lodges. He corresponded with the editor of a music magazine, Dalmas.

His entrance onto the stage sparked jealousy that led him to move to Prussia in 1765. Diderot took an interest in this artist. In 1768, he wrote letter to Mlle Jodin in Dresden: "It is not favorable for French comedians to associate with Ofrene [sic!], who has separated from them in discontent." Later settled in Vienna, Aufrêne assembled a troupe that was considered one of the best French troupes in Europe. In 1772, he went on a tour of Italy, notably in Modena (fifteen performances), Venice (twenty-eight performances), etc. Diderot's Le Père de famille was part of this troupe's repertoire and was very well received in Naples. Aufrêne was connected to Voltaire, who recommended him to Catherine II. He entered the service of the Russian court on June 13, 1785, for three years, with a salary of 2,500 rubles and a travel allowance of 250 rubles "to play the roles of kings in tragedy, noble fathers and other roles related to that position in comedy, all in leading or shared roles." He also played "the first old men" in both comedies and tragedies. In 1791, when he was inspector of the French troupe, his salary was raised to 3,000 rubles. The sovereign entrusted him with the courses in declamation and literature at the 1st Corps of Land Noble Cadets, where Aufrêne staged several tragedies. He also served as the stage manager of the Hermitage Theater. The French ambassador in Russia, Count de Ségur, saw him perform at the Hermitage Theater around 1785 n 1792, according to Fortia de Piles, he was supposed to consider retirement. The last three-year contract was signed with him on May 1, 1798.
Teaching institutions and families: 1st Corps (Saint Peterburg)

Education: University of Strasbourg.
Career: Teacher and head of boarding-house. He taught history, geography, French and German at Saint Petersburg around 1770. He had founded a boarding school which still existed in 1788. In 1784, the boarding school was controlled by a commission founded for this purpose by the Academy of Science.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status: There were 12 pupils in Aulery’s boarding school that year.
Teaching methods and materials: The commission found that his geography and history lessons were «very strange». All teaching was done individually, each pupil going in turn to see the teacher. The teacher gave too many dictations. German was taught by Aulery himself, starting with grammar then going on to translation. But his German was not perfect and the teaching suffered therefore. The teacher had excellent knowledge of French, but the members of the commission found his method somewhat slow. For geography Aulery used a children’s atlas, otherwise no other text-book was used.

Personal records: (†1809, Moscow) Originally from Paris. Married to: Élisabeth N., from Montbéliard.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, French literature, rhetoric, translation of Russian authors into French, analytical reading of French authors.
Career: Professor. He was responsible for the education of the Volkonski princes, grandsons of Prince Nicolay Vasilievich Repnin (son of Prince Grigori Semionovich Volkonski and Princess Alexandra Repnina, from whom Nikolay Grigorievich, Prince Volkonski, later Prince Repnin-Volkonski, a Russian military leader and statesman, descended). He resided in the 9th district of Moscow when he had to take the oath of loyalty to the crown of France in the spring of 1793. On 1796-03-04 or 1796-03-07, he succeeded Baudouin as extraordinary professor of French and French literature at Moscow University. He also taught rhetoric, the translation of Russian authors into French, analytical reading of French authors, and French literature. In 1809, he was replaced at the university by Frédéric de Villers. Some years later, he intended to open an educational boarding house in Moscow with Jean-Baptiste Maudru du Bocage, for which the Prospectus was reportedly published in 1807.
Teaching institutions and families:
Volkonski, Repnin families
Moscow University (1796–1809)
Students and their social status: Volkonski princes
Teaching methods and materials: He taught French literature based on La Harpe's manual
Language and other teaching books by the:
He published a verse translation of the ode by G. Derjavin titled Bog: Dieu. Ode, traduite librement du russe de mons. Derjavine dans la classe de style français et récitée à l’assemblée solemnelle à la Pension des nobles en l’Université de Moscou, le jour de la distribution des prix, in: Речь, разговор и стихи, читанные в публичном акте, бывшем в Благородном университетском пансионате декабря 22 дня, 1789, Москва, [1799], p. 15-20. On June 30, 1798, he delivered a speech at the solemn Assembly of Moscow University that was published: Discours sur les sciences considérés dans leurs diverses périodes. Prononcé à l’assemblée solemnelle tenue en l’Université de Moscou à la fin de l’année scholaire, pour célebrer la fete nominale de Sa Majesté Paul Premier, empereur et autocrateur de toutes les Russies par C. Aviat de Vatay, professeur extraordinaire en la dite Université. Moscou, de l’imprimerie de l’Université, chez Rüdiger et Claudi, 1798, [2], 20 p., in-4°. He also translated the works of Bogdanovich and wrote a literature manual, but did not have the time to publish them. Personal records: (* 1753-10-03, Metz, France; he was likely related to Baltus de Varimont). Religion: Catholic.
Education: He studied at the college and then at the seminary in Metz, where he entered in 1770.
Career:
He was ordained a priest on 1778-04-04, by Cardinal Louis-Joseph de Montmorency-Laval, Bishop of Metz. He served as vicar at the royal parish of Saint-Victor in Metz until 1783, and then was appointed curate at Beney (-en-Woëvre, Meuse) until 1791. He emigrated to Germany after refusing to take the civil oath required of the clergy by the National Assembly in 1791. He went to Russia in 1794-07. He was the parish priest of the Catholic church of St. Louis of the French in Moscow from 1794-11-01, until at least 1797.
He also served as a tutor in Moscow for the Naryshkin family, a prominent noble family, then for Mme Calowtrov (?), and finally for the Buturlin family. Baltus remained in Moscow and was still there in 1819, occupying the position of French language reader at the Sainte Catherine Institute. That year, he addressed a letter to Empress Maria Feodorovna, the patroness of the institution, in which he wrote: «Having been occupied for many years in teaching the Russian youth my mother tongue, both in various crown establishments and in private homes, the experience gained through my long practice has allowed me to make numerous observations that lighten the study of this language».
Teaching methods and materials: He had drafted a course on syntax along with a summary of rhetoric in Russia, aimed at «correcting several errors and addressing many omissions found in Lhomond’s great grammar».

Career: In Russia as a preceptor around 1794–1795. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar.
Career: It is only known that P. Barluy was a teacher in the classes of the “phara and infima” at the Pereiaslav Collegium in 1768–1769.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1768–1769).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks At the end of the 1760s, more than 160 students were enrolled at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Several dozen people studied in the classes of “phara and infima”, in which Peter Barluy taught. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) studied there as well.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) in which Peter Barluy taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. Peter Barluy also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. When Peter Barluy worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book by Emmanuel Alvarez “De institutione Grammatica.” However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at that time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not precisely defined at the Pereiaslav Collegium. The surviving school exercises intended for the Collegium students of those years make it possible to say that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (*1758, Flamanville, Normandy) Religion: Catholic.
Education: He studied letters, philosophy, theology.
Career:
Priest. Former parish priest in Bordeaux, he emigrated to Russia around 1792. He taught French and Latin in Russian noble families.
In 1798, Father Barthélemy was in Berlin where he served as treasurer of the French Society, a charity «that provides shamefaced poor with firewood during the winter». In 1797, this society supplied wood to 730 French or German families. Abbé Barthélemy then lived in the house of a Humbert and gathered «charitable donations» there.
Students and their social status: Nobility.

Personal records: (*1785, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied first at the Kharkiv Collegium (between 1797 and 1803), then at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1804–1807), including the theological class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar; Ancient Greek grammar and syntax; German grammar and syntax
Career: We know that immediately after graduation in 1807 Timofei Basmanov became a grammar class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium. He also taught Ancient Greek. Afterwards he was a poetics class teacher and taught German. In 1810, he was no longer on the list of teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium
Students and their social status: Clergy. At the beginning of the 19th century, more than 600 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1808, there were 84 students in the lower grammar class, in which Timofei Basmanov taught Latin. That year, he taught Ancient Greek to 77 students. German was also learned by several dozen students. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So in 1808 there were 22 “secular” students among the 84 students of the lower grammar class, in which Timofei Basmanov taught.
Teaching methods and materials:
In the grammar class taught by Basmanov, students studied Latin grammar rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises.
At the beginning of the 19th century, well-established traditions of teaching Ancient Greek and German were present at the Kharkiv Collegium. The teaching of languages was planned over a two-year period.
When Timofei Basmanov worked at the Kharkiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book of Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions concerning sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises intended for the Collegium students at the beginning of the 19th century make it possible to say that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Quite often students translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated (students left information about it). Many copies of the books were available at the library of Kharkiv Collegium. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. As evidenced by memories of the Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly).
As well as other Kharkiv Collegium teachers, Timofei Basmanov apparently used the Ancient Greek textbook written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. He also used several Latin-Greek lexicons and grammar books which were available in the library of the Collegium at that time. The surviving library catalogues of Kharkiv Collegium reveal the range of lexicons that were at the disposal of the teacher. Most books were written in Latin. It was common practice to read short extracts from works of various Greek authors (by Agapetus and others) in order to consolidate grammar rules, as well as to do exercises on translation of extracts from various texts (by Aesop, Ephrem the Syrian, John Chrysostom and others).
Little is known about the methods of teaching German, but it is obvious that Timofei Basmanov did not lack textbooks for students. He could use German grammar books and lexicons, which were available at the library of the Collegium. The books were transferred to the library by Belgorod bishops (who had once been teachers).

Personal records:
(Baudoin; *Rouen – †1796-10-23, Moscow)
No heir (the act of his succession was only recorded at the French vice-consulate in Moscow in 1807). 
He is probably the same Baudouin who was a professor at the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg (see Baudouin).
Education: «Licensed in law».
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, etymology, syntax, stylistics, French translation.
Career: He served first as an adjunct (or assessor) and then as an extraordinary professor at Moscow University. He left France in the 1760s and was initially engaged in Russia as a governor in the Fonvizin family (according to information from S.P. Shevyrev). Appointed to the university in 1776, he had already been replacing Berland de La Bordelière since 1773-01-23. In the following August, he received a testimonial from his examiner L. Bachmeister: «He speaks French well and expresses himself in the same language with ease and accuracy, while observing the rules of spelling and other parts of grammar. He explains a Latin author without difficulty and translates quite well into the same language. He is also very knowledgeable in history and geography. In short, among the French who present themselves here, one will seldom find someone with the same knowledge». He taught courses in etymology, syntax, stylistics, and French translation at Moscow University. He covered the works of Virgil and J.-J. Rousseau, having students memorize them. He taught in Moscow until his death in 1796, holding the rank of college counselor. Upon his death, he was succeeded by Professor Charles d’Aviat de Vatay. He corresponded with Iakov Bulgakov, Russian ambassador in Turkey (RGB, Mss, fonds 41, folder 60, dos. 14, reference in Les Archives de l'Est et la France des Lumières).

Fonvizin family;
Moscow University (1773–1796).

Personal records: (or Baudoin)
Languages and other subjects taught by t: History (in French); History of the Arts (?)
Career:
Professor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg, Baudouin was hired in October 1772 for 200 rubles a year, to replace the governor Tanas, who was neglecting his duties. He taught history to students of the 5th "age" (grade). When the students moved on to art exercises, his classes were suspended.
The Academy Council, uncertain of his competence, asked him to prepare a prospectus on general history, particularly focusing on the history of the arts. In this project, the author noted how important it was to be able to explain to students the subjects of paintings, and he added: "One cannot inspire young people too early with a commitment to the public good, loyalty to their sovereigns, and that true generosity which ensures the happiness and prosperity of states." The plan was eventually approved, and the author's salary was raised to 350 rubles. In September 1773, he was allowed to combine teaching at the Academy with private lessons. However, in March 1774, the Academy decided that Baudouin was causing too many complications, that he had unjustified pretensions, and that he was not sufficiently competent: he no longer had a place at the Academy. He received a certificate stating that "he taught history in French with great success and behaved correctly..."
Baudouin corresponded with the Russian academician Jacob Stählin, to whom he sent his Ode in 1775. Baudouin was portrayed as a history professor.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1772–1774, Saint Petersburg)
Sources and bibliography: RGIA, fonds 789, inv. 1, part 1, dos. 542 (1773); RNB, Mss, fonds 871, F-871.

Personal records: (*1755, Hamburg).
Career: Before coming to Russia: Seller’s assistant. In 1777, he arrived in Saint Petersburg; from that time on he worked as a teacher at Johann Georg Wedemeyer’s school, which was located in Gorokhovaya Street near a new bridge over the Catherine Canal, in a corner house belonging to the titular counsellor Yershov. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which checked this school in 1780, noted that the school was located in the second Admiralty part of the city; it was attended by 35 children aged from 6 to 15, including 29 boys and six girls. 23 children were boarders. The children were divided into two classes, depending on their abilities. The inside of the school was spacious; it consisted of eight rooms, all of them clean and tidy. The Commission noted that at the school children were taught Russian, German, French and Latin, as well as arithmetic, geometry and other areas of mathematics, and also geography and history; they were taught to draw, dance and play musical instruments, as well. The Commission highly appreciated the results of the school and stressed that students could achieve great success in all the taught languages, sciences and arts. Bauman was constantly present at the school to supervise the young students who studied there.
Teaching institutions and families: Wedemeyer’s private boarding school (from 1777, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Merchants; artisans; military men; civil servants.
In 1780, 35 children were enrolled at the school. The boarders were: Langkoenig, son of a chef; Lippertova, daughter of a merchant; Kepping son of a silversmith; Olshinsky, son of a tailor; Lindgolm son of a quality checker; Tarabarova, daughter of an assessor; Asanov, son of a native of Turkey; Kabbell, son of a manufacturer; Telschau, son of a baker; Antropov, son of the chief secretary of the Admiralty; Kenevec, son of a lieutenant; Birginyan, son of a cook; Tatarinov, son of a director; Karpova, daughter of a merchant; Gordin, son of a former chief secretary of the Senate; Schade, son of a merchant; Tolokmit, son of a silversmith; Shefova, daughter of a major; Tekutyev, son of a sergeant of the Semyonovsky Life-Guards Regiment; Yakovleva, daughter of a major; Norstet, son of a court counsellor; Byankin, son of a ballet dancer (his father was a ballet dancer participating only in the corps de ballet); Bockeberg von, son of a Livonian nobleman. Day-school students were: Gol, three children of a medallist; Holzhausen, two sons and a daughter of a tailor; Posnikova, daughter of an assessor; Zuyev, son of a Guards corporal; Trunov, son of a lieutenant, Pokharsky, son of a doctor; Fischer, son of a wainwright.
Teaching methods and materials:
He gave eight lessons of German reading per week using an alphabet book and Luther's catechism in the junior class as well as eight lessons of German, French and Russian writing. According to the Commission of the Academy of Sciences, in 1780 he was “very skilled” in teaching.
German reading; German writing; French writing; Russian writing.
Speaking only German with the children.
Luther M. Der Kleine Catechismus. Reval. 1727 (reprinted several times in the 18th century).
Sources and bibliography: SPF ARAN, f. 1, op. 2, 1780, d. 4, fol. 9v, 42v-43.

Personal records: (*1750, Hamburg) Religion: Lutheran.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German writing; German grammar; French writing; catechism; arithmetic.
Career:
Personal attendant, clerk.
In 1770, he arrived in Saint Petersburg; in 1770–1773, he served as a clerk in Petrischule (Saint Peter’s School), then he held the same position at the Land Noble Cadet Corps.
According to the Commission of the Academy of Sciences, in April 1780, he was a teacher in Jean Link’s boarding school, opened in 1760 in New Saint Isaac’s (Novaya Isaakiyevskaya) Street in the house of the dancer Varvara Mikhailova. There were 16 children: eight boys and eight girls. According to members of the Commission, Baumann spoke French fluently and understood a little Russian. In 1784, Baumann was not mentioned among the teachers of Jean Link’s boarding school.
Teaching institutions and families: Jean Link’s boarding school (early 1780s, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Children of artisans, military men, civil servants.
The children at Jean Link’s boarding school in April 1780 were: Yeremeyeva, daughter of the secretary of the Senate; Soltvedel, two daughters of a secretary; Thomas, daughter and son of a watchmaker; Yaroslavtseva, daughter of a deputy; Ustinia (her family name is not available), daughter of a lieutenant; Yakobliya (nothing else is specified); (the name is not available), daughter of a hairdresser; Edward, son of a merchant; Pavel (his family name is not available), son of a merchant; Bogolyubov, son of a collegiate assessor; Heidenreich, son of a butler; Mittag, two sons of a musician; Guge, son of an innkeeper.

Personal records: (Monastic name: Iov) (1723-10-31, Boromlia, a sotnia town in the Akhtyrsky Regiment, Russian Empire – 1776-05-02, Pereiaslav, Russian Empire). Born into the famous priest family of Bazilevich. One of his brothers, Vasily, was the rector of the Kharkiv Collegium, another – Piotr – the prefect of the Pereiaslav Collegium, two more (Piotr and Pavel) were well-known protopopes. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied first at the Kharkiv Collegium, then at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including the theology school (class).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew, rhetoric, philosophy, theology.
Career:
After completing his studies at the Kyiv Academy, Bazilevich became a monk, then was a hieromonk in one of the monasteries. From 1752 to 1770, he taught at the Kharkiv Collegium. He went through all the stages of the career ladder: from teacher and prefect to rector (from 1763). In 1752–1755, he taught Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew and rhetoric at the Collegium. He was the first to teach Ancient Hebrew at the Collegium and the second (after Iakinf Karpinsky) to teach Ancient Greek. In 1755–1759, he was a professor of philosophy, in 1759–1770 – a professor of theology. In 1770, he became rector of the Znamensky Monastery of Our Lady of Kursk, and on 31 October 1770, he was ordained Bishop of Pereiaslav and Boryspil and remained bishop until his death.
As the Bishop of Pereiaslav, Iov Bazilevich made efforts to contribute to the development of the Pereiaslav Collegium. Firstly, he contributed to the founding of a philosophy class at the Collegium. Secondly, sons of the clergymen of the diocese went to the Collegium for their education. Iov Bazilevich paid great attention to strict observance of this requirement. At the same time, he never forgot the Kharkiv Collegium – until the end of his life, he maintained a correspondence with his former colleagues, the teachers of the Collegium, and discussed their needs and problems.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1752–1770).
Students and their social status:
During his teaching career, about 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium (for example, in the 1759/1760 academic year, there were 472 students). Iov Bazilevich taught Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew in the rhetoric school (class). However, these languages were not studied by all the students of the class. They were usually taught to 7–10 people.
Since at the time the majority of students attending the rhetoric class at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergymen’s families (although sons of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there), it may be assumed that the students of Iov Bazilevich were primarily children from families of clergymen.
Teaching methods and materials:
The Instructions on «how to teach and what to teach» at the Collegium, written by the Bishop of Belgorod Samuil Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector, the prefect and the teachers, appeared at the time when Iov Bazilevich was the rector of the Kharkiv Collegium. The document gives a fairly complete picture of the teaching of basic disciplines, including foreign languages. Undoubtedly, Iov Bazilevich adhered to these rules when teaching Greek. The teaching of Greek grammar was designed for two years. The Instructions mentioned the necessity to use copybooks at the initial stage of learning so that students could practise writing Greek letters. The teacher was recommended to resort to the assistance of «native Greeks» to help students in acquiring writing skills. Furthermore, according to the «Instructions», the teacher was supposed to teach grammar rules using the book on Ancient Greek written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, according to the «Instructions», the teacher was supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles, practising grammatical analysis of declensions and conjugations. The poems that were analysed by students and their teacher in this way were later to be used by them as a material for short speeches and translation exercises. It was recommended to finish the study of the grammar sections and to start learning the syntax and the «idioms» of Greek in the second year of Greek studies. The author of the «Instructions» recommended that, at this stage, students memorize short sentences from the lexicon compiled by Cornelius Schrevelius. Undoubtedly, the library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of the book and the lexicon. According to the ‘Instruction’ the students had to learn Latin well (in grammar and poetics classes) before starting learning Greek (in rhetoric class) which is explained by the fact that the majority of grammar books in Greek were written in the Latin language (they were intended for the use in Jesuit colleges). The practice of teaching in Collegiums shows that grammar rules were consolidated through reading a few other lexicons available in the library of the Collegium. It was common practice to read short extracts from works of various Greek authors (Agapetus), as well as through exercises on translation of extracts from texts (at that time Aesop's texts and speeches of Ephrem the Syrian and John Chrysostom were referred to most often). Some of the students continued learning Ancient Greek at the next stages of education, in the classes of philosophy and theology, where they were engaged in advanced studies of the language. The «Instructions» recommended that students take complementary courses in Modern Greek. It was believed that this would improve understanding of Ancient Greek.
Little is known about the teaching of Ancient Hebrew by Iov Bazilevich. He «expounded» the basics of Ancient Hebrew grammar. The books that he used for his teaching were written in Latin and were intended for use in Jesuit schools. Apparently, he used several lexicons and grammar books that were available in the library of the Kharkiv Collegium at that time. The surviving catalogue of the Collegium library (1753) revealed the exact books he used. It is also known that Iov Bazilevich had a personal library where he kept books written in Latin, Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew (later these books were transferred to the collection of Pereiaslav Collegium).

Personal records: (*Rouen, France)
Career: Tutor and then merchant. Career: Johann Beitner joined the Noble Infantry Cadet Corps in 1736. He was engaged as master of writing and had to teach German and Latin writing. Personal records: Probably from Montbéliard.
Career:
Governess brought from Berlin by the jeweler Pozier for the young Counts Vorontsov, sons of Roman Illarionovich Vorontsov.
She later became a teacher at the Smolny Institute before 1783.
Teaching institutions and families:
Vorontsov family;
Smolny Institute (Saint Peterburg)
Students and their social status: Sons of Roman Illarionovich Vorontsov (1707-1783), Chief General, Governor of the provinces of Vladimir, Penza, and Tambov: Alexander (1741-1801), future diplomat, senator, president of the College of Commerce; Semion (1744-1832), diplomat, Russian ambassador in London; and probably their sister Ekaterina (1744-1810), known as Princess Dashkova, future president of the Academy of Sciences, author of Memoirs). Personal records: (or Berkhan) Married to: Helena Petersen (†1757-08-13, Saint Petersburg). Religion: Lutheran.
Career: It is reported that Berkhahn already lived in Moscow, when J.E. Glück engaged him in 1705 to teach German at his newly founded Moscow Foreign Language School. In the following years, Berkhahn taught reading and writing in German in the lowest German class (“tertia”), six hours per day for an annual salary of 20 roubles with an additional 28 roubles for food. In March 1711, he was dismissed because of the decreasing number of students – there were only 12 students left in his class. Later, from 1720 onwards, Berkhahn worked as sexton at St. Ann’s Church in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow Foreign Language School (1705–1711).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; soldiers; merchants; craftsmen.
At the very start of the Moscow Foreign Language School pupils almost always came from the administration or (in some cases) from the higher nobility. The pupils had to learn foreign languages for service in the administration and the ministries (collegia) or diplomatic service. Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was extended significantly and sons of soldiers and craftsmen also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: those who received a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. In order to attract more pupils, in the first years of the school’s existence, students were exempted from military service.
Semen Kudriavtsev; Ivan Poliakov; Alexei Zenzerov; Andrei Gorlov; Petr Popov; Semen Pavlov; Ivan Kartsov; Alexei Efimov; Fedor Zavodin; Galakhtion Chizhov (pupils of Berkhahn’s class in 1711, see Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. 114).
For the complete list of pupils, studying at the Moscow Foreign Language School between 1703 and 1715, see Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. XXII-XL.
Teaching methods and materials: Comenius, Johann Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698). It is not quite sure which editions of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Foreign Language School. We know only that J.E. Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis pictus” into Russian. The “Vestibulum” was completed by the end of 1703 and Glück addressed a petition to the tsar asking for permission to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров, 1907, p. 47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished. Other texts used in language classes at the Moscow Foreign Language school were: various nomenclatures (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (possibly the Latin-German dialogues of Johann Georg Seybold); the Lutheran Bible; the Lutheran catechism; German hymns.

Fullname: Berland de La Bodelière, chevalier François
Personal records:
(Brelan, through deformation; Bordeliere, or de la Brelandière) (*around 1726, Richeling, Lorraine (Moselle)). Father: François Berland (†before 1793), lord of the fief and seigneury of la Bordelière, who during his lifetime was the king’s prosecutor of the city of Richeling (Moselle). Mother: Renée Thibault. Married to (on 1793-10-18 at the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg): Christine Mézière (born and bapt. in Iambourg). Children:
  • Sophie Berland (*1794);
  • Alexandra Berland (*1798);
  • Marie Berland (*1801).
Religion: Catholic.
Career: «Lesser-known» poet and honorary professor at Moscow University. He was in Saint Petersburg before entering Moscow University. He was an honorary professor at Moscow University in 1772-1773, succeeding the reader Saint-Nicolas. Upon his resignation in January 1773, he was replaced by Professor Baudouin. In 1773, he embarked on the French edition of the Feuilles périodiques that were to be published every Tuesday. The subscription price was 10 rubles per year in Moscow and 12 rubles in Saint Petersburg. Subscriptions could be made with Berland in Moscow near the Nikolski Monastery, in the Kislovka district, and with Larmée in Saint Petersburg, at Hannevard’s shop. The Feuilles were to be sent to the homes of subscribers. Berland had a poor reputation (he was said to be an accomplice of the counterfeiter Champagnolot) and was suspected of having stolen 2000 rubles worth of furniture, books, and silverware from Jean Châtelain in 1773. The Duke of Fronsac also had claims against him in July 1776: Berland was said to have been sent to Siberia in 1777. Berland was back in Saint Petersburg in 1780 and planned to start a business with two merchants, Magenthies and Sage. Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier of Corberon) wrote a fierce description of him in his letter to the minister on January 10: «Brelan, an intriguing man, a subaltern and dangerous writer, is the author of a memorandum against the consul in the Boissonnet affair. [...] This man has been in Russia for several years, arriving there with a girl he raised, passing her off as his wife, who soon left him to become the mistress of a Russian. This Brelan was once employed in Germany in the composition of a gazette, and his existence here without acknowledgment is sustained only by the continuation of his intrigues. He must conduct himself in a manner that is generally disapproved of - since, with a certain wit and the indiscriminate and somewhat unrefined use of all possible means, he has been unable to acquire an honest fortune in a country where it is so easy to do so. His name is so badly regarded there that Mr. Count Panin could not recover from his surprise when he learned that he was involved in this matter». He was still in Russia, in Saint Petersburg, when he took the oath of 1793*. He was reportedly a professor of philosophy at the Imperial University of Moscow in 1806 and a college advisor. At that time, he likely resided temporarily in the 4th Admiralteyskaya part of Saint Petersburg, at the house of Shtevine at No. 300. He took the oath of submission to Russia in 1806.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University
Teaching methods and materials: He conducted commented readings of articles from the newspapers for students.
Language and other teaching books by the:

Education: He passed the examination of the Moscow University on 1769-11-09.
Career: Tutor, secretary, journalist, writer. He was admitted as a professor in the syntax class at the gymnasium (school) of the Moscow university in 1775 following Saint-Nicolas; he was dismissed on August 26, 1776. In 1782 he found himself as a secretary and interpreter for a Cantacuzen prince, most likely Prince Nikolai Rodionovich Cantacuzen (1763-1841), son of Prince Rodion Cantacuzen. He reappears in Saint Petersburg around 1786: he contributed to the Mercure de Russie, a literary review founded and directed by Gallien de Salmorenc in 1786 (8 issues published). A Freemason, he was a member of the third degree of the Zur Verschwiegenheit lodge in Saint Petersburg in 1786-1787.
Teaching institutions and families: Gymnasium of the Moscow University (1775–1776)

Career:
French governor at the college associated with the Academy of Fine Arts in Petersburg, he resigned in October 1769. He also taught at educational boarding schools and was forced to leave one or the other position. He thus declared to the director of the Academy: «I protest to you, sir, that it is almost impossible for me to leave the students. I confess that if I want to count the students I have for myself, I have in total 350 rubles per year and all the upkeep, but I can also assure you, sir, that I am busy from morning till evening» [we have respected the spelling of the original, which reflects the cultural level of the tutor]. Yet François Bernard had a servant in his employ.
It was probably him that Pierre Martin, Vice-Consul of France, and the Marquis de Juigné (Le Clerc, Marquis de Juigné), Ambassador of France, sought in vain in early 1777 in Moscow and in Saint Petersburg.

Career:
Professor of French and French literature at Moscow University between 1757 and 1764, he succeeded Professor Raoult. He was arrested in 1757 for debts.
He was also the secretary of the Conference (administrative organ) of the university, for which he drafted the minutes in French, not knowing Latin (it was only after his disappearance that the new secretary Karl Langer wrote the minutes in Latin). In 1759, he received a first salary increase of 50 rubles, followed by a second in 1762. He remained the university’s secretary until his death.
In 1763, he took charge of the syntax class for which he was paid 250 rubles. He was replaced at the university by the French lecturer Préclos de Léry.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (between 1757 and 1764).
Students and their social status: Among his students was the famous Russian Freemason and publisher Nikolai Novikov, who was expelled from the university in 1760 for not attending the French class.
Teaching methods and materials: In his lectures to students, he explained the Dialogues des morts and other works of Fontenelle, Fénelon’s Télémaque, he read newspapers, etc.
Language and other teaching books by the: In 1763, he wrote an abridgment of French syntax (with a promise of the equivalent of one hundred copies in cash after publication). His works did not come to light as the professors disapproved of the question-answer format the work took and recommended translating instead L’Art de bien parler le français by De la Touche.

Personal records: (1772-06-02, Russian Empire – 1844-05-31, Saint Petersburg). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1783 to 1791, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theological class.
Career:
It is known that immediately after graduation in 1791, Alexander Birukov became a grammar class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium. Then he successively taught in the syntax, poetic (1795), rhetoric (1796), and philosophy (from 1799 onwards) classes. He was a teacher until 1803, when Vasily Nazarovich Karazin, the founder of Kharkiv University, invited him to serve at the Ministry of Public Education. At first, Alexander Birukov was a forwarder at the Dispatch office of the School Board. In 1817, he was transferred to the Department of Public Education. At the same time, from 2 April 1821 onwards, he was a censor at Saint Petersburg Censorship Committee. From 4 August 1826 to 11 May 1827, he was a member of the Main Censorship Committee.
Alexander Birukov’s activity at the Censorship Committee became particularly famous. He was involved in censoring Alexander Pushkin’s and Vasily Zhukovsky’s as well as many other authors’ works. Therefore, the name of Alexander Birukov was repeatedly mentioned by many authors (including Alexander Pushkin) in their correspondence and memoirs. Alexander Birukov was repeatedly reported for passing suspicious books for publication. In 1824, he was brought to justice for having passed Johannes Evangelista Gossner’s book for publication. The trial lasted until 1828 and ended with Birukov’s complete acquittal. Birukov died with the rank of actual state counsellor.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1791–1803).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In 1792–1793, 455 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The grammar class taught by Alexander Birukov had 48 students.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families (although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). So, in 1792–1973 there were 13 “secular” students among the 48 students of the grammar class in which Alexander Birukov taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax class taught by Alexander Birukov, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Alexander Birukov worked at the Kharkiv Collegium, Latin grammar and syntax classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises intended for the Collegium students of the 1790s make it possible to say that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Quite often students translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated (students left information about it). The books were available in large numbers at the library of Kharkiv Collegium The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Personal records: (or Blemeur) (*Metz, France). Married to: Augustine, known as Justine Allerdings (native of Dorpat) (marriage concluded on 27 June 1770, in the Catholic Church of Saint-Catharine of Alexandria in Saint-Petersburg). Son: Benoît Blemer (alive in 1793).
Education: He approached the Academy of Sciences in order to take an exam to receive a certificate authorizing him to be a teacher. He planned to teach French and German: he wrote in French correctly and fluently, knew a little grammar and made few mistakes. He was weaker in German, but wrote and spoke the language "very fast and not too badly". His signature also certifies that he wrote correctly: "J'ai reçu mon attestat Mathieu Blemeur le 11eme aoust 1770".
Career: He worked as a teacher at a boarding school. In 1770, he proposed to open a private school in Saint-Petersburg. Undoubtedly, it was he who was employed at the school at the Academy of Fine Arts in 1782 to teach children of the third "age group", replacing the tutor Bourgeois. Then he apparently left Saint-Petersburg to settle in Moscow. In the 1790s, there were more than fifty students at his boarding school. They studied arithmetic, geometry, Russian grammar, history, geography, French and Italian, English (which was extremely rare at the time) and drawing (the Frenchman Ivan ou Jean Daniel was the teacher). He was living in the sixth district of Moscow, when he took an oath of allegiance to the French crown in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school; school at the Academy of Fine Arts (1782), all Saint Petersburg; boarding school in Moscow (1790s).

Personal records: (Secular name: Kozma Simeonovich) (1714 ?, Voronkov town of Pereiaslav Regiment, Russian Empire – Russian Empire). Kliment Bogdanovich was born into the family of the priest of the Mikhailovskaya Church in the town of Voronkov. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1728 onwards, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class.
Career:
He became a priest upon graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Concerning Bogdanovich, it is only known that he was a teacher in the grammar and syntax classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in 1739–1740. From 1741, he was a cathedral clerk at the Saint Sophia Monastery in Kyiv. In 1743, he made monastic vows. In 1743, he became a syntax class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1744 onwards, he was a preacher at the Holy Spirit Monastery in Vilnius (Mahilyow diocese). In 1746–1747, he taught philosophy at the Smolensk Seminary.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1739–1740); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (from 1743); Smolensk Seminary (1746–1747).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. There were several dozen students in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Kliment Bogdanovic at the Pereiaslav Collegium and the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium and Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students coming from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Kliment Bogdanovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy was the book by Emmanuel Alvarez “De Institutione Grammatica libri tres,” which was widely used in Jesuit schools. The surviving school exercises of the Pereiaslav Collegium and the Academy students enable us to say that their teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Collegium or the Academy. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records:
(Bonafond d’Albert; *before 1735).
Married; father of a son living in 1780.
His wife and son were in France, and he had no news of them in 1780.
Education: He requested in 1770 to take the examination of the Academy of Sciences to obtain a certificate of competence. His examiner, Charpentier, found that he spoke and wrote French correctly and was «very fit to teach».
Career: Theatre prompter and private tutor. By 1780, he was already employed at the Smolny Institute and boasted of having created an opera-comique there titled L’Amant déguisé. He was the director of studies at the Smolny Institute in January 1783. Bonnafous informed Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon) about the affairs of the Institute, and he likely played a role in the harsh verdict that the chevalier issued regarding this institution that was preparing «polished savages». Corberon mentioned in his Journal in 1779 that Bonnafous was a «poor French devil, unfortunate, honest, and misanthropic», of whom he declared himself a friend, despite his many enemies. Bonnafous was heavily in debt, and his meager salary did not allow him to repay his creditors quickly, Falconet père (2,000 rubles) and Cuvillier. He was forced to renew a three-year contract with the Smolny Institute in 1781 to pay off his debts and secure an annuity of eight hundred rubles upon his return to France.
Teaching institutions and families: Smolny Institute (Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: The documents do not specify the first name of the teacher Booker, working in the Academy School in 1750. However, given the fact that there were four brothers in the Booker family, all studying at the Academy School in the 1730s and 1740s, it is very probable that later on, one of them became teacher there. Taking into account the date of birth and enrolment at the Academy School, this could have been Nathanael Booker. The biographical data in this article are based on the presupposition that the documented teacher Booker was Nathanael Booker. (*1727-11-20, Saint Petersburg). Father: John Booker (†1738, Saint Petersburg), a forwarding agent at the Russian Company, married to Adelgunde Minau (1725-01-19, Saint Petersburg), died from the pox. Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Nathanael Booker was enrolled at the Academy School on 15 March 1736. The documented teacher Booker studied at the Academy university.
Career: Booker was engaged at the Academy School as a German teacher around 1750. Apparently, he spoke Russian and had good skills in translating from Russian into German and vice versa.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (from ar. 1750, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Noble Infantry Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. The names of a large number of them, aged between 6 and 20 years-old, are known and listed in the school registers, including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
There were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils, among them nobles and non-nobles. The family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants, such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia, to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.
