Personal records:
(*Lunéville, France). The family name underwent transformations, probably due to the shift of stress from the last syllable to the second, which gave at least two new forms: sounding like "Bordenov" in Russian or "Bordenau" suggesting a Germanic origin. Older brothers:
  • Jean-Louis Bordenave;
  • Basil (Vasily) Bordenave (*1777), a major in the Russian army, then entered the civil service in Moscow, and held the rank of collegiate assessor in 1825.
Married to: Anne-Élisabeth Stichdiesnoth (*Lunéville). He had six children, including:
  • Alexandre Bordenave (*Moscow, bapt. at Saint-Peter and Saint-Paul’s Church on 17 March 1784; godfather: Nicolay Zherebtsov; godmother: Anna Zherebtsova);
  • Sophie Bordenave (*Moscow, bapt. at Saint-Peter and Saint-Paul’s Church on 13 July 1791; godfather: François Hartenberg; godmother: Agrippine de Vande);
  • probably, Jean Bordenave (see ?).
Mrs. Bordenave became the godmother of Michaël-Joseph Tenauer on 7 July 1790 at Saint-Peter and Saint-Paul’s Church; she was in the Kaluga province when she took an oath of allegiance to the French crown in 1793. As a Catholic, she was a parishioner of the Church of Saint Louis of the French in Moscow in 1798. Religion: Catholic.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French; German; history; geography; arithmetic; Divine Law.
Career:
A French tutor, on 19 August 1765, he received approval to teach at Moscow University. In the 1780s, with the permission of the city police, he founded an educational boarding school in Moscow. In 1785, French, German, history, geography and arithmetic were taught there as well as "Divine Law" whose teacher was not sufficiently competent. At that time, the boarding school had twenty two students (19 boys and 3 girls), and the results were mediocre. The annual tuition fee was 150 roubles. In 1790, the number of students increased to 42 (29 boys and 13 girls). Four teachers (two Germans and two Russians) taught German, arithmetic, geometry, geography, history and religion. The boarding school was located in a house that belonged to Bordenave, in the parish of the Ascension: Bolshaya Serpukhovskaya street, 3rd part, 3rd quarter. The school was closed by the authorities in the second half of 1792. He resided in the sixth district of Moscow when he took an oath of allegiance to the French crown in 1793 for himself and his family; he was still living in Moscow in 1798.
The boarding school teacher Bordenave acted as a guarantor for the French merchant Louise-Elisabeth Boromée in the 1790s. However, in 1798, after a search by the police, her activity was discontinued under the pretext of her trafficking illegal goods. She then fled with Bordenave, who sold his house in haste.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school (1780s – 1792, Moscow).

Personal records: (*Paris – †1796-12-15, Saint Petersburg; he died at the age of 70 and was buried on the 17th in the cemetery on Vasilievsky Island (witnesses: Marie-Denis Dussard known as Neuville, Louis Bilon, Arthur Paulet).
Education: In 1757, he requested to be examined by the Academy of Sciences to obtain a certificate of competence. He wrote in French correctly and was recognized as capable of teaching it.
Career:
Preceptor who was in Saint Petersburg in 1757. He became the French governor at the college of the Academy of Fine Arts in Petersburg in 1772. He remained there until 1789 when he was dismissed because he did not know Russian. He received an annual retirement pension of 160 rubles, representing half of his salary.
However, he still resided in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793.

Personal records: (*around 1713, Strasbourg).
Career:
Tutor. Arriving in Russia in 1742, he first served as the secretary to the Grand Master of Artillery, Prince Vasily Anikitich Repnin (†1748), and was the governor of his son Nikolai Vasilievich (1734–1801).
He was in Saint Petersburg in 1756. He rented an apartment on Vasilievsky Island, in the first line, at the Semibratskoye Inn, from which he sublet rooms.
In the 1760s, he taught geography and French at the Land Noble Cadet Corps.
He witnessed the marriage of Guillemaut/Deyriard in Saint Petersburg in 1762 and was the godfather of Anne-Elisabeth Deyriard on 1761-08-12, at the Catholic church in St. Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families:
Repnin family;
Land Noble Cadet Corps (1760s).
Students and their social status: Nikolai Vasilievich Repnin (1734-1801), a future diplomat, general aide-de-camp, and later field marshal.
Language and other teaching books by the:
He was the author of a French grammar written for the students of the Land Noble Cadet Corps where Boujot taught (and translated into Russian by A. Lukin): - Краткие правила французской грамматики, сочиненные в пользу учащегося в Сухопутном шляхетном кадетском корпусе юношества, [translated from French by Alexei Lukin], Санкт-Петербург, [2], 221 с. (the fact is established in: Chamraï). He was the author of an ode presented to Emperor Peter III, printed in two hundred copies, of which almost the entire print run was destroyed by order of Catherine II upon her accession to the throne:

Personal records: Originally from Burgundy or Franche-Comté.
Career: Professor of singing to Catherine II and in the pension of Louis-Stanislas Carbonnet in the 1760s in Saint Petersburg. He was in Moscow in 1767 and presented himself at the University to be examined and obtain a certificate as a tutor, which he received on 1767-06-26, to teach French «by principles». Subsequently, he reappeared in Saint Petersburg, where he served as governor at the college of the Academy of Fine Arts for the third age classes; he remained at the Academy from 1772-11 to 1773-02, but was dismissed due to «his wrongful conduct, the nonperformance of his duties, and the impertinences said against Mr. the Inspector». He was once again in Moscow in 1777-01.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1772–1773; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (*1749-09-18, Paris) Married to: Renée-Angélique Poutrel (present in Saint Petersburg in 1781). Son: Michel-Louis Bourgeois (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at St. Catherine of Alexandria on 1775-05-15; godfather: Michel-Nicolas Duhazé; godmother: Susanne Vallin de La Mothe).
Career: Governor admitted to the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in place of the resigned Gillot. In 1781, he submitted his resignation, under the pretext of a promise made to the Marquis de Vérac, ambassador of France at the Russian court: «I gave him my word to finish the preparations of a festivity that started about two months ago; since this work cannot be completed in 4 or 5 weeks and requires constant presence, it is impossible for me to pursue it without permission to temporarily abandon my duties concerning the Academy». He was replaced by governor Blemer (or Blemeur).
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (Saint Petersburg).

Personal records:
(Family originally from Pontarlier, ennobled by office in 1732; arms: Azure, a silver bird perched on a gold ball). Grandfather: Jacques Bousson (1677 – 1763, Pontarlier), appointed on 1732-08-21, to the ennobling position of counselor-master in the Chamber of Accounts of Dole. Grandmother: Catherine Courtois. Father: Claude-Gaspard Bousson, counselor in the bailliage and presidial court of Salins in Franche-Comté. Mother: dame Charlotte de Mairet. Sister: Marie-Anne Bousson, present in Saint Petersburg in 1775-09 (she owned property in Franche-Comté). He lived with Marie-Claudine Germain, wife of Benoît Rozet, who was also in Saint Petersburg in 1778 and mother of four children. He likely had a daughter from a marriage in France:
  • a daughter married to sieur de La Biche, sub-governor in the Page Corps in Saint Petersburg in 1779.
Career: Tutor. Present in Saint Petersburg in 1779-08, he became the governor in 1784-02 of the young Count Nikita Petrovich Panin, with the rank of lieutenant-colonel; he was presented to the Empress and the Grand Duke. He was the financial supporter of the children of Marie-Claudine Rozet, who passed away in Moscow on 1784-02-01, a renowned French bookseller. He registered powers of attorney at the French vice-consulate in Moscow on 1786-11-29 and 1787-04-08. He lived at the London Inn and held the rank of lieutenant-colonel when he refused to take the oath in 1793 and had to leave Russia.
Teaching institutions and families: Panin family.
Students and their social status: Count Nikita Petrovich Panin, future vice-chancellor of the Russian Empire.

Education: On 1759-11-20, he passed the examinations at Moscow University to obtain a certificate of competence to teach French, history, and geography.
Career:
Tutor who arrived in Russia in 1759.

He left the university on 1763-04-26, following a quarrel with Dilthey, an influential professor at the university.

Personal records: (or Boële; born in Neufmoulin, Franche-Comté).
Career:
Preceptor. He was appointed professor of literature at the Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg in 1780, having proposed his candidacy as follows: «The public schools, which are multiplying increasingly across this Empire, the need for preceptors, and the number of individuals who hire tutors for their children have inspired Marie-Théophile Boële with the intention of moving to Russia to be as useful as his abilities permit. Furthermore, being informed that by a decree from the Throne, it is ordered that the Directors of the Academies and public schools, as well as private individuals, employ only teachers who possess a certificate from the Academy of Sciences of St. Petersburg attesting to the qualifications of the applicant, he, in accordance with the spirit of this decree, humbly requests the members of the commission of the Academy of Sciences of St. Petersburg to examine him in French and German grammar, geography and history, and the art of translation in both languages. Signed: Marie-Théophile Boële».
In 1793, he lived in the Yaroslavl region, in the Romanov district, with Lieutenant of the Guard Nikolai Ushakov as a tutor. He had a passport signed by the French consul Lesseps and a certificate of proficiency to teach French issued by the Academy of Sciences of St. Petersburg.
He took the oath of 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Sciences (since 1780; Saint Peterburg).
Sources and bibliography:
SPbV, 1793, No. 81; SPbZ, 1793, No. 84.

Personal records: (or Branc; born in Strasbourg)
Career: Tutor. He spent a lot of time in France. In 1757, he was in Saint Petersburg at the house of the chamberlain Balk to teach French to his nephew. He requested to take the examination for tutors at the Academy of Sciences and obtained a certificate of competence to teach French and German, the examiners having found that he mastered both languages very well.

Personal records:
Originally from Brussels.
Presumably the husband or son of Mme Brackel.

Personal records: Presumably the wife or mother of Jean Brackel.
Career: Pension holder. She ran a boarding school in Moscow, 4th district, during the 1790s. In 1790, there were thirty-eight students in her boarding school (twenty boys and eighteen girls), twenty in 1791, and twenty-two in 1792. Four professors taught French, German, Russian grammar, arithmetic, and drawing there. This boarding school was closed by the authorities in 1792.
Teaching institutions and families: She ran a boarding school (early 1790s, Moscow).

Personal records: (*Zerbst, Germany). Married in January 1710. Son: Christian Gottlieb Brettschneider (*1710), who was enrolled as a pupil at the Academy School in Saint Petersburg in 1727. Son-in-law: Johann Apitz (in Russia: Ivan Khristoforovich), teacher at the School of the Lutheran New Community in Moscow in the 1740s. Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Brettschneider matriculated as a student of Halle University on 4 August 1698.
Career: Tutor. Together with his colleagues Johann Christian Büttner and Michael Ruttich, Peter Daniel Brettschneider was sent to Moscow by A.H. Francke. He arrived in Moscow in December 1705 and became a German and Latin teacher (upper class, prima) at the Moscow Foreign Language School (annual salary: 100 roubles plus 46 roubles for food, from January 1709 on, 110 roubles). Later, from 1711 on, Brettschneider also taught Swedish. He left the school in August 1712 due to the declining number of students. In 1714, he is documented cantor of the court orchestra/chapel. Until 1732, he was a German teacher at the school of the Lutheran New Community in the German Quarter.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow Foreign Language School (1705–1712); school of the Lutheran New Community (till 1732, Moscow).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; soldiers; merchants; craftsmen.
At the very beginning of the Moscow Foreign Language School, pupils almost always came from the administration or (in some cases) from the higher nobility. The pupils had to learn foreign languages for service in the administration and the ministries (collegia) or diplomatic service. Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was significantly extended and sons of soldiers and craftsmen also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: those who received a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To attract more pupils, in the first years of the existence of the school, students were exempted from military service.
Fedor Butkovskii; Maksim Butkovskii; Ivan Chebotarev; Stepan Chebotarev; Petr Glebov; Ivan Kartsov; Alexei Khrushchev; Andrei Khrushchev; Boris Khrushchev; Ivan Khrushchev; Semen Khrushchev; Ivan Ladyzhenskii; Matvei Lovzin; Prince Fedor Meshcherskii; Prince Petr Obolenskii; Leontei Ostrovskoi; Iakov Rubinov; Vasilii Samarin; Artemii Solovetskii; Semen Tarasov; Ivan Ushakov; Ignatii Yudin (Белокуров/ Зерцалов 1907, p. 113, 126, 178f.).
The complete list of pupils studying at the Moscow Foreign Language School between 1703 and 1715 was published by Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. XXII-XL.
Teaching methods and materials: In July 1712, Brettschneider gave a report about the progress of his students. After one-and-a-half years of instruction, the student Матвей Ловзин could “talk and translate” in German, but his translation skills were not yet perfect, which was documented by his translation of a book, given to him by Fedor Polikarpov (Белокуров/ Зерцалов 1907, p. 178). Polikarpov was the author of the “Slavonic-Greek-Latin Primer”, published at the Moscow Print Yard in 1701, but it is not clear, which books Brettschneider gave to his pupils. Another pupil, Fedor Butkovskii, developed the same translation skills as Matvei Lovzin. Other pupils, who had studied German for half a year, namely Iakov Rubinov, Semen Tarasov and Ivan Kartsov could read and write and to some extent also talk (Белокуров/ Зерцалов 1907, p. 178f.). Comenius, Johann Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698). It is not quite sure which editions of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Foreign Language School. What we know is that J.E. Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis pictus” into Russian. The “Vestibulum” was completed by the end of 1703 and Glück applied to the tsar with a petition to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, p.47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished. Other texts used in language classes at the Moscow Foreign Language school: various nomenclatures (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (possibly the Latin-German dialogues of Johann Georg Seybold); the Lutheran bible; the Lutheran catechism; German chants hymns.

Personal records: Religion: Catholic.
Career: Priest. Tutor to the Samoylov family in the late 18th century. Still in Moscow in 1821, he was among the subscribers supporting the flood victims. He was most likely the one who taught at a private boarding school in Stockholm in the second half of the 18th century.

Personal records: (*Versailles, France – 1783-08-20, Bogoroditsk, Province of Livonia, Russian Empire; his death certificate was signed by Andrey Bolotov, a famous scientist and writer, who was the governor of Bogoroditsk and Bobrikov districts at that time; testament dated 15 August 1783 and posthumous inventory dated 3 January 1784 in Moscow; his widow and daughter had disputes over property division). According to the chargé d'affaires Campredon, the chevalier de Brigny family originated from Saint-Malo. Among the relatives of Pierre-Louis de Brigny there were: Adrien (in Russia: Andreyan) de Brigny (in Russia: Debriny), a military engineer, a lieutenant general in the Russian army, a knight of the Order of Saint Alexander at the time of his death in 1746; the latter’ son Adrien de Brigny (ab. 1735, Russia), and his brother Pierre de Brigny, who served in the Russian army and became a general engineer in 1726; as well as a certain de Brigny (presumably, a relative of the above de Brigny), who received the rank of major in 1799 and the rank of commander in 1807 in the Russian army. Pierre-Louis de Brigny was married. In January 1777, he had two children, including: Jeanne-Catherine de Brigny (*Moscow), she lived in the Kaluga province in the spring of 1793, and took an oath of allegiance to the French crown in 1793; she was married to N. Labord; they had a daughter, Christine Labord (*ab. 1784), who was living with her mother in 1793, she was a parishioner of the Church of Saint Louis of the French in Moscow in 1797.
Career: A boarding school teacher in Moscow in August 1762.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school (ab. 1762, Moscow).

Personal records:
(*Amboise, Touraine) He represented a dynasty of dramatic artists. Father: François Brochard (†before 1792). Mother: Marie Duprat. Married to: 1.) Rose Marché (†before 1776); 2.) Marianne Cesari (from 1792-12-31). Children from the 1st marriage:
  • Marie Brochard (*around 1754), Mme Médard Urbain, with descendants;
  • Claire Brochard, married on 1792-12-31, at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg to Pierre-Nicolas Bourdais.
Possible children:
  • Jacques Brochard;
  • Thérèse Brochard, Mme François Michel;
  • Jeanne Brochard, Mme Jean Rochefort;
  • N. Brochard, unmarried in 1794, an actress who played confidantes.
He was the godfather of François Brochard on 1787-04-25, of Marie Brochard on 1790-02-05, and of Joseph-François Michel on 1790-10-06, at Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul in Moscow. He was a witness at the marriage of Sage/Martin on 1771-10-05, at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg.
Career: Actor of tragedy and singer in the French troupe at the Russian court, present in Russia since at least 1770. Mooser suggests he was a manager of the French spectacle in The Hague in 1762–1763 and performed in several French comic operas in Amsterdam. He joined the French troupe in Saint Petersburg on 1770-02-21, with a salary of 1,200 rubles and 300 rubles as travel compensation (in 1783). In 1777-10, he performed Le Médecin par occasion before the Empress at the Hermitage theater. Brochard delivered a dialogue that included the words: «A woman at thirty being in love is acceptable, but at sixty!» At that moment, the Empress stood up saying, «This play is silly, boring». The actors were forced to stop the performance. Around 1778, he also obtained the position of manager for performances given by the pensioners of the Smolny Institute, with an additional salary of 300 rubles. On 1783-04-29, at 6 o’clock, the first performance of the five-act comedy by Hauteroche titled L’Esprit follet and another one-act comedy were given for his benefit at the theater «near the imperial garden» (prices for «ordinary» seats and boxes to be reserved with Mr. Vacary). He retired on 1792-10-01 (annual pension of 600 rubles). He resided with his wife in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793. He was still there in 1797 (witness at the marriage of Daimières/Majour on 1797-07-03 at Saint Catherine of Alexandria). Paul I signed the order to expel Thérèse Michel and her father from the borders on 1799-09-12. The former actor was accused of having received a letter from his daughter, sent from Paris, during her stay at the beginning of 1799.

Personal records: (or Broquet) († before 1796). The Broquet family, called Broquette, was a family of gardeners who settled in Russia during the reign of Peter the Great and played an important role in setting up the gardens of the main imperial residences in the first half of the century. The family members were perfectly integrated in Russia, but formally continued to consider themselves French nationals. Father: Denis Broquette (†1734, Saint-Petersburg), a Protestant, a gardener, who arrived from Paris in Saint-Petersburg in 1710. Wife: (née) Marie Vinsch (Camin) († before 1796). Uncle: Jacques Broquette, a brother of Denis Broquette, an architect. Religion: Protestant (?)
Career: Being a gardener at the court, he was living in Moscow in 1748. Later he was a boarding school teacher in Moscow.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school (after 1748, Moscow).

Personal records: (or Pavel)
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French grammar; French syntax; translation; colloquial language; arithmetic; algebra; geometry; trigonometry.
Career: Concerning Pierre Brouillon, it is only known that he was a French tutor and worked for different families in Kyiv. As a Frenchman by origin, he was invited to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, where he taught French, arithmetic, algebra, geometry and trigonometry in 1788–1789. Since Pierre Brouillon did not speak Russian very well, Ivan Cherniavsky, a philosophy class student who was fluent in French, was appointed to help him in January 1789.
Teaching institutions and families:
Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1788–1789).
It is known that as a tutor, Pierre Brouillon taught French in several families in Kyiv, but no detailed information about him has been preserved.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few students from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
At the time, the textbook compiled by Martyn Sokolovsky was used for teaching French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. It is obvious that Pierre Brouillon did not lack textbooks for students. He could use other French grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library’s catalogue, it contained a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries at the time (by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey). Rather short book descriptions do not make it possible to identify all the books accurately.

Personal records: (or Rajmund) (1763-12-07 – 1848-08-23, Massa Lubrense, Campania, Italy) Brother: Tadeusz Brzozowski. Religion: Catholic.
Education: Raimund Brzozowski became a member of the Society of Jesus and entered the novitiate in Polatsk on 2 February 1780. After two years in the novitiate (1780–1782) he moved to the rhetoric class at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium, from which he graduated in 1783. From 1786 to 1788, he studied in the philosophy class at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French; Latin (?); rhetoric; poetics; mathematics; philosophy; theology; canon law.
Career:
Priest. From 1784 to 1786, Raimund Brzozowski, being a magister, taught French at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium. After studying at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium, he taught French and rhetoric (1788–1789, 1794–1798), and was later the seminary inspector (1804–1806) at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium. In addition, he taught rhetoric and poetics at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium (1793–1794), mathematics, philosophy, theology and canon law at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium (1799–1800, 1806–1812) and at the Polatsk Academy (1812–1814). From 1814 to 1817, he was the chancellor, and later the last rector (1817–1820) of the Polatsk Academy.
In 1820, Raimund Brzozowski was elected Assistant to the Superior General of the Society of Jesus Luigi Fortis and remained in that position until the latter's death in 1829.

Personal records: Probably originally from Neuvy-le-Roi, Indre-et-Loire. Married to: Marie Pierre (alive in 1793).
Career: Governor for the 2nd «age» at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg since 1782, he was dismissed on 1784-05-25, and was replaced in this position by governor Dumure. He was then employed at the Corps of Noble Cadets in Saint Petersburg. In 1793, he presented his passport issued in Versailles in 1779, another from Ambassador Ségur, as well as two certificates from the Academy of Fine Arts and the Corps of Noble Cadets of Saint Petersburg. Personal records: Married to: Sophie Le Fort. Son: François Burdiat (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul on 1789-07-14; godfather: Hubert-Marc Vavrin, Count of Villers du Tertre; godmother: Louise-Élisabeth Triquet, born Le Fort).
Career:
Tutor. He was admitted in 1786-02 to the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in place of governor Moissonnier (who pretended to leave due to poor health), with an annual salary of 200 rubles. His wife was the godmother of Jean-Jacques Triquet on 1785-07-16, at Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul in Moscow.
Burdiat remained a tutor for many years in Russia. Initially working without any authorization, he received a certificate from Moscow University on 1807-01-09. It was with this certificate that he traveled in Russia, without possessing any other documents. When in 1810 a police officer pointed out to him that the document was not valid for traveling in Russia, Burdiat approached the Moscow police, which added «on the back of my certificate another permission to stay and travel», all registered with the police and at the «address bureau». After the end of the war against Napoleon, Burdiat worked in Astrakhan and Saratov, where he was located in 1817-04. He sent a letter to the French ambassador in Russia, Count de Noailles, asking him to recognize him as French and to issue him a passport.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (from 1786, Saint Petersburg).

Personal records:
(*1713, Lyon, bapt. at Saint-Nizier – †1789-02-05, Saint Petersburg, registered at the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria; from a Lyonnaise family whose lineage has been traced since the early 18th century; the family still exists). Father: Jérôme Burdin, merchant. Mother: N. Ramette. Married to: Marie-Victoire Warlu (*1726, Barlemont, Flanders – †6 Germinal Year XII, Seine-Port, Seine-et-Marne). Benoît Burdin de Saint-Martin had several children, including:
  • Maximilien-Benoît Burdin de Saint-Martin (*Aranjuez, province of Toledo, Spain; godfather: Pierre Deleau, consul of France, on behalf of Marquis Paulnée, commander of the galleys of the Kingdom of Naples – †Laguiche, Saône-et-Loire, 1865-03-30), married on 1788-01-26, in Liège (Catholic parish of Saint-Nicolas) to Gertrude-Jeanne Hoorman (*1768, Haarlem), daughter of Jacob Librecht Hoorman and Anne Cornélia Sténis, of the Reformed faith, with descendants; he left Russia following the Marquis de Vérac and accompanied him to Holland (1783) and then to Solothurn (1787–1791); as an émigré, he did not return to France until 1802.
Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Merchant and then governor. He certainly spent part of his youth in Malaga, Spain, where his sister Catherine also resided and married François Mortemard, brother of the serving consul of France.
He traveled to Russia for business and lived in 1760 in Saint Petersburg in the house of tailor Georges (Millionnaya Street?). In April, together with his brother-in-law Mortemard, they announced a sale of clothing, silverware, jewelry, and other items at their residence on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays until their stock was exhausted. Burdin de Saint-Martin returned to Spain, holding the position of secretary to the Russian ambassador, but returned to Russia shortly after 1765.
As governor at the Academy of Fine Arts, he became acting inspector in 1773. In 1778, he received a gold medal from the Empress for his services. It was on his recommendation that French governors were hired at the Academy, including Godfrin and Thys, who served as sub-inspectors, Bourgeois, Gillot, Le Clerc, historian, etc. He was a sub-inspector in 1782. He retired on 1785-01-01, with an annual pension of 365 rubles.
He was a witness at the marriage of Jouanin/Druault on 1762-02-19, at the Catholic Church.
His wife also served as a governess at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg between 1767 and 1773.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (Saint Peterburg).
Teaching methods and materials: Burdin de Saint-Martin proposed a list of books (missing) «for the amusement of the students during their recess».

Personal records: (From a Huguenot family originating from Champagne; 1752-08-30, Kiekebusch, near Berlin – 1816-02-16, Berlin). Father: Jean Burja. Mother: Marie Péronne. Married to (on 1781-05-24, in Saint Petersburg): Christine Julienne (Élisabeth) Mahs (*1752-02-25, Saint Petersburg – †1814-07-08, Berlin), daughter of Johann Joachim Mahs and Catherine Hedwig Grän. Religion: Protestant.
Career: Initially a professor at the French College in Berlin (where Russian students formed, given their number, the second largest foreign group after the Italians). He traveled to Russia in 1777 to be a tutor for the children of a Tatishchev, in his estate in Boldino (this likely refers to the children of Yevgraf Vasilievich Tatishchev (1717–1781), an active state councillor, son of Vasily Nikitich Tatishchev, a famous historian of Russia). He explained in his Observations: «I was to go there to take under my guidance his two eldest sons [likely Rostislav, 1742-1820, and perhaps Alexei, 1760-1832]. He wanted them to travel through Europe». Burja must have met many French tutors in Russia because he divided them into three classes: «The first is composed of scholars without fortune, or discontented with their homeland, who come to seek asylum in this country; they are the smallest number». Another category consisted of merchants or soldiers who had lost their fortunes, and the third was made up of the general public, including wigmakers, lackeys, and bonnet-makers… He then became a mathematics teacher at the Land Noble Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg. His talents were appreciated there: «I had the happiness of being esteemed by the Chiefs and loved by the Cadets». Nevertheless, he acknowledged the validity of the opinion that «despite all the fine arrangements made at the Noble Cadet Corps, it does not produce all that one might expect; and the number of educated people and good soldiers who emerge from it is quite small». Often, he believed, the students were corrupted by their peers during the six years they spent at the Corps: «There are those who, however they are raised, will never love anything but idleness, mischief, and disorder; and these are the ones that must be kept in check, lest they spoil their classmates». Men are not naturally equal, he wrote, as a good Protestant pastor. Another reason for the failure lay within the teaching staff itself: professors were often ignorant and lacking in virtues, «they are taken as they are», noted Abel Burja. Burja was also aware of the education of young girls at the Smolny Institute, whose director, Sophie Lafont, was also of Huguenot origin. According to Burja, at the Institute «the education is the same as at the Cadet Corps, as far as the difference of the sexes allows». Sophie Lafont, for her part, was, according to Burja, a «respectable lady... due to the diligence with which she performs her duties». He himself resigned from his teaching position to become a preacher for the French Protestants in Saint Petersburg, two years after the departure of preacher Jean Curchod from Lausanne. He served as pastor in this church from 1779 to 1784. He recounted his election: «I was elected unanimously by the congregation, but as I had not yet received the laying on of hands, they addressed the Justice College for this purpose, which acts in ecclesiastical matters as a Superior Consistory. This College ordered, after having examined me as usual, to proceed with my consecration». The Reformed Church at that time gathered about seventy French Protestants against five hundred Germans. J. Bernoullis mentioned Burja as a modest young pastor but full of talents. His Observations were dedicated to Prince Vladimir Sergeyevich Dolgorukov (1717–1803), who worked at the Russian embassy in France in 1742, later becoming a current private counselor and Russian envoy to Prussia for twenty-four years (from 1762), and at one point converted to Catholicism. The author describes, in the form of a daily journal, the route he followed, often providing detailed descriptions of the regions he traversed. There are observations on Russian society of the time. According to Burja, «public entertainments are numerous and brilliant in Petersburg», «gambling is very fashionable», «the nobles have adopted the lifestyle of other Europeans; the bourgeois, being usually freed slaves, retain almost all the customs of their state, and are quite few in number». He denounced the coarse morals of the peasantry, particularly drunkenness, specifying: «Their intellectual cultivation is very little; they cannot read or write; all their wisdom consists of proverbs... They love to sing and always sing». He also noted the Russians’ relationship with money: «However disinterested the Russians may be, they easily develop a taste for money, especially when they start trading: then they are perfectly similar to Jews, just as exorbitant in the prices they demand, just as obstinate in haggling over every penny; but at the same time, just as willing to be satisfied with the smallest profit if they cannot sell otherwise». Patriotism, in his view, «is as rare in Russia as a point of honor. Everyone is selfish, everyone thinks of their fortune and interests; no one, except the Sovereign, cares much for the public good». He developed his conception of the public good: «More freedom for the people and less power for the great would perhaps be the means to put all orders of the state in mutual dependence», «so that the happiness of each individual would largely depend on the public good: from there would arise the love of the homeland». Burja was an unconditional admirer of Catherine II: «The influence of Russia on the political system of Europe has been continually increasing since Peter I; and today, under Catherine II, it has reached a very high period». As for domestic policy, aimed at multiplying schools and training a more enlightened clergy, for Burja, these were merely «the first steps ever taken to increase the level of civilization». However, Pastor Burja did not appreciate certain cultural innovations that affected the court but little or not at all the Russian people: «All the rest – Academies, men of Letters called at great expense and generously rewarded, established courts, luxury introduced into the country, French fashions adopted at court and among the nobility – have little influence on the bulk of a nation». Upon his resignation, he was replaced in the Reformed Church by Pastor Étienne Dumont. Upon his return to Berlin, Burja was elected to the Berlin Academy of Sciences in 1787 and, in 1794, became an honorary member of the Academy of St. Petersburg. He distinguished himself as a mathematician, being one of the first to measure time in music and a precursor of telegraphy. He was certainly a Freemason. Burja Abel, mathematics teacher, was in Russia from 1777 to 1784. In 1783, he met Euler shortly before the latter’s death. Eyewitness accounts of Euler's demise.
Teaching institutions and families:
Tatishchev family;
Land Noble Cadet Corps; Smolny Institute, all in Saint Petersburg.

Betankour-Biakster, p. 497. Burja A. The Death of Leonard Euler. Publ. N. E. Pavlova. - In: Leonard Euler. Collection of Articles in Honor of the 250th Anniversary of His Birth. Moscow, 1958, p. 605-607. Translated from the edition: Burja A. Observations d'un voyageur sur la Russie... Berlin, 1785.

Personal records: (or Bütner) (*Lohsa, near Hoyerswerda, Saxony – beginning of 1714, Moscow). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Büttner was enrolled as a student of theology at the university of Halle on 5 October 1701.
Career:
Teacher, director of school.
From 1703 to 1705, Büttner was head of the Lutheran grammar school in Pressburg (today Bratislava). Due to anti-pietistic movements in Hungary, he left Pressburg in 1705 and returned to Halle.
Büttner was sent to Moscow by A.H. Francke in autumn 1705 together with his colleagues P.D. Brettschneider and M. Ruttich. He arrived in Moscow in December 1705 and became a Latin and German teacher (first class, “prima”) at the Moscow Foreign Language School. In summer 1706 (5 July) he succeeded J.W. Paus as director of this school. He remained director until the end of 1710 for an annual salary of 120 roubles and 50 roubles for food. Büttner knew Czech and quickly learned Russian. In his correspondence with A.H. Francke, he regularly reported the difficulties he met in running the school. Conflicts arose especially with the Russian administration and the parents of rich pupils, who often were sent to the school by order of tsar Peter I and not because their parents wished it. Büttner was very interested in languages and commissioned studies about the language and culture of his Tatarian, Kalmyk and Armenian pupils. He was also the author of the Theologia Patrum Graecorum, a compilation of sentences of Greek church fathers with their translation into Latin. His request to publish his works at Halle was refused. His translations of the New Testament into Russian and Armenian remained unfinished. In 1710, Büttner asked to be released for health reasons. Following Kovrigina, it was more likely that the actual reasons were the administration plans to reorganize the school by transforming it into a foreign language school only. He left the school in March or April 1711. In the following years, he taught the pupils of the German schools in the German Quarter. In 1714, Büttner died in Moscow.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow Foreign Language School (1705–1711).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; soldiers; merchants; craftsmen.
At the beginning of the Moscow Foreign Language School, pupils came almost always from the administration or, in some rare cases, from the higher nobility. They had to learn foreign languages for diplomatic service or service in the administration and the ministries (collegia). Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was significantly extended and sons of soldiers and craftsmen also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To attract more pupils, in the first years of the existence of the school, students were exempted from military service.
In 1711: Boris Khrushchev; Ivan Lodyzhenskii.
The complete list of pupils, studying at the Moscow Foreign Language School between 1703 and 1715 was published by Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. XXII-XL.
Teaching methods and materials: Comenius, Johann Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […]. Comenius, Johann Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698). It is not quite sure which issues of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Foreign Language School. What we do know is that J.E. Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis pictus” into Russian. The “Vestibulum” was completed by end of 1703 and Glück applied to the tsar with a petition to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, p. 47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished. Other texts used in language classes at the Moscow Foreign Language school were: various nomenclatures (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (possibly the Latin-German dialogues of Johann Georg Seybold); the Lutheran bible; the Lutheran catechism; German hymns.

De fide et ritibus Armenorum (1708), unpublished. Büttner was very interested in the Armenian church, culture and tradition. His works on these topics were delivered to A.H. Personal records: Probably of Italian origin, but French-speaking. Married to (on 1766-12-15 at the Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg): Ève-Christine Vedel. Son: Adolphe Canevaro (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at St. Catherine of Alexandria on 1769-12-29; godfather: Count Alexei Razumovsky, certainly Alexei Kirillovich Razumovsky, future Minister of Public Instruction). Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Colon and French language teacher. He came to Russia as a colonist at the expense of the Chancellery for the Guardianship of Foreigners, but refused to continue to the colonies of Saratov because he found a position in Saint Petersburg. He worked notably as a «French language teacher for the second and third classes» at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg starting in 1769. He earned 225 rubles in annual salary, part of which was deducted to repay his debt to the Chancellery for the Guardianship of Foreigners.
In 1772 or 1773, he was mistreated by a Russian merchant from Saint Petersburg named Mikhail Osepolov, originally from Tula, who was his creditor for 30 rubles. «Having learned that my wages from the Academy were being withheld by order of the Chancellery of Guardianship and consequently that he could not have a share in them for prompt repayment, he sent six soldiers from the Guild and had me seized like a scoundrel in front of the Cadet Corps in my carriage. […] When I was before the Burgomaster, I asked him if he had given the soldiers the authority to seize me so shamelessly in the street, and I urged him to pay attention to the fact that I had the honor of being under the Academy of Sciences».
Shortly thereafter, Canevaro endured the same indignity: he was seized in the middle of the bridge over the Neva, dragged before the Admiralty, and released only thanks to the intercession of an assessor he knew. Canevaro asked the president of the Academy of Sciences to intervene to obtain «reparations for honor» from the merchant. In 1773-11, Prince Grigori Grigorievich Orlov (1734–1783) [one of the authors of the coup that elevated Catherine II, favorite of the Empress and president of the Academy], having learned of Canevaro’s troubles, requested to see his «certificate of attendance and conduct». L. Bachmeister provided this assessment: «Mr. Canevaro has infinite troubles in the lower class he teaches and deserves that the Commission does not refuse him the certificate he requests. If he does not come sometimes during his class hours, as the Commission knows from my reports, it will, as I hope, be easy for him to justify himself».
In 1774-04, knowing that his colleague earned 300 rubles per year, Canevaro requested a raise: «the great inequality combined with the number of more than thirty students requires a great deal of effort if one wishes to derive any benefit from it. […] I must teach how to read well, pronounce correctly, and the rules of grammar, which is the fundamental basis of the language, and hold twelve hours of class per week, while my colleague has a single class for translation, six hours».
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Sciences (from 1769, Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (1742-03-09, Pont-de-Veyle, Ain, France – 1793-10-31, Paris; guillotined).
Education: A self-taught individual.
Career: Man of letters. Jean-Louis Carra left France in 1772 due to troubles with the police (he had been accused of a serious theft), passing through Greece, Turkey, and Ukraine before landing in Saint Petersburg in 1775. He received a recommendation that allowed him to find a position as governor and secretary to the hospodar of Moldavia, Grigori Ghika. In 1775–1776, Carra lived for a year in Jassy, the capital of Moldavia, with the hospodar’s family; in 1777, the latter was beheaded by order of the Sublime Porte. Carra described the rebuffs faced by the French in Moldavia in his History of Moldavia and Wallachia. A Freemason, J.-L. Carra was affiliated in 1776 in Jassy to the Moldova lodge. Upon returning to France, he became the secretary to Cardinal de Rohan. An active member of the Jacobin Club, he befriended Brissot and was appointed keeper of the Royal Library on the recommendation of Mme Roland, who wrote of him that he «dreamed of the happiness of his country and the liberation of all Europe with inexpressible complacency». A member of the insurrection committee that prepared for August 10, he was elected deputy to the Convention for two departments, voted for the king’s death, and was sent to Vendée with Auguis to oversee the conscription of 300,000 men in 1793-03. Accused on 1793-07-28, he was tried and executed alongside the leaders of the Gironde.
Language and other teaching books by the:
He was a prolific author and published notably: - Odazir, roman philosophique, La Haye, Bouillon, 1772, in-8°;
  • Système de la raison, ou le Prophète philosophe, Londres, 1773, 88 p. in-8°;
  • Nouveaux principes de physique, Paris, Esprit, 1781-1783, 4 vol. in-8°;
- Histoire de la Moldavie et de la Valachie, avec une dissertation sur l'état actuel de ces deux provinces, Jassy: aux dépens de la Société typographique des Deux-Ponts, 1777, 223 p. in-8°; - Essai particulier de politique dans lequel on propose un partage de la Turqui européenne, par Monsieur C***, À Constantinople, 1777.
  • Considérations, recherches et observations sur les États généraux, [s.l.], 1789, in-8°; 1790, in-8°;
  • Mémoires historiques et authentiques sur la Bastille, Londres et se trouve à Paris, chez Buisson, 1790, 3 vol. in-8° (on the events of July 14, 1789, a great commercial success).
Being in France, he participated in the writing of the Encyclopédie and was later employed at the King’s Library on the recommendation of Cardinal de Rohan. He was one of the revolutionary leaders in France from the outset of the Revolution and contributed to the drafting of the Mercure national or Journal d’État et du citoyen, as well as the Annales patriotiques et littéraires, which he animated along with L. S. Mercier.

Career:

Personal records: (or Grignet de Champagnolot) (ar. 1736, Burgundy, France – ar. 1776, Saint Petersburg). According to Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon), Madame Champagnolot, who was very pretty, had come to Russia with the coachman of Count Piotr Chernyshev (no doubt Piotr Grigorievich Chernyshev (1712–1773), a diplomat, Russian ambassador in Berlin and in Paris, state councillor, brother of Zakhar and Ivan Chernyshev, influential statesmen under Catherine II) at the beginning of the reign of Catherine II. Her husband having drowned, she married again, this time Jacques Tullier whom Corberon calls Touilly. Widowed yet again, her third husband was Champagnolot who made a living «from industry with her, either from her charms which she began to make public, or from the complicity of the councillor Bonneau» («d’industrie avec elle, soit de ses charmes qu’elle commençoit à rendre un peu publics, soit de la complaisance du conseiller Bonneau»). Religion: Catholic.
Education: In 1766 Champagnolot took the exam intended for preceptors at Moscow University.
Career:
According to Corberon, Champagnolot was a former Oratorian, a former officer, who had come to Russia in the 1760s.
On 18 February 1766 Champagnolot took the exam for preceptors at the University of Moscow. He presented the university with a statement signed by Lieutenant general Mikhail Izmailov and received a certificate from the university to teach French «par principes». On 3 April 1767 he was engaged by the university to teach French to the lower class. He was dismissed some time afterwards for not having fulfilled his functions. But in 1770 he applied again to replace Henri de Lavie who had just died. This time Champagnolot addressed the university authorities in Latin. His rivals for the post were Pierre Fauvel and Fiodor Karjavin, the famous translator, and it was the latter who won. 
In 1768 he opened a boarding-school in Moscow in the house of Andrey Borisovich Buturlin, in Miasnitskaya street , near the court ( ?) of Tatishchev. In n° 22 of the journal Moskovskiye Vedomosti in the same year he announced that he could be found in the house of councillor Fonvizin. He made a «Prospectus de l’établissement», definitely printed, where he explained the method he wanted to follow and the organisation of his establishment. As well as the usual subjects, he taught fencing, for six roubles a month, and music for seven roubles. The pupils had to study fencing and music from 16h30 to 20h. He also accepted day students. The teaching was to begin on 15 January and the teachers he had engaged were «the best».
Towards 1776 Champagnolot ran a sort of inn or bed-and-breakfast in Saint Petersburg. He went to the French embassy to apply for a passport, then one day he invited Corberon with his secretary, Combes, to his house. His wife used to attend Mass at the hôtel de France and reproached Corberon with not having come to see her. Other French diplomats had liaisons with her, notably Saint-Paul and Chastenet de Puységur who had lived in Paris with the Champagnolots. These visits were later held against Corberon when he fell into disgrace at the Russian court. The Champagnolots had kept up a correspondence tending to introduce counterfeit banknotes, a traffic involving Berland de La Bordelière. In 1776, the husband left Russia entrusting the family interests to the consul Lesseps. He sent the cargo from France by boat in packets addressed to his wife. A certain Courant from Neuchâtel was mixed up in this but he denounced Champagnolot. The affair was discovered in October 1776, Champagnolot’s wife was exposed and imprisoned for three days before being exiled from Russia with her mother and brother; the empress however gave each of them 100 roubles for the journey. According to Corberon, Champagnolot was arrested in Poland, transferred to Saint Petersburg where he was condemned to death or cut his throat «in despair». Mme Champagnolot owed the elder Bousquet 75 roubles in September 1776.
Teaching institutions and families: University of Moscow (1767 – dismissed some time afterwards); boarding school in Moscow (from 1768).
Teaching methods and materials: He taught French at the University of Moscow; French, «usual subjects», music and fencing in his boarding-school.

Personal records: Born in Biermes (arr. of Rethel, in Champagne-Ardennes, according to the Biographie ardennaise of J.-B.-J. Boulliot, the first source to provide information about Charpentier). «Native of Paris» (according to the 1779 certificate from the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg, likely by approximation). Born around 1740 (biographical dictionaries) or in the 1720s (Abbé de Lubersac, who knew Charpentier around 1782, claimed that he had stayed in Saint Petersburg for more than thirty-five years and therefore must have arrived before 1747, while still young). Died in Saint Petersburg around 1800 (biographical dictionaries). However, there is no trace of his presence in Saint Petersburg after his resignation from the Academy of Sciences in 1779. He may be the Charpentier who served as a bank manager («économe») and, like all the French residing in Russia, took the oath in 1793. Also referred to as Jean-Charles (in his appointment as French master at the Academy of Sciences school in Saint Petersburg and in the minutes of Charpentier’s installation dated 1763-08-04). Known as Jean-Baptiste-Jude Charpentier (according to his autograph signature on the death certificate and the inventory after the death of J.-B. Le Prince, respectively on 1781-10-01 and 1781-10-10, published by J. Hédou in 1879), he was called Ivan Charpentier in Russia (cf. his request dated 1763-07-25, in which he applied for the position of French master in the upper class of the «Gymnasium» of the Academy of Sciences with a salary of 300 rubles per year). Father: Charles Charpentier. Married to: Anne-Catherine-Louise Le Prince, sister of the painter. He had at least one son.
Career:
Author of the first Russian manual published for the French, teacher; «formerly abbé», according to the travel journal of Jean-Louis PICTET, a Genevan astronomer who met Charpentier in Saint Petersburg. French master (since 1761) at the Academy of Fine Arts (then still formally affiliated with Moscow University) in Saint Petersburg, he held the same position in the upper class of the Academy of Sciences school from 1763 to 1779. He was responsible for examining in French the prospective tutors who, since 1757, had to apply to the Academy for a certificate of competence. He also served at the Academy as a translator from Russian and German into French. Charpentier resigned from his position at the Academy in 1779-02, dissatisfied with his salary of 300 rubles per year, and was replaced by the reader Th. Joli. Charpentier also gave private lessons to various individuals, notably, in 1777, to Piotr Vasilievich Zavadovski (1739–1812, at that time a favorite of Catherine II, future count, senator, minister of education, etc.). After the departure in 1764 of the military man and governor Marignan from Saint Petersburg, Charpentier revised and expanded his manuscript grammar; he indeed states in the preface: «It is therefore rather the work of Mr. de Marignan than my own that I present to the public». He thus published in 1768 a Russian grammar. Charpentier himself organized the sale of his manual, which was published at his own expense, and all the print run (2000 copies) was handed over to him after the payment of 669 rubles 20 kopecks. This book was put on sale in Moscow by the publisher-bookseller Christian Rüdiger, who assigned it a fictitious title in Russian (the book does not have a Russian title, and the author’s name is also not indicated on the title page): Грамматика Российская, на французском языке, изданная Гг. Мариньяном и Шерпантье (Grammaire russe en français, éditée par Messieurs Marignan et Cherpentier). In the early 1780s, this book was also printed in 2400 copies at the expense of Vilkovski, an employee at the Academy of Sciences bookstore, who sold it for 1 ruble 15 kopecks; by 1783-06, only 520 unsold copies remained. This book is not a translation of Lomonosov’s Russian Grammar (Российская грамматика, Saint Petersburg, 1755 [1757]), as some linguists believe based on the claims of the authors, who were either too modest or not modest enough in their ambitions. Marignan and Charpentier made a critical and free adaptation of Lomonosov’s grammar. H. L. C. Bacmeister already pointed this out in 1789 in the Projet d'une Bibliothèque, peu nombreuse, pour servir à donner quelque connaissance de l'état de l'Empire de Russie depuis les tems les plus reculés jusqu'à nos jours, Saint Petersburg, 1789, p. 19. The chapter on «The Verb», although Charpentier claims in the preface of the book (he asserts that he follows Lomonosov «step by step») contains criticisms of Lomonosov’s conception. For example, Marignan and Charpentier wisely eliminate two of the three pluperfects that Lomonosov notes among the ten tenses of the Russian verb. They reduce the number of genders of Russian nouns to three (masculine, feminine, and neuter) and eliminate the fourth one proposed by Lomonosov (the common gender). Charpentier and Marignan are generally less bold and more reasonable, much more «pedagogical» and practical than their Russian model: it is French common sense that triumphs over Russian excess. They simplify, sometimes erroneously and falsely, but often correctly, the brilliant intuitions of the Russian scholar. Elements de la langue russe is a good practical manual of Russian (the first published in Russia), with translation exercises, interesting dialogues on Russian civilization, and a collection of Russian proverbs. The latter inaugurates the publication of such collections in Russia. He may be the Charpentier who served as a bank manager («économe») and, like all the French residing in Russia, took the oath in 1793. The Genevan astronomers J.-L. Pictet and J.-A. Mallet, traveling in Russia in 1768, met Charpentier several times: on 1768-06-29, it was during a dinner at Count Alexander Stroganov’s, where J.-A. Mallet found «a Mr. Woronzoff, senator, cordon bleu, brother, as I believe, of the chancellor, Count Munnich, also a cordon bleu, president of the College of Commerce, Baron Tott, two Russians whose names I did not know, a Mr. Charpentier, François, formerly abbé, now a language master and author of a Russian grammar that is about to be published [...]». On July 6, Mallet encountered Charpentier again at the same Stroganov’s. In 1772, Charpentier lived in Saint Petersburg in Neumann’s house on Lugovaya Millionnaya Street, near the Green Bridge, or Police Bridge, opposite the private hotel of Count A. S. Stroganov. There he sold a curious work titled:
  • Lettres d'un Scyte [sic!] franc et loyal, A Monsieur Rousseau, de Bouillon, Auteur du Journal Encyclopédique, Amsterdam and Paris, 1771, 65 p., in-12°. This work, which is a refutation of the famous Voyage en Sibérie by Abbé Chappe, contains two letters. The first («Sur le danger des Préjugés nationaux»), very interesting from a philosophical, philanthropic, and even Masonic perspective, is directed against the prejudices that abound in Chappe’s work. The second («Sur l'Histoire de Sybérie [sic!]») is devoted to the numerous errors of the learned abbé. The commission for this pamphlet likely came from Catherine II; in any case, these Lettres are inspired by the famous Antidote, ou Examen d’un livre superbement imprimé intitulé «Voyage en Sibérie […]» (published anonymously in 1770 in Saint Petersburg), adopting the same biting and mocking tone towards Abbé Chappe and his work, the same examples of Russia’s spectacular progress since the reign of Peter I in various fields (political, cultural, and military), and sometimes the same expressions, but the style of this letter is less heavy and more elegant than that of its model. One might wonder if Charpentier is also the author of the Lettres d'un Scyte.
It is possible that during his five-month stay in Saint Petersburg, Diderot learned some elements of Russian thanks to Charpentier’s grammar and perhaps even under his guidance. Upon returning to Paris, Diderot sold his copy of the Elements de la langue russe to the King’s Library on 1775-07-04, along with his other Russian books, for the sum of 900 livres. This would be the copy cataloged as Rés. p. Z. 1772. Charpentier was probably the same person as «Charapant», the speaker of the French works of the lodge Égalité since 1776-06-30. Charpentier met Abbé Lubersac in 1782, the author of Premier discours sur l'utilité et les avantages que les princes peuvent retirer de leurs voyages en parcourant les monuments publics, with an epistle to Grand Duke Paul Petrovich of Russia; the abbé appreciated Charpentier for his information about Count of the North (the future Paul I). In 1793, a Frenchman named Jean-Charles Charpentier, a bank manager, took the oath of loyalty to the crown of France required by the Russian authorities. Could this not be the grammarian Charpentier? Zavadovski, director of the state banks, could have secured this position for his former teacher.
Teaching institutions and families:
Academy of Fine Arts; 
Academy of Sciences school.
Students and their social status: Piotr Vasilievich Zavadovski
Teaching methods and materials: Lomonosov M.V. Rosiyskaya grammatika, Saint Petersburg, 1755 [1757].
Language and other teaching books by the: He published in 1768 a Russian grammar titled: - Elements de la langue russe ou Methode courte et facile pour apprendre cette langue conformément à l’usage, Saint-Petersbourg, de l’imprimerie de l’Académie des sciences, 1768, [16], 368 p., 1 tabl., in-8° (reprints: Saint Petersburg, 1791, 1795, 1805). He can be attributed a pompous and grandiloquent letter titled: - Lettre d'un Russe de St. Petersbourg à un de ses amis de Moscou, sur les Evénemens actuels de l'Empire des Russes, Saint Petersbourg, [Printed by the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg], [1768 and not 1767], 15 p. in-8°. The letter is dated 1767-11-26 (p. 13); other editions: 1770 (3rd), 1773 (4th). One of the copies of this Letter (RGADA) bears this inscription: «The author of this piece is a Frenchman newly arrived in St. Petersburg. He is not named, it is only said that he practiced as a lawyer in France. He has expatriated himself, it is said, to make his fortune in Russia». The Archives of the Academy of Sciences specify that «by decision of the Commission at the Academy of Sciences dated March 10 [1768] No. 197, a piece in French entitled Lettre d'un Russe was printed for Master Charpentier, with a print run of 500 copies on Lubeck paper - in total, a sheet in small octavo cicero» (tr. from Russian, SPFA RAN, fonds 3, inv. 1, dos. 312, f. 34); this piece was published at Charpentier’s expense, who signed this autograph note: «For 500 copies of the Lettre d'un Russe de S. Petersbourg à un Russe de Moscou on Lubeck-style paper, I paid eleven rubles eighty-one kopecks. on March 24, 1768» (autograph signature in French without a first name). It is a panegyric to Catherine II, portrayed as the «mother of the fatherland» and as a worthy heir of Peter I: the Empress establishes a commission for the drafting of laws (this obviously refers to the commission for the development of the new code of laws, which, following Catherine II’s famous Nakaz, began its work precisely in 1767), she cultivates the land in the uninhabited provinces of the empire (likely an allusion to the campaign for recruiting settlers in the 1760s), she opens educational institutions for children of both sexes (indeed, the Moscow House of Education and the Smolny Institute for Noble Girls were founded in 1764) and prioritizes education, «elsewhere so neglected», she takes care of commerce by opening her ports to foreigners, restores the Academy of Fine Arts, and makes the «happy choice» of her ministers, who are «Sully and Colbert». This pamphlet is also one of the first curious and accurate descriptions of the equestrian statue of Peter I by Falconet, «rival of Praxitelles and Phidias [sic!]», a description that seems directly inspired by Falconet. «At the feet of this immortal hero, the Mother constantly leads her son. There she teaches him the Art of reigning» (let us remember that we are in 1767 and that the statue does not yet exist!). The sculptor is said to have personally drawn the author’s attention to the admirable work accomplished by Marie-Anne Collot, the creator of the head of this statue (see also Bilbassov, 1896, t. 12, part 1, no. 91). It is legitimate to wonder who initiated the composition of this pamphlet, written in French and of which copies can be found in libraries in Western Europe (three copies of different editions in the National Library of France). Could it be Catherine II, who, through the publicity of the monument in honor of her great predecessor, seeks to glorify her own reign which has just begun? Or Falconet? Or perhaps Count Alexander Sergeyevich Stroganov? Some clues suggest that it may be Stroganov.

Personal records:
(*Paris, around 1735)
«Originally Swiss».
Education: In 1773-08, he approached the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg to take the examination required for foreign tutors. He characterized himself in this way: «He writes and speaks French purely and correctly; it is enough to say that he knows its principles and is able to demonstrate them, particularly in writing, which he has studied in depth. He is well-versed in history. Finally, he combines all these qualities with a refined mind and a quite happy memory, which will enable him to instill in the students entrusted to him virtuous principles and patriotic sentiments». The examiners considered that he possessed a foundation in arithmetic, the history of ancient and modern times, and that he mastered geography and French.
Career: Tutor. He served for fourteen years in the French East India Company and «he only left it when its trade ceased». «He had just been appointed chief writer of its ships when the King, taking on the debts of this company, seized all its possessions» (1769). He was in Saint Petersburg in 1773. In 1784–1785, he was a rhetoric professor at the Imperial Corps of Noble Cadets. A Freemason, he was initiated in the Loge des coeurs réunis in Montpellier, a member of the Saint John Lodge (La Réunion des Elus du Nord) of the Orient of Saint Petersburg, with the Masonic rank of «all degrees» and the Masonic dignity of Master.

Personal records: (1725-05-20, Orléans – 1773-11, Moscow; inventory after death on 1773-11-15). Father: Gabriel de Chaumeix (originally from Saint-Pardoux d’Arnet near Crocq (Creuse), major of the Royal Corps of Engineers, who retired to his estate in Chanteau, near Orléans). Mother: Anne Pierret (†1729). Married to (in Paris on 1759-05-17): Béatrix-Françoise Le Clercq, daughter of Simon Le Clercq, a merchant from Lille, and Marie-Magdeleine Cousin. Daughter: Sophie-Joseph de Chaumeix, married the academician Pierre-François-Célestin-Joseph Duquesne.
Education: He studied philosophy at the Jesuit college and theology at the seminary in Orléans, with the intention of becoming a priest.
Career: Man of letters. Abraham-Joseph de Chaumeix was a tutor in Orléans, squandered the inheritance he received from his father, and then accepted the position of tax prosecutor in Henrichemont (Cher), where he stayed for a short time. He settled in Paris in 1757; he worked there as a tutor and then as a philosophy tutor, managing to make a living by his writing. «Former vinegar merchant», according to Voltaire, who also described him as a Jansenist convulsionist, he attacked the Encyclopédie at the beginning of its publication and drew attention with his Prejugés légitimes contre l’Encyclopédie et essai de réfutation de ce dictionnaire (Paris and Berlin, 1758–1759, 8 vol. in-12). He thus incurred the ire of the encyclopedists, and Morellet published against him a Mémoire pour Abraham Chaumeix, contre les prétendus philosophes Diderot et d’Alembert (Amsterdam, 1759, in-12) and Leclerc de Molinet Préjugés légitimes contre ceux du S. Chaumeix (1759, in-12). Voltaire ridiculed him in Pauvre Diable and the Contes de Guillaume Vadé. His name often appears in Voltaire’s writings: «Let us make only one reflection on these passages, which is that if some philosopher had expressed himself in the Encyclopédie like the Dominican missionary Labat, a crowd of Patouillets and Nonottes, Chiniacs, Chaumeix, and other rascals would have cried out against the deist, the atheist, the geometer». Despised by philosophers in France, he took refuge in Moscow in 1762 or 1763, where he became a schoolmaster. He is attributed a role in the publication of an ordinance concerning the burial of the poor, who were often deprived of a grave. He was the godfather of Claude-Catherine-Marie Vendredy on 1763-11-03, at the Catholic church in Saint Petersburg.
Language and other teaching books by the:
He drew attention with: - Prejugés légitimes contre l’Encyclopédie et essai de réfutation de ce dictionnaire (Paris and Berlin, 1758–1759, 8 vol. in-12). A prolific author, he also published:
  • Sentiment d’un inconnu sur l’Oracle des nouveaux philosophes, 1760, in-12;
  • Les Philosophes aux abois, 1760, in-8°;
  • Nouveau Plan d’études, ou Essai sur la manière de remplir les places dans les collèges que les jésuites occupaient, Cologne, Paris, 1762, 2 vol., in-12;
  • Petite Encyclopédie, ou Dictionnaire des Philosophes, Ouvrage posthume d’un de ces Messieurs, Antwerp, Jean Gasbeck, 1771.
He contributed to the Censeur hebdomadaire and provided various pieces for newspapers. See on his work: Albertan-Coppola.

(*ar. 1722, Paris)
Married to: Amelia-Sabina Frankin, a Swede; on 1758-08-19, at the Catholic church in Saint Petersburg (witness: Jean Devaux).
Career:
Tutor. He arrived in Russia from Amsterdam in 1750 with Lieutenant Mikhail Lvovich Izmailov of the Semyonovski Guard Regiment. He served as a tutor for Izmailov in Moscow and, after the lieutenant’s departure to Saint Petersburg, for his brother, the non-commissioned officer of the same regiment, Dmitri Izmailov, until 1752-01-02, without any residence permit. At the beginning of 1752, he requested that a residence permit be issued to him in Moscow and submitted a petition to Empress Elizabeth Petrovna, describing his life since arriving in Russia. He was interrogated, appeared «without suspicion», and received the requested title on April 27: he could now live in Russia wherever he wanted, with the obligation to register properly, but without the permission to leave the Empire freely. The document described him in detail: «he measures two archines and seven verchoks [about 1.70 m], round face, brown eyes, dark chestnut hair, straight nose, a bit freckled».
In 1757, Louis Chevalier took the examination at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg to obtain a certificate of professional qualification. He was found capable of teaching French.
Teaching institutions and families: Izmailov family

Personal records: Originally from Strasbourg. Married to: Marie N., a governess.
Career: Tutor. He resided in the 5th district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793. His wife was a governess with the Bibikov family. After returning to Moscow from Kaluga in 1794-11, he was still residing there in 1795. Out of work and considered by the police to be a free thinker, he was part of a group of fourteen tutors who, in 1795 in Moscow, proposed to establish a mutual aid society for tutors. The contributions were intended to cover the medical expenses of the members, provide those who found themselves without a position with «housing, wood, candles, tea, coffee, and food for the price of 25 rubles per month», and serve to create a library accessible to all members. Catherine II prohibited the establishment of «such useless societies and organizations» and threatened the tutors with expulsion from the Empire if they persisted in their intention (see notice Noël).
