Personal records:
(1752-02-24, Strasbourg – 1814-09-17, Moscow). Father: Antoine Courtener, blacksmith. Mother: Marguerite Hains. Married to: Henriette-Marie-Anne Dreyer, known as Anna Antonovna (*ar. 1761, Strasbourg). She was a harpist and taught harp at the Smolny Institute for Noble Girls from 1781 to 1782. She was still alive in 1793. Children:
  • Élisabeth-Henriette Courtener (*ca. 1782), Mme Jean Gautier-Dufayer;
  • Joseph-Jean-François Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1783-03-19; godfather: Jean Butler; godmother: Josèphe-Marie Dreyer);
  • Eugénie-Julie Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1784-05-28; godfather: Jean Butler; godmother: Christine Dreyer);
  • Caroline-Marie Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1785-08-10; godfather: Jean Butler; godmother: Anne-Marie Maÿ); she was the godmother of Catherine-Caroline Courtener on 1793-12-09, at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul;
  • Jean-François Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1787-05-16; godfather: Jean-Otto Maÿ, bookseller; godmother: Nathalie Schwartz);
  • Alexandrine-Dorothée Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1788-07-04; godfather: Jean-Otto Maÿ, bookseller; godmother: Dorothée Subert);
  • François-Pierre Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1789-10-14);
  • Antoine-Georges-Louis Courtener (*Moscow, 1790-12-07, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on the 13th);
  • Alexandrine-Caroline Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1792-08-23; godfather: Pierre-Guillaume Maÿ, bookseller; godmother: Élisabeth-Henriette Courtener);
  • Catherine-Caroline Courtener (*Moscow, 1793-12-07, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on the 9th; godfather: Dominique Riss, grand French bookseller in Moscow; godmother: Caroline Courtener);
  • Théodore-Jean Courtener (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Pierre-et-Paul on 1795-09-18).
Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Bookseller originally from Strasbourg, residing in Moscow before 1776. François Courtener requested a passport to go to France in 1776-10. In 1782, he settled in Moscow in the house of a Pastukhov on Ilyinka Street and opened a grain store where he sold, among other things, flower bulbs from Holland and France. It was in 1785 that he opened a bookstore in Moscow at 3 Ilyinka Street, which he would manage for over twenty-five years. The location of his bookstore on a very busy street in the heart of Moscow, in a neighborhood inhabited by Russian aristocrats, contributed to the success of his business. He sold French books and later introduced Russian books and prints. He subscribed his clientele to multi-volume editions, sometimes positioning himself as a co-publisher. He often resorted to this trick, leading the public to believe that a particular book was published by him, while in reality, he was merely adding a few sheets to a foreign edition. He regularly published his catalog. Registered in 1791 in the 3rd guild of merchants in Moscow, he transferred his store to the house of Ievlev, also on Ilyinka Street, and left for abroad in 1791-04. He then published an advertisement in the Moskovskiye Vedomosti on April 19/23 (in French in the newspaper): «François Courtener, bookseller on Ilyinsky Street, has the honor to inform gentlemen lovers of foreign literature that he will undertake a journey to France, Switzerland, and Germany, from where he hopes to return by the end of September of this year. He will take on any commissions entrusted to him related to his business that are within his knowledge. He will be satisfied with a provision or profit of 10 percent for purchases, receiving the amount of the commission in advance. Transportation costs will be paid upon receipt. Commissions that arrive after his departure will also be fulfilled; those for Paris and Switzerland should be given during the month of May; and those for Germany will be accepted until the end of June and will be addressed to the bookstore on Ilyinsky Street, which will provide good new arrivals during his absence, served by active and intelligent persons. By declaring and recognizing as good and valid the signature of his wife during his absence, he asks gentlemen lovers of literature to show him the same confidence that he has been honored with until now». Upon his return in September 1791, François Courtener established himself on Nikolskaya Street in the house of T. D. Chevaldychev, opposite the Zaikonospasski Monastery, where he remained until 1802. In addition to books, he sold board games and carriages. Accepted as a merchant of the 3rd guild at the same time (until 1812), he had Jean Gautier, his future son-in-law, sign on his behalf for his capital declaration. In 1795, François Courtener and the Gay brothers conducted a joint operation: they announced the launch of a subscription to [Jean-Jacques Bouvier Lionnais], Traité de la mythologie, orné de cent quatre vingt gravures en taille douce; à l’usage des jeunes gens de l’un et de l’autre sexe. Par m. l’abbé Lyonnois, t. 1-2, chez F. Courtener, 1795, in-8°. The illustrations were published separately: Collection des 180 figures pour la mythologie, Moscow, chez F. Courtener, s.a. In the preface, the publisher states that this is a reprint of the 1788 edition from Nancy. This book was sold at Courtener’s on Nikolskaya Street in Moscow, and at the Gay brothers and Klostermann in Saint Petersburg. However, other editions by Courtener are probably false editions:
  • Julie, Nouvelle / Translated from the Russian of Mr. Karamzin by M. de Boulliers, Moscow, Chez F. Courtener, 1797, [4], 51 p., in-12° (according to the notes of S.D. Poltoratski on this copy, the book was published in Hamburg; p. 1 contains a poem composed by the translator and dedicated to Karamzin) [National Library of Russia reference: Rossica, 13.16.8.81]. Could the translator be Denis de Bouliers, originally from Avignon, who resided in the 19th arrondissement of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793? This translation served as the basis for several other translations of this short story by Karamzin: Mr. Karamzin’s Julia translated from the Russ (sic!) into French by Mr. du Boulliers and from the French in to English by Ann P H, St. Petersburg, 1803.
In 1797, continuing to expand his network, Courtener tried to form an international company: a testament to this attempt was the release of a catalog titled «Note de livres nouveaux et autres, en vente chez Pierre Courtener, libraire à Basle, et chez François Courtener, libraire à Moscou». His relative in Basel soon spoke about the release of his catalog in Moscow: (November 1797, Gazette de Berlin): «Pierre Courtener and Company have the honor to announce to the Booksellers of Germany and the North, as well as to gentlemen lovers of good literature, both ancient and modern, that they have just established their bookstore in this city. Numbers 1 to 10 of their new catalogs are now available; they can be obtained as well as the continuation in Leipzig at J.H. Muller and Co., in Copenhagen at the King’s, and in Moscow at François Courtener. Basel, November 1, 1797». During the French Revolution, François Courtener also sold revolutionary publications. In February 1802, he founded a trading company in Paris under the name «Courtener, Rebannier et Co», which was responsible for commissions related to the purchase of books. It was also in 1802 that Courtener, under the pressure of commercial constraints, transferred his bookstore to the house of Prince Nikolai Alexeyevich Golitsyn (1751-1809, groom, senator, Russian ambassador to Sweden, private counselor), on Bolshaya Lubyanka Street: his son-in-law Jean Gautier-Dufayer followed him there. In 1804, Courtener sold his bookstore to Gautier-Dufayer and opened a seed store, still in the house of Prince Golitsyn on Bolshaya Lubyanka Street: on the first floor was his son-in-law’s bookstore, and on the ground floor was a furniture workshop. However, he continued his activities as a bookseller and publisher: in 1804–1805, he published Le Nouveau plan de Moscou, Aux dépens de F. Courtener / First-class proof / Sold in Moscow by I. Gautier, [Moscow, 1805], with index, 29 p., 1:10500. In 1807, a reissue of this plan, 2nd ed. / Sold in Moscow by the Brothers Courtener, booksellers (catalog available at , consulted in February 2007). Having founded in 1805 a bookstore «Les frères Courtener» for his sons François and Antoine, who returned to Russia after studying abroad, he sold his seed store and dedicated himself to creating a «Musée de lecture» for two hundred people, which opened on 1806-08-20, initially offering nearly 20,000 books to its readers. This was the first enterprise of its kind and scale in Moscow. He attempted to make this «musée» a center for business and commercial information. In 1806, following changes in Russian legislation, François Courtener became naturalized «with his wife Marie and his sons François, Antoine, and Théodore». By 1807, his bookstore, known as a «musée de lecture», unlike Lemoine’s «reading cabinet», was still located on Bolshaya Lubyanka Street in a house belonging to the same Prince Golitsyn. In 1811, it was found in the house of the Medical-Surgical Academy near the Blacksmiths’ Bridge.

Education:
In 1803, Théodore Courtener left Moscow to study in Strasbourg. He was partly raised in the home of the parents of the novelist Lajechnikov and partly in that of the Princes Cherkasski.
In 1811, he passed an examination at Moscow University and received certification to teach French, German, and mathematics.
Career:
Librarian and Teacher. In 1806, he became a Russian subject like the rest of his family. He entered the service at the Medical-Surgical Academy as an assistant librarian in 1811 but resigned on 1812-07-03.
In 1816, he joined the technical drawing workshop directed by Major General Carbonier. He was assigned as a junior employee to military and labor battalions for the construction of civil buildings but resigned in 1821. He taught French at the Alexandre School since 1817, at the House of Education from 1818, at the Alexandre Institute, and at the Institute of Oriental Languages from 1832. In 1830, he became the second French lecturer at Moscow University, where he remained until 1848. He was awarded diamond rings twice in 1835 and was decorated with the Orders of Saint Stanislaus, 4th class, and Saint Anne, 3rd class. Appointed State Counselor in 1852, he received insignia for twenty-five years of impeccable service. Since 1848, he had been receiving a lifetime pension of 857 silver rubles.
Teaching institutions and families: Alexandre School (from 1817); House of Education (from 1818), Alexandre Institute; Institute of Oriental Languages (from 1832); Moscow University (1830–1848).

Personal records: (born Grünberg) (*1750, Narva). German native. Father: a musician. Married to: Cruz, the artist; marriage concluded in 1775; the husband left her with two children three years later. Religion: Lutheran?
Career:
She lived in Saint Petersburg from 1775 onwards and spoke Russian fluently.
In 1778, she opened a school in Millionnaya Street in the house of the valet Popov. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences checked the school in April 1780 and stated that there were 18 children (seven boys and 11 girls) aged from 7 to 12 years old. The Commission noted that the school premises consisted of two rooms which were cramped but clean. The school had two teaching assistants: Johann Christian Horn, a 25-year-old German from Elbingen, and Peter Kalesin, a 20-year-old nobleman from Novgorod. The children were taught to read, write and understand German, Russian and French; they also learn the fundamentals of arithmetic. The documents of the Commission on the Establishment of Public Schools (or “Commission to Establish Public Schools”) issued in December 1784 do not mention the school as a working one.
Teaching institutions and families: Private school in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records:
(or Dorbeil)
Most likely originally from Orbeil, in Puy-de-Dôme, near Issoire.
Career: Poet and pamphleteer, professor. He was in Saint Petersburg around 1786 and collaborated with Mercure de Russie, a literary review founded and directed by Gallien de Salmorenc (8 issues published). Cuinet d’Orbeil refers to himself as «professor of belles lettres at the Imperial Cadet Corps» (Cours mémorial de géographie..., 1789) or «professor of history and the French language» at the same institution (La reconnaissance..., 1789). Around 1792, he was among the professors at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. At that time, he was received into the high society of Petersburg. For a derogatory remark made during a celebration at Peterhof regarding King Louis XVI, who was then imprisoned, he was taken from his hotel and thrown into the hold of a ship. He escaped by jumping into the sea, according to Major Masson. The French envoy Genet was concerned about the fate of D’Orbeil and other Frenchmen in Russia who were in the same situation and suffered from the «malice of the émigrés» (see also Agé, Mioche).
Teaching institutions and families: Imperial Cadet Corps; Academy of Fine Arts

  • Justine-Sophie Cuvillier (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic church on 1765-09-07; godfather: Jean Bering; godmother: Justine Fesser);

  • Charles Cuvillier (Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1769-12-31).
Religion: Catholic.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, arithmetic, geometry, history, mythology.
Career:
Tutor and painter. Jean Cuvillier passed an examination at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg and received a certificate on 1757-07-16, authorizing him to teach French, Latin, history, and geography. He joined an educational boarding school where he taught French, Latin, arithmetic, and geometry. He later became the director of a boarding school himself. He was mentioned as a commissioner of the imperial lottery in the marriage contract of Vendredy/Duval on 1760-12-24/1761-01-04, in Saint Petersburg.
He then began working as a painter at the tapestry factory run by Bressan, a favorite of Grand Duke Peter, who would later become Peter III. He was introduced to Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov, a favorite of the Empress, and received a position as a French teacher at the college of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg, replacing Professor Du Boulaye du Thé, who had just been dismissed, with an annual salary of 300 rubles. He committed to teaching French, history, geography, and mythology. At the same time, he was employed as the Academy’s secretary for correspondence with foreign academicians and for maintaining academic records. He became an inspector at the Academy College in 1763.
His tasks were varied: overseeing the uniform for the governesses at the Academy of Fine Arts, purchasing cows, oats, and hay for the College, adjusting the price of student breakfasts, and monitoring the health of the students (he reported cases of smallpox at the Academy to the Council). In February 1764, he rented an apartment on Vasilievsky Island, in the first line. The Russian poet Sumarokov described him as: «a beast and ill-mannered, unmatched in Russia».
Cuvillier incurred significant debts: by the end of the 1760s, they amounted to 7815 rubles, an enormous sum for the time, and he had ninety-six creditors! The Academy of Fine Arts did not want to lose a valuable employee and appointed a tutor for him, the deputy rector of the Academy, the famous architect Vallin de La Mothe. It was decided to deduct 1100 rubles from Cuvillier’s salary (1600 rubles per year) to be paid to the creditors each year. The Academy eventually announced to his creditors that they should no longer trust him. Cuvillier also had numerous disputes with Russian merchants.
In 1767, the director of the Institute for Noble Girls, Madame de Lafond, proposed transferring Cuvillier to the Noble Cadet Corps. It was certainly due to his numerous abuses of power and debts that he obtained in 1767 permission for his wife to replace him in his position during his absence. In 1772, he admitted a certain Pierre (or Petr) Cuvillier as a copyist at the Academy, likely a relative, probably his son (see below).
He was dismissed on 1771-03-07, with a pension of 350 rubles: the Academy continued to pay his debts until 1779 when he found a position at the Noble Cadet Corps.
He was the godfather of Jeanne-Françoise-Catherine Godfrin on 1769-01-18, at the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Educational boarding school; College of the Academy of Fine Arts (till 1771); Noble Cadet Corps (from 1779), all in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records: (1771-10-06 – 1846-06-17, Ternopil, Austrian Empire) Religion: Catholic.
Education: Józef Cytowicz became a member of the Society of Jesus on August 14, 1792 and studied for a year in the Polatsk novitiate. From 1796 to 1798, he studied in the philosophy class at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium, where he also studied theology for four years, from 1799 to 1803.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; Latin grammar; Russian; mathematics; chemistry; natural history; astronomy; architecture.
Career:
Priest. In 1793–1794, Józef Cytowicz taught Latin grammar and Russian at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium. He worked in the same position at the Vitsebsk Jesuit Collegium from 1794 to 1795. During the following academic year (1795–1796), Cytowicz taught Latin grammar and German at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium. In between studying in the philosophy and theology classes at the Polatsk Collegium, he taught German (1798–1799), and later (1810–1811) architecture and Russian at the same collegium. After graduating from the collegium in Polatsk, he was sent to Saint Petersburg, where he was first the seminary inspector (1803–1806), and later a mathematics and German teacher (1806–1810) at Saint Petersburg Collegium Nobilium. In 1810, Cytowicz left the capital. He taught chemistry, natural history (1813–1815), mathematics, astronomy and architecture (1818–1820) at the Polatsk Academy, founded in 1812. From 1815 until the closing of the Academy, Cytowicz was the dean of the Faculty of Philosophy; from 1818 he was also the dean of the Faculty of Liberal Sciences.
He was in a Jesuit mission in Romanov, Volhynian Governorate, for a few months in 1811–1812. After the dissolution of the Society in Russia, he was the rector of the Ternopil Jesuit Collegium (1831–1833).

Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; Latin rhetoric; poetics; Latin literature.
Career:
Priest. Stanisław Czerski began his teaching career at the Vitsebsk Jesuit Collegium, where he taught German, rhetoric and poetics in 1796–1798 and 1800–1801. While studying philosophy in Polatsk, he taught German for a year (1798–1799). During the academic year 1801–1802, he taught German, rhetoric and poetics at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium. Then he returned to Polatsk, where he taught (till 1806) the same disciplines as he did later at the Orsha Collegium in 1806–1810. During the academic year 1810–1811, Czerski worked as head of the library at the Vitsebsk Jesuit Collegium. Then his name disappeared from the records of the Society of Jesus. It is clear that he was no longer a member of the society. Nearly nothing is known about his life between 1812 and  1815, Czerski returned to teaching and worked as a teacher of Latin language and literature at the Vilnius Grammar School until 1819.
For ten years, Czerski was a priest in various dioceses of the Lithuania-Vilna Governorate. From 1821 to 1825, he was a canon of the diocese of Vilnius in the city of Varniai, and from 1825 to 1831 – a canon of the diocese of Samogitia in the city of Salantai.

Languages and other subjects taught by t: French; Russian; Latin grammar; Latin rhetoric; poetics.
Career:
Priest. Between studying philosophy and theology at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium, Andrzej Czyż taught Latin grammar, rhetoric, poetics and Russian at the same collegium (1786–1791). After graduation from the Polatsk Collegium, he taught Russian, poetics and rhetoric (1794–1795), as well as French at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium (1795–1798). Later he had an administrative job: in the academic year 1798–1799, Czyż was the Prefect of the Jesuit schools in Vitsebsk; he held the same position for one year (1799–1800) in Mstsislaw and for two years (1800–1802) in Polatsk. After the opening of the Jesuit houses in Saint Petersburg, he was transferred to the capital. First he was head of the student hostel (1803–1806), and then rector of Saint Petersburg Collegium Nobilium from 1806 until the closing of the collegium in 1815.
In 1813–1816, Andrzej Czyż worked as Assistant to the Superior General of the Society of Jesus.
Teaching institutions and families: Polatsk Jesuit Collegium; Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy; nobility; urban lower and middle class.

Scholastic.

Personal records: (Daniłewicz, Gawriił) (*1716, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth). He was born into a meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; Polish; elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar.
Career: All we know concerning Gavriil Danilevich is that in the academic year 1744–1745, while still a student, he taught in the analogy class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the academic year 1744–1745, there were 256 students in the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy where Gavriil Danilevsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class) in which Gavriil Danilevich taught. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. Personal records: (*Russian Empire) Religion: Orthodox.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar.
Career: The only thing we know concerning Stefan Davidov is that he was a teacher in the classes known as “phara” (analogy class) and “infima” at the Chernihiv Collegium in 1767–1768.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1767–1768).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1767–1768 school year, 46 students were enrolled in the analogy (phara) and infima classes in which Stefan Davidov taught. In total, 213 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium that year. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. In the academic year 1767–1768, out of the 46 students enrolled in the analogy (phara) and infima classes taught by Stefan Davidov, 28 were children of “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) in which Stefan Davidov taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. Stefan Davidov also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. When Stefan Davidov worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at that time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Chernihiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. (1730-05-25, Paris – 1804, Paris) Father: Jean De Velly. Married to: Louise-Françoise Rolland (on 1756-12-08, at the Catholic Church in Saint Petersburg; witnesses: Count de Castelli; François Le Prince, gilder, brother of the painter). Children:
  • Louise-Catherine De Velly, alive in 1793;
  • Marie-Agrippine-Louise De Velly (*1760-03-04, Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic Church; godfather: Louis Rolland, sculptor; godmother: Thérèse Valeriani, probably from the family of Giuseppe Valeriani, painter in the service of Elizabeth), alive in 1793;
  • Alexandre-François-Agrippine-Armand De Velly (*1761-06-27, Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic Church; godfather: Alexandre de Bressan, brigadier, favorite of Peter III; godmother: Agrippine Bastidion);
  • Agrippine-Joseph De Velly (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic Church 1762-06-30; godfather: Joseph Raimbert, a prominent French merchant in Saint Petersburg; godmother: Agrippine Valeriani, born Bastidion, probably from the family of Giuseppe Valeriani, painter in the service of Elizabeth);
  • Alexandre-Jean De Velly (*1763-11-25, Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic Church; godfather: Alexandre de Bressan; godmother: Jeanne Rondet);
  • Louise-Henriette-Marie De Velly (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic Church on 1766-12-16; godfather: Louis Rolland, sculptor; godmothers: Henriette Rolland, Caroline De Velly);
  • Jean-Alexandre-François De Velly (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1768-06-22; godfather: Alexandre Andreyevich, Russian colonel; godmother: Dame Anna Chione);
  • Pulchérie De Velly, alive in 1793;
  • Élisabeth De Velly, living in Moscow in 1798;
  • Thérèse De Velly, living in Saint Petersburg in 1793.
Career:
Painter, draftsman, and portraitist. He moved to England in 1754 and then to Russia (before 1756-12), where he painted a ceiling titled "Entrance of the Emperor of China" at the Tsarskoye Selo Palace in 1756. From 1759-03 to 1760-12, he held the position of painting instructor at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. In 1759, he signed a one-year contract: "Jean Louis De Velly, painter, from Paris, has engaged […] as a painter for Moscow University, attached to the Academy of Arts established in Petersburg." He committed to giving public and private lessons, working for the court, and leaving a painting of his choice at the Academy as a "token of his art." De Velly took the place of Le Lorrain at the Academy of Fine Arts, who had just died, but a year later he ceded it to Lagrenée the Elder. He organized the plaster model drawing class with N.-F. Gillet and, starting in 1760, the live model class (the Hermitage Museum preserves a drawing by De Velly).
However, he did not leave Russia and continued to paint ceilings and execute portraits. Three portraits painted by De Velly date from the late 1750s: P. Rotari painting the portrait of Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov (ar. 1756, Hermitage Museum), Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov (before 1758, Russian Museum), and the merchant J. Stelling (1759, Hermitage Museum). During the coronation festivities of Empress Catherine II in Moscow, De Velly, then under the protection of Grigori Grigorievich Orlov (1734–1783), the empress's favorite, made sketches of the main moments of the coronation. On 1763-02-11, he signed a contract that made him a court artist with the task of executing the drawings for the coronation. He completed this work with Mikhail Ivanovich Makhayev, a draftsman from the Academy of Sciences, in 1763 in Moscow and then from 1763 to 1767 in Saint Petersburg: a drawing of the attributes of the Empire by De Velly and fifteen drawings in which the foreground was executed by De Velly and the architectural background by Makhayev have been preserved (Hermitage Museum).
He was also the author of portraits of Empress Elizabeth and drew Catherine II, as well as Grand Duke Paul Petrovich as a child (1765). He also painted portraits of Count Burkhard Christoph Münnich (1764), Prince Grigori Orlov, the brothers Alexei and Grigori Orlov in Moscow during the plague, Count Adam Vasilievich Olsufiev, a senator, current private counselor, and secretary of State for Catherine II (1775), Count Alexei Ivanovich Musin-Pushkin, future president (ober-prokuror) of the Holy Synod, president of the Academy of Fine Arts, and discoverer of the Tale of Igor's Campaign, and Prince Alexander Borisovich Kurakin, chancellor of the Russian orders, current private counselor, and member of the State Council (1779). Some of his portraits were reproduced in engravings by Evgraf Petrovich Chemesov. Among his achievements, his beautiful self-portrait should be mentioned.
In the 1760s and early 1770s, De Velly and his family lived in a house they owned on Vasilievsky Island, between lines 13 and 14. De Velly frequented a fairly wide circle of acquaintances, including the famous engraver E. P. Chemesov, for whom he painted a portrait, as well as foreign artists such as gilder François Le Prince and painter Giuseppe Valeriani, etc.
De Velly reportedly presented a petition to the empress during a posing session and narrowly escaped deportation to Siberia. According to other sources, he undertook a journey to Siberia. Upon his return, he entered into a dispute with merchant Keller. Driven by poverty, he began teaching drawing at the Academy of Sciences in Petersburg starting in 1779, where he remained for a year. From this time dates the last known drawing by De Velly, Portrait of A. V. Kurakin (probably Alexander Borisovich Kurakin, chancellor of the Russian orders, current private counselor, and member of the State Council), which was later engraved. In 1793, De Velly was said to be a court painter, and at least three of his daughters were then alive and residing in Saint Petersburg. Like all other French nationals, he took the oath of 1793. He was described in his death certificate as "painter to Empress Elizabeth Petrovna."
His wife was the godmother on 1759-05-18, at the Catholic Church in Saint Petersburg of Alexandrine-Louise-Pierre-Marguerite Du Boulay du Thé.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (1759–1760), Academy of Sciences (from 1779), all in Saint Petersburg.

(*Dun-sur-Meuse). Father: Pierre I Deforges. Brother: Pierre II Deforges. Sister: Marie-Suzanne Deforges-Duvivier. Married to: Marie-Madeleine Petrovitz. Children:
  • Alexandre Deforges (*Moscow, bapt. in Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul on 1786-08-27; godfather: Alexandre Shishkoff; godmother: Marguerite Certellet);
  • Pierre III (Piotr Ivanovitch) Deforges (†1835), naturalized Russian, served in the 2nd department of the Justice Chamber in Moscow in 1809 as a kantseliarist; in 1834, major of a railway engineering detachment, he was promoted to the rank of colonel in 1835; married to Maria Semenovna N., he had: Alexandra (*ar. 1826), Elizaveta (*ar. 1827), Ivan (*ar. 1832), Érasme (*ar. 1835).
Career:
Tutor. Jean Deforges arrived in Russia in 1760 with his father. He passed the examination required for foreign tutors at Moscow University and was shortly thereafter admitted as a professor of German and French at the Gymnasium (school) of Kazan, affiliated with Moscow University. In 1764, he informed the office of the Foreign Affairs College in Moscow that his father had died. At that time, Jean Deforges was living with the captain of the reserve guard, Sergei Vasilievich Sheremetiev, as a tutor.
However, he had just taken leave and intended to return to France for personal matters, accompanied by his sister-in-law Élisabeth Deforges and his niece Catherine Duvivier, daughter of the former court cook Joseph Duvivier. It was Antoine Berlire, a merchant of the 1st guild in Moscow, who guaranteed him. On July 30 of the same year, they received a passport to travel to Saint Petersburg: upon arrival, they were to present themselves at the office of the Foreign Affairs College.
Jean Deforges returned from France the same year. But in 1766-08, he again requested permission to leave Moscow for France. He was still a French tutor. He was to take with him to France Jean, the eleven-year-old son of the late Benjamin Roger, a French merchant. He was guaranteed by Prince Nikolai Sergeevich Dolgorukov, and the boy by his mother Anne Roger. The passport was issued to them on August 10.
He passed through Saint Petersburg in 1792-01 and 1792-02 and stayed with Baron Sollogub. He was still living in Moscow in the II district when he took the oath in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Gymnasium (school) of Kazan, affiliated with Moscow University.

(*ar. 1690, Paris – between 1762-03 and 1764-07) Children:
  • Pierre II Deforges (*1714);

Career:
French teacher in Moscow. In 1762-03, he informed the office of the Foreign Affairs College in Moscow that he had received a passport in Versailles on 1759-07-13, along with his son Jean, that they had left France for Hamburg (where he had been a roaster), and that in 1760 they had departed for Russia with a passport issued by the Russian envoy Sergei Vasilievich Saltykov (1726–1813) (original of the passport in the file). They lived in Saint Petersburg and Moscow, where his son Pierre and daughter Marie-Suzanne had been since at least 1752.
Having only the 1759 passport (which moreover lacked Saltykov's signature) and wishing to settle permanently in Russia, Deforges requested permission to establish himself there. He received the guarantee of Major of Engineers Prince Vladimir Sergeevich Dolgorukov, who praised the kindness and honesty of this family. It turns out that the prince had known the Deforges previously, during his studies in Paris. In 1762, Pierre Deforges did not yet speak Russian; the residence permit was issued to him in 1762-03.

Personal records:
(or Desforges, Deforger, De Forge) (*ar. 1714, Zorliant ?, France). This family still exists in Russia. It is certainly not by chance that the principal hero of Alexander Pushkin’s novel «Dubrovsky» is concealed under the identity of a French preceptor named Deforges: the family, certainly in its early days, devoted itself to education and teaching in Russia. Father: Pierre Deforges; Siblings: Marie Suzanne Duvivier and Jean Deforges. Married to: Elisabeth Vispolski (*Vilnius), a Frenchwoman, living in Moscow in 1793, a governess; marriage concluded in 1762 in Moscow. Children:
  • Jean Deforges (*ar. 1765, no doubt in Moscow); his father sent him to France to study in 1779, entrusting him to French people returning to France, among them François Pinay, preceptor; Jean Deforges remained there for several years;
  • Anne (*ar. 1777, no doubt in Moscow).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: English; French; German; geography; history; mathematics; geometry.
Career:
Preceptor and head of a boarding-school in Moscow.
In 1745 he left his native town for Travemunde, no doubt with his sister. From there he travelled to Saint Petersburg, then Moscow where he was to be found in 1752 at the latest. Indeed, it was in October 1752 that he was accused of incest with his sister Marie-Suzanne. The denunciation written by Du Boulaye, a language teacher, and Joseph Duvivier, a cook, husband of Marie-Suzanne, was sent to the Catholic church in Moscow and gave rise to an ecclesiastical enquiry.  
Around the year 1780, Deforges was living in the 11th district of Moscow, in a house belonging to the University of Moscow, home of the Frenchman Français Baudouin, professor of the university.  Baudouin ran a boarding-school and Deforges helped him with language teaching for the younger pupils. At the time he had in his possession a certificate from the university authorising him to work as a teacher. 
At the beginning of the 1780s he himself founded a boarding-school in Moscow. This establishment was attended by twenty-five children, only boys, for the price of 150 roubles per year. At the time Deforges had in his possession a certificate from the Catholic church. The school was opened with the authorisation of the university of Moscow. The commission which controlled this establishment, just as it did the others, noted that there was no religious instruction and some pupils did not even know the Credo. Moreover, the pupils’ results were somewhat mediocre, whether in French, geography, history, arithmetic or in geometry, «non-existent» in both German and Russian.
Teaching institutions and families: Baudouin’s boarding-school; Deforges’ boarding-school, all in Moscow.
Authors: Vladislav Rjéoutski, information from Svetlana Turilova

Personal records: (De France; †before 1765-01). Married to: 1.) Marguerite Lemi, or Lemir; 2.) Victoire-Angélique de Chardelle. Daughter from the 1st marriage: Geneviève-Dorothée Defrance (*1725-06-19, Rouen, bapt. Saint-Eucaire 8; godfather: Nicolas Evrad; godmother: Françoise Gillet, †1791-02-07, Paris - †1791-03-22, Poissy), wife of Nicolas-François Gillet; Son from the 2nd marriage: Adrien-Paul-Nicolas-François Defrance (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at the Catholic Church on 1757-07-18; godfather: Nicolas-François Gillet, sculptor).
Career: Architect and member of the Academy of Sciences of Rouen, he worked on the main churches of this city starting in 1719 and was the author of the fountain of the Gros Horloge and the abbey of Saint-Ouen. Present in Saint Petersburg since at least 1755, he opened the same year an exhibition, a "theater of mechanical figures," in the house of Count Shuvalov (probably Count Piotr Ivanovich Shuvalov, an influential Russian statesman) on the Street of Italians in Saint Petersburg. He was mentioned on 1756-01-16, in the Sanktpeterburskiye Vedomosti as a machinist residing in Saint Petersburg, on Malaya Morskaya Street. In 1763, Defrance was admitted, likely with the support of his son-in-law N.-F. Gillet, to the Academy of Fine Arts of Saint Petersburg: "I, the undersigned Jean Pierre de France of the Academy of Sciences of Rouen, hereby commit myself to the service of Her Majesty the Empress of All Russia to demonstrate in her Academy of Arts, under the orders of His Excellency Monseigneur the Chamberlain of Beskoy [Ivan Betskoy – ed. note], General Director of Buildings, Arts, and Manufactures throughout the Empire of Russia, the various parts of Mechanics listed below. To wit [followed by a long enumeration of the disciplines that De France was capable of teaching]...". Defrance committed for three years with the enviable annual salary of 1,000 rubles. In 1765-01, his widow Angélique Defrance requested the Academy of Fine Arts to pay the remaining salary of her deceased husband.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (from 1763; Saint Petersburg).

Career: Tutor. He arrived in Russia in 1789. Teaching French at the Corps of Noble Cadets of the Navy in 1798, he resigned the same year, leaving his class to the Russian professor Chijov. Delabelle taught twenty-four hours a week for 450 rubles a year. Chijov, on the other hand, taught twelve hours with a remuneration of only about 150 rubles a year, likely because he was neither a native of France nor very experienced. Delabelle resided in the house of a Naryshkin, State Councillor, on Line 8 of Vasilievsky Island, and his rent amounted to 75 rubles a year.
Teaching institutions and families: Corps of Noble Cadets of the Navy (1798; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (ar. 1759, Normandy – 1799-12-29, Saint Petersburg; died of consumption; buried on the 30th in the Smolenskoye cemetery on Vasilievsky Island). Father: Joseph Delamotte.
Career:
Professor of French at the Corps of Noble Cadets of the Navy, he resigned in 1783. He was deprived of a bonus of 50 rubles due to the mediocre results of his students. He received 75 rubles to cover his housing expenses. He lodged with Nicolas Ferdel (?), College Councillor, on Line 7 of Vasilievsky Island. He later became a French professor at the school of the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg, where he was admitted on 1799-03-10, with an annual salary of 300 rubles (upon his death, he was replaced by Abbé Deslonde). He was residing in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath of 1793.
A Freemason, he was a member, then an honorary member (in 1780–1781) of the Neptune Lodge in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Corps of Noble Cadets of the Navy (till 1783); School of the Academy of Sciences (1799), all in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records:
(Delapière)
Originally from Burgundy.

At that time, he was residing in the house of General Field Marshal Prince Nikita Iurievich Trubetskoy (1699–1767), President of the College of War, Attorney General of the Senate, a cultured man and friend of literary figures A. Personal records:
(in Russia: Piotr Petrovich; *1780s) Father: Pierre-Michel Deleau. Mother: Thérèse N. Married to (on 1833-02-03): Anna Nikolayevna Kunina, daughter of Nikolay Kunin. Children:
  • Vladimir Deleau (*1833-11-09; godmother: the wife of the titular councillor Pavel Petrovich Deleau, brother of Piotr Petrovich Deleau);
  • Olga Deleau (*1842-05-24; godmother: Varvara Deleau, daughter of the titular councillor Pavel Petrovich Deleau, her uncle);
  • Paul or Pavel Deleau (*1843-05-10).
Religion: converted Orthodox.
Education: He completed his studies at the Noble Gymnasium affiliated with Moscow University.
Career:
Official. He entered the service of the Senate in 1804, where he served as a clerk (1805) and registrar (1808); in 1810, he was transferred to the department of the Ministry of Justice and the same year to the leading Senate department. Secretary of the government in 1811, he became a protocol officer the same year, a college secretary in 1814, and a titular councillor in 1817. By 1827, he was a secretary in a Senate department. In 1831, he resigned due to illness to become a secretary at the Committee of the Crafts School of the Moscow Foundling Hospital, where he remained until 1852. He was appointed a college assessor in 1840.
A Knight of the Order of Saint Anne, 3rd class, in 1824, of Saint Vladimir, 3rd class, in 1831, and of Saint Stanislaus, 2nd class, in 1839, he received insignia for 20, 25, 30, and 35 years of impeccable service.
In 1852, pursuant to the Senate ukase of 1840, he was ennobled and registered in the first part of the nobility register of the Moscow government along with his wife and children.

Personal records:
(*1755-07-24, Verquigneul, France; bapt. the same day; godfather: Auguste-Jean-Baptiste Delesalle; godmother: Albertine Françoise Gottran). Father: Philippe-Auguste Delesalle. Mother: Marie-Anne-Josèphe Lemaire. Married to: 1.) N. Müller; 2.) Louis-Noël de Forceville (on 1790-12-14 at Saint Louis of the French in Moscow), son of Claude-Eustache de Forceville and Marie-Geneviève Mailliard (witnesses: Jean De Bosse, Vice-Consul of France in Moscow, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle, Félix de Forceville, Jacques Le Doulx, and Louis Soulages). Children from the 2nd marriage:
  • Jean de Forceville (*1792);
  • Nicolas-Alexis de Forceville (1796).
She was the godmother of Alexandrine Delesalle, daughter of Gabriel-Hubert Delesalle and Suzanne Digault, on 1789-05-26, at the Catholic Church of Saints Peter and Paul in Moscow.
Education: Arriving with her family in Russia in the spring of 1765, she likely attended the Carbonnet boarding school, established for this purpose by order of the Empress, along with two of her sisters. The educational expenses for "the three young Delesalle girls of Her Imperial Majesty's cabinet" were covered by the treasury.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, reading, politeness, and good manners
Career:
Governess.
At the beginning of 1772, she and her father entered the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg as a governess. She sent the following letter to the Director of the Academy:
"Mr. Director of the Imperial Academy of Fine Arts,
The undersigned has the honor to offer her services to teach the French language, reading, politeness, and good manners, to oversee the conduct of the students entrusted to her care if she has the honor of filling the position of governess that is vacant at the educational college. She will do everything in her power to fulfill her duties and earn your esteem. I have the honor to be your humble and very obedient servant, Albertine Delesalle. In Saint Petersburg, January 20, 1772."
Her father and she were recommended by Nicolas-Gabriel Le Clerc, physician at the court and future historian of Russia: "I have been assured that Mr. Kakorinoff needs two subjects for the students of the Academy of Arts: if this is true, I believe that Mr. Delesalle and his daughter would be suitable for these positions. Their honesty and conduct since their arrival in Russia encourage me to recommend them to the kindness of Mr. Director, to whom I present my very humble respects. Le Clerc, physician to His Excellency the Grand Admiral and the Imperial Corps of Noble Cadets, January 18, 1772."
On 1772-05-02, both requested to be relieved of their duties. In the petition that Philippe-Auguste Delesalle submitted regarding this to the Director of the Academy, it was specified that Albertine was "too young to remain alone." It seems that her father was preparing to leave Saint Petersburg. Upon their dismissal, they were paid a severance of 320 rubles as annual salary. The Delesalle family settled in Moscow by at least 1777.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (1772; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records:
(*1751-08-12, Verquigneul, near Béthune, France; bapt. the same day in the church of Verquigneul; godfather: Mathias-Guislain-Joseph Leroy; godmother: Marie-Scholastique-Florice Delesalle). Father: Philippe-Auguste Delesalle. Mother: Marie-Anne-Josèphe Lemaire. Married to: Elisaveta N. Children:
  • Nicolas Delesalle;
  • Anne-Alexandra Delesalle, married to Jean-Louis Berng-Dubuc de Bruneau or Brimeau († after 1820) (see below).
Career: Tutor. He arrived with his parents and siblings in Russia in the spring of 1765. He was a witness on 1769-05-11, at the marriage contract of his sister Marie-Anne with Louis-Philippe Bachelier. He resided in the XIII district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793*. He then went to the Vladimir government and had to take the same oath again. He later moved to the Oryol region. In 1812, he was "a boarding school director and teacher." He owned his house in Moscow in 1812.

Personal records: (*Saint Petersburg or Moscow – †1851-05-23, Moscow) (bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1777-06-30, godfather: Dimitri Palibin). Father: Philippe-Auguste Delesalle. Mother: Alexandrine Rozet. Married to: Ekaterina Ivanovna Gregorius, daughter of a college secretary, a Lutheran (probably the sister of Iakov Ivanovich Gregorius, rector of the German school of Peter and Paul in Moscow, who taught languages for a time at the educational boarding school run by Sofia Delesalle). Son: Pierre (or Petr) Delesalle (*1821-04-05, bapt. Orthodox on April 13, Zubov near Moscow – †1876-03-04, buried at Danilov Monastery in Moscow), married to Varvara Ivanovna N., with whom he had three children.
Career: Professor, boarding school master. Dimitri Delesalle was in the Penza government when he took the oath in 1793. On 1793-10-13, he began working as a professor at the Noble Boarding School affiliated with Moscow University. In 1805, the Moskovskie Vedomosti published his announcement for the opening of his educational boarding school "here in Moscow in the Khamovnicheskaya part in the 3rd district in the parish of Saint Nicholas the Miracle Worker in the house of His Excellency Major General and Knight Anton Ivanovich Guérard." This boarding school was to accommodate twenty boys; subjects taught included mathematics, history, geography, French and German, drawing, dance, music, and "exercises." On 1814-01-24, he became a French teacher at the Moscow District School. In 1821, he was promoted to registrar. On 1824-03-24, he resigned from the university and on 1824-06-09 took up the post of French teacher at the School of Architecture under the Moscow Palace Office. Promoted to government secretary on 1825-06-05, college secretary on 1826-05-25, and titular counselor on 1830-04-16, he received a certificate to continue serving in the Senate. On 1826-09-28, he was awarded a diamond ring by the emperor, and on 1830-04-22, he received an excellence badge for his impeccable service over fifteen years, and on 1835-05-21, he was decorated with the Order of Saint Stanislaus, 4th class. Between 1814 and 1817, Dimitri Delesalle built a house in Moscow for his educational boarding school, which he owned until 1830 when it passed to the widow of Lieutenant Anna Kologrivova (this house still exists today at 15/2, Zubovski Boulevard, and is known as the "Delesalle House"). In 1830, the boarding school was moved to another building on Neopalimovski Lane, in the Khamovnicheskaya part of the city. This house belonged to the Khitrovo family and later passed to Dimitri Delesalle's son, the architect Piotr Dmitrievich Delesalle, who sold it to L. N. Belikova (this house now houses the editorial office of the magazine Nache nasledie [Our Heritage]). In 1842, this house was valued at 4,571 silver rubles. Dimitri Delesalle mortgaged it in 1850. Ekaterina Gregorius-Delesalle also owned a house in Moscow in the 2nd district of the Khamovnicheskaya part of the city. It was probably Dimitri Delesalle who served as the model for Dessal in Leo Tolstoy's novel War and Peace. In 1835, Dimitri Delesalle requested to be registered with his son Pierre (or Piotr) in the nobility register of the Moscow government under the Order of Saint Stanislaus, of which he had just been decorated, and on 1835-10-28, they were ennobled by a decision of the ruling Senate and entered into the 3rd part of the register.
Teaching institutions and families: Noble Boarding School affiliated with Moscow University (from 1793); his own educational boarding school in Moscow (1805–1830); Moscow District School (from 1814); School of Architecture under the Moscow Palace Office (from 1824).

Personal records: (or Nicolay Frolovich) Parents: Auguste-Florice and Élisabeth Delesalle. Married. Son: Alexandre Delesalle (*1818 - †1882, Stavropol 1882), married to Favetina Knotté, with whom he had two children.

Personal records:
(*before 1725, Athies, a village located five kilometers from Arras, Pas-de-Calais – †after 1793). Father: Jean-Baptiste Delesalle (*1692 – †1756-10-19), a resident of Béthune, a rentier and provost of the Saint-Éloi brotherhood of that city. Mother: Marie-Josèphe Parent (*1695-12-25 - †1749-11-09). He had three sisters and one brother. Married to: 1.) (before 1751) Marie-Anne-Josèphe Lemaire; 2.) Alexandrine Rozet, possibly the daughter of Mme Rozet, born Germain. Children from the 1st marriage:
  • Auguste-Florice Delesalle (*1751-08-12, Verquigneul – †after 1820);
  • Augustine Delesalle, known as Justine (*1752-08-27, Verquigneul), Mme Alexis Jossot;
  • Marie-Anne Delesalle (1753–1790), Mme Louis-Philippe Bachelier, then Mme Piotr de Iagresti;
  • Hubert-Gabriel Delesalle (†1815-04-04, Moscow);
  • Albertine Delesalle (*1755-07-24), Mme Müller, then Mme Louis-Noël de Forceville;
  • Claire-Aldegonde Delesalle (*1756-09-19), Mme François-Hippolyte de Forceville;
  • Auguste Delesalle, born in France, arrived with his family in Russia in the spring of 1765 and died shortly thereafter;
  • Julien-Joseph Delesalle (*1758-02-20);
  • Pélagie Delesalle (*1759-03-16), Mme Joseph-Nicolas Hemmer;
  • Valentin-Joseph Delesalle (*1761-05-01);
  • Marie-Josèphe-Sabine, known as Sofia Delesalle (*1762-12-29 - †1816-02-05), Mme Pierre-Marie Dunoyer;
  • Adélaïde Delesalle.
Children from the 2nd marriage:
  • Marie Delesalle (*1772-02-17 – †1804-03-04, Moscow);
  • Marie-Adélaïde Delesalle (*Saint Petersburg; bapt. on 1774-01-09; godfather: Joseph-Julien Delesalle; godmother: Augustine Delesalle);
  • Élisabeth Delesalle, Mme François-Antoine Girardin, then Mme Iakov Evtikhievich Anichkov (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1775-11-03);
  • Louis-Dimitri Delesalle (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1777-07-30);
  • Ignace Delesalle (*1777-12-22, Moscow - †1849-10-30, Moscow).
Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Farmer-cultivator in Verquigneul near Béthune, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle experienced difficulties in his farming in 1763: his wheat froze, excessive rain ruined his crops, and many of his horses died. He had to part with his belongings, which were sold at auction in 1764, as he had not found a buyer beforehand.
Accompanied by his family and some relatives, he left France on 1765-01-08, and went to The Hague, where he met Count Alexandre Romanovich Vorontsov (1741–1805), the Russian minister plenipotentiary in the Netherlands, who facilitated his passage to Russia, following the directives of the Russian manifesto of 1763-07-23. An agreement among the Russian diplomats in Holland, Count Alexey Semionovich Musin-Pushkin (†1817), the Russian envoy in The Hague, and Count Vorontsov, was established for this sending on behalf of the treasury. However, the recruiter Meunier de Précourt persuaded Delesalle to change his mind, to sign a contract with him, and to depart at the expense of his company, with the commitment to settle in the colony founded by the three directors, Meunier de Précourt, Coulliette d’Hauterive, and De Bosse (or de Bof).
The group of colonists left The Hague and passed through Amsterdam, Lübeck, Saint Petersburg, and Oranienbaum. In Saint Petersburg, Delesalle, believing he had been cheated by the recruiters, complained to the Chancellery for the guardianship of foreigners and decided, along with part of his group, to settle in one of the state colonies. It was in Oranienbaum that the colonists composed the statutes of the company "Les Frères réunis", which provided for collective farming of the land in Ukraine. Frustrated and disappointed by the difficulties related to land allotment, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle sought to establish himself in Saint Petersburg. He had actually returned to France in 1766, at the urging of the Marquis de Bausset, and was imprisoned in Lille; he owed his release to the intervention of the intendant of Flanders, Lefèvre de Caumartin, who allowed him to return to Saint Petersburg.
Several of his children had been settled in Saint Petersburg since 1765: the three youngest were placed in a boarding school thanks to the protection of the Empress; three children were placed with Count Piotr Borisovich Sheremetyev (1713-1788), chief general, grand chamberlain, and immensely wealthy lord; two with General Balk; the eldest daughter with Mr. du Rocher; the eldest son kept the accounts for Ador, the court jeweler, and the youngest son kept them at the imperial porcelain factory; the older Delesalle children spoke Russian and German as early as 1767.
It was also in Saint Petersburg that in 1769 three of Delesalle's daughters "of the chamber of Her Imperial Majesty" were enrolled in the educational boarding school of Louis-Stanislas Carbonnet, founded by the Empress to educate the young girls of this family. It was also in Saint Petersburg that in 1772 Philippe-Auguste and his daughter Albertine took positions as governors at the Academy of Fine Arts, on the recommendation of Nicolas-Gabriel Le Clerc, a future historian of Russia. They left the Academy on 1772-05-02, and prepared to depart from Saint Petersburg, probably for Moscow.
The Delesalles are indeed mentioned in the list of the French colony in Moscow compiled by the French vice-consul in 1777: they are declared to be returning from the Volga colonies. In reality, they had never been there: this deception was intended to provide them, if necessary, with the protection of the French consul. Philippe-Auguste Delesalle went to Saint Petersburg on 1777-04-08, for the wedding of his daughter Aldegonde to François-Hippolyte de Forceville.
In 1779-05, Delesalle opened an educational boarding school in Saint Petersburg. This boarding school was located on the 8th "line" on Vasilievsky Island, near the Grand Prospect, in a house belonging to Lieutenant Soloviev. The boarding school had twenty-seven children (eighteen boys and nine girls), and there were also ten other students who attended only during the day. The premises were very spacious, with ten large, very clean rooms. It was a family boarding school because, out of the seven people who took care of the students, four belonged to the Delesalle clan: Philippe-Auguste himself, one of his sons, his daughter Claire-Aldegonde, and her husband, François-Hippolyte de Forceville.
Several subjects were taught there: French, German, Russian, arithmetic, geography, and embroidery for the girls. Delesalle and his relatives taught French for twenty-four to thirty hours a week. De Forceville taught geography, mythology, and history. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which examined this boarding school, concluded that its students had every chance of making progress in French and Russian, but not in the other subjects, and certainly not in German. The boarding school disappeared before the next inspection organized in 1784, probably because the Delesalles moved to Moscow.
Indeed, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle was the godfather of his grandsons Philippe-Alexandre Delesalle on 1784-09-26, and Philippe Delesalle on 1795-11-08, at the Catholic Church of Saints Apostles Peter and Paul in Moscow.
In the 1790s, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle was elected syndic of the French Catholic Church of Saint Louis in Moscow; he was a witness at the Delesalle-Saucier marriage on 1792-04-07. Philippe-Auguste Delesalle resided in the 5th district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (1772); his own educational boarding school (1779 – before 1784), all in Saint Peterburg.

Personal records: Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know concerning Dembitsky is that in 1762 he was a grammar class teacher at the Chernihiv Collegium.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1762).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1760s, more than 200 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class taught by Dembitsky. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Dembitsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Dembitsky worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at that time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Chernihiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises intended for the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: Father: Deschamps (†before 1762). Mother: Thérèse Palouard, living on rue Saint-Jacques, parish of Saint-Benoît in Paris. Married to: Guillaume Raoult, a French lecturer at Moscow University.
Career: Supervisor at the Smolny Institute for Young Girls in 1792. She resided in Saint Petersburg when she took the oath of 1793. She later became an inspector at the Smolny Institute. By a ukase dated 1797-01-16, Paul I granted her, for good and loyal services to the Institute, lifetime and hereditary enjoyment of the village of the imperial family of Mejnia and the village of Batova (Saint Petersburg government, district and canton of Rojdenstveno) with 170 and 21 serfs, their wives and children, and the adjacent lands and dependencies, respectively.
Teaching institutions and families: Smolny Institute (1790s; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: Originally from Metz.
Career: French teacher at the Vanderendé boarding school (?) in Moscow in 1792. French, Italian, arithmetic, drawing, and Russian grammar were taught there. The school had eight students, two boys and six girls, and four teachers, including a Frenchman, an Italian, a German, and a Russian. Languages and other subjects taught by t: French grammar; French syntax; translation; colloquial language.
Career: All we know about Pierre des Covettes is that, as a Frenchman by origin, he was invited to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, where he taught in the lower French class in 1784–1785.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1784–1785).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few students from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
At the time, the textbook compiled by Martyn Sokolovsky was used for teaching French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. It is obvious that Pierre des Covettes did not lack textbooks for students. He could use other French grammar books and lexicons, which were also available at the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library catalogue, it contained a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries (by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey) at the time. Rather short book descriptions do not make it possible to identify all the books accurately.

Personal records: Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Priest. Chaplain to the legation of Juigné (Le Clerc, Marquis de Juigné) in Russia. Before his departure, Chevalier de Corberon (Bourrée, Chevalier de Corberon), who was part of the same journey, inquired about him and received a note on 1775-06-14, from Duru, the chamberlain of Ambassador Durand de Distroff. It stated that abbot Desforges had previously come to Russia with Henriette-Françoise-Marie Foulon, Mme Jean-François Billiot, associated with the consul and merchant Raimbert, of whom she was the niece: he was not a priest at that time and worked as a tutor for the governor of Tsarskoye Selo, where he stayed for some time; he then returned to France.
During his second journey from Paris to Moscow from 1775-06-22 to 1775-08-12, he was not well regarded by Chevalier de Corberon (Bourrée, Chevalier de Corberon), who criticized him for having 'all the faults of his robe' and being 'sly, crawling, flattering on the surface, but arrogant, self-interested, and scheming underneath.' He also noted that he spoke Russian, which served him in his intrigues. He seems to have been the cause of Saint-Paul's disgrace in 1777.
According to Corberon, the Russian dignitaries did not like the abbot either: his manner of speaking and his appearance displeased the head of the Russian Foreign Affairs, Count Panin. Nevertheless, the abbot enjoyed the full confidence of the Marquis de Juigné. The abbot wished to become a Freemason and asked General Melissino to accept him into his lodge.
He officiated at the baptism on 1776-08-24/09-05, of Barthélemy-Louis-Michel de Lesseps, son of the consul of France in Russia, Martin de Lesseps.
Students and their social status: He was a tutor for the governor of Tsarskoye Selo.

Personal records: Born in Nancy. Married to: Marie-Angélique Pesé or Peté. Child: Charles-Jean-Marie Deville (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 1769-04-23; godfather: Jean-Louis Voille).
Career: Governor of the Smirnof children. "Master," present at the meeting of the lodge La Réunion des étrangers de l’Orient in Moscow on the 1st day of the 5th month of the year 5775 (1775). In 1782-07, he became a governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts.
Teaching institutions and families:
Smirnof family;
College of the Academy of Fine Arts (from 1782; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (De Villiers) (†1777-09-22/10-03, Moscow). Originally from Lorraine. Father: Charles-Joseph Devilliers, a doctor of medicine and former president of the Royal College of Medicine in Nancy. Mother: Marguerite Thirion (†1783-10-14, Nancy). He had a brother who settled in England. Married to (on 1771-07-17 in Moscow): Louise Marisal, daughter of Nicolas Marisal. Son: Jean Devilliers (*Moscow, bapt. on 1772-04-29), Catholic; a courier at the College of War, residing in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath of 1793.
Career:
Professor at Moscow University, he was in Saint Petersburg in 1757-08 and was preparing to depart for France with his servant Tretou. He lived on Millionnaya Street in the house of merchant Iberkampf. In 1770, he was again in Moscow and presented himself at Moscow University to take the examination for a tutor. He received his certificate on 1770-03-10, to teach French, Latin, history, and geography.
His widow was present in Moscow in 1784-11, where she was staying with Prince Golitsyn, near the Nikitski Gate.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University

Personal records: (*ar. 1749) (From a noble family). Father: Jean-Baptiste Dieudonné, intimate advisor to Prince Charles of Lorraine. Mother: Marie-Françoise Gravel (†before 1777). Married to: Sophie Humbert, daughter of Claude-François-Gaspard Humbert, a doctor of medicine in Warsaw, and of Marie Le Doux; marriage contract concluded on 1777-09-06, and registered in the chancellery of the consulate on 1778-05-04.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin, French, geography, history, calculation, laws, jurisprudence.
Career: Tutor, former lawyer at the parliaments of Nancy and Paris. He was in Saint Petersburg in 1773 because he intended to teach in Russia. In 1773-07, he requested to take an examination at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg in order to obtain the certificate of tutor: “Mr. Dieudonné, Esquire, Lawyer at the Parliaments of Paris and Nancy, Lieutenant Seneschal of Her Royal Highness Madame the Princess of Lorraine, Aunt of His Majesty the Emperor of the Romans, and His Intimate Advisor. He has the honor to present himself to the Imperial Academy of Sciences, to ask the gentlemen Academicians to grant him the grace of examining him, first, in the Principles of the Latin and French Languages, in all their parts. Secondly, on geography, history, and calculation. Thirdly, on laws, jurisprudence, and customs of all France. He dares to flatter himself that they will kindly honor him with their votes and at the same time grant him the certificate.” Dieudonné. He received the requested certificate. He was then appointed professor and librarian at the Land Corps of Noble Cadets.
Teaching institutions and families: Land Corps of Noble Cadets (Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (Siłwestr Daniłowicz) (1712, The regiment town of Hadiach, Russian Empire – 1767, Budischa village of Hlukhiv sotnia, Nizhyn Regiment, Russian Empire). He was born into the family of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Silvestr Dobryna studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. During his studies, he took monastic vows at the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; Polish; elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar and syntax.
Career: He began teaching in the analogy class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the academic year 1737–1738, while he was still a theology class student. Then he taught in the subsequent grammar classes: the poetics (1741–1743) and the rhetoric (academic year 1743–1744) classes. From 22 June 1744 onwards, he was hegumen at Saint Peter and Paul Monastery in Kyiv, from 1748 – hegumen at Saint Cyril's Monastery in Kyiv, and from 1749 on – hegumen at the Holy Spirit Monastery in Vilnius. From 1760 till his death, he served as archimandrite at Saint Peter and Paul Monastery.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. There were several dozen students in the grammar classes where Silvestr Dobryna taught. For example, in September 1740, there were 68 students in the grammar class taught by him. In total, more than 567 people studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in those years. Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there. For example, in September 1740, out of the 68 students enrolled in the grammar class taught by Silvestr Dobryna, 12 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class) in which Silvestr Dobryna taught. The teacher also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (1752, Domontiv town, Pereiaslav Regiment, Russian Empire – 1819-02-27, Pereiaslav, Russian Empire). Fiodor Domontovich was born into a Cossack family. Apparently it was while studying at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy that he changed his inherited family name (Reznik). Married to: Anastasia, daughter of Aleksei Prokhorovich, rector of the Holy Trinity church in Pereiaslav. Fiodor Domontovich’s daughter married the Pereiaslav Collegium teacher Iosif Kozachkovsky. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy from 1764 to 1774, including in the theology class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax.
Career: Immediately after graduation in 1774 he began teaching in the analogy class at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Then he was a teacher in subsequent grammar and syntax classes and later in poetics, rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes. He was ordained a priest but did not give up his teaching. He was a priest at the Holy Trinity church in Pereiaslav and a member of the Pereiaslav Consistory. From November 1797 onwards, he was protoiereus at the Cathedral of the Ascension in Pereiaslav. He was also the Prefect (1786–1802) and then the Rector (1802–1808) of the Collegium. According to his contemporaries, Fiodor Domontovich had a perfect command of Latin (he taught theology in Latin) and Ancient Greek. He left the Collegium in 1812 for health reasons.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1774–1775 school year, there were 54 students in the analogy class of the Pereiaslav Collegium where Fiodor Domontovich taught Latin. In total, 241 students were enrolled at the Collegium that year. The grammar and syntax classes had several dozen students in subsequent years. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So, in the 1774–1775 school year, out of 54 students in the analogy class taught by Fiodor Domontovich 16 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the analogy (phara) in which Fiodor Domontovich taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. In subsequent years, Fiodor Domontovich worked in grammar and syntax classes where he taught grammar and syntax rules, grammar analysis and translation. When Fiodor Domontovich worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions concerning sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by writings of Pereiaslav Collegium students, all of them had copies of the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records: Married, father of a daughter.
Career: French professor present in Saint Petersburg in 1760-04. He was preparing to leave the capital with his wife and daughter and announced their departure in the Sanktpeterburgskie Vedomosti, indicating their address: Vasilievsky Island, 1st Line, Semibratskoye Inn.

Career: Tutor. His passport was issued in Versailles in 1780. French governess at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. She resigned in 1772.

Career: Mechanic and clockmaker, he was admitted to Moscow University to take charge of the physics laboratory in place of Dumoulin on 1765-07-01. His salary was initially set at only 50 rubles; then on 1767-11-01, the university signed a contract with him assigning him to the position of mechanic with an annual salary of 100 rubles. In 1770, he was tasked with training two students. He was still in this position in 1780.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (from 1765 till at least 1780).

(or Drevetsky, Derevitsky) (*Russian Empire)
Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class.
Career: He became a priest after graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. All that is known concerning Stefan Drzewiecki is that he taught at the Pereiaslav Collegium: in the grammar and syntax classes in the academic year 1738–1739, and in the poetics and rhetoric classes in 1739–1740. In 1740, he was also the Prefect of the Collegium.

Clergy; Cossacks.

Personal records:
(or La Boulay du Thé, known as Du Boulay; or Alexis-Louis). Married to: Magdeleine Labeck. Children:
  • Louis Du Boulay du Thé (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic church on 1747-02-17; godfather: Count Mikhail Illarionovich Vorontsov, then vice-chancellor of the Empire; godmother: Mme Thanrin);
  • Alexandrine-Louise-Pierre-Marguerite Du Boulay du Thé (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. in the Catholic church on 1759-05-18; godfathers: Count Alexandre Sergeyevich Stroganov, future president of the Academy of Fine Arts and member of the State Council, and Prince Pyotr Khovansky, likely Pyotr Vasilievich Khovansky (*ar. 1723), chamberlain, son of the ober-president of the Main Magistrate Vasili Khovansky; godmothers: Louise De Velly, née Rolland, wife of the painter, and Marguerite Lieven).
Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Merchant, then tutor. Formerly an abbot, imprisoned for nine years in the Bastille by order of Cardinal Dubois and released on the condition that he return home. He left for Brussels, where he married a Catholic woman. Upon his arrival in Russia in 1744, he sold essences and liqueurs and taught Latin. He certainly was the one who wrote in 1752 in Moscow with Joseph Duvivier a letter to the fathers of the Catholic Church in Moscow denouncing Duvivier's wife and his brother Pierre Desforges for incest. He then served as governor in the house of Count Mikhail Illarionovich Vorontsov, who recommended him to Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov. From 1755 to 1757, Du Boulay taught French and mythology to students at the gymnasium of Moscow University. As he did not speak Russian, he sought the help of a Frenchman who spoke Russian and proposed Mathias Agia. He did not want, along with a few other tutors, to be under the authority of the rector of the University and claimed to have privileges over the other tutors, which was denied to him.
His class of "art students" was transferred in 1758 to the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg (his remuneration was set at 400 rubles per year). There, he also taught history and mythology. Dismissed in 1763 by Ivan Betskoy. He left Russia in 1763-09.
Teaching institutions and families:
Vorontsov family;
Gymnasium of Moscow University (1755–1757); Academy of Fine Arts (1758–1763; Saint Petersburg).
