Personal records:
(1746, Riom – 1814, Strasbourg).
Son of a confectioner.
Career:
Tutor. Forced to choose the profession of confectioner, which he did not like, and to marry a woman he did not love (1768), he got entangled in business, incurred debts, and failed in his studies in Lyon and Paris. He returned to Riom, then, on the advice of Dubreul, the director of the Riom post office, he left in 1776 to seek his fortune in Paris. Thanks to Gilbert Romme, another Riomois with whom he had studied in his youth, he found a job with Madame de Montesson. Later, it was again thanks to Romme that he was hired as secretary to Count Alexander Sergeyevich Stroganov, a senator, future president of the Academy of Fine Arts, and director of the Imperial Library, and the father of Paul Stroganov, a student of Gilbert Romme. Initially, Démichel was also tasked with preparing the catalog of the count's library and his natural history cabinet. Romme then recommended him as a tutor for Grigori Alexandrovich Stroganov, cousin of Paul Stroganov, Romme's student. According to one piece of information, this contract was amicably terminated on 1785-06-01.
Démichel left Paris in 1783-07 after long hesitations. His first stay in Russia lasted from 1783-09 to early 1785-07. In 1785, he settled with his student in Strasbourg, where he remained until the autumn of 1787. He was in Riom with Romme in June–July 1788, then in the south of France with his student, before returning to Paris around 1789-03. His second stay in Russia extended from 1789-06 to early 1790-02.
In Russia, he quickly joined Romme and settled under the same roof. He was, in a way, Romme's secretary, particularly responsible for conducting correspondence with Riom. This correspondence is characterized by strong self-censorship, as the author was fully aware of the dangers he faced. Démichel also kept a journal in which he entrusted his reflections on thorny subjects (such as the death of Peter III, etc.).
Indeed, the censorship of correspondence was a constant obsession for Démichel: he warns his correspondents against adding 'details that could only compromise me since all letters are read' (all quotes are from: Rol-Tanguy). Returning to France in 1790-02, he exclaims: 'The 9th of this month was the happy day when I regained my freedom,' undoubtedly not only professional but also political, notes H. Rol-Tanguy. He is pleased to finally express himself freely about the Russians, 'who only love money and are capable of all sorts of baseness to procure it,' about the Senate, which is 'the first body of slaves in Russia,' about the Livonians, who 'groan under the yoke of the Russians,' and about the Russian nobles, whose 'dispositions to rage' deeply shock him...
Nevertheless, his 'Russian' correspondence is quite rich and covers various subjects: religion (Lent, religious rites), customs and traditions, the national character of the Russians; Saint Petersburg, its population, its main buildings, its gardens, its surroundings (notably Peterhof); landscapes, climate; food; the court and Catherine II; etc. He also provides a detailed description of Count Stroganov's house, whose luxury and number of servants, 'all slaves,' greatly impress him (for a detailed analysis of this correspondence, see: Rol-Tanguy).
The life that Démichel led in Saint Petersburg was partly imposed on him by Romme's tastes, who shunned social gatherings. Démichel thus lived a reclusive life and only knew two Russians well: Count Alexander Stroganov, the father of Romme's student, and the father of his own student. He did not learn Russian because in Russia there was 'no house above the common where one does not speak French.' He also did not associate with the French living in Russia, who inspired little sympathy in him. Without making much of his qualities as a tutor, Démichel is scathing towards his colleagues practicing the same profession in Russia: 'Out of 2000 governors there may be in Saint Petersburg, barely 10 deserve any regard.'
Around 1784, Démichel moved into the family of Paul Stroganov's cousin, Baron Grigori Alexandrovich Stroganov (1770–1857), son of Baron Alexander Nikolaevich (1740–1789). In 1785, Démichel defined his educational project as follows: 'To inspire a lot of humanity in my student. Destined to one day be the absolute master of 10 to 12 thousand peasants, I will neglect nothing so that these unfortunate souls find in him a benevolent and sensitive heart.'
In 1787, Démichel took his student to Alsace and Lorraine, then they joined Romme in Riom; a niece of Romme believed that Démichel was not as strict as Romme, 'he has more wit than knowledge; he is rather an amiable man than a scholar.'
In 1790, Démichel left Russia to settle in Strasbourg. At that time, he was a convinced supporter of the Revolution, a moderate republican. He continued his correspondence with the Stroganov family, and it was through him that Romme learned he would have to part ways with his student in 1790. In 1792, as a public official and municipal officer, he became the mayor of Strasbourg in 1795, a government commissioner near the municipality, then its president, and later deputy mayor and (from 1808) prefectural councilor, all in Strasbourg.
Démichel's correspondence with Gabriel Dubreuil, a friend of Romme and the director of the Riom post office, is preserved in the Romme papers in Russia (2 volumes of 560 pages, correspondence 1776–1786, and 600 pages, correspondence 1787–1793).
Teaching institutions and families: Stroganov family.
Students and their social status: Nobility (Grigori Alexandrovich Stroganov).

Personal records: (*1745) Religion: Lutheran?
Career:
Sailor, assistant librarian. He served on ships belonging to Denmark; he had a Danish passport when he arrived in Saint Petersburg in 1767 with the person who looked after Baron Johann Albrecht Korff’s (1697–1766) library. Korff was Russian envoy extraordinary to the Danish court and earlier the president of the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences. (Baron Korff’s library had about 34 thousand volumes. In 1764, the library was purchased by Catherine II for 50 thousand roubles for the Grand Duke Paul (Pavel) Petrovich, but Korff had the right to use it until his death).
After arriving in Saint Petersburg in 1767, he was employed as an assistant librarian in Baron Korff’s library. In 1774, he married the daughter of major Ch. Lichnowsky, German by birth; they had two children. The level of Russian of both Ehrhardt and his wife was as good as was necessary for everyday communication. In 1777, he founded a school, located in Millionnaya Street in the first Admiralty part of the city, in the house of brigadier Fukov, where he resided as well. From 1779, he kept a boarding school. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences checked the institution in April 1780 and stated that there were six children (five boys and one girl) at the boarding school, and about 30 children aged from 8 to 13 attending the day school. The school premises consisted of two rooms, which were very cramped. The school had two teachers of German origin: Christian Lichnowsky and another (indecipherable), born in Kiel, aged about 30. According to the conclusion of the Commission of the Academy of Sciences, apart from the initial basics of the three languages (Russian, German, French) and arithmetic, children “could not learn anything here”. According to the results of examinations for boarding school guardians and teachers, held in the main German public school (Petrischule) from 3 November to 4 December 1784, Ehrhardt was “most ignorant and incapable of all the boarding school guardians, and his assistants were just as incapable as him”. In October 1784, 19 boys attended the school.
Teaching institutions and families: Private boarding school in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records: (*1755, Zhulinki village, Ruthenian Voivodeship, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy from 1775 to 1784, including in the theology class.
Career: Concerning Ivan Eleneev, it is known that after his graduation in 1784, he became a lower grammar class teacher at the Chernihiv Collegium. He soon left teaching and was ordained a priest. At the beginning of 1802, he served as cathedral protoiereus in Chernihiv.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the mid-1780s, approximately 400 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the lower grammar class taught by Ivan Eleneev. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although, students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ivan Eleneev, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ivan Eleneev worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions concerning sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by writings of the Chernihiv Collegium students, all of them had copies of the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records: (*Paris) Married; father of a daughter in 1761. Religion: Catholic.
Career: Tutor. On 1761-10-13, he passed the examination required for tutors at Moscow University and received a certificate to teach French and arithmetic. He then joined the Preobrazhensky Guard Regiment (certificate from 1777). He was working as a tutor in the Pskov province when he took the oath of 1793. He is found in Moscow in 1798.

Career: Governor engaged at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in 1769-12, replacing governor Bertrand. In 1770-04, he was transferred to the “Noble Cadet College,” likely the Noble Land Cadet Corps, and was replaced by Simonet.

Personal records:
(in Russia: Ivan Stepanovich or Ivan Andreyevich)
It is difficult to determine Fabian's origins, likely a descendant of Huguenots.
Education: He completed his studies at Moscow University.
Career:
Translator and teacher. A translator in the heraldry department before 1797, he taught German syntax at Moscow University in 1799 and held the rank of college secretary at that time.
Fabian had certainly been living in Russia for a long time as he translated from German and French into Russian.
He was a Freemason.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (1799).
Language and other teaching books by the:
In 1799, he published a German grammar manual, Novaya nemetskaya grammatika, in Moscow. He was also the author of:
  • Nouveaux dialogues français et russes divisés en 99 thèmes sur les neufs parties du discours, ou Manière très facile pour apprendre les principes de la grammaire française par Jean Frédéric Fabian, Moscow, À la typographie de A. Rechetnikov, 1799;
  • ABC instructif, pour apprendre aux enfans les élémens de la langue françoise, Moscow, 1779.
In 1804, he published a collection of texts, Metoditcheskoye chteniye, translated from the original German by I. Wegelin. He also translated the correspondence of Catherine II with Voltaire (1763–1778), which was published in Moscow in 1803 in two volumes. He collaborated in 1782 with one of the periodicals of the publisher and Freemason Nikolay Novikov, Vecherniaya Zaria.

Personal records:
(or Vaumale de Fages)
A gentleman originally from Vivarais.
Career:
#“Counselor of the Royal Chancellery of Poland” and tutor in Russia, he presented himself in 1770 at Moscow University to obtain a certificate allowing him to work as a tutor. According to Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon), he was a defrocked monk who had first fled to India, where he was said to have been the secretary of Joseph Dupleix, the governor of India, and then to Italy, where he spent all his fortune before coming to Russia. There, Catherine II appointed him as a tutor to Grigori Alexandrovich Potemkin in 1763, and he later became his secretary. He then served a Razumovski. In 1777, he was in the service of Lev Alexandrovich Naryshkin as a tutor to his younger son, likely Dmitri Lvovich Naryshkin.
In 1784, in a note written by Grimm, a Vaumale was referred to as the “first governor of the choristers of the Imperial Chapel.” He is said to have returned to France in 1785.
Teaching institutions and families: Naryshkin family
Language and other teaching books by the:
Fages de Vaumale composed a course of studies:

Léon de Narischkin, général en chef, chevalier des ordres et grand ecuyer de Russie, s.l., [1777], 33 p. in-4°. The book was also sold by subscription.

Students and their social status: Count Dmitri Nikolayevich Bludov (1785–1832), Minister of Justice, attorney general.

Personal records:
(*1720, Coutances, Manche)
Married, father of at least one child in 1777.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, German, Italian, history, geography.
Career:
Tutor; he was a former military man in the service of the Lithuanian army. He was in Saint Petersburg in 1759-02. He requested to take the examination for tutors at the Academy of Sciences to obtain a certificate of qualification. He was examined by Academicians Lomonosov, Müller, and Taubert, along with "several other experts." He received a certificate to teach French and three other languages (Latin, German, Italian), as well as history and geography. After staying in Moscow in 1761, he ran an educational boarding house in Simbirsk for six years and then another for three years in Orenburg. He returned to Moscow in 1770 and applied at the university for the position of lecturer after the death of lecturer Henry de Lavie, competing with Champagnolot and Fiodor Karjavin, who won the position.
He was still residing in Saint Petersburg, in the XIII district, when he took the oath in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: In 1760s, he ran an educational boarding house in Simbirsk (during six years), then another in Orenburg (during three years).

Personal records: (or Joasaph; secular name: Yakov/Jacob Pavlovich) (*1718, Demyantsy village of Pereyaslav sotnia in the Pereyaslav Regiment, Russian Empire). Father: Pavel Favorsky, priest at the Church of the Elevation of the Holy Cross. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: What we know about Ioasaf Favorsky is that he was a teacher in the infima and grammar classes at the Pereyaslav Collegium in the 1743–1745 school years. From 1745 onwards, he served as clerk at the Mezhyhirya Monastery (Kyiv Diocese) and took monastic vows at the same time.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (1743–1745).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the 1740s, more than 120 students were enrolled at the Pereyaslav Collegium. In the classes taught by Ioasaf Favorsky, there were 38 students in the 1743–1744 school year and 45 students in the 1744–1745 school year.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there. Thus, in the classes taught by Ioasaf Favorsky, there were 27 raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks) students in the 1743–1744 school year and 22 students of this origin in the 1744–1745 school year.
Teaching methods and materials: The teacher taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The Latin textbook used at the Pereyaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the 1740s was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that their teachers used the textbook by Alvares and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereyaslav Collegium. The name of one of the summaries (compendia), containing grammar exercises, which was compiled under Ioasaf Favorsky’s direction in 1743–1744, is available. [Alvares E.] Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (*1758, Russian Empire) Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Ivan Fedorchin studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theology class.
Career: The only thing we know concerning Ivan Fedorchin is that immediately after graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium in 1782 he became a Latin teacher in the grammar class of the school. In 1783, he was no longer among the teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1782).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In 1782, 508 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The grammar class taught by Ivan Fedorchin had 51 students at the time.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ivan Fedorchin, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ivan Fedorchin worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, written by the bishop of Belgorod Samuel Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector, to the prefect and to the teachers, were in use at the Collegium. The document gives a sufficiently complete idea of the teaching of basic school disciplines, including foreign languages. According to the Instructions, Latin grammar classes were supposed to be based on Johann Matthias Gesner’s version of the book by Christoph Cellarius, published at Moscow University in 1762. In his Instructions, Samuel Mislavsky also pointed out that grammar rules were necessarily supposed to be consolidated by reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. Mislavsky mentioned Lange’s book both in its Russian and original versions. The Instructions contained detailed recommendations on the organisation of classroom and homework exercises for students. It listed sections and paragraphs of the books that the teacher was supposed to be guided by at various stages of teaching. In his Instructions, Samuel Mislavsky also focused on methods that would allow students to consolidate the “lighthearted vocabulary, intelligent designs, prompt responses and pleasant adventures of eminent men” in their memory. For this purpose, he advised teachers to use the book named “Reasonable Comrade” (Семенов П. Товарищ разумной и замысловатой, или Собрание хороших слов, разумных замыслов, скорых ответов, учтивых насмешек и приятных приключений знатных мужей древняго и нынешняго веков, Moscow, 1787). All of the books were available in the library of the Kharkiv Collegium (they were bought on purpose; quite a few books were also donated by Samuel Mislavsky). According to the library catalogue dated 1769, the Collegium had several different books by Cellarius and Lange. Their general number exceeded ten copies at the time. Besides that, the library had a few modern dictionaries, lexicons by different authors, published in Halle and other centres (unfortunately, the book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately). Personal records: (*1773, Russian Empire). Vasily Fedorovsky was of clergy origin. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1785 to 1796, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theology class.
Career: All we know about Vasily Fedorovsky is that he became a grammar class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium immediately after graduation in 1796. He was ordained a priest. In 1797, he taught the poetics class, from 1799 onwards – the rhetoric class. He was a teacher until 1803.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1796–1803).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1796–1797 school year, approximately 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class taught by Vasily Fedorovsky.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Vasily Fedorovsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Vasily Fedorovsky worked at the Kharkiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises performed by the Collegium students of the 1790s show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Quite often students translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated (students left information about them). The books were available in large numbers at the library of the Kharkiv Collegium. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. As evidenced by memoirs of the Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues”. Personal records: We know that Karl-Johann Fegen was a native of the German lands.
Education: We do not know exactly where K.-J. Fegen studied, but it is clear – thanks to the correspondence of the Kharkiv Collegium direction with the diocesan authorities and to that between the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy and the Kyiv Metropolitan – that people who studied at Western European universities were invited to take up positions as teachers of the “new languages”.
Career: From the beginning of the 1780s, K.-J. Fegen taught German at the Kharkiv Collegium. In February 1784, he sent a petition to the Kyiv Metropolitan Samuel Mislavsky, in which he asked for an appointment as a German teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. He worked at the Academy until August 1785.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (early 1780s); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1784–1785).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; nobility.
When Karl-Johann Fegen was a teacher, more than 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. K.-J. Fegen was a German teacher. Most of his students were from the syntax and rhetoric classes, a few were from the philosophy class. In total, he had several dozen students. He also taught German to several dozen students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there. It is known that many sons of noblemen (szlachta) learned German.
Teaching methods and materials: Little is known about the German teaching methods. It is obvious that Karl-Johann Fegen used the book by Johann Christoph Gottsched to teach German to his students. In general, he did not lack textbooks for them. He could use German grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Collegium and at the Academy. At the time, the Kharkiv Collegium and the Academy had a significant number of German grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries. The books had been transferred to the library by Belgorod bishops and Kyiv metropolitans (who had once been teachers). Educational institutions also bought grammar books in large numbers. German grammar books are often found in the descriptions of the belongings of students. However, the rather brief book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately. As a part of the learning process, students also translated extracts from different books in German. At the time, the tragedy Der Tod Adams by the eminent German poet Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock was often used for translations. Греч И. М. Personal records: (or Fieodorowicz; monastic name: Pavel or Paul) Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know concerning Platon Feodorovich is that he was an analogy class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in 1748–1750. He took monastic vows at the same time.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1748–1750).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the end of the 1740s, about two hundred students attended the analogy class, which Platon Feodorovich taught. In total, more than 1000 students were enrolled at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in those years.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), which Platon Feodorovich taught.
At the time, the textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely.

Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. The library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: It is known that Filaret Finevsky was a grammar class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium in the 1756-1757 school year and a poetics teacher from 1759 onwards. In 1765 he was appointed Prefect of the Collegium. While working at the Collegium, he was a hieromonk. From 1765 onwards, he served as hegumen at the Sudzhensky Predtechev Monastery (Kursk Diocese), and from 1784 to 1787 – as rector at the Assumption Monastery in Svyatye Gory (Kharkiv Diocese). He was dismissed from his responsibilities at the monastery for the release of several monastic peasants.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1756–1765).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1750s, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class, which Filaret Finevsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Filaret Finevsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Kharkiv Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the middle of the 1750s was still the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. A large number of Latin textbooks published for Jesuit collegiums of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) were mentioned in the library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753). Also, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already in use at the time. The library of the Collegium had several lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Kharkiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Personal records: (Cyrillic: Петр Лаврентьев сын, Петерсон) (Copenhagen – 1740-03-22, Yekaterinburg, Russian Empire). Religion: Lutheran.
Career:
He served with Duke Charles Frederick of Holstein-Gottorp before coming in Russia.
He taught a son of the voyevod (military governor) Ivan Kirillovich Khrushchev and after that he 'returned'  to Yekaterinburg and on 7 January 1736 he submitted a petition for his admission to serve in the chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters. When testing the ability to translate from German into Russian he was unable to translate professor I.G. Gmelin’s letter sent from Irkutsk, referring to an incomplete knowledge of Russian grammar. So, on 18 March 1736 Finn signed a contract for his admission to serve as a steward (manciple) at a traktir (inn), where orphans and children who came from Kungur district (uyezd) and enrolled at schools in Yekaterinburg were supposed to live. The contract was signed for three years with a salary of 60 roubles per year. The traktir started to work in June 1736 in a specially designated house, where Finn lived with his family.  But the paucity of the nutrition provided by Finn and the lack of proper control over his expenses on the part of the authorities caused an outflow of those wishing to live in the traktir (out of the 22 students enrolled only 10 remained; in October 1737, seven of them wished to organise their food themselves, receiving a state salary). 
In August 1737, Finn submitted a petition for his appointment as a teacher at the German school for a two-year period. In doing so, he aimed to replace the deceased Anton Roze. In September, he put forward the following conditions: a salary of 120 roubles, equal to that of Roze, half of his salary for the position of steward (manciple), and a flat near the schools, to avoid living in a traktir. In the case of someone else being hired as steward (manciple), he would agree on a teaching position with a flat. If two years later he did not wish to continue the service, he would then be given two state-financed carts to depart for Saint Petersburg.  
But the Ural authorities only agreed to raise his salary to 84 roubles for performing both positions and asked V.N. Tatishchev what to do. It is by his decree of Samara dated November 1737 that Finn was banned from taking a teaching position, as many of the noble children were to study in Yekaterinburg, and Finn could keep them according to his contract. Meanwhile, the teaching position was being negotiated with Herwarth, a student from Moscow who wished to take it. 
But on 6 April 1739, the day after Störmer was dismissed from teaching, the Ural authorities signed a contract for Finn’s admission as a German school teacher for a year with a salary of 84 roubles. On 11 April, Finn began to teach German to children transferred from the arithmetic school of Yekaterinburg. Finn occupied his teaching position for less than a year. On 22 March 1740 he died. He probably died suddenly because of debt recovery procedures, which had just begun. According to the decree of the General Mining Directory (“General-berg-direktorium”) that arrived in Yekaterinburg, a debt of 120 roubles was ordered to be recovered from Finn. That amount of money was taken with a promissory note as early as in 1731 from the merchant’s estate managers Schiefner and Wolfe Senlein, who had not requested the payment of the debt for many years. Earlier, according to the decision of the Ural authorities dated 8 May 1739, 28 roubles were to be taken from Finn’s salary in favour of the protocol officer Lodygin, who worked at the Krasnoyarsk mining office at the time. Regarding the debt of 120 roubles, during an interrogation at the chancellery (office), he stated that he had nothing to pay with except his salary. On 2 February 1740 it was ordered to confiscate Finn's house and land and sell them at a public auction (he had managed to build his own house in Yekaterinburg in 1737). It turned out that, in addition to that, Finn owed 50 roubles to the pastor Soechting and the captain Brandt, but a lawsuit on their part was denied, due to the need to pay a large amount taken in 1731. The total amount of Finn’s debt with interests and duties amounted to 160 roubles 42 kopecks. Only at the beginning of 1742 was the issue of the debt basically resolved. The following debts remained: the one he owed a merchant (27 roubles 9 kopecks) and the debt that he owed Lodygin (6 roubles 31 ½ kopecks). Finn’s wife, who wished to travel through Moscow to her country in March 1742, was denied the use of carts, as they were not mentioned in her husband’s contract. It was ordered to deliver her to Moscow free of charge. She was supposed to take ships that were sent in a caravan loaded with Ural iron every spring.
Teaching institutions and families:
Yekaterinburg German school.
Family of the Yeniseysk city voivode (governor) Ivan Kirillovich Khrushchev.
Finn mentioned the family in his petition [for his admission to the service in Yekaterinburg] submitted to the chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters in January 1736. He said that he had arrived in Yeniseysk to teach “foreign sciences” to the voivode’s son.
Students and their social status:
From 11 April 1739 Finn taught 10 students from the German school in Yekaterinburg – a new group of students, specially transferred from the arithmetic school to the German one. The age of students was relatively uniform at that time, i.e. from 10 to 14 years old. All of them received a state allowance of 4 roubles per year.
They were mostly children of the lower ranks – military men; clerks; factory workers. 
Children of factory administration workers and officers were already taught at the school, so in April 1739 the children of four soldiers, a gunner, a copyist, two craftsmen and two factory workers were accepted in the school.
Teaching methods and materials:
He began to teach children the alphabet, vocables, German writing and reading the New Testament.
According to the reports of the students’ progress, they first learned the German alphabet, and then moved on to studying pronunciation, writing words and reading the New Testament in German.

Personal records: (*1713-06-22, Esslingen, Duchy of Württemberg). Father: Georg Abraham, grammar-school teacher. Mother: Maria Euph., née Boekler Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Fischer registered as a pupil of the Academy School in Saint Petersburg on 1 October 1733. Later, he became a student at the University of the Academy of Sciences, in Saint Petersburg.
Career: Fischer was appointed teacher at the Academy School on 7 April 1741. In August 1742, he is documented as teacher of the upper German class (“prima”). Presumably in 1743, he was dismissed, possibly due to an insufficient knowledge of Russian.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1741–1743, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; merchants; clergy; soldiers; servants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers, published by Sukhomlinov, list about 820 pupils attending the Academy School during this period. At least two-thirds of these pupils learned German.
In principle, there were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitz’ report (1736) lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School, especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia, to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.

Personal records: Cyrillic: Михаил (Андреевич) (†1765, Moscow). Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Fischer started his career at the grammar school attached to Moscow University in 1757 as a French teacher. In July 1761, he was transferred to the German third class (the so-called „syntax“ class), to replace teacher Gottr. (?), who had been dismissed. In May 1762, Fischer asked to be dismissed, because he wanted to open his own private school. He realized his plan and even obtained the imperial privilege for his school. Fischer died in 1765.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to Moscow University (1757–1762); own private school.
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 on M.V. Lomonosov’s initiative in order to prepare students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so-called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European Languages (i.e., German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the beginning, there were 50 scholarship students (among them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number was increased quite quickly. The highest number of students was achieved in 1787, when the school counted 1010 pupils (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials: J.G. Reichel, lecturer in German language and literature at Moscow University from 1757 and professor from 1761, described the concrete circumstances of language teaching at the grammar school of Moscow University in his correspondence. The most common method of grammar teaching at the time was the presentation of rules, which had to be learned by heart by the students. It seems uncertain that the rules were explained sufficiently, so that students understood them and could apply them. As to this issue, Reichel wrote in December 1761: The teachers of the German class of ‘syntax’ “were not able to explain the rules by heart”, but they “dictated the rules and did not concern themselves with the explanation and application of the rules.” (Reichel, letter of 27 December 1761, quoted from Lehmann, 1966, p. 141). In the same letter, Reichel complained about the poor results of language teaching in general: “Students have to spend more than one year on spelling, more than one year on declination and conjugation and two years on syntax. However, when they finally get to phrasing, they are not able to write three lines in one hour and they cannot read either.” (Reichel, quoted after Lehmann, 1966, p. 141). [Gottsched, Johann Christoph], Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst, Nach den Mustern der besten Schriftsteller des vorigen und jetzigen Jahrhunderts abgefasset von Johann Christoph Gottscheden, Leipzig, 1748, (4-ed. 1757). [Шванович, Мартин], Немецкая грамматика, из разных авторов собрана и российской юности в пользу издана от учителя немецкого языка при Санкт-Петербургской гимназии, St. Petersburg, Tipogr. AN, 3rd ed.,1745. In the case of the grammar school attached to Moscow University and the university itself, the choice of books used for learning foreign languages was quite well documented. Initially, the school regulations, published at its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works, like for example Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738, which were used in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). In the following years, the professors’ conference, which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered the books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963). In general, grammar books constituted the main basis for language instruction in the 18th century. The grammar covered all the important aspects of a language, not only the grammar rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology”, which meant morphology, syntax and prosody. There were two German grammars, which were used in the late 1750s and early 1760s at the grammar school. The school regulation of Mikhail Lomonosov of 1758 implemented J.Ch. Gottsched’s German grammar “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ for German classes (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459). Before the school probably used M. Schwanwitz’ German grammar, which was printed at the Academic University in Saint Petersburg (fourth edition in 1745). Still in 1758, Moscow University ordered 40 copies for the grammar school pupils (Пенчко, 1960, p. 140).

Personal records: (*ar. 1761, Avillers (-Sainte-Croix, Meuse)). Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Ordained a priest in 1785, he served several churches in France in the diocese of Verdun. Abbot Jean-Dominique Florentin left France after the decrees of -1792-05-27 and 1792-08-26, which compelled local authorities to expel clergy who had not sworn allegiance to the Civil Constitution of the Clergy. He withdrew to the Duchy of Bouillon, then to Liège, before staying in Austria. He was secretary to Mgr de Camiers in Brussels and, at the end of 1793, became a tutor in a respectable family in Limburg. In 1794-07, he was expelled to Frankfurt with his students. In 1796, as the French advanced on Frankfurt, abbot Florentin had to retreat to Hamburg and, in 1797, separate from his students. Thanks to various wealthy houses, a charitable institution for emigrants had just been formed in Hamburg. Florentin became its chaplain.
In the meantime, abbot Florentin became acquainted with the Russian minister in Hamburg and decided to go to Russia in 1798. A favorable proposal was made to him by Count Litta (probably Yuli Litta (1763–1839), one of the leaders of the Order of Malta in Russia, close to Emperor Paul I): they wanted him to take on the role of chaplain of the order. However, "fearing that such a commitment would force him to renounce his homeland forever" (as one of the goals of the order was to combat the revolution), he refused. He served for some time as a tutor for private individuals before leaving Saint Petersburg for Moscow.
He was entrusted with the direction of several private libraries belonging to Russian nobles in Moscow, notably with Prince Iuri Golitsyn (?), while he was also "working to put in order the temporal affairs of the Catholic Church of Moscow [the Church of Saint Louis of the French], which the extreme modesty of its resources threatened with imminent collapse." In 1804, he was appointed syndic of this church. After two years, he succeeded in gathering part of the amount necessary to redeem the land of the church sold by the first syndics, adding his own savings and those of some of his colleagues.
In 1806, vice-consul Patot d’Orflans was forced to leave Russia and handed over the consulate records to abbot Florentin, who fulfilled the duties of the French agent in that city in 1807. Patot d’Orflans returned to Moscow during the year 1808; abbot Florentin was also relieved of his duties as syndic of Saint Louis. He took up residence near the church, where he still lived in 1808.

Personal records: (*1736, Amiens; died suddenly in the night of 1800-04-10 to 1800-04-11, in Saint Petersburg; buried on 1800-04-12 in the Volkovskoye cemetery). Father: Claude-Eustache de Forceville, counselor, consul, and merchant in Amiens. Mother: Marie-Geneviève Maillard. Brother: Louis-Noël de Forceville. Married to (contract executed at the chancellery of the consulate on 1777-03-29/04-08): Claire-Aldegonde Delesalle (*1756-09-29, Verquigneul; bapt. the same day; godfathers: Vaast Aicadre and Bruno Lemaire; godmother: Marie-Claire Gottran), daughter of Philippe-Auguste Delesalle and Marie-Anne-Josèphe Lemaire.
Education: He completed his studies at a Jesuit college in Amiens and then engaged in trade in Holland.
Career:
Governor. Originally from Picardy.
He arrived in Russia in 1768, served two years in an English company in Saint Petersburg, and then became a tutor both in Saint Petersburg and Moscow. In 1779, he assisted his father-in-law in his educational boarding house on Vasilievsky Island in Petersburg, teaching geography, mythology, and history. He resided in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793.
His wife arrived with her family in Russia in the spring of 1765 and likely attended the boarding school established by Carbonnet at the behest of the Empress, along with two of her sisters. The educational expenses for "the three young Delesalle girls from the cabinet of Her Imperial Majesty" were covered by the treasury. It is known that she was educated for six years at the Smolny convent for noble girls; in addition to French, which was her native language, she mastered German and Russian. In 1780, already married to François-Hippolyte de Forceville, she taught at an educational boarding house founded by her father Philippe-Auguste Delesalle in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Educational boarding house of Philippe-Auguste Delesalle (1779; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records:
(*Amiens) Religion: Catholic. Father: Claude-Eustache de Forceville. Mother: Marie-Geneviève Maillard. Brother: François-Hippolyte de Forceville. Married to (on 1790-12-14, at Saint Louis of the French in Moscow, by contract on 1790-12-08, at the French vice-consulate in Moscow): Alexandra-Albertine Delesalle, widow of Müller, originally from Béthune in Artois, daughter of Philippe-Auguste Delesalle and Marie-Anne-Joséphine Lemaire (witnesses: Jean De Bosse, Philippe-Auguste Delesalle, Félix de Forceville, Jacob Le Doulx, Louis Soulages). Children:
  • Jean de Forceville (*1792-09-30, Moscow; bapt. at Saint Louis of the French on 1792-11-14; godparents: Ivan and Elisaveta Wadkowski, Arnauld-Sabin, Marquis de Lanlay, and Jean Batiment), living in 1793;
  • Nicolas-Alexis de Forceville (Nikolay Noevich) (*1796-01-15, Moscow; bapt. at Saint Louis of the French on 1796-01-24; godfather: General Nikolay Lodyjenski; godmother: Claire-Aldegonde de Forceville, née Delesalle); lieutenant. At the request of his parents, the Counts de Forceville, to know his fate, it was revealed that the Delesalle family, relatives through his mother, had lost sight of him since his youth and only knew that since his resignation, he had married a Russian and had lived for a long time in the Tver province, Zubtsov district, where he was the steward of the estates of a certain V. A. Chashnikova. In 1834, he was said to be the salt inspector in Zubtsov when he partially inherited from Nicolas-Eustache de Forceville, who died in Tours in 1811. He died no later than 1837. Upon his death, his estate was recovered by the district court of Zubtsov in the Tver province: his fortune consisted of a village in this district named Kudrino, which had 21 male serfs, their wives and children, and included a manor house. An announcement was made inviting heirs to appear in court.
Career:
Miniature painter, boarding school master. He had stayed in England before arriving in Russia. He was a witness at the marriage contract of Mathelin/Chevalier on 1785-09-16. An inventory of his belongings was drawn up by De Bosse, manager of the French vice-consulate in Moscow, on 1790-12-06.
He resided in the VII district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793. He opened an educational boarding house for eighteen students in Moscow in 1795, which trained the famous memorialist F. F. Viguel. The latter described this boarding house as "a true school of parrots." Dimitri Delesalle (his brother-in-law, son of Philippe-Auguste Delesalle) taught there for a time. Louis-Noël de Forceville was still residing in Moscow in 1798.
Teaching institutions and families: An educational boarding house for eighteen students in Moscow.

Personal records:
(or Phorinel; Joseph)
Frenchman by origin.
Career: All that is known concerning Iosif Forinel is that he was invited to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, where he taught French in the 1788-1789 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1788–1789).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The contract that was signed with Iosif Forinel stated that he was supposed to teach reading, writing, speaking, translating from French into Russian and from Russian into French as well as letter writing rules. His duties also included the teaching of two particular students at the Academy, so that in case of illness they could replace him.
At the time, the textbook compiled by Martyn Sokolovsky was used for teaching French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. It is obvious that Iosif Forinel did not lack textbooks for students. He could also use other French grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library catalogue, it contained a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries at the time (by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey). The rather short book descriptions do not make it possible to identify all the books accurately.

Personal records:
(in Russia called 'Franière')
Originally from Fribourg.
Career:
Military, captain in the service of France, he was later engaged as a French governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in 1765-01. Dissatisfied with the insufficient amount of his salary, he, along with two other Frenchmen, Richard and Jenessière, requested a raise from the Academy, and then submitted his resignation in 1765-11.
In 1770, he requested to be examined by the Academy of Sciences to obtain a certificate of professional competence. L. Bachmeister, who examined him, found that he spoke French correctly and fluently and had no doubt that the children would quickly learn to speak under his guidance. However, the few words written in Fragnière's own hand on the certificate he was issued cast doubt on this enthusiastic opinion: "I received the certificate, Jean François Fragnier," wrote the tutor. He resided in the V district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1765; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (or François) Originally from Burgundy. Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Priest. He was invited to Moscow University by Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov, the curator of the university. He was examined in Müller’s apartment, and a certificate was issued confirming his knowledge of Latin, elementary mathematics, and the basics of physics: “He can teach physics on the condition that he meticulously prepares his lessons,” it was stipulated in the certificate.
On 1757-05-21, abbot Francozi gave his first course on experimental physics. The course was conducted in French in the university's large hall in front of a large audience. Starting the following autumn, he held his classes on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday afternoons. In 1758, he was replaced by another, more experienced professor.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (1757–1758).

Personal records: Originally from Switzerland.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, German, Russian, history, geography.
Career: Tutor. He served in France as a lieutenant during the Swiss War. He passed an examination at the Academy of Sciences in Saint Petersburg and received a certificate on 1757-05-29, authorizing him to teach French, Latin, German, Russian, history, and geography. He then taught in Saint Petersburg to the children of the foreign merchant Poggenpohl.

Personal records: (†1783-01-02/13, Moscow) From a noble family originally from Lorraine. Coat of arms: Or, a cross sable, with a franc gules charged with a silver tower. He drafted his will on 1782-12-07, and had it deposited at the vice-consulate in Moscow on the 28th. His brother, captain commanding the artillery in Nancy, inherited 300 rubles, a debt owed by Madame Polivanoff.
Career: Tutor. A former gentleman cadet of the Duke of Lorraine, he became in 1770 in Moscow the governor in the family of the chief general of the Russian army, Count Valentine Platonovich Musin-Pushkin, organizer of the court of the heir (where Mlle Besson and a certain Didier also resided). In 1782, he appointed Perlot, governor of General Yushkov's sons, as his executor. He boasted of counting the said general among his friends.
Teaching institutions and families: Musin-Pushkin family

Personal records:
Originally from Salins (Jura). Mother: Marguerite Bailly, widow Gaillard, residing in Salins. Brother: Jean-Joseph Gaillard. Married to: Louise-Monique N. (1), with whom he had at least two daughters. Children:
  • Henriette Gaillard (*1786-01-30, Moscow, bapt. at Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul on 26 August 1786; godfather: Jacques Dietz, doctor of medicine; godmother: Catherine de Pestel), alive in 1793;
  • Louise Gaillard, alive in 1793.
He remarried, probably before 1790, to Marie-Madeleine Régnier (marriage contract registered at the French vice-consulate in Moscow on 19 December 1791).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Russian, German, “Divine Law”, geography, history, mythology, arithmetic, mathematics, dance
Career: Governor and merchant. He registered powers of attorney at the French vice-consulate in Moscow on 22 May 1787, 26 January and 8 May 1790. By that time, in 1788, he already owned a house located at the corner of the street of the Bridge of Blacksmiths and Neglinny Proyezd, under number 413, which would later become the property of a Simoni. In 1792, he received permission from the Prikaz obshchestvennogo prizrenia to open a boarding school for noble boys in Moscow. He intended to teach, along with other professors, “according to a method,” the following subjects: French, Russian, German, “Divine Law,” geography, history, mythology, arithmetic, and other parts of mathematics, as well as dance. He wished to “preserve the innocence of the morals of the children entrusted to him” and therefore only accepted children aged three to ten. He promised to provide healthy, abundant food suitable for the age and constitution of the children and to keep the premises as clean as possible. The number of children was to be limited to twelve. The tuition fee varied according to the age and subjects chosen by the parents. The head of this boarding school lived on Nikitskaya Street, in the parish of Fyodor-Stoudit, in the house of Nikolai Fyodorovich Jarkov. He resided in the VIII district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793, before becoming naturalized in 1793. He was the godfather of Sophie-Alexandrine Simon on 16 February 1791; his second wife was the godmother of Alexandre La Croix on 21 January 1790, and of Alexandre-Jean Thévenet on 18 June 1796, at Saints-Apostles-Peter-and-Paul. He was a creditor of the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg at the turn of the 18th and 19th centuries.
Teaching institutions and families: A boarding school for noble boys in Moscow
Students and their social status: Nobility

Mother: Augustine-Geneviève Desmarets (†before 1793). Personal records: (or Gej)
Education: Licentiate.
Career: Jurij Gej held the academic degree of a licentiate and is documented as teacher of French, German, history and philosophy at the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps in July 1737. His main subject was French, which he taught 22 hours per week to a class of 40 students. He also taught German style four hours weekly to a group of 13 students. Furthermore, he was a teacher of state history and philosophy. These subjects were taught by Gej 12 hours weekly to a group of seven cadets.
Teaching institutions and families: Infantry Noble Cadet Corps (1737; Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Nobility.
Teaching methods and materials:
The main instrument of language learning at that time was learning by heart. Thus, the students learnt declination and conjugation forms from the grammar book and also memorized vocabulary and dialogues. These studies were completed by translation, one of the “principal means of teaching foreign languages in the Cadet Corps” (Rjéoutski, 2013). “The cadets were trained to translate from German into French and from French into German and, later, at least at the beginning of the reign of Catherine, from and into Russian as well” (Rjéoutski, 2013).

Neukirch, Benjamin, Anweisung zu Teutschen Briefen, Leipzig, 1709 (1. issue), 1727 (2. issue).

Personal records: (1744-12-03, Cieple, Poland – 1793-02-02, Mahilyow, Russian Empire) Religion: Catholic.
Education: After joining the Society of Jesus in 1763, Kajetan Gieryk studied at the Vilnius Jesuit Collegium.
Career: Priest. Kajetan Gieryk began his career in Russia as the Prefect of the Jesuit schools in Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) (1776–1777). Due to the fact that the catalogues of the Society of Jesus in Belarus covering the years from 1778 to 1782 are lost, it is impossible to determine in what capacity he was employed at the time. It is known that in the 1783–1784 academic year, he was a German teacher at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. Then he was transferred to the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium, where he worked until his death, first as a German teacher (1784–1786), then as Rector (1786–1793).

Personal records: (*1734, Russian Empire) Son of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Ioann Gilevsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the rhetoric class, then at the Kharkiv Collegium (till 1762): for two years in the philosophy class and for four years in the theology class.
Career: After graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium in 1762, Ioann Gilevsky began to teach Latin in the grammar class of the same Collegium. Later he was a teacher in the poetic and rhetoric classes, and from 1776 to 1791 he taught in the philosophy class. In 1761, he was ordained a priest; in 1787 he became a protopope (archpriest). In 1791, he retired from the Collegium due to illness.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1762–1791).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
At the beginning of the 1760s, more than 300 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class taught by Ioann Gilevsky.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ioann Gilevsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ioann Gilevsky worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at the time. The Collegium library had a few books by these authors as well as some modern dictionaries and lexicons by different compilers, published in Halle and other centres; unfortunately, the book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Kharkiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises intended for the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: Father: Joseph Gillot, collector for the king at the office of unified duties in Nancy.
Career: French governor, he was admitted in place of Thys (who became a deputy inspector) at the end of 1772 at the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg. Initially employed for three months, his contract was extended. In 1774, he submitted a resignation request citing “the current state of my health preventing me from being able to fulfill the duties attached to my position any longer.” He was replaced by Nicolas Bourgeois. Personal records: (Secular name: Grigory Pavlovich) (1717, Russian Empire – Russian Empire). He was born into a meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class (until 1743).
Career:
During his studies at the academy he took monastic vows.
Immediately after graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in 1743 he became a teacher in syntax and poetic classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium. In 1745, still teaching in these classes, he served as the prefect of the Collegium. From 1748 to 1750, Gavriil Ginovsky taught Latin in the grammar class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1751 to 1774, he was hegumen of Saint Michael Monastery in Sorochintsy.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (from 1743); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1748–1750).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. There were several dozen students in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Gavriil Ginovsky at the Pereiaslav Collegium and the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium and Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Gavriil Ginovsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1740s and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy was “De Institutione Grammatica libri tres” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used in Jesuit schools. The surviving school exercises of Pereiaslav Collegium and Kyiv-Mohyla Academy students show that their teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Collegium or the Academy. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (*Versailles) Father: Jean Girard. Mother: Suzanne Durocher. Married to: 1.) Mme Girard (see the following entry), a governess and boarding house mistress; 2.) Aglaé Larcher D’Aubcourt (Marseille) (contract at the consulate's chancery on 7 October 1784), daughter of the actor Jean-Pierre-François Larcher D’Aubcourt and Marguerite Dubois.
Career: Dance master at the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg from 1 September 1768 to 18 February 1789. Girard was one of the few dance teachers who satisfied the Academy's requirements: before him, dance masters Dmitri Volkov and La Comté, both French, had been dismissed for not being fit to perform their duties. However, Girard was among the professors who missed their classes: in 1773, the Academy's administration informed them that for each missed class, one-twentieth of their monthly salary would be deducted. Girard staged ballets at the Free Russian Theatre (Volny rossiski teatr). At the Academy of Fine Arts, which had its own theater, Girard staged several ballets, including ballets of his own composition, and he also directed the organization of summer festivities in the academic garden. He was heavily in debt in 1779 when he was appointed to teach music at the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg. He then moved to Moscow, where he resided in the VI district when he took the oath of 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (1768–1789; St. Petersburg).

Career: Already present in St. Petersburg in 1766. A French governess at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts from 1770, she resigned in 1772. Personal records: (or Girczicz; secular name: Fiodor) (*1720, Poltava, Russian Empire). Son of a merchant. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Foma Girchich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar.
Career: In 1747–1748, Foma Girchich began teaching in the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; later on, he taught in the grammar class. He took monastic vows. He taught in the poetic (1749–1750 school year) and rhetoric (1750–1751 school year) classes. From 1753 onwards, he was a cathedral preacher at Saint Sophia’s Monastery in Kyiv. In the same year, he was appointed to the position of preacher at the Holy Trinity Lavra of Saint Sergius. In 1754, he was appointed prefect at the Trinity Lavra Seminary and a cathedral hieromonk.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; Holy Trinity Lavra Seminary (Sergiyev Posad).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the end of the 1740s, more than 100 people were enrolled in the grammar classes taught by Foma Girchich. In total, more than 1000 people studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in those years.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class) in which Foma Girchich taught. The teacher also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records:
(or Ernestus) (1654-05-18, Wettin, near Halle/Saale – 1705-05-05, Moscow). Married to: Christina Emerentia von Reuter (†1740). Children:
  • Christian Bernard Glück (†1735-12-24), teacher at the Moscow Foreign Language School and Russian privy counselor (“kammerrat”);
  • Ernst Gottlieb Glück (†1757), Russian counsellor of Justice;
  • several daughters.
Religion: Lutheran.
Education: According to an entry in the Bible of the Glück family, Johann Ernst was enrolled at the grammar school at Altenburg (Thuringia) at the age of eleven. He probably attended this school for the usual duration of seven years, before he matriculated at the university of Wittenberg in 1672 to study theology. Presumably, he finished his studies in 1675 and left for Livonia (Riga) – some sources also note that he moved there in 1673. A few years later, he returned to his homeland in order to improve his knowledge of Hebrew and Old Greek and therefore registered at the university of Leipzig in summer 1679.  Glück also studied Hebrew with the renowned orientalist Esdras(s) Edzardus in Hamburg.
Career:
Theologian, preacher and pedagogue.
In 1680, Glück moved to Livonia again, where he became pastor and provost in Marienburg (1683). He founded the first schools for Latvian children and started to train teachers for these schools. He translated the Bible and the catechism into Latvian (New Testament, Riga 1685, Old Testament, Riga 1689) and also wrote Latvian primers (fibulas). Furthermore, he translated the Slavonic Bible into Russian, though the manuscript was lost afterwards. During the Northern War, in August 1702, Glück and his family were captured by Russians and brought to Moscow, where they arrived on 6 January 1703.
After about two weeks Glück and his family were allowed to leave the monastery, where the Latvian captives had been kept imprisoned. They were released relatively quickly, since Glück enjoyed an excellent reputation as pedagogue, translator and adept of the Russian language and they probably received some support from Marta Skavronskaya, the later wife of Peter I, who was brought up in the household of J.E. Glück. They moved into the house of the Lutheran pastor Bartholomäus Vagetius, who had acted as a guarantor for Glück, in the German Quarter. At the same time, on 19 January 1703, Peter I entrusted Glück with the reorganisation of a small school of foreign languages, which had been run by N. Schwimmer at the Posolskiy prikaz (Foreign Department) since July 1701. Thus, Glück became the teacher of nine pupils (six from Schwimmer’s school plus three brothers Веселовский). Glück and two other teachers engaged by Glück (probably Johann Gustav Wurm and Glück’s son Christian Bernhard Glück, Johann Werner Paus or Johann Jean Lambert [Merlot]), successfully taught the pupils Latin, German and French. On 15 December 1703, Glück addressed a petitionary letter to Peter I and asked for permission to expand the school on a state-approved and state-funded basis (letter published by Белокуров, С.А., Зерцалов А.Н., 1907, p. 46f.). Other oral petitions addressed to the tsar by Glück with detailed information about the organisation of the projected institution are equally documented by Белокуров, С.А., Зерцалов А.Н., 1907, p. 47f. The school was intended to be a grammar school, similar to the Western European type of Knight Academy, with a focus on teaching languages (Latin, German, French, Slavonic, Hebrew and other oriental languages) as well as rhetoric, philosophy, geometry, arithmetic, geography, politics and history. Glück’s plans even foresaw the teaching of dancing and riding, but these ideas were never realized. In March 1704, Glück contacted A.H. Francke and asked for support for the school by sending teachers and books. At that time, according to Glück’s statement, 16 pupils attended the school, amongst them one noble (Yury [Jurge!] Ivanovich Gagarin, see: letter from Glück to Francke dated 8 March 1704, published by Winter, 1953, p. 373-378). Glück’s working conditions improved when he received permission to move into the palace of the late prince Naryshkin in Pokrovka-Street, where students and teachers could be accommodated together. Eventually, the tsar agreed to Glück’s plans to found a real grammar school and enabled him to put them into practice. Based on the decree of 25 February 1705, the school was officially founded and put under the control of the authorities of Saint Petersburg and Ingria (Ingermanland) with an annual budget of 3000 roubles for maintenance. The school was provided with several privileges. Accordingly, pupils had a daily allowance (4–10 kopeck) and were exempted from military service. As a result, the number of pupils attending the school quickly rose to 28 in the course of the year 1705. Tragically, Glück was not given the opportunity to put his school project into action completely. He died unexpectedly only two months after the official foundation of his school on 5 May 1705. Nevertheless, Glück is remembered as the founder of the first Russian grammar school. After Glück’s death the school was directed by J.W. Paus (until summer 1706) and J.Ch. Büttner (summer 1706 until the end of 1710).
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow Foreign Language School (1703–1705).
Students and their social status:
Civil servants; servants; nobility.
Glück’s first pupils, who had started to learn foreign languages at N. Schwimmer’s school, were predominantly the sons of civil servants. They were trained to become translators in the administration or to be sent abroad to work in the diplomatic service.
Semen (Semyon) Andreev; Fedor (Fyodor) Bogdanov; Avraam Pavlovich Veselovsky; Isaak Pavlovich Veselovsky; Fedor (Fyodor) Pavlovich Veselovsky; Petr Ivanov Volkov; Ivan Gramotin; Yakov Gramotin; Petr Gubin; Samoilo Kopyev; Vasily Kurdevsky; Aleksey Nikitin
Teaching methods and materials:
In his letter to A.H. Francke dated March 1704, Glück described briefly the methods implemented for teaching languages in his school. A lesson usually started as follows: the pupils had spontaneously to read one chapter of the bible and translate it into Russian. Afterwards, they had to repeat the content and draw a conclusion. Since the number of manuals was insufficient, pupils often had to copy books by hand. This was the case, for example, with J.A. Comenius’ “Vestibulum”, a dictionary, which was transcribed by the students, who also added a Russian translation (see letter from Glück to Francke, in Winter, 1953, p. 377).

Comenius, Johann Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. 
Comenius, Johann Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […],
Comenius, Johann Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698).
It is not quite clear, which editions of Comeniusʼ books were used at Glück’s school. What we know is that Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis pictus” into Russian. The “Vestibulum” was completed by the end of 1703 and Glück addressed a petition to the tsar to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, стр. 47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished. 
One of Glückʼs translations of the “Orbis pictus”, which was marginalised by J.W. Paus, is kept in the manuscript section of the Library of the Academy of Sciences in St Petersburg (BAN, otd. ruk., osn. sobr. 26.3.50.).
Other texts, used in language classes at Glück’s school:
Lutheran bible; Lutheran catechism; German chants; French grammar
The texts were translated or adapted by J.E. Glück for his Russian pupils.
Language and other teaching books by the:
Unfinished manuscript of a Russian Grammar (1704)
The manuscript contains two parts: etymology and syntax. The other classic parts of a grammar, orthography and prosody, are missing. The grammar, written by Glück from 1703 onwards, was intended to help foreigners to learn Russian. One target group might have been the teachers of Glück’s school, for whom it was necessary to learn Russian. Glück’s reference was the Slavonic Grammar of Meletij Smotryckij (ed. 1648), in which Glück tried to find examples of contemporary Russian language. The systematic organization of Glück’s grammar was based on the Latin school grammar of Johann Georg Seybold (4th issue, Nürnberg 1675). The manuscript of Glück’s Russian grammar was edited by H. Keipert, B.A. Uspenskij and V.M. Živov in 1994. The grammar is one of the earliest grammatico-graphical works in the Russian language.

Hübner, J. Kurze Fragen aus der neuen und alten Geographie, Leipzig, 1693.
J.E. Glück together with J.W. Paus was charged with the instruction of Czarevitch Alexej Petrovich. In this context, the popular teaching manual “Short questions from old and new geography” by Johann Hübner was translated into Russian. The manuscript is preserved in the manuscript section of the Academy of Sciences in the estate of J.W. Paus. Following the previous research literature, it is not quite clear whether Glück or Paus was the author of this translation (see Glück, Polanska, 2005, p. 111f.). 

52 Lutheran hymns
Glück translated 52 Lutheran hymns into Russian for the use in his classes. The hymns, preserved in the estate of Paus, were edited by Perec, 1902, p. 7-84.

Translations of the New and Old Testament and the catechism into Latvian (New Testament, Riga 1685, Old Testament, Riga 1689).
