Personal records: (*1775, Russian Empire) Son of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1788 to 1800, he studied at Kharkiv Collegium up to the theological class.
Career: Ivan Gnedich began teaching Latin when he was still a theology student and continued his teaching career after graduation. In 1799–1801, he taught Latin and other disciplines in the grammar classes at Kharkiv Collegium.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1799–1801).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
During the teaching career of Ivan Gnedich, more than 500 students were enrolled at Kharkiv Collegium (for example, in the 1798–1799 school year there were 531 students, in 1800–1801 – 686). In 1799, he taught Latin in the middle and later in the higher grammar classes. There were more than 100 students in his class.
Most of the students at Kharkiv Collegium were from families of clergy (although, students coming from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). It is known that at the time there were more than ten children of lay parents in the grammar classes.
Teaching methods and materials: Ivan Gnedich taught Latin starting from the middle grammar class. In this class, students studied the rules of grammar and grammatical analysis, and did translation exercises. These activities continued into the higher grammar class. Students were supposed to converse in Latin, as well. Latin grammar classes at Kharkiv Collegium were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The Collegium had a great number of books by this author, published in different years, so that each student had a book. The surviving school exercises used at the Collegium show that the student translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for doing exercises. The rector of Saint Petersburg Academic Gymnasium, Martin Schwanwitz, participated in the translation of the book. The Collegium had a great number of Lange’s “School Dialogues” as well, published in different years, including those in Latin, published earlier in Halle. Personal records: (or Gaudenti, Godenti Gatrani; Cyrillic: Годенти, Годендий, Готенди, Геденти, Годенди; Петр Михайлов сын) (1700-06-02, Rimini – 1781-12-24, Vienna). Married to: Anna Pavlovna Stepanova (?) († 1765-03-17, Prague?) Religion: Catholic.
Education: Jesuit College in Rimini.
Career:
Italian teacher.
In letters written to his former teacher Giovanni Bianchi in the early 1730s, Godenti complains about his work in Milan with a master whose name is unknown. In the second half of the 1730s and early 1740s he became an Italian teacher for foreigners in Paris; his address was “maître de langue Italienne dans le Bureau de Monsieur Fontanieu à Paris” (Italian teacher in the office of Mr Fontanieu in Paris), probably G.-M. A. Fontanieu, a French official and historian. In Paris Godenti met “count Tencin” (Semen Kirillovich Naryshkin, a Russian aristocrat and diplomat), who later helped him to leave Russia. His first Russian pupil in Paris was Aleksandr Mikhailovich Golitsyn, the future field marshal general.
Godenti arrived in Russia in 1742 with a recommendation from A.D. Kantemir. He  lived and worked in Moscow, then in Saint Petersburg and left the country at the beginning of 1761.
Papers from the Archive of the Academy of Sciences and Godenti’s letters certify that he started working at the Academy School on 12 August 1748, succeeding P.A. Leroi who had taken leave from the Academy, and was granted a salary of 400 roubles. At the time he was probably already employed by Aleksei K. Razumovskii, whose brother Kirill was President of the Academy: in the following years in documents of the Academy he is called “teacher  of Count Aleksei Razumovskii” and he often brings his requests to borrow books from the library. 
On 18 January 1752, after the death of one of the French teachers of the school, Godenti applied for his post “at the same conditions as in the past year 1748” (St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences. f. 3, op. 1, № 161, fol. 426). He occupied this post until the end of 1760, when he asked  to be dismissed in order to leave Russia. 
Godenti’s teaching and competence were apparently highly appreciated. In a project for the organization of teaching at the Academy school (1758), M.V. Lomonosov suggested engaging him for the advanced French course (M.V. Lomonosov, Polnoe sobranie sochinenii, Moscow-Leningrad 1955, vol. 9, p. 513). In 1754 at the  request of the Academy Chancellery, S.P. Krasheninnikov and K.-F. Moderach wrote a report on the teachers and pupils of the School. Godendi was said to be «A worthy teacher of French and Italian, both for his solid preparation and decent behaviour. And if he were able to give the same hours as the other teachers, there would nothing better and it would be possible to do without one of the French teachers» (St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences. f. 3. Op- 9. ed. khr. 57). After Elisabeth Petrovna’s decree of 5 May 1757 requiring foreign tutors to pass an examination, Godenti was asked more than once to examine candidates (St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences, f.3. op.1, N.831, fol.63, 64, 69).
He took leave from the Academy on 28 August 1760 and received a certificate in Russian and Latin stating that he had taught «diligently and assiduously» («docuisse industrie…gessisseque se honestissime», St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences. f.3. op.1, N.825, fol.149, 150).
He left Russia at the beginning of 1761, overcoming the obstacles that his wife’s family had for a long time put in his way. He was allowed to leave with his son, while his wife joined him the following year with the help of A.V. Olsuf’ev (Archive of foreign Policy of the Russian Empire, f. 2/6. Vnutrennie kollezhskie dela, N. 3564, Reshenie KID po prosheniiam ital’iantsa Godenti i ego zheny ob otpuske za granitsu i vydache im pasportov i perepiska po etomu voprosu (12 December 1747 – 14 December 1761).
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School (at the Academy of Sciences, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
High nobility.
Golitsyn (Princess Tat’iana Borisovna Golitsyna, widow of general M.M. Golitsyn); Razumovskii (Count Aleksey Grigor’evich Razumovskii)
Godenti wrote to G. Bianchi that at the beginning of his stay in Russia he had worked for several aristocrats, but mainly in the house of Princess Tatiana Golitsyna. His service with Count Alexey Razumovskii apparently began at the same time as his appointment at the Academy School and consisted firstly in teaching the children of the former’s brother, Count Kirill Razumovskii.
Prince Dmitrii Mikhailovich, later ambassador in Vienna, brother of Prince Alexandr Mikhailovich Golitsyn; all sons of Count Kirill Razumovskii.
Teaching methods and materials: «He taught French, sometimes also Italian, history and geography, according to situations and needs» (St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences, f. 3. op. 1. N. 825, f. 147v.)
Language and other teaching books by the:
[G. Bonechi], Bellerophon opera répresenté pour la premiere fois a St. Petersbourg sur le nouveau theatre de la Cour..le 25 novembre 1750, St. Petersbourg, 1750.
The name of the translator is not indicated, but a letter by D.I. Shumakher, librarian of the Academy, asks Godenti to translate the opera enclosed with his message «pour être imprimé incessamment» (St. Petersburg Branch of the Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences, f. 3, op. 1, № 38, fol. 169, November 1750). «Bellerophon» by G. Bonechi (music by F. Araya) was the only opera whose French translation was published by the Academy in 1750.

Personal records: Married to: Marie-Marguerite Richard (*Strasbourg), a governess at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts from 1767 to 1772. Daughter: Jeanne-Françoise-Catherine Godfrin (*St. Petersburg, bapt. at St. Catherine of Alexandria on 18 January 1769; godfather: Jean-François Grolier; Jeanne Cuvillier).
Career: Governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg since 1767. At the Academy council meeting on 10 March 1771, the deputy inspector of the Academy, Perrin, resigned and was replaced by Professor Godfrin, whose salary was increased by 100 rubles. However, on 20 November 1772, he was dismissed: he created complications for Burdin de Saint-Martin, the interim inspector of the Academy, and was criticized by other governors, such as Thys, who wrote that “Godfrin was dragging me down, inspiring everyone with aversion for me, as if my company were pernicious. I wanted to believe nothing since at the same time he claimed to have all kinds of regard for me, but shortly after, two governesses and a governor who left the Academy at the same time spoke to me in the same way”; “Mr. Godfrin, continued Thys, told me that I was right to stay at the Academy, since if I left, it would be impossible for me to find employment elsewhere.” The certificate issued to him indicated that he incurred no blame for his work at the Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (from 1767; St. Petersburg).

Personal records: (Secular name: Andrey) (1671, Stayki village of Kyiv sotnia in the Kiev regiment, Russian Empire – 1737-04-10, Vyatka, Russian Empire). L. Gorka was from a Cossack family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class.
Career: Immediately after graduation, Lavrenty Gorka took monastic vows at the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra and, having the rank of hieromonk, in the academic year 1706–1707, he was a teacher in the syntax class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, then he taught in the poetics, rhetoric and philosophy classes. From 1713 onwards, Lavrenty Gorka was hegumen of the Vydubychi Monastery in Kyiv; from April 1722, he was archimandrite of the Moscow Resurrection New Jerusalem Monastery. He did not enter the latter position, because he was appointed ober-hieromonk of the squadron commanded by Peter I and departing for Persia. He returned to the Moscow Resurrection New Jerusalem Monastery the same year. From 8 September 1723 he was bishop of Astrakhan, from 22 May 1727, bishop of Veliky Ustyug, from 1731, bishop of Ryazan, and from 26 September 1733 until his death, he was bishop of Vyatka and Great Perm.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the syntax class, in which Lavrenty Gorka taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Lavrenty Gorka, students studied grammar and syntax rules; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. As did other syntax teachers’ students, Lavrenty Gorka’s students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The library of the St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery in Kyiv still has a collection, which includes a series of exercises performed by Yakov (Jacob) Rudinsky, one of Lavrenty Gorky’s students, under his guidance (сборник «экзерциций» и «оккупаций» - a collection of “exercises” and “occupations”, No. 505, ff. 60-81, 164-168). These exercises reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in a syntax class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Т. 1–4. Cracoviae [Kraków]: sumptu et typis haerodum Francisci Caesarii, 1668.
Language and other teaching books by the: The handwritten poetics and rhetoric courses that Lavrenty Gorka gave at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy are still available. While teaching in the poetics class, he wrote the tragicomedy “Joseph the Patriarch ...” (1708), based on a biblical story, traditional for a school drama. As the bishop of Vyatka and Great Perm, he did a lot to streamline the educational and organizational life of the Vyatka Seminary, including the transfer of his personal library.

Personal records: (Secular name: Ioakim Andreevich) (1705-09-08, The regiment town of Pryluky, Russian Empire – 1754-12-10, The town of Grayvoron, Belgorod province, Russian Empire). He was born into a Cossack-gentry family of the bunchuk comrade, Akim Gorlenko. His grandfather was Daniil Apostol, a Mirgorod colonel and a hetman. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1713 onwards, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class. During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar and syntax.
Career:
In August 1729, he was appointed analogy class teacher; from 1731 onwards, he worked as a syntax class teacher. From 1734 onwards, he was hieromonk and examiner at the Kyiv Metropolia; from 1735 onwards, he was a member of the consistory. From June 1737 onwards, he was hegumen of the Saviour-Transfiguration Mhar Monastery (Poltava diocese); from 1744, he was archimandrite of the same monastery. In January 1745, he was appointed head of the Trinity Lavra of Saint Sergius. From 2 June 1748 until his death, he was Bishop of Belgorod and Oboyan.
As bishop of Belgorod and Oboyan, Joasaph Gorlenko did a lot for the development of the Kharkiv Collegium. He repeatedly visited the collegium and thanks to him, “philosophical general debates were sent out” more than once. He took books for reading from the library of the Kharkiv Collegium. At the same time, the library catalogue shows that Joasaph Gorlenko transferred a number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries concerning different languages to the Kharkiv Collegium. Joasaph Gorlenko is also known as the author of several literary works, teachings, and prayers.
In 1911, he was canonized.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied in the analogy and syntax classes, in which Joasaph Gorlenko taught. In total, more than 600 people studied at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the late 1720s.
Most of the students at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), in which Ioasaph Gorlenko taught. The teacher also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, “De institutione Grammatica”, by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Clergy; Cossacks.

Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Filipp Goshkevich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. Personal records: (or Grechka) (Russian Empire – 1812, Pereiaslav, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Stepan Grechka studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career:
Soon after his graduation in the 1764–1765 school year, Stepan Grechina began teaching in the syntax and grammar classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Then he was a teacher in subsequent classes (the poetics, rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes). He was ordained a priest, but did not give up his teaching. He was a priest at Pereiaslav Resurrection Cathedral and a member of the Pereiaslav consistory, protoiereus from October 1780 onwards. He retired from teaching for reasons of age.
Stepan Grechina was known in Pereiaslav as a brilliant preacher and connoisseur of the Latin language. Numerous contemporaries characterized him as such. An especially high estimation of Grechina’s talent was presented by the famous preacher Ioann Levanda from the Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv (who taught at Pereiaslav Collegium for some time, as well) in his letters and “Words” (Леванда, Иоанн, Слова и речи Иоанна Леванды, протоиерея Киево-Софийского собора: в 3 ч., St. Petersburg, 1821). Historians of Ukrainian literature have repeatedly questioned the prototype of Grigory Grechka from “The Twins” by Taras Shevchenko. Researchers believe unanimously that Stepan Grechina (Grechka) had served as such.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1764–1800?).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. In the 1764–1765 school year, 37 students were enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes, in which Stepan Grechina taught. In total, 164 students were enrolled at the Collegium that year. In subsequent years, the number of students in these classes gradually grew. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low-middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. Thus, in the 1764--1765 school year, out of the 37 students enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Stepan Grechina, 25 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Stepan Grechina, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Stepan Grechina worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at the time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereiaslav Collegium. The surviving school exercises intended for the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. Stepan Grechina was repeatedly mentioned as a “rare connoisseur of the Latin language” in Pereiaslav bishops’ decrees. Ilia Timkovsky, a future professor at Kharkiv University, who was taught by Stepan Grechina at the Pereiaslav Collegium, also characterised him as the “most skilled Latinist of the time.” [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (or Grené). Originally from Brie. Married to: Marguerite Patine (or Patin).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, German, geography, history, arithmetic, geometry, surveying, measuring, garden distributions, hydraulics (?)
Career:
Colonist, then tutor. He was part of the group recruited by Philippe-Auguste Delesalle, who was sent by Russian diplomats to Hamburg in April 1765 and brought to Russia the following May under the supervision of the Frenchman Larmée and at the expense of the recruiters Meunier de Précourt, De Bof (De Bosse), and Coulliette d’Hauterive. Before going to Oranienbaum, the gathering place for the colonists, Claude Grenet presented himself at the Chancellery for foreign guardianship, declaring that he had already established himself as a gardener on Kamenny Island in St. Petersburg and that he had received permission from the recruiters to leave the status of colonist. However, the Chancellery refused him the necessary passport to live freely in the empire. In 1771, he requested to be hired as a tutor at the Academy of Fine Arts school, "making known his talents": "He knows the French language by principle [grammar – editor's note], Geography, History in brief, Arithmetic, Geometry, Surveying and measuring, all types of garden distributions and fountains as part of hydraulics, speaks and reads a little German." He was hired at the Academy in 1771, as was his wife. The guardianship Chancellery asked the Academy to repay its debt of 205 rubles and 36 kopecks by deducting 25 rubles from his annual salary. In January 1772, a dispute broke out between the French tutors, Mmes Lefebvre and Grenet, and Messrs. Grenet and Saunier: the inspector of the Academy preferred to dismiss them all.
The Grenets were found in Moscow in 1777. Claude Grenet registered a record there on 1 March 1786, at the French vice-consulate. It was probably he who was a merchant in Moscow in 1792 and a creditor of the merchant François-Étienne Varin. He resided in the Penza government when he took the oath of 1793.
He was the godfather of Jeanne-Marie-Èva de Monbourguet or Maubourguet on 17 December 1782, and of Marie Martin on 26 June 1788, at Saints Apostles Peter and Paul in Moscow.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts school (?) (1771–1772; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (or Grigorowicz, Iłarion) (1696-12-20, The sotnia town of Sosnytsia in the Chernihiv Regiment settlement, Russian Empire – 1760-12-03, Moscow). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Ilarion Grigorovich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. During his studies, in 1724, he took monastic vows at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv.
Career: Immediately after graduation in the 1725–1726 school year, Ilarion Grigorovich began teaching the syntax class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In 1726, he was appointed to the position of rhetoric teacher at the newly-established Kharkiv Collegium; from 1729 onwards, he taught philosophy and was the Prefect. He served as archimandrite at the Assumption Monastery in Svyatye Gory from June 29, 1733; the Saint Nicholas Monastery in Belgorod from 1738; the Savvino-Storozhevsky Monastery from 1740; the Chudov Monastery in Moscow from 1740; and the New Jerusalem Resurrection Monastery from 1744. From 1748 until his death, he was bishop of Krutitsy (of Saray and Don).
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1725–1726); Kharkiv Collegium (1726–1733).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the syntax class, which Ilarion Grigorovich taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Ilarion Grigorovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time: “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. In grammar classes, students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The exercises which have survived reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in a syntax class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (or Grigorowicz; Weniamin; hieromonk name: Vinary or Vikary) (Russian Empire – 1745, Kyiv). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. During his studies, he took monastic vows in the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar and syntax.
Career: In the 1734–1735 school year, he taught in the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1736 on, he served as hieromonk. In the 1736–1739 school years, he taught in the subsequent grammar classes: from 1739 onwards, he was a steward (manciple) at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv. In 1740, he went to Petersburg to address the Academy’s financial affairs. He came back to the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv in 1742 and remained there until his death.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1734–1739).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the grammar classes in which Veniamin Grigorovich taught.  In total, in the 1737–1738 school year, there were 494 students at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class) in which Veniamin Grigorovich taught. The teacher also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time: “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: Probably originally from Saint-Menge (Vosges).
Career: “Master of the French language,” he was in St. Petersburg in August 1776 and requested to take the exam for tutors at the Academy of Sciences to obtain a certificate of competence. According to the examiners, he “speaks and writes French correctly, has sufficient knowledge of the principles, and is capable of teaching,” furthermore, he could teach history, geography, Latin, and German, which he knew a little. However, he had only general knowledge in history and geography. He requested a passport to stay in Russia in August 1776.

Personal records:
(*1743, Gigny, Franche-Comté) Father: Pierre Gréa, a notary in Franche-Comté. Mother: Thérèse Colin (residing in Lons-le-Saulnier). Brother: Claude-François-Augustin Gréa, a lawyer at the Parliament. Sisters:
  • Agathe Gréa, widow of Seyriau;
  • Jeanne-Françoise Gréa.
Nieces: Suzanne and Julie Courbe, daughters of his sister Françoise Gréa. Aunt: Jeanne-Françoise Colin. Religion: Catholic.
Education: He studied law at the University of Besançon.
Career:
Tutor. After studying, he went to Russia and was in St. Petersburg in 1773. He worked as a tutor in the Adadurov family (probably the family of Vasili Adadurov (1709–1780), a mathematician, writer, translator, and academician, notably of Vasili Vasilievich Adadurov (1765–1845), a future military major general). In January 1773, he requested to take an exam at the St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences to obtain a tutor's certificate. The examiner L. Bachmeister certified that he had a very good command of French and Latin.
He was an inspector at the Noble Cadet Corps when he filed his will at the consulate's chancery on 10/21 November 1777. In it, he stipulated that the amount of his estate would be sent to his mother, who would ensure its distribution among his designated heirs. The executor of the will was Mr. de La Biche, deputy governor and tutor to the Empress's pages.
Teaching institutions and families: Adadurov family; Noble Cadet Corps (1770s; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records:
(1748-08, Lunéville – 1817, Russia; she had lost her mind during the fire of Moscow in 1812). Father: Barthélemy Guibal (1699, Nîmes – 1757-05-05, Lunéville), sculptor to the King of Poland. Mother: Jeanne Lécrivain (†1788, Moscow; inventory after death on 5 April 1788). Married to: 1.) Louis Carbonier (*Vesoul – †1780, Luxeuil), architect and hydraulic engineer at the Senate of St. Petersburg (marriage on 25 January 1770, at the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in St. Petersburg; without her mother’s consent); 2.) Jean Perret, major general. Children from the 1st marriage:
  • Louis-Barthélemy Carbonier (1770-11-22/12-03, St. Petersburg – 1836-04-27/05-09, St. Petersburg);
  • Lisinka Carbonier (1773–1773).
Career:
Governess. In 1774, under pressure from her sisters according to her husband, she entered the service of General Purpur, who was widowed, as the governess of his daughter. She was living in St. Petersburg in August 1775, her engagement with General Purpur having ended. Due to an illness, she delayed her departure but committed by an act in the form of a transaction on 23 August 1775, before the French consul, to join her husband in France, with their son, in January 1776; she protested and revoked this act on 6 January 1776. Her husband demanded her return in August 1777. She had invoked the nullity of her marriage in 1776 to obtain a legal separation of body and property in the Russian courts (request of 10 August 1776, sent notably to the bailiwick of Vesoul). The separation was pronounced by the Justice College of Finland on 7 February 1778.
Mrs. Carbonier had “changed her religion, embracing Lutheranism,” and according to Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon), she had secretly remarried a Swiss named Peret (also known as Perette), who was said to have become an aide-de-camp to Paul I, from whom she claimed to have had the child that Mr. Carbonnier was demanding.
Teaching institutions and families: Purpur family.
Students and their social status: Daughter of General Purpur.

Personal records: (*1742, Paris) Son of a retired military officer. Religion: Catholic.

Personal records:
(*ar. 1771) Originally from Metz. The hypothesis of Hainglaise's English origin (made by Mr. Ophee) is based on the text of one of the songs composed by him, but it is likely incorrect. Married to: Jeanne de La Traverse (*ar. 1776, Moscow), daughter of Jean-Balthazar de La Traverse and Françoise Moutendre. Children:
  • Anne-Françoise-Antoinette Hainglaise (*1797, St. Petersburg), married in 1818 to Jean-Pierre Chapuit (*1787) (witness: Basile Fabre, doctor of medicine);
  • Alexandre Hainglaise (*ar. 1800);
  • Élisabeth Hainglaise (*1805, St. Petersburg).
Career:
Governor, merchant, and likely author (and publisher?) of a musical periodical. He resided in St. Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793 with his wife. He was a witness at the marriage of Bouliant/Bourdon on 3 October 1792, and at the marriage of Du Rosay/Legros on 24 July 1793 at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in St. Petersburg.
In 1806, Hainglaise was said to be a merchant and lived in the first part of St. Petersburg in the house of merchant Safonov; he then took the oath of allegiance to Russia.
Language and other teaching books by the: He was certainly the publisher of the famous weekly Journal d’airs italiens, français, et russes avec accompagnement de Guitare par J.B. Hainglaise, St. Petersburg, chez l’auteur et Gerstenberg et Dittmar. It began appearing in 1796, and in 1797 its title was modified to Journal de guitare par J.B. Hainglaise, second year. The journal continued until 1798. In issue No. 4, 1796, it was announced that subscribers could collect the journal on Thursdays at the author's home, at Mr. Schreiber's house, 84, Malaya Millionnaya Street.

Personal records:
(in Russia: Ganotel, by deformation) (*Sedan).
Likely the brother or son of Jean Hanotel de Léry.
Married.
Career:
Governor then merchant. A professor at the educational boarding school of Nikolay Baman in the 1790s in St. Petersburg, he held a certificate from the German School that authorized him to teach. This boarding school was one of the largest at the time, with nearly seventy students. In 1793, he taught at the boarding school of Wilhelm Rokerhover (?), along with another Frenchman, Girardin.
He resided in St. Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793. He moved to Moscow in 1795 with his wife. A registered merchant in 1797 in the 3rd guild of Moscow, he lived near the Blacksmiths' Bridge, in the house of Prince Sibirski (most likely Vasili Fiodorovich Sibirski, a general of infantry who was to be exiled by Paul I), and ran a business selling "fashionable" items.
His wife was a dressmaker for women. She established her workshop in 1795 in Moscow on Tverskaya Street, in the house of Major General Fiodor Ivanovich Kiselev, at No. 197, and employed apprentices there. In 1797, her shop was located in the house of Prince Sibirski (where she lived with her husband), under the Petrovskaya pharmacy. She announced at the end of June that she had just received hats from St. Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Educational boarding school of Nikolay Baman (1790s; St. Petersburg); boarding school of Wilhelm Rokerhover (?).

Career: Tutor. In 1762, he became an appointed professor of French in the "lower class" at the gymnasium of Moscow University; his colleagues included Bonald and Orlov, who taught French in the second etymological class, Cotti, who taught French in the syntactical class, and Lavie, who was responsible for the French style class. In 1767, he received a reprimand for failing to attend classes.
Teaching institutions and families: Gymnasium of Moscow University (from 1762).
Teaching methods and materials: One of the books that Hatton used was the Lexicon by Volchkov.

Personal records: (*Prussia – 1737-12-07, Yekaterinburg, Russian Empire). Married. Son: Johann (*1737, Yekaterinburg). Brother-in-law: Johann. Religion: Lutheran.
Career:
Before signing a contract to teach at the Yekaterinburg school, he worked as a clerk in Saint Petersburg. Other information is not available in the documents. Bernhard Störmer, a teacher at the academic school, recommended and introduced him to the Chancellery of the Academy of Sciences, as his assistant in the teaching of the German language at the Yekaterinburg school. Heinsch signed the contract which stated that he would work in Yekaterinburg as an assistant to Störmer for five years. The contract was signed in the Senate on 13 June 1735 and stipulated that Heinsch’s annual salary would be equal to 200 roubles, that it would be given every fourth month of the year, and that the state would provide him with a flat near the school. For travelling to Yekaterinburg, 50 roubles were added to the salary. That money was used to pay rides on two carts. He was probably a young man, recently married, quite wealthy, possibly due to his wife’s dowry. He worked for about two years at the German school in Yekaterinburg. According to the property inventory compiled after his death, he had a good income and lent money to residents of Yekaterinburg; there were 13 people among his debtors, including Störmer (10 roub.), Soechting (16 roub. 50 kopecks), the doctor Siemens (34 roub.), the pharmacist Tamm (15 roub.) and other Russian citizens and foreigners.
Johann Christoph Heinsch arrived in Yekaterinburg with his wife and underage brother-in-law Johann, the younger brother of his wife. At the beginning of 1737, a son was born to the family. His name was Johann. His wife died after giving birth to the baby. At the time of his death in December 1737, Heinsch’s son was only 11 weeks-old. The German pastor Laurentius Soechting took care of his son, and the Swedish captain Karl Brandt, the chief of police in Yekaterinburg, took care of his brother-in-law. Heinsch did not have other relatives in Russia. In 1746, his wife’s brothers claimed their inheritance rights.
Teaching institutions and families: German school (1735–1737, Yekaterinburg).
Students and their social status:
Officers; factory administration; clerks; foremen; lower military ranks.
Sons of officers (one son of a captain, two sons of lieutenants), factory administration workers (two sons of supervisors, one son of a treasurer), clerks (two sons of junior office clerks, five sons of copyists, one son of a courier), three sons of foremen, lower military ranks (three sons of soldiers, a son of a dragoon).
Heinsch taught in the lower (third) form at the Yekaterinburg German School. At the opening of the school, in November 1735, eight students were accepted, four more enrolled in January 1736 and five more in February. From October 1736 to December 1737, he taught 21 students out of the 41 who were studying at the school.
The age of the students ranged from 10 to 18 (two students were 10 years old, nine students were 14 years old, four students were 15, and there was also one student for each of the following ages: 11, 12, 15, 16, 17 and 18).
Teaching methods and materials:
The teacher did not teach the fundamentals of grammar. Students began to study German grammar in the 2nd form.  Apparently, teaching the basics of the Latin language began in the 3rd form and was introduced with the consent of the head of factories V.N. Tatishchev.
Learning German and Latin began with the study of the respective alphabet books, then the students proceeded to study pronunciation, as evidenced by the reports of the students’ progress, submitted every four months to the Chancellery of the factory headquarters.
Apparently, the lack of previous practice of language teaching in Heinsch’s experience affected the rate of learning. Students of the 3rd form advanced much more slowly in learning German compared to the teenagers enrolled in the 1st and 2nd forms at the same time. To some extent this was a result of studying the basics of Latin as well.

Personal records: (*1730, Silesia) Brother: Benjamin Heinzelmann.
Career: In 1766, he arrived in Saint Petersburg, where he served in a variety of merchant families as an attendant. In 1777, he opened a private school in Yamskaya Street. But in January 1780, his brother Benjamin Heinzelmann died and Ernst Christian took over the direction of the private school opened by Benjamin to support his widow, who was left with three children and was expecting another. The school was located near the Blue Bridge. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which checked the school in April 1780, noted that the only room owned by the family was at the same time a classroom. In 1784, the widow Heinzelmann became the owner of the school.
Teaching institutions and families: Private school in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Artisans; raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks).
In 1780, 18 children attended the school: 16 boys and two girls. All of them were day-school students. Peter and Johann Norström, sons of a goldsmith; Maxim Pshenichny; Johann Beckmann, son of a widow; Gustav Sido, son of a hairdresser; Samuel Ban, son of a woodcarver; Johann Romp, son of a blacksmith; Johann Buretti, an Italian; Johann Pinner, son of coppersmiths; Vasily Makarov, son of a postmaster; Pyotr Nikiforov, son of a postman; Jacob Hirschveld, son of a lackey; Gregory and Vasily, children of a lackey; Carl Jurgenson, son of a coachman; Ivan Nikiforov, son of a merchant; Helena Widerberg, daughter of a hairdresser; Catherine Kozman, daughter of a hairdresser. In 1784, 28 children attended the school: 14 boys and 14 girls.

Personal records: (*Memmingen, Bavaria – 1746-04-14, Saint Petersburg). Married to: Brigitta Besson, widow Utermark; marriage concluded on 29 September 1737. Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Hermann joined the Academy School as Latin and German teacher in June 1732. He taught Latin in class four (also called “quarta”) and supervised the teacher Potapski in teaching German in class five (also called “quinta”). Hermann was also charged with writing fair copies of documents for the Academy Chancellery. In 1737 Hermann is documented as teacher in the German class. He received a salary of 200 roubles per year. According to a decree of 5 May 1743, Hermann was discharged, presumably because he did not know Russian. The Academy Chancellery criticised Hermann for using Latin as medium of instruction and proposed that translators or students should take over Hermannʼs class, so that Russian pupils could understand their teacher more easily.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Science (1732–1743, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; merchants; clergy; craftsmen.
In the first half of the 18th century, both the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers, published by Sukhomlinov, list about 820 pupils attending the Academy School during this period of time. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. In 1738, Hermann instructed a group of 11 pupils in German; the latter had been sent to the Academy of Science from the Moscow Slavo-Greco-Latin Academy, among them M.V. Lomonosov, N.I. Popov, I.I. Golubtsev and V.I. Lebedev.
In principle, there were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitz’ report (1736) lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children, whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School, especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants, such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia, to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.
Teaching methods and materials:
Hermann taught Latin and German, i.e. reading, writing, spelling, grammar, conversation and vocabulary exercises, and also arithmetic. A report of December 1737 includes the following note: “Teacher in a German class. He teaches his students the fundamental rules of Latin, makes them translate from Latin into German and from German into Latin, teaches them spelling and arithmetic.” (Сухомлинов 1886, v. 3, p. 580f.).
In February 1738, Christian Hermann gave a detailed report on the 11 muscovite pupils, whom he instructed in German. He describes the progression of the learning contents as follows: 1. reading and writing in German, 2. declination and conjugation, 3. learning by heart and analysing Latin and German dialogues, 4. learning syntactical rules and translating them from Latin to German. Furthermore, pupils received a specific amount of vocabulary each day and had to memorize the words.

Personal records: Married, present in Moscow in 1761 with his wife, father of several children in 1768.
Career: Journalist, translator, and tutor. He was in Russia, in Moscow, around 1761 and published a weekly journal titled Journal des Sciences et des Arts particulièrement consacré à l'instruction de la jeunesse russienne. He corresponded with Marc-Michel Rey, a well-known bookseller in Amsterdam, whom he seems to have known well. He informed him about his periodical: “It has difficulty gaining traction in a country where letters barely pierce their shell [...] But it is impossible for me to do it well without your help,” he wrote to Rey, “and I need all your accuracy for the shipment of the books I will ask you for. Needing these books, it will not cost me more than to try a small business.” He sent Rey three furs for sale in 1760. Hernandez wanted to provide Rey with money to pay for the shipment of books, but also to print “one or two works” there. Hernandez hesitated about the choice of transport for these shipments, directly from Amsterdam to St. Petersburg or from Hamburg, via Lübeck to St. Petersburg. The books were to be addressed to MM. Le Maignien in St. Petersburg, who were informed. He showed interest in the periodicals Nouvelle Bigarrure and Nouvelliste Econome, and requested similar sheets from Holland. He also asked Rey to send him Etrennes Mignonnes, up to 800 copies (later he requested 400, including one hundred bound) that he was sure he could sell in Russia. Upon the release of his review, he planned to send fifty copies to Rey to sell in England. He proposed to Rey to send him “some unfortunate man of letters burdened with his person,” and in September 1761, Rey indeed sent him Chavanne, who was very well received by Le Maignien and arrived in October in Moscow. In one of the letters, there is a long list of works that Hernandez requested from his bookseller (letter of 18/29 October 1761, Fransen, 1915, p. 5). Among the books he requested in addition to one copy were La Nouvelle Héloïse (12 copies), les Œuvres of Rousseau (4 copies), and the works of Voltaire (vol. 18 in 16 copies), the Mémoires sur Fontenelle by Abbé Trublet (2 copies), the Dictionnaire portatif of Richelet (2 copies), the Eléments de l'histoire by Vallemont (2 copies), an Histoire du prince Aprius (4 copies), the Livre des enfants (2 copies), Etudes des demoiselles (2 copies), etc. Almanacs sold particularly well; however, Hernandez had to return to Rey the Histoire de Naples by Giannone, which he could not sell in Moscow. Hernandez admitted to Rey: “I find myself very well in Russia, where a man of letters is very well regarded.” In 1761, for nine months, he had been a tutor in the family of Prince Alexey Sergeyevich Golitsyn, whom he found very amiable. “The whole thing earns me 2400# silver from France with board, 2 footmen, a carriage, and 4 horses just for me [...] Only the harshness of the climate will drive me away from here. But I must stay for at least 4 to 5 years. Later, he moved to the family of the Dolgoruki princes. In 1768, he was preparing to leave Moscow with his wife and children; he lived in the house of Prince Vasili Sergeyevich Dolgorukov (†1803, son of Prince Sergey Grigorievich, a Russian diplomat in Paris, Vienna, London, and Warsaw), behind the Prechistenski Gate, in the parish of the Church of the Virgin of Rzhev.
Teaching institutions and families: Golitsyn, Dolgoruki families
Students and their social status: Nobility
Language and other teaching books by the: He is known for his English translation of J.-H. Grose's book Voyage aux Indes Orientales, “translated from English by Mr. Hernandez, one of the authors of the Journal Etranger,” Lille, Veuve Panckoucke, 1758, 1 vol., in-12°. He translated English articles and was one of the authors of the Journal Etranger from 1756 to 1758 (this journal was directed and written, among others, by Abbé Prévost, Suard, Rousseau, Fréron, Abbé Arnaud, Diderot...). He published a weekly journal titled Journal des Sciences et des Arts particulièrement consacré à l'instruction de la jeunesse russienne par mr. Hernandez, ci-devant, l'un des auteurs du Journal Etranger. This journal was printed at Moscow University by the printer T.S. Höjer, and its two volumes were published in 1761. The content of the Journal was very varied: thus, in the first issue, topics included gardening, agriculture, economics, navigation, miniature painting, architecture, astronomy, physics, and medicine (deafness, inoculation). Other frequently addressed themes in the journal included geography, mathematics, engraving, history, music, technology, in short, all fields of knowledge. Hernandez regularly included announcements of new books, particularly English books, and published many translations from English in the journal.

Personal records: (*1745, Lignica, Prussian Silesia) Married to: a German woman; marriage concluded in 1773 in Saint Petersburg.
Education: He studied at the orphan school in Bunzlau, then at the school of Lignica; he studied theology, philosophy and foreign languages, but he had to give up his studies for lack of money.
Career: In 1770, he went to Saint Petersburg. He founded his school in the yard of the Finnish Church just after his arrival in Saint Petersburg. On 16 October 1775 the following announcement was published in the Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti (No. 83): “Teacher Hertwig, who lives in the courtyard of the Finnish Church, publishes this to notify the public that the school that he has recently established, and where he teaches German, French, Russian and Latin, as well as geography, violin and clavier playing and arithmetic too, will now provide a dance class twice a week. For those who want their children to be half-day boarders, he assures that he admits children to his school “at a cheap price”. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which checked this school in April 1780, noted that Hertwig and his wife spoke good German and some Russian. The inside of the school was quite spacious, but humid, because it was located on the ground floor. The school was attended by 30 students: 24 boys and six girls. Two boys were boarders. The Commission noted that the school taught German, French, Latin, arithmetic and geography. The school had two teaching assistants: Georg Girschgauer, a German from Vienna, and Johann Galla, a German who was born in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: His own private school in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Artisans; military men; musicians; merchants.
In April 1780, the school had two boarders: Vasily Petrov and Alexander Gorecki, sons of merchants; the other students, 22 boys and six girls, were not boarders: Peter Ferschter, son of a musician; Hendeman, son of a merchant; Jacob Gramatina, son of an interpreter; Ivan Trubayev, son of a barber; Johann Kotomk, son of ascore-keeper; Johann Vagnec, son of a blacksmith; Ferster, son of a musician; Seger, son of an architect; Peter Joseph, son of a lackey; Peter Buyanin, son of a dancer; Dmitry (no family name), son of a doorman; Sinitsim, son of an officer; Mangenrod, son of a blacksmith; Ceteus, son of a widow; Nicolay (no family name), son of a secretary; Rehl, son of a kettledrummer; Michael Poltater, son of a pharmacist; Schindrer, son of a joiner; Jacob Liflyanev, son of a court counsellor; Nivelsky, son of an officer; Kondrat (no family name), son of a hairdresser; Tatarinok, son of a dancer; Anna Naton, daughter of a musician; Elizabeth Robadovskaya, daughter of a hairdresser; Katherine and Anna, daughters of a blacksmith; Anna Pinge, daughter of a hairdresser; Dorothea Franz, daughter of a chef.

Personal records: (or Herwardt, Herrwartt) (Holy Roman Empire – 1776-09-04, Saint Petersburg). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Studies in jurisprudence and mathematics.
Career:
Johann Georg von Herwart used to be a maths teacher and worked in this profession for several years in his native country. He was also involved in land measurement in Gotha and Weimar.
Herwart came to Russia in 1732. He worked as private tutor and started to study jurisprudence and maths at the academic University, where he later became a “Kandidat” in jurisprudence and mathematics.
In May 1748, Herwart was recruited by the Academy School to replace Michael Groening, who left the school the same month. Herwart worked in the higher/upper (also called: first) German class and the lower French class until November 1750. His annual salary amounted to 300 roubles. There is evidence of several very negative criticisms on his pedagogical work. In January 1750, Johann Eberhard Fischer, the rector of the Academy School, reported: “[...] his intellect, and his knowledge, and his natural talents leave much to be desired. [Сухомлинов, 1900, vol. 10, p. 241f.] In November 1750, professor Stepan Krasheninnikov also assessed Herwartʼs qualification just as negatively: “[...] he is weak in French, and he has bad pronunciation, and nearly the same in German; at least what is true is that he teaches his students English in a disorderly manner, so there is not the slightest hope that the properties of the language can be understood from his teaching; neither does he make an effort to accustom his students to the correct pronunciation of words, and so they read in German in such a way that not only their pronunciation seems hideous to those who know the language, but their reading is incomprehensible as well.” [Сухомлинов, 1900, vol. 10, p. 638.] Furthermore, Krasheninnikov pointed out the unfavourable consequences of Herwartʼs deficient skills: “This being so, the fruitless waste of time under this teaching caused some of the independent students to fall behind in school and to study for a fee on an extracurricular basis, which contributed to a negative image of the school.”  [Сухомлинов, 1900, vol. 10, p. 638.] As a result of this report, Herwart was released from the position as a French teacher (he was replaced by the Frenchman Sougie, who used to teach at the Cadet Corps) and was assigned to support his colleague Oestermann in the lower German class which had quite a lot of pupils. Later on, Herwart was also discharged from this position and left the Academy School. Count Cyril Razumovsky, the Academyʼs president, confirmed in a letter that Herwart was discharged “because of his incompetence and his unsettled lifestyle” [Schröder, 1996, p. 440] and also because he insulted K.F. Moderach, the inspector of the Academy School. In later years, Herwart became inspector of the Artillery and Engineering Cadet Corps.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Science (1748–1750); Artillery and Engineering Cadet Corps, all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Nobility; merchants; craftsmen; civil servants; peasants.
Between 1748 and 1750, the number of pupils attending the Academy School fluctuated between 57 and 89. A significant part of them most likely joined the German class, because all students aiming to study at the Academy's University had to learn German and/or Latin. The names of a large number of these pupils, aged between 6 and 20 years-old, are known and listed in Suchomlinov’s registers, including information about the pupils' social backgrounds and learning progress.
The Academy School was attended by two different categories of students. The first group were pupils in receipt of a government scholarship, the second group were independent (self-funding) pupils. Among the group of independent pupils were nobles and non-nobles and also quite a lot of non-Russian pupils. Scholarship students were often children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School, especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants, such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia, to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.
Teaching methods and materials:
Herwart taught German in the first (upper) German class, French in the lower French class, and also geography and history. In May 1748, the rector of the Academy School, Johann Eberhard Fischer, gave a detailed account of the organisation of the Academy School (Report on Saint-Petersburg Academy School). The aspects ?? and subjects, taught in the first German class, are described as follows: “The first German class is devoted to: the Orthodox religion, review of arithmetic and initial geometry studies. Review of essay rules and demonstration of properties of the German language. Interpretation of a simple writer and interpreting from German into Russian and from Russian into German. Translation from German into Russian and from Russian into German, according to the style and composition used for writing letters. Demonstration of the use of geographical maps, and history teaching. The French language. Calligraphy. Drawing. Dancing.” [Сухомлинов, 1897, vol. 9, p. 183f.] Regarding the number of German lessons in the first German class Fischerʼs organisation plan set up two lessons in the morning on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays. On Wednesday and Saturday mornings, Herwart had to teach geography and history instead of German. In November 1750, as documented by a report of Prof. Krasheninnikov from November 1750, the German lessons in the first German class still took place in the mornings and lasted two hours. The number of French lessons was fewer; in 1748 for example, it was four hours per week.
As for the teaching methods, Fischerʼs organisation plan of the Academy School pointed out that the German teachers, as often as possible, should use German and not Russian as the language of instruction, because the students should learn German and would benefit more from the German and also would get used to it. [“German teachers should offer their teaching in German and not in Russian as much as possible, because it is a way to study German, and the student receives large benefits from teaching offered in German, and gradually gets used to the German language. ” [Сухомлинов, 1897, vol. 9, p. 188.]]

These books were listed in a report written by K.F. Moderach, the inspector of the Academy School, to the Academyʼs chancellery in July 1750. Most of these books were popular textbooks used in Western Europe. Some of them were translated into Russian or complemented by a Russian version (like e.g. Weißmannʼs dictionary, Hübnerʼs questions about geography and Langeʼs dialogues). Others, like Curasʼ “Universalhistorie”, were used in the original German version. The members of the Academy, professors or teachers, wrote their own textbooks, too. So for example did Professor G.W. Krafft, whose “Einleitung zur […] Geographie” was first published in German (Academy Press, 1738). The Russian translation was published a year later at the Academy Press, too. The German grammar, which was bilingual in German and Russian, was compiled by the Academy Schoolʼs teacher Martin Schwanwitz and constituted the first German grammar printed in Russia for the needs of Russian students (first edition: Academy Press, 1730). In the middle of the 18th century, the print run of the grammar was already quite high so that a certain number of the students could be provided with their own personal copy of the grammar. For example, this was the case for eight students, who each received the German grammar in June 1748 after having passed the exam to get the Academy scholarship.

Career:
Johann Christian Horn was born in Elbingen in 1755. He taught at the local school.
In November 1777, he arrived in Russia, entered service as a clerk at the Collegium for Livonian and Estonian Affairs, but resigned four months later. From that time on, he maintained a private teaching practice in private homes in Saint Petersburg, teaching children French and German, as well as the basics of arithmetic and geography.
Teaching institutions and families: From 1778 onwards, he worked at Natalia Christina Cruz’s private school in Millionnaya Street in the valet Popov’s house. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences checked the school in April 1780 and stated that there were 18 children (seven boys and 11 girls) aged from 7 to 12 years old.

Children of raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks), children of artisans.
In April 1780, 18 children attended the school: Guettée (Guetté, Gette), son of a deceased counsellor; Bukendal, son and daughter of a court wainwright; Wagner, son of a court musician; Schlau, son of a baker; Wunsch, son and daughter of an architect; Ferrier, son and daughter of Count Orlov’s Intendant; Ivan, son of the Kuchenmeister who worked in Siversova’s house; three daughters of the coppersmith Sperling; Ekerman, daughter of a sugar factory foreman; Rolls (Rolles), daughter of a baker; Timon, daughter of a lieutenant; Filiteini, daughter of a musician; Glazova, daughter of a gardener.

In the afternoons, he gave nine lessons, including French reading, writing and elementary grammar and taught the basics of arithmetic (at Cruz’s school).

Personal records: (or Hoelterhoff, Geltergof; Franciscus, Franciskus) (1711-03-04, Lennep, today part of the city of Remscheid, Duchy of Berg – 1805-12-23, Sarepta, Russia). Son of a clothier. Married to: Sophie Helene von Brümmer († 1778, Moscow). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Hölterhof first attended school in his native city, Lennep. Later, in 1728, he enrolled at the grammar school in Soest, where he studied for about a year and a half. Afterwards, Hölterhof worked as a private teacher and preacher in Schwelen in the county of Mark, before he moved to Halle in 1731 in order to study Theology at the University of Halle. He finished his studies with the degree of Magister of philosophy in 1734.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German language and literature; German morphology, syntax, phrasing and eloquence.
Career: Tutor and preacher. After finishing his studies in Halle, Hölterhof moved to Reval, where he became a tutor in the family of the deacon Eberhard Gutsleff. His next engagement was on the island Ösel (Estonian: Saaremaa). He relocated to Arensburg in 1737. There, Hölterhof was ordained and also became head of school. Three years later, in 1740, he became pastor of the town of Iama and stayed in this function until 1747. Then, due to his relations with the Moravian Church, Hölterhof was accused of political treason and taken into custody. The next 12 years he spent imprisoned at the Peter and Paul Fortress in Saint Petersburg. In 1759, he was banished to Kazan. Similarly to many other banished people at the time, he first earned his living as a tutor, but soon (1760) was engaged as German teacher at the recently-founded grammar school of Kazan. When Hölterhof was finally amnestied in 1762, he already possessed such a good reputation as a German teacher that the Moscow University invited him to overtake the lectureship of German language and literature. So Hölterhof moved to Moscow and succeeded Johann Gottfried Reichel, the first lecturer in German language and literature at the Moscow University, in 1763. Hölterhof taught German in the most advanced German class of the grammar school of the Moscow University (the so-called class of German style) and also had a class of university students who were instructed in German morphology, syntax and phrasing. Hölterhof composed a whole slew of dictionaries and an excellent German grammar designed for use at the grammar school and the university. This grammar had a completely new methodical approach and became the most successful German grammar for Russian students in the 18th and also the first third of the 19th century (its 10th and last issue appeared in 1829). Owing to the dictionaries, which described primarily the Russian, but also the German, French and Latin languages, Hölterhof is presumed to be one of the most important lexicographers of Russian (see Keipert, 1987). Furthermore, Hölterhof was the leading mind in creating the first official manual for teaching languages methodically, the so-called «способ учения» (‘method of teaching’), issued by the professors’ conference at the Moscow University in 1771 and, in a second edition, in 1790. Hölterhof stayed at the Moscow University until his retirement in 1779. Afterwards he joined the settlement of his fellow Lutherans in Sarepta in the Volga region, where he died in 1805.
Teaching institutions and families:
Kazan grammar school; Moscow University; grammar school attached to Moscow University;
Family of Eberhard Gutsleff.
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
Gavrila Romanovich Derzhavin; Matvei Gavrilovich Gavrilov.
Derzhavin attended the Kazan grammar school and learned German in Hölterhof’s class. Gavrilov was one of Hölterhof’s most able pupils in the grammar school at the Moscow University.
The grammar school at the Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative, with the intention of educating students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: One department for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of sciences” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the beginning, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was reached in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials: The schedule of classes in 1775 gave the following information about the contents of Hölterhof’s class of German style: Hölterhof “is going to teach German style, imitation and letter writing, conversations and brief speeches; in addition, he is to make his pupils read Tessin’s letters to the young Prince, explaining them according to the rules of style and thoroughly inspiring the learning; teaching the historical style, he is also going to read the news and interpret them through historical and geographical remarks” (Объявление, 1775, no pagination). The first official guideline for teaching languages at a Russian school or university, the “method of teaching”, was published in 1771 at the Moscow University (for the complete version see Сычев-Михайлов, 1960, app. 8, pp. 160-165). Written by professors of the Moscow University under the guidance of Franz Hölterhof, it described in detail the contents, structure and textbooks for language teaching at the grammar school. Furthermore, it provided the language teachers with detailed methodical instructions. It is not definitely proved whether the requirements of these guidelines were in fact implemented. However, evidence shows that this probably was the case. The schedules of classes of the grammar school confirm not only the use of textbooks recommended by the guideline, they also emphasize that lessons followed the published methodical instructions. The fact that the “method of teaching” underwent a second edition in 1790 too, indicates that the guidelines proved their worth in practice (for the 2nd edition see Сычев-Михайлов, 1960, app. 9, pp. 166-172). The “method of teaching” clearly focused on the practical use of the language to be learned and was against the method of memorizing. Practical exercises should be a main element in each stage of the learning process. Right from the beginning, the instruction of the alphabet, reading and writing should be linked with exercises of frequent words and phrases. Practicing dialogues and correct pronunciation was very important. In the second class, the so-called “etymological”, declension and conjugation were learned by drilling patterns, with examples always being presented within a linguistic context (e.g. phrases and sayings) in order to demonstrate to pupils how to use the words. Phrases were also used for morphological analysis and translation exercises. The next step in progression was the work on simple texts, such as Aesop’s fables for example. These texts were to be read and afterwards translated into Russian. Translating the text, clause elements and familiar words should be analysed according to already known morphological rules. These rules were also to be looked up again in the grammar book. This way, rules were learned by frequent reading and repeating as well as by practical analysis. After the translation into Russian, the texts were to be translated back into the original language. Additionally, the teacher should continue to practice dialogues and generally speak as much as possible in the language to be learnt. The instruction in the class of syntax followed the same methods for analysing and translating texts and exercising dialogues. In particular, the «method of teaching» underlined that teachers should always correct the student’s translations and works. If possible, students should assist the teacher in finding the mistakes themselves. In the most advanced class, the class of German style, the teacher dealt with the rules of rhetoric and poetry, which again were to be demonstrated on the basis of selected examples. Following these examples, students should compose their own letters and speeches. Franz Hölterhof’s reputation as a renovator of methodical approaches to language teaching is based not only on his impact on the «method of teaching». In particular, it was his German grammar, which became a milestone in the evolution of text books for language teaching. In general, grammar books made up the main basis for language teaching in the 18th century. The grammar covered all important aspects of a language, not only the grammatical rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology,” which meant morphology, syntax and prosody. Maintaining this structure, the first edition of Hölterhof’s grammar, issued in 1770 and written in Russian, seems to be rather conventional. The influence of Gottsched’s grammar “Deutsche Sprachkunst,” which was highly popular in Russian in the 1750s and 1760s, is still visible. Especially in the parts of spelling and “etymology,” Hölterhof copied several paragraphs from Agentov’s grammar of 1762, which in fact was a plagiarism of Gretsch’s Russian translation of Gottsched’s grammar (1760). Nevertheless, Hölterhof’s grammar was one of the most innovative German grammars for Russians in the 18th century. It renewed methods and approaches for teaching modern languages in Russia in a groundbreaking way. Hölterhof was the first author who gave detailed descriptions of didactical methods and approaches. Furthermore, he was a pioneer in devising specific exercises and tasks for language learning. His grammar was the first German grammar for Russians, containing practical tasks and exercises. Until then, the most common way of practicing had been learning by heart. In the second half of the 18th century, this method was increasingly criticized. Hölterhof too militated against memorizing. In his opinion, it was “an excruciating method […] [to agonize] the memory of the poor young people in an irresponsible way with memorizing complete grammar books […].” (Hölterhof, 1776, p. 20). Instead of memorizing rules, pupils should diligently practice, for example when learning spelling and the gender of nouns (Hölterhof, 1776, p. 34). Similarly to some other pedagogues of his time (for example J.E.F. Schall), Hölterhof also favoured the cognitive approach to learning: “When learning grammar, the teacher must make his pupils use their reason more than anything else” (Hölterhof, 1770, preface). Hölterhof’s grammar firstly presented specific types of exercises related to particular grammatical subjects. Memorizing was recommended only in a very few cases, e.g. the formation of the plural of nouns ending with -er (like Amt ->Ämter), or conjunctions introducing subordinate clauses with the conjugated verb in the end (Hölterhof, 1770, pp. 46, 262). For other aspects, like for example the conjugation of verbs and the use of tenses, Hölterhof advised “frequent reading of the examples given” (Hölterhof, 1770, preface). The same method applied to learning the gender of nouns or the use of interjections, which had to be acquired by reading comedies and tragedies (Hölterhof, 1770, pp. 36, 96). In order to support cognitive learning, each page in the morphological part contained questions for the pupils to answer. Regarding the use of the article, for example, questions were the following: How many articles exist? How does one use the article? What is a noun? Do articles exist in Russian? (Hölterhof, 1770, p. 35). Equally new were exercises where pupils had to relate words to specific grammatical categories. To practice the cases of nouns, Hölterhof presented a short story (“Als mein Bruder gestern im Garten unserer Muhme war, schenkte der Gärtner ihm einen Apfel […]”). Pupils had to identify the nouns and had to specify case and number by asking questions: Wer? Wessen? Wem? Wen? [Who? Whose? [To] whom? Who?] (Hölterhof, 1770, p.201). In another story, pupils had to identify verbs followed by nouns in genitive (Hölterhof, 1770, p.210f.). A different type of exercise was the correction of sentences containing mistakes, for example regarding the use of the definite and indefinite articles, the government of prepositions or word order in subordinate clauses (Hölterhof, 1770, pp. 267, 268, 271). The grammar also included short texts, most likely used for translation exercises. Due to the fact that these texts were related to specific grammar topics, pupils simultaneously could practice certain grammatical structures. For example, short dialogues were translated to practice the use of pronouns: “Was macht dein Bruder? Er ist itzt wieder besser, gestern war er etwas krank. Aber wie befindet sich deine Schwester? Sie hat heute das kalte Fieber […].“ (Hölterhof, 1770, p. 232). From the second edition of 1775 on, the grammar contained an appendix “Sammlung einiger Stücke aus guten Schriftstellern zur Übung in der deutschen Sprache [‘collection of several works of good authors for practicing German’] (Hölterhof, 1775, pp. 275-360). These more substantial texts, like for example poems, short prose works and letters, could likewise be used for translation exercises with focus on specific grammatical topics. Compared to the other German grammars for Russians published in the 18th century, Hölterhof’s grammar was the first to present more complex example sentences and complete texts. Quite often, the linguistic material was closely linked to Russian reality, so that students could use these sentences in real life conversation. As already mentioned above, Hölterhof was also one of the most important lexicographers of Russian. His etymological dictionaries followed the model of Christoph Cellarius’ very popular Latin dictionary “Liber memorialis”, published in 1688 or 1689 in Merseburg, which was also used in Russia. A first version with Russian translation of the original German-Latin text was published at the Academic University in Saint Petersburg in 1746. Hölterhof’s dictionaries demonstrate how pedagogues in the 18th century tried to transfer the methods of teaching Latin to the teaching of modern languages. Similar to Cellarius’ principle of the “natural order” of words, Hölterhof introduced the lexis by word stems presented in alphabetical order. Each root was given together with the associated derivations, compounds, grammatical information and the corresponding translations into Russian. The dictionaries were not intended for looking up unknown words. Instead, they were to simplify learning vocabulary by reducing the thesaurus to word stems. In order to recognize the rules of word formation, which would facilitate language learning, the learner first had to study word roots and afterwards learn the words that contained these roots. In case of the grammar school attached to Moscow University and the university itself, the books used for learning foreign languages are quite well documented. Initially, the regulations of the school, published with its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works, for example Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738, which were applied in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). In the following years, the professors’ conference, which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963). Additionally, the «method of teaching» prescribed the use of specific textbooks. Hölterhof’s “Немецкой Целлариус“ was used intensively at the grammar school. Only one year after it spublication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and officially prescribed it to be used in German classes. In later years, it was continually purchased for the grammar school. Likewise, the “method of teaching” prescribed “Немецкой Целлариус,” Hölterhof’s German grammar, Formey’s “Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften” and Aesop’s fables for use in the class of German morphology. Furthermore, the «method of teaching» ordered that the class of German syntax should use Hölterhof’s German grammar and the German Cellarius, as well as Comenius’ Orbis pictus, Formey’s “Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften” and Hoffmann’s “Zwei Bücher von der Zufriedenheit” (Белявский, 1955, p. 307f.). Tessin’s letters and Gellert’s works were to be used in Hölterhof’s class in German style, as well as Hoffmann’s “Zwei Bücher von der Zufriedenheit” (Объявление, 1775; Пенчко, 1963, pp. 289f, 376; Белявский, 1955, p. 308). Gottsched’s works used in the upper German classes (syntax and style) are listed in the book catalogue of the school library, attached to the minutes of the professors’ conference of 15th January 1765 [“Catalogus Librorum pro stipendiariis studiosis et discipulis universitatis et gymnasii moscuensis” (Пенчко, 1962, p.29)]. Hölterhof himself also ordered Gottsched’s rhetoric book (probably: “Vorübungen der Beredsamkeit”) for the scholarship pupils in his class (e.g., in 1767, see Пенчко, 1963, p. 109). Moreover, pupils were rewarded with Gottsched’s works at the yearly public exams (e.g., Пенчко, 1962, pp. 129, 131).
