Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: Concerning Roman Illarionov, all that is known is that he was a grammar and syntax class teacher at the Chernihiv Collegium in the 1767–1768 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1767–1768).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1767–1768 school year, 48 students were enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes, in which Roman Illarionov taught. In total, 213 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium that year. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. Thus, in the 1767–1768 school year, out of the 48 students enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Roman Illarionov, 27 were children of raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Roman Illarionov, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Roman Illarionov worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at that time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Chernihiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (*1730, Sweden). Daughter: Мaria Ioranzon (*1760, Sweden).
Career: Merchant. From 1765 onwards, he lived in Saint Petersburg. In 1768–1769, he served as a clerk at the local auditing agency. In 1770–1771, he worked as a writing and arithmetic teacher in Petrischule (Saint Peter’s School). In 1773, he opened his own school. On 6 March 1775 the following announcement was published in the Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti (No. 19): “The arithmetic and calligraphy teacher Johann Ioranzon has changed his address and now lives on the bank of the Moyka River in Chirkinov’s house. He teaches various languages and sciences as well as Italian accounting”. On 10 June 1778 the following announcement was published in the Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti (No. 55): “Those who would like to learn to keep merchant’s books decently according to the universally adopted Italian pattern, and to acquire other knowledge useful for commerce, can address themselves to Ioranzon, who lives on the bank of the Moyka River in the house of the State counsellor and chevalier Nikita Akinfievich Demidov. He makes his students translate works of different kinds and write letters fairly and completely”. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which checked the school in April 1780, noted that it was located on the Catherine Embankment in the house of the notary Volkov, that Ioranzon had good feedback about his work, and that he spoke some Russian and understood French. The school was attended by 18 children: 14 boys and four girls; only one boy was a boarder. The school taught Russian, German, French, arithmetic, geography, and merchant accounting. As a result, the Commission noted that in this school children could get a good knowledge of grammar in three languages and could learn arithmetic. The school had two teaching assistants. Documents on the inspection of private schools and boarding schools dated 1784 do not mention Ioranzon’s school.
Teaching institutions and families: Petrischule (1770–1771); his own private school (from 1773), all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Merchants; artisans; military men; civil servants.
In 1780, 18 children attended the school: Bernardin, son of a merchant, a boarder; two sons of the notary Volkov; Okhlopkov, son of a captain; Kuzmin, son of a lieutenant; two sons of the president Puchkov; Karzhavin, son of a mayor; Svikeyev, son of a merchant; Ruskonogov, son of a merchant; Retz, son and daughter of a silversmith; Berg, daughter of a hatter; Koensberg, daughter; son and daughter of the painter Rudolph; Gibrat, daughter of a cook; Rader, daughter of a cook.

Personal records: (*1760, Sweden). Father: Johann Georg Ioranzon (*1730, Sweden).
Career: From 1765 onwards, she lived in Saint Petersburg. In 1773, her father opened his own school, where she began to teach. The school was attended by 18 children: 14 boys and four girls; only one boy was a boarder. The school taught Russian, German and French, arithmetic, geography, and merchant accounting. As a result, the Commission noted that in this school children could get a good knowledge of grammar in three languages and could learn arithmetic. Documents on the inspection of private schools and boarding schools dated 1784 do not mention Ioranzon’s school.
Teaching institutions and families: Johann Georg Ioranzon’s private school (Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Merchants; nobles; raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks).
In 1780, 18 children attended the school: Bernardin, son of a merchant, boarder; two sons of the notary Volkov; Okhlopkov, son of a captain; Kuzmin, son of a lieutenant; two sons of the president Puchkov; Karzhavin, son of a mayor; Svikeyev, son of a merchant; Ruskonogov, son of a merchant; Retz, son and daughter of a silversmith; Berg, daughter of a hat maker; Koensberg, daughter; son and daughter of the painter Rudolph; Gibrat, daughter of a cook; Rader, daughter of a cook.

At the school, Maria Ioranzon taught eight German reading lessons per week, checked home reading in three languages (German, French, Russian), gave one German calligraphy lesson according to Sulzer’s book, dictated newspaper articles for spelling exercises and translations, and gave eight French lessons according to the "local French alphabet book", per week.

Personal records: (or Iwanicki; Warłaam; secular name: Vasily) (1704, the town of Kobylnica in Premeal County, Ruthenian Voivodeship, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – Russian Empire). It is known that Varlaam Ivanitsky was born into a priest’s family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Varlaam Ivanitsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax; elementary Polish reading and writing; Polish grammar and syntax.
Career: In the 1740-1741 school year, Varlaam Ivanitsky taught in the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In 1740, he took monastic vows. Then he taught in the subsequent grammar classes. In 1743, he was a poetics teacher at the Smolensk Seminary, then a philosophy and theology teacher. From 1748 to 1778, he was the Prefect of that seminary. At the same time, he served as archimandrite at the Saint Abraham’s Monastery of the Saviour’s Transfiguration in Smolensk.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (from 1740); Smolensk Seminary (from 1743).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the grammar classes in which Varlaam Ivanitsky taught. For example, in the 1740–1741 school year, there were 152 students in the analogy class where Varlaam Ivanitsky taught. In total, more than 564 people studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy during that school year. There were 64 students during the 1741–1742 school year in the syntax class taught by Varlaam Ivanitsky; (in total, there were 687 students at the academy).
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class) in which Varlaam Ivanitsky taught. The teacher also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Moscow University.
Career: Sergei Ivanov applied for the position of teacher in the German class of “etymology “ (which in fact meant “morphology”), which was vacated following the death of Ivan Kalinovsky. After the positive judgement of the Professors’ conference, who had examined Ivanov, he was engaged on 21 January, 1766 for an annual salary of 100 roubles. On 7 December 1769 his salary was increased to 130 roubles. Ivanov is documented in this position until June 1770, but may have occupied it still longer.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to the Moscow University.
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at the Moscow University, founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative in order to prepare students for studying at the Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and the other for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so-called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European languages (i.e. German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the beginning, there were 50 scholarship students (both nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number was increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was reached in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
Apparently, there were issues concerning the teaching of languages at the grammar school of Moscow University, so that the professors of Moscow University felt compelled to draw attention to this issue in their conference in May 1767. They made the following decision:
“It has been observed that students at the grammar school, especially in the lower classes, get very tired of learning grammar rules that they do not understand and that are not explained to them in practice; hence the Conference demands: (1) After writing on the blackboard examples subject to grammar analysis, teachers should immediately translate them into Russian or from Russian into French, German (or Latin and Italian) and that they should do so every day. This is particularly important for practicing conversation (dialogues). Dialogues, words and phrases explained in such a way should be learned by heart. Grammar rules should be explained in detail several times during the phrase analysis and read about in grammar books, then they will be understood without much difficulty. They should be studied in advance. Every week one day should be used entirely to practice free conversation consisting of questions and answers. (2) Teachers should force their students to do exercises given in the classroom and for homework three times a week, and on the following morning teachers should sign the work and note the day when the task was given and corrected. Similar exercises should be introduced by teachers in other classes too, for example, in the mathematics, as well as in the geography and history classes. These exercises, showing the diligence of both teachers and students, should be supervised by the inspector and the rector, they should be also the first to be paid attention to by the examiners in the public examinations.” (Minutes of the conference of the professors of Moscow University from 12th May, 1767, published in Пенчко, 1963, p. 41).
Thus, the main focus was put on the translation of example sentences. Contrary to prior practices, the student’s mother tongue – Russian – was now incorporated into the process of instruction in order to increase the student’s understanding. Oral skills were to be built up by memorizing sample dialogues from the so called “dialogue books.” Along with grammar books, these dialogue books represented the main basis for language instruction.

In the case of the grammar school attached to Moscow University and the university itself, the choice of books used for learning foreign languages was quite well documented. Initially, the school’s rules, published at its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works like for example Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738 which were applied in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). In the following years, the professors’ conference, which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered the books to be used in class. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963). Additionally, the «способ учения» (“method of teaching”) prescribed the use of specific textbooks.
Hölterhof’s “Немецкой Целлариус” was used intensively at the grammar school. Only a year after its publication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and officially imposed it for use in German classes. In later years, it was continually purchased for the grammar school. Likewise, the «способ учения» (“method of teaching”) prescribed the “Немецкой Целлариус,” Hölterhof’s German grammar, Formey’s “Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften” and Aesop’s fables for use in the class of German morphology. (Пенчко, 1962, p. 255; Белявский, 1955, p. 308).

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Stefan Ivanov studied at the Kharkiv Collegium.
Career: All we know concerning Stefan Ivanov is that in the 1789–1790 school year he taught Latin at the Kharkiv Collegium.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1789–1790).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1789–190 school year, 549 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The higher grammar class taught by Stefan Ivanov had 55 students. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, though students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low- and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. For instance, in the 1789–1790 school year, there were 16 “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks) children among the 55 students of the higher grammar class in which Stefan Ivanov taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Stefan Ivanov, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Stefan Ivanov worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, written by Bishop of Belgorod Samuil Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector, the prefect and the teachers, were in use at the Collegium. Latin grammar classes were based on Johann Matthias Gesner’s version of the textbook by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues.” At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions as to what sections and paragraphs of the books should be studied at what stages of learning. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. The library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Personal records: (or Jakobus, Jakobäer) (*German lands).
Education: Studies in jurisprudence.
Career: Karl Heinrich Jakobäus is documented as student of jurisprudence in the minutes of the meetings of the Conference of the Academy of Sciences in 1734. At the same time, Jakobäus was adjunct of jurisprudence at the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps and preceptor of the cadets. In 1737, he still worked at the Cadet Corps as teacher of philosophy and jurisprudence. His second subject was German style, which he taught four hours per week. In later years, he was counsel at the Collegium of Justice.
Teaching institutions and families: Infantry Noble Cadet Corps (1734–1737, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Nobility.
Teaching methods and materials: The main instrument of language learning at that time was learning by heart. Thus, the students learned declension and conjugation forms from the grammar book and also memorized vocabulary and dialogues. These studies were completed by translation, one of the “principal means of teaching foreign languages in the Cadet Corps” (Rjéoutski, 2013). “The cadets were trained to translate from German into French and from French into German and, later, at least at the beginning of the reign of Catherine, from and into Russian as well” (Rjéoutski, 2013). Personal records: (Also known as James, then Jaunez-Sponville). (1750, probably in Metz – 1805). Father: Pierre Jaunez, contractor of the king's buildings in Metz. Mother: Jeanne Hollard. Married to: Élisabeth-Adélaïde Mathis, a minor daughter of Basile-Benoît Mathis, sculptor to the late king of Poland, and Marie-Jeanne Guibal, residing at Mme Apraxin's, Nikitskaya Street in Moscow at the time of the marriage (marriage contract at the vice-consulate of Moscow on 10 November 1784).
Career:
A lawyer at the Parliament of Metz, he came to Paris around 1770 and met Gilbert Romme there. In early 1781, Jaunez-James obtained, on Romme's recommendation, a position as tutor to Piotr Razumovski; he arrived in Moscow the following summer. 
In the summer of 1784, he accompanied the Counts Razumovski and Apraxin and painter Barnabé-Augustin Mailly on their journey to Ufa. He sent a lengthy letter to Romme dedicated to this trip to Siberia (collection of Lobanov-Rostovski, from the former Library of the Winter Palace at the Archives of the Russian Federation, GARF).
He had to return to France with his young wife, Élisabeth-Adélaïde Mathis, in April or May 1785: Count Alexei Razumovski, who had attended the wedding, declared that this engagement was incompatible with his responsibilities as a tutor. Shortly after, Jaunez fell ill: he was close to death, and his illness lasted until January 1786.
Just before leaving Russia, Jaunez, Nicolas Bugnet, and Drago pooled their resources (which amounted to £32) to buy land in France and engage in agriculture together. His wife, meanwhile, had returned to Moscow in 1791. She was reported as single in 1793 when she had to swear allegiance to the crown of France in St. Petersburg to obtain a residence permit. The French scholar Gabriel-Auguste Daubrée wrote in the notes of one of his works that a certain Jaunez-Sponville was managing mines near Nizhny Tagil, possibly referring to Pierre-Ignace.
Teaching institutions and families: Razumovski family
Students and their social status: Piotr Alexeyevich Razumovski, son of Count Alexei Kirillovich Razumovski.
Teaching methods and materials: Well-educated, Jaunez-James not only educated his pupil (Piotr Razumovski) according to Rousseau's pedagogical theories but also assisted Count Alexei Razumovski in his chemical and physical experiments. Notably, they launched a hot air balloon in April 1784.

Personal records: (Known as Jubé de La Cour) (1674-05-27, Vanves – 1745-12-30, Paris). Son of a laundress. Religion: Catholic.
Career: Jansenist priest. He studied theology at the Sorbonne before being appointed priest in Vaugrigneuse, then in Asnières, thanks to his merit and the support of Cardinal de Noailles. He celebrated the liturgy in an ultra-Gallican spirit, read the Gospel in French, distinguished himself by the rigor of his morals and conduct, and by the discipline he demanded from his parishioners. When Pope Clement XI promulgated the bull Unigenitus in 1713, which condemned the propositions of the Jansenist Pasquier Quesnal, Jubé rebelled and organized the army of the "appellants." However, his activism eventually displeased the authorities; he was summoned by the police lieutenant, forced to leave his parish, and after a mysterious mission in Italy, he took refuge in Holland, where he remained for nearly three years, from early 1726 to October 1728. In the Netherlands, Jubé took the name Jubé de La Cour. He continued his propaganda, encouraged by the presence of many clergy and faithful supporters of Jansenism. At that time, there was a Russian princess in The Hague, Irina Petrovna Dolgorukova, born Golitsyna, who had converted to Catholicism. Her husband had returned to Russia, and she was to join him. However, she needed a chaplain who would also be the tutor for her children. The refugees in Holland then turned to the Jansenist doctors from the Sorbonne. They saw the opportunity to revive the issue of the union of the Churches, which they had unsuccessfully raised in 1717 during Peter the Great's stay in Paris (the doctors had submitted a memorandum to the tsar, which he had passed on to the Russian bishops, but their response had been negative). The circumstances now seemed more favorable, as there was a chance to send someone to Russia who could discuss directly with the Orthodox clergy. The Sorbonne thought of Jubé, whose theological knowledge, business acumen, vigorous temperament suitable for enduring the climate and hardships, and especially his unwavering courage were well-known. Jubé hesitated, seeking to know God's will before going "to an unknown, rustic country, stubbornly attached to its customs and blindly believing what it has been told." But he eventually accepted and received instructions from the Sorbonne, as well as extensive powers granted by the Jansenist Archbishop of Utrecht. On 20 October 1728, he left Holland with Princess Irina and her children. The travelers passed through Berlin, Danzig, Königsberg, Mitau, and then directly from Riga to Moscow, without taking the usual route through St. Petersburg. It was a long and tiring journey, with the common misadventures of the time: carriages stuck or even dislocated, risky passages over the dunes of East Prussia and the ice of the Baltic Sea, and a storm at sea. The journey lasted two months. Upon their arrival in Moscow on 20 December 1728 (new style), Prince Sergei Dolgorukov took the travelers to his estate in Nikolskoye, near the city. Certain circumstances, at least at the beginning, favored Jubé's mission. The young Tsar Peter II had exiled Prince Alexander Danilovich Menshikov, the former favorite of his grandfather Peter the Great, and power was now in the hands of the Dolgorukovs. Furthermore, not all Russian prelates were hostile to the idea of union. Four of them were in favor: Lopatinsky, Archbishop of Tver, Vonatovich, Archbishop of Kiev, Coletti, Archimandrite of the Savior Monastery, and especially Kholmski, Archbishop of Kazan. But the most important asset for Jubé was the support of the Duke of Liria, the Spanish ambassador to Russia. Thanks to all his support and his energy, Jubé was able to surround himself with translators (notably Antiokh Cantemir, translator of Fontenelle), distribute more than four hundred volumes, and conceive vast educational projects for young Russians. But the abbot was to encounter many obstacles. First, there were theological divergences, primarily the question of the Filioque (the Holy Spirit proceeding from the Father and the Son for Catholics, and only from the Father for Orthodox). Jubé sought to minimize these differences, even though they were articles of faith that were nearly irreconcilable. Furthermore, the absence of a patriarch in Russia was an argument against any discussion. Even the prelates favorable to the union "were alarmed by the claims of the Court of Rome," and Jubé had a hard time convincing them that the Church of France reconciled the respect due to the Pope with the liberties acquired. In 1730, the situation in Russia changed radically, making Jubé's task even more difficult. On 30 January Peter II died, and it was a niece of Peter the Great, Anna, daughter of Ivan V, who succeeded him. Anna Ivanovna's reign was a reckoning with the representatives of the aristocracy who had opposed her absolute power, primarily the Dolgorukovs and the Golitsyns. Jubé lost significant support there, especially since Anna surrounded herself with Germans and the French representative was merely a chargé d'affaires. Archbishop Prokopovich, a determined opponent of the union, became very influential again and ceased discussions with Jubé. Any propaganda became suspect and subject to severe penalties. The situation worsened for the abbot with Liria's departure for Vienna on 30 November. Jubé lost a protector and a friend who lent him newspapers from Holland and kept him informed of politics. The French consul Villardeau de Monicault described him as a man of irreproachable morals but heavily in debt. In June 1731, Jubé narrowly escaped arrest at the same time as the Archbishop of Kazan. In August, he received an order to leave Russia. He requested a three-month extension to be able to depart by sleigh. The French consul warned him that he risked his life. He had to leave the country hidden in a bundle of goods, after accomplishing a remarkable feat: having remained for two years under the reign of Anna Ivanovna! However, to avoid swearing on the Gospel, he did not request a passport and left Russia clandestinely. He passed through Warsaw and returned to Holland, where he arrived on 21 May 1732. He continued to fervently oppose the bull Unigenitus, revitalizing the waning energies, but could not bring himself to consider his mission in Russia as finished. He endeavored to assist Princess Irina, who was being persecuted and lacking resources. He managed to communicate with her secretly with precautions worthy of a conspirator. After the death of Anna Ivanovna, he clandestinely met in Paris with two of Irina's sons, who were completing their studies in France and whose debts he paid. Apparently, the abbot made several trips between France and Holland. And it was in Paris that he died in December 1745.
Teaching institutions and families: Dolgorukov family
Students and their social status: Nobility
Teaching methods and materials: Despite his final failure, did Jubé's mission in Russia have positive aspects? Opinions differ on this point. In any case, traces remain since the abbot, upon his return, wrote a narrative titled La Religion, les mœurs et les usages des Moscovites. In the first half of the 18th century, accounts of Russia are rare. The only one in French, prior to Jubé's, is the brief Voyage en Moscovie by Dr. Deschisaux, published in 1727. Jubé's manuscript narrative, which we discovered in Rouen and published in Oxford, thus predates the famous Voyage en Sibérie by Chappe d’Auteroche by about thirty years, which was published in 1768. It is a report on the abbot's actions, but also a testimony to Russian civilization in the 1730s, with detailed descriptions of the major events of the time: the burial of Peter II, the coronation of Anna Ivanovna, the turmoil of the interregnum, and the intrigues of high-ranking figures. Jubé met many people. He vividly portrays the extraordinary atmosphere of this transitional period, where a group of aristocrats failed in their attempt to limit autocracy for their own benefit. The abbot sees in the sudden changes of fortune, which do not spare even the most powerful, a kind of law of Russian history. His narrative is poorly composed, but it provides a vivid picture of Russian life. A curious and observant mind, Jubé meticulously describes everyday objects (stoves, sleighs). Nothing, or almost nothing, escapes his gaze: food, housing, corporal punishments, hunting, the army, marriages, funerals, customs, and religious celebrations… Numerous pen drawings, a rare occurrence, illustrate the work. The author is not without prejudices, and he sometimes reiterates the commonplaces of his predecessors. His view of Russia and the Russians is very critical, but his judgments are, after all, less severe than those of Chappe d’Auteroche and Custine. Jubé de la Cour was the author of numerous anonymous writings.

Education: We do not know exactly where G. Jungius had studied, but the contract which he signed to work as a teacher mentioned that he was a “magister”. From the correspondence of the Kharkiv Collegium direction with the diocesan authorities, it is clear that people who studied at Western European universities were invited to take up positions as teachers of the “new languages”.
Career:
Godfrid Jungius, as well as being the first teacher of the “new” languages at the Kharkiv Collegium (Boneberg), was a foreigner (no one knows exactly where he came from).
All that is known concerning G. Jungius is that he was the second German and French teacher (after Boneberg) at the Kharkiv Collegium. We can say precisely that he worked during one school year, 1741–1742 (although it is possible that he continued working for a few more years).
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (from 1741 till 1742 or later).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
When Godfrid Jungius worked as a teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, more than 200 students (210 in the 1741–1742 school year) were enrolled at the school. Several dozen students from the grammar classes and the rhetorical class studied German and French.
According to his contract, G. Jungius was allowed to teach other children along with the Collegium students.
Teaching methods and materials:
Godfrid Jungius taught German and French grammar and syntax.
Little is known about his teaching methods. According to his contract, he was supposed to spend two hours on his teaching every day (including on Sundays and Holydays) It is obvious that the teacher lacked textbooks for students. However, it is logical to assume that he used a few French and German grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the Collegium library at the time. The surviving library catalogue (1753) identifies the specific lexicons and dictionaries, which were available for the teacher, and shows that they had been transferred to the library by the Belgorod bishops Epiphanius (Epiphany) Tikhorsky (the founder of the Collegium) and Dositheus (Dosifey) Bogdanovic-Lyubimsky.

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Gerasim Kalenovich studied at the Pereiaslav Collegium and then, apparently, at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar and syntax.
Career:
After graduation he became a priest.
In the 1750s, soon after his graduation, Gerasim Kalenovich began teaching in the analogy and infima classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium. In the 1760–1761 school year, he was mentioned as a syntax and grammar class teacher. Then, in 1764, he was a poetics class teacher. In subsequent years, he was no longer on the list of teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. In the 1760–1761 school year, 42 students were enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes in which Gerasim Kalenovich taught. In total, 131 students were enrolled at the collegium that year. In subsequent years, the number of students in these classes grew gradually. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low- and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. Thus, in the 1760–1761 school year, out of the 42 students enrolled in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Gerasim Kalenovich, 26 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the analogy (phara), in which Gerasim Kalenovich taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. In subsequent years, Gerasim Kalenovich worked in grammar and syntax classes, where he taught grammar and syntax rules, grammar analysis and translation. When Gerasim Kalenovich worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez. However, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already in use at that time. The library of the collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari. Personal records: (or Kalinovski) (1740, Russian Empire – 1765, Moscow). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Kalinovsky had been educated at the Novgorod seminary before being sent to Moscow University in October 1757 to continue his studies.
Career: Kalinovsky enrolled at the Moscow University on 10 October 1757. By order of M.M. Kheraskov, he started to teach German and Latin at the grammar school in 1760, while at the same time continuing his studies. In July 1762, Kalinovsky succeeded his colleague Mikhail Agentov in the German class of etymology (which is morphology). In 1764, Kalinovsky received an award for excellent achievements in his studies (Mosk. Ved.,1764, No. 53. Suppl.). In July 1765, the professors’ conference proposed that the curator of the Moscow University should provide Kalinovsky with a teacher’s salary of 50 roubles per annum instead of the student scholarship he received before, taking into account that teaching and studying at the same time was difficult. Following the death of Kalinovsky in 1765, the etymology class was taken over by the student Sergey Ivanov in 1766.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to Moscow University (1760–1765).
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at the Moscow University, founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative in order to prepare future students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for European Languages (i.e. German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To start with, there were 50 scholarship students (both nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was achieved in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
[Агентов, Михаил], Грамматика немецкая, собранная из разных авторов Михаилом Агентовым, Moscow, 1762.
[Gottsched, Johann Christoph], Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst, Nach den Mustern der besten Schriftsteller des vorigen und jetzigen Jahrhunderts abgefasset von Johann Christoph Gottscheden, Leipzig, 1748, (4-ed. 1757).

The books used for learning foreign languages in the grammar school attached to Moscow University are quite well documented. Initially, the rules of the school, published at its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of certain standard works, such as Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738, which were used in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p.298). In the following years, the professors’ conference, which was one of the administrative institutions of the university, chose and ordered books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963).
In general, grammar books made up the main basis for language teaching in the 18th century. The grammar covered all the important aspects of a language, not only the grammar rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology”, which meant morphology, syntax and prosody.
There were two German grammars, which were used in the early 1760s at the grammar school. The school statute written by Mikhail Lomonosov in 1758 introduced Johann Christoph Gottsched’s German grammar “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ for German classes (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459). From 1762 onwards, the grammar school used the German grammar by Mikhail Agentov, a teacher of the German syntax class at the grammar school itself, who was ordered to compose a new grammar for the school probably in 1761 (Koch, 2002, p.238).
Gottsched’s textbook „Vorübungen der Beredsamkeit“ might also have been used in Kalinovsky’s class. This is indicated by the fact that his pupils were awarded with Gottsched’s «Краткого [учебника] красноречия» (Пенчко, 1962, p. 131), for excellent results in the exams in June 1765.

Personal records: (Secular name: Evdokim Savvich) (1775 or 1776 ?, Bogushkova Slobodka village of the Pereiaslav regiment, Russian Empire – 1825-05-24, Voronezh, Russian Empire). Son of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Yepifany Kanivetsky studied at the Pereiaslav Collegium, including in the rhetoric class, then in the philosophy and theology classes at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (until 1798). During his studies, he was praised for his high level of Ancient Greek, French and German, philosophy and theology.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar and syntax; Ancient Greek grammar and syntax.
Career:
After graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, he was a higher grammar class teacher at the Pereiaslav Collegium from September 1798 onwards. On 16 September 1800 he took monastic vows. In 1805, he was appointed as a rhetoric and mathematics teacher at the Novgorod Seminary; in 1806, he was transferred as a hermeneutics and ecclesiastical history teacher to the Alexander Nevsky Seminary. He served at the Saint Trinity Cathedral of the St. Alexander Nevsky Lavra. In 1807, he received the rank of archimandrite and was appointed rector of the Holy Spirit Monastery in Vilna (now Vilnius). In 1808, he was appointed rector and theology professor at the Kazan Theological Academy and rector of the Saviour-Transfiguration Monastery in Kazan. For the founding of a library at the Academy in 1811 he was awarded the 2nd class of the Order of St. Anne. On 26 March 1816 Yepifany Kanivetsky was ordained bishop of Voronezh. He remained so until the end of his days, and was buried in the Annunciation Cathedral in Voronezh.
Yepifany Kanivetsky was known for his preaching and for his speeches, not many of which were published. As a bishop of Voronezh, he was actively involved in educational activities; he also organised the collection of funds for charity and gave his own money to support poor students from clergy families.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium; Novgorod Seminary; St. Alexander Nevsky Seminary; Kazan Theological Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1798–1799 school year, when Yepifany Kanivetsky taught languages at Pereiaslav Collegium, 433 students were enrolled in the school. Yepifany Kanivetsky taught Latin in the grammar class; he had more than 100 students. He taught Ancient Greek too; the language was studied by more than 40 students.
Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families. However, students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there (in the 1798–1799 school year, there were 89 secular students at the collegium).
Teaching methods and materials: At the end of the 1790s, there were well-established traditions of teaching Latin and Ancient Greek at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Teaching Ancient Greek grammar was planned over two years. Students were supposed to finish the grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. In the higher grammar class taught by Yepifany Kanivetsky, students finished studying Latin grammar rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. In the class, students had conversations in Latin. Latin grammar classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The collegium had a great number of books by this author, published in different years. It is known that the direction of the Pereiaslav Collegium ordered these books several times, more than 100 copies at a time. The surviving school exercises of the collegium’s students show that they also translated prayers, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” (“School Dialogues”) was also used for exercises. Ancient Greek grammar was taught using the book written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. The book used at the end of the 19th century was translated from Latin. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, the teacher was supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. The library of the Pereiaslav Collegium had several lexicons, dictionaries and grammar books on Ancient Greek. Some of them came from the personal collection of the bishop of Pereiaslav, Iov Bazilevich (who had once taught Ancient Greek at Kharkiv Collegium). It is known that Yepifany Kanivetsky also had a personal library containing books in foreign languages. Personal records: (ab. 1723, Krasny Kut town in the Kharkiv regiment, Russian Empire – 1798-11-29, Moscow). Born into the family of an archpriest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: His initial education was received at the Kursk and Belgorod Seminary (up to the poetics class), then he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the upper classes of philosophy and theology. In September 1746, he was sent to the Kyiv Academy to study Greek and Ancient Hebrew. Apparently, he studied under the famous Hellenist and Hebraist Varlaam Liaschevsky, who taught the Greek language at that time (he in turn was a disciple of Simon Todorsky).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Reading in Greek; writing in Greek.
Career: After completing his studies at the Kharkiv Collegium in 1744, he took monastic vows and was appointed to work as a professor and prefect of the Collegium. He taught poetics during his stay at the Kyiv Academy (from 1746), where he was sent to study Greek and Ancient Hebrew. In 1749, as evidenced by a decree of the Bishop of Belgorod Ioasaf Gorlenko, Iakinf Karpinsky was appointed to work as a professor of rhetoric and Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium. He was the first teacher of Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1757, he was ordained archimandrite and became the abbot of the SS. Boris and Gleb’s Monastery in Dmitrov. From 17 January 1758, he was the abbot of the Pereslavl Holy Trinity Danilov Monastery, from 1761 – the abbot of the Holy Transfiguration Monastery in Sevsk, in 1767–1771 at the Monastery of St. Nicholas in Rylsk (Kursk Diocese), the Old Golutvin Yepifany Monastery near Kolomna (1771 – 16 January 1774), the Vyazhitsy Monastery near Novgorod (16 January 1774 – 28 September 1774), the Kirillo-Belozersky Monastery (28 September 1774 – 27 June 1792), the Yuriev Monastery near Novgorod (27 June 1792 – 18 April 1795), Moscow Donskoy Monastery (18 April 1795 – 18 December 1797), and finally, from 1797 until his death – at the Moscow Novospassky Monastery. During his Archimandrite years, he was the rector of Pereslavl-Zalessky, Kolomna, Kirillo-Belozersky, Vologda and Novgorod seminaries. He taught theology in these seminaries. From 1794, he was a member of the Moscow Synodal Office, a member of the Synod.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium, Kyiv Academy, Pereslavl-Zalessky, Kolomna, Kirillov-Belozersky, Vologda and Novgorod Seminaries
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
The Kharkiv Collegium saw students from different backgrounds (the clergy, the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants). Since most of the students were from clergymens’ families, it may be assumed that the students of Iakinf Karpinsky were primarily children from families of clergymen.
In the eighteenth century, the Kharkiv Collegium was one of the largest educational institutions in terms of student numbers (for example, in the 1759/1760 academic year it had 472 students). Iakinf Karpinsky taught Greek in the rhetoric school (class), which was also common in the following years. However, this language was not studied by all the students in the class. Greek was usually taught to 7–10 people at that time. However, this should not be considered a negligible number of learners. In order to understand and evaluate how this language was introduced into educational practice, one should note that it is only on 27 August 1784, that a decree on the compulsory study of Greek in seminaries was issued in the Russian Empire. The decree stressed the need to start preparing for the teaching of the language. Three years were given for that purpose. Since during that period the process was still slow, another decree was issued in this regard in 1784. The decree demanded that information on all the teachers and students who taught and studied Greek, including the command of the language, should be collected. The collected information shows a very limited number of students learning the language in the empire. Since Iakinf Karpinsky taught Greek in the 1749/1750 and 1750/1751 academic years, it might be assumed that he started to teach Greek to about ten students.
Teaching methods and materials:
Iakinf Karpinsky taught the Greek language starting with basic grammar. Students in his class learned to read and to write in Greek.
The books that Iakinf Karpinsky used for teaching Greek were written in Latin. Apparently, he brought them from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, where books of this kind, written for Jesuit schools, were used. It is the use of the Latin-Greek lexicons and books that explains the prohibition to start learning Greek in classes prior to the rhetoric class, the prohibition that can be found in the instructions for the Kharkiv Collegium. In order to learn Greek, students had to be fluent in Latin. It is known that the grammar rules were consolidated through reading examples from works of various Greek authors (Agapetus) as well as through exercises on the translation of extracts from texts (from Aesop's texts, from speeches of Ephrem the Syrian and John Chrysostom). It is also logical to assume that Iakinf Karpinsky used a book on the study of Greek, written by his teacher Varlaam Liaschevsky. Undoubtedly, he also used several Latin-Greek lexicons and grammar books that were available in the library of the Collegium at that time. The surviving catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium library (1753) revealed the exact lexicons that were available for the teacher, as well as the fact that the books had been given to the library by the Bishop of Belgorod Yepifany Tikhorsky (the founder of the Collegium) and by Dosifey Bogdanovich-Liubimsky.
Although Iakinf Karpinsky is known as the author of a book on theology in Latin (Compendium orthodoxae theologicae doctrinae ab archimandrita Hyacintho Karpinski concinnatum), which was used in the theological schools of the Russian Empire for several decades, he did not leave any comment on how to learn the language. At the same time, his books and his numerous sermons and instructions show that he had a great command of Latin and Greek. He found relevant examples from texts written in Latin and Greek by various authors, then used them for his reasoning, and he did it with ease. He was called "Cicero" among the learned monks for his mastery of the Latin language.

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: We know that in 1772 Avraam Kisilevsky was a syntax class teacher at the Pereiaslav Collegium. In 1772, he asked the bishop of Pereiaslav, Iov Bazilevich, to appoint him to one of the parishes of Right-bank Ukraine, a part of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) at the time. His petition was granted, and subsequently Avraam Kisilevsky was a protopope (archpriest) in the town of Tetiiv near Kyiv.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1772).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. We know that at the beginning of the 1770s there were several dozen students in the grammar classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Most of the students at Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Avraam Kisilevsky taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. When he worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues”. At the time, the collegium had well-defined traditions as to what sections and paragraphs of the books to study at what stages of learning. School exercises of the collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Pereiaslav Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogs” (the collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records: (or Petr, Piotr) (*Russian Empire). Son of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Peter Kizimovsky studied at the Chernihiv Collegium until 1798, including a three-year course in theology.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar and syntax; Ancient Hebrew grammar.
Career: From 1798 onwards, Peter Kizimovsky taught Latin in the lower grammar class, and Ancient Hebrew as well. He was the first to teach Ancient Hebrew at the Chernihiv Collegium and taught it until 1807.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1798–1807).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
When Peter Kizimovsky taught at the Chernihiv Collegium, more than 700 students were enrolled in the school (for example, in the 1796–1797 school year, the collegium had 711 students). First, he taught Latin in the lower grammar class, later in the higher grammar class. There were more than 100 students in his classes. A few of the students in the rhetoric class (not more than 10) studied Ancient Hebrew.
Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families. Students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants studied there at the same time.
Teaching methods and materials: In the late 1790s, there were well-established traditions of teaching Latin at the Chernihiv Collegium. Little is known about Peter Kizimovsky’s methods of teaching Ancient Hebrew. He taught the basics of Ancient Hebrew grammar, using a few lexicons and grammar books which were available in the library of the collegium. In the lower and higher grammar classes taught by Peter Kizimovsky, students studied grammar rules and grammar analysis, and did translation exercises. In these classes, students were supposed to converse in Latinas well. Latin grammar classes at the Chernihiv Collegium were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The collegium had a great number of books by this author, published in different years. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students show that they also translated prayers, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia Scholastica” (“School Dialogues”) was also used for exercises. It is known that Peter Kizimovsky was a good teacher of Ancient Hebrew. Apparently, he used several Ancient Hebrew books and dictionaries which had been transferred to the collegium as part of the Chernihiv bishop Kirill Liashevetsky’s personal library in 1770 (after his death, according to the request of the teachers). These were, for example, John-Heinrich Michaelis’ grammar book and Johann Joachim Lange’s books. Personal records: (or Wilhelm Heinrich; in Russia: Андрей Абрамович) (*1745-10-12, Friedland, Mecklenburg). Religion: Lutheran.
Career:
Heinrich Wilhelm Kohrtz came to Russia in 1766. In 1769 he became a copyist / scribe at the Academy of Sciences. In April 1773 he was recruited for the position of teacher of Latin, French and German calligraphy at the Academy school and replaced A. Borecius, who had left the school. Kohrtz also worked in the administration of the Academy as a recorder and proof-reader. According to H.L.Ch. Bacmeister, inspector of the Academy school, who attached great importance to the qualification of teachers, the pedagogical qualification of Kohrtz was quite good. During his first month, he taught on probation. After this period, Bacmeister confirmed Kohrtz’s good teaching skills. In the following years, Kohrtz taught the lower German class, at least until 1780.
In addition to his teaching work, Kohrtz had several other duties. In October 1788, he became archivist of the Academy’s conference. He is still documented in this position in 1812. From October 1800 till September 1801 he also worked as editorial journalist at the newspaper “Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti” which was published by the Academy. He was promoted to the rank of collegiate assessor and, probably in the early 1803, became vice rector at the Academy School. In 1816 he was still working for the Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School (Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (or Eleutherios, Liberius, Euthymius, Iereus Liberius) (1683, Athens, Ottoman Empire – 1737/1738, Saint Petersburg). Liberius left notes on his books, where he declared that he was from Athens. He called himself “Ἀθηναῖος”. His father’s name was Ioann. His brother’s name was Rodion. Koletti’s brother was mentioned in several documents. In May 1728, Rodion Ivanov, Koletti’s son, submitted a petition for the attention of the sovereign, asking for his brother Liberius Koletti to be released from the monastery and returned from exile (RIO (Russian Historical Society) Collection, vol. 79, St. Petersburg, 1891, p. 363). In Russia, he was in the service of Cantemir (Kantemir). Brothers: Ilya and Dmitry Koletti. The exact date of Koletti’s death is unknown. P. Pierling believed that he died in 1738 or in 1739 (Pierling P. La Russie et le Saint-Siège ..., p. 393); P. Bushkovich, apparently following Pierling, cited the same years, clarifying that Koletti died at the Peter and Paul Fortress (Бушкович П. Петр Великий... p. 403), but according to the documents of the Synod, Koletti did not just die in the fortress, but was “put to death” (ODDS (Description of Documents and Files Stored in the Archives of the Holy Governmental Synod)), vol. XIX (1739), St. Petersburg, 1913, No. 93, col. 154). Religion: Orthodox.
Education:
1696–1708 – Flanginian School in Venice; 1708 – University of Padua, Faculty of Liberal Arts.
In 1696, Liberius entered the Flanginian School in Venice, created in 1665 with the money of Thomas Flanginis, a famous figure of the Greek fraternity in Venice. Anastasy (Anastasius) or Afanasy (Athanasius) Condoidi (Kondoidi), the future bishop of Vologda, later bishop of Suzdal, interceded over his admission to the school. Koletti’s studies took 12 years. Philological disciplines formed the basis at the Flanginian School: Ancient Greek and Modern Greek, Latin and Italian, grammar, poetics, rhetoric, logic, philosophy. After graduation from the school, Liberius Koletti was admitted to the Faculty of Liberal Arts at the University of Padua. A few years later, he interrupted his studies at the university, apparently to move to Halle.
Career:
During his studies at the Flanginian School, Liberius was ordained a priest. 
Apparently, in Halle he cooperated with Francke not only in the publication of the Gospel, but he also taught at the Collegium Orientale Theologicum, headed by the German scholar. In 1728, Koletti wrote about this period of his life. Among other things, he mentioned that he had taught Greek at the Saxon Academy in the city of Halle (RGIA (Russian State Historical Archives), f. 796, op. 9. 1728, No. 638, fol. 15)
In Halle, he met Tsarevich Alexey (Alexei) Petrovich. It is difficult to say how exactly he met Alexey Petrovich and who exactly initiated the meeting. According to I.A. Chistovich, Koletti could be recommended as a confessor to the then German resident Aleksey Petrovich, who was studying at the University of Halle with the son of the head of the Monastery Prikaz P.I. Musin-Pushkin. Acquaintance with the Tsarevich must have been made by 1710, because in a letter sent from Leipzig on 1 October of the same year, the Tsarevich reported that the day before he had received Communion from the Greek Priest (apparently, he meant Liberius. – D.R.) He was in the service of Aleksey Petrovich until January 1712.
In 1712, Liberius Koletti arrived in Moscow with a letter dated 23 January 1712 from Tsarevich Alexey Petrovich to Yakov Ignatyev, in which the Tsarevich called him “father Liberius, the “Holy-Greek-Priest” and asked Ignatyev “to not leave him in need”.
By order of the locum tenens of the patriarchal throne, Stefan Yavorsky, he was appointed Greek teacher. In the Russian prikaz documents, he was only referred to as “the Greek school teacher, the Greek priest Liberius” or “the Iereus Liberius” while his surname Koletti was never mentioned. Liberius sometimes indicated his surname (in Greek), when he put his signature in account books to obtain money.
In 1714, he was summoned to the Tsarevich in Saint Petersburg and went with him to Germany. The events of 1714–1718 have only been retraced tentatively (?). On 4 March 1718 he was unfrocked for the trip to the Tsarevich, of whom he knew that he was on the run (and why he took 200 chervonets), and for compiling a ciphered alphabet. On 16 March 1718 for participation in the case of Tsarevich Alexey, he was convicted and exiled “forever” to the Solovetsky Monastery. It was mentioned that he had confessed to the accusations. It should be noted that during the interrogation Alexey Petrovich denied the fact of having met Liberius Koletti while he was on the run in Europe. Perhaps, this saved Koletti from execution. He was brought to Solovki on 16 July 1718 and spent 10 years in exile. We know little about this period of his life. There he took monastic vows under the name of Evfimy (Euthymius).
In 1728, following the decision of the Supreme Privy Council, he was released and returned to Saint Petersburg. On 14 October 1728, after learning about the death of the archimandrite of the Novospassky Monastery, he submitted a petition to the Supreme Privy Council for a “gracious appointment”. In December 1728, his petition was transferred to the Holy Synod, where on 23 December it was ordered to appoint him archimandrite at the Novospassky Monastery in Moscow in place of the deceased archimandrite Ierofey (Hierotheos). According to the decree of the Empress Anna Ioannovna dated 16 September 1730, he was transferred as the archimandrite to the Chudov Monastery in Moscow. In 1730, he became a member of the Holy Synod. However, his quick and successful career in the Church was quite short. He spent four incomplete years at large. On 10 August 1732, he was arrested again, this time for his contacts with the Dominican Ribeira and for copying and translating his “notebooks”, Ribeira’s treatise against the book by Buddeus. Until 1734, Koletti was an archimandrite, but in 1735 he was unfrocked and deprived of the priesthood. Therefore, the Synod ordered that he be called by his former name – not Euthymius, but Liberius. Then he was arrested and, apparently in 1738 or 1739, according to the documents of the Synod, he was “put to death”.

In the early 1730s, he became an active participant in several notable episodes of theological polemics. At the time, along with other members of the Synod, he was an object of interest for the Catholic missionary Abbot Jubé, who negotiated with him on the convening of a conference on the union of churches. It is also known that Koletti took the side of the archimandrite Platon Malinovsky, who opposed V.K. Trediakovsky.
He was particularly active in the affair, which eventually led to his imprisonment and death. In October 1728, with the assistance of the archbishop Feofilakt (Theophylactus) Lopatinsky and with the permission of the Supreme Privy Council, the work «Камень веры» (“The Stone of Faith”) written by Stefan Yavorsky was published, directed against the foundations of Protestantism; according to Feofan (Theophan) Prokopovich, it was written in favour of Catholics. In 1729, in Leipzig, a specialised German academic publication (Acta eruditorum, mens maji. Lipsiae, 1729) published an analysis of the written monument with attacks on Lopatinsky. The same year in Jena, another work on the same topic was published in the Meyer printing house: the book by a Protestant theologian, professor of the Jena University, J.F. Buddeus (Epistola apologetic pro ecclesia lutherana contra calumnias et obtrectationes Stephani Javorskii), who sharply criticised the “Stone of Faith” and Stefan Yavorsky personally. The publications marked the beginning of a long polemic in Russia and in Western Europe between supporters of Catholicism and Protestantism. Feofilakt (Theophylactus) Lopatinsky and the chaplain at the Spanish embassy, the Dominican Bernard Ribeira, each wrote a treatise refuting the contributions of the Protestant theologian. Koletti contributed to the copying of the Latin text of the work by Ribeira for a subsequent translation, which was later blamed on him by the Russian authorities.
Teaching institutions and families:
Liberius Koletti’s Greek School (Moscow).
The school existed from March 1712 to 1714 at the Novgorod Podvorye in Moscow and was administered by the Book Printing Prikaz, through which the school was financed. The first payment of Koletti’s salary was dated 13 March 1712, when he was paid ten roubles. Then, throughout 1712, his salary was 2 grivnas “per day”. He was paid his salary on 15 July, 9 September, 22 October, 29 November and 24 December 1712. In January 1713, his salary increased and became “six altyns, four dengas per day” (RGADA (Russian State Archives of Ancient Documents), f. 1182, d. 110, p. 7, 41, 70); it was paid on 28 January, 9 March and 18 May 1713. In June 1713, Liberius was paid “ten altyns a day. Nine roubles in total.” Liberius received his salary until 7 February 1714, when he was last mentioned in the books of the Book Printing Prikaz. “The Greek school teacher, the Greek priest Liberius” or “the Iereus Liberius”.
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
Ivan Grigoryev, Kuzma Grigoryev, Nikita Grigoryev, Nikolay Prokofyev, Vasily Alekseev, Kozma Semenov (Semyonov), Ivan Elevferiev.
Among Liberius’ students, who received meal allowances, several were initially mentioned: Ivan Grigoryev, Kuzma Grigoryev, Nikita Grigoryev, Nikolay Prokofyev, and only the first was given “three dengas a day”, the others received “two dengas” (RGADA, f. 1182, d. 64, fol. 32v-33). A year later, the number of students increased: among the people who received daily meals on 30 March 1713, there were six students (ibid., d. 108, fol. 58v-59) – “Ivan Grigoryev from Meshchanskaya, Filipov priest’s son”; “Nikita Grigoryev from Ioakim (Joachim) and Anna, who live behind the Moscow river, a deacon’s son; Nikolay Prokopiev, Philip the Apostle’s, behind the Arbat gate, the deacon’s son; Vasily Alekseev, from the Savior in Glinitsa, a deacon’s son; Kozma Grigoryev, an iconographer’s son; Kozma Semenov (Semyonov), from our Lady of the Sign, a priest’s son”; from June 1713 onwards, a certain Ivan Elevferiev was also mentioned.
Teaching methods and materials: Unknown. One can only assume that it was based on teaching methods used at European collegiums.
Language and other teaching books by the:
After graduation from the school, he took part in the work on the poetry collection “Ἄνθη Εὐλαβείας” (“Flowers of Piety”), published in Venice in 1708. The authors of the poems were school graduates. Koletti composed a poetic prologue and epilogue for the edition; he was also the editor of the entire collection.
After interrupting his studies at the university, he moved to Halle, where he participated in the project of the famous German theologian, the scholar-philologist August Hermann Francke (1663–1727), devoted to the publication of the New Testament in Ancient and Modern Greek. In this case, Koletti translated the text into Modern Greek and acted as an editor for the publication, as indicated in the book.

Personal records: (Monastic name: Irakli) (*1703, Russian Empire – 1765-10-26, Chernihiv, Russian Empire). Ivan Komarovsky was born into the family of a priest of noble origin. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: Immediately after graduation in the 1720s Ivan Komarovsky began teaching Latin in the syntax class at the Chernihiv Collegium; then he became a rhetoric professor. On 1 November 1730 he took monastic vows and the monastic name Ivan. He served as hieromonk and cathedral clerk in Chernihiv. In 1731–1732, he was hegumen of the Kostyansky Holy Trinity Monastery (Chernihiv Diocese), then of the Surazhichi and Kamensky Starodub Monasteries (Chernihiv Diocese). From 1737 onwards, archimandrite at the Holy Trinity Ilinsky Monastery in Chernihiv. From 8 September 1752, bishop of Chernihiv and Novhorod-Siverskyi. In 1761, he retired and was soon appointed archimandrite at the Holy Trinity Ilinsky Monastery, where he died.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the early 1720s, more than 200 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium; so there were several dozen students in the syntax class taught by Komarovsky.
Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Komarovsky, students learned grammar and syntax rules; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Chernihiv Collegium from the first years of its existence was the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari, De Institutione Grammatica, Monachii [München]: apud Nicolaum Henricum, sumptibus Samuelis Maderi, 1625.
