Personal records: (or Kiryak) (1703, Russian Empire – 1788-09-14/25, Saint Petersburg). Father: a nobleman, sotnik (officer) in the Okhtyrka Sloboda regiment; he was killed at the Battle of Poltava in 1709. Uncle: Gabriel Boužinskij (1680–1731), graduated from the Kyiv-Mohyla Collegium, taught philosophy at the Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy in Moscow in 1709–1711; appointed adviser to the Holy Synod and protector of schools and printing houses of the spiritual department in December 1721; from 1726 onwards he was the bishop of Ryazan and Murom; a representative of the early Russian Enlightenment, an author of many sermons, he translated the following works from Latin into Russian: “Friendly Conversations” by Erasmus of Rotterdam (1716), “An Introduction to the History of the Principal Kingdoms and States of Europe” by Samuel Puffendorf (1718), and “Featron or Historical Shame” by Wilhelm Stratemann (1724). In 1731, Gabriel Boužinskij’s large library was transferred to the Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy. G. Boužinskij had a great influence on the formation of K. Kondratovich as a person. In 1738, Kondratovich married the daughter of a Swedish hammersmith in Yekaterinburg; three of his children were also born there. Religion: Orthodox.
Education:
Kondratovich wrote about the education that he had received in his childhood and teenage years at his own expense, in his report for the Chancellery of the Academy of Sciences dated 13 October 1766: “Upon the death of my parent, along with Russian writing and besides vocal and instrumental music, I studied – at the Kyiv Academy – the Latin and Polish languages for 15 years at my own expense and, beginning with grammar, I finished studying in Latin – focusing on poetry, rhetoric and parts of philosophy: logic, physics, metaphysics and theology, the which exercises, according to the ukase (decree) of the Emperor Peter I, should be considered ranks and should be taken into account for professors”.
He graduated from a full course at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy with a break in 1730, but continued his self-education through active reading during his whole life.
Languages and other subjects taught by t:
Latin; Russian; civil and ecclesiastical history; logic; physics; poetry; rhetoric; literature; philosophy.

In 1735–1736, Kondratovich had to teach Russian to some of the first pupils of the Latin school, who were not sufficiently trained to read and write at home, or were transferred from the Yekaterinburg verbal school to the Latin one without solid writing skills.
Career:
School teacher. In 1727, the bishop of Ryazan and Murom Gabriel Boužinskij called for Kondratovich to come to Pereslavl-Ryazansky, where he taught Latin at the Slavic-Greek-Latin School from September 1727 to August 1728. Back in Kyiv, he graduated from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in 1730. In 1731–1732, he was a singer at the court of the barons Stroganov in Moscow, from where he was taken to the imperial court as a gusli player and took part in concerts, playing the table-like gusli. Later he claimed that he had been a “court philosopher”. In November 1733, K. Kondratovich was transferred to Theophan Prokopovich to assist in the translation of theological works. He translated Reyman’s work “Изображение сокращения богословского” from Latin (the location of the manuscript is unknown).
According to Kondratovich, in March 1734 Prokopovich recommended him to V.N. Tatishchev, appointed head of the state-owned factories in the Urals and Siberia, as a translator of Latin books, which Tatishchev needed in order to write the “Russian History”, and as a teacher of the future Latin school.
On behalf of Tatishchev, Kondratovich compiled a list of books for the future Latin school in Yekaterinburg; the list was sent to the Academy of Sciences in January 1735. As the school pupils advanced in the sciences, he compiled new reading lists for the Latin school. As a result, when Kondratovich and the rector Störmer provided their next lists of books necessary for foreign-language schools in Yekaterinburg, in December 1737 V.N. Tatishchev sent a large parcel of books (269 books including independents) from Samara to the Urals. The books were ordered by I. Kirilov for the school, which he was going to open in Orenburg after its founding. The books were transferred to the Ministry of Mines Library and began to be used by teachers in Yekaterinburg.
From 6 November 1735, the opening day of the Latin school in Yekaterinburg, up to its closure in December 1741, he was a Latin teacher and taught all the Russian students, children of church major and minor orders, who were brought, by order of the authorities, from all the state-owned factories, settlements and villages, ascribed to the factories, from Kungur and the surrounding villages. The second teacher Soechting, who did not speak Russian, taught only a few foreigners living in Yekaterinburg. Kondratovich deserves credit for teaching children of the Urals clergy Latin as well as the basics of poetry, rhetoric, history, literature, and the ABC of philosophy.
Since no copy of E. Alvarez’s Latin grammar book (Kondratovich had ordered 25 copies) was brought from the Book Chamber of the Academy of Sciences to Yekaterinburg in 1735, he undertook the compilation of the first Russian textbook of the Latin language. For this purpose, he translated his personal textbooks into Russian.
Of course, this work could be carried out only with Tatishchev’s permission and blessing. The textbook compiled by Kondratovich was supposed to be sent to the Academy of Sciences for printing and using in Russian schools. While the textbook was being compiled, some parts were distributed among the pupils of the Yekaterinburg Latin school for copying and learning.
In October 1737, he requested eight dest’s (192 sheets) of “good” paper for copying the Latin-Russian grammar book and syntax – that he had translated himself – in order to send it to Saint-Petersburg. On 28 December 1738 Tatishchev sent the “syntax translated by Kondratovich” from Samara to the Academy. On his arrival in the capital, on 15 February 1739 he announced a “prosody of Latin poetry” translated by Kondratovich.
In 1742, he returned to Saint Petersburg, where he applied for a position of “professor of Latin-Russian and Russian-Latin lexicons at the Academy of Sciences”. In 1743, he was accepted as a senior translator at the Academy of Sciences with a salary of 300 roubles per year, where he worked on the compilation of a number of lexicons and translated various works into Russian. Only a part of those works has been published.
Kondratovich’s last published works were “Польский общий словарь и библейный…” (St. Petersburg, 1775) and “Декционер или речениар по алфавиту российских слов о разных произращениях” (St. Petersburg, 1780). A large number of translations made by Kondratovich have never seen the light of day, including the “Перевод Гомеровых Илиады и Одиссеи” (Translation of the Homeric Iliad and the Odyssey). But his first lexicon presented to the Academy subsequently formed the basis for the development of the first Russian dictionary, published by the Russian Academy in 1786–1794.
Bibliographical sources present an ambiguous evaluation of Kondratovich’s translations and essays, but note at the same time that he is worthy of attention as one of the first representatives of the literary “workafrolics” – people obsessed with a passion for writing and translations – who emerged in Russia in the 18th century.
Teaching institutions and families:
Pereslavl-Ryazansky Slavic-Greek-Latin School (1727–1728); Yekaterinburg Latin School (1735–1741).
The family of Baron Stroganov, Saint Petersburg (1742–1743).
In the family of Baron Sergey Grigorievich Stroganov (1707–1756), he taught the only son Alexander Sergeyevich (1733–1811), a future State council member, senator, president of the Imperial Academy of Arts, a famous collector.
Students and their social status:
Church officers; factory workers; clerks; merchants; landless peasants.
Kondratovich taught in the 2nd and 3rd forms of the Yekaterinburg Latin School, where mostly students from Russian families were present. Children of foreigners living in Yekaterinburg went to the 1st form and were instructed by the German teacher Lawrence Soechting, who did not know the Russian language.
On 6 November 1735 the sons of the Yekaterinburg protopope (archpriest) Ioann – Petr and Alexey (11 and 12 years old) – became Kondratovich’s first pupils. In January 1736, six pupils from settlements ascribed to factories, from Kungur and the surrounding villages were enrolled, in February, eight more, in September, five more pupils entered the school. From the summer of 1736 onwards, three teenagers studied “according to their own free will”.
The age of the first students was from 10 to 20 years-old. After a fourth form was created under the guidance of the exiled assistant Alexander Nakrapaev in the middle of October 1736, Kondratovich taught 20 students (12 in the 2nd form and 8 in the 3rd form); 17 students (11 and 6 respectively) in March 1738, and 16 students (10 and 6 respectively) in November of the same year. In 1739–1740, the division into forms was not shown in the reports.
In May 1739, there were 41 pupils at the school, and Kondratovich probably taught 28 of them, judging by the “sciences”, including grammar. From September 1739 to May 1740, 47 students studied at the school; the number of Kondratovich’s students possibly increased.
According to the decree of the Synod dated 28 August 1739 and 1 April 1740 and addressed to the General Mining Directory (“General-berg-direktorium”), and to the supporting decrees issued by the Directory on 4 September 1739 and 30 April 1740, the Ural authorities were no longer allowed to accept children of clergy in the mining schools; instead they were supposed to let them enter the seminaries of the Vyatka and Tobolsk eparchies (dioceses).
After 37 children of clergy were dismissed from the school in June 1740, in addition to the seven remaining pupils, 13 newcomers were accepted in the Latin school in March 1741. Nakrapaev started teaching the beginners, and Kondratovich continued teaching six teenagers who enrolled in the school on 1 September 1739 and one more student who enrolled in 1736.
In the first place, children of priests and clergymen, who lived on the territory of the Ministry of Mines (priests, deacons, readers, sextons, men responsible for refectories), enrolled in the Latin school, although according to the Russian legislation then in force (Spiritual Regulation 1721, decrees of 1722), they were subject to being taught at the Vyatka and Tobolsk seminaries. From October 1736 onwards, Kondratovich gave classes to children of clergy and to one son of a craftsman. Among the “free” people, who had entered the school at their own request, he taught Petr Klyucharov, nephew of the secretary of the Chancellery of the factory headquarters (until September 1738), Matvey Borisov, son of the clerk, and Alexey Kharchevnikov, son of a merchant (in 1737 they were no longer listed).
After the dismissal of the children of clergy in June 1740, Kondratovich continued teaching seven teenagers, among whom sons of craftsmen (hammersmith, handler, sawyer), of a blacksmith, of a furnace charger, and of a landless peasant.
Teaching methods and materials:
The educational programme at the school has been reconstructed on the basis of reports about students’ progress, which teachers submitted to the authorities every fourth month of the year; on the grounds of certificates, which teachers gave to their best students when sending them for further training with factory specialists; as well as on the basis of the certificate obtained by Kondratovich himself when he finished his work at the school in 1741.
During the first year of the school’s work, until the assistant Nakrapaev was accepted, Kondratovich taught the alphabet, pronunciation and the basic etymological rules of the Latin language, he also taught some of his students Russian writing. From the autumn of 1736 to 1741, he conducted a broad range of classes from grammar to “higher” sciences.
After “doucheniye” (completing learning?) and “tverzheniye grammatiki” (“grammar repetition and consolidation?” – which in fact meant spelling), students began the study of syntax and started doing translations from Russian into Latin. Some students (probably because the part of the prosody translated by Kondratovich was not available for them) began to “translate minor exercises” immediately after the “tverzheniye grammatiki” (spelling). The following comment was made in relation to some of the students: “he begins to translate at the end of the grammar course”.
Studying prosody, that is the intonational aspect of the language, students continued practicing translation from Russian into Latin, while in the last third of 1738 (September–December) the following comment was made in respect of all of the students who were “at the beginning”, “in the middle” or “at the end of the prosody” course: “with translation and book interpretation”. This means that along with translating texts from Russian into English, interpretation of the books that the students were reading was introduced. Unfortunately, their names have never been mentioned. They might have included small volumes of poetry by Horace and Virgil, and other publications available at the school.
Upon finishing the prosody course (after two and a half years in the school), his best student, son of a priest Andrey Vesnin, moved from prosody to rhetoric – in May 1738 he was “at the end of the prosody course” and was working with “poetical and rhetorical tropes and schemes”. In the first third of 1739, the second best performing pupil, son of a priest Fedor Kochnev, who enrolled in the school in February 1736, “finished learning prosody, and was studying poetical and rhetorical tropes and schemes”.
As noted by P.V. Znamensky, a specialist in the history of religious schools in Russia, rhetoric in most seminaries of that time was the pinnacle of education; and some handwritten rhetoric textbooks were available. Apparently, the manuscripts on rhetoric which Kondratovich used were the same manuscripts that he had used for his education at the Kyiv Academy. Some individual leaves were copied for students, in particular those focused on figures of speech (tropes and schemes), expressions of praise and censure, and laudation; sonorous phrases, comparisons, sententiae, examples from history, etc.
In the second third of 1739 (May–August) – after three and a half years of study – two of the best students were reported “at the beginning of (the course on) poetry, verse-making and at the beginning of (the course on) logic, which is the first part of philosophy”.
In the last four months of 1739, they were already “at the beginning of physics and poetry exercises”, in the first third of 1740 – “in the middle of physics”. Seven pupils began studying logic. Some of them repeated (consolidated) grammar, prosody and syntax for a third time.
Reports for the first third of 1740 noted that several students (who were “at the end of the grammar course”) also read the Latin and Russian Bible and made “broken” Latin verses, that ecclesiastical and civil history was interpreted for them, and that they wrote about and explained different ages of the Latin language, and about barbarisms and solecisms, as well as translated exercises.

The first stages of language learning were based on the printed alphabet. Then students copied into their notebooks and memorised I.F. Kopiyevsky’s vocables. Having reached the middle of the pronunciation course, students began to write in Latin in their notebooks. Those who were bad writers in Russian practiced their native language as well. After that, the “Latin grammar” (by which Kondratovich meant spelling and etymology) was copied into a special notebook. It was followed by copying the following parts of grammar – syntax and prosody.
Students copied the text from the manuscript grammar while Kondratovich composed its text in Russian, apparently using his own printed textbook “Alvares Emmanuel, De institutione grammatica libri tres”. This grammar book was very popular in Europe in the 17th-18th centuries and even until the middle of the 19th century. It is this book that Kondratovich included in the list of textbooks for the Latin school, ordered by the Ural authorities for the Academy of Sciences in 1735, but of which not a single copy was sent to Yekaterinburg. Apparently, the Book Chamber itself did not have the book.
The grammar text, translated by Kondratovich, was copied without corrections by his assistant Nakrapaev in order to send it to the Academy of Sciences. The book probably had multiple copies, because a single rough copy, written by Kondratovich, was hardly enough. Several students copied the beginning, the middle, and the end of the grammar book at the same time (a final draft of the translation was ready to be sent to Samara for Tatishchev in November 1738). As Kondratovich pointed out in his report for the authorities in October 1738, seven reams of paper, that is 2940 sheets, were needed for 40 students.
As long as the grammar book was being copied, the text was memorised and then repeated (consolidated). Probably because the multiple copying of the handwritten text of the textbook was too slow, some teenagers, according to the reports, repeated (consolidated) grammar, syntax, and prosody for a second or even third time.
The following aspects were written down in some notebooks: “poetical and rhetorical figures”, “translation exercises from Russian into Latin”, “translation from Latin into Russian”, “composing Russian poetry”. Special notebooks were required for “copying Latin-Russian and Russian-Latin poetical verses”, for “Discussions”, for “philosophy, logic, and so on and so forth”. The most advanced students were supposed to have 11 notebooks. Thus, they formed their own set of hand-written textbooks.

On Tatishchev’s instructions he also participated in the compilation of the following language lexicons: a Russian-Latin lexicon, which he put together with Störmer’s Russian-German lexicon to create a single Russian-Latin-German dictionary; he also began to compose a Latin-Russian-German dictionary, and collected words starting with the letter “A”. The compilation of the language lexicons of peoples of the Urals was conducted according to the following rule: up to 200 similar Russian words were selected for the lexicon. Personal records: (or Koncewicz, or Koptsevich/Kopcewicz) († 1720-01-23, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Serapion Kontsevich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: We only know that in 1718 Serapion Kontsevich was a grammar class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. He was appointed by Feofan Prokopovich as a teacher in Pskov, but died before he could start work.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the grammar class, in which Serapion Kontsevich taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Serapion Kontsevich, students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. As did other grammar teachers’ students, Serapion Kontsevich’s students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The library of the St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery in Kyiv still has a collection of exercises performed by Serapion Kontsevich’s students at school and at home (“Liber occupationum etеxercitiorum…”,No. 509, ff. 1-84). These exercises reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in this class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: We only know that in the 1756–1757 school year Pakhomy Kopiysky was a syntax class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium. At the time, he was a hieromonk.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1756–1757).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1750s, more than 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the syntax class, in which Pakhomy Kopiysky taught.
Most of the students at Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families (although, students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there).
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Pakhomy Kopiysky, students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at Kharkiv Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the middle of the 1750s was still the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. A large number of Latin textbooks published for the Jesuit collegiums of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) were recorded in the library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753). Also, Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues” were already used at that time. The library of the collegium had several lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Kharkiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Personal records: (1764, Drimaylivka village in the Nizhyn regiment, Russian Empire). Son of a priest. Brother: Fiodor Ivanovich Korbeletsky (1775–1837), a public school teacher in Saint Petersburg, then served in the Novgorod provincial government, later at the Ministry of Finance; he was the author of a number of solemn odes and of the brochure titled «Краткое повествование о вторжении французов в Москву…» («A Brief History of the French Invasion of Moscow ...») Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Until 1792, Ioakim Korbeletsky studied at the Chernihiv Collegium, including the theological class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar and syntax; Ancient Greek grammar and syntax; philosophy.
Career: Immediately after graduation in 1792, Ioakim Korbeletsky became a Latin teacher in the higher grammar class at the Chernihiv Collegium. From 1796 onwards, he taught philosophy and Ancient Greek. He was ordained a priest, and from 1798 onwards, he was the Prefect of the collegium and protopriest. In 1803, as a result of a conflict with the Bishop of Chernihiv, Victor (Sadkovsky), he was dismissed from the collegium and became a protopope (archpriest) in the town of Oster. During this conflict, Ioakim Korbeletsky wrote several appeals to the Minister of Justice Gavriil Derzhavin, with a request for help. These letters were written in verse form.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1792–1803).
Students and their social status:
Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families (though students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). In the 1790s, there were more than 20 secular students in the higher grammar class. Several sons of secular parents also studied Ancient Greek.
When Ioakim Korbeletsky taught at the Chernihiv Collegium, more than 700 students were enrolled at the school (for example, in the 1796–1797 school year, the collegium had 711 students). First, Ioakim Korbeletsky taught Latin in the higher grammar class. There were more than 130 students in this class. Then he taught Ancient Greek to students from the rhetoric class and to several students from the philosophy class. By the beginning of the nineteenth century, the number of those who studied the Greek language had increased to 50. Contemporaries associated this fact with Ioakim Korbeletsky’s teaching talent.
Teaching methods and materials: At the beginning of the 1790s, there were well-established traditions of teaching Latin and Ancient Greek (from the beginning of the 1780s) at the Chernihiv Collegium. Teaching Ancient Greek grammar was planned over two years. Students were supposed to finish the grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of their studies. In the higher grammar class taught by Ioakim Korbeletsky, students finished learning Latin grammar rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. In this class, students were supposed to converse in Latin as well. Latin grammar classes at the Chernihiv Collegium were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The collegium had a great number of books by this author, published in different years. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students show that they also translated prayers, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. Ancient Greek grammar was taught, using the book by Varlaam Liaschevsky. The book was translated from Latin and was used at the collegium at this time. After learning the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, the teacher and his students were supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. In the library of the Chernihiv Collegium, there were more than ten textbooks on Ancient Greek. A huge number of Greek grammar books, Greek-Latin lexicons and various books in Greek were transferred to the collegium at the request of teachers as part of the Chernihiv bishop Kirill Liashevetsky’s personal library in 1770 (after his death). Personal records: (1764-06-13 – 1831-08-11, Stara Wieś, Austrian Empire). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Antony Korsak joined the Society of Jesus in August 1781 and entered the Orsha Collegium, where he studied for three years. Later, he studied in the philosophy (1786–1788) and theology (1793–1797) classes at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. He finished his studies at the house of the Tertianship in Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) (1797–1798).
Career: Priest. During his teaching career, Korsak worked at all the Collegiums of the Society of Jesus in what is now Belarus. He began teaching in Vitsebsk, where he taught Latin grammar (1784–1786). While learning at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium, Korsak taught Latin grammar and Russian (1788–1789) as well as French (1793–1794). During the 1789–1790 academic year, he taught French, rhetoric and poetics at the Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit Collegium. During the next academic year, he taught the same subjects at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium. Here he was later a boarding school regent (head) (1799–1800) and acting rector (1813–1819). Korsak worked as a teacher of French, rhetoric and poetics, as a boarding school regent and Prefect (1791–1793, 1798–1799) at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium. Finally, he taught rhetoric from 1800 to 1805 at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium. In addition, Korsak was an assistant to the provincial of the Order in Belarus (1805–1812), and the rector of Jesuit churches in Orsha (1819–1820), just before the expulsion of the Jesuits from Russia.
Teaching institutions and families: Vitsebsk Jesuit Collegium; Polatsk Jesuit Collegium; Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit Collegium; Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium; Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium; Orsha Jesuit Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy; nobility; urban middle class.

Scholastic.

Yakov Kozelsky originated from the Cossack elite that joined the Russian nobility. Father: Pavel Stepanovich Kozelsky, an appointed Sotnyk of the Poltava regiment of the Russian Empire. Uncle: Yakov Kozelsky was a deputy of the Commission for the Drafting of a New Code of Laws for the Russian Empire (source: wikipedia.org). Children: Evgraf, Ekaterina. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1744 until 1750, Kozelsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. He finished the course on rhetoric and acquired a basic knowledge of Latin. Although he had not completed the whole educational programme, in 1750 he moved to Saint Petersburg and enrolled at the Academy School. In 1752, he matriculated at the academic university to study philosophy with Professor Joseph Adam Braun and maths with Professor Georg Wilhelm Richmann.
Career: Translator, writer. Like many of his fellow students, Kozelsky was obliged to teach at the Academy School in addition to his studying at the university. Accordingly, in 1753, he began to teach German in the lower German class. A report of K.F. Moderach, inspector of the Academy School, including detailed comments on the pedagogical abilities and personal qualities of the ‘student-teachers’, contains information about Kozelsky (see SPFA RAN, f. 3, op. 9, no. 1120, pp. 1-4). Kozelsky taught German at the Academy School until January 1756. In May 1757, he asked to leave the Academy of Sciences and joined the army. Promoted by the prokuror of the Ministry of commerce (Kommertskollegiia) N. Samarin, he became an infantryman in the Preobrazhenskiy regiment and finally obtained the rank of an engineer-captain of the artillery (1764). In the early 1760s, Kozelsky returned to his pedagogical activities, in fact as maths and mechanics teacher at the Artillery and Engineering Cadets Corps. Simultaneously he began to compose his own school books on arithmetic (‘Арифметические предложения’) and mechanics (‘Механические предложения’), both published in 1764. Furthermore, he translated works on European political history from French and German into Russian. In 1766, Kozelsky left the army to join the civil administration as a secretary of the Senate. Possibly due to his democratic ideas, Kozelsky was dismissed from the Senate in 1770 and was transferred to the Collegium of Little Russia in Glukhov. He retired in 1778 with the rank of a privy councillor. However, he renewed his teaching work once again, becoming inspector of the Grammar School for Foreign Fellow Believers (‘гимназии для чужеземных единоверцев’), which was installed at the Artillery and Engineering Cadets Corps especially for children from Greek families who came to Russia during the Russian-Turkish War of 1787–1791. Due to health reasons he retired permanently in July 1793 and moved back to his estate in the Ukraine.
Teaching institutions and families:
Academy School at the Academy of Sciences; Artillery and Engineering Cadets Corps; Grammar School for Foreign Fellow Believers (all in Saint Petersburg).
From 1755 on, Kozelsky was a tutor in German, Latin and mathematics for the nephew of the Ministry of Commerce procurator (later – Ministry of commerce vice-president) Nikolai Mikhailovich Samarin.
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants.
Nephew of N.M. Samarin, Ministry of Commerce procurator.

Personal records: (or Kozłowicz, or Koslovich/Kosłowicz; secular name: Zakhary) (1703, Lutsk, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – 1758-03-17, Pereiaslav, Russian Empire). Ioann Kozlovich was born into a meschane (urban low- and middle class) family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Ioann Kozlovich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar; Polish grammar; Latin syntax; Polish syntax; philosophy.
Career: Immediately after graduation, in the 1738–1739 school year, Ioann Kozlovich became a teacher in the grammar class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In the 1739–1740 school year, he taught in the syntax class. At that time, he took monastic vows. In the 1740–1741 school year, he taught in the rhetoric class. In 1742–1748, Ioann Kozlovich was a philosophy teacher and a prefect, then he became the rector of the Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy. On 8 May 1748 he was appointed archimandrite at the Donskoy Monastery and the Zaikonospassky Monastery (the Monastery of the Holy Mandylion) in Moscow. From 7 March 1753 until his death, he was bishop of Pereiaslav and Boryspil.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1738–1741); Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy (1742–1748).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied in the grammar and syntax classes, in which Ioann Kozlovich taught. For example, in 1738, there were 50 students in the grammar class taught by Ioann Kozlovich; in 1739, there were 65 students in the syntax class.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Ioann Kozlovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. As other grammar teachers’ students, Ioannn Kozlovich’s students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The exercises we still have reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in a syntax class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Career: Translator. In February 1754, Adam Krabe was appointed teacher for the German language in the middle [«средний»] German class of the Academy School. Later, in May 1760, Krabe is documented as «komissar» (commissary) at the Academy of Sciences [head of economic supply and pay office].

Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
There were two different categories of students attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils, among them nobles and non-nobles. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Konstantin Kryzhanovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class. We also know that after the academy he studied abroad (presumably in Pressburg (now Bratislava)).
Career: In the 1752–1753 school year, Konstantin Kryzhanovsky taught Ancient Hebrew and German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1753 onwards, he taught French. In 1754, he became a priest at the academic congregational church; from 1758 he was a cathedral preacher. At the same time, he continued teaching Ancient Hebrew and French. From 1760 onwards, he served as protoiereus in the town of Romny (Myrhorod regiment). According to the available sources, in 1771 Konstantin Kryzhanovsky was still a protoiereus in Romny.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1752–1760).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At that time, several dozen Kyiv-Mohyla Academy students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes learned Ancient Hebrew, German and French as an option.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
Konstantin Kryzhanovsky continued the systematic teaching of Ancient Hebrew and German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, initiated by Simon Todorsky, Varlaam Liaschevsky and Manassia Maksimovich. The teaching of Ancient Hebrew, German and French was designed for two years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. Students were supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. By this time, the Academy had developed certain rules for teaching languages, which can be traced through a number of instructions and reports made by teachers. Konstantin Kryzhanovsky’s reports have also been preserved.
Some of the books used by Konstantin Kryzhanovsky for teaching the languages had been brought by Simon Todorsky from Germany. For teaching Ancient Hebrew, he used a grammar book written by Johann Heinrich Michaelis. It is known that grammar rules were consolidated through reading abstracts from works by various authors as well as through translating passages from various texts. Probably, Konstantin Kryzhanovsky used some of the different lexicons and grammar books that were available at the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (for example, the books by Heinrich Opitz and Johannes Buxtorf). Something similar can be said with respect to German, for a large number of books concerning the study of the language were available at the library of the academy. However, the rather short descriptions in the catalogue do not make it possible to identify accurately many lexicons, grammar books and dictionaries. 
It is obvious that Konstantin Kryzhanovsky did not lack French textbooks for students either. He could use French grammar books and lexicons that were available at the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library catalogue from the time, it contained a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey.

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: Concerning his career, it is only known that Antony Ksenatsky was “prepared” for the teaching of the Ancient Greek language. He was invited to the Kharkiv Collegium by the rector Iov Bazilevich (he also previously taught Ancient Greek). The choice of teacher was influenced by the fact that Antony Ksenatsky was of Greek origin. In the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach” at the Collegium, written by the Bishop of Belgorod Samuil Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector Iov Bazilevich, to the prefect and to the teachers, modern Greek was also recommended for students to learn. This was believed to improve their understanding of Ancient Greek.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium.
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
During the teaching career of Antony Ksenatsky, slightly more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium (for example, in the 1769/70 school year, there were 422 students). Antony Ksenatsky taught Ancient Greek in the rhetoric school (class), but this language was not studied by all the students. As a rule, 7–10 students learned it.
At that time, most of the students of the rhetoric class at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergymen’s families (although students coming from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). It is most likely that the students of Antony Ksenatsky were primarily children from the families of clergymen.
Teaching methods and materials: The Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach” at the Collegium appeared at the time when Antony Ksenatsky was working at the Kharkiv Collegium (1769). The document gives an idea of the teaching of basic school disciplines, including Ancient Greek. The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was planned over two years. The teacher was supposed to use copybooks at the initial stage of learning so that students could practise writing Greek letters. Grammar rules were taught using the book on Ancient Greek written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, the teacher was supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practice their grammatical analysis. The poems that were analysed by students and their teacher in a similar manner were later to be used by them as material for short speeches and translation exercises. It was recommended to finish the study of the grammar sections and to start learning the syntax and the “idioms” of Ancient Greek in the second year of Greek studies. At this stage, students were supposed to memorize short sentences from the lexicon compiled by Cornelius Schrevelius. The library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The “Instructions” specified that Greek was to be studied by students of the rhetorical, philosophical and theological classes whose command of Latin was good: this was required to understand grammar books and lexicons that were all written in Latin. Concerning the practice of teaching at Collegiums it is known also that grammar rules were consolidated through reading a few other lexicons available in the library of the Collegium. In the second half of the 1760s, several grammar books, dictionaries and lexicons of the Greek language, compiled by well-known European authors (for example, Jacob Gretser, Grzegorz Knapski and others), appeared in the Collegium library. It was common practice to read short extracts from the works of various Greek authors and to translate extracts from various texts (at that time Aesop’s fables and the sermons of Ephrem the Syrian and John Chrysostom are referred to most often). Some of the students continued learning Ancient Greek in the following stages of their education, in the philosophy and theology classes. Then they were engaged in advanced studies of the language. Since Antony Ksenatsky was Greek and spoke Modern Greek, it may be assumed that he taught this language to his students. This practice was common at the Kharkiv Collegium in subsequent years. Personal records: (*Russian Empire) Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Ioann Kurasovsky is that in the 1789–1790 school year he taught Latin at the Kharkiv Collegium. At the time, he was a priest.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1789–1790).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In the 1789–1790 school year, 549 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The lower grammar class taught by Ioann Kurasovsky had 77 students. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families (although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there). For example, in the 1789–1790 school year, there were 15 “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks) children among the 77 students of the lower grammar class in which Ioann Kurasovsky taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ioann Kurasovsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ioann Kurasovsky worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, written by the bishop of Belgorod, Samuil Mislavsky, in 1769 and addressed to the rector, the prefect and the teachers, were in use at the collegium. Latin grammar classes were based on Johann Matthias Gesner’s version of the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues”. At the time, the collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. The library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Personal records:
(or Labache, likely due to deformation)
Gendre de Bousson de Mairet. He was probably the one who was married to a Miss Merray. She arrived in Russia in 1773 and was about thirty-five years old in 1780; she entered the household of Count Panin in Moscow as a governess for his children before marrying de La Biche.
Career:
Deputy governor and tutor to the pages of the Empress in Saint Petersburg, he had been teaching there for ten years by 1779.
The La Biche couple opened an educational boarding school in Saint Petersburg in May 1779. It was a boarding school for girls aged seven to fourteen. They taught French, French spelling, Russian, German, and arithmetic. Mme La Biche personally taught twelve French classes per week, her husband taught eight classes of French spelling and six classes of arithmetic. Mme Rat (?), a German, taught German and Russian. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which examined this boarding school, praised the order, cleanliness, and progress of the students: they could read equally well in Russian, French, and German. However, the boarding school disappeared before the next inspection (1784).
La Biche had to intervene as the executor of the estate in the settlement of the Gréa succession. The French ministry asked him to hand over the amount of the estate to Patot d’Orflans, chancellor of the French consulate in Saint Petersburg. He explained his position in a letter to Vergennes dated 24 January 1780: “It is not from a lack of the strongest confidence that I did not hand it over in time to the said Consul, but he only offered me three livres sixteen sols tournois for the ruble, which at that time was bringing in about four livres two sols through trade with Holland. And if I am not currently depositing the funds of this estate in his chancellery, it is solely to comply with the orders I have received from the heir's family. Thus, My Lord, pressed on one side by the orders of the executrix who instructs me to send the funds of this estate to Mr. Parquez, banker in Paris, and on the other by my respectful submission to your Greatness's orders, I took the liberty of sending them today by a good letter of exchange to the said Mr. Parquez with all the related papers.” La Biche complained of dealing with a family filled with litigious spirit and reported that the deceased was his friend, that the heirs were poor, and that he himself had received nothing for the recovery of this estate.
Teaching institutions and families: An educational boarding school (1779 – before 1784; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (*Thionville) Father: Joseph Labiche. Single. Religion: Catholic.
Career: Governess. She was in the Kaluga province when she took the oath in 1793. Residing in Moscow in 1795, she worked as a tutor for Prince Kozlovski and was part of a group of fourteen French tutors who proposed to establish a mutual aid society for tutors. The members hoped to benefit from the protection of the director of public schools in Moscow. The contributions were intended to cover the medical expenses of the members, provide those who found themselves without a position with "housing, firewood, candles, tea, coffee, and food for the price of 25 rubles per month," and to create a library accessible to all members. Catherine II prohibited the establishment of "such societies and useless organizations" and threatened the tutors with expulsion from the empire should they persist in their intention (see Noël). She was a parishioner at Saint Louis of the French.

Personal records: (or La Fermière) (1737-01-22, Strasbourg – 1796-03-12/23, Andreyevskoye near Pokrovsk, in the estate of Count Alexandre Romanovich Vorontsov (1741–1805), a diplomat and president of the Collegium of Commerce, later chancellor of the empire under Alexander I; buried there). Father: François-Charles Lafermière, an innkeeper. Mother: Marguerite Petit. Religion: Catholic.
Education: François-Hermann Lafermière studied at the University of Strasbourg.
Career: Writer, librarian, and professor to Grand Duke Paul Petrovich. In the mid-1760s, he was engaged as a secretary in the service of Count Mikhail Illarionovich Vorontsov, former chancellor of the empire, who was traveling in Europe. He followed him to Russia. He witnessed the marriage of Dessault/Campion on 31 May 1766 at the Catholic Church in Saint Petersburg. Recommended by Count Vorontsov, he was admitted to the household of Grand Duke Paul Petrovich as a librarian, professor of French literature, French reader, and also as a secretary. He held these positions during the 1770s and 1780s. Lafermière was, by unanimous opinion, a cultured, intelligent, and sociable person; it is not surprising that he quickly played a role at the court of the heir to the throne and in the cultured circles of Saint Petersburg, where he counted many friends, including the famous composer G. Paisiello and the Grand Duke's treasurer and future president of the Imperial Academy of Sciences, Baron H. L. von Nikolai, also originally from Strasbourg. Expatriate French and Swiss individuals, such as the adventurer Pictet "the Giant," a friend of Voltaire and "secretary to the Empress," or Baron Ch. L. Andreu de Bilistein, were part of his circle. Lafermière accompanied the Grand Ducal couple on their travels in Europe. He participated in the amateur theater of the small court and composed librettos for comic operas, at least two of which were set to music by D. S. Bortnianski: Le Faucon in 1786 [the opera was presented again in 1972 by the B. Pokrovski Theater and is still performed by the "Sankt-Peterburg opera"], and Le Fils rival, ou la Moderne Stratonice, staged in 1787. These performances enjoyed considerable success at the Grand Duke's court. Lafermière maintained a close relationship with the heir's wife, Grand Duchess Maria Fiodorovna, who was born and raised in Montbéliard, serving as her French reader; it was probably for this reason that he had to leave the court in 1793 when Paul Petrovich fell in love with Madame Nelidova. He was said to be retired and residing in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793. He soon withdrew to the estate of Count Alexandre Romanovich Vorontsov to spend his final days there. His portrait was executed by an unknown painter (see Russkiye portrety, vol. IV, no. 166).

Vorontsov family; 
professor to Grand Duke Paul Petrovich (future emperor Paul I) in 1770s – 1780s.

Personal records: (1767-02-11, Augsburg – 1844-01-25, Rome). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Alois Landes entered the Society of Jesus in August 1787 and spent the following two years at the Polatsk novitiate.
Career:
Priest. After graduation from the novitiate, Alois Landes taught German at the Mahilyow Jesuit College in the 1789–1790 academic year. Then he was a boarding school regent (head) and a German teacher at the Mstsislaw Jesuit College (1790–1794, 1799–1800). He performed the same functions in 1794–1795 and 1798–1799 at the Vitsebsk Jesuit College. For two years (1795–1797), Landes was a Prefect and a preacher at the Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit College. In 1801–1803, he taught philosophy and mathematics to scholastics at the Polatsk Jesuit College. In March 1803, along with several colleagues, he arrived at the newly-opened mission of the Society of Jesus in Saratov and was at its head until 1809. In 1809, he returned to Polatsk and assumed his duties as a provincial of the Society of Jesus in Belarusia. From 1814 to 1817, he was the rector of the Polatsk Academy, then (1817–1820) he worked as the instructor of the house of the Tertianship in Vitsebsk.
After the dissolution of the Society of Jesus in Russia, Landes went to Vienna, where he sought permission for the Order to remain in the Austrian Empire. In 1822, he was appointed novice master in Stara Wieś (Galicia), and from 1823 to 1828, he was the rector of the local collegium. During the 1828–1829 school year, he was the rector of the Ternopil College. During the Congregation of the Society of Jesus in 1829, he was elected assistant in Germany and remained in that position until his death in 1844.
Teaching institutions and families: Mahilyow Jesuit College; Mstsislaw Jesuit College; Vitsebsk Jesuit College; Dünaburg (now Daugavpils) Jesuit College; Polatsk Jesuit College.
Students and their social status: Clergy; nobility; urban low and middle class.
Teaching methods and materials:
Scholastic.

Career: Lange came to Saint Petersburg in order to study at the Academy University. In November 1735, he was recruited at the Academy School to teach the German class. In August 1737, he was dismissed for health reasons.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1735–1737, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps in St. Petersburg were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils, aged between 6 and 20, attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. Most of these students’ names are known and listed in the registers, including information about their social backgrounds and learning interests.
In November 1736, the rector of the Academy Schoolʼs German section, Martin Schwanwitz, gave a detailed report of the number and social status of all students who were enrolled at the Academy School and learned German. In principle, there were two different categories of students attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitzʼ report lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School specially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was diverse: from the higher nobility, army officers and government functionaries such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants.

(later Marville) (†1755, Paris).
Her maiden name is said to be Latour.
A widow of Count de Launoy (†1726).
Remarried in 1742 to Count de Marville († six months after his wife in 1755 or 1756), a property owner in Villejuif.
Career:
Governess. In 1717, she accompanied her husband to Russia, who had followed Peter I on his journey to Paris. She was appointed in 1719 as the governess and French tutor to the Tsar’s daughters, Anna and Elizabeth, providing them with three lessons a week. According to Campredon, she had "a more than limited intellect, the air of an adventurer rather than that of a woman of status." She was still present at the Russian court in 1725. She introduced Father Cailleau to Empress Catherine I.
Countess de Launoy followed Princess Anna to Holstein after her marriage and returned to France after the latter's death. Empress Elizabeth held her in great affection and took an interest in her well-being until her death. The Countess de Launoy returned to Russia in 1747, having been given 2,000 rubles (equivalent to £10,000) by the Empress; she hoped to regain a position at court and spend her days near her former charge. She was warmly received, had her own apartment at court, and dined almost every day at the Empress’s table. However, she only stayed in Russia for a few months and was back in France before the end of 1747. Grand Duchess Catherine, the future Catherine II, mentioned in her Memoirs the Empress’s desire to rid herself of this unwelcome guest.

Anna Petrovna, Elizabeth Petrovna, daughters of Peter I.

Personal records:
(ar. 1701, probably in Bordeaux – 1770-10-17, Russia) Father: Henry Lavie (*1677, Bordeaux), consul. Mother: Françoise Rocante (*Bordeaux). Children:
  • a son, probably Jean-Théodore de Lavie;
  • a daughter, converted to Catholicism, living in 1745, wife of the Italian gardener at the court, Massa.
Religion: Protestant.
Career:
Tutor. His father brought him to Saint Petersburg around 1717 and placed him as an apprentice with an English merchant in 1722. He was of Protestant faith.
Henri de Lavie served as a tutor in various families in Russia for over forty years. He taught at the Artillery Academy, the Military Engineering Academy, and the Academy of Sciences, where he had Vasili Bajenov as a student. Starting in 1765, he is said to have replaced Nicolas Bilon as a public lecturer and member of Moscow University (according to other sources, he replaced the lecturer Préclos de Léry). Lavie’s candidacy was proposed by the university curator Adadurov along with La Bourdonnais de Couettion, who had the endorsement of the Academy of Sciences. Lavie claimed to have composed Latin verses, but "not being a Poet," he did not wish to take on the teaching of versification; he was also knowledgeable in mythology. He was ready to teach eloquence, "to explain all the figures of rhetoric, to provide the Rules of a discourse, to teach them to compose a narration, an amplification, a fable, to deduce the moral meaning from it, and to explain what hyperbole, pleonasm, irony, and apostrophe are." Lavie passed the examination; it was found that he spoke French, Russian, and Latin fluently. He was also given a topic for a speech, that of the method of learning the French language. He delivered this speech in March 1765 before all members of the university conference and made the best impression. He therefore hoped to receive the position he sought: "When I took the liberty of begging you to honor me with your votes, to be accepted at the University, among other reasons that determined me, the first and most flattering for me was the honor of entering the service of Her Imperial Majesty; the second, the hope that the same position, which Mr. de Léry had been honored with, would not be denied to a man who has been settled in Russia for over forty years, who has served faithfully and honorably, always in the top ranks, as you could see in several letters I have presented, a man who has spent most of his life in Russia, always occupied with the education of the national youth; I implore you to grant me the same honor." By emphasizing the time he had spent in Russia to educate the "national" youth, Lavie believed he was providing a strong argument. This is far from the negative image of the French tutor in Russia, perceived as light-hearted, without constant work, resorting to teaching as a temporary means of livelihood.
It was then that a contract was signed with him for three years. Lavie requested to be appointed as a French reader rather than an "informer," as the title of reader had more advantages. The university curator agreed on 17 May.
On 11 June 1768, Lavie sent a letter to the university conference requesting a salary increase (he earned 300 rubles per year) or permission to leave the university. However, it seems he remained in his position until his death, as it was only in October 1770 that a competition was announced to find his replacement. Champagnolot, Fauvel, and Fiodor Karjavin (one of the first Russians of the third estate to have completed his studies in France) applied for the position, and the latter won it.
Teaching institutions and families: Artillery Academy; Military Engineering Academy; Academy of Sciences; Moscow university; Gymnasium of Moscow university (1765–1770).
Students and their social status: Vasili Bajenov
Teaching methods and materials: At the Gymnasium of Moscow university, Lavie was to teach two hours each day, except on Sundays, explaining the best French authors, literary styles, having students compose speeches and essays on various subjects, correcting them, and also writing examples himself. Additionally, he was to remain at the university twice a week, on Wednesdays and Saturdays, to teach French to students (grammar, reading, analysis of newspapers). He used the Aventures de Télémaque in his lessons. He also participated in the translation of documents at the Empress's request and was released from the obligation to teach for this reason.
Language and other teaching books by the:
He was the author of:
  • L'Alphabet français ou Alphabet françois enrichi d'un vocabulaire et de dialogues les plus faciles augmenté de préceptes et de sentences morales à l'usage des classes inférieures du Gymnase de l’Université de Moscou, new edition revised and corrected by H. de Lavie, public lecturer and member of Moscow University, Moscow, de l'imprimerie de l'Université, 1767, 107 p., in-8°. The work was reissued in 1779, 1780, and 1782. This book was a great success in Moscow bookstores: in 1783, there were 463 copies available in various bookstores in Moscow.

Personal records: (or Ławrowski) Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Iosif Lavrovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including the theology class. During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Career: All we know about Iosif Lavrovsky is that after graduation in 1725 he became an infima class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the infima class in which Iosif Lavrovsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Iosif Lavrovsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (1699-10-15, Wesel, Duchy of Cleves – 1774-07-06, Berlin) Father: Pierre le Roy. Mother: Marie Bossu. He was likely of Huguenot descent.
Education: Pierre-Louis Le Roy studied in Berlin, Frankfurt, and Halle.
Career:
Professor, foreign honorary member of the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg. He was called to Russia in 1731 to become the tutor of the eldest son of Duke Biron. He joined the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg as a translator and professor of "modern history" on 5 May 1735. On 19 May of the same year, he was introduced to the members of the Academy by its president, Baron I. A. Korf. He received a salary of 660 rubles. By the Senate decree of 30 June 1735, he was appointed secretary and curator of the maps of the newly created geography department, which was directed by the academician N.-J. Delisle. He was thus tasked, along with Delisle and Leonhard Euler, with the design of the map of the Russian Empire. He was also to assist Delisle in preparing the Russian geographical dictionary. At the Academy sessions on 21 February and 4 March 1736 Le Roy delivered a discourse titled De epitaphio Adami in insula Ceylo inviniendo, in which he criticized the legend that Adam's tomb was located on the island of Ceylon; this discourse displeased his colleagues. Le Roy read other works of his composition at the Academy of Petersburg, including:
  • Analecta de frigore maximo quo hyemes quaedam notabiles fuere;
  • Iridis insolitae Petropoli observatae brevis descriptio.
In 1743, he began composing a history of Russia based on the resources of the Academic Library. Teaching history at the Public College associated with the Academy of Sciences, he was also tasked, starting 5 May 1735, with teaching French. In June 1739, he was appointed professor of French, replacing Professor Ruynat, and remained in this position until his departure from the Academy on 10 August 1748. However, students criticized his teaching. In 1742, he gave lectures on universal history on Wednesdays and Saturdays. He was appointed inspector of the College of the Academy in 1744, but in 1748 he was relieved of this position (retaining only the senior French class) to become the archivist of the Academy Conference and assistant to its secretary. In 1747, he signed a letter denouncing the abuses of Schumacher, one of the founders of the Academy and the director of its chancery: the matter was brought before the Senate. He was dismissed from the Academy on 10 August 1748 (with a pension of 400 rubles) upon the return of Professor Müller from Kamchatka, whose position Le Roy had occupied. The opinions of some specialists regarding Le Roy's competencies are negative (cf. Vucinich, pp. 88-89). He served as tutor, starting in 1750, to the sons of field marshal Piotr Ivanovich Shuvalov. He accompanied them on their travels abroad, particularly to France and Switzerland. He instilled in one of the Shuvalov brothers, Andrei, a taste for literature and the arts. Andrei Petrovich Shuvalov later played a significant role in the development of belles-lettres and historical studies in Russia: he corresponded with Marmontel, Levesque, and Voltaire, who received him at his home in Ferney. He intended to go to France in 1757; he was still living in the house of Count Piotr Shuvalov. He was the godfather of Anne-Rose Couvet on 14 September 1759 at the Catholic church in Saint Petersburg. He spent the last years of his life abroad, receiving a pension from the Shuvalov family.
Teaching institutions and families: Biron family; Academy of Sciences (1735–1748; Saint Petersburg); Public College associated with the Academy of Sciences; Shuvalov family
Students and their social status: The eldest son of Duke Biron; sons of field marshal Piotr Ivanovich Shuvalov.
Language and other teaching books by the:
A friend of Derzhavin, Fonvizin, and Mikhail Vasilyevich Lomonosov, he himself published some poems in French verse and a historical work. Pierre-Louis Le Roy dedicated a collection of verses to his talented pupil, Poésies diverses du Sr. P.L.L.R., Amsterdam, chez Jean-Joubert, 1757, 187 p., in-8°. A study of his poetic works exists: "О стихотворениях академика ле-Руа," Российская библиография, 1881, n° 93(17). Le Roy is the author of a narrative recounting the adventures of captain Inkov and three sailors who spent several years in Spitsbergen:
  • Relation des avantures arrivées a quatre matelots jettés par une tempête prés de l’isle deserte d’Ost-Spitzbergen, sur laquelle ils ont passe six ans et trois mois. On y parle par occasion, de diverses coûtumes établies en Russie, et de choses qui ont rapport à la religion du pays. Par Mr. P. L. Le Roy, professeur d’histoire, et membre de l’Académie Impériale des Sciences de St.-Pétersbourg. Petersburg, 1766, 70 p., in-16°. This narrative was translated into several European languages and published in Riga and Mitau in German in 1768 (Svodny katalog knig na inostrannykh iazykakh, vol. 2, n°1715; translated and edited several times in Russian: see Le Roy).
Le Roy translated into French several writings, including:
  • Description et représentation exacte de la Maison de Glace construite a Saint-Petersbourg au mois de janvier 1740... avec quelques remarques sur le froid en général et particulièrement sur celui qu'on a senti cette même année dans toute l'Europe: composée... par George Wolffgang Krafft, ..., Saint Petersburg, Imprimerie de l’Académie des sciences, 1741, 32 p., pl. engraved, in-4°;
  • The first volumes of Sammlung Russischer Geschichte, as well as diplomatic dispatches, accounts of Münnich's victories, descriptions (Description et usage d’un cadran solaire universel compose par Isaac Bruckner..., Saint Petersburg, [4], 15 p.), etc.

Career: Teacher at the Noble Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg, and then for ten years as the governor of the children of major general Piotr Alekseyevich von der Pahlen, he settled in Moscow around 1795, where he sought to serve as a governor to the families of the high nobility. He was capable of teaching French, morals, ancient and modern history, and geography. However, he was not willing to leave Moscow, even temporarily (as governors typically followed their masters to their estates during the summer) because he needed to complete "an important work." Three individuals could recommend him: commander-in-chief Heyking, Count Buturlin, and the chief director of the Imperial Education House, G. Goguel. In 1795, he lived in a house owned by Madame Deleau in the 9th district of Moscow, in quarter 3, at number 530. He was present at the Witzmann/Gautier wedding on 8 April 1777.
Teaching institutions and families: Noble Cadet Corps (Saint Petersburg); Von der Pahlen family.
Students and their social status: Children of major general Piotr Alekseyevich von der Pahlen, the governor of the province of Riga.
Sources and bibliography:
MAE Nantes, pap. Lesseps, reg. chanc., consulat, Saint-Pétersbourg 1775-1778, f° 241.
MV, 1795, 3-14.

Personal records:
From a family originally from Berry. Coat of Arms: Azure with a gold sun and a silver crescent placed palewise. Father: Jean-Pierre Lecointe de Laveau (†1834, La Villette, Paris). Mother: probably Sophie de Mertz. Brothers:
  • Julien-Pierre Lecointe de Laveau (*1775, La Villette, Paris), a language teacher in Moscow in 1834;
  • Charles-Henry Lecointe de Laveau (*1773-01-19, La Villette), a merchant in Moscow, present in 1834, who had interests in the business of merchant Charles Henry Larmée;
  • Auguste-Jean Lecointe de Laveau (*1778-04-27, La Villette), was in 1834 in Belgorod, Kharkov Governorate, Ukraine.
Married to: Louise-Augustine Cabot d’Épreville, daughter of Pierre-Augustin Cabot d’Épreville and N. Goujon. Daughter: likely Marie-Alexandrine Lecointe de Laveau, godmother of Eugène Allart in 1808.
Career: Lecointe de Laveau was probably a French teacher at the boarding school of Auguste-Louis Wille, the rector of Moscow University, in the early 1790s. He replaced another Frenchman, Ledoux. He then became a teacher at the Ronca boarding school and was also associated with the bookseller Maurice-Gérard Allart (1779-1847). He was the editor of the Bulletin du Nord in Moscow in 1828-1829. Lecointe de Laveau was one of the most attentive observers of the fate of the French colony in Moscow. For example, he recounts the beginnings of the French theater in Moscow. According to him, the actors were pitiable; they rarely performed the same play more than three or four times, probably because, despite the well-known enthusiasm for French theater, their audience was not as varied as one might usually think. As early as 1805, this overlap from one play to another is truly remarkable: after Le Bénéfice followed by Les Folies de la Vieillesse on 28 January, the theater announced La petite ville ou les Ridicules de provinces, which was followed by Le Calife de Bagdad for 30 January; the day after this performance, they were already preparing to play Les Deux frères désunis by Kotzebue. He was the author of Moscou avant et après l’incendie, published in Paris in 1814, where he notably narrated the misadventures of the French in Moscow in 1812. He himself was arrested, along with other foreigners, on the orders of Count Fiodor Rostopchin, the governor-general of Moscow, on the night of 31 August 1812. They were placed in the house of a Bezborodko. A letter addressed to them by Fiodor Rostopchin stated, among other things: “French, Russia has given you asylum, and you have not ceased to make wishes against her. It is to avoid a massacre and not to tarnish the pages of our history by imitating your infernal revolutionary fury that the government is obliged to remove you. You are leaving Europe; you are going to Asia; you will live among a hospitable people, faithful to their oaths, and who despise you too much to do you harm. Try to become good subjects there, for you will not succeed in infecting it with your bad principles. - Enter the boat..., return to yourselves, and try not to make it a boat for Charon.” (translated from Russian). These foreigners were taken to a boat that transported them to Nizhny Novgorod. They remained there until 1814. Only ten of them decided to leave Russia; the others settled again in Moscow, including Lecointe de Laveau. His brothers were then in Moscow. He believed that by ordering the exile of these foreigners, Count Fiodor Rostopchin had followed the example of the English. Lecointe de Laveau also recounted in his book the history of the creation of a municipality in Moscow in 1812, where the occupying troops attracted many “Russian” French. Many of these French believed they were compromised and left Moscow with Napoleon's troops. Many perished along the way. In 1824, Lecointe de Laveau published a Guide du voyageur à Moscou, where he wrote these lines: “I like to think that far from seeing it as a reckless production on the part of a foreigner, one will only seek a monument of his gratitude for a hospitable city where he found a second homeland.” A Freemason, he was a member of the 3rd degree and an honorary member of the lodge Les Amis Réunis in Saint Petersburg, in 1817.
Teaching institutions and families: Boarding school of Auguste-Louis Wille (early 1790s); boarding school of Ronca
Language and other teaching books by the:
Works:
  • Moscou avant et après l’incendie, Paris, 1814.
  • Guide du voyageur à Moscou, Moscow, 1824.
He was also the editor of the Bulletin du Nord in Moscow in 1828–1829.
Sources and bibliography:
RGIA, fonds 730, inv. 1, dos. 41, f° 413-414 v°; MAE Nantes, Série administration centrale, actes de chancellerie, carton 170, Moscou, 1834-1839, actes notariés, année 1834 (p. 3-3 v°, 1834).
Lecointe de Laveau, 1814; 1824.
Shchukin, vol. 2, p. 27-29; Domergue, vol. 1, pp. 256-257; Martynova-Poniatovskaya, vol. 1; Serkov, p. 1094.
