Fullname: Lefébure de Richier de Cerisi, chevalier
Personal records: Religion: Protestant.
Career: As a tutor in Saint Petersburg until 1756, Lefébure de Richier de Cerisi addressed a "Mémoire, ou observation sur l’état actuel du Nord et sur les rapports de ses puissances avec la France, par le chevalier de Cerisi, mousquetaire de la première compagnie, 1766" to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1766. In it, he discussed issues of trade, government, the Senate and its growing importance in Russia, the third estate that was beginning to form in Russia, the nobility which, according to him, aspired to freedom, and the educational significance of the travels of noble representatives abroad.
Sources and bibliography:
MAE, MD Russie, vol. 11, f° 45-58.
Kämmerer, p. 107.

Personal records: Probably the same as Jean-Baptiste Lœillot.
Career:
He certainly served as governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg from 25 July 1776 to 3 September 1778; his duties involved teaching and supervising the students of the second "age." He was a professor of French at the Smolny Institute around 1783. His salary increased from 600 to 700 rubles per year during his contract at the Institute.
By the late 1780s to early 1790s, Jean Leliot was teaching at an educational boarding house run by a certain Wedemeyer (?) in Saint Petersburg. He was probably the same individual who served as governor at the Page Corps when he had to take the oath in Saint Petersburg in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1776–1778); Smolny Institute (ar. 1783); an educational boarding house run by a certain Wedemeyer (?) (late 1780s – early 1790s), all in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching methods and materials: Leliot's students used an alphabet book of his composition for learning French; no book signed by him has been identified, but it is likely one of those French alphabet books that were printed in Russia during the 18th century, for example: [ABCdaire français, Saint Petersburg, 1773, 32 p. in-8°]. The next step involved reading the famous book by Comenius, Orbis visibilis or Die sichtbare Welt; this book was published in Russia, with a French translation, in 1768: Iоанна Амоса Комения Видимый Светъ на латинском, российском, немецком, италианском и французском языках... Москва, при Имп. Московском Ун-те, 1768. [24], 477 p., followed by a trilingual edition (Latin, Russian, and German): Зрелище вселенныя, на Латинском, Российском и Немецком языках, изданное для народных училищ Российской Империи по высочайшему повелению Царствующия Императрицы Екатерины Вторыя, Санкт-Петербург, 1788, [8], 142 p., 81 f° ill. (numerous reprints). A little later, it appeared with a translation in French, Russian, and German; here is the second edition: Зрелище вселенныя, на французском, российском и немецком языках, вторым тиснением, Санкт-Петербург, 1793, [8], 142 p., 80 f° ill. Other French books were used by Leliot: L’Ami des enfants by Arnaud Berquin (the first edition is probably from 1783, Paris: Pissot et T. Barrois (at the Office of "L'Ami des enfans"), January 1782 – December 1783, 24 issues in 12 vol. in-18°), and for translation practice, Le Magasin des enfants, ou dialogues d’une sage gouvernante avec ses élèves de première distinction... by Marie Le Prince de Beaumont (first edition in London, 1756, numerous reprints including one in Moscow in 1795), which he used with students of the "first age"; or even a Livre de lecture à l’usage des classes inférieures de la Communauté Impériale des demoiselles nobles (not yet identified). For translating Russian into French, an Essai sur guide grammatical en traduction by Schlesner (?) was used, as well as Le Moraliste François and L’Histoire universelle abrégée (this probably refers to the following book: Voltaire, Abrégé de l’Histoire universelle, depuis Charlemagne à Charlequint, The Hague, Jean Neaulme, 1753, 2 vol., numerous reprints).
Language and other teaching books by the: An alphabet book of Leliot's composition has not been identified, but it is likely one of those French alphabet books that were printed in Russia during the 18th century, for example: [ABCdaire français, Saint Petersburg, 1773, 32 p. in-8°].
Sources and bibliography: RGIA, fonds 730, inv. 1, dos. 41, f° 572-579; see also about him: RGIA, fonds 759, inv. 18, dos. 196 (f° 54), 692 (f° 2). Svodny katalog knig na inostrannykh iazykakh, vol. 1, p. 17, no. 9. Gaponova; Likhacheva, 1890, t. I, p. 147.
Authors: Vladislav Rjéoutski, information from Sergei Vlasov

Personal records: Originally from Liège.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, rhetoric, poetry, writing, mythology, geography, history, philosophy, logic, metaphysics, ethics, physics.
Career: Tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg in 1779 and requested to take the examination required for tutors. He addressed this letter to the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg [spelling from the original]: “I flatter myself that you will allow me to teach the French and Latin languages, to provide the elements of French and Latin rhetoric and poetry, and the manner of writing in all genres, to teach mythology, geography, and history. You may also, if you deem it appropriate, propose to me some arguments on philosophy, e.g., Logic, Metaphysics, Ethics, and both General and Special Physics.” The examiners found that he had solid knowledge in all these disciplines and mastered the French language very well, which was his mother tongue.
Sources and bibliography: SPFA RAN, fonds 3, inv. 9, dos. 373 (1779), f° 1-6.

Personal records:
(*1708-04-08, Paris). Married to: Marie-Étiennette Chateauneuf, daughter of Jean-Baptiste Chateauneuf, in the service of the Russian court, and Catherine Henriette Couchet residing in Paris (marriage contract on 3/14 February 1748, and on 4/15 February at the Catholic church of Saint Petersburg; witnesses of the groom: Michel Du Chaulmont and Jean-Nicolas De Rosimond (his real name Prévost), actors in the service of the Russian court; witnesses of the bride: Jean-Baptiste Chateauneuf, Charles De Sérigny, and Dominique Préfleury, also actors in the service of the Russian court). The groom brought 100 rubles to the marriage. Children:
  • Pierre-Basile de Lespine de Morembert (*1750-02-09, Saint Petersburg; godfather: Prince Vasili Golitsyn (1731–1789, chamberlain, son of Prince Boris Vasilievich Golitsyn); godmother: Alexandra Korsakova), it is likely that this son is the one Morembert refers to in a letter addressed to his friend, the playwright Charles-Simon Favart, thanking him for showing friendship to his son (though it could also be a son from a previous marriage);
  • François-Jean-Nicolas de Lespine de Morembert (*1751-08-16, Saint Petersburg; godfather: François-David de La Baume, later a lecturer at Moscow University; godmother: Françoise-Henriette Chateauneuf, an actress);
and probably:
  • Catherine Morembert, wife of Charles-Roger de Fréville, a former soldier in the service of France.
Religion: Roman Catholic.
Career: Actor, governor, and spy. An actor at the Comédie-Française, he arrived in Russia in November 1742. He played numerous roles in performances staged by the French comic troupe or De Sérigny’s troupe, particularly in Molière's plays. He is referred to as the "governor of the Empress's pages" in a letter from 1745 addressed by Favart to Morembert. If this is not an error by the editor, it can be inferred that Morembert served as a teacher in the pages' school established in 1742, which preceded the founding of the Page Corps in 1759. However, it is more likely that Morembert was appointed governor of the pages in 1759, probably under Peter III (see his verses below). His appointment is likely explained by his connections with Baron Tschudy, an actor and later secretary to Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov, chamberlain (hofmeister) of the Page Corps. Morembert taught the pages French, history, geography, and heraldry. He likely had as students Alexander Radishchev, a future writer and author of A Journey from Saint Petersburg to Moscow, Alexei Kutuzov, a future writer and Freemason close to Novikov, and Pyotr Chelyshchev, a future translator and writer. A mocking spirit, Morembert echoed this commitment in a couplet sent to Favart: That from a subject of whom everyone cares For some important position, They turn a blind eye to birth, That does not surprise me; But that a flat-footed man, spurred by pride, A cobblestone batterer and a player, Be appointed by an emperor As the governor of his pages, That is what astonishes me. He was not satisfied with his position. In his letters to Favart, he mentions the opportunity to leave in 1760 with Prince Piotr Ivanovich Repnin, the new Russian ambassador to Spain: “I had agreed with him to accompany him as secretary to Spain itself; but due to business interests, which I could not arrange here, where I would have left double what I owe, I was held back; and, upon reflection, I acted foolishly.” His ambitions were unfulfilled, and he held Ivan Shuvalov responsible; at the time of Shuvalov's departure from Russia in 1762, he wrote to Favart: “I do not have much to praise about the good he has done for me. As I remain attached to those for whom I have developed some friendship, whether they serve me or not, I will remain silent about him in this regard.” Morembert considered Shuvalov a perfect representative of those great Russian lords “who believe they know everything better than anyone else, while they are still at the elementary level. Our very illustrious excellence will find disillusionment in traveling, provided he reflects and does not retain the presumptuous rust of the nation.” His dissatisfaction and lack of resources led him to become a secret informant for Versailles regarding all matters concerning Russia. He summarized his entry into this role: “Before the merging of the two courts, that is, the arrival of Mr. the Marquis de l'Hôpital, I was in regular correspondence for more than eighteen months with Mr. the Count de Sade, an old acquaintance, regarding our affairs.” This likely refers to the father of the famous writer, Jean-Baptiste-Joseph-François, Count de Sade, a diplomat and military man. The Count de Sade communicated Morembert's letters and reports to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. “I obtained,” wrote Morembert, “or, to put it better, I was granted, without hardly asking for it, an annual stipend of one hundred pistoles, at the representations of the said Count de Sade and recommendations from the late Mr. Marshal de Belle-Isle, with whom I had been acquainted for a long time. I enjoyed this stipend for eighteen months, which Mr. de l'Hôpital paid me. Mr. de Bernis, the then minister, having been dismissed and pensions suspended, my stipend was abolished. After Mr. de Breteuil left, I began again to devote as much time as I could to Mr. Beranger, who remained in charge of affairs; he even wrote a word to Mr. Count de Choiseul, though without naming me.” Morembert wanted his pension to be maintained and was ready to continue his role as an informant. He was going through a difficult financial period and was in dire need of money: “This grace would be a relief to my situation, which is quite harsh, and a benefit for my wife and children who, with just 500 livres added, would be much better off, and would enable me to serve our court again during the diplomatic void and future rapprochement, as I had done before. It was during the enjoyment of this stipend that I decided to send my wife and children to France, so that by receiving it there, if it were to be continued, I would only have to think of myself here.” Indeed, in the archives of the Diplomatic Archives in Paris, there is an "Extrait du journal du Sr Moremberg" (MAE, MD Russie, vol. 1, f. 192-193v) in which the author recounts events at the court of Russia, from the "revolution" of 1741, which elevated Empress Elizabeth to the throne, until 1756. Morembert provides a detailed account of Elizabeth's coup d'état, although he was not a witness to it. The information he offers about La Chétardie’s (Trotti, Marquis de La Chétardie) relations with the small court adds an interesting element to the story of the downfall of the French diplomat: "On Saturday, 1 June, at 5 o'clock in the evening, H.M. the Empress being absent for a few days, H.I.H. [Grand Duke Peter - V.R.] on horseback and the Zerbst princesses, mother and daughter [the Grand Duchess Catherine Alexeyevna, future Catherine II, and her mother - V.R.] in a carriage came by to see Mr. de La Chétardie, who received H.I.H. on his porch. The Grand Duke did not dismount, but he spoke to Mr. [text crossed out, referring to La Chétardie - V.R.] and said a few words quite softly. From there, Mr. went to meet the princesses and conversed with them for a while. Upon returning, he appeared pensive throughout the evening." A few days later, La Chétardie received orders to leave the Empire within eight days. Sir Mackensie Douglas, staying in Saint Petersburg in 1757, recommended to the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs to grant Morembert some liberality due to his ability "to provide great insights and reliable knowledge about Russian affairs." In his correspondence with Favart, Morembert mentions his French acquaintances in Saint Petersburg: Clairval, Pochet, and Tremblin. Morembert signed the certificate of life for Pierre-Nazaire Navarre at the end of 1745. He was the godfather of Jean-Antoine Bernard on 24 September 1748, and of Marie-Anne Hyacinthe La Comté on 3 July 1750, at the Catholic church in Saint Petersburg. He was noted in 1759 as a debtor to a prominent French confectioner in Saint Petersburg and as a witness in the consulate's chancery during the marriage contract of Vendredy/Duval on 24 December 1760/4 January 1761, and at the religious wedding on 9 January 1761 at the Catholic church. His wife was the godmother of Anne-Marie Creping on 7 July 1752 at the Catholic church in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Pages' school (?)
Students and their social status: He likely had as students Alexander Radishchev, Alexei Kutuzov, Pyotr Chelyshchev.
Language and other teaching books by the: Stimulated by the example of Favart, whose success in both Paris and Brussels was on the rise, Morembert ventured into literature. He signed an ode in glory of Empress Elizabeth, a tragedy titled Licurgue, and likely other works that have not yet been identified. He also translated Sumarokov's play Sinav and Truvor, which would be the first translation of this play into French verse (information from Alexei Evstratov).

Personal records:
(1736-03-28, Paris – 1812-05-12, Paris) Married to: Marie-Françoise-Élisabeth Haulteterre, harpist, originally from Dreux, who was witty, educated, and capable of appreciating her husband's talents. Daughter:
  • Marie-Louise-Rose Levesque (*1768, Paris), a student at the Institute for Noble Girls in Saint Petersburg (Smolny Institute), where her mother was employed.
Education: Collège des Quatre-Nations, then college Louis-le-Grand, all in Paris.
Career: Historian and moralist, engraver, governor, and professor at the Land Noble Cade Corps and professor at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. He was a member of the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres, a professor at the Collège de France, and a member of the Institute. Having learned the trade of engraver, Levesque secured the means to pursue his classical studies in Paris, first at the Collège des Quatre-Nations and then at Louis-le-Grand. Upon graduating, he began to write and translate. His works included Les Rêves d’Aristobule, philosophe grec, suivis d’un Abrégé de la Vie de Formose philosophe français (Paris, 1761; 1788 in vol. XXXI of Voyages imaginaires), and a Choix de poésies de Pétrarque traduites de l’italien (Paris, 1774; 1786), which emerged from his pen. Thanks to the protection of Denis Diderot, who signed a contract for him on 7 May 1773, Levesque was appointed governor of the Land Noble Cadets Corps in Saint Petersburg (the text of the contract was published: Jurgens; Mazon, pp. 18-23). By this contract, Mr. "Pierre Charles L’Evesque, Bourgeois of Paris residing at Place de l’Estrapade, parish of Saint Benoist," committed to "fully fulfill the aims of the establishment of this School of Cadets" and, for this purpose, was to travel to Rouen to embark on 20 May 1773, bound for Saint Petersburg. Levesque received one thousand livres from France for travel expenses. He committed for six years to teach at the Corps while enjoying certain privileges, namely: to have "meals with the gentlemen students, an apartment next to theirs," to be served by the Corps' servant, to have "Sundays and solemn holidays, when there was no school, the use of a carriage," to receive 500 rubles in salary for his services, with a bonus of 600 rubles at the end of the contract, and to enjoy throughout the duration of the contract the privileges attached to the ninth class (the rank of titular counselor according to the rank table). Following were the "conditions of the governor," which presented a genuine educational program. Instruction was to be based on interest and pleasure rather than boredom and constraint. The governor was required to have "honesty and regularity of morals." It was forbidden for governors to engage in "other matters that could distract them from these same duties of men made to educate the elite youth of the empire"; these governors were not to be "confused with mercenary or base-minded individuals." It was assumed that the governor possessed all the necessary knowledge, and he was asked to provide a brief outline of what he could teach the students. It was advised to choose "gentle" and "cheerful" subjects, suitable for inspiring "easy and noble manners, equality of mood, cheerfulness, and amiability." Other contracts of this type were signed shortly thereafter, benefiting Antoine Nicolas Imbert, Nicolas Leopold Liebault, and Guillaume Louis Junker. Diderot recommended Levesque to Falconet and Mlle Collot in his letter dated 30 May 1773: "He is an honest and gallant man who combines knowledge and talent with a rare gentleness and modesty"; "he has separated from a worthy woman who is his. He loves his wife, my friend; and this in a country where, as you know, it is not too common. A life usefully occupied has saved him from the epidemic libertinism that has affected all classes of our society. You will speak to him of literature, and he will respond; you will show him your monument, and his admiration may flatter you, because he draws and engraves, not like the late Mr. Count de Caylus, for he is not a great lord and therefore must know what he knows; but like a professional artist. My friend, I recommend Mr. Lévesque to you." Levesque arrived in Saint Petersburg shortly before his patron Diderot. Diderot had recommended him to Falconet and praised his knowledge, gentleness, and modesty. This meeting with the sculptor marked the beginning of a great friendship, as Levesque wrote in his introduction to the Œuvres complètes of Falconet, titled Vie d’Etienne Falconet par M. Levesque (Paris, 1808). Aside from Falconet, Levesque was undoubtedly in contact with Diderot himself during Diderot's stay in Saint Petersburg from October 1773 to March 1774. By a decision of the Council of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg on 26 April 1774, Levesque replaced the history professor Baudouin within the Academy, with a salary of 250 rubles per year. Levesque had been recommended by the Academy's deputy inspector Burdin de Saint-Martin. However, he was unable to teach due to several external events, and thus Levesque was denied this position. Levesque is sometimes confused with his main competitor, Le Clerc, who was also a professor at the Academy of Fine Arts. Following Dmitri Kobeko, several historians mistakenly counted Levesque among the instructors of Grand Duke Paul. Levesque's wife, for her part, was a harp teacher at the Smolny Institute. Levesque moved in an intellectual milieu in Saint Petersburg formed by academicians and a few noble history enthusiasts. He was notably part of the circle of Johann Albrecht Euler, the secretary of the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg, who gathered a genuine "French Academy" at his home, including Jean-Baptiste Maudru du Bocage. Levesque also frequented Count Andrey Shuvalov, a statesman, patron, man of letters, and amateur historian, as well as Prince Mikhail Shcherbatov, a renowned historian who had a significant influence on Levesque and likely provided him with certain documents on Russian history. Levesque's main activity in Russia was the writing of a national history. He compiled ancient chronicles, studied Russian and Old Church Slavonic, and gathered an impressive list of sources. Masson and Laharpe were not wrong to praise the qualities of his Histoire de Russie, tirée des chroniques originales, published in Paris in 1782 in five volumes, which was supplemented in 1783 by l’Histoire des différens peuples soumis à la domination des Russes, ou Suite à l’Histoire de Russie, published in Paris in 1783 in two volumes. Fortia de Piles believed that Levesque had spent too much time in Russia and that he was not objective because he was indebted to that country. Nevertheless, Masson wrote that Catherine II hated this work as much as that of Chappe d’Auteroche because it had dared to label her as the murderer of Peter III and Tsarevich Ivan. Levesque himself admitted that he preferred to return to France in 1780 to publish his work away from any pressure from the Empress: he did not even send her a copy. In his eulogy for Levesque, Malte-Brun summarized the merits of this Histoire and the reception it received: “The French forgave their compatriot his erudition, his critical discussions, and his scrupulous accuracy [...] In Germany, the scientific merit of the History of Russia could be appreciated even more because the research on which it was based was common to several German scholars, either established in Russia or returning from there. It was glorious for the French historian to receive no serious criticism from these severe judges, but rather to receive motivated and sincere praise. Indeed, although tireless erudition has opened up some new sources since the first appearance of this work, it was in 1782 perfectly in line with the knowledge then acquired [...] But it is not enough for a modern historian to please the learned Europe; he must also satisfy the wishes of the nation whose Annals he recounts, under penalty of being subjected to attacks driven by self-love and national pride. The moderation of Mr. Levesque earned him this difficult and rare success” (cited from Mazon, pp. 38-39). Levesque took pride in repeatedly correcting the information about Russia provided by Voltaire. As for Le Clerc’s Histoire de la Russie ancienne et moderne, Levesque humorously noted its weaknesses and errors and protested against its numerous plagiarisms. Upon his return to France, Levesque joined the Academy of Inscriptions in 1789 and became a professor at the Collège de France, where he held the chair of history and morals from 1791 until his death. He entered the Institute in 1795. He was able to highlight his teaching experience gained in Russia. It was certainly thanks to Levesque that Maudru du Bocage, his former colleague from the Noble Cadet Corps, was able to give a lecture at the Institute.
Teaching institutions and families:
Land Noble Cade Corps; Academy of Fine Arts, all in Saint Petersburg.
He was a member of the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres, a professor at the Collège de France, and a member of the Institute.
Language and other teaching books by the:
Pierre-Charles Levesque is the author of:
  • Les Rêves d’Aristobule, philosophe grec, suivis d’un Abrégé de la Vie de Formose philosophe français (Paris, 1761; 1788 in vol. XXXI of Voyages imaginaires);
  • Choix de poésies de Pétrarque traduites de l’italien (Paris, 1774; 1786) (see the analysis of this work in: Mazon, pp. 8-18);
  • Vie d’Etienne Falconet par M. Levesque (Paris, 1808);
  • Histoire de Russie, tirée des chroniques originales, published in Paris in 1782 in five volumes;
  • Histoire des différens peuples soumis à la domination des Russes, ou Suite à l’Histoire de Russie, published in Paris in 1783 in two volumes;
Levesque's Histoire de la Russie, published in Paris in 1782, was reprinted three times until 1812. It was distributed in Russia in 1782 by subscription and through the efforts of Madame Rozet, a Moscow bookseller acquainted with Euler; Levesque issued a prospectus for this purpose (Somov, 1997). The list of subscribers allows us to know the circle of his readers in Russia, among whom were the heir to the Russian throne and his wife (see regarding this: Somov, 1982, 1986, and 1988). The first edition of Levesque's Histoire included an Essai sur les rapports de la Langue des Slaves avec celle des anciens habitans du Latium, later developed into a dissertation read at the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres. The Russian translation of the Histoire de la Russie began in 1787, but only the first volume was published: История Российская из достовернейших Российских историковь соч. г. Левеком, ч. I, Москва, 1787. N. Karamzin, the future author of The History of the State of Russia, may have met Levesque in Paris in 1790 and held a high opinion of his work: his Histoire de la Russie, “although it has many flaws, is nevertheless better than all the others” (see for more details: Mazon, pp. 43-47). Levesque composed other works in Russia: - L’Homme moral, ou l’Homme considéré tant dans l’État de pure Nature que dans la société, Amsterdam, 1775 (three editions in the same year, without publisher mention, two of which were “furtive,” according to Levesque; the corrected and expanded edition titled L’Homme moral ou les Principes des Devoirs, suivis d’un Apperçu sur la Civilisation, Paris, 1784, published by de Bure the Elder);
  • L’Homme pensant ou Essai sur l’histoire de l’Esprit humain, Amsterdam, published by Marc-Michel Rey, 1779.
The manuscript of L’Homme moral was likely brought to The Hague by Diderot in 1774, who sold it to Marc-Michel Rey; in August 1776, Diderot expressed concern that the money he received from Rey had still not been given to Levesque, and he asked Grimm to give 200 livres to him. A. Mazon characterizes these two works as follows: “L’Homme moral (1775) and L’Homme pensant (1779) are indeed sister works, equally personal and rich in reflection. Both evoke ‘the savage man’ and oppose him to ‘the man in society,’ judging each in turn, favoring the primitive man, discussing the social contract, the formation of states, various types of government, the duties of the citizen and the head of the family. But L’Homme moral remains a sort of rough breviary for the use of inner life and social life. L’Homme pensant, on the other hand, adds to this breviary a vast inquiry into the history of various peoples, their religions, the doctrines of philosophers, the origins of the universe and life” (Mazon, p. 26). Levesque published an ode in Russia:
  • Ode sur la paix conclue entre la Russie et la Porte, par P.Ch. Levesque, [St. Petersburg, printing house of the Noble Cadet Corps], 1774, [8] p. in-4°.
Alongside his historical works, only L’Homme pensant was published in Russian in 1803:
  • Человек размышляющий, сочинение г. Левека, translated undoubtedly by major general and knight of orders A. P. Ermolaev.
Levesque was also the co-author, along with Watelet, of a Dictionnaire des arts, Histoire de France sous les cinq premiers Valois. Some letters from Levesque are preserved in the Archives in Russia: RGB, Mss, fonds 255, the Rumiantsev, folder 8, dos. 23, Lettre de l’historien Pierre Charles Lévesque au comte Nikolay Petrovich Rumiantsev (Frankfurt, 7 January 1791), in French, 2 fol., unsigned, accompanied by an excerpt, clerk's copy, in French, 2 fol. (indication in Les Archives de l'Est et la France des Lumières).

Personal records: (or Liashchevsky/Łjaszczewski, or Laschevsky/Lashchevsky/Łaszczewski; Barlaam, Warłaam; secular name: Vasily) (ab. 1704, Kobylnica town, Ruthenian (Russian) Voivodeship, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – 1774-07-28, Moscow). Varlaam Liaschevsky was born into the family of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Varlaam Liaschevsky was a student at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. His studies included the ancient languages, and his teacher was Simon Todorsky. While studying in the philosophy class, as one of the best students he was sent to take courses at the University of Halle. On his return, he continued his studies in the theology class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; Polish; Ancient Greek; Ancient Hebrew.
Career:
In 1739, after studying in Halle, Varlaam Liaschevsky began teaching Latin and Polish at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, in the phara (analogy) class. In the 1740–1741 school year, he taught in the poetics class. In 1740, he took monastic vows. In the 1741–1742 school year, he was a rhetoric class teacher, but after Simon Todorsky left for Moscow, i.e. from May 1742 on, he taught Ancient Hebrew and Ancient Greek. In the 1746–1747 school year, he was a theology professor and Prefect of the Academy. In May 1747, according to the decision of the Synod, he was summoned to Saint Petersburg for the revision and correction of the Slavonic translation of the Bible. At the same time, Varlaam Liaschevsky was hegumen at the Mezhyhirya Savior-Transfiguration Monastery (Kyiv diocese). From June 23, 1753 onwards, he served as Rector at Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy and as archimandrite at the Zaikonospassky Monastery (the Monastery of the Holy Mandylion) in Moscow. In 1754–1758, he was a member of the Synod. Then he served as archimandrite at the Donskoy Virgin Assumption Monastery in Moscow until his death.
Varlaam Liaschevsky donated significant amounts of money to remunerate Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew teachers working at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy and also to purchase textbooks on these languages for the academic library. He bequeathed to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy his personal library which contained a large number of textbooks, grammar books and lexicons on various languages.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, taught by Varlaam Liaschevsky in the 1739–1740 school year, there were 77 students (in total, there were 536 students at the academy that year). At the time, Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew were studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy by students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes as an option.
Most of the students at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) class in which Varlaam Liaschevsky taught. The teacher also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. Varlaam Liaschevsky continued the systematic teaching of Ancient Greek and Hebrew at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, initiated by Simon Todorsky. The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was designed for three years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. Students were supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. A similar “plan” was used for teaching Ancient Hebrew. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. Varlaam Liaschevsky’s methods of teaching Ancient Greek are illustrated by the grammar book, which he worked on for publication. Varlaam Liaschevsky is known to have used his teacher Simon Todorsky’s notes for his grammar book. For teaching Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew, he used grammar books written by Johann-Heinrich Michaelis. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading abstracts from works by various authors as well as through translating passages from various texts. When teaching Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew, Varlaam Liaschevsky used a number of grammar books and lexicons that were also available in the library of the academy in Kyiv (for example, textbooks by Johann Scapula, Cornelius Schrevelius, Georg Pasor, and books by Heinrich Opitz and Johannes Buxtorf). A large number of textbooks were available in Varlaam Liaschevsky’s personal library, which he bequeathed to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (for example, books by Johannes Buxtorf and textbooks by Johann Scapula). Rather short descriptions in the catalogue do not make it possible to identify accurately all the lexicons, grammar books and dictionaries, mentioned in the catalogues. Personal records: (or Liatskoronsky) († 1754-05-08, Kyiv). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Silvestr Liaskoronsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin grammar; Polish grammar; Latin syntax; Polish syntax; poetics; rhetoric; theology.
Career: Immediately after graduation in the 1734–1736 school year, Silvestr Liaskoronsky became a teacher in the grammar class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In the 1736–1737 school year, he taught in the syntax class. In the 1737–1738 school year, he taught poetics at the academy; in 1738–1740, he taught rhetoric. He also took monastic vows. In 1740, he was a member of the Kyiv consistory, in 1741–1744, he was hegumen at the Holy Spirit Monastery in Vilna (now Vilnius); from 1745 onwards, he served as archimandrite at the Annunciation Nazareth-Virgin Monastery of Nizhin. From 23 January 1746 until 28 August 1751, he was a theology professor at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, and rector and archimandrite at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv. Afterwards, Silvestr Liaskoronsky retired to the Vydubychi Monastery in Kyiv, where he died.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1734–1740; 1746–1751).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied in the grammar and syntax classes in which Silvestr Liaskoronsky taught. For example, in September 1737, there were 71 students in the syntax class taught by Silvestr Liaskoronsky.
Most of the students at Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Silvestr Liaskoronsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. As other grammar teachers’ students, Silvestr Liaskoronsky’s students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The exercises we still have reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in a syntax class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari, De Institutione Grammatica, Monachii [München]: apud Nicolaum Henricum, sumptibus Samuelis Maderi, 1625. Language and other teaching books by the: The handwritten rhetoric lectures that Silvestr Liaskoronsky gave at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy are still available. While teaching in the poetics class, he wrote his “Tragicomedy” (1737–1738).

Personal records: (*Silesia). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: According to him, he studied at the Noble Land Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg. He graduated from the Cadet Corps in 1762.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German Grammar; translation from Russian into German; Russian calligraphy; Russian reading.
Career: Christians Lichnowsky arrived in Russia in 1752, where, according to him, he studied at the Noble Land Cadet Corps. After graduation from the Cadet Corps, he served as an officer in the army. In 1768, he left Russia. He returned to the country the same year, having a Polish passport. He worked at Ehrhardt’s school from the time of its foundation in 1777. The school was located in Millionnaya Street in the first Admiralty part of the city, in Brigadier Fukov’s house.
Teaching institutions and families: Ehrhardt’s school (from 1777, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Children of raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks), children of artisans.
The Commission of the Academy of Sciences checked Ehrhardt’s day school and boarding school in April 1780 and stated that there were six children (five boys and one girl) at the boarding school, and about 30 children aged from 8 to 13 years old at the day school.
The boarders were: Clement Sytin, son of a captain; Dmitry Plavkov, son of a captain; Andrey Aputin, son of a merchant; Mikhail Stepanov, vykhovanets (fosterling); Pavel Kozlov, son of a valet; Anna Myshlyakovskaya, daughter of a coffee-waiter. The day-school students were: Gottlieb Thieme, son of a wainwright; Lukyan Vasilyev, son of a widow; Johann and Anna Volgach, children of a baker; Johann Lübeck, son of a hatter, Nikolay Wilhelm, Sofia Gaspar, children of a hairdresser; Ivan Akhlebinov, orphan; Anton Miller, son of a carpenter; Sofia and Regina Ginz, daughters of a tailor; Katherine Miller, daughter of a bookbinder; Alexander and Wilhelm Knot, children of a doorman; Maria Griberkhova, daughter of a silversmith; Peter Moltrech, son of a confectioner; Samuel and Anna Kelstren; Dmitry Rostovtsev, son of a coppersmith.
Teaching methods and materials:
He taught German grammar; his teaching methods included translating Aesop’s fables from Russian into German. He gave four lessons of Russian calligraphy and eight lessons of reading every week.

Personal records: (or Likud, Leichoudes, Licudis; Ioannikii, Ioannikios, Ioann, Johann) (1633, Lixouri, Cephalonia, the Venetian Republic – 1717, Moscow). Father: Mark (†1666), a ship captain. Mother: Susanna (according to Russian sources) or Trusianna (according to Greek sources). Younger brother: Spiridon (Sofrony or Sophronius in monastic life) (1652–1730). Sister: Padulya (she remained in Cephalonia and lived in Ioanniky’s house). His wife Paola was Ioann (John) Debonaire (Debonair)’s daughter (he married at the beginning of 1654, died in 1683/1684). His sons’ names were Nikolay and Anastas. He also had a daughter. In the 1690s, they arrived in the Russian capital and petitioned for a princely title. His daughter stayed in Venice. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He received his primary education from a priest in Cephalonia. Then he went to Venice, where he studied at a Greek school. His teacher was a famous scholar, the philologist Gerasim Vlach (Vlakh), presumably from 1655 to 1660. The sources mention that the Likhud brothers attended lectures of “the most learned and wisest hieromonk Arseny Kalludiev” at the Cottunian (Kottounian) Collegium for nine years, but, apparently, only Sofrony Likhud received a doctoral diploma of the University of Padua, because no records concerning Ioanniky are available in the documents of the university. Going to Venice was a common way of getting further education for the children of wealthy Greeks from the Western Greek islands, which were under the protectorate of Venice.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Greek language; grammar; poetics; rhetoric; Latin language; rhetoric; poetics; logic; philosophy; Italian.
Career: From May 1660 onwards, he signed as a hierodeacon in notarial documents of Cephalonia, and from December of the same year, he put his signature as a priest (iereus). His signatures in the archives of the island show his presence until 1663; from 1665 onwards, there was no evidence of his stay in Cephalonia. Most likely, he was absent for at least five years. After returning from Venice to Cephalonia, from 1671 onwards, he undertook teaching activities. An agreement was signed in May 1671 between the teacher Ioann Likhud and lord Stamatelos Katsaitis concerning the transfer of his brother Spyros to Ioann’s school to teach Latin grammar. Another document, dated January 1678, is a contract between Orandzios Kuruklis and the “Iereus Ioann Likud”, according to which Ioann was supposed to teach French and simple Greek to Kuruklis’ son Vasilis. According to the agreement, the training was planned over four years (publication of both the documents: Πεντόγαλος Γ.Η. Ιωαννης (Ιωαννίκιος και Σπυρίδων (Σωφρόνιος) αδελφοί Λυκούδη (Λειχούδαι), σ. 23-25). In addition, the documents of Cephalonia contain information about Ioanniky’s trips to Venice, presumably between 1675 and 1677. In 1683, he went to Constantinople with his brother, where they lived for five months (RGADA (Russian State Archives of Ancient Documents), f. 52, op. 1, book 8, fol. 78v) awaiting the decision of the Jerusalem Patriarch Dositheos, who sent them to Russia in response to a request from the Russian government to appoint Greek teachers. The decision was taken after Dositheos was convinced of their adherence to Orthodoxy. The Likhud brothers presented their statement of faith and preached for the gathered patriarch, metropolitan, archbishop, bishop and clergy. They left Constantinople on 3 July 1683, having received the blessing of the patriarchs and taken a “sheet certified by the hands of all the patriarchs”. The Greek copy of the document is available at MPT No. 194 (Athens, National Library of Greece). They were on the road from July 1683 to March 1685. The Likhud brothers’ writings “Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”) and “Акос” (“Akos”), as well as the interrogation speeches of the Ambassadorial Prikaz contain information concerning their route to Moscow. At first, their road lay to Moldavia and Wallachia, then to Hungary. There the Likhud brothers stayed longer due to military actions, in which the Prince of Wallachia Șerban Cantacuzino participated. In addition, “Akos” gives more detailed information on the stay in the Transylvanian cities and on the theological disputes that the brothers had there. According to the brothers, their activities were quite successful. The Likhud brothers had to endure debates with representatives of various faiths: “In Belgrade, Lower Hungary, with the theology professor of Prince Michael Apafi, with a Calvinist, and in Simbin – with Jacob Tsambani – a Lutheran, theology professor in the same city, and with professor Clavioupol, a Calvinist” (Горский А.В., Невоструев К.И. Описание Синодальной библиотеки, vol. II, 3, p. 382). Only in June 1684, were the Likhud brothers able to go to Rzeczpospolita, where on 5 August 1684 they were presented and favourably received by Jan (John) Sobieski “in a town called Zalukovia” (“Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”), RGADA, f. 381, No. 415, fol. 14). However, unexpectedly, he changed his mind and forced the Likhud brothers to stay for several months. For a long time, the historiography did not give a precise answer to the question as to why they were delayed. However, various assumptions were made. The circumstances became clear when D. Papastratu discovered a letter written by the Greek œconomus of Saint Catherine’s Monastery on the Sinai Peninsula, by the mane of Hadjikiryak, who was corresponding with the Sinai Archbishop Athanasius of Veroia, and to whom he wrote about the Likhud brothers’ stay in Poland 20 years later: according to the letter, the reason for the delay was suspicion of espionage for Turkey. Hadjikiryak contributed to the release of the Likhud brothers, personally interceding for them with the king. During their stay in Lwów (Lviv), they had a dispute with the Jesuit Teofil (Theophilus) Rutka. Various dogmatic questions were discussed in the debate. The questions are reflected in the content of the “Sword of the Spirit”, composed as 21 dialogues between the Likhud brothers and Rutka. Then their journey lay through Little Russia. They went from Lwów (Lviv) to Zhovkva, Brody, Dubno, then reached the borders of Kyiv and stopped at the Mezhyhirya Monastery. Afterwards they passed to the Borysthenes (Dnepr, Dnipro) River and from there to Nizhyn and further to Baturin (RGADA, f. 381, No. 415, fol. 16). In Baturin, they received a traveller’s certificate from the hetman Ivan Samoylovich (the original version: RGADA, f. 159, op. 2, pt. 2, d. 2991, fol. 15-15v). Then they went to Moscow via Sevsk, where they were provided with carts, and where the voivode Neplyuyev gave them a traveller’s certificate. The Likhud brothers spent 16 days on their journey from Baturin to Moscow. On 6 March 1685, the brothers arrived in Moscow and went to the Ambassadorial Prikaz immediately upon arrival. Soon after arriving in Russia, on 13 March 1685, an audience with the sovereigns took place (RGADA, f. 159, op. 2, No. 2991, fol. 19-23), where Ioanniky and Sofrony spoke separately, one in Greek, and the other in Latin (ibid., f. 52, op. 1, book 8, fol. 87v) and bowed low to petition for a “state salary”. On March 1685, Russian documents mentioned Ioanniky and Sofrony Likhud as philosophy and theology teachers (ibid., f. 159, op. 2, d. 2991, fol. 27) as well as teachers of the “high sciences” (ibid., f. 235, op. 2, d. 115, p. 262) for the first time. First the brothers settled in the Saint Nicholas Greek Monastery, then, on 21 March 1685, in the Chudov Monastery in the Kremlin. On 28 March of the same year, the construction of cells began for them in the Epiphany Monastery, where on 1 July 1685, the Likhud School was opened. It laid the foundation for the Slavic Greek Latin Academy. The date of the creation of the school is considered the moment of the founding of the Slavic Greek Latin Academy in Moscow. The status of the institution is reflected in the salary, which was assigned to teachers in September 1686, that is 100 rubles per year (ibid., f. 1182, op. 1, d. 86, fol. 42). In 1687, the Academy moved to a more spacious stone building in the Monastery of the Holy Mandylion (Zaikonospassky Monastery). The building was specially built for the purpose. However, soon Ioanniky was forced to leave Russia temporarily and to go to Venice, where his children lived. In Venice, he also negotiated with the Venetian doge about an alliance with Russia against the Ottoman Empire. In 1688–1691, during his absence in the Russian capital, Sofrony performed the main duties at the Academy. They continued teaching at the Academy until 1694, when the brothers were suspended from teaching. No documents have survived concerning their activity in 1694–1697, but we can suppose that they gave private Italian lessons. In 1697–1700, they taught at the Italian language school, apparently created especially for them. The educational institution was administered by the Order-in-Charge Prikaz. On 30 July 1700, the last document relating to the activities of the Italian school was issued; this should be considered the school’s closing date. M.N. Smentsovsky mentions that the Likhud Brothers were at the Novospassky Monastery from 1698 to 1704 (Сменцовский М., Братья Лихуды, p. 318), but this does not correlate with documents showing that in 1694 the Likhud Brothers received a homestead in Golutvino. Before, the homestead belonged to a podyachy (assistant clerk) from the Order-in-Charge Prikaz Gleb Afonasyev, who was convicted of plundering a huge amount of gold from the State treasury (RGADA, f. 210, prikaz, st. 2558, fol. 218). In January 1704, the Likhud Brothers were sent to the Ipatiev Monastery in Kostroma, where they stayed until January 1706. There they continued their polemical activities and also compiled an extensive Greek grammar book. On 31 January 1706, a decree regarding their transfer from the Ipatiev Monastery to the metropolitan Iov (Job) in Novgorod was issued. They moved there with the help of the metropolitan of Novgorod, who wanted to create a Greek Slavic school in Novgorod. From the very first days of their arrival, they devoted their activities to the founding of a new school in Novgorod. After the departure of Sofrony Likhud to Moscow in 1707, Ioanniky remained one of the main teachers at the Novgorod school, where he taught until 1716, when he followed his brother to Moscow. There is no exact information as to whether he helped Sofrony in teaching at the Greek school or not, but it is certain that he was involved in the correction of the text of the Bible, organised at the Moscow Print Yard. In 1717, he died and was buried in the Holy Mandylion (Zaikonospassky) Monastery.

The Likhud Brothers’ best-known students at the Slavic Greek Latin Academy were Fedor (Fyodor) Polikarpov, who later became the head of the Moscow Print Yard, and then of the printing house, and also Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov), who taught at the Slavic Greek Latin Academy in 1694–1698, together with Fedor (Fyodor) Polikarpov, and who was later a corrector at the Moscow Print Yard (he died in 1716). Many other of the Likhud Brothers’ students from the Slavic Greek Latin Academy worked at the Print Yard later, for example Fedot Ageev, Iosif Afanasyev, Karp Fedorov (Fyodorov) and others.
Moisey Arsenyev Ivanov was a student of the Likhud Brothers at the Italian School. Later he was a Greek, Latin and Italian interpreter (translator) at the Ambassadorial Prikaz and participated in diplomatic missions to Poland (1701) and Turkey (1702–1708). When archives were established at the Collegium of Foreign Affairs in 1724, he worked as an archivist at the Moscow bureau of the Collegium. Fedot Ageev, a student of the Likhud Brothers at the Slavic Greek Latin Academy, also studied at the Italian School. He participated in the translation of their works into Slavonic.
When the Novgorod School was opened, 119 people entered it, but most of them were students at the Slavic School, and only a few could study at the Greek school, where Sofrony and Ioanniky Likhud taught. The identification of the first students of the Greek Novgorod School was undertaken by I.A. Voznesenskaya. The basis for the study included a copy of Likhud’s Extensive Grammar. The students of the school copied the grammar book, indicating their names. Then, after a certain break, several students entered the school in 1711, namely Stefan Ivanov and Savva Irodionov, and in 1714, Varfolomey Fedorov (Fyodorov), Ivan Evdokimov, Evstafy Fedorov (Fyodorov), Ivan Ivanov, Timofey Tikhonov, Ivan Grigoryev, Stefan Maksimov, Andrey Nikitin, Ivan Kharitonov, Timofey Semenov (Semyonov), Matvey Fedorov (Fyodorov), Aleksey Nikitin. In 1709, the “paint master’s son” Ivan Maksimov was also accepted into the school. Ioanniky Likhud’s disciple Fedor (Fyodor) Maksimov then became head of the Greek Slavic School in Novgorod, and also compiled a textbook on Slavonic grammar, published in 1723.

Immediately after his arrival in Moscow, he and his brother took an active part in the theological and polemic activities on the side of the “Greek Party”. Disputes with the Latinophiles Yan Andrey Belobodsky and Sylvester Medvedev did not only have a religious orientation, but also concerned their personal relations, because each of the polemists claimed to be a teacher at the future Slavic Greek Latin Academy. Discussions were conducted either verbally or in writing, so it is possible to follow the development of the disputes: the theological-polemical treatise “Акос, или Врачевание, противополагаемое ядовитым угрызением змиевым” (“Akos”) reflects the history of the dispute with Belobodsky about the transubstantiation of the Holy Gifts, which took place on 15 March 1685. In 1690, another anti-Latin treatise “Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”) was created, based on the dispute between the Likhud Brothers and Teofil (Theophilus) Rutka, held in Lwów (Lviv) in 1684.
The Likhud Brothers were also involved in preaching activities; the manuscripts included sermons and panegyrics written jointly with his brother and independently, and also comprised accusatory theological treatises: “Похвала Алексея, человека Божия, обрученную свою оставившаго” (“…Alexis, the Man of God…”), “Поучение в пятую неделю великаго поста о предопределении, произнесенное в 1701 г. в Московском Успенском соборе за три приема” (…”the Fifth Week of the Great Fast…”); «Лютерские ереси» (“Luther’s Heresies”) (until January 1704); “Обличение и показание ересей Лютера и Кальвина” (“Revelation and testimony of the heresies of Luther and Calvin”) (1705-1706), “Слово о Софии премудрости Божией” (“The Tale of Sophia the Wisdom of God”) (Novgorod, 1708); “Похвальное слово Варлааму Хутынскому” (“Panegyric to Barlaam of Khutyn” (Novgorod); as well as panegyrics to Peter I – “Триумф царя, Петра Алексеевича, под Азовом 1697 г.” (“The Triumph of the Tsar, Peter Alekseevich, near the Azov in 1697”), “Похвальное слово царю, Петру Алексеевичу, по возвращении его из Голландии в 1698 г.” (“Panegyric to the Tsar, Peter Alekseevich, Upon His Return from Holland in 1698”); concerning the conclusion of peace with Sweden – “The Triumph of the Happiest and Most Glorious Eternal Peace ... with the Swedish Crown”, 1721).
Upon his return from Novgorod to Moscow, he took part in the correction of the Slavonic translation of the Bible.

Personal records:
(or Likud, Licudis, Leichoudes; Sophronius, Spiridon) (1652, Lixouri, Cephalonia, the Venetian Republic – 1730, Moscow). Apparently from quite a wealthy family. Father: Mark (†1666), ship’s captain. Mother: Susanna (according to Russian sources) or Trusianna (according to Greek sources). Siblings:
  • Ioann (Ioanniky in monastic life) Likhud (1633–1717);
  • Padulya, she remained in Cephalonia and lived in Ioanniky’s house.
Religion: Orthodox.
Education:
In his motherland, Sofrony received his primary education at a local school from a “certain priest”. Then he went to Venice and Padua for further education. The sources mention that the Likhud brothers attended lectures of “the most learned and wisest hieromonk Arseny Kalludiev” at the Cottunian (Kottounian) Collegium for nine years. Upon graduation from the collegium, Sofrony received a doctor’s degree. The archives of the University of Padua have documents attesting that Sofrony passed the graduation examination on 16 May 1670, with the highest mark and was awarded the rank of Doctor of Philosophy (publication: Ястребов А. Братья Лихуды в Падуе и Венеции, p. 219). According to the exam sheet, the thesis defence took place in the Collegio Veneto of Padua University; on 15 May, questions on philosophy related to Aristotle’s treatises “On the Soul” and “Posterior Analytics” were framed (ibid.) On the following day, 16 May, Sofrony defended his thesis. He answered Giovanni Cicala’s question on logic and Domenico Marchetti’s question on philosophy.
Not every Greek originating from the Western Greek Islands, which were under the rule of Venice, could receive an education like this. Financing education by a local priest, and then supporting children living in Venice or Padua was quite expensive and not everyone had the means to do it. In addition, passing the exam at the university also assumed an initial full payment for the procedure.
Career: In 1670, after receiving a university degree, he returned to Cephalonia, in Lixouri, and was ordained deacon in November of the same year. According to Russian sources and documents from the University of Padua, he became a monk while still a university student (before 1670); according to Greek sources, he did so in February 1672, when the notarial documents of the archives of Cephalonia recorded the mention of Sofrony as “hieromonk” for the first time (Πεντόγαλος Γ.Η. Ιωαννης (Ιωαννίκιος και Σπυρίδων (Σωφρόνιος) αδελφοί Λυκούδη (Λειχούδαι), σ. 10-11). He taught in Cephalonia for a while, and then went to the diocese of Nafpaktos and Arta, where he continued his teaching activities at Manolakis Kastorianos’ school. Then, according to an autobiographical note in the “Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”), he went to Macedonia and Thessaly, where he also taught and preached. In 1680, he returned to Cephalonia, from where, in 1683, he went to Constantinople with his brother, where they lived for five months (RGADA (Russian State Archives of Ancient Documents), f. 52, op. 1, book 8, fol. 78v) waiting for the decision of the Jerusalem Patriarch Dositheos, who sent them to Russia in response to the request of the Russian government to appoint Greek teachers. The decision was taken after Dositheos was convinced of their adherence to Orthodoxy. The Likhud brothers presented their statement of faith and preached for the gathered patriarch, metropolitan, archbishop, bishop and clergy. They left Constantinople on 3 July 1683, having received the blessing of the patriarchs and taken “the sheet certified by the hands of all the patriarchs”. A Greek copy of the document is available at MPT No. 194 (Athens, National Library of Greece). They were on the road from July 1683 to March 1685. The Likhud brothers’ writings “Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”) and “Акос” (“Akos”), as well as the interrogation speeches of the Ambassadorial Prikaz contain information concerning their route to Moscow. At first, their road lay to Moldavia and Wallachia, then to Hungary. There the Likhud brothers stayed longer due to military actions, in which the Prince of Wallachia Șerban Cantacuzino participated. In addition, “Akos” gives more detailed information on the stay in the Transylvanian cities and on the theological disputes that the brothers had there. According to the brothers, their activities were quite successful. The Likhud brothers had to endure debates with representatives of various faiths: “In Belgrade, Lower Hungary, with the theology professor of the Prince Michael Apafi, with a Calvinst, and in Simbin – with Jacob Tsambani – a Lutheran, theology professor in the same city, and with professor Clavioupol, a Calvinist” (Горский А.В., Невоструев К.И. Описание Синодальной библиотеки, vol. II, 3, p. 382). Only in June 1684, were the Likhud brothers able to go to Rzeczpospolita, where on 5 August 1684 they were presented and favourably received by Jan (John) Sobieski “in a town called Zalukovia” (“Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”), RGADA, f. 381, No. 415, fol. 14). However, unexpectedly, he changed his mind and forced the Likhud brothers to stay for several months. For a long time, the historiography did not give a precise answer to the question as to why they were delayed. However, various assumptions were made. The circumstances became clear when D. Papastratu discovered a letter written by the Greek œconomus of Saint Catherine’s Monastery on the Sinai Peninsula, by the name of Hadjikiryak, who was corresponding with the Sinai Archbishop Athanasius of Veroia, and to whom he wrote about the Likhud brothers’ stay in Poland 20 years later: according to the letter, the reason for the delay was suspicion of espionage for Turkey. Hadjikiryak contributed to the release of the Likhud brothers, personally interceding for them with the king. During their stay in Lwów (Lviv), they had a dispute with the Jesuit Teofil (Theophilus) Rutka. Various dogmatic questions were discussed in the debate. The questions are reflected in the content of the “Sword of the Spirit”, composed as 21 dialogues between the Likhud brothers and Rutka. Then their journey lay through Little Russia. They went from Lwów (Lviv) to Zhovkva, Brody, Dubno, then reached the borders of Kyiv and stopped at the Mezhyhirya Monastery. Afterwards they passed to the Borysthenes (Dnepr, Dnipro) River and from there to Nizhyn and further to Baturin (RGADA, f. 381, No. 415, fol. 16). In Baturin, they received a traveller’s certificate from the hetman Ivan Samoylovich (the original version: RGADA, f. 159, op. 2, pt. 2, d. 2991, fol. 15-15v). Then they went to Moscow via Sevsk, where they were provided with carts, and where the voivode Neplyuyev gave them a traveller’s certificate. The Likhud brothers spent 16 days on their journey from Baturin to Moscow. On 6 March 1685, the brothers arrived in Moscow and went to the Ambassadorial Prikaz immediately upon arrival. Soon after arriving in Russia, on 13 March 1685, an audience with the sovereigns took place (RGADA, f. 159, op. 2, No. 2991, fol. 19-23), where Ioanniky and Sofrony spoke separately, one in Greek, and the other in Latin (ibid., f. 52, op. 1, book 8, fol. 87v) and bowed low to petition for a “state salary”. On March 1685, Russian documents mentioned Ioanniky and Sofrony Likhud as philosophy and theology teachers (ibid., f. 159, op. 2, d. 2991, fol. 27) as well as teachers of the “high sciences” (ibid., f. 235, op. 2, d. 115, p. 262) for the first time. First the brothers settled in Saint Nicholas Greek Monastery, then, on 21 March 1685 in the Chudov Monastery in the Kremlin. On 28 March of the same year, the construction of cells began for them in the Epiphany Monastery, where on 1 July 1685, the Likhud School was opened. It laid the foundation for the Slavic Greek Latin Academy. The date of the creation of the school is considered the moment of the founding of the Slavic Greek Latin Academy in Moscow. The status of the institution is reflected in the salary, which was assigned to teachers in September 1686, that is 100 rubles per year (ibid., f. 1182, op. 1, d. 86, fol. 42). In 1687, the Academy moved to a more spacious stone building in the Monastery of the Holy Mandylion (Zaikonospassky Monastery). The building was specially built for the purpose. They continued teaching at the Academy until 1694, when the brothers were suspended from teaching. No documents have survived concerning their activity in 1694–1697, but we can suppose that they gave private Italian lessons. In 1697–1700, they taught at the Italian language school, apparently created especially for them. The educational institution was administered by the Order-in-Charge Prikaz. On 30 July 1700, the last document relating to the activities of the Italian School was issued; this should be considered the school’s closing date. M.N. Smentsovsky mentions that the Likhud brothers were at the Novospassky Monastery from 1698 to 1704 (Сменцовский М. Братья Лихуды, p. 318), but this does not correlate with documents showing that in 1694 the Likhud brothers received a homestead in Golutvino. Before, the homestead belonged to a podyachy (assistant clerk) from the Order-in-Charge Prikaz Gleb Afonasiev, who was convicted of plundering a huge amount of gold from the State treasury (RGADA, f. 210, приказной стол (prikaz), col. 2558, fol. 218). In January 1704, the Likhud brothers were sent to the Ipatiev Monastery in Kostroma, where they stayed until January 1706. There they continued their polemical activities and also compiled an extensive Greek grammar book. On 31 January 1706, a decree regarding their transfer from the Ipatiev Monastery to Metropolitan Iov (Job) in Novgorod was issued. They moved there with the help of the metropolitan of Novgorod, who wanted to create a Greek Slavic School in Novgorod. From the very first days of their arrival, they devoted their activities to the founding of a new school in Novgorod. Sofrony was not there for long. At the end of 1707, his departure to Moscow took place in order to pick up the equipment of Symeon Polotsky’s Upper Printing House, but he stayed in Moscow to teach Greek. In 1708, he began teaching at the Greek School at the Kazan Podvorye in Vetoshny Row in Moscow, where he was the only Greek teacher until 1716. From 1716 onwards, he was apparently helped by Ioanniky Likhud, who had returned from Novgorod. Alexey Kirillovich Barsov also taught from 1718 to 1720. In 1722, his situation changed. From May 1722 onwards, Afanasy (Athanasius) Skiada was sent to be head of the school, and Sofrony was left without a position. From 1723 to 1729, he served as archimandrite at the Solotchin Monastery in the Ryazan Diocese. In 1730, he was transferred to the Novospassky Monastery in Moscow, where he died in 1730.

The identification of the first students of the Greek Novgorod School was undertaken by I.A. Voznesenskaya. The basis for the study included a copy of Likhud’s Extensive Grammar. The students of the school copied the grammar book, indicating their names.

Immediately after his arrival in Moscow, he and his brother Ioanniky Likhud took an active part in the theological and polemic activities on the side of the “Greek Party”. Disputes with the Latinophiles Yan Andrey Belobodsky and Sylvester Medvedev did not only have a religious orientation, but also concerned their personal relations, because each of the polemists claimed to be a teacher at the future Slavic Greek Latin Academy. Discussions were conducted either verbally or in writing, so it is possible to follow the development of the disputes: the theological-polemical treatise “Акос, или Врачевание, противополагаемое ядовитым угрызением змиевым” reflects the history of the dispute with Belobodsky about the transubstantiation of the Holy Gifts, which took place on 15 March 1685. In 1690, another anti-Latin treatise «Мечец Духовный» (“Sword of the Spirit”) was created, based on the dispute between the Likhud Brothers and Teofil (Theophilus) Rutka, held in Lwów (Lviv) in 1684.
Sofrony was also involved in preaching activities; the manuscripts included sermons and panegyrics written jointly with his brother and independently, and also comprised accusatory theological treatises: “Похвала Алексея, человека Божия, обрученную свою оставившаго” (“…Alexis, the Man of God…”), “Поучение в пятую неделю великаго поста о предопределении, произнесенное в 1701 г. в Московском Успенском соборе за три приема” (…”the Fifth Week of the Great Fast…”); «Лютерские ереси» (“Luther’s Heresies”) (until January 1704); “Обличение и показание ересей Лютера и Кальвина” (“Revelation and testimony of the heresies of Luther and Calvin”) (1705–1706), “Слово о Софии премудрости Божией” (“The Tale of Sophia the Wisdom of God”) (Novgorod, 1708); “Похвальное слово Варлааму Хутынскому” (“Panegyric to Barlaam of Khutyn” (Novgorod); as well as panegyrics to Peter I – “Триумф царя, Петра Алексеевича, под Азовом 1697 г.” (“The Triumph of the Tsar, Peter Alekseevich, near the Azov in 1697”), “Похвальное слово царю, Петру Алексеевичу, по возвращении его из Голландии в 1698 г.” (“Panegyric to the Tsar, Peter Alekseevich, Upon His Return from Holland in 1698”); concerning the conclusion of peace with Sweden – “The Triumph of the Happiest and Most Glorious Eternal Peace ... with the Swedish Crown”, 1721).
In 1712, he was involved in the correction of the Slavonic translation of the Bible. The work was carried out together with his former students and Moscow Print Yard employees, F. Polikarpov, Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov) Golovin, and also Feofilakt (Theophylactus) Lopatinsky during 1713–1720. An important direction in the correction of the Bible was the elimination of the bookish “hellenisms”. The activity made the Church Slavonic language more understandable and brought it closer to the Russian language.

Languages and other subjects taught by t: German syntax, morphology, translation from Russian to German (and vice versa).
Career: Limberg was one of the first German teachers at the grammar school of Moscow University. The schedule of lectures of 1757 records that Limberg taught in the noble section of the grammar school. He taught German syntax, “etymology”, which meant morphology, and also translation from Russian to German and vice versa.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to the Moscow University.
Students and their social status:
Nobles.
The grammar school at the Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 at the initiative of Mikhail Lomonosov in order to prepare future students for the Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To start with, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was reached in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
[Gottsched, Johann Christoph], Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst, Nach den Mustern der besten Schriftsteller des vorigen und jetzigen Jahrhunderts abgefasset von Johann Christoph Gottscheden, Leipzig, 1748 (4th - ed. 1757).
[Lange, Joachim], Colloquia Scholastica, Школьные разговоры, Schul-Gespräche, Dialogues, St. Petersburg, 1738.
[Шванович, Мартин], Немецкая грамматика, из разных авторов собрана и российской юности в пользу издана от учителя немецкого языка при Санкт-Петербургской гимназии, St. Petersburg: Academy of Sciences Publishing House, 3rd ed.,1745.
The first years at the grammar school attached to the Moscow University were characterized by a significant shortage of textbooks for language tuition. There were only a few standard works, which had been printed at the Academic University in St. Petersburg and used at the Academic grammar school as well. One of these books were Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues,” published in 1738, which was used in the lower German classes according to the regulations of the Moscow grammar school of 1755 (see: Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). Another standard work was M. Schwanwitz’ German grammar, printed in a fourth edition at the Academic University in St. Petersburg in 1745. Most likely, it was used at the very beginning of the Moscow grammar school, too. Still in 1758, Moscow University ordered 40 copies for the grammar school pupils (Пенчко, 1960, p. 140). In addition to that, a highly popular German grammar from Leipzig, Johann Christoph Gottsched’s “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst,“ was used. It had been introduced at the Moscow University by J.G. Reichel, the first lecturer in German language and literature and a student of Gottsched himself, who used it in his classes in 1757 (see Koch, 2002, p. 237). In 1758, it was also officially implemented by Lomonosov’s school regulation (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459).
In general, grammar books made up the main basis for language instruction in the 18th century. The grammar covered all the important aspects of a language, not only the grammar rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology,” which meant morphology, syntax and prosody.

Personal records: (or Risievich) (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Like other first teachers at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Ioann Lisievich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (including the theology class).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Elementary Latin reading and writing; Latin grammar.
Career:
After graduation he was ordained a priest.
All we know about Ioann Lisievich is that he was a teacher in the phara and infima classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1738–1739 school year. He continued teaching in subsequent years; he was a rhetoric teacher and Prefect of the Collegium (in 1741–1744).
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (from 1738).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In total, 110 students were enrolled at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1738–1739 school year. Several dozen people studied in the phara and infima classes in which Ioann Lisievich taught.
Most of the students at Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) in which Ioann Lisievich taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, at Orthodox collegiums there was a preparatory class. Ioann Lisievich also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students.
The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence was the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and also made their students translate prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereiaslav Collegium.

Personal records: (or Litke, Litken) (1705, Jüterbog, The Duchy of Saxe-Weissenfels, Holy Roman Empire; bapt. on 27 August 1705 – 1771, Kaluga, Russian Empire). Father: Philipp Lütke, taylor. Mother: Catharina Groe. Married in 1746. Children: ; ; ; . Grandson: Friedrich Benjamin Graf von Lütke (граф Фёдор Петрович Литке, 1797–1882), who was a well-known Russian , , and , admiral in 1855, in 1866, (1829), (1855), and (1864) of the s in . Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Lütke started to study theology at the University of Frankfurt (Oder) in May 1727 and continued at the University of Wittenberg from March 1728 on, where he also received his Masterʼs degree.
Career: Master of theology. Lütke came to Saint Petersburg in 1735, together with Christlieb Ehregott Gellert, Jacob von Stählin and Johann Georg Lotter, who were invited to the Academy of Sciences. Lütke became deputy rector of the Academy School with a contract for six years but quit very soon after. In 1736/1737, it is documented that he was rector of the German St. Petri School and in 1737/1738 assistant to the pastor of St. Anne’s church. Due to his obviously difficult disposition, he often got in trouble and never remained for long in one position. Next, he moved to Swedish Finland, then, in 1741, to Poland and back to Moscow in 1743. In Moscow, Lütke was elected pastor of the German New Church (1744–1749) and founded his own boarding school. After the foundation of the Moscow University in 1755, Lütke became the first German teacher at the university (1756). In 1757, he also taught the most advanced German class as well as physics in the noble section of the grammar school attached to the university. He remained in this position until 1758. In 1759, he returned to St. Petersburg and was engaged as German teacher at the Page corps (until 1762). For a short period of time, he also worked at the First Noble Infantry Cadet Corps. He died of some infection in Kaluga in 1771.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1735, Saint Petersburg); St. Petri School (1736–1737, Saint Petersburg); private boarding school (from 1744, Moscow); Moscow University Grammar School (1756–1758); Page Corps (1759–1762, Saint Petersburg); First Noble Infantry Cadet Corps (Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Prince Grigory Alexandrovich Potemkin
Potemkin learned German in Lütkeʼs private boarding school, maybe also in the Moscow University School.
Teaching methods and materials: German phrasing, composition of letters, short speeches and dialogues, reading and analysis of newspaper articles.
Language and other teaching books by the: Lütke, Johann Philipp, Versuch eines neuen physikalischen Systems, nach physikalischen und chymischen Gründen entworfen, Frankfurt, Leipzig, 1757.

Personal records: Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Victor Liubinetsky is that in the 1719–1720 school year he was an infima class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1719–1720).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the infima class in which Victor Liubinetsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Victor Liubinetsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century.
