Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Samuil Liuliansky is that in 1738–1743 he was a grammar and syntax class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium. At the time, he was a monk. In the 1743–1744 school year, he was no longer on the list of teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1738–1743).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied in the grammar and syntax classes in which Samuil Liuliansky taught in 1738–1743.
Although most of the students at Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, in the grammar and syntax classes taught by Samuil Liuliansky in 1738–1743, most of the students were sons of “secular” parents.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Samuil Liuliansky , students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis, they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at Kharkiv Collegium from the first years of its existence and at the turn of the 1730–1740s was the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, which was widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. A large number of textbooks published for Jesuit collegiums of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) were mentioned in the library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753). In the 1730s, the “purchase of the Alvarez” was a frequent expense at the Kharkiv Collegium. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. A very remarkable collection (workbook) of school exercises, which Samuil Liuliansky 's student Ivan Ushivsky did under his teacher’s direction in 1738–1743 has been preserved (and serves as the main source concerning Samuil Liuliansky ’s work at the collegium). This collection attracted attention from the point of view of the history of literature (N.I. Petrov), of “the lively literary interests of schoolchildren of the 18th century.” However, it also serves as an authentic source for characterising the teaching of Latin in grammar and syntax classes. The collection is distinguished by a large volume (213 sheets), and it is a clean copy with no strikethrough, ink spots, torn sheets (typical in most of similar documents). The workbook gives us an idea of the types of exercises that Samuil Liuliansky ’s students were supposed to work with, as well as their “typical” content. Among the phrases translated by the student, there were regular greetings used by the teacher when entering the class, as well as phrases describing usual and unusual “school situations,” which certainly aimed at attracting the attention of the student (“such a sensible student, who, screwing up his face, asks for dismissal from the teacher assigning him exercises”). The workbook demonstrates a palette of exercises for translating short passages, proverbs, sayings, which the teacher picked up from different sources: spiritual books, works by classical authors (Sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates), and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. The teacher used a lot of proverbs from folklore (some of them were modified) as material for translation exercises. The workbook shows Ukrainian, Russian and Polish proverbs (“Baba z voza, kolesam legshe”, “Osmak kopi sterezhe”, “Yaky pan, taky yogo kram”, etc.). The surviving school exercises of the collegium students of those years show that they usually translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, and excerpts from the Gospel, as well. The collection (workbook) of school exercises performed by Ivan Ushivsky under Samuil Liuliansky ’s direction, allows us to trace typical tasks and exercises, as well as specific ones, characterising this particular teacher. Career: In October 1730, Ljurcenius is registered in the list of employees of the Academy of Science as writing master («шрейбмейстер») in the Academy School.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Science (1730; Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. The names of a large number of these pupils, aged between 6 and 20 years-old, are known and listed in the pupil registers including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
There were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils, among them nobles and non-nobles. The family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.

Personal records: (Secular name: Ivan Vasilyevich) (1763, Kyiv, Russian Empire – 1817, Kursk, Russian Empire). Iakinf Loganovsky was from an impoverished noble (szlachta) family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1779 to 1792, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including the theology class.
Career: After graduation in 1792, Iakinf Loganovsky was appointed to work as a grammar class teacher at the Pereiaslav Collegium. He also taught Ancient Greek. From 1793 onwards, he was a grammar class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In 1795, he took monastic vows. Then he taught successively in the rhetoric (from 1796) and philosophy (from 1800) classes. He was also the Prefect of the academy. From 8 September 1803, he was archimandrite at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv; from 30 March 1804 he was the rector of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1813 until his death, he was archimandrite at the Znamensky Virgin Monastery in Kursk.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium; Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the beginning of the 1790s, several dozen students learned Latin in the grammar classes of the Pereiaslav Collegium and the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Most of the students who learned Ancient Greek were from the rhetoric class, a few were from the philosophy and theology classes (more than 20 students studied the language).
Most of the students at Pereiaslav Collegium and Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Iakinf Loganovsky taught Latin grammar and syntax rules, grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. He also taught Ancient Greek grammar and syntax. At the end of the 18th century, there were well-established traditions of teaching Ancient Greek at the Pereiaslav Collegium. The first year of studies was devoted to grammar, the second was meant for studying syntax. Iakinf Loganovsky’s Latin grammar classes (both at the collegium and at the academy) were based on the book by Christophorus Cellarius (= Christoph Martin Keller). There were a great number of books by Cellarius, published in different years, so that each student had a book. It is known that the direction of the Pereiaslav Collegium bought these books several times, more than 100 copies at a time. The surviving school exercises of the collegium students show that they also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. Johann Joachim Lange’s “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. There were also a great number of copies of this book, published in different years. Grammar rules were taught using the book on Ancient Greek written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, the teacher and his students were supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. During the second year of studies, students were supposed to memorize short sentences from several lexicons that the teacher had. At the Pereiaslav Collegium, there were several lexicons, dictionaries and grammar books on Ancient Greek. Some of them entered the library of the collegium from the personal collection of the bishop of Pereiaslav, Iov Bazilevich (who had once taught Ancient Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium). Personal records: (or Luppé, Luppa) (*1731, Lunéville, Lorraine). Son of a poor nobleman. Religion: converted Orthodox.
Education: Vasily Luppe is known to have studied in France.
Career:
After graduation, Vasily Luppe had a four-year period working in France. Then he taught French for three years at a Jesuit Collegium in Warsaw, worked as a teacher for various families and afterwards taught at an academy in Zamość (Rzeczpospolita).
In 1769, Vasily Luppe came to Kharkiv, converted to Orthodoxy and until 1777 was a private French teacher, working for various families. From September 1777 to October 1783, he was a French teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. He was dismissed, because the academic direction considered his command of the language insufficient.
Teaching institutions and families:
We know that as a tutor (private teacher), Vasily Luppe taught French in several families in Kharkiv, but no detailed information about this activity has been preserved.
Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1777–1783).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few students from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
At the time, the textbook compiled by Martyn Sokolovsky was used for teaching French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. It is obvious that Vasily Luppe did not lack textbooks for students. He could also use other French grammar books and lexicons that were available in the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library catalogue, it contained, at the time, a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries (by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey). The rather short book descriptions in the catalogue do not make it possible to identify all the books accurately.

Personal records: (1752-09-07, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – 1815-06-05, Polatsk, Russian Empire). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Antony Lustyg was a member of the Society of Jesus from 1768. He received his initial education at the Jesuit College in Łomża (Poland). After the dissolution of the Society in 1773, Lustyg completed his education in Russia. Due to the fact that the catalogues of the Society of Jesus in Belarus covering the years from 1772 to 1773 and from 1778 to 1782 were not preserved, it is only known that in the 1774–1775 academic year, Lustyg studied at the Polatsk Jesuit College.
Career: Priest. At first, Antony Lustyg taught German: in 1776–1777, at the residence of the Society of Jesus in Mahilyow, in 1780–1782 and 1783–1787, at the Polatsk Jesuit College, in 1787–1789, at the Vitsebsk Jesuit College, in 1789–1791, at the Orsha Jesuit College. From 1791 on, Lustyg worked in Mahilyow, first as the Prefect (1791–1793) and then as the Rector of the College (1793–1802). During his time as Rector in Mahilyow, Lustyg was elected Assistant to the Superior General in 1799. He held this position until his death. In 1802–1805, he was the Provincial of the Society of Jesus in Belarus. From 1805 to 1812, he was the Rector of the Polatsk College, then in 1812–1814, he worked as the first Rector of the Polatsk Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Mahilyow Jesuit College; Polatsk Jesuit College; Vitsebsk Jesuit College; Orsha Jesuit College; Polatsk Academy.
Students and their social status: Clergy; nobility; urban low and middle class.
Teaching methods and materials: Scholastic.

Fullname: Léonard, Count of Moriolles, Alexandre-Nicolas-Edouard-Charles-Marie de
Personal records:
(The second Count of Moriolles, chevalier, seigneur of Beauclair, Étrépigny, in the bailiwicks of Clermont-en-Argonne and Mouzon, Alexandre de Léonard de Moriolles) (*Château de Beauclair in Lorraine, near Montmédy, Meuse, bapt. on 20 February 1760 – †1845-06-30, Lorient, Morbihan). From a family originally from Bas-Limousin, which, through marriage, moved to the Champagne Ardennes in the mid-18th century. Arms: Azure, strewn with small crosses of gold, a lion of the same, on a chief sewn with azure, charged with three stars of gold. Semis of flames (leo ardens). Father: Henry-François-Marie de Léonard, baron, later count of Moriolles, lieutenant general of the king's armies (1784) and commander of Saint-Louis (1786). Mother: Marie-Gabrielle Renart de Fuchsambert, dame of Beauclair and Étrépigny in Champagne, married by a contract signed by the king on 25 November 1759. Godfather: Alexandre, Duke of La Rochefoucauld. Godmother: Countess de Monrey, born Roucy, his paternal grandmother. Grandfathers: Claude-Antoine de Léonard, squire, seigneur of Moriolles; Charles Renart, chavalier, seigneur count of Moncey, grand master of waters and forests in the department of Metz. Grandmothers: Marie de La Rochefoucauld-Cousanges (married in 1724); Nicole de Roucy. Married to: 1.) (ar. 1789) Élisabeth de Bertrand (†1843, Lorient); 2.) (in 1844) Marie Brandmuller, his Polish governess and chambermaid, who had entered his service in 1825. From the 1st marriage he had several children who died in infancy and:
  • Alexandrine de Léonard de Moriolles, who married after 1845 to Commander Kerdrain, son of Admiral Kerdrain, with at least two sons.
Career:
Military. Raised in the household of the Duke of Penthièvre, he was enrolled at the age of twelve in the king's bodyguards, Luxembourg company; he became a captain of cavalry on 21 April 1777, a replacement captain in the 1st company of the 2nd battalion of the Penthièvre infantry regiment on 9 April 1784, second major in the Cambrésis regiment, stationed in Bayonne, on 1 May 1788, and then major in the Penthièvre dragoons regiment on 20 December 1788. He then became secretary to the Duke of Penthièvre.
Elected under the title of Marquis of Moriolles, substitute deputy of the nobility of the Sedan bailiwick to the Estates General of 1789, he then resided in Sedan, at Étrépigny, a league from Charleville, and in his very large Château de Beauclair, near Montmédy, a land erected into a county by his father with an annual income of £40,000.
He emigrated at the beginning of the French Revolution; he was found in the army of Condé, where he served as a quartermaster. He was appointed a Knight of Saint-Louis on 25 December 1796, and received it on 1 September 1797. He stayed in Poland with Count Bystri, near Jytomir, and then sought to establish a French boarding school in a small Polish town. He later served in Russia under the command of Count Vasili Sergeyevich Sheremetiev, major general, who was appointed in 1793 as governor of the occupied governments of Iziaslavl and Konstantinovsk, and protector of the Delesalle family. He resided from 1797 to 1810 with Count Branicki in Belaya Tserkov, Ukraine (amnesty certificate dated 14 Floréal Year XI).
Retired camp marshal, he entered in 1810 the service of Grand Duke of Russia Constantine Pavlovich as governor of his recognized illegitimate son, Paul Alexandrov, with an annual salary of 33679 rubles. He was elevated to the dignity of Knight of Saint Stanislaus, 2nd class, on 16 November 1825. He then lived at the Belvedere Castle near Warsaw and remained with the Grand Duke as a retired courtier and spiritual companion. He returned to France for a visit in 1825 and received a portion of the indemnity for émigrés. During the Polish revolution, he fled to Breslau in December 1830 and unsuccessfully attempted to regain a position at the Russian court, despite his falling out with the Grand Duke. He definitively returned to France in 1832 or 1834 (an Alexandre de Moriolles, music teacher, was indeed residing in Moscow in 1834 when he signed a power of attorney at the French vice-consulate. MAE Nantes, Série administration centrale, actes de chancellerie, carton 170, Moscou, 1834-1839, f° 35.). He settled in Dreux, then in Lorient.
Students and their social status: Paul Alexandrov, recognized illegitimate son of Grand Duke of Russia Constantine Pavlovich.
Language and other teaching books by the: He left behind Mémoires sur l’émigration, la Pologne et la cour du grand-duc Constantin (1789–1833), prefaced by Frédéric Masson and published in Paris by Ollendorff in 1902, in-8°.

Personal records: (or Ljurcenius)
Career: In October 1730, Lürsenius is registered in the list of employees of the Academy of Sciences as writing master («шрейбмейстер») in the Academy School.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1730, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils, aged between 6 and 20, attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. Most of these students’ names are known and listed in the registers, including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
There were two different categories of students attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils, among them nobles and non-nobles. The family background of the pupils was diverse: from the higher nobility, army officers and high-ranking civil servants such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants.
Sources and bibliography: Сухомлинов, М., Материалы для истории Академии наук, St. Petersburg, [1885], vol. 1, p. 650, 654.

Personal records: (or Mainvillers; his real name Genu-Soalhat) (*1714-07-14, Mainvilliers, according to his own account) He was probably not a chevalier, as Madame Leprince de Beaumont, who likely knew him in London, states that he came from a family of prosecutors (Œuvres mêlées, 1775, vol. VI, p. 295, note by F. Weil, Dictionnaire des journalistes). He probably did not die in Danzig on 12 June 1776: a Mainvillier was present in Russia, in Moscow, around 1777.
Career:
Writer and tutor. Charles-Louis-Philippe, chevalier Mainvilliers-Genu-Soalhat traveled extensively throughout Europe before coming to Russia. He settled in Geneva, where he presented himself as the Moses of philosophers and was accused of making blasphemous speeches. He was ordered to leave the city. He also lived in need in London. He passed through Berlin, while his writings mention other travels to Brunswick, Hamburg, Copenhagen… He returned to Germany, where he was supported by Count Rantzau. The adventurer sought to enter the world of literature, associating his name with those of known writers. In Le petit-maître philosophe, Mainvillier mentions his relations with the Marquis d’Argens, of whom the chevalier claims to have been a friend for two years (he provides his portrait in vol. 3, pp. 1-13). Baulacre wrote that his “confession of faith is pretty much the same” as that of the Marquis d’Argens. Around the same time, he allegedly participated in the edition of Le Siècle de Louis XIV by Voltaire:
  • Le Siècle de Louis XIV, nouv. éd. augm. d'un très grand nombre de remarques par M. de La B*** [Beaumelle], volumes 1-3, by François-Marie Arouet known as Voltaire, Frankfurt, Vve Knoch and J.G. Eslinger, 1753. This is an edition made by La Beaumelle based on those from Berlin, 1751, and The Hague, 1752. Upon his arrest in Paris in April 1753, due to an offensive note in volume 2 regarding the House of Orléans, La Beaumelle claimed to be the author only of the notes in volume 1, asserting that those in the other two volumes were by the chevalier de Mainvilliers, and he stated that he had protested against the mention of his initials in the title.
Mainvilliers arrived in Russia before February 1757, likely Tschudy, who, after spending a few months in the Bastille, was released from prison thanks to his patron Shuvalov and was returning to Russia. The chevalier was probably introduced to the favorite, who was then the curator of Moscow University, and was appointed professor of politics and heraldry at the college of the university. In June 1757, Ivan Melissino, the rector of the university, wrote to Shuvalov that professors Mainvilliers and Du Boulaye refused to obey him and claimed to be above the other professors. At that time, Mainvilliers composed a speech that the university refused to publish. A Mainvilliers was in Moscow in January 1777.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Moscow university (from 1757).
Language and other teaching books by the:
In Geneva, he began the publication of a periodical titled Le Petit-maître philosophe ou aventures philosophi-badines de Soalhat, chevalier de Mainvilliers. Avec ses études, ses voyages pour perfectionner ses connaissances, son système sur toutes choses. Ouvrage périodique, In Geneva, published by Henri Albert Gosse and Co., 1750, of which only one issue was released before the publication was shut down. The work was later reissued and expanded. Notably, we mention:
  • Le petit-maître philosophe: ou voyages et avantures de Génu Soalhat, chevalier de Mainvillers, dans les principales cours de l’Europe, La Mecque [Holland], at the expense of the pilgrims, [1751], vol. 1, VIII, 162 p.; vol. 2, 216 p.; vol. 3, 161, [1] p. (other editions, in London, in 1752). In this book, an ironic petit-maître recounts his life from birth until his arrival at the court of Frederick the Great. He claims to have attended the seminary in Chartres, then in Paris, then at La Trappe, and finally to have joined the Maillebois regiment in 1734. The author summarizes the life of his hero: “Is it not rather insulting to men to instruct them in the perfect indifference with which I honor all that they do, say, and believe; to finally teach them that after having renounced their society, I have confined myself to the sole company of women, as more agreeable for those who know how to take advantage of it?” Thus, the hero acquires a reputation as a man traversing Europe, making “my journeys a kind of gallant map.”
Mindful of his image as a wandering philosopher, Mainvillier claims in Le Petit maître philosophe that the inhabitants of the cities he passed through had his portrait engraved and accompanied it with these verses: ‘To this cheerful air, gracious Cavalier, One sees a Philosopher, a singular spirit: Looking back, he laughs at his misfortunes, With Plato, he defies the threats of fate. Always persecuted by envious spirits, He travels through Europe, seeking the learned. Polished Petit-Maître, knowledgeable without verbiage, He unites science with charming banter. Sincere admirer of a generous Prince, Forgetting his woes among the unfortunate, He rises to glory through misfortune. Faithful debtor, true heart without bitterness, Eloquent, courageous, amusing, and gallant, He would be without flaw, but... he is fickle.’ The book also contains stanzas signed ‘Chev. Dulussy, author of Les Francs-maçons vengés and La Muse maçonne’ written to celebrate Mainvilliers' new secret philosophy and his ‘system on preexistence.’ These two works were then sufficiently known; the author of these stanzas is none other than Baron de Tschudy, a Freemason and writer who became a comedian and secretary to the favorite of Empress Elizabeth in Russia, Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov. The two men undoubtedly knew each other well and mentioned one another in their writings. Tschudy did not forget Mainvilliers upon the publication of the first issue of Le Caméléon littéraire, a periodical he edited in 1755 in Russia. One can read: ‘But perhaps I would be mistaken for the Chev. de M., and in such misunderstandings, one plays for high stakes; I could lose as much as I could gain, let us remain as we are, Mr. inhabitant of the world, I, a small inhabitant of the North’ (no. 1 of 5 January 1755). He speaks of twenty years of travel in another of his books, L’Homme-dieu (1754). In Russia, Mainvilliers devoted himself to composing a vast epic poem that had as its main theme the glorification of Peter the Great and Russia:
  • La Pétréade, ou Pierre le créateur, by Mr. G.-S. chevalier de Mainvilliers, Amsterdam, J. H. Schneider, 1762 (reprinted: 1763), in-8°, IV-285 pp., frontisp., fig., and engraved plates. The frontispiece depicts Peter the Great accompanied by François Le Fort and Wisdom, descending from the throne to greet Science and the Arts, which he invites to Russia. The sovereign tramples Idleness, Ignorance, and Cruelty underfoot, “which have long reigned in his Country.” The text accompanying this frontispiece explains that the first arts to arrive in Saint Petersburg were Architecture and Navigation, followed by “Agriculture, Astronomy, History, Poetry, Painting, and Sculpture, which complete the roster of Science.” This poem in ten cantos recounts the great deeds of Peter the Great, featuring, alongside the Russian sovereign, many figures from his reign, notably his close collaborators François Le Fort and Alexander Menshikov. Peter's first journey to Europe occupies a significant place in this poem. Mainvilliers is extremely laudatory towards the Russian sovereign, whom he sees as the man who brought about a revolution in the morals of his people, taking Europe as an example to thoroughly reform Russian life: combating prejudices and religious fanaticism, developing sciences and arts, and introducing Russia into the concert of European nations, this “universe that laughs at its [Russia’s – ed.] nothingness.” Ivan Shuvalov, who had commissioned Voltaire to write a history of Peter the Great and understood the importance of Peter’s figure for Russia's image in Europe, may have been the originator of this project. If Mainvilliers did not dedicate his work to the favorite, as Tschudy had done in 1754 for Le Philosophe au Parnasse français and the chevalier Maugue Des Essarts for his Voïageur Moscovite, it is probably because by the time of publication, the era of Elizabeth had ended, and Shuvalov was no longer the man of the moment.
Mainvilliers was also the author of:
  • Les Huit philosophes avanturiers de ce siècle, ou Rencontre imprévue de MM. Voltaire, d’Argens, Maupertuis, Marivaut, Prévôt, Crébillon, Mouhi et de Mainvilliers.... Comédie de nos jours, The Hague, Ed. L. Saurel, 1752 (reissued as Les Huit Philosophes errants, s.l., 1754);
  • L’Homme-Dieu ou l’univers seule famille, London, 1754, a poem containing an ode to the Empress of Russia;
  • Nouvelle philosophie secrète, ou Abrégé et Plan systématique de l’histoire universelle critique et raisonnée du ciel et de la terre, avant et depuis la formation du monde visible, London, l’Auteur, 1772, 114 p. in-8°.
He is said to be the translator of his own play:
  • Die acht irrende Philosophen, oder Neue Entdeckungen von Voltaire, von Maupertuis, von Montesquiou, von dem Marquis von Argens, von dem Abt Prevot. lustiges Schauspiel itziger Zeit..., 1754, [II-]60 p. in-8°.

Personal records: (Secular name: Mikhail) (The town of Sorochyntsi in the Mirgorod Regiment, Russian Empire – 1758-07-28, Kyiv). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Manassiya Maksimovich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class.
Career: In 1746, while studying in the theology class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, Manassiya Maksimovich was appointed as a German teacher and from 1747 onwards as an Ancient Hebrew teacher at the Academy. In 1749, he took monastic vows at Saint Sofia’s Monastery in Kyiv. He taught German and Ancient Hebrew until 1755, when he became a theology professor, rector of the Academy and archimandrite at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv. He fulfilled these duties until his death.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1746–1758).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes learned Ancient Hebrew and German as an option at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
Manassiya Maksimovich continued the systematic teaching of Hebrew and German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, initiated by Simon Todorsky and Varlaam Liaschevsky. The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was designed for three years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. One was supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. The teaching of German grammar was designed for two years.
Some of the books used by Manassiya Maksimovich for teaching languages had been brought by Simon Todorsky from Germany. For teaching Ancient Hebrew, he used a grammar book written by Johann-Heinrich Michaelis. It is known that grammar rules were consolidated through reading abstracts from works by various authors as well as through translating passages from various texts. Probably, Manassiya Maksimovich used different lexicons and grammar books that were available at the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (for example, the books by Heinrich Opitz and Johannes Buxtorf). Something similar can be said with respect to German, for a large number of books concerning the study of the language were available at the library of the academy. However, rather short descriptions in the catalogue do not make it possible to identify many lexicons, grammar books and dictionaries accurately.

Language and other teaching books by the: Several translations (from German), instructions and notes on the theology course written by Manassiya Maksimovich have been preserved in the form of manuscripts. He also participated in the correction of the book by Dimitry of Rostov: “Lives of the Saints.”

Personal records: (*1716, Sokal, a town in the Belz Voivodeship, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth). He was born into the family of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Aleksei Malinovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class (he was a theology student in 1737).
Career: We know that Aleksei Malinovsky was a teacher in the grammar and syntax classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1741–1742 school year. He continued teaching in the following years. He was a rhetoric teacher in the academic year 1742–1743 and a poetics teacher in the 1744–1745 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1741–1745).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In total, 120 students were enrolled at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1741–1742 school year. There were several dozen students in the syntax class which Aleksei Malinovsky taught.
Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Aleksei Malinovsky taught grammar and syntax rules and did translation exercises with his students. The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the 1740s was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that their teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereiaslav Collegium. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari, De Institutione Grammatica, Monachii [München]: apud Nicolaum Henricum, sumptibus Samuelis Maderi, 1625.

Personal records:
(also known as Boudri; in Russia: David Ivanovich) (1756-02-21, Neuchâtel, Prussia at the time, currently Switzerland – 1821-10-05, Saint Petersburg; widowed, with his two daughters by his side). Father: Jean Mara (†1783-01-26, Geneva), of Sardinian origin, who emigrated to Geneva, converted to Calvinism, and became a citizen of Boudry. Mother: Louise Cabrol (†1782-04-26, Geneva), born in Geneva, a Protestant from a family of wigmakers from Castres (Tarn) who had also been forced to emigrate to Switzerland. David Mara had eight siblings, including Jean-Paul Marat (1743–1793), the famous physician, journalist, and revolutionary deputy. Married to: Maria Timofeyeva (*Paris), daughter of captain Labkoff (*Moscow – †before 1792-12) and Marie Dunefour (*Brussels); marriage on 29 December 1792, in the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg; witnesses: Philippe Demuth, innkeeper; André Desnoyers, Daniel Jourloff. Daughter:
  • Marie de Boudry (*1794-03-24).
From Anna Semenova, daughter of the translator of Oriental languages, Kilimchin, he had:
  • Olympiade de Boudry (*1802-08-29).
Education: Academy of Geneva.
Career: Tutor. After higher studies in languages, philosophy, and theology at the Academy of Geneva, David Mara (at that time, all family members still bore this name without the 't') was engaged in 1784 as a tutor at the invitation of the Russian chamberlain Vasili Petrovich Saltykov and went to Russia. Until 1795 (as mentioned by Masson in his Memoirs), he lived with the Saltykov family but also taught in other households. He also frequented the home of Nikolai Ivanovich Saltykov, a trusted man of Empress Catherine II, who was tasked by her to oversee the education of her two grandsons, Alexander and Constantin, whom she wished to distance from their parents. Like David Mara, Count Saltykov sought to maintain a relationship of trust with the mother of the two wards, Maria Fedorovna, wife of the future Paul I. David Mara also had as a student the young Nikolai Goncharov, who would become the father-in-law of the poet Alexander Pushkin. Before dedicating himself exclusively to pedagogy, David tried his luck, though without lasting success, by purchasing a textile factory from the Goncharovs, a line of business that was part of the family tradition of his maternal side. In 1793, at the time of his brother Jean-Paul's assassination, whom he loved and respected, David Mara was not yet working in any official educational institution. In a troubled political context and on the eve of becoming a father, he requested to bear the name David de Boudry (Boudry being the locality near Neuchâtel from which his family originated). This favor was granted to him "by imperial permission." He continued, until 1805, his private tutoring with the Mirkovich family (one of his students, Fedor Iakovlevich Mirkovich (1790–1866), later became the governor-general of Vilna). David de Boudry was appointed in 1803 as a professor of French literature at the Institute of Saint Catherine of Alexandria, where, upon the recommendation of Maria Fedorovna, he received the rank of 9th class professor. In 1806, he joined the University Lyceum of Saint Petersburg (gimnaziya). That same year, residing in Russia, he took an oath at the Senate Church to obtain "eternal Russian citizenship." In 1808, he was promoted to the rank of titular advisor. From 1811, he taught French literature at the Imperial Lyceum of Tsarskoye Selo while continuing his work at the Institute of Saint Catherine of Alexandria. The poet Alexander Pushkin was one of his students at Tsarskoye Selo, in the first class that also included, among others: Danzas, de Broglie, Gorchakov, Guriev, Illichevski, Korf, Lomonosov, Malinovski, Matiuchin… Pushkin referred to him as a "man of taste" but also as a "skilled courtier." A drawing by the poet depicting this professor, whom he greatly admired, still exists. Numerous students left comments on his strong personality and great teaching talent. Modeste Andreyevich Korf, a future count and director of the Imperial Public Library in Saint Petersburg, described him as follows: "This little comic old man, short of stature, with a big belly, a greasy and slightly powdered wig, was the only one among all the teachers who fully understood his vocation; as he had a highly practical mind, he contributed more than anyone else to our education, and not just in the knowledge of the French language." In 1819, Boudry was promoted to the rank of college assessor. He was also a knight of the Russian orders of Saint Anne 2nd class and Saint Vladimir 4th class. The retirement of Marat de Boudry for health reasons and the granting of a pension were considered during the Professors' Conference in October 1821. It was at the end of this same session that his death was announced. The Lyceum and the Pension of Tsarskoye Selo paid him solemn tribute, with students as well as the director of the Lyceum, Engelhardt, participating in the transport of the coffin. David's daughters were entitled to a pension since, on 24 June 1822, Marie de Boudry submitted a request for it to be paid through the French literature professor Fleury, whom David had strongly recommended to replace him at the Pension of Tsarskoye Selo. A similar request was made for Olympiade’s pension, still a minor, by the advisors Miller and Achlobkov, executors of David's will.
Teaching institutions and families: Saltykov, Mirkovich families; Institute of Saint Catherine of Alexandria (from 1803); University Lyceum of Saint Petersburg (gimnaziya) (from 1806); Imperial Lyceum of Tsarskoye Selo (1811–1821).
Students and their social status: Nikolai Goncharov; Fedor Iakovlevich Mirkovich; Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin

David de Boudry was the author of various bilingual works on French grammar, published in Saint Petersburg:

A l’usage de la jeunesse russe avec diverses remarques sur le rapport des deux langues, agréée par le Ministere de l’Instruction publique et adoptée à l’Institut pédagogique, au gymnase du gouvernement de St Pétersbourg et dans d’autres maisons d’éducation par D. de Boudri, Professeur au Lycée impérial et à l’Institut des Dlles nobles de l’ordre de Ste Catherine. Personal records: An obscure figure, unknown to biographical dictionaries; P.M. Maikov mentions Marignan (sometimes referred to as Matignan) in his articles dedicated to the Razumovski family (RBS). Marignan had a fourteen-year-old son in November 1782. In 1819, Marignan's son, who was in a difficult situation in Paris, sought support from Andrey Razumovski.
Career:
Co-author, with Jean-Baptiste-Jude CHARPENTIER, of the first Russian grammar published in French; a military man and tutor. A French officer (referred to as "lieutenant" by August Lüdwig von Schlözer), Marignan was in 1764 the third tutor or "governor" (after Bourbier and de l’Isle) of the eldest sons of Count Kirill Razumovski (Alexey, Piotr, and Andrey) at the "Academy of the 10th Line" on Vasilievsky Island: this is how Schlözer, one of the professors at this institution and our main source of information, refers to the private hotel specifically rented to educate the children of the count and a few other Russian dignitaries. Marignan was provided with food and lodging free of charge, along with an annual salary of 600 rubles (the average equivalent of a professor's salary at the Academy of Sciences in Saint Petersburg!).
Unpublished documents from the Razumovski archives, consulted by A. Vasilchikov, reveal that Marignan left Russia for Strasbourg with his pupils in December 1764 and never returned, while remaining a tutor in the count's family. In 1768, Marignan undertook an educational trip to England with his charges, maintaining good relations with Andrey Razumovski, his favorite pupil, until the end of his life. A few words about Marignan's students: Andrey was a childhood friend of Grand Duke Paul, future Paul I, and the lover of his first wife, who died in childbirth; he later became a diplomat stationed in Vienna, a friend of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, and an extravagant figure. Alexey Kirillovich Razumovski was a famous Freemason and later became the Minister of Public Education.
In May 1770, Marignan was in Paris; he assisted the Vorontsovs in finding a tutor for Illarion Vorontsov, the son of Count Roman Vorontsov, in Strasbourg; Illarion's sister, Princess Ekaterina Dashkova, who was in Strasbourg at the time and dissatisfied with this tutor, obtained from Marignan that Illarion be placed with a tutor from the Razumovski family.
In 1771, Schlözer met him in Göttingen. According to a letter dated 5 June 1782, sent by Count Andrey Razumovski from Naples to Marignan, the latter was then living in France, in Salins, in the Jura.
In 1782–1784, Marignan was responsible for supervising Kirill Razumovski's fifth son, Grigori, in Lausanne. In February 1784, dissatisfied with his gloomy and touchy pupil, Marignan parted ways with him in Lausanne and went to Saxony. After this date, all trace of him is lost.
Teaching institutions and families: Razumovski family; "Academy of the 10th Line" (1760s; Vasilievsky Island, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Sons of Count Kirill Grigorievich Razumovski (Alexey, Piotr, Andrey, Grigori).
Language and other teaching books by the: According to Schlözer, Marignan was quite learned. He had written a manuscript article on the officia palatina of the Merovingians. He is credited with a critical and free manuscript adaptation of Lomonosov's Russian Grammar (1755–1757). His manuscript, which has not survived, served as the basis for the anonymous manual "Les Eléments de la langue russe," published in Saint Petersburg in 1768 by Charpentier, a French teacher in the upper class of the Academy of Sciences school in Saint Petersburg (see the entry on J.-B.-J. CHARPENTIER).

Career: Vice-consul of France in Moscow and tutor. Arriving in Russia in 1753, he was the governor of the children of a Prince Dolgoruki in 1756. He rendered great services to Chevalier Douglas during his mission in Russia in 1756 and caught the attention of French diplomats. In 1759, a vice-consulate of France was opened in Moscow, with Pierre Martin as its first holder. He received, on 1 April 1760, the provisions of vice-consul (without salary or gratuity), authorized by the letters patent of the king dated 25 May 1757, and approved by the Minister of the Navy, Berryer, on 4 August 1760. In the instructions sent to the new vice-consul of France in Saint Petersburg on 1/12 April 1760, signed by the consul general in Saint Petersburg, Decury de Saint-Sauveur, the ministry specified several points (“Instruction pour Le Sr. Pierre Martin Etabli Vice-consul de France à Moscou et dépendances, par patentes du Sr. De Cury de St. Sauveur Consul général de France en Russie en date du premier avril 1760,” in: Vice-consulat de France à Moscou et dépendances. Gestion du Sieur Pierre Martin années 1760, 1761, 1762, 1763, et 13/24 juillet 1764, exclusivement, 168 pages; MAE Nantes, Moscou, consulat, 1*, f° 23-30). This instruction clearly reflects the ministry's view of French emigrants in general and the French in Moscow in particular. In Article 1 of the instruction, attention was drawn to “the position of vice-consul of the French nation”: this “does not aim to establish a consular jurisdiction tending to render or pronounce any judgment between the subjects of the King, both because there are very few French merchants present and due to the difficulties the vice-consul would encounter in exercising jurisdiction over a multitude of French subjects, most of whom are fugitives without acknowledgment or expatriates for whom the king's graces are not made [...]. We therefore confine Mr. Martin's functions to the small number of French known to be good and loyal subjects of the King and of good life and morals, of whatever state and condition they may be, who by their titles deserve to enjoy the protection of His Majesty's Ministers in Foreign Courts.” Aside from the protection of French foreign trade, the only justification for the departure of French subjects abroad, the consular agent was therefore to limit himself to protecting the subjects of the king who had departed properly and to abandon the unacknowledged French, in the absence of a treaty between France and Russia. Pierre Martin was to fulfill the duties of his consular function in administrative, notarial, and judicial matters: “Mr. Martin's functions concerning these latter [loyal French subjects – note] will consist of granting them all the expeditions in the Chancery that they may need, such as certificates of life, legalizations of baptismal and death extracts, and marriage celebration acts, to receive powers of attorney, declarations, deposits, and last wills, to affix seals at the time of death; to appoint trustworthy individuals to guard both the seals and the effects, to lift said seals, to proceed with the inventory of their belongings, all assisted by two credible witnesses. He is also to be informed of all disputes between acknowledged and deserving French subjects, not to render or pronounce any judgment, but to conciliate them and prevent, as much as possible, their differences from being brought before the courts of the country by warning them that whoever proceeds with that will henceforth be deprived of all protection from the King and assistance from his officers.” The comments on this article, probably written by the French consul Decury de Saint-Sauveur, specify that “The highlighted expeditions will likewise be granted to unworthy French subjects, not as a personal grace, but because of the damage that their refusal would cause to their relatives in France, who should not be held responsible for their misconduct. Another area of activity for the vice-consul was that of commerce, or what we would today call industrial espionage: “As for the interests of our trade in general, Mr. Martin will learn as accurately as possible everything related to both importation and exportation. He will also inquire, with prudence and discretion, about all foreign manufactures established in Moscow and its dependencies to inform us of the importance of the objects as well as their state of progress or decline, depending on the perfection or imperfection of the imitation, whether in quality, taste, or design.” This activity of the consulate was traditional (see Henry Lavie). It found its rationale in the same concern for the promotion and protection of French industry and commerce. Russian manufactures were therefore not worthy of the vice-consul's attention, probably because they were not considered serious competitors. It was natural that the vice-consul was also required to pay attention to all economic regulations introduced in Moscow concerning foreigners. The sixth article of the instructions mandated Pierre Martin to compile lists of the French in his jurisdiction: “It would be very good if he could, at his leisure, prepare a general statement of all the French established both in Moscow and in the surrounding areas, noting in as many columns as necessary what he learns about the time of their arrival, their age, their marital status, their children, their talents, trades or positions, and especially their good or bad qualities. However, he should gather this information rather than conduct inquiries with ostentation, as it must remain confidential.” The injunction not to display his activities is perfectly understandable when considering the idea that French diplomats in Saint Petersburg had of expatriate French people. Intimidated by the letters from the French embassy or genuinely aware of the moods that had developed in the Moscow community, the French vice-consul exclaimed in 1760, in a letter regarding the “prejudicial remarks” about the Dauphin of France made by a certain Jean Desessart (translated from Russian): “I ask you to protect me regarding everything I have just communicated to you, as I greatly fear ill-intentioned people” (AVPRI, fond 93, inv. 1, dos. 15, 1760, file on the French resident in the house of a Princess Volkonskoi named Chevalier Desessart who spread prejudicial remarks about his king, f° 2). Martin resigned, unable to continue, in April 1763 and went to Saint Petersburg for this purpose; he did not find Decury de Saint-Sauveur, who had just died, and handed over the papers of the vice-consulate of Moscow on 13/24 July to Laurent Bérenger, chargé d'affaires of the King. Martin was a privileged witness to the formation of the Francophone colony in Moscow; he was well acquainted with a large part of his compatriots in Moscow, which distinguished him from his high-ranking colleagues in Saint Petersburg, perhaps with the exception of the consul general. Consul Martin de Lesseps requested to reinstate him in his service upon his arrival in Russia. The reasons for establishing this consular position were as follows, as Durand de Distroff wrote in 1775 (echoing Lesseps' arguments): “The necessity to protect the French colony in Moscow, to give an authentic and legal form to all its acts, and primarily to ensure the fate of its provisions and successions; the importance of overseeing French commerce and promoting its progress, both for the relations of its colony with the interior of the Russian Empire and for exports via the Baltic and the Black Sea, in the event that the establishments projected by Russia on the latter sea combine with the trade of France; and thirdly, the political utility of establishing French consideration among the Russians.” In June 1776, Martin additionally received a gratuity of 600 £. In 1777, the Marquis de Juigné (Le Clerc, Marquis de Juigné), ambassador of France, requested permission for him to wear the uniform of vice-consul, which would earn him respect. In 1778, the Marquis de Juigné reiterated his requests in favor of the vice-consul of France in Moscow, who, in his opinion, deserved to be commissioned by the king and thus entitled to the uniform, thanks to his zeal and good conduct. This distinction was becoming almost an “indispensable necessity” in the position that Martin occupied in Moscow, as the uniform was “of general use and of great consideration.” It was necessary to maintain this consideration for him so that he could be useful to the French in Moscow, Juigné asserted, and especially “because of the obligation he frequently has to present himself before the local courts” to defend the interests of these French subjects. However, Pierre Martin could not live without the salary provided by Princess Cherkasski, whose children he was raising and with whom he was lodging; he had to leave Moscow several months a year for this reason; however, he was not engaged in commerce (letter from Pierre Martin dated 16 November 1777, MAE, Political Correspondence, Russia, vol. 100 (1777), f° 391). In Paris, the arguments of the Marquis de Juigné regarding the utility of the vice-consulate in Moscow were acknowledged: the French in Moscow often needed to affix seals, conduct inventories of property, etc.; the intervention of Russian officials in these cases was quite costly and resulted in numerous abuses. In addition to successions, the need to enter into marriage contracts, “with respect to which ignorance of French laws would cause the same inconveniences, independently of the abuses that the most unscrupulous would make of this ignorance,” also justified the presence of a vice-consul. The same necessity arose in disputes involving the French among themselves or between the French and the Russians. The vice-consul also contributed to “maintaining good harmony between the two courts through wise conduct.” Considering these reasons, the minister consented to grant Pierre Martin the king's commission on 23 November 1778, but without salary: the vice-consul had actually been receiving an annual pension of 600 £ since 1776; it was reduced to 300 £ in 1781. Martin's situation remained precarious, and he wrote: “It is not possible for me to reconcile the position of vice-consul with that of governor without failing in the duties that I am obliged to fulfill towards the young princes Čircassi [Cherkasski], the former giving me more occupation than ever due to the number of French in Moscow and the variety of matters they present to me.” One should also note his letter dated 1778 in which he addressed the French minister in Russia: “Since circumstances do not allow Your Excellency to fix my status in Moscow by attaching a salary to it, I will no longer insist on this matter and will not fulfill all the duties attached to it with any less zeal and activity. […] I fear only one thing, which is the infirmities that one cannot foresee or prevent when they come upon us; then I would find myself without fortune and without hope of being assisted; but no, My Lord, it is wrong to presume upon your fairness and the goodness of your heart” (letter from Pierre Martin dated 19 October 1778, ANF, AE BI 988, f° 275). For the establishment of this vice-consulate, there were also some hesitations on the part of the Russians, who claimed that Moscow was not a maritime city and that, moreover, the English did not have a vice-consul in this city (which was mainly explained by the minor importance of the English colony in Moscow). Chevalier de Corberon (Bourrée, Chevalier de Corberon), chargé d'affaires of France, was very hostile towards Pierre Martin. He sent a memorandum on 12 October 1779, in which he referred to Martin as a former “uchitel” (governor of children, a despised position in Russia) under Count Golovkin and indicated his questionable morals (his taste for women and his numerous illegitimate children). Corberon thus suspended the sending of the vice-consul's commission to Pierre Martin in 1779. Martin, for his part, wrote letter after letter to the Marquis de Vérac, asking him to send him this commission. “It would be appropriate,” Vérac wrote to the minister, “that a commissioned officer of the King should not be in the position of being at the mercy of a private individual of the nation among whom he resides, and it seems to me that if Mr. de Sartine persists in believing that the good of the service requires a vice-consul in Moscow, it would be advisable to grant him a salary.” However, in 1785, Count de Vergennes was still not convinced of the utility of such a position: “Our trade relations in Moscow do not yet have enough extension for me to propose to His Majesty the expense that would be incurred by establishing a vice-consul in this part of the Russian Empire.” Finally, one of the functions of the vice-consul of France in Moscow was to obtain payment of sums owed by Russian nobles who had stayed in Paris (for example, in 1785 Count Buturlin remained in debt for goods he had received in Paris). Martin also played a role in resolving the conflict that arose in 1784 in Moscow between foreign merchants and their 1,600 Russian colleagues (see Rossius). Pierre Martin was to serve as vice-consul in Moscow until June 1788, after which he returned to France, following several decades of absence. In 1790, he was the mayor of Joppécourt (Meurthe-et-Moselle).
Teaching institutions and families: Dolgoruki, Cherkasski, Golovkin families.
Students and their social status: Children of a Prince Dolgoruki

Personal records:
Originally from Billon (Puy-de-Dôme).
Brother of Catherine Martinet, who resided there.
Career:
Lawyer at the parliament and later a tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg in November 1774. He intended to open a free school in Moscow to “teach the youth Latin, French, as well as geography, mythology, and arithmetic.” He took an examination at the Academy of Sciences to obtain the tutor's certificate. His examiners assessed that he had a perfect command of French, could understand simple Latin, knew the basics of arithmetic, and was very skilled in mythology.
He settled in Moscow with a Prince of Gagarin. He still resided in the VI district of Moscow when he took the oath of 1793. He was a parishioner of the Saint Louis of the French church in Moscow in 1798.
Sources and bibliography:
MAE Nantes, vice-consulat, Moscoг; RNB, Mss, fonds in diff. languages, F-II, 27/1, f° 134, Saint Louis of the French in Moscow, confessions, 1798; SPFA RAN, fonds 3, inv. 9, dos. 262 (1774), f° 26.

Personal records: (1762, Douai, Nord – 1818-03-14, Saint Petersburg). Probably the brother of Hippolyte Masclet. Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Priest. He was called from France in 1790 by the Catholic Archbishop of Mohilev, who sent him a passport dated 23 April 23, 1790. He was placed at the French parish of the Roman Catholic Church in Saint Petersburg, Saint Catherine of Alexandria, in 1791. He occupied three rooms in the buildings belonging to the church and received 300 rubles in annual salary (which did not allow him to live decently) and later 540 rubles. He took the oath of 1793 and was actually tasked with receiving the oath from his compatriots.
In 1800, he was appointed by Emperor Paul I as chaplain of the Order of Malta with a salary of 600 rubles. He signed his writings as follows: “conventual chaplain of the Order of Saint John of Jerusalem; chaplain of the Imperial Institute for Noble Maidens (Smolny); canon of Mohilev; priest of the French.” He held these positions for three months. In October 1800, his parish was taken from him, and he was “almost expelled from the Church,” as he wrote on 9 April 1801, to a count, probably Alexander Romanovich Vorontsov: “and then I took refuge at the Palace of Saint John, where I remained alone for a month, locked up without daring to appear for fear of being sent further away, as I had been threatened. What my crime was, I do not know.” He complained about his disastrous situation, where, in his words, “I was dragged down by the fall of others.” He requested to be reinstated in his positions and returned to his parish. On 10 and 16 April 1801, the oldest syndics of the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine in Saint Petersburg submitted a petition asking the new emperor to “confirm him in his property according to the diploma of Catherine the Great,” and also “to restore in his church those of the former priests,” including Father Masclet, “who has earned the trust of all the parishioners.” This petition was signed, among others, by Jean Grabit, Guillaume Culot, and Louis Rusca. Reinstated in his duties, he remained there until at least 1806. He was living in 1806 in the chapter house, 3rd part Admiralteyskaya in Saint Petersburg, when he took the oath of allegiance to Russia. Later became a bishop.

He may be the author of:

Par Masclet, Saint Petersburg, from the printing house of the Imperial Corps of Noble Cadets, 1793, [5] p. in-4° (parallel text in French and Russian, the Russian translation is by Vasili Nechayev; it could also be attributed to Hyppolite Masclet).

Career: Tutor to the son of general Naryshkin, he was present in Saint Petersburg as early as 1771 (he was a witness at the marriage of Moutendre/Buschman on 1 November 1771, at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg). A Freemason, he was a member of the Apollo Lodge in Saint Petersburg, founded in 1771 (with a predominantly German membership). In 1775, he traveled with his student, the young Frédéric-Ferdinand-Charles de Vietenghoff, to Strasbourg. After returning to Russia in 1779, he became friends with Gilbert Romme. He returned to France in 1782 and visited Strasbourg, Paris, and Lyon, accompanying his new student, Prince Mikhail Petrovich Golitsyn.
Teaching institutions and families: Naryshkin, Vietenghoff, Golitsyn families.
Students and their social status: Son of general Naryshkin; Frédéric-Ferdinand-Charles de Vietenghoff; Prince Mikhail Petrovich Golitsyn.

Personal records: (Known as Masson de Blamont) (1761-01-22, Blamont, Doubs – 1807-06-03, Koblenz, Rhineland-Palatinate; poisoned). Father: Pierre-Nicolas Masson, clerk of the seigneurial court of Blamont. Mother: Marie-Catherine-Emmanuelle Masson (*1736, Clairegoutte, Haute-Saône). Grandparents: Pierre Masson (†Glay, Doubs), fiscal prosecutor of the seigneury of Blamont, and his second wife Judith Louis on one side; and Henri Masson, pastor, and Anne-Catherine Bouthenot on the other side. Older brother: Pierre-Conrad Masson. Married to (in 1795): Baroness Rosen, a Livonian. Daughter: Olga Masson (*1796-09); she met the young Alexander Pushkin, who dedicated verses to her.
Career:
Military officer, tutor, and writer. He is said to have apprenticed in watchmaking in Switzerland, in La Chaux-de-Fonds, before going to Neuchâtel and Basel. There, he became acquainted with a society of men of letters. He composed verses there, some of which were published. These literary beginnings allowed him to find a position as a tutor in a Prussian family, with Count Lehndorf. Around 1786, he joined his older brother, an officer in Russian service, in Russia. He was admitted at the end of 1786 to the Noble Cadet Corps of Artillery and Engineering, certainly thanks to the protection of the Corps director P. I. Melissino (whose niece was married to his older brother); he was appointed a non-commissioned officer of the guard in 1787 and a lieutenant in the same Cadet Corps in 1788. Masson taught geography and published in 1789 a Cours mémorial de géographie, which was used in studies. In 1788, during a visit by Grand Dukes Alexander and Constantine to the Corps, he signed a panegyric that was published and seems to announce the forthcoming evolution of his career:
  • Торжество на прибытие их императорских высочеств государей великих князей Александра Павловича и Константина Павловича при Артиллерийском и инженерном шляхетном кадетском корпусе 4 августа 1788 г. Творение г. Массона де Бламон, перевод г. Шимовского. СПб., печ. в Имп. тип., 1788, text in Russian and French).
Indeed, in 1789 he was recommended by Melissino to Count Nikolai Ivanovich Saltykov (1736–1816), president of the War Collegium and educator of the grand dukes, and subsequently became his secretary for foreign correspondence and tutor to his sons. Appointed captain of dragoons in 1789 and then aide-de-camp to Saltykov, he quickly attained the rank of major in one of the guard regiments and was entrusted with a mission to Bayreuth, Stuttgart, and Karlsruhe to announce in the German courts the birth of Grand Duchess Anna Pavlovna, granddaughter of Catherine II. In 1790, he participated in the war against the Ottoman Porte and witnessed the capture of Ismail. He spent eight years in the family of Count Saltykov and resided during this time in the imperial palace. Saltykov's support earned him the position of mathematics teacher for the grand dukes, alongside general Protasov and Baron Osten-Sacken, who took care of the rest of their education. He even reportedly prepared annual reports on the grand dukes' progress in their studies to submit to the empress. It was during this time that Masson was appointed secretary to the commands of Grand Duke Alexander Pavlovich, the future emperor, and registered in the Ekaterinoslavl grenadier regiment. He lost the favor he enjoyed at the time of Paul I's ascension. His republican ideas and commitment to republican France, on one hand, and the favor shown to him by Saltykov, on the other, led to his expulsion along with his brother in December 1796. His wife and daughter could not follow him and remained in Russia. Initially engaged as an officer in the French regiments stationed in the Helvetic Republic, Masson de Blamont did not return to France until 1799 (or 1800). He ended his career and life as the secretary general of the Rhin-et-Moselle prefecture. He was an associate member of the Institute of France.
Teaching institutions and families: Noble Cadet Corps of Artillery and Engineering (from 1786; Saint Petersburg); Saltykov family.
Students and their social status: Sons of Count Nikolai Ivanovich Saltykov (1736–1816), president of the War Collegium; young Count Lehndorf; Grand Dukes Alexander Pavlovich and Constantine Pavlovich.
Language and other teaching books by the:
In 1789, Masson published:
  • Cours mémorial de géographie, ou Méthode facile et agréable de faire l’inspection des Cartes, en formant le goût des jeunes gens: A l’usage du Corps Impérial des Cadets Nobles, A St. Petersbourg, de l’Imprimerie du Corps, 1789, [12], 48 p. in-8° (3rd ed., 1st ed. in Berlin, 1787; 2nd ed. in Switzerland, according to the preface), which was used in studies. The preface is written by Cuinet d’Orbeil, who reveals the author's name: he cites the review of this work in the Gazette Littéraire de Berlin from 9 April 1787. The author of this review explains that Mr. Masson de Blamont composed his Cours mémorial in verse to facilitate the study of geography for the young Count Lehndorf, of whom he was the governor. In the warning, the author explains the origin and use of his course.
He translated the poem by Stepan Stepanovich Djunkovski (1762–1839):
  • Alexandrovo ou Les Jardins de Son Altesse Impériale monseigneur le grand duc Alexandre Pauloide: Poème dédié à Sa Majesté Impériale Catherine Seconde impératrice et autocratrice de toutes les Russie. Translated from Russian, [Saint-Petersbourg, De l’Imprimerie de l’Académie Impériale des sciences], 1793 (reissued in 1794), [4], 15 p. in-4°. This poem was dedicated to the gardens designed according to the wishes and indications of the empress between Tsarskoye Selo and Pavlovsk, based on an allegory composed by Catherine II, the tale of the Tsarevich of Chlor, 1782. As E. Liamina writes, Masson "had a penchant for detailed metaphorical comparisons, elaborate poetic images, sometimes lacking taste and clarity."
The Massons harbored strong resentment towards those Russian dignitaries who had long favored them but did not dare to speak up for them at the time of their expulsion. It was in 1797 that Masson de Blamont first expressed his grievances to the public in the journal Minerve (Ernstliche Aufforderung und Bitte, an die, in russischen Diensten gestandenen Herren von Masson). His name became famous after the publication in 1800 of:
  • Mémoires secrets sur la Russie, et particulièrement sur la fin du règne de Catherine II et sur celui de Paul Ier (Paris, Pougens, vol. 1-2, 1800; vol. 3, 1802). This was followed by translations into German (Geheime Nachrichten über Russland, two translations published in Paris), into English (Secret memoirs of the court of Saint-Petersburg, London, three editions), into Danish, with reprints (Amsterdam, Paris, etc.)
This very controversial work was bound to provoke strong reactions. Indeed, in his preface, Masson de Blamont announced that his aim was “to present to the public remarks and anecdotes that are more interesting about a country and a nation that deserve to be well known and are worthy of a better government. […] I claim to write useful memoirs, not a satire or a panegyric.” The Mémoires secrets, which resembled a pamphlet, made major Masson famous, partly compensating for the “terrible personal disillusionment in a particularly vindictive character” (Corbet) that the expulsion from Russia and the abrupt end of his brilliant career represented for him. The Mémoires were banned from publication in Russia for a long time. The Russian envoy in Berlin sent the book to Saint Petersburg, which tried to take measures to limit the damage. In 1802, the German poet August von Kotzebue published L’année la plus remarquable de ma vie; suivie d’une Réfutation des Mémoires secrets sur la Russie, Paris, Buisson-Bertrand-Levrault-Mongie, 1802. This fifty-page writing was very critical: “This work has made much more noise than it deserved,” wrote Kotzebue. “It was believed, and perhaps still is, that its author drew all the accounts he gives, all the facts he presents, from well-authenticated sources; that is what is important to refute. […] Mr. M… has spread his venom” and “has this art of reporting gossip with an important air.” According to Kotzebue, his entire work was nothing but a “bold edifice of lies and treachery.” In 1802, a few months after the Réfutation, an Examen de trois ouvrages sur la Russie, Voyage de M. Chantreau, Révolution de 1762, Mémoires secrets, par l’Auteur du Voyage de deux Français au nord de l’Europe (Fortia de Piles), was published. This rather short work devoted several dozen pages to the critique of the works mentioned in the title, without animosity or insults, always in a measured tone and with as much objectivity as possible. Still in 1802, “C. F. Ph. Masson, formerly major in the Russian service, and secretary to the commands of Grand Duke Alexander Pavlovich,” published his response to Kotzebue, titled:
  • Lettres d’un Français à un Allemand, servant de réponse à Mr. De Kotzebue, et de supplément aux mémoires secrets sur la Russie (a preface and twenty-two letters, Koblenz, 1802). Major Masson refuted Kotzebue's allegations according to a precise plan: the origins and history of Kotzebue in Russia, his own experience in the Russian Empire, and finally his judgment on Russia, reaffirming his Mémoires secrets.
Masson also responded to Fortia de Piles in:
  • Un mot à l’auteur de l’Examen de trois ouvrages sur la Russie.
Masson de Blamont is also the author of:
  • Торжество на прибытие их императорских высочеств государей великих князей Александра Павловича и Константина Павловича при Артиллерийском и инженерном шляхетном кадетском корпусе 4 августа 1788 г. Творение г. Массона де Бламон, перевод г. Шимовского. СПб., печ. в Имп. тип., 1788, text in Russian and French).
  • La Nouvelle Astrée, ou les Aventures romantiques du temps passé, traditions publiées par Ch.-Fr.-Ph. Masson, Montbéliard, printed by P. Hoffmann, 1893, in-16, 158 p.; reissued in October 1987, éditions Cêtre, Besançon;
  • Les Helvétiens, en huit chants, avec des notes historiques, par Charles-François-Philibert Masson, Paris, C. Pougens, year VIII, in-8°, XXXII-315 p. (a poem about the war between the Swiss and Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy).

Masson.
Bouteiller; Corbet, pp. 47-50; Grève, pp. 1258-1259; Michaud, vol. XXVII, p. 428 and following; Liechtenhan, 1993, p. 38-41; Liamina; Martin, p. 112-113; Riabinin; RBS, 1999, vol. Maak-Miatleva, p. 117-118 (notice by O. Kornolovich); Somov, 1986-I; Thiébaud, 2002, p. 253-254.

Personal records: Originally from Strasbourg. Married to: Anne-Catherine N. Son: Jean Masson (*Saint Petersburg, bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 18 July 1769).
Education: University of Strasbourg.
Career:
Professor and head of an educational boarding school in Petersburg. Promoted from the University of Strasbourg, he arrived in Russia at the age of twenty-six. He served as a tutor in various families during the first ten years of his life in Russia. He was admitted in 1776 to the Cadet Corps of Artillery and Engineering in Saint Petersburg as a French teacher for the senior class.
In 1777, he opened an educational boarding school in the Liteynaya part of the city (which was certainly his second boarding school, the first having been opened around 1775). The boarding school specialized in military arts and was therefore reserved for boys. There were twenty-six students, aged 9 to 18, mostly sons of officers. Subjects taught included French, German, Russian, history, geography, mathematics, drawing, dance, fencing, and music. Four of his students attended the Artillery Corps to study artillery and fortification. Masson taught two hours of classes four days a week, after lunch: he taught French, Russian, geography, and history. There were six other teachers, including two Frenchmen: François Lamet, a septuagenarian who had been in Russia for twelve years, teaching French, German, and sacred history, and Girarol, a dance teacher.
In 1780, the Academy of Sciences commission examined this boarding school alongside others. The commission's opinion was not favorable: Masson himself did not have much time to devote to his boarding school, although he was proficient in the languages he taught, while the teachers in his employ “did not demonstrate much knowledge or ability.”
The boarding school still existed in 1784 when it was examined again, now by the Commission for the Establishment of Public Schools. It now had thirty-four students, still all boys.
Masson hired mathematics teachers who taught at the Cadet Corps, Alexei Argoun and Ivan Efimov, who used Russian textbooks. Russian was taught by the Frenchman Guilert, who also taught in many other boarding schools and was proficient in the language with much experience. On the other hand, German was taught very poorly, as the teachers themselves did not have a good command of the language.
The other teachers working at this boarding school included: Gottfried Semeer (?), from Hamburg, who had been engaged at this boarding school for seven years but did not have a certificate from the Academy of Sciences; Philippe Gomel (?), from Hanover, formerly a copyist, without certification; Karl Rasse (?), a clerk from Prussia, also without certification.
Jean Masson was said to be a full advisor when he took the oath in 1793 in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching institutions and families: Educational boarding schools (1770s – 1780s), Cadet Corps of Artillery and Engineering (from 1776), all in Saint Petersburg.
Teaching methods and materials: Masson was unable to explain to the commission of 1784 what method he used to teach history; he began with Hübner's history and also made extensive use of the works of Abbé Lenglet du Fresnois (certainly referring to his frequently reprinted “methods” in the 18th century: Principes de l'histoire pour l'éducation de la jeunesse par années et par leçons. Première (-sixième) année, Paris: Debure l'aîné, 1736-1739, 6 vol.; Méthode pour étudier l'histoire..., Nouvelle édition…, Paris: P. Gandouin, 1729-1741, 6 vol., of which 2 are supplements; Méthode pour étudier la géographie... Quatrième édition revue, corrigée et augmentée, Paris: N.-M. Tilliard, 1768, 10 vol. in-12°.) The commission noted that his teaching was practically limited to the names of sovereigns, but nothing was learned about the reasons for a state's power, its internal and external situation, or the customs of its peoples... The teaching of geography was also very rudimentary: students were made to memorize the names of countries, rivers, and cities, but everything related to commerce, the crafts developed there, the natural wealth of these regions, etc., was overlooked. The globe was not used. There was no properly developed course in either geography or history. Masson taught French grammar only to those of his students who already knew how to read and write in French; afterward, he had them do translations and “showed them the style.” He was assisted by a tutor to teach reading and writing in French. In French classes, the teaching was of good quality, but style was not really taught, and conversation was emphasized more. There was no division into classes based on age and student level.

Personal records: (Wife of Pierre-Ignace Jaunez, known as James) (*1762). Father: Basile-Benoît Mathis. Mother: Marie-Jeanne Guibal. Married to: Pierre-Ignace Jaunez, known as James, a lawyer at the parliament of Metz, residing with Prince Alexei Razumovski, the adult son of Pierre Jaunez (†before 1784), contractor for the King's buildings in Metz, and Jeanne Hollard (marriage contract at the vice-consulate of Moscow on 10 November 1784; witnesses: Bernard Laurens, surgeon attached to Count Alexei Razumovski, and Aurelien Drago). Her dowry was 6,000 £ (1,500 rubles, including 1,000 rubles in cash and 500 rubles on credit) and 500 rubles worth of furniture and belongings.
Career:
Governess. She was living with a lady named Apraxina, on Nikitskaya Street in Moscow, at the time of her marriage and was the godmother of Nicolas-Louis Richelle on 16 November 1784, at Saints Apostles Peter and Paul. She later became the governess of the daughter of a Princess Shakhovskaya.
Her husband described her in 1784 as a twenty-two-year-old woman with an excellent character and a sensitive soul. Everyone spoke well of her. The Jaunez-James family approved of this marriage, but Count Alexei Razumovski, with whom Jaunez was working at that time, declared that his marriage was incompatible with his responsibilities as a tutor (Count Alexei Razumovski nevertheless attended the wedding). She left Russia in April or May 1785 with her husband. She returned to Moscow around 1790 and left the city with Henri Weyer, her brother-in-law, and little Nicolas Richelle, her godson. She was in Saint Petersburg, single, in the spring of 1793 when she took the oath of loyalty to the crown of France.
Teaching institutions and families: Shakhovskoy family.
Students and their social status: Daughter of a Princess Shakhovskaya.
Language and other teaching books by the: She was the author of: Les Délassemens d'une mère, ou Recueil de nouveaux contes à la porte de l'enfance, par Mme Jaunez-Sponville, Paris, F.-M. Maurice, 1824, in-12, 215 p., illustrated.

Personal records:
Originally from Artois.
Likely the brother of Étienne-Joseph Mathon.
Career:
Tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg as early as 1773 and requested to take the examination at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg in September to obtain the tutor's certificate. The examiner found that he was well-prepared in Latin, French, and geography.
He was the godfather of Jean-Louis Péraudin at the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria on 12 June 1776.

Personal records:
Originally from Artois.
Son of a merchant.
Likely the brother of Jean-Baptiste Mathon.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, Latin, geography, history, arithmetic, geometry, algebra.
Career: Tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg in December 1774 and was staying with the innkeeper Ninant, behind the Stock Exchange. Since he had studied before coming to Russia, he requested to take the examination at the Academy of Sciences to obtain a tutor's certificate. According to his examiners, he had a good command of geography, history, arithmetic, geometry, Latin, French, and algebra. The Academy authorized him to teach not only beginners but also advanced students.
Sources and bibliography: SPFA RAN, fonds 3, inv. 9, dos. 262 (1774), f° 22.

Personal records: Originally from Paris. Married to: Christina-Eva Bischoff. Daughter: Jeanne-Marie-Ève Maubourguet (*Moscow, bapt. at Saints Apostles Peter and Paul on 17 December 1782; godfather: Claude Grené; godmother: Jeanne-Marie Maubourguet).
Career:
Tutor. He presented himself at Moscow University and obtained a tutor's certificate on 19 August 1769. He received permission to teach French, history, geography, and physics.
He was the godfather of Marie Martin on 26 June 1788, at Saints Apostles Peter and Paul.
