Personal records:
(*1740, Mirecourt, Vosges – † likely after 1808). Single in 1806. He had two sons in 1792:
  • Piotr (or Pierre) Maudru du Bocage (*1786);
  • Paul Maudru du Bocage (*1792).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, literature; professor of linguistics (professor slovesnykh nauk).
Career: Lawyer, linguist, and educator. He was a professor of French language and literature at the Noble Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg, having settled in Saint Petersburg as early as 1771, where he reportedly published, at the expense of the Corps, a manual titled Lettre à madame la duchesse de *** (location not specified) which presented "the outline of the author's Reading System, applicable to all languages" (this was certainly the same work that was later reissued in France). In May 1774, the secretary of the Conference of the Academy of Sciences of Russia, Johann Albrecht Euler, wrote to Samuel Formey, a Berlin academician of Huguenot origin, that a true "French Academy" was meeting at his place, mainly consisting of governors and professors from the Cadet Corps, among others Charles-Pierre Levesque and Jean-Baptiste Maudru. In 1775, he held a private educational school in Saint Petersburg, with or without boarding; boarding cost between 150 and 300 rubles per year, while external students paid 100 rubles. In 1786, to regularize his situation, he wanted to be registered in the city's residents' registry and requested to be recorded in the section of "honorary citizens" of the city. On this occasion, he presented a certificate from the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg dated 15 January 1786, signed by Euler, which recognized him as a scholar after reviewing his works. However, since this certificate was not sufficient, he was ultimately registered as a "foreign guest" in the merchant class (5th part of the city's residents' registry). His departure from Russia was forced. He reportedly sent a letter to the governor of Saint Petersburg in 1789 with these words: "... I long for the happy moment when I can see my homeland again, to see it and dedicate what remains of my life to it"; and in 1790, to the governor general, a memorandum with these words: "... it is since that time that in the name of the French, which I bear, I have added the titles of Iménite [notable citizen] and professor. I am ready to relinquish these titles whenever desired, and to shed the last drop of my blood for the first." He explained the circumstances of his departure in the autobiographical pamphlet Les Pourquoi: "In 1791, out of hatred for his civic duty, he lost in Russia everything he possessed. Detained for sixteen months in chains and sentenced three times to the scaffold, he saw himself stripped of a fortune of more than one hundred thousand écus, the fruit of eighteen years of work, after enduring the most barbaric treatment; and expelled from the country without being given a penny to return to France." He would therefore have returned to France around 1792, leaving his sons Piotr (or Pierre) Maudru and Paul Maudru du Bocage. In France, Maudru’s career did not advance. Serving as the secretary-clerk of the constitutional committee, he translated four works from English: one by Barlow, one by Smith, one by Williams, and one anonymous. He then moved on to the commission responsible for analyzing projects related to the constitution, and was later called to the Committee of Public Safety as head of the external relations division, and then entered "the general war depot, to head one of the two subdivisions that make up this depot, that of the archives." However, he was progressively sidelined and remained without work. At that time, he was reduced to poverty and offered to members of the legislative body to copy their documents because, he said, "I have very legible handwriting." He was then living in Paris, "on Rue du Bacq, opposite the former Convalescens, no. 554, on the 2nd floor on the street." He was a professor at the École Normale de la Seine until 1802 and was accepted as a member of the Academic Society of Sciences of Paris, the Free Society of Instruction, and the Galvanic Society. In 1802, he published in Paris his major work, Les Eléments raisonnés de la langue russe, in 2 volumes. He described his work as a "masterpiece of patience, zeal, and courage." He stayed a second time in Russia after 1803. In 1806, he lived in the 4th section of Admiralteyskaya in Saint Petersburg, in Paul’s house at no. 918, when he took the oath of allegiance to Russia required by the authorities; he was said to be a professor of linguistics (professor slovesnykh nauk). He taught French in Moscow and was preparing in 1807 to open an educational boarding school there with Charles d’Aviat de Vatay, a professor at Moscow University. The "Prospectus" for this establishment was published in 1807 (Moskovskie Vedomosti, 1807, no. 24, 27, pp. 551, 625; supplements in no. 47).
Teaching institutions and families: Land Noble Cadet Corps; his own private educational school (1775), all in Saint Petersburg; later taught in Moscow
Teaching methods and materials: In 1796, shortly after the election of his former colleague Levesque to the Institute of France (1795), Maudru presented his reading method to this assembly. Maudru spoke of his method as a propaganda tool in service of the Revolution. It is hard to imagine that Levesque did not lend his support in this circumstance; it is even very likely that the historian, a long-time friend of Maudru, organized this presentation and perhaps facilitated the publication of Maudru's work titled A ses concitoyens membres de l'Institut national. In an appendix to this work, Maudru quotes in full the letter from his other colleague, Nicolas-Gabriel Le Clerc, physician to Grand Duke Paul and director of studies at the Cadet Corps, which attests that the most delayed cadets were successfully learning to read in French thanks to this system.

Personal records: (also known as Desessarts) (*ar. 1730, Clermont-Ferrand, or Rouen). Family originally from Auvergne. Coat of arms: Azure with a gold fess, accompanied at the top by three silver stars and at the bottom by a chevron of the same. According to his own words, born around 1730 in Clermont-Ferrand in Auvergne or, according to another version also from him, called Louis-Gilles, chevalier and seigneur des Essarts-Pain "from the city of Rouen in Normandy and Licentiate in civil and canon law from the University of Caen in the same province of Normandy". Father: Joseph Maugue, a tax collector. Mother: Anne Roi. He chose as a pseudonym the name of an estate belonging to his father. Married to: 1.) a Catholic from Lyon († before 1777); 2.) Lucrèce N. (*Lyon), from 1793. Father of a child in 1761, widower still having a child to care for in 1777. Religion: Catholic.
Career: Adventurer, writer, and tutor. Jean Desessarts initially served as a volunteer in France in the Montmorin infantry regiments and the Royal Dragoons, which he left several times because his family intended him for the ecclesiastical state. In 1753, he deserted and left France without a passport. He stayed between 1753 and 1757 in Italy, England, Holland, and Germany. In England, where he stayed the longest, he claimed to have been the secretary and translator for the French ambassador, Charles-Pierre-Gaston-François de Lévis, Duke of Mirepoix, and later a tutor. Arriving in Russia no later than 1757 with a passport issued to him by Sergei Vasilievich Saltykov, envoy of Russia to Hamburg and former lover of Grand Duchess Catherine, the future Catherine II, he took an examination at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg to obtain a certificate of competence. In August 1757, he sent a letter to the Academy in which he expressed himself in an elaborate style: "[...] and shows you that he came to this city with the intention of dedicating himself to the instruction of the French language with some young student of distinguished birth, of whom he flatters himself to be able to form the heart to virtue by adorning the mind with some of that useful knowledge that characterizes the honest man, the amiable man, and the good citizen. This undertaking (one must admit) presents many difficulties in its execution and requires much knowledge on the part of those who are destined for this important function; thus, the petitioner, who knows how to do himself justice, is far from presenting himself as a master in this art; what good will it do him to make a vain display of his talents? Since, in accordance with the orders of Her Imperial Majesty, dictated by her love for her subjects and by the interest she takes in their education, he is obliged to provide, so to speak, a public proof of it by undergoing examinations prescribed and accustomed in front of renowned academicians whose enlightenment, science, and insight cannot be deceived." The examiners found that he mastered French and Latin perfectly and could teach them. Desessarts engaged as a tutor for Kirill Grigorievich Razumovski, hetman of Little Russia and President of the Academy of Sciences. He was the tutor for the hetman's sons in his estate in Glukhov in Ukraine for a year, alongside the physician Nicolas-Gabriel Clerc (later known as Le Clerc, historian of Russia); he left Glukhov almost simultaneously with the physician. He went to Moscow in 1760. His arrival was very noticeable. In November of the same year, a Frenchman in Moscow wrote a letter to a French diplomat in Saint Petersburg, in which he reported that Desessart had made trips to England, that he "had embraced the errors of Calvin" in Holland, that he had made imprudent remarks to the Marquis d’Avraimont in Sweden, and finally that in Moscow, the said Desessart spoke of the king and the dolphin with little respect. The grand chancellor of the Empire himself took an interest in this matter, and attempts were made to gather information about the individual. In 1761, Desessart passed another qualification exam in Moscow and obtained a second certificate to teach French and "several other sciences." He became a tutor in various families, notably with Prince Nikolai Sergeyevich Dolgorukov and brigadier Ivan Mikhailovich Ignatiev. Desessart entered into a contract with Ignatiev under which he was housed and accommodated by his employer, received 220 rubles per year, had a servant at his disposal, could use a sled or carriage, and was permitted to have students outside the lord's house. He was prepared to teach Ignatiev's sons French, spelling, conversation, letter writing, geography, and sacred history. Shortly thereafter, he had a dispute with his employer. This quarrel illustrates the gap that existed between the ideas of the governor and those of his employer regarding the rights and responsibilities of both parties. Desessart, contesting certain orders from Ignatiev, decided to leave his employer's house, but in vain, as he was seized by the brigadier's men and forcibly returned to the house. The tutor declared himself outraged and made complaints to the police. Ignatiev's actions were inconceivable to him; moreover, he refused to believe that the offender would go unpunished. For each adversary, the maneuvers of the other remained incomprehensible and scandalous. It is probably during his service with the Razumovski that Desessart's presumed acquaintance with Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov, the favorite of the Empress and a key figure in the field of education in Russia, dates back. A dedication made by Desessart in his unpublished work Voïageur Moscovite ou Lettres Russes: ouvrage Histori-Politi-critique Traduit du Russe Par M.M. chev. Des Essart (RNB, Mss, Fr. Q.XV.38, 95 f°) allows for the assumption of this relationship. In it, he praised Shuvalov's merits (in the original spelling): "No one is unaware, My Lord, that you alone have placed literature at the level it currently enjoys in Russia. No scholar or lover of letters feels that he does not owe you what he is. It is through you that the arts are protected, talents encouraged. This University of Moscow, this Academy of St. Petersburg are your work. You continually strive to make both flourish. Soon, through your care, they will be seen as not yielding in any way to other assemblies of scholars in Europe. I do not speak of the important affairs with which you are daily occupied. [...] I therefore confine myself, My Lord, to giving you, along with all those who love literature, the title of Protector of the Sciences." This work was undoubtedly written, if not on commission, at least with Shuvalov's approval. Indeed, its content responds to the propaganda efforts that Shuvalov deployed to improve Russia's image on the international stage. It addressed Russia's role in the Seven Years' War, the progress of the Enlightenment in Russia, and the credit due to Peter the Great. Desessart defended the tsar's work, attributing to a Russian traveling in France the following remarks: "We owe to ourselves the state so different from what it once was that we enjoy today. I say to ourselves, and indeed; no one is unaware that civilized, enlightened Russia is the result of Peter the Great's own work. He alone knew how to untangle the chaos of his immense empire." The author used a well-known image to emphasize Peter's role: "He who from an ignorant, corrupt people has made a hardworking, virtuous, literate, polite people, like a skilled sculptor who takes a block of marble and undertakes to create a statue." Anticipating the criticisms that, following Rousseau, accused the artificial and "borrowed" nature of the reforms undertaken by Peter, Desessart wrote: “Will one object to me, to refute what I have stated, that he sought enlightenment abroad, that he went to educate himself outside, that the nation is nonetheless indebted to foreigners, albeit indirectly, for what it is today? And it is this very objection, magnificent as it is, that fills our nation with glory. Yes, Peter I went to educate himself abroad; he humbled himself to the status of a simple craftsman, he worked as such, and he reserved from his title of Emperor only the intention of making the peoples happy. What monarch has been able to achieve greatness through such a path?” Desessart also expressed his views on subjects that were dear to him, such as the condition of French tutors in Russia. “Here, for example, a man without resources becomes an uchitel (a tutor); one is even surprised when one sees a servant who knows four words in a row not embracing this state.” He also confirmed the legends about adventurous Frenchmen who displayed false titles to be better received and better paid in Russian society and who “wander from house to house with their infamy and their poverty.” This work remained unpublished, and one can understand the reasons. On one hand, with the accession to the throne of Catherine II, Shuvalov fell into disgrace, distanced himself from the court, and emigrated from Russia; on the other hand, being “madly” Francophile, he would not have appreciated the attacks against the French that Desessart had made. Indeed, Desessart did not spare his compatriots: “Happy inhabitants of a frozen Empire,” he addressed the Russians. “One does not see among you this eagerness, this fire to declare yourselves friends”; or again: “Your cold indifference is a thousand times preferable to those outbursts, those flashes that inevitably announce slander, misplaced irony, the most cruel calumny,” and “This chaos of the most dreadful crimes, common to all nations, seems to have become the particular appanage of one that is considered today to be the most civilized.” With an enterprising spirit, Desessart partnered in 1766 with the manufacturer Joseph Vandier, to whom the government had refused a subsidy; Desessart attempted in vain to obtain a loan of 12,000 rubles to establish a silk factory near Astrakhan and produce silk fabrics “as beautiful as those from Lyon.” He certainly remained in Moscow for many years, as he is found there as a member of the church council of Saint Louis at the beginning of the 1790s. He was living in Moscow in 1793 when he, along with other French residents in Russia, took an oath of loyalty to the king of France; he was still there in 1798.

Personal records: (or Mayr, Mayer) (1765-12-07, Germany – 1841-03-14, Linz, Austria). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Johann Meyer arrived in Russia and entered the Society of Jesus in August 1787. Then he studied at the novitiate (1787–1789), in the philosophy (1789–1790) and theology (1794–1798) classes at Polatsk Jesuit College.
Career:
Priest. In 1790–1793, Johann Meyer taught Latin and German at the Vitsebsk Jesuit College. In 1793–1794, at the Mahilyow Jesuit College, he was also a boarding school Prefect. At the same time he taught Latin and German, and in 1802–1803, he taught French. While studying in the theology class at the Polatsk Jesuit College, Meyer also taught German (1794–1797). In Mstsislaw, in 1798–1799, he worked as an instructor for priests of the Society of Jesus, and in 1801–1802, he was the Prefect of the congregation for education. He performed the same functions in Vitsebsk in 1799–1800. In 1800–1801, Meyer worked as the Rector of the house of the tertianship in Dünaburg (now Daugavpils). In 1803, he was sent to the mission of the Order in Saratov. From 1803 to 1807, he was the Rector in the village of Semionovka, from 1807 to 1809 – in Paninsk, and from 1809 to 1820, he worked as the Rector of the mission in Saratov.
After the dissolution of the Society of Jesus in Russia, Johann Meyer left for Galicia, where between 1820 and 1824 he was the head of the mission of the Order in Lemberg (Lviv), and then in 1824–1829, he was a novice vice-magister at the College in the town of Stara Wieś. In 1829–1830, he was the head of the house of the novitiate and first studies in Gleisdorf (Austria). After the Jesuit houses’ moving from Gleisdorf to Graz, Meyer was the spiritual Prefect of the College in 1831–1833. He finished his career in Linz, where from 1833 to 1841 he served as spiritual rector at the local College.
Teaching institutions and families: Vitsebsk Jesuit College (1790–1793); Mahilyow Jesuit College (1793–1794; 1802–1803); Polatsk Jesuit College (1794–1797).

Personal records: (or Odrovonzh-Migalevich/Odrowąż-Migałewicz) (1712, the town of Medzhybizh, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – 1744-04-02, Novgorod, Russian Empire). Son of a nobleman (szlachta). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Innokenty Migalevich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Career: In 1737–1739, he taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; in the 1739–1740 academic year, he was a grammar class teacher (with the rank of hieromonk). Innokenty Migalevich was summoned from Kyiv to the Novgorod Seminary as a teacher “skilled in Latin literature.” In 1741–1743, he taught poetics and rhetoric and was appointed prefect at the Novgorod Seminary. From 10 July 1743 until his death, he served as archimandrite at the Antoniev Monastery in Novgorod.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1737–1740); Novgorod Seminary (1741–1743).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen persons studied in the grammar classes which Innokenty Migalevich taught at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. For example, in 1738, there were 64 students in the infima class taught by Innokenty Migalevich; in December 1740, there were 61 students in the grammar class.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Innokenty Migalevich, students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis, they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. The surviving school exercises performed at school and at home show that the students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek) which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (*1773, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1785 to 1797, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theology class.
Career: All we know about Yakov Mikhailovsky is that he became a syntax class teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium immediately after graduation in 1797. In 1800, he was no longer on the list of teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1797–1799).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In 1797–1799, 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1797, there were 64 students in the syntax class taught by Yakov Mikhailovsky. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So, in 1797 there were eight “secular” students among the 64 students of the syntax class which Yakov Mikhailovsky taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Yakov Mikhailovsky, students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Yakov Mikhailovsky worked at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Latin grammar and syntax classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. This is confirmed by the surviving report by Yakov Mikhailovsky on the teaching of syntax in 1799. School exercises performed by the Collegium students of the 1790s show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Quite often students translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated (students left information about it in their memoirs). The books were available in large numbers at the library of the Kharkiv CollegiumThe library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. As evidenced by writings of the Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records:
(*Burgundy, probably Selongey, Côte-d'Or). Married to (in 1792): Frederica Wickmann, a Catholic Swede. Children:
  • Armand-Jean de Morancourt (†1793-01-10, Saint Petersburg; at the age of six weeks, buried in the 11th cemetery on Vasilievsky Island, “according to the report of the father”);
  • Nicolas de Morancourt (*1795-02-04, Moscow, bapt. at Saints Apostles Peter and Paul on 6 February 1795; godfather: Joannes Rosrecht; godmother: Anne-Catherine Richiger);
  • Albertine de Morancourt (†1798-08-05, Saint Petersburg; died “of convulsions” at the age of one, and buried on 6 August in the cemetery on Vasilievsky Island).
Career:
Tutor. Didier de Morancourt de Selongey went to Russia in 1790 to teach French. He lived for three months in Saint Petersburg near the Krasny Bridge, at the home of the French designer Villiers. He had the opportunity to meet general Kutuzov, through whom he was engaged, with a very modest salary, at the Cadet Corps of the Navy; he taught French there for more than two years. He was dismissed from his position on 29 February 1792, due to the poor results of his students. He received a certificate from the Cadet Corps of the Navy, which he was stripped of by the government administration at the time of the oath of 1793, “an oath against the atrocities of the rebels in France,” as he stated. He taught in many homes “with tickets” (certainly coming to give lessons in different houses). The Morancourt family lived at that time on Malaya Meshchanskaya Street in Moscow, at the merchant Sizov's house.
In March 1794, Morancourt left with his wife for the Pskov government and district, in the village of Nikolay Semenovich Alekseyev, and taught the two sons of this man for five or six months until Alekseyev's death. Since it was impossible for him to stay in this village, Morancourt went to Pskov, then to Smolensk, but found no work anywhere. The Morancourts returned to Moscow in January 1795. He saw an advertisement for an apartment rental posted on Gorokhovoye Field and rented rooms from the German tailor Plerik (?), from where he moved three months later to the house of the French church of Saint Louis, in the very center of Moscow. He met Varennes des Carrières at the church, and they sympathized over their shared destitution. When Varennes des Carrières suggested he fabricate two letters attributed to a Frenchman serving in the revolutionary army and deliver them to his wife in Saratov, Morancourt accepted, probably hoping to make money from this venture. However, the deception was discovered by the police, and the two Frenchmen found themselves in the dungeons of Moscow: the Empress ordered them expelled from the Empire. Morancourt was sent to Swedish Finland with his wife and their ten-month-old child. From there, he sent his wife a letter addressed to general Izmailov dated 2 February 1796 (we preserve the spelling of the original): “I very much doubt that if His Majesty as well as His Excellency had been informed of this matter, I would not have been placed at the borders for such a fault, knowing that the Incomparable, The Gracious, The Immortal sovereign of all Russia, who has always protected foreigners in her Great Empire.” He was residing in Saint Petersburg in 1798.
Teaching institutions and families: Cadet Corps of the Navy (early 1790s, Saint Petersburg); Alekseyev family
Students and their social status: Sons of Nikolay Semenovich Alekseyev

Personal records: (1777-03-05 – 1845-08-12, Stara Wieś, Austrian Empire). Religion: Catholic.
Education: After joining the Society of Jesus and a two-year period at the Polatsk novitiate, Józef Morełowski studied French at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium during the 1792–1793 academic year, then he studied rhetoric at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium in 1793–1794. From 1797 to 1799, he studied in the philosophy class at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium.
Career: Priest. In between studying in the rhetoric and philosophy classes, Morełowski taught French at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium (1794–1795), French and Latin grammar at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium (1795–1796), French (1796–1797) at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium. After graduation from the philosophy class at the Polatsk Collegium, Morełowski stayed there to teach rhetoric, poetics (1799–1800) and French (1800–1804). In 1804, he was sent to Saint Petersburg, where he was a boarding school Prefect (1804–1806, 1809–1810) and a teacher of poetics and Russian (1806–1809) at the Collegium Nobilium. In 1810, Morełowski left Saint Petersburg and arrived in Orsha, where he taught rhetoric and poetics to scholastics from 1810 to 1814. He worked as an assistant to the provincial in Belarus (1814–1816) and as the rector of the Jesuit churches in Polatsk (1816–1818) and Romanov (1818–1820).

Personal records: Originally from Paris. Father: Nicolas Moribel. Married to: Anne N. He had four children born in Paris, among whom: Anne Moribel.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, German, Russian, history, geography, mythology.
Career:
Governor and then headmaster. He was admitted on 5 August 1776, as the governor of students in the 2nd “age” at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. He taught French, history, geography, and mythology. He was also responsible for the “German” class in the absence of a German teacher at the Academy, receiving an additional salary of 150 rubles for this duty. He owed State counselor Diakov 63 rubles and 88 kopecks, and the magistrate requested that the Academy deduct this amount from his salary. He left the Academy in January 1783 and received a certificate.
In 1792, he was the headmaster of an educational boarding school in Moscow. This establishment for noble children was initially located in the house of Mme Birkina, between Miasnitskaya and Sretenka streets, and then around November 1792 at Ilinski Gate, in the parish of Saint Nicholas of the Great Cross, in the house of secretary Kostrovski. Around August 1794, Moribel purchased the house of general Potapov, in the parish of Saint Serge of Radonezh, near the Blacksmiths' Bridge, in the 5th district of the 5th part, at number 467. He always ended his advertisements with the same phrase, reminding that the headmaster of the boarding school “for the good of the Fatherland and the satisfaction of parents commits to using all possible efforts for the education of the youth.” The subjects taught at Moribel's boarding school included French, German, Russian grammar, and Russian, catechism, arithmetic, history, and geography; most of the subjects were taught by a Russian teacher, Lev Prokhorov. Moribel himself taught French, German, and Russian. The boarding school had between ten and twelve children in 1792, and this number increased to forty-two children in 1793 (35 boys and 7 girls).
Moribel resided in the first district of Moscow when he took the oath of 1793. He was a parishioner of the Saint Louis of the French church in Moscow in 1798.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1776–1783, Saint Petersburg); an educational boarding school (1790s, Moscow).

Career: Priest. Alois Moritz arrived in Russia in 1786; on 15 August 1787 he re-entered the Society of Jesus. (1744, Ax, county of Foix – 1796-07-05, Saint Petersburg; died at Nikita Korsakov's house “following several illnesses, particularly from stones”; buried in the Volkovskoye cemetery in the presence of Nikita Korsakov, François Amey, Daniel-François Mussard, Jean-Baptiste Hainglaise). Father: Jean-Baptiste-Claude Moutendre. Mother: Jeanne Boyer (also the mother of Jeanne-Marie, Mme Joseph Darbès, and probably of Françoise, Mme Jean-Balthazar de La Traverse). According to Amburger (no. 91398), he was the father of several other children, including:

Career:
Governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts between 1766 and 1776, at least. He requested in 1772 to take an exam at the Academy of Sciences to obtain the certificate of tutor: “Having had the honor of presenting myself to fill the vacant position [...], I dare to flatter myself that I deserve their [the Directors of the Academy – note from the editor] choice by the care I propose to give for the progress of the gentlemen students, neglecting nothing that would be proper to form their minds and hearts. […] My lessons during ordinary classes will be explanations of the rules of the French language based on the principles of Grammar” [it is worth noting the emphasis that the encyclopedists placed on teaching French grammar to instill logic and metaphysics in children]. In practice, Montandre was ready to teach several subjects in French: in addition to grammar, history, geography, and declamation. According to his examiners, he had a good command of French and Italian. He served as a history teacher at the Academy of Fine Arts from May to August 1772 (based on 300 rubles per year). He was also hired by Carbonnet as a tutor for his children, then he left the Academy after receiving a job offer in Moscow. He resided again in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath of 1793.
He was the godfather of Sophie-Catherine-Pierre Dumoutier in August 1771 at Saint Catherine of Alexandria.

Personal records: (or Mużyłowski) Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Dionisy Muzhilovsky is known to have studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (until 1727).
Career: All we know about Dionisy Muzhilovsky is that he took monastic vows at Saint Sophia’s Monastery in Kyiv and taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the 1741–1742 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1741–1742).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the 1741–1742 school year, 81 students were listed in the infima class which Dionisy Muzhilovsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Dionisy Muzhilovsky, students learned grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek) which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (Russia – 1746, Moscow). Married to: Anysia Yemelyanovna. Son: Afanasy (*1744). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Slavonic-Greek-Latin Academy, but apparently did not graduate from it.
Career:
In September 1736, together with a group of other convicts, he was sent from the Kazan provincial chancellery (office) to Yekaterinburg to serve an exile. Having learned that Alexander Nakrapaev had studied at the Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy, the Ural mining authorities decided to examine his knowledge of Latin in order to use him as an assistant for teaching children at the Yekaterinburg Latin School.
The examination was entrusted to the Yekaterinburg Latin School teacher Kiryak Kondratovich, who reported: “he speaks Latin rather well, and his learning results are notable, except that due to a long non-use of the language, he has partially forgotten the grammar rules, which he will soon consolidate in his memory once he has the books. He can translate from Russian into Latin, though not without some errors, but he translates too little from Latin into Russian, although he can attain a great success little by little, according to his indication”.
On 15 October 1736 Nakrapaev was appointed assistant to the teacher Kondratovich. He taught in the lowest, fourth form, where the teenagers who enrolled by the order of the Ural authorities were headed; in 1738 he taught in the fourth and fifth forms.
As a convict, he received a salary of three kopecks per day. From May 1737, after he submitted a petition for an increase in salary, he received five kopecks a day in summer and four kopecks a day in winter. It is not known why he was sentenced. No reply was received to the request of the Ural mining authorities to the Kazan provincial chancellery (office). It was only clear that he had been flogged.
After the closure of the school in December 1741, he remained in Yekaterinburg. In September 1744, he was released from exile on the basis of the decree dated 15 July 1744 and left for Moscow.
Teaching institutions and families: Yekaterinburg Latin School (1735–1741).
Students and their social status:
Children of priests; clergy; factory workers; clerks; raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Firstly, children of priests and clergymen, who lived on the territory of the Ministry of Mines (priests, deacons, dyachoks (readers), sextons, men responsible for refectories, enrolled in the Latin school, although according to the Russian legislation then in force (Spiritual Regulation 1721, decrees of 1722), they were subject to instruction at the Vyatka and Tobolsk seminaries. In September 1736, children of a master craftsman, a carpenter, a clerk (three people) were accepted. In 1739, along with the children of two priests and a dyachok (clerk), children of a podyachy (assistant clerk), a blacksmith, a furnace worker, a landless peasant, and two master craftsmen were accepted.
In March 1741, when the children of clergy were dismissed from the Latin school and entered the seminaries of the Vyatka and Tobolsk eparchies (dioceses) at the request of the Synod and according to the decree of the General Mining Directory (“General-berg-direktorium”), children of factory workers, in particular master craftsmen (seven people), carpenters (three people), a furnace worker, a guard, and a raznochinets were accepted into the school. Nakrapaev began to teach them the basics of Latin.
The lowest fourth form was created as part of the Latin school in October 1736. Teenagers who freshly enrolled for studying Latin were headed for that form. In 1738, due to an influx of several groups of newcomers, a fifth form was temporarily created.
By the order of the Chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters, students taught at home to read and write in Russian were recruited from the clergy, mostly coming from settlements ascribed to factories, from the town of Kungur and from the Kungur district (uyezd) as well as from other state-owned factories. From the summer of 1738, groups of children of clergy, trained to read and write at verbal schools, opened at the initiative of V.N. Tatishchev as the head of the factories, began to enrol in the school. In July 1738, nine students were transferred from the Kamensk verbal school, in August five students came from the Alapaevsk school, and in November five students were sent from the Kungur verbal school.
As the students advanced in mastering the basics of Latin, they passed to teacher Kondratovich’s form. In March 1741, due to the dismissal of all the children of priests and clergymen from the schools of the Mines department, including the Latin school, 13 children of factory workers were transferred to the Latin school from the Yekaterinburg verbal school.
In October 1736, 11 of Kondratovich’s students accepted in September-October 1736 were transferred to Nakrapaev. In March 1738, there were eight students in the 4th form; in November 1738, there 25 students in the 4th-5th forms.  In March 1741, Nakrapaev’s form had 13 students who were freshly enrolled in the Latin school.
The age group of the students was quite high. Since the first enrolments in the Latin school were composed of children, trained at home to read and write, among the accepted students there were 17 and 19-year old boys and even three 20 year-olds, but the 19-20 year-old students were released from training and sent home to the Kungur district (uyezd) in December 1736.
Among those who began to study in March 1741, there were teenagers of 11, 13, 15, 19, 20 (one person), 12 (four people) and 14 (four people) years-old.
Non-residents (students from other places) were quartered in the flats of the Yekaterinburg residents, or their fathers settled them at their friends’ and relatives’ places. Several students, who received a state allowance, were settled at the inn of the steward (manciple) Finn, where they were fed and provided with some clothes thanks to the money.
Teaching methods and materials:
He only taught reading, writing, basics of Latin grammar. He taught the alphabet, reading and writing in Latin. Some children of clergymen, accepted into the school from their homes or verbal schools affiliated with other factories, had a poor level of written Russian and developed their writing skills thanks to Nakrapaev. 
In the reports on the students’ progress, it is indicated against some of the family names that when they began to study vocables, they were also trained to write in Latin and Russian correctly.
After learning the Latin alphabet, children began to read vocables. Having reached the middle of the vocables course, along with that they began to write in Latin. For vocables, the teacher listened to each student’s reading. At the end of reading the vocables, students were supposed to “repeat” (consolidate) them.  At the end of the repetition (consolidation), the teacher proceeded to teaching the basics of Latin grammar, and afterwards the students were transferred to Kondratovich.

Personal records: (Secular name: Daniil) (1721-01-31, Poltava, Russian Empire – 1793-05-05, Kyiv). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: David Naschinsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. Although a number of authors have written that he studied abroad (at German universities), the documents available do not confirm this information.
Career: After graduation in the academic year 1747–1748 he taught Latin in the grammar class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; later he was a syntax class teacher. From 1751, he was a poetics teacher; from 1752 onwards, he also taught German. From 1753, he worked as a philosophy teacher and prefect at the Academy. From 1755, he served as archimandrite at the Monastery of the Holy Trinity in Slutsk which belonged to the Minsk diocese and was located on the territory of Rzeczpospolita. From 1758 onwards, he was a theology professor and rector at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. From 1761 on, he was archimandrite at the Monastery of the Nativity of the Mother of God in Hamaliivka, from 1769, at Saint Peter and Paul’s Monastery near Hlukhiv (Chernihiv Diocese), from 1772, at the Monastery of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross in Biziukovo (Smolensk Diocese). In 1788, he retired to the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra (Kyiv Monastery of the Caves), where he died.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1747–1755, 1758–1761).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen persons studied in the grammar and syntax classes which David Naschinsky taught. In total, several dozen students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes learned German as an option.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by David Naschinsky, students studied Latin grammar and syntax rules and did translation exercises. David Naschinsky continued the systematic teaching of German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy that had been initiated by Simon Todorsky and Manassiya Maksimovich. The teaching of German was planned over two years. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. However, “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange were already used at the Academy at the time. One of the books by Lange is known to have been translated from German by David Naschinsky. The library of the Academy had several books by this author as well as a number of contemporary dictionaries and lexicons by different compilers, published in Halle and in other centres. In grammar classes, students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The surviving exercises reveal the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in a syntax class. Many of the books used by David Naschinsky for teaching Latin and German had been brought from Germany by Simon Todorsky. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari ... Personal records:
Children:
  • François Noël, born in Russia, living in 1795 in Moscow, tutor;
  • Élisabeth Noël, wife of Herberg (*Moscow); she was in the Kaluga government in the spring of 1793 and took the oath of loyalty to the crown of France.
Career:
Tutor in Moscow. He resided in the 19th district of Moscow when he took the oath of 1793. In 1795, he owned a large house there where he organized a boarding house for unemployed tutors. The government, which had just banned gatherings in inns, considered this boarding house a masked form of public activity, illegal in its eyes. Together with his son François, Noël the father was one of the fourteen French tutors who, in 1795 in Moscow, proposed to establish a mutual aid society for tutors. Only two years after the measures controlling French nationals in Russia, the founders, aware that the situation was not conducive to such an undertaking, imposed conditions on the acceptance of applications for membership: candidates had to be duly authorized to practice as tutors, have impeccable morals, provide a guarantor, and “employ their knowledge and talents for the general good.” The founders of the society also relied heavily on the protection of Alexandre Petrovich Kurbatov, director of public schools in Moscow, whom they knew well. The contributions were to cover the medical expenses of the members, provide those who found themselves without a position with “housing, wood, candles, tea, coffee, and food for the price of 25 rubles per month,” help create a library accessible to all members; the society was to organize a small concert every month where members could bring their students, etc.
Nevertheless, all their efforts were in vain. Fourteen tutors (J. Dannenberg, J.-H. Ahler, Noël the son, J. Goix, E. Labiche, N. Petit, P. Hippert, Raimond, Colinet, J. Colinet, Maineok, Hustache, Mortien, J.-B. Peron) signed a request to obtain permission for this society. The request was addressed to the director of Public Schools in Moscow. The authorities took the matter very seriously; the governor-general of Moscow, Prince Piotr Petrovich Dolgoruki, ordered inquiries to be made about the members. He reported to the attorney general of the Empire, Count Samoylov, in these terms: at first glance, this project seems only light and unfounded, “but when one considers the main objective of forming a meeting, a special society, composed mostly of people who are not known by their birth or wealth, it raises suspicions: does this project not hide other intentions, entirely different?” This deliberately vague language, which constantly alluded to the political aspect (see Pesme de Matignicourt), doomed any such undertaking to failure. Catherine II thus prohibited the founding of “such societies and useless organizations” and threatened the tutors with expulsion from the empire if they persisted in their intention.
This is probably the same individual who was a merchant in Moscow in 1798 and lived near the Prechistenski gate at No. 371, in the house of Lvov, where he ran his shop: he sold the latest fashionable bonnets and feathers of various colors.
Teaching institutions and families: A boarding house in Moscow.

Personal records: (*Ingermanland).
Career: Johann Georg Oestermann belonged to the group of the first students of the Academy of Science in St. Petersburg, who were recruited in 1725. His teaching career began in September 1726. He was appointed to teach reading and writing in Latin and German in the lowest class of the Academy School. His yearly salary accounted for 120 roubles. For the following years (e.g., in 1728–1730) the documents repeatedly mention Oestermann as "collaborator" or "adjunct" to Martin Schwanwitz, the main German teacher. In 1737 Oestermann was one of four German teachers in the German Section of the Academy school. He still worked in the lowest class and kept this position also in the 1740s. In January 1750, the Academy school had only two German classes, one conducted by Oestermann and the other by Johann Georg Herwart. According to Johann Eberhard Fischer, the rector of the Academy School, these classes were "not in the best condition". Fischer describes Oestermann as follows: "He is a simple and uneducated person, and it is not possible to entrust him with more than teaching reading and writing." Therefore, Oestermann had to teach only reading and writing and nothing else. Apparently, Oestermann continued to teach in the lower German classes. He is last-mentioned in the Academy's documents in 1754 as "Untermeister" of the lower German classes.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1726 – 1754 or later, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers, published by Suchomlinov in his “Materials for the History of the Imperial Academy of Sciences”, list about 820 pupils aged between 6 and 20 attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. The names of quite a large number of these pupils are known and listed in Suchomlinov’s registers including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
The most detailed report of the number and social status of all students registered at the Academy school and learning German was given by the rector of the German Section of the Academy School Martin Schwanwitz (Shvanovich) in November 1736. In principle, there were two categories of students attending the Academy school: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitz’ report lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy school especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was quite diverse, ranging from high nobility, army officers and government officials such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants. Another report, written by Johann Georg Oestermann, provides information about the independent pupils attending the Academy school in October 1748. Most probably all of the 13 students listed in this report attended Oestermann’s own class, the lower German class. Most of the students were aged between 12 and 15, but there were also one eight-year-old, one nine-year-old and two seventeen-year-old boys. Their social backgrounds varied enormously, too. The fathers' occupations included civil servant, secretary, captain and Admiralty council, merchant, physician, craftsman, valet or stable lad at the court.
Teaching methods and materials:
Oestermann's main duty at the Academy school was to teach reading and writing, some grammar, and the rudiments of translation in the lower German class. This is shown by several documents. In December 1737, for example, a report about the functions and current activities of the academic staff recorded Oestermann teaching "[...] the new students reading, writing, and arithmetic [...]" and "reading the Catechism with foreigners." A detailed plan about the organisation of the Academy school, written by its rector Johann Eberhard Fischer in 1748, defines the teaching and learning contents of the lower German class as follows: "The lower German class is devoted to: the Orthodox religion, arithmetic, reading and writing in Russian, German and Latin. German words. German grammar. Simple interpretation from Lange's dialogues. Calligraphy. Dancing."
Oestermann's report of 1748 provides some interesting insights in the teaching conditions of the lower German class. The pupils were not only unequal in age, they also had a very varying command of German, because they joined the class at different stages. Some of them had already learned German for three years, others only for several months or a couple of weeks. As a result, while one of the youngest pupils was only starting to learn the alphabet, others learned reading and writing or vocabulary and studied different topics of the German grammar system. That is, some could be dealing with adverbs, whereas others, at the same time, could be learning their nouns and still others their adjectives. Under these conditions the teacher probably couldn’t teach all his students as a single class, but the pupils had to learn individually, e.g. by memorizing the rules of grammar.

Oestermann most probably used the textbooks that were printed at the Academy or generally used there for teaching German. For more details, see the entry about Martin Schwanwitz. A catalogue of books used in the German class in July 1750 lists among other things: 
1) [Weissmann, Ehrenreich], Teutsch-lateinisch- und rußisches Lexicon, samt denen Anfangsgründen der Rußischen Sprache. Zu allgemeinem Nutzen bey der kayserl. Academie der Wissenschaften zum Druck befördert. Немецко латинскии и русскии лексикон купно с первыми началами рускаго языка к общей пользе при Имп. Академии наук, печатию издан (St. Petersburg: Printing House of the Imperial Academy of Sciences, 1731); 
2) Die Teutsche Grammatica. Aus unterschiedenen Auctoribus zusammengetragen und Der Russischen Jugend zum Besten herausgegeben von dem Informatore der Teutschen Sprache bey dem St. Petersburgischen Gymnasio. Немецкая грамматика, из разных авторов собрана и российской юности в пользу издана от учителя немецкого языка при Санкт-Петербургской гимназии (St. Petersburg: Printing House of the Imperial Academy of Sciences, 1730) by Martin Schwanwitz; 
3) Lange, Joachim, Colloquia Scholastica. Школьные разговоры. Schul-Gespräche, Dialogues (St. Petersburg: Printing House of the Imperial Academy of Sciences, 1738). 
These books might have been used in Oestermann's lower class. An explicit note indicates that Oestermann possessed one copy of the Academy's rules (Regulations of the Academy of Sciences) in Russian.

Personal records:
Married.
His estate was recorded by De Bosse, manager of the French vice-consulate in Moscow, on 10 August 1791.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: History, grammar, mythology, geography, reading, arithmetic.
Career: Governor of the young princes Boris and Dimitri Golitsyn, sons of Prince Vladimir Borisovich Golitsyn, brigadier, and Princess Nathalia Petrovna, daughter of Count Piotr Grigorievich Сhernyshev, a diplomat, Russian ambassador in France, envoy to Denmark, Prussia, and England (Prince Boris became a colonel in the Semionovski regiment of the guard, lieutenant general in the war against Napoleon; he was wounded there and died; Prince Dimitri was a cavalry general in 1814, knight of orders, a hero of the War of 1812, governor-general of Moscow from 1820, member of the State Council from 1821, created an illustrious prince in 1841). Michel Olivier accompanied the two brothers on their "Grand Tour" of Europe in 1782. Throughout this journey, the tutor maintained regular correspondence with the princes' mother. The princes were expected to spend a lot of time working on their epistolary style; a small travel library was available to them. They departed on 19 June 1782, from Kronstadt. The first stop was in Copenhagen: welcomed by Kastalinski, secretary of the Russian legation, they were taken to the history cabinet and the palace. They then traveled to Hamburg, accompanied by the son of the grand equerry Naryshkin. On board, Olivier protected Prince Boris from the “most indecent and filthy remarks” made by a Prince Viazemski by lending him “a handwritten pamphlet in Russian verse by a certain Barkoff [a libertine Russian poet].” At the end of July, they traveled from Hamburg to Frankfurt (dinner at M. de Gross’s), then to Hanover and Kassel, where they attended a military parade. By the end of August, they reached their destination, Strasbourg. The very next day, they were introduced to the Count and Countess of the North (the Grand Duke heir and his wife), who were traveling in Europe. In the following days, the tutor and the princes followed the heir to the theater or to military drills organized by the Marquis de Saxe. They attended the defense of a thesis by a Ukrainian at the University of Strasbourg. Olivier arranged lessons for the princes. Some of their professors were affiliated with the university. Thus, they had daily lessons in languages, mathematics, and fencing; Latin and English were taught three times a week for an hour; history, grammar, mythology, geography, reading, and arithmetic were taught by Olivier himself. The princes also took three dance lessons per week. The two brothers spent a total of six years in Strasbourg and studied at the military academy. In 1789, Olivier traveled with the princes to Paris. Prince Boris was already grown; he had just published an “idyll” in the Mercure. Olivier often went to the National Assembly, where he listened to “superb speeches for and against the Church” and assured Princess Golitsyn that “except for the noise of carriages rolling in the streets at night, one could willingly hear a fly buzzing.” They visited the court and the city, dined with Princess Hohenzollern, Duchess de Cereste, Madame de Caraman, and Madame du Bocage.
Teaching institutions and families: Golitsyn family
Students and their social status: Princes Boris Vladimirovich Golitsyn, Dimitri Vladimirovich Golitsyn
Teaching methods and materials: Olivier had a personal vision of education, which he explained to the parents: “When he [Prince Boris Golitsyn] has finished his exercises or a part of them and has made happy progress as I hope, then, with his mind well furnished with good principles, his intellect will be able to act on them successfully; he will read and write with great benefit because his reason will be enlightened by the study of good Latin, German, English, and French authors, with knowledge of Mathematics which will give him order and accuracy, placing him in a position.”

(or Aulery, Georges Louis) (*1725, Alsace).
Married.
He had two (according to other sources – four) children.
Education: He graduated from the University of Strasbourg in 1744.
Career: In 1768, Olrich came to Saint Petersburg with his wife and two children (according to other later sources, he had four children; some of them were probably born in Saint Petersburg). He entered service as a teacher at the Land Noble Cadet Corps; fifteen months later he retired. In 1771, he opened a boarding school in Konyushennaya Street. He taught at his boarding school with two teaching assistants: Nikolay Monakov and the dance teacher Volkov, who was well known in the city. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which checked this boarding school in April 1780, noted that Olrich (Aulery) and his wife spoke good German and French, but did not understand Russian. The inside of the boarding school consisted of six rooms and was clean and tidy. His boarding school was also checked in 1784. The Commission found that the geography and history lessons were "very strange". All the teaching was conducted individually with each student. For geography, the teacher only used a children’s atlas, no other books were used.
Teaching institutions and families: Land Noble Cadet Corps; private boarding school (from 1771 till at least 1784), all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Military men; merchants; nobles.
In 1780, the boarding school was attended by ten children aged from 12 to 18, among them six children of staff officers, the Moldavian Prince Ratakudin, a son of a captain, two sons of German merchants, the daughter of Malkovetsky. In 1784, the boarding school was attended by nine boys.
Teaching methods and materials:
He made children translate from one language to another; he often used dictation as a method too. He began with grammar and proceeded with translations. His knowledge of German was not perfect and his teaching was affected by this, as was noted by the Commission in 1784. He had a good knowledge of French, but his teaching methods seemed slow to the Commission members.

Personal records: (*Russian Empire) Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All that is known concerning Aleksandr Osipovsky is that he was appointed to teach the phara and infima classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1753–1754 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1753–1754).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. More than 100 students were enrolled at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1750s. There were several dozen students in the phara and infima classes which Aleksandr Osipovsky taught. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) which Aleksandr Osipovsky taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. Aleksandr Osipovsky also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the 1750s was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that their teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereiaslav Collegium. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari ... Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Kozma Ososkov is that he was a higher grammar class teacher at the Chernihiv Collegium from 1796 to 1798. He was dismissed at his own request in order to be ordained a priest.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1796–1798).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In 1797, the higher grammar class taught by Kozma Ososkov had 168 students. In total, 711 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium that year. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So, in 1797 there were 25 “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks) students among the 168 students of the higher grammar class which Kozma Ososkov taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Kozma Ososkov, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Kozma Ososkov worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the end of the 18th century show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memories of the Chernihiv Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records:
(or Piotr).
It is known that Piotr Otton was a foreigner. This was stated in a letter from the Belgorod bishop Samuil Mislavsky to the Sloboda-Ukrainian governor Yevdokim Scherbinin (dated 25 May 1771). Unfortunately, the birthplace of the teacher was not mentioned in the documents.
Education: We do not know exactly where Piotr Otton studied, but it is clear thanks to the correspondence of the Kharkiv Collegium direction with the diocesan authorities that people who studied at Western European universities were invited to take up positions as teachers of the “new languages.”
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French grammar and syntax; translation; colloquial language (speaking).
Career: The only thing we know concerning Otton is that he was invited to come from Moscow University in order to teach French at the Kharkiv Collegium. The correspondence between Samuil Mislavsky and Yevdokim Scherbinin shows that the curator of Moscow University, Ivan Melissino, participated in the search for the teacher. Although P. Otton was invited to the so-called “surplus classes” at the Kharkiv Collegium, Samuil Mislavsky wrote that he would teach French to all students. All that can be said precisely is that Otton taught French for a few years, beginning in 1771.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium; “additional classes” affiliated with the Kharkiv Collegium (State school) (from 1771).
Students and their social status: Clergy; nobility. While Otton was teaching, about 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. Several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few students from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there. It is known that many sons of the nobility (szlachta) learned French, and mainly noble children studied in the “additional” classes.
Teaching methods and materials:
When Piotr Otton taught at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, written by the bishop of Belgorod, Samuil Mislavsky, in 1769 and addressed to the rector, to the prefect and to the teachers, were in use at the Collegium. Since many of the books on the “new languages” were written in Latin, the Instructions emphasized that students were only supposed to start learning other foreign languages from the syntax class on, when they had a sufficiently high level of Latin. Unfortunately, the Instructions did not have any special section on the teaching of the “new languages”. Samuil Mislavsky outlined some of his considerations on the teaching of French in his letter to the governor Yevdokim Scherbinin (25 May 1771). He wrote that the experience of speaking to the students of the Kharkiv Collegium in French demonstrated that they were not fluent in the spoken language. He expressed the hope that Piotr Otton would pay special attention to the teaching of colloquial language to his students.
In his letter to the governor Yevdokim Scherbinin, Samuil Mislavsky formulated the methods of teaching French which Piotr Otton was supposed to adhere to. It is interesting to note that in addition to courses in a classroom, the bishop suggested that the direction of the Collegium select four students (from the rhetoric, philosophy or theology classes) and settle them together with Otton in the same apartment to ensure constant communication in French. Samuil Mislavsky described the methods of studying the language. At the first stage, the teacher had to study grammar with his students, paying attention to the pronunciation (it was supposed to be “the most Parisian, and not the Gasconian pronunciation”). Grammar and then syntax classes were supposed to be based on “Restaut’s Grammar”. This was a reference to the book by Pierre Restaut. The book, then popular in Europe, was available at the Kharkiv Collegium in a Russian translation. At the next stage, students were supposed to read French newspapers and to do translations into Russian in order to acquire a good style and taste. Later, according to the bishop, students were to translate articles from the “French Encyclopaedia”, as well as letters of the famous French writers Rousseau and Voltaire, under the guidance of the teacher. Concerning the exact extracts from their works, the bishop noted that only those that did not contain any “reprehension of our faith and goodness” were supposed to be chosen for translation (several books of these authors were available in the library of the Collegium). Students were also supposed constantly to practice writing letters in French.
Students of the Kharkiv Collegium (had) translated different authors from German and French earlier. It was a widely-used practice. In August 1769, the Sloboda-Ukrainian governor Yevdokim Scherbinin even proposed the creation of a printing house in Kharkiv in order to publish these works (the printing house was not yet established at the time). It is known that one of the exercises that students performed was translating extracts from different books written in French. At the time, the novel by François Fénelon “Les Aventures de Télémaque” (“The Adventures of Telemachus”) was very often mentioned. Therefore, “French books” are often found in the descriptions of the belongings of students who attended collegiums. So, the “Adventures of Telemachus” and three volumes of writings (“History”) by Voltaire were among personal books of one of the students in 1771.
Piotr Otton did not lack other teaching aids for students. He could use French grammar books and lexicons, available at the library of the Collegium. The catalogues of the library (1753 and 1769) show that at the time the Kharkiv Collegium had a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries. The books were transferred to the library by Belgorod bishops (who had once been teachers): Yepifany Tikhorsky (the founder of the Collegium), Dosifey Bogdanovich-Liubimsky, Ioasaf Gorlenko and Mitrofan Slotvinsky. It is interesting to note that the library had several dictionaries by Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey. Rather short book descriptions do not make it possible to identify the books accurately.

Personal records: (or Parrate, likely due to distortion) (†beginning of 1778) Married to: Barbe (or Varvara Ivanovna) N. (*Paris), who later remarried Abraham Wille.
Career: Translator, headmaster. Jean-Baptiste Parat ran an educational boarding school in Moscow, at least since 1768, for the children, both boys and girls, of noble families. This boarding school was initially established in the house of the second major of the guard, Evtikhi Ivanovich Safonov, located in the Earthen City (Zemlyanoy gorod), parish of the Church of the Intercession of the Virgin (Pokrova Bogoroditsy), Levshin district, and then, in 1770, in the house of colonel Nikolay Loginych Shcherbachev on Povarskaya Street. In 1776, Parat was in Saint Petersburg where he took a position as a translator at the Academy of Sciences. He handled the foreign correspondence of the Academy. After his death, the Swiss Roussal was appointed in his place on 15 February 1778. Parat continued to run an educational boarding school. Jean-Baptiste Parat's wife was a governess for the children of the first "age" at the Academy of Fine Arts College in 1772; she left the Academy due to poor health on 28 September 1773. He addressed a letter to the academician J. Stählin (RNB, Mss, fund 871, no. 615).
Teaching institutions and families: An educational boarding school in Moscow (at least since 1768); Academy of Sciences (till 1778, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Nobility
Teaching methods and materials: In the boarding school that Parat ran, he committed to educating the children in a manner appropriate to their background and to teaching them French, Latin, Italian, German, history, geography, mathematics, and catechism. Orthodox catechism was taught there, which was rare at that time. Parents and "lovers of the sciences" could come to observe the organization of the boarding school.

Personal records:
(1767, Montbéliard – 1852, Finland; buried in Saint Petersburg).

He was the 14th child of the sworn bourgeois master Jacques Parrot.
He married in 1789 in Karlsruhe and had two sons, including the geographer Frédéric Parrot, who made the first ascent of Mount Ararat in Armenia (5156 m).
Education: Georges-Frédéric Parrot studied at the French school in Montbéliard, then transferred in 1782 to the Caroline Academy in Stuttgart.
Career:
In 1786, Parrot entered the service of Count d’Héricy, a Protestant gentleman from Normandy. He settled in Livonia in 1795 and became the tutor to the children of Prince Karl von Sieves (Sievers?). He moved to Riga in 1796.
As an advisor to Alexander I, he reorganized the University of Dorpat (Tartu, in the Baltic provinces) in 1802, which had been closed following the Northern Wars in 1710. He held the chair of physics there. He corresponded with all the great scholars of his time, including his compatriot Cuvier. He was elected a member of the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences in 1826 and later became its rector, then vice-director in 1837. He was appointed state councilor in 1840. He was a knight of the Orders of Saint Anne and Saint Vladimir.
Teaching institutions and families: Von Sieves (Sievers?) family; University of Dorpat; Academy of Sciences (since 1826, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Children of Prince Karl von Sieves (Sievers?)

Personal records: (or Pause) (1670-11-01, Salzungen, Thuringia – 1735-02 or 1735-03, Saint Petersburg). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Paus studied theology, maths, music and oriental languages among others at the universities of Jena, Wittenberg and Halle. He completed his studies in 1699 with a degree in philosophy from Halle, where he made the acquaintance of the pietist, theologian and university professor, August Hermann Francke, the founder of the educational institutions known as “Francke Foundations” (Franckesche Stiftungen). Paus became a follower of the pietist movement. He had a very broad spectrum of knowledge and was able to teach Greek, Latin and Hebrew as well as geography, history, philosophy, physics, logic, ethics and singing. During his stay in Russia he also developed a profound knowledge of Russian and Old Church Slavonic.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; Russian; Greek; Latin; Hebrew; geography; history.
Career:
Theologian, preacher and pedagogue.
On August Hermann Francke’s orders, Paus started a missionary journey to Sweden in 1700, where he worked as preacher and pedagogue. However, these activities were disapproved of by the Swedish authorities. Paus was expelled from Sweden in 1701 and returned to Halle.
In autumn 1701, Paus set off on a new mission trip. This time, August Hermann Francke, who had established good relationships with the Russian authorities, sent him to Moscow, where Paus arrived in February 1702. The beginning was difficult: Paus was taken for a secret agent from Sweden and was put into prison. Promoted by Laurenz Blumentrost the older, the personal physician of Czar Peter I, he was released from prison and became the tutor of Blumentrostʼs sons, amongst them Laurenz Blumentrost the younger, who became the first president of the Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg in 1724. In 1702 Paus started to teach Latin, Greek and “European languages” (Белокуров, Зерцалов, 1907, p. X) at the school of the New Lutheran Community, one of the German schools in Nemetskaia Sloboda (German Quarter). In this position, he began to create didactic materials for his own lessons, for example chronological tables for Roman history, for biblical history and for the reigns of the European kings. Due to personal problems with Justus Samuel Scharschmidt, pastor of the New Lutheran Community, he left the school in 1705 and became a teacher at the Moscow Grammar School, managed by Pope Johann Ernst Glück since 1703. After Glückʼs death in May 1705, Paus took over the management of the school on 29 May and implemented a strict new school regulation (Правила Петровского училища) that limited the rights of the teachers and required more discipline from the students. Paus also continued the translation activities of his predecessor, who had begun to translate Lutheran literature and hymns, as well as teaching materials for the purpose of language learning, into Russian (especially the language books of John Amos Comenius). However, he again got into conflict with the school authorities, the other teachers, the pupils and their parents and was dismissed once more in July 1706. In 1707 Paus continued his pedagogical work as private tutor, secretary and translator in various noble Moscow families (e.g., prince Mikhail Dolgorukov) and with some families of the German Quarter. Supported by August Hermann Francke, Paus got into contact with Baron Heinrich v. Huyssen, tutor of Tsarevich Alexei Petrovich, and was engaged as the Tsarevich’s geography and history teacher. In addition, he carried on translating Western literature into Russian and worked on several of his own philological manuals and the translations of J.E. Glück. In 1711, Paus became a diacon and teacher of Russian for Alexeiʼs wife Princess Charlotte-Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel. In 1714, Paus moved to St. Petersburg, where he was engaged as a librarian. In 1721, he travelled back to Germany, probably with the intention of publishing his philological works at the Russian printing shop in Halle which had existed since 1704. However, Pausʼ manuscripts were not published. Upon the instigation of Baron von Huyssen, Paus returned to Saint Petersburg in 1721. After the foundation of the Russian Academy of Sciences in 1724, Paus became the first translator at the Academy (November 1724) and received an annual salary of 300 roubles. Here, he continued to work on his philological studies. Furthermore, he worked on Russian historical sources, especially on Russian chronology. Paus had good relations with Gottlieb Siegfried Bayer (member of the Russian Academy of Sciences since 1726) but his relations with other colleagues at the Academy, for example the librarian Johann Daniel Schumacher, were rather difficult. Namely Schumacher is said to have prevented the printing of Paus’ most important works -- the Russian grammar (“Anweisung”) and the Russian-German dictionary – which were both offered to the Academy for printing. In the end, not any of his works were published and his merits as a philologist were recognized only recently: today Paus is regarded as the founder of Russian morphology (see A. Huterer, 2001, pp. 12-15).

School of the New Lutheran Community in Moscow; Moscow Foreign Language School; Russian Academy of Sciences.

Nobility; members of the German community in Moscow; civil servants.
