At the beginning of the Moscow Foreign Language School, pupils came almost always from the higher nobility or the administration. They had to learn foreign languages to be eligible for diplomatic service or service in the administration and the ministries (collegia). Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was significantly extended and sons of soldiers and craftsmen also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: students in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To attract more pupils, in the first years of the existence of the school, students were exempted from military service.
Teaching methods and materials:
In the school of the New Lutheran Church in the German Quarter of Moscow, Paus taught German, Latin, Ancient Greek and “Juish” language. In the Moscow Foreign Language School, he taught Latin, three hours per day.
Regarding the Moscow Foreign Language School, founded by Johann Ernst Glück, there are various documents that give insights into the procedures and methods of teaching foreign languages. Pausʼ new school regulation set up some quite demanding rules. For example, pupils were not allowed to talk in Russian, in order to encourage them to use the foreign languages they had learnt. A description of the daily timetable which was preserved in Paus’ estate, shows that the schedule was quite intense: Pupils got up at 6 o’clock in the morning and started the day with praying and /or learning and singing hymns. After that, pupils read from the New Testament. Classes began at 9 a.m. The largest part of the lessons was reserved for language learning. Until 10 a.m., pupils worked with Comenius’ “Orbis sensualium pictus.” From 10 a.m. to 11 a.m., pupils dealt with Latin grammar, from 11a.m. to 12 a.m. with German or French grammar. After lunch, from 1 p.m. to 2 p.m., pupils practised spelling. The afternoon was devoted to various exercises in German and Latin (epistolae germanicae, exercitia latina, imitations, calligraphy, reading, translating), as well as maths and, for older pupils, rhetoric and phraseology. French was taught from 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. Until 6 p.m. pupils did history or homework before finishing up the day with rhetoric, maths or philosophy in the evening. In many lessons, the language of instruction was most probably German, because the majority of teachers had German as their mother tongue and not all of them knew Russian. Furthermore, most of the materials used were written in German if not in Latin, for example the New Testament and hymns, German primers or dialogues.

Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698).
It is not quite sure which editions of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Grammar School. What we do know is that J.E. Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis sensualium pictus” into Russian. “Vestibulum” was completed by the end of 1703 and Glück applied to the Tsar with a petition to publish it under the title “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, p. 47). However, all these manuscripts remained unpublished. Paus continued Glückʼs translation activities. Manuscripts of Pausʼ translations of “Orbis sensualium pictus” (BAN, Mss, osn. sobr. 1.2.1, fol. 1-105) and “Vestibulum” (BAN, Mss, osn. sobr.1.2.1, fol. 113-157) are kept in the manuscript section of the Library of the Academy of Sciences in Saint Petersburg, as is one of Glückʼs translations of the “Orbis sensualium pictus” which was marginalised by Paus (BAN, Mss, osn. sobr.26.3.50).
Other texts, used in language classes at the Moscow Grammar school, include: various nomenclatures (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (maybe the popular Latin-German dialogues of the German philologist Johann Georg Seybold – Paus translated these dialogues into Russian); Lutheran bible; Lutheran catechism; German hymns; French grammar.
All these texts were translated or adapted by J.E. Glück and/or J.W. Paus for their Russian pupils.

Pausʼ “Anweisung” is one of the oldest Russian grammars. The merits of this grammar are seen especially in the innovative chapters on Russian morphology. Paus first tried to publish this work in 1720 and therefore presented it to Peter I. Unfortunately, this attempt failed and the manuscript got lost. Later, Paus prepared a new version which was given to the Academy of Sciences in 1729. Due to some intrigues of the academic librarian J.D. Schumacher, this version was not printed either. Nonetheless, Paus’ colleagues did not hesitate to use the “Anweisung” as a very valuable source of Russian linguistic material which was later utilised for another Russian grammar, titled “Compendium”, that was composed by a group of teachers and translators of the Academy of Sciences in 1731.

Observationes, inventions et experimenta circa Literaturam et Historiam Russicam in camera obscura et optica ad Academiam Scientiarum instituta (SPFA RAN, R. III, op. 1, no. 168a). In his unfinished text “Observationes” of 1732, Paus gives an account of all his philological and historical works, including detailed descriptions of the linguistic concepts of his grammars and dictionaries. The text was edited by Eduard Winter in 1958.
Historical works, especially on Russian chronology, for history lessons; panegyric and religious poems; pedagogical essays. None of these works was published.

Personal records: (*1775, Russian Empire). It is known that Iov Pavlovsky’s father was a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Iov Pavlovsky studied at the Pereiaslav Collegium, including in the rhetoric class, then he studied philosophy and theology at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; he also learned Ancient Greek and German.
Career: All we know about Iov Pavlovsky is that from September 1798 onwards he was a teacher in the lower Latin grammar class at the Pereiaslav Collegium. He was ordained a priest. In subsequent years, Iov Pavlovsky was a higher grammar class teacher and a poetics class teacher. In 1801, at his own request, he was dismissed from the Collegium in order to serve as rector at the church in the town of Reshetylivka.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1798–1801).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. At the end of the 1790s, several dozen students learned Latin in the grammar classes of the Pereiaslav Collegium. In the 1798–1799 school year, there were 443 students at the Collegium. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Iov Pavlovsky taught Latin grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. Iov Pavlovsky’s Latin grammar classes were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The Collegium had a great number of books by Cellarius, published in different years, so that each student had a book. It is known that the direction of the Pereiaslav Collegium bought these books several times in quantities of more than 100 copies at a time. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students show that they also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. There were also a great number of copies of this book, published in different years. Personal records: (*Russian Empire – 1794, Kharkiv, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Ivan Pereverzev studied at the Kharkiv Collegium.
Career: Soon after graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium in 1770, Ivan Pereverzev began teaching Latin in the grammar class at the same school. Then he also taught in the subsequent classes. It is well known that he was a rhetoric class teacher in 1773–1774. In these and subsequent years, he also taught history and geography. From 1776 to 1778, he was a rhetoric teacher at the Voronezh Theological Seminary, in which he also began teaching history. On his return to Kharkiv in 1780, Ivan Pereverzev became director of the Main Public School and remained in this position until his death.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium; Voronezh Theological Seminary; Kharkiv Main Public School
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1770s, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar class taught by Ivan Pereverzev.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ivan Pereverzev, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ivan Pereverzev worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, that were written by Bishop of Belgorod Samuil Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector, to the prefect and to the teachers, were in use at the Collegium. The document gives a sufficiently complete idea of the teaching of basic school disciplines, including foreign languages. The instructions indicated the need for Latin grammar teaching according to the book by Christoph Cellarius in Johann Matthias Gesner’s version published at Moscow University in 1762 instead of the book by Alvarez which was used at the Kharkiv Collegium in the first half of the 18th century. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also pointed out that grammar rules were necessarily supposed to be consolidated by reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. Samuil Mislavsky’s book bore the Russian name as well as the original one. The instructions contained detailed recommendations on the organisation of classroom and homework exercises for students. It listed sections and paragraphs of the books that the teacher was supposed to be guided by at various stages of teaching. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also focused on methods that would allow students to consolidate “lighthearted vocabulary, intelligent designs, prompt responses and pleasant adventures of eminent men” in their memory. For this purpose, he advised teachers to use the book “Reasonable Comrade” (Семенов П. Товарищ разумной и замысловатой, или Собрание хороших слов, разумных замыслов, скорых ответов, учтивых насмешек и приятных приключений знатных мужей древняго и нынешняго веков, Moscow, 1787). In addition to this, the author of the Instructions advised teachers not to bother their students with learning rules and exceptions by heart, in order to keep them studying with interest. He drew the attention of teachers to the fact that a child could learn all the best grammar rules, but it would not help him understand or write, if he did not use them constantly in his own translations. It is important to note that all the books were available at the library of the Kharkiv Collegium (they were bought purposefully, quite a few books being granted by Samuil Mislavsky). According to the library catalogue of 1769, the Collegium had several different books by Cellarius and Lange. Their number exceeded ten at the time. Besides that, the library had a few modern dictionaries, lexicons by different authors, published in Halle and other centres (unfortunately, the book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately). Career: Tutor. He lived with his wife in Moscow in 1761. He was hired as a governor for the children of Alexander Iurievich Neledinski-Meletski (1729–1804), son of senator Iuri Stepanovich, a military man and future private counselor. Pexonne's contract stipulated that he would receive for his work “three hundred rubles, a carriage, tea, sugar, coffee at will, and in case of illness, care and medicine.” The tutor was to follow the family wherever they went, according to the orders of his mistress. Pexonne initiated young Iuri Alexandrovich Neledinski with “great zeal” in French, arithmetic, chronology, Italian, and Latin, “if requested.” Notably, the contract included words about the necessity of instilling “purity of morals,” for which the governor also committed to teaching morality. After the premature death of his mother, his student was placed in the home of his grandmother A.I. Talyzina, and then, at the age of thirteen, sent to Saint Petersburg to his second grandmother, Princess A.I. Kurakina. In 1769, he would go abroad to study at the University of Strasbourg. I.A. Neledinski-Meletski (1752–1829) would become the director of the Main Public School in Moscow in 1786, a senator in 1800, state secretary to Paul I, a writer, and a poet.

Pfundheller is documented in Iglau (now Jihlava in Moravia, Czech Republic) and in Saxony in 1754. However, nothing is known about his activities there.
Pfundheller was engaged at the grammar school of Moscow University on 30 April 1763. For the next six years, he taught Latin and Greek, namely the third Latin class (“syntax”) and the first (“lower”) Greek class. In November 1769 he took over the position of his colleague М.I. Agentov, who had died, and became teacher of the third German class (“syntax”) in the section for noble students. It is not documented when Pfundheller left the grammar school. In 1772, he was apparently still living in Moscow.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to the Moscow University (from 1763).
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative in order to prepare young people to studying at the Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for the European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of science” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. In the beginning, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number was increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was achieved in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
Apparently, there were problems in the teaching of languages at the grammar school of Moscow University, so that the professors of the Moscow University felt compelled to draw attention to this issue in their conference in May 1767. They made the following decision:
“It has been observed that students at the grammar school, especially in the lower classes, are very tired because of studying grammar rules that they do not understand and that are not explained in practice; whereby the Conference demands: 1) That teachers, writing on the blackboard examples subject to grammar analysis, should immediately translate them into Russian or from Russian into French, German (or Latin and Italian) and that they should do it every day. This is particularly important for practising conversation (dialogues). Dialogues, words and phrases explained in such a way should be learned by heart. Grammar rules, that have been explained thoroughly during the analysis and read about in grammar books, and thus understood without much difficulty, should be studied in advance. One day a week should be used entirely to practise free conversation consisting of questions and answers. 2) That they should force their students to do exercises given in the classroom and for homework three times a week, and that on the following morning teachers should sign the revised work and note the day when the work was given and corrected. Similar exercises should be introduced by teachers in other classes, too, for example, in the mathematics, as well as in the geographical and historical classes. These exercises, showing the diligence of both teachers and students, should be observed by the inspector and the rector, they should be the first to be paid attention to by the examiners on the public examinations.” (Minutes of the conference of the professors of Moscow University from 12 May 1767, printed in Пенчко, 1963, p. 41).
Thus, the main focus was on the translation of example sentences. Contrary to prior practices, the student’s mother tongue Russian was now incorporated into the process of instruction in order to increase the student’s understanding. Oral skills were to be built up by memorizing sample dialogues which were presented in the so called “dialogue books”. Next to grammar books, these dialogue books represented the main basis for language instruction.

[Formey, Johann Heinrich Samuel], Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften zum Gebrauch der Jugend, Moscow, 1764.
[Gottsched, Johann Christoph], Vollständigere und Neuerläuterte Deutsche Sprachkunst, Nach den Mustern der besten Schriftsteller des vorigen und itzigen Jahrhunderts abgefasset, und bey dieser fünften Auflage merklich verbessert, Leipzig, 1762.
[Hoffmann, Johann Adolf], Zwei Bücher von der Zufriedenheit nach den Gründen der Vernunft und des Glaubens, Hamburg, 1766.

[Hölterhof, Franz], Немецкая грамматика, в которой не токмо все части речи, или произведение слов, но и синтаксис, или сочинение слов, оба надлежащими примерами объяснены, в пользу российскаго юношества издана учителем Немецкаго языка в Московском имп. университете, Moscow, 1770, 1775, 1784, 1791, 10th ed., 1829.
[Komenský, Jan Amos], Иоанна Амоса Комения Видимый свет на латинском, российском, немецком, италианском и французском языках представлен, или Краткое введение, которым изъясняется, что обучающемуся юношеству лехким способом не только языку, разумным упражнением, но также и вещи достойныя знания самонужнейшия должны быть вперены, изо сто пятидесяти одной главы состоящее, из которых каждая вместо надписи и содержаия из свайщеннаго писания взятым свидетельством означена, и с реестром самых нужнейших российских слов, который вместо лексикона для употреблений российскаго юношества служить имееть, место на пяти языках дополнить может, изданное, Joh. Amos Comenius Sichtbare Welt in Lateinischer, Russischer, Deutscher, Italiänischer und Französischer Sprache, oder Kurze Einleitung, der zarten Jugend auf eine leichte Weise, nicht nur die Sprachen durch eine vernünftige Uebung, sondern auch die derselben zu wissen nöthige Sachen beyzubringen, in hundert und ein und funfzig Capiteln verfasst, davon ein jedes an statt der Aufschrift und des Inhalts mit einem Spruche aus der Heiligen Schrift versehen ist, und mit einem alphabetischen Register der russischen Hauptwörter, welches die Stelle eines Wörterbuchs für die russische jugend in fünf Sprachen vertretten kann, heraus gegeben, Moscow, 1768.
[Lange, Joachim], Colloquia Scholastica, Школьные разговоры, Schul-Gespräche, Dialogues, St. Petersburg, 1738.
In the case of the grammar school attached to Moscow University and the university itself, the choice of books used for learning foreign languages is quite well documented. Initially, the regulations of the school, published with its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works, such as Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738 which were used in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). In the following years, the professors’ conference which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered the books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963). Additionally, the «способ учения» prescribed the use of specific textbooks.
Hölterhof’s Немецкой Целлариус was used intensively at the grammar school. Only one year after its publication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and officially imposed it for use in German classes. The «способ учения» ordered that the class of German syntax should use Hölterhof’s German grammar and «Немецкой Целлариус», as well as Komenský’s “Видимый свет” (Orbis sensualium pictus), Formey’s “Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften” and Hoffmann’s “Zwei Bücher von der Zufriedenheit” (Белявский, 1955, p. 307f.).
Gottsched’s works which were used in the upper German classes (syntax and style), are listed in the book catalogue of the «учебная библиотека» [school library] attached to the minutes of the professors’ conference of January 15th 1765 [“Catalogus Librorum pro stipendiariis studiosis et discipulis universitatis et gymnasii moscuensis” – «список книг для учебной библиотеки» (Пенчко, 1962, p. 29)] Moreover, pupils were awarded with Gottsched’s works at the annual public exams (e.g., Пенчко, 1962, pp. 129, 131).

Personal records: Originally from Paris.
Career: Governor at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg until 1779, he was also a tutor for Prince Alexander Borisovich Kurakin (1752–1818), chancellor of the Russian Orders, current private counselor, and member of the State Council. Letters from Picard addressed from Saint Petersburg to Kurakin are known, who accompanied Grand Duke Paul and his wife on their trip to Europe in 1781–1782. The tutor reports on fashions, news from the court, as well as literary, artistic, diplomatic, and other news. For instance, in October 1781, he writes about the trend of travel that had spread among Russian nobles and informs Kurakin about the opening of a new theater opposite the Summer Garden. He pays particular attention to theatrical performances at the Hermitage, the Cadet Corps, the theater of the Frenchman Pochet, etc. The old tutor regrets not knowing Russian well enough to send the prince excerpts from new Russian literary works. However, he most often reports on news and gossip concerning the empress and the high-ranking figures of her court: Prince Potemkin, Count Semion Vorontsov, Counts Skavronski, etc. His letters are considered a valuable source on Petersburg society of that time. It is likely the same individual who authored, in 1783, a collection of prose and poetry presented to Miss Passek (Russian State Library, RGB, fonds 183/1, dos. 3326, 73 f., containing excerpts from works by French authors, primarily from the 18th century, noted in Les Archives de l’Est et la France des Lumières). Already settled in Moscow in January 1777, he was residing there in 1793 in the 5th district when he took the 1793 oath. This is certainly the same Picard who frequented the home of Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov in Moscow at that time. Having once made a joke regarding a Russian lord, Picard was reprimanded by Shuvalov, who believed that an émigré who had found refuge with the Russians had an obligation of gratitude towards his hosts.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (till 1779, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Prince Alexander Borisovich Kurakin.

Personal records: (or Pizki) (*1735, Welau, Prussia) Married to a German woman, the marriage was celebrated in Saint Petersburg. Religion: Lutheran.
Career: In 1755, aged twenty-five, Picker came to Russia as a painter’s apprentice and worked several years exercising this profession. In 1764 he opened a private boarding school.  He lived in the house belonging to the tailor Olshinsky, in Ofitserskaya street (2nd Admiralty part of Saint Petersburg) and opened his school in the same house. The Commission of the Academy of Sciences, which inspected this school in April 1780, noticed that the classroom was too small for such a large number of pupils (53). However, the Commission remarked positively that the dormitory was separate from the classroom.  Apart from the German lessons, Picker taught Scripture history, read Luther’s Great Catechism with pupils, and taught basic French, Russian and arithmetic. The Commission noticed that pupils were quite successful in studying German, the history of religion, counting and writing; however, they could not really learn French and Russian well. His boarding school still existed in 1784 (near the Siny bridge, opposite the garden of Count Chernyshev). He taught German and French. In French he used the grammar by Pepliers, translated with pupils’ texts from French into German, but 'did not show spelling'. The inspector noticed that Picker 'did not have a good level for teaching French and ought to find a good teacher'. The separation of children into classes was noted positively by the inspector.
Teaching institutions and families: Private boarding school (from 1764 till 1784 at least, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Children from the families of merchants, carpenters, tailors, hairdressers, locksmiths, butchers, shoemakers, weavers and one ribbon maker.
In 1780 there were 53 pupils in his boarding school, 17 girls and 36 boys aged from eight to sixteen years. The names of these pupils are known: son of the bookseller Emmanuel Scheibner; three children  of the dance teacher Briukhov; daughter of a smith Aksiniia (those three were on full board); and numerous pupils without board: son of the hairdresser Fischer; son and daughter of the merchant Hartkop; son of the cabinet maker or carpenter Zumfort; three children of the widow Kraptsova; son of the turner Goman; two children of the major Lehman; son of the tailor Donapfel; son of the hairdresser Weber;  son of the tailor Towanius; son of the tailor Schenwal; son of the cabinet maker or carpenter Kligart; son of the assessor Kolesnikov; two sons of the cabinet maker or carpenter Begero; son of the footman Lund; son of the doctor Bergman; son of the coppersmith Heierman; son of the butcher Schober; two sons of the cabinetmaker or carpenter Zimmerman; son of the butler Liubimov; son of the shoemaker Klotz; son of the tailor Olshinsky; son of the tin smith Hakker; son of the wine trader Walman; son of the tailor Lazar; son of the army officer Volkov; son of the tailor Wulf; son of the maker of fur coats Brant; daughter of a gunmaker; daughter of the cabinet maker or carpenter Simsen; two daughters of the locksmith Farquist; daughter of the saddler Schmitt; daughter of the tailor Liubi; daughter of the glove maker Dannoberg; daughter of the "Tafeldecker" or table cloth maker Walter; daughter of the steward Rabe; daughter of the weaver Preiz; daughter of the ribbon  maker Buman; two daughters of the furrier Han; two daughters of the tailor Katner.
Teaching methods and materials:
German language (two lessons per week), dictations (four per week), German, French and Russian spelling (four lessons per week), translations.
Pepliers’ grammar.

Fullname: Pierredon, baron de Falguières, Vincent-Laurent de
Personal records: (or Laurent, Vincent; in Russia: Laurant Vincent or Vincent Laurant) (1745, Alès, Gard – 1830-05-20, Geneva, at 196 (currently 37), Grande Rue). From a Protestant family of the Cevennes nobility, whose first known ancestor lived in 1588; seigneur de Falguières, de Saint-Étienne-Vallée-Française, du Mazel, de La Rouvière, de Lepausadou, co-seigneur de Serres and du Meyran, de Ferron. Arms: Azure, a pyramid rock in silver surmounted by a golden sun; with a chief sewn in red, charged with a silver crescent flanked by two silver stars. Married in Russia to: Marie-Élisabeth Ferron (†Moscow, buried at Saint Louis of the French on 4 August 1795), governess at the Smolny Institute for Noble Girls. Son: Alexandre de Pierredon (*1793-09-01, Saint Petersburg; godfather: Prince (?) Saltykov (the first Prince Saltykov, Nikolai Ivanovich, was created prince in 1814); godmother: Countess Miatleva (†1886-10-26, Villereversure, Ain, Château de Noblens)), brigadier in the honor guard regiment of the Léman department in 1813, knight of the Order of the Lily, holder of the Saint Helena medal, later a merchant, converted to Catholicism at the age of eighty; married on 23 December 1825, in Geneva to Françoise-Jacqueline-Louise or Fanny Arlaud (1802-03-03, Geneva – 1871-06-29, Chimilin, hamlet of Buclin, Isère), a miniature painter, daughter of Jérémie Arlaud known as the Roman, director of the Free School of Drawing, and Anne-Louise Caldesaigues; with three children. Vincent-Laurent de Pierredon likely remarried in Geneva to Marie-Madeleine Fillion (ar. 1762, Geneva? – 1825-03-05, Grand-Saconnex).
Career: After studying in Paris, Vincent-Laurent de Pierredon is said to have met Prince Vladimir Sergeyevich Dolgoruki (1717–1803), then attached to the Russian embassy, and he was responsible for the education of his son, starting in 1775 at the latest. He traveled several times with his pupil, which led him to visit the Prussian court multiple times, where Prince Dolgoruki had been appointed ambassador (1767–1791). Vincent-Laurent de Pierredon emigrated to Russia before 1785, where he is found, under the name Vincent Laurent, as secretary of the Admiralty College with Count Ivan Grigorievich Chernyshev (1726–1797), minister of the Navy. He resided in Saint Petersburg when he took the 1793 oath. He was a witness at the Delahaye/Dupont marriage on 27 November 1794, at Saint Catherine of Alexandria. He was appointed a knight of Saint Vladimir, 3rd class, and was pensioned. He left Russia in 1799 or 1800 and went to Brussels, then to the Geneva region, where he settled permanently. He purchased a property in Grand-Saconnex around 1804. A Freemason, 1st degree in 1775 in the lodges of the Union of the Three Globes, a member of the 3rd degree (absent in 1783) of the Genant Irene lodge in Memel (currently Klaipeda, Lithuania). A miniature of Vincent-Laurent de Pierredon was executed by Ritt (1793) in Saint Petersburg, as well as one of his son Alexandre.
Teaching institutions and families: Dolgoruki family
Students and their social status: Son of the Prince Vladimir Sergeyevich Dolgoruki.

Personal records: (*1722-07-06, Lyon) Father: Pierre Pinay.
Career:
French governor, “pensioner of the King of Poland,” François Pinay was engaged at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in 1772. As early as July 1772, he requested leave due to poor health.
He was still in Saint Petersburg in January 1776.
He was in Moscow in 1779 and was preparing to return to France, accompanying a child named Deforges.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1772, Saint Petersburg).
Teaching methods and materials: He presented the Academy of Fine Arts with a comprehensive program of studies and education for the students: “Nothing is as important as the early education of children in their first years; they are young plants that must be cultivated with precision and, above all, with a lot of gentleness in everything they are taught, without imposing it as a duty, which would discourage them instead of encouraging them. Noble feelings that correspond to the birth of those who have given them life must be instilled in them; through this means, they become good citizens capable of serving their country. They should always have before their eyes the noble deeds of great men and be made to abhor the bad.”
Sources and bibliography: ANF, AE BI 988, f° 155 v°, inv. reg. chanc., consulat, Saint-Pétersbourg; RGIA, fonds 789, inv. 1, dos. 459, f° 19-21.

Personal records:
(†1776-12-26/1777-01-06, Saint Petersburg). Married to: Catherine Courtin. Father of seven children including:
  • Érasme Pincemaille;
  • Ève Pincemaille, Mme Ponlaville;
  • Noël Pincemaille.
Career: Perfumer in Metz, Érasme Pincemaille was also, in 1764, the venerable of Saint-Jean de la Candeur, Orient of Metz, at the time of its official constitution by the Grand Lodge of France. He was accused there of engaging in the commerce of Freemasonry, specifically selling high-degree notebooks to brothers who had received lower degrees. He was the Second Grand Inspector of the Provincial Lodge of Metz, presided over by Baron de Tschudy, who was tasked with formally notifying Pincemaille. He resigned in 1766, presenting himself in a letter addressed to the Grand Lodge as “an honest bourgeois, whose small business, his profession, and the care of providing for a large family must take precedence” (quoted from Beaurepaire, 2004-II). It is likely that through the Masonic network in Metz and his “Russians” such as Tschudy and Meunier de Précourt, Pincemaille was inspired to go to Russia. He is indeed found in Moscow around 1775. A merchant in Moscow, associated with Jean-Baptiste Prins, he primarily sold fine groceries and toiletries and beauty products: “lemon essence, powder, rosemary essence, jars of pomade, starch, cologne water, burning pastilles, coral, jars of white for providence, jars of red, pomade for hair growth, soaps and soap bars, makeup, orgeat syrup, almond powder, blonde, red, gray.” He also sold theater costumes, “clothes for theatrical use,” and outfits “Greek, peasant, Mordovian,” likely due to his daughter, Ève Pincemaille, who was a popular actress during the reign of Catherine II. Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon) became acquainted with him in December 1775: he one day visited Pincemaille, “who is a very great Mason,” accompanied by the actor Dugué. Pincemaille taught Corberon two secrets, one of which was to combat fever and involved mixing five Pater with a paste of cut nails... “One would hardly believe,” commented Corberon, “that in the eighteenth century, the age of philosophy, such traits are reported, but reason does not always come with age.” He was Master in the chair of the Réunion des Etrangers, a predominantly French lodge, in Moscow in 1775. The widow of Pincemaille resided in the Orel government when she took the 1793 oath. She lived in Moscow in 1798.

SPbV, 1793, no. 86.
Bakunin; Serkov, p. 954; Beaurepaire, 2004-I, 2004-II.

Personal records: Father: Érasme Pincemaille. Mother: Catherine Courtin.
Career: Professor at the gymnasium of Moscow University starting in 1786. A Freemason, he was master in the chair of the Constance (Postoyanstva) lodge founded in April 1784 in Moscow, affiliated with the Zu den drei Fahnen lodge, of which he was also a member.
Teaching institutions and families: Gymnasium of Moscow University (from 1786).
Sources and bibliography: Serkov, p. 953, 957.

Personal records: (*1759, Lunéville) Married to: Alexandra, daughter of the college assessor Adamovich.
Career: French teacher. He lived with his wife in the Moskovskaya part of Saint Petersburg, in the house of merchant Kazulin at No. 118, at the residence of the current State counselor Goriainov, when he took the oath of allegiance to Russia in 1806.

Personal records:
(or Pinget)
Probably from the Pinguet de Suzemont family, established in Lorraine, Picardy, and Vendômois, which bore: Sable with a lowered gold eagle.
Married and father of two children.
Career: Tutor. Joseph de Pinguet claimed to be a member of the Academy of Arcades of Rome, a knight of Saint Sepulchre, and a graduate of the University of Paris. He passed an examination in 1762 at Moscow University intended for foreign tutors and received permission to teach French, Latin, Italian, history, and geography. He was admitted to teach at the gymnasium of Moscow University in 1762. In 1763, he complained to the university about the abuses committed against him by his employer “Gregoroff,” who ordered him to leave his home while retaining all his belongings. The university, eager to assert its “independence,” intervened and obtained from the governor of Moscow that his belongings be returned “in accordance with justice.” He lived in 1770 in Moscow in the house of tailor Jean Goutte, located between Petrovka and Dimitrovka streets. He offered to serve as a tutor in French, Italian, Latin, geography, and general history. In 1777, he was an assistant to the French lecturer at the university. He announced in the Moskovskie Vedomosti that he could teach “at home” for lords and welcome students to his home.
Teaching institutions and families: Gymnasium of Moscow University (from 1762).
Language and other teaching books by the:
He sold a book of his own composition, published by Moscow University:
  • Рассуждение о воспитании, нарочно сочиненное для Российского юношества ou Raisonnement sur l’éducation composée exprès à l’intention de la jeunesse russe, in Russian and French for 25 kopecks per copy.

Personal records: (Paris – 1777, Saint Petersburg) Father: François Pochet, former illuminator to the king. Mother: Marie Thibert. Sister: Marie Pochet, wife of Grangé. Married to: 1.) Catherine Boullangé, daughter of François Boullangé, bourgeois of Lunéville († av.1766) and Catherine Boullangé; niece of Christophe Planchenault (marriage concluded on 14/25 January 1766; witnesses: Jean Michel, merchant, Pierre Beaumont); 2.) Claude-Victoire Ancelet (*Paris) (marriage concluded on 28 January 1773 in the Catholic church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria in St. Petersburg; witnesses: Pierre Grangé, dancer and ballet master, Antonio Amati). Daughter from the 2nd marriage: Magdeleine-Adélaïde Pochet (*Saint-Pétersbourg, bapt. on 28 January 1777 by abbé de La Force, chaplain to the French legation; godfather: Nicolaus Slallemberg; godmother: Marie-Élisabeth Carbonier, née Guibal). He left over £200,000 in debts in Paris at his death.
Career: St. Petersburg merchant and actor in the service of the Empress. In 1762, the St. Petersburg Academy of Fine Arts purchased mathematical instruments and architectural drawings from him. Through him, Duhamel du Monceau sent a copy of his work Exploitation des bois (Paris, 1764, 2 vols.) to the Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg. In 1765, when Mahomet was performed in Tsarskoe Selo, he played one of the characters in Voltaire's tragedy . He was probably a member of the Comédie-Française troupe. On 25 June 1770, Alexandre Pochet was granted a privilege to establish a French theater in St. Petersburg and, according to Corberon (Bourrée, chevalier de Corberon) , a position worth six hundred rubles at the Cadet Corps as "intendant des plaisirs et répétiteur des enfants" (steward of pleasures and repetiteur of children) who were made to play comedy. Catherine II saw him as an "intriguer by trade". In 1772, the Academy refused to admit Pochet as professor of theatrical declamation. He was a witness, as was his wife, to the Grangé/Pochet marriage contract on 22 October 1769, and godfather to Jean-Alexandre Grangé on 24 October 1771, at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records: (*1715-03-22, Berlin) Father: Henri Pontet. Mother: Charlotte Sophie Jercelat. Married to: a French woman. Religion: Protestant.
Career: Tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg in 1757, where he taught French to the children of brigadier of the leib company, lieutenant Matvey Evenski. It seems he also ran an educational boarding house. He requested to take the examination for tutors at the Academy of Sciences in order to obtain a certificate of aptitude. The examiners found that Pontet was unable to teach French according to the “principles,” that is, grammar, but he could teach its practical use to young children. He received this certificate on 4 June 1757. He then taught at the Noble Cadet Corps alongside six other professors, including two Frenchmen, Louis Boujot and Daniel Feray, two Germans, and two Russians, one of whom was Vasili Bunin, the author of a French grammar.
Teaching institutions and families: Evenski family; an educational boarding house (?); Noble Cadet Corps, all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status: Children of lieutenant Matvey Evenski.

Personal records:
(1720-07-01, Yuriev-Polskoi of Suzdal Governorate, Russian Empire – 1782-07-15, Voronezh, Russian Empire).
Son of a deacon.
Education: Popov began his studies at the Moscow Slavonic Greek Latin Academy. In late 1735, he and eleven other students, among them Mikhail Lomonosov and Ivan Golubtsev, were sent to the Academy School in Saint Petersburg, where they became scholarship students. The group was supervised by the adjunct V.E. Adodurov. Apparently, the students first started to learn German under the guidance of the teacher Christian Hermann. The lessons took place daily between 6 and 7 oʼclock in the morning. In December 1736, Popov and some other members of this group were enrolled in the Latin section of the Academy School. Popov attended the grammar class and also continued the German classes with Christian Hermann. In February 1738, the group is still mentioned in Hermannʼs reports.
Career: In September 1740, Popov was appointed translator for the Russian Assembly at the Academy of Science. Like many other translators at the Academy, Popov was obliged to teach at the Academy School. He is documented as teacher of the medium German class from October 1741 until March 1742. The inspector of the Academy School, G.W. Krafft, mentions Popov in his reports rather negatively. Due to Popovʼs frequent being absent from school, Krafft recommended dismissing him from his duties as German teacher. Thereupon, the Academy Chancellery warned Popov hid salary would be cut if he did not change his behaviour. Finally, Popov himself asked to be relieved of his duties as German teacher. In March 1742, he was released from his position in the German class, as the number of pupils had declined and the remaining two teachers Golubtsev and Fischer could manage them on their own. In October 1744, Popov was assigned to the professor of astronomy Joseph-Nicolas Delisle to further improve his knowledge in this field, including practical guidance in observation. After Delisle’s departure from Russia in 1747, Popov continued his studies in astronomy under the guidance of professor Christian Nicolaus von Winsheim. In 1748, Popov became an adjunct of the Academy and was made responsible for lectures in theoretical astronomy for students at the academic university. In March 1751, he was appointed professor of astronomy. In 1761, Popov was one of the Russian scientists who were sent to Siberia for the observation of the Venus transit. However, the results of Popovʼs observations in Irkutsk were not published and it is not quite clear whether they were successful or not. In May 1765, Popov is documented with the rank “aulic councillor” (надворный советник). In 1768, Popov was dismissed from the Academy, presumably upon his own request. Later, Popov was engaged as assistant to the governor in Voronezh, where he died in 1782.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
Higher nobility; army officers; сivil servants; craftsmen; soldiers; farmers; servants.
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils, aged between six and twenty, attending the Academy School during this period of time. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. The names of a large number of these pupils are known and listed in the pupil registers including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
There were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils, among them nobles and non-nobles. The family background of the pupils was very diverse, ranging from the higher nobility, army officers and officials such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants.
Teaching methods and materials: Popov actively advocated the interests of native Russian students at the Academy School. For example, in December 1742, he blamed the Academy Chancellery for recruiting only German teachers who did not have any knowledge of Russian for the instruction of German and Latin. From Popov’s point of view, this policy explicitly tried to put native Russian pupils at a disadvantage, as they lost several years learning German which was necessary to understand the teachers. According to Popov, Russian pupils needed about six or seven years to learn enough German to be able to follow Latin classes. After this period, Popov pointed out, the students did not have enough time left to learn Latin which was indispensable for university studies. That way, in Popovʼs opinion, the Academy Chancellery would prohibit Russians from access to academic education, so that the German scholars would not lose their importance and their posts at the Russian Academy of Sciences.
Language and other teaching books by the: Popov translated scientific literature and articles from the “Saint Petersburg newspaper” (Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti) with its calendars and writings on astronomy. Not all of his works or observations were published.

Personal records: (or Petr) (1762, Russian Empire – 1789, Kharkiv, Russian Empire). Son of a church officer (minister) Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1775 to 1786, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theology class.
Career: We know that immediately after graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium, Petr Popov began teaching Latin at the same school. He died in 1789.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium.
Students and their social status: Clergy. Between 1786 and 1789, more than 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The grammar class taught by Petr Popov had 50 students. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Petr Popov, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Petr Popov worked at the Kharkiv Collegium as a Latin teacher, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, that were written by the Bishop of Belgorod, Samuil Mislavsky, in 1769 and addressed to the rector, to the prefect and to teachers, were in use at the Collegium. Latin grammar classes were based on Johann Matthias Gesner’s version of the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. Surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of the 1770–1780s show that, as a rule, students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. In addition, students translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. The library of the Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Personal records: (or Potapski) (*Prussia ?)
Education: Potapsky was one of the first pupils at the Academy School, where he is documented on 13 September 1727. Two years later, in September 1729, he became a student at the academic university.
Career: Similarly to other students of the academic university, Potapsky was recruited as a teacher for the Academy School. In September 1732, he took over the position of the teacher Styx, who had died, and became teacher of class five, also known as the lower (“нижний”) class or Quinta, for an annual salary of 100 roubles. He was supervised by his colleague Christian Herrmann, teacher of class four (Quarta). In 1735, Potapsky was still in this position and asked for his annual salary to be increased to 150 roubles, because his predecessor Styx earned that sum. Whether Potapsky got the salary rise or not is unknown. In February 1739, he still worked in the German section of the Academy School, presumably first and foremost in the medium class (“средний”). In April 1741, Potapsky left the Academy School at his own request.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1732–1741, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status:
In the first half of the 18th century, the Academy School and the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) list about 820 pupils attending the Academy School during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German. The names of a large number of these pupils, aged between 6 and 20, are known and listed in the pupil registers including information about their social backgrounds and learning progress.
The most detailed report of the number and social status of all students, who were registered at the Academy School and learned German, had been written by the rector of the German Section of the Academy School Martin Schwanwitz in November 1736. In principle, there were two different categories of students, attending the Academy School: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitz’ report lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was very diverse, ranging from the higher nobility, army officers and officials such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants.
Teaching methods and materials:
Potapsky started as teacher of the German class five (Quinta), where he taught German reading, writing and grammar (only for the older pupils) and also Latin reading and spelling. Later on, Potapsky (also) worked in the medium class. He also gave lessons in geography and spelling (e.g., in December 1737).
The learning contents of the medium class consisted in grammar, conversation, vocabulary and simple exercises to be translated from Russian into German, as documented in the curriculum of March 1735. 
In February 1739, the rector of the German section in the Academy School, Martin Schwanwitz, reported that his two colleagues M. Potapsky and J.G. Oestermann were having great difficulties because of the large number of pupils in their classes. Particularly the grading of numerous translation exercises posed a problem. In this context, Schwanwitz mentions the difficulty in hiring teachers who knew both German and Russian. He therefore suggested training some of his most skilled students as teachers. One may conclude from this report that Potapsky himself knew Russian. More evidence of this is the fact the Potapsky translated a Latin Grammar into Russian.
Another problem mentioned in Schwanwitz’s report was the teaching of writing. Most of the Russian pupils could not write in Russian or had difficulty in writing in Russian. According to Schwanwitz, it was almost impossible for the teachers to teach the large number of pupils writing in Latin, German and Russian. Therefore, Schwanwitz requested the purchase of copperplate engraved, printed writing samples (“in Kupfer gestochene Vorschriften”) to sell them to the pupils. This was intended to help the pupils to learn writing and facilitate the “hard work” of the teachers.

German calendar.

Potapsky most probably used the textbooks that were printed at the Academy or generally used there for teaching German.
Language and other teaching books by the: In his report of February 1739, Schwanwitz noted that Potapsky translated a Latin grammar, the very popular schoolbook “Märcksche grammatic” (Compendium grammaticae latinae, oder: Kurtzer Auszug aus der größeren Lateinischen Grammatica Marchica, Berlin, 1716), into Russian and recommended printing it. Hereupon Schwanwitz got the order to deliver the translation to the Russian conference, so that it could be revised by the conference members. However, it is not clear whether the conference really revised Potapskyʼs manuscript which, in the end, remained unprinted. Some years later, it was Potapskyʼs colleague V.I. Lebedev, who translated this Latin grammar into Russian, probably using Potapskyʼs work. It was published in 1746 (Сокращение грамматики латинской, St. Petersburg, 1746).

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Iosif Prilutsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: All we know about Iosif Prilutsky is that he taught the phara (analogy) and infima classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1768–1769 school year and that later he taught grammar, syntax and rhetoric classes.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (from 1768).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. It is known that at the beginning of the 1760s there were several dozen students in grammar classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) which Iosif Prilutsky taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. Iosif Prilutsky also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. When Iosif Prilutsky worked at the Pereiaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Ivan Prokhorovsky is that he was a teacher in the higher Latin grammar class at the Pereiaslav Collegium from 1795 to 1798. At the same time, he taught Ancient Greek. In subsequent years, Ivan Prokhorovsky was no longer on the list of teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1795–1798).
Students and their social status: Clergy; Cossacks. In the second half of the 1790s, several dozen students learned Latin in the grammar classes of the Pereiaslav Collegium. Most of the students who learned Ancient Greek, were from the rhetoric class; a few were from the philosophy and theology classes (more than 20 students studied the language). In total, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Collegium in these years. Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Ivan Prokhorovsky taught Latin grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. He also taught Ancient Greek grammar and syntax. At the end of the 18th century, the Pereiaslav Collegium had well-established standards for teaching Ancient Greek. The first year of teaching was devoted to grammar. Syntax was apparently taught during the second year. Ivan Prokhorovsky’s Latin grammar classes were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The Collegium had a great number of books by Cellarius, published in different years, so that each student had a book. It is known that the direction of the Pereiaslav Collegium bought these books several times in quantities of more than 100 copies at a time. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students show that they also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. There were also a great number of copies of this book, published in different years. Grammar rules were taught using the book on Ancient Greek written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declensions and conjugations, the teacher and his students were supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. During the second year of studies, students were supposed to memorise short sentences from several lexicons that the teacher had. There were several lexicons, dictionaries and grammar books on Ancient Greek at the Pereiaslav Collegium. Some of them entered the library of the Collegium from the personal collection of the Pereiaslav bishop Job Bazilevich (who had once taught Ancient Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium). Personal records: (or Andrei Semionovich) (1756-11-28, the town of Novy Sanzhary in the Poltava Regiment, Russian Empire – 1826-01-29, Kharkiv, Russian Empire). Andrei Prokopovich was from a senior noble family living in the Poltava Regiment. He inherited lands in the Ivanovsky khutir (hamlet) in the Kharkiv Governorate. In 1792, Andrei Prokopovich was included in the first part of the “Family Register of the Nobility of the Kharkiv Viceroyalty”, in which it was recorded that he was married and had three children. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Although many reference publications indicate that Andrei Prokopovich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, numerous documents indicate that he only studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including in the theology class. He studied Latin, Greek and German; apparently, he also studied Polish at the Collegium.
Career:
Immediately after graduation from the Kharkiv Collegium in 1780, Andrei Prokopovich taught Latin in the grammar and syntax classes (until 1782). Then he successively taught poetics, rhetoric, philosophy (from 1791 on) and theology (from 1794 on) classes. He was also the Prefect of the school. When he became a teacher, Andrei Prokopovich was soon after ordained a priest and became a priest at Saint Nicolas’ Church, then protoiereus and a member of the Kharkiv spiritual direction. From 1796 onwards, he served as rector at the Assumption Cathedral in Kharkiv (without leaving teaching). In 1798, he was the first of the Kharkiv clergy to be awarded a gold pectoral cross. On 29 March 1801 Andrei Prokopovich was appointed rector at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1803, he was awarded the 2nd class Order of Saint Anne. He took an active part in the creation of the Kharkiv University. He was elected an honorary member of the Society of Sciences of the Kharkiv University. In 1822, he was dismissed from the post of rector on charges which were later dismissed in the course of a long investigation which ended in the Synod in 1825. Soon after, he died.
As rector of the Assumption Cathedral in Kharkiv, Andrei Prokopovich explained publicly the Apostolic Letters over 20 years on Sundays and Feast Days. His sermons were considered exemplary, as was repeatedly noted by local bishops. In 1795, one of his sermons was published in Moscow. Andrei Prokopovich did a great job of popularising academic knowledge (primarily concerning agriculture). He had a direct involvement in all the first editions of the first Kharkiv printing house, established under the prikaz (department) of public charity (he was either a translator or an initiator of publications). His cooperation with Kharkiv University resulted in publishing several Latin chrestomathies which were used by students at the Collegium, and at the University. At the beginning of the 19th century, a number of his translations of Western European authors were published (he did them together with the students of the Collegium). Andrei Prokopovich included a description of the Governorate, the town of Kharkiv and the Kharkiv Collegium in some of his publications (menologies and calendars) which were the first publications of regional studies in Ukraine, destined to familiarise a broad population of readers with the distinctive features and history of the region. In the 1820s, he focused on theological works, some of which were published. In his opening remarks, the author noted that the publications were a part of the course which he presented at the Kharkiv Collegium.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1780–1822).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
At the beginning of the 1780s, more than 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the grammar classes which Andrei Prokopovich taught.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar and syntax classes taught by Andrei Prokopovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Andrei Prokopovich worked at the Kharkiv Collegium as a Latin teacher, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach,” written by the Bishop Samuil Mislavsky of Belgorod in 1769 and addressed to the rector, to the prefect and to teachers, were in use at the Collegium. The document gives a complete idea of the teaching of basic school disciplines, including foreign languages. The instructions indicated the need for Latin grammar teaching according to the book by Christoph Cellarius in Johann Matthias Gesner’s version published at Moscow University in 1762 instead of the book by Alvarez which was used at the Kharkiv Collegium in the first half of the 18th century. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also pointed out that grammar rules were necessarily supposed to be consolidated by reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. Samuil Mislavsky’s book bore the Russian name as well as the original one. The instructions contained detailed recommendations on the organisation of classroom and homework exercises for students. It listed the sections and paragraphs of the books that the teacher was supposed to be guided by at various stages of teaching. In his Instructions, Samuil Mislavsky also focused on methods that would allow students to consolidate “lighthearted vocabulary, intelligent designs, prompt responses and pleasant adventures of eminent men” in their memory. For this purpose, he advised teachers to use the book “Reasonable Comrade” (Семенов П. Товарищ разумной и замысловатой, или Собрание хороших слов, разумных замыслов, скорых ответов, учтивых насмешек и приятных приключений знатных мужей древняго и нынешняго веков, Moscow, 1787). In addition, the author of the Instructions advised teachers not to bother their students with learning rules and exceptions by heart, in order to keep them studying with interest. He drew the attention of teachers to the fact that a child could learn all the best grammar rules, but it would not help him understand or write, if he did not use them constantly in his own translations. It is important to note that all the books were available at the library of the Kharkiv Collegium (they were bought purposefully, quite a few books being granted by Samuil Mislavsky). According to the library catalogue of 1769, the Collegium had several different books by Cellarius and Lange. Their number exceeded ten at the time. Besides that, the library had a few modern dictionaries, lexicons by different authors, published in Halle and other centres (unfortunately, the book descriptions do not make it possible to identify them accurately). At the beginning of the 19th century (in 1810–1811, 1817), Latin chrestomathies compiled by Andrei Prokopovich for students of poetics and rhetoric classes were printed, including many examples from works by Latin poets. Chrestomathies were not only used by the students of the Collegium, but also by the University students. Although the books were printed at the beginning of the 19th century, they were prepared for publication much earlier. The publication was delayed, because there was no typography (printing house) in Kharkiv. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including the theology class.
Career: All that is known concerning Simeon Prokopovich is that he taught the phara and infima classes at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1739–1740 school year and the grammar and syntax classes the following year. We know that he continued teaching in subsequent years and was a poetics teacher in 1746.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereiaslav Collegium (1739–1746).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In total, 124 students were enrolled at the Pereiaslav Collegium in the 1740–1741 school year. There were several dozen students in the classes which Simeon Prokopovich taught.
Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy) which Simeon Prokopovich taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at Orthodox collegiums. Simeon Prokopovich also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The Latin textbook used at the Pereiaslav Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the 1740s was “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that their teachers used the textbook by Alvarez and that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereiaslav Collegium. [Alvarez, Emmanuel], Emmanuelis Alvari ... (Paris – 1765-01, Moscow)
Married. 
The Capuchins serving the Catholic Church in Moscow refused him burial on the grounds that he had not provided certain evidence of his religion during his life and that he was a Freemason. At the insistence of the deceased's widow, the most obstinate of the Capuchins were banished from the empire, reported a French diplomat in his correspondence on 19 March 1765. Catherine II alluded to this incident in her correspondence with Voltaire in a letter dated 22 August 1765.
Career: Military officer, pamphleteer, teacher, and publisher. A French colonel in the service of Poland, Jacques Préclos de Léry arrived in Saint Petersburg in January 1763 without a letter of recommendation. He was presented to the Conference of Moscow University by the university curator Adodurov on 29 November 1763. Admitted as a lecturer at Moscow University after Bilon, he remained in this position until his death. His position was taken over by Henri de Lavie.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (till 1765).

He had edited a French newspaper in Frankfurt am Main for a time and would have begun, starting in 1764, the publication of a French-language journal in Moscow (not identified). He delivered a speech at Moscow University assembly in 1764. This speech was published:

A panegyric to Catherine II signed by Léry is found in the archives of J. Stählin (RNB, Mss, fonds 871, no. 872). Préclos de Léry also pointed out inaccuracies in Dilthey's Universal History.

Personal records: (1770-04-12, Austria – 1807-01-05, Polatsk, Vitsebsk Governorate, Russian Empire). Brother: Alois Puell (1767–1796). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Upon arriving in Russia in 1788, Anton Puell joined the Society of Jesus and studied at the Polatsk novitiate for two years (1788–1790). In 1797–1801, he studied theology at the Polatsk Collegium.
Career: Priest. After graduation from the novitiate, Anton Puell taught German (1790–1791, 1793–1795) and rhetoric (1794–1795) at the Orsha Jesuit Collegium. He also taught Latin grammar and German at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium (1791–1793) and at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium (1796–1797). In 1797–1799, Puell studied in the theology class at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium and at the same time taught German. After graduation, he became a teacher of philosophy and mathematics in Polatsk.

Personal records: (1778-12-31 – 1824-12-26, Pilzno, Austrian Empire). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Wincenty Raciborski entered the Society of Jesus in August 1793, spent two years at the novitiate in Polatsk, then studied rhetoric at the Orsha Collegium (1795–1796), and philosophy (1796–1798) and theology (1804–1808) at the Polatsk Collegium.
Career:
Priest. After graduation from the philosophy class, Raciborski was sent to the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium to teach Latin grammar and French (1798–1799). During the 1799–1800 academic year, he taught the same subjects at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium. Then, from 1800 to 1802, he taught rhetoric and poetics at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. He taught the same subjects as well as French at the Orsha Collegium (1802–1803) and the Vitsebsk Collegium (1803–1804). Upon completion of his education in Polatsk, Raciborski was sent to Saint Petersburg, where he was a boarding school regent (head) (1808–1809) and a teacher of rhetoric, poetics and Russian (1809–1811) at the Saint Petersburg Collegium Nobilium. Upon the opening of the mission of the Order in the estate of Count August Ilyinski, in the village of Romanov in Volhynia, Raciborski became its rector; from 1817, he was the rector of the local Collegium.
After the expulsion of the Society of Jesus from Russia, W. Raciborski left for Galicia, where he was a missionary in the village of Pilzno from 1821 until his death in 1824.

Personal records: (*1756, Sotnia town of Devitsa in the Nizhyn Regiment, Russian Empire). Ivan Radishevsky was born in a Cossack family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy from 1773 to 1784, including in the theology class.
Career: All we know concerning Ivan Radishevsky is that after his graduation in 1784 he became a higher-grammar-class teacher at the Chernihiv Collegium. Soon afterwards he left teaching.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1784).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
At the beginning of the 1780s, approximately 400 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the lower grammar class taught by Ivan Radishevsky.
Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ivan Radishevsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ivan Radishevsky worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Chernihiv Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records: Married to: Marguerite Deschamps, daughter of Deschamps († before 1762) and Thérèse Palouard (living on Rue Saint-Jacques, parish of Saint-Benoît in Paris).
Career:
First French lecturer at Moscow University in 1757, Guillaume Raoult was replaced by the lecturer Bilon in 1759. He is said to have been the French language professor for the Grand Duke heir in 1758. He announced his return to France at the beginning of 1759; at that time, he lived on Millionnaya Street at the inn run by the Frenchman Bouvier. The Raoults lived in Moscow in October 1762 at the home of Prince Alexey Sergeyevich Golitsyn (1713–1765), a college counselor, married to Princess Anna Sergeyevna Dolgorukaya, who from 1764 to 1767 was the director of the Smolny Institute.
Marguerite Raoult, his wife, became the inspector of the Institute for Noble Girls (see Deschamps, Charlotte-Marguerite).
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (1757).
Students and their social status: Grand Duke Peter Feodorovich (future emperor Peter III) (?)
Teaching methods and materials: He committed to teaching French through Latin, and to “explain” Latin authors in French and French authors in Latin.

Personal records: (*German lands). Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Johann Recht was one of the first German teachers at the Moscow University Grammar School. He was engaged on 8 August 1756, as teacher of German writing, reading and calligraphy with an annual salary of 200 roubles. In May 1760 he had a pay rise and henceforth received 250 roubles. In the following years, Recht continued to teach the lower German class («нижный немецкий») as well as calligraphy. In 1766, he is documented as a teacher of Greek (Пенчко, 1960, р. 370). Recht is listed in the reports on the student’s yearly examination which always took place in June, until 1770.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to the Moscow University (1756–1770).
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at Moscow University which was founded in 1755 at the initiative of Mikhail Lomonosov with the aim of educating students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one department for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of sciences” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the start, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was achieved in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:

For the Grammar school attached to Moscow University and the university itself, the books used for learning foreign languages are quite well documented. Initially, the regulations of the school, published with its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works, for example Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738 which were used in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). In the following years, the professors’ conference which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 and 1963).
In general, grammar books were the main basis for language instruction in the 18th century. The grammar covered all important aspects of a language, not only the grammatical rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing too and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology,” which meant morphology, syntax and prosody.
Several German grammars were used in the late 1750s and early 1760s at the grammar school. Mikhail Lomonosov’s “School regulation” of 1758 prescribed J.Ch. Gottsched’s German grammar “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ for German classes (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459). Before, the school may have used M. Schwanwitz’ German grammar which was printed at the Academic University in St. Petersburg (4th edition in 1745). Still in 1758, Moscow University ordered 40 copies for the grammar school pupils (Пенчко, 1960, p. 140). From 1762 onwards, the grammar school used the German grammar of М. Агентов, teacher of the German syntax class at the grammar school itself, who had received the order to compose a new grammar for the school, probably in 1761 (Koch, 2002, p. 238).
Hölterhof’s “Немецкой Целлариус” was used intensively at the grammar school. Only one year after its publication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and imposed it officially for use in German classes (Пенчко, 1962, p. 255).
