Personal records: (1727-02-02, Luckau, Electorate of Saxony – 1778-10-25, Moscow). Father: Ernst Gottfried Reichel. Mother: Maria Elisabeth Reichel. Married to: Katharina Elisabeth Duven (1757-06-05, Hamburg). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Reichel enrolled at the University of Wittenberg on 4 April 1744. He completed his studies with a Master’s degree.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; German literature; history of literature; history; statistics.
Career:
Philologist. Reichel was a disciple of the German philosopher and critic Johann Christoph Gottsched (1700–1766) at the University of Leipzig.
After the foundation of Moscow University in 1755, the teaching staff was selected very carefully. Many, if not most, of the professors and teachers were enticed away from German universities. Concerning the teachers for German language and literature, Moscow University approached J.Ch. Gottsched through the intermediary of the historian G.F. Müller (Academy of Sciences, Saint Petersburg) and asked for the delegation of two tutors (see letter from G.F. Müller to Gottsched dated 10 December 1756, Lehmann, 1966, p. 97f.). Hereupon, Gottsched recommended Reichel and his colleague Christian Gottlieb Köllner (1729–1760), who were both sent to Moscow in 1757. Köllner received a teaching assignment for universal history, but died only three years later. Reichel became lecturer in German language and literature («Немецкая словесность»). The schedule of lectures at Moscow University in 1757 announced Reichel’s lectures as “German grammar and the rules of German oratory/rhetoric [«красноречие»] and about the history of philosophy and literature” (Объявление, 1757, p. 10). Reichel succeeded J.Ph. Lütke at the grammar school in August 1758 (Пенчко, 1960, p. 123). The very first years in Russia must have been quite hard for Reichel, in particular because not everybody at the university was in favour of him (e.g., the head of the grammar school, Johann Mathias Schaden, who was an opponent of Gottsched). Reichel’s letters to his benefactor G.F. Müller give some detailed information about these difficulties. For example, Reichel complained about the need to take extra-curricular employment as a private tutor in order to make ends meet. In his letter dated 11 December 1760, he wrote about the difficulties involved in making a living, teaching in the mornings in a family and in the afternoons at the university (Lehmann, 1966, p. 139f.) Finally, in 1761, Reichel was promoted professor of German language and literature. According to the schedule of lectures of 1763, he taught universal history, the foundations of German phrasing and the history of German literature (Реестр, 1763). In 1764, he became professor of history and statistics and stayed in this function until his death in 1778. In addition to his professorship, Reichel made a great contribution to the development of the university, serving as its first librarian. Furthermore, he actively promoted the translation activities of the students, amongst others by publishing a new periodical which was called «Собрание лучших сочинений к распространению знания и к произведению удовольствия или Смешанная Библиотека о разных Физических, Экономических, також до Мануфактур и до коммерции принадлежащих вещах». This journal contained a variety of scientific articles, translated by students, amongst them Denis and Pavеl Fonvizin. For financial reasons and because of dissent between Reichel and the contributors about the further content of the journal, it was stopped after only four issues in the course of the year 1762 (Биографич. словарь, 1855, p. 344ff.)
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University; Grammar school attached to Moscow University.
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
Denis Ivanovich Fonvizin; Pavel Ivanovich Fonvizin; Mikhail Naderin.
The grammar school at Moscow University which was founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative, with the intention of educating students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: one for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for European languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of sciences” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two categories of students: those in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the start, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was achieved in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
In his correspondence, Reichel described the concrete circumstances of language teaching at the grammar school of Moscow University, as it was practiced in the early 1760s. The most common method of grammar teaching in those days was undoubtedly the presentation of rules which had to be learned by heart by the students. It seems uncertain if rules were explained sufficiently for students to understand them and be able to apply them. As to this issue, Reichel wrote in December 1761: The teachers of the German class of ‘syntax’ “were not able to explain the rules by heart”, but they “dictated the rules and did not concern themselves with the explanation and application of the rules.” (Reichel, letter of 27 December 1761, cit. after Lehmann, 1966, p. 141). In the same letter, Reichel complained about the poor results of language teaching in general: “Students have to spend more than one year learning spelling, more than one year learning declension and conjugation and two years for syntax. However, when they finally get to phrasing, they are unable to write three lines in one hour and they also cannot read.” (Reichel, letter of 27 December 1761, cit. after Lehmann, 1966, p. 141).

The first years at the grammar school attached to Moscow University were characterized by a significant lack of textbooks for language tuition. There were only a few standard works which had been printed at the Academy’s University in Saint Petersburg and which were used at the Academic grammar school as well. One of these books was Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues”, issued in 1738 which was used in the lower German classes according to the regulations of the Moscow grammar school of 1755 (see: Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p. 298). Another standard work was M. Schwanwitz’s German grammar, printed in a fourth edition at the Academic University in St. Petersburg in 1745. It was very likely used at the beginning of the Moscow grammar school too. Still in 1758, Moscow University ordered 40 copies for the grammar school pupils (Пенчко, 1960, p. 140). In his correspondence to. G.F. Müller, Reichel commented on the lack of books. All the books needed for teaching his German phrasing class were organized by himself at his own expense (see letter of 12 March1761, cit. in Lehmann, 1966, p. 142f.) Very probably, these books were J.Ch. Gottsched’s “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ and „Kern der Deutschen Sprachkunst“ which were used by Reichel in his classes (see letter of Ch.G. Köllner to G.F. Müller of 17 October 1757, cit. in Lehmann, 1966, p. 119). In 1758, Gottsched’s “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst” was implemented officially by Mikhail Lomonosov’s school regulation (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459).
In general, grammar books made up the main basis for language instruction in the 18th century. Grammar books covered all important aspects of a language, not only the grammatical rules themselves. Therefore, pupils used a grammar book for learning reading and writing, and even for learning the correct pronunciation. Typically, a grammar book was organized in four main parts: spelling, “etymology”, which meant morphology, syntax and prosody.

An author of dramas, stories, tales and travel sketches. He wrote and published a biography of his grandfather, a famous theologian (Reinbeck G. Leben und Wirken des Dr. Th. Johann Gustav Reinbeck, Stuttgart, 1842).
Upon returning from Russia, he published travel sketches about his travels (Reinbeck G. Flüchtige Bemerkungen auf einer Reise von St. Petersburg über Moskwa, Grodno, Warschau, Breslau nach Deutschland im Jahre 1805: vol. 1–2, Leipzig, 1806), from September 1806 until Spring 1807, he lived in Weimar, and then in Heidelberg and Mannheim; in 1808, he settled in Stuttgart. He was a Mason. He was the editor of the “Morgenblatt für gebildete Stände”. From the spring of 1811, he worked as a professor of German, rhetoric and poetics in a gymnasium. He participated in major cultural projects in Stuttgart, including the creation of a reading union and an association for the installation of the F. Schiller monument. He became acquainted with the famous sculptor B. Thorvaldsen and contributed to the acquisition of Thorvaldsen’s works by the Stuttgart Art Collection. A monument to F. Schiller by Thorvaldsen was installed in Stuttgart in 1839. Reinbeck was known for his charitable activities. He received a chivalric order from the King of Württemberg for his social and cultural activities. He also received the title of honorary citizen of the city of Stuttgart. He retired in 1841.

At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few from the philosophy and theology classes) studied German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
Little is known about Remer’s teaching methods. Obviously, Karl Remer used books by Ilya Kopievsky (Kopievich), also known as “Nomenklator”, and by Johann Christoph Gottsched. He did not lack textbooks for students. He could use German grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Academy, primarily the lexicons by Erich Weismann (with different years of publication) and a number of other publications. As a part of the learning process, students also translated extracts from different books in German.

Personal records: (known as Résimont; in Russia: Ivan Stepanovich) (1768-01-17 or 1766, Toul, Meurthe-et-Moselle – 1844-03-02, Saint Petersburg; buried in the Volkovskoye Lutheran cemetery). Gentleman. Coat of arms: Or, a band gules and an azure quarter charged with a silver lion. Father: Etienne Résimont. Married to: Sophie-Frédérique-Wilhelmine de Lagarde (1780-07-24, Berlin – 1853-09-07, Pavlovsk; buried near her husband) (marriage concluded in Saint Petersburg in 1810 in the presence of Vasili Viskovatov, a member of the Academy of Sciences, Jacques-Alexandre Fabre, lieutenant-colonel attached to the Corps of Engineers of Communications (KIPS), future major-general, Charles Potier, captain attached to the same corps, future lieutenant-general and Director of KIPS, and Piotr Manicharov, steward of the Institute of Bridges and Roads). Son: Alphonse Ivanovich Résimont (ar. 1811 – after 1839-01, unmarried), a major at KIPS. After the examination (6 June 1826) of the Institute of the Corps, he was promoted to ensign (praporshchik), on 2 June 1827 – second lieutenant (podporuchik), on 4 June 1828 – lieutenant (poruchik) (16th promotion of the KIPS Institute). In the summer of 1827, he interned under colonel Adam, who was involved in bridge construction in Saint Petersburg. In 1829–1830, he attended the public course on air mechanics and mathematical physics by Ostrogradski. In 1829 and later – he was a tutor at the KIPS Institute. In the late 1820s and early 1830s, he taught with Ianushevski in the 2nd class and gave courses in special mathematics and synthetic statics under the direction of professor G. Lamé; he also taught geodesy in the 4th class; he was appointed assistant professor at KIPS on 24 March 1836; major on 24 March 1836; from 1835 to 1837, he directed the construction of the Nizhne-Lebiaji Bridge over the Lebiajia Kanavka in Saint Petersburg (according to the project by Pierre Dominique Bazaine); he resigned on 24 January 1839, for family reasons.
Career: Governor, then professor and major-general of KIPS. Jean-Baptiste de Résimont is said to have been a priest in France or, according to other sources, an officer and royalist. He emigrated during the Revolution and arrived in Russia around 1792. He resided in Saint Petersburg when he took the oath in 1793. He was hired in 1794 by Count Uktomski, presumably as a tutor, and subsequently resided in the Vologda region. He then taught until 1800 with the Sablukov family, and later with the Durnovo family. He also offered private "mathematics classes" in Saint Petersburg. He was referred to as a mathematics professor at the Institute of Internal Communications in his marriage certificate (1807). Upon the formation of KIPS on 13 March 1810, he was enrolled at the rank of commander (major) and appointed professor of applied mathematics at the Institute of this corps. According to A.I. Delwig, Résimont may have drawn this position by lot. He enjoyed real protection, likely due to his former student Alexandre Sablukov (who was, in 1806, a member of the Water Communications Department, and from 1810 major-general of KIPS). Résimont spoke Russian, French, English, German, and Italian, "mastered literature, mechanics, and natural philosophy," and was proficient in mathematics. He was promoted to lieutenant-colonel and made a knight of the Order of Saint Vladimir, 4th class (25 October 1814). In 1816–1817, he gave a condensed course on mineralogy for the officers of the KIPS Institute for the first time; he taught this subject until his resignation (he was replaced in 1836 at the chair of mineralogy by V.P. Sobolevski). He was an active member of the Imperial Mineralogical Society. He was already a colonel (since 17 April 1819) when he was appointed, in September 1823, a member of the Committee (later the Scientific Committee) for the publication of the Journal des voies de communication (JVC). In 1824, he became a member of the Council and the Conference of the KIPS Institute and assistant to the director of the Institute (from 1829, “of the study section”). He was also appointed inspector of classes. In 1828, he served as acting director during the six months of absence of director Pierre Dominique Bazaine. He was promoted to major-general on 11 (or 14) April 1829. From January to March 1831, he participated in the well-known public courses, where he gave two lectures on the theory of mountain chain formation and volcanic activity. He was awarded the Order of Saint Stanislaus, 1st class (17 June 1831), and the Order of Saint Anne, 1st class (26 June 1833). He served as acting director of the KIPS Institute from 7 September to 6 December 1834. He resigned in October 1836. In 1829, he invented portable water filters, which were accepted by the Commission for Projects and Estimates. For the KIPS Institute, he created the project for the lithological cabinet with a collection of Russian building stone materials. He had a reputation for being a good, educated pedagogue, full of wit and kindness, yet having “a tendency towards clericalism” and certain peculiarities. In the 1829 report from the head of the gendarmes, Benkendorf, he was described as “worthless, greedy for gain, and avaricious.” From April 1822 (and likely until his resignation), he lived “near the Obukhov Bridge at the Corps of Communications” (the former Yusupov Palace with its services).

Career:
Initially established in Amsterdam. In 1764, at the instigation of the Russian envoy in Holland, Count A.S. Musin-Pushkin, François Richard went to Saint Petersburg with three companions (including Zanelli) via Hamburg and Riga to establish a silk factory. They were all sent back from Russia in August 1764 with a personal travel compensation of five hundred rubles, under the pretext of the “uselessness” of their project. Their transport and accommodation in Russia amounted to 1409 rubles, which they were not reimbursed for.
Nevertheless, he remained in Russia. He was found as a French governor engaged at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Petersburg in January 1765. Discontented with the insufficient amount of his salary, he, along with two other Frenchmen, Fragnière and Jenessière, requested a raise from the Academy, then in August 1768 requested leave. He was still in Saint Petersburg in 1772 when he requested to take an exam at the Academy of Sciences to obtain a tutor's certificate: according to his examiners, he spoke and wrote correctly in French.
It was undoubtedly his wife, Marie Richard, who from 1786 ran an educational boarding house in Saint Petersburg on Sadovaya Street, in the house belonging to the Catholic Church of Saint Catherine, at no. 817, which she was still renting in the late 1790s. The boarding house then had twenty-two students, exclusively young girls, twenty-five in 1794. Among the teachers were French: Rigot (or Rigault) taught writing and arithmetic, and Guilert, a professor at the Noble Cadet Corps, taught German and French, while Pingaud (?) taught dance. This boarding house existed until at least 1800. There were 28 students in her boarding house that year.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (1760s; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (1769-01-29, Langres, France – 1849-05-05, Metz, France). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Didier Richardot graduated from the seminary of Saint Nicholas in Paris, as well as from the Theological Faculty of the Sorbonne, acquiring the degree of “Doctor of both Laws” in 1788. He arrived in Russia in 1792, joined the Society of Jesus and entered the novitiate in Polatsk, where he studied for two years (1792–1794). In 1813, he was awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Theology of the Academy of Polatsk.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French; French literature; general history; church history; canon law.
Career:
Priest. After graduation from the novitiate, Didier Richardot was a boarding school deputy regent (head) (1794–1796) and a French teacher at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium (1796–1800). In the 1800–1801 academic year, he was a boarding school regent at the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium. He was one of the first Jesuits who came to the Russian capital in 1801. He taught French at the newly-opened Saint Petersburg Collegium Nobilium from 1801 to 1805. Along with teaching in Saint Petersburg, he worked as a secretary of the General Rector of the Society of Jesus (1802–1805). In 1805, Richardot returned to Polatsk, where he was a preacher at the Jesuit churches (1805–1807, 1809–1810) and a teacher of French, French literature, general history, church history and canon law at the Academy (1811–1816). He was the rector of the churches in Vitsebsk (1807–1808) and Mahilyow (1808–1809, 1816–1817). He was appointed Vice-rector of the Orsha Jesuit Collegium (1817–1819) in 1817 and Rector of the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium in 1819.
After the expulsion of Jesuits from Russia, Didier Richardot returned to his homeland, where he was the Provincial of the Society of Jesus in France (1821–1824) and the head of the mission of the Society of Jesus in Laval (1826–1830). In 1831, he arrived in Galicia, where he was a preacher (1831–1836), a teacher of French (1831–1832), a spiritual mentor (1845–1848) at the Ternopil Jesuit Collegium, a professor specialising in moral theology and the teachings of the Church Fathers (1836–1839), in ecclesiastical history and canon law (1840–1841) at the Collegium of Nowy Sącz, an instructor in teaching the rules of the Society of Jesus (1842–1845) at the Collegium of Stara Wieś.

Career: A former lieutenant-colonel aged about forty at the end of the 18th century, he was serving as a governor for the Golitsyn princes and later for the Viguel family. The memorialist Philippe Wigel describes him in his Memoirs as a tall, thin man with a large nose, very clean, intelligent, and cautious, who wanted to be on good terms with everyone and knew how to please both lords and servants. He spoke to his student of France as the best of countries, always “illuminated by the brilliance of the sun and intelligence,” and of the French as an elected people. The revolutionaries had temporarily seized “this Olympus.” He regarded the Russians as barbarians but spoke of them with a tone of compassion. He was critical of religion and enjoyed telling risqué stories to his student.

Tutor. He was in Saint Petersburg in 1757, where he taught French in the house of commander Pushchin. Personal records: (or Luca) (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Luka Romanovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: Concerning Luka Romanovsky, we know that he taught the phara (analogy) and infima classes at the Pereyaslav Collegium in the 1769–1770 school year, the grammar and syntax classes and then the poetics class in the following years (1771–1772).
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (1769–1772).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
In the 1769–1770 school year, 57 students were enrolled in the phara (analogy) and infima classes, which Luka Romanovsky taught at the Pereyaslav Collegium. In total, 169 students were enrolled at the Collegium that year.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. In the 1769–1770 school year, out of the 57 students enrolled in the phara (analogy) and infima classes taught by Luka Romanovsky, 23 were children of “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy), which Luka Romanovsky taught. In contrast to the Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at the Orthodox collegiums. Luka Romanovsky also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. When Luka Romanovsky worked at the Pereyaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Pereyaslav Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records:
(Wife of N. Dunant and later of Mathew Guthrie) (†1800). A Frenchwoman, probably of Protestant origin. Married to: 1.) a Dunant, likely the secretary of the British embassy; 2.) the Englishman Mathew Guthrie (1743–1807), a physician, graduate of the University of Edinburgh (marriage concluded in 1781). He initially practiced in London before going to Russia in 1769; he returned shortly after to Scotland to receive his medical degree in 1770 from St Andrews University. Upon returning to Russia, he was authorized to practice starting in 1778; he served as the chief physician of the Noble Cadet Corps. He was a recognized scholar for his work in various fields, including medicine, and was appointed state counselor. Children from the 2nd marriage:
  • Anastasia Jessy Guthrie (1782–1855), married in 1797 to Charles Gascoigne; governess to Anna Lopukhina, mistress of Paul I;
  • two other daughters, one of whom died in infancy.
Career: Director of the Smolny Institute for Noble Girls, she succeeded Sophie Lafont in this position.
Teaching institutions and families: Smolny Institute (Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (1750-03-26, Riom – 1795-06-17, Paris) Father: Charles Romme (1681–1763), prosecutor at the presidial court of the seneschal of Auvergne. Mother: Marie Anne Desnier (1714–1800). Brother: Nicolas-Charles Romme (1745–1805), surveyor, mathematician, and scholar.
Education: Oratory College in Riom.
Career: After studying at the Oratory College in Riom, Romme arrived in Paris in September 1774. He enrolled at the Faculty and studied medicine for a year. He earned a living working as a mathematics tutor, notably for the son of Count Alexandre Alexandrovich Golovkin. He met famous scholars: d'Alembert, Bertier, Bezout, Bossut, Guettard, Lalande, Marie, Rozier, Sigaud de Lafond, and others, and unsuccessfully sought a paid position related to science. In 1776, he proposed to Turgot, the controller-general of finances, a project for a chair of mathematics and experimental physics in Riom, of which he himself would have been the director. Count Golovkin, Countess d'Harville, Romme's patroness, and a series of Parisian scholars and notable figures from Riom participated in advancing the project, but Turgot's resignation in May 1776 compromised its realization. Romme attempted to propose his project to the two government leaders who succeeded him, but in vain, and he eventually abandoned it in the spring of 1777. On 29 December 1776, he became a member of the Masonic lodge Les Neuf Sœurs in Paris, where, starting in 1779, he served as an expert. His ties to Freemasonry were interrupted by his journey to Russia. After 1776, Romme became close to one of the leaders of the lodge Les Neuf Sœurs, Count Alexandre Sergeyevich Stroganov, and in May 1779 became the tutor to his son Pavel. With the Stroganov family, he left for Russia in September 1779, passing through Austria and Poland. The day before his departure, Romme wrote to his friends in Riom: “The great Beaumarchais, whom I have only seen from a distance in my life, honored me by visiting me at the moment of my departure, which is set. He speaks to me for the first time, and it is to ask for a favor. I will do everything in my heart that he asks me, but I have strong doubts about the success” (Romme, Correspondence, vol. 1, t. 1, p. 579). It is possible that the “favor” Beaumarchais, a spy for the French government for many years, requested from Romme was to gather information on the Russian armed forces. In any case, in the year following Romme's arrival in Russia (late November 1779), he gathered important documentation on the state of the Russian army and produced a report titled “Observations on the Military of Russia,” which he sent to France and is currently housed in the archives of the MAE (the draft is preserved in Romme's personal documents in Saint Petersburg, SPBII RAN, fond 8, dos. 86). During his trip to Crimea in 1786, he also noted the positions of the Russian army in Southern Russia in his travel journal. This information is found in a secret memorandum “Observations on the Current State of Crimea” composed by chevalier Charrette de La Colinière for the French government. According to the contract, Romme received a salary of 2400 livres for the first three years and 3000 for the following years, which allowed him, starting in 1782, to acquire a large house and a fairly extensive plot of land in the village of Gimeaux near Riom (see a power of attorney in favor of Gabriel Dubreuil, director of the post office in Riom, to collect the inheritance of his father who had just died on 24 October/4 November 1782, and another power of attorney to the same on 25 January/3 February 1783, for the purchase of a house and land “in the place and belongings of Gimeaux”). As a tutor, Romme enjoyed absolute trust from Count Stroganov but suffered from very tense relations with his wife: “The discredit and kind of dishonor that governors are covered with in this country alarms my delicacy too much for me not to pay the greatest attention to disturb as little as possible by my presence those in your society who would have a repugnance to breathe the same air as a tutor; it is already from my own experience that I pity with all my heart the sensitive beings who are reduced to running the same career as I am here.” However, shortly after their arrival in Russia, the Stroganov couple separated. The Countess went to Bratsevo, a village near Moscow, while the Count was engaged in the service of the court, leaving the education of their son Pavel entirely on the shoulders of the tutor. Among his correspondents during his time in Russia was Antoinette Daudet, lady-in-waiting to Countess Stroganova, with whom he experienced an unhappy love. Romme recommended his compatriot, confidant, and collaborator Jacques Démichel to take the position of tutor for Grigori Alexandrovich Stroganov, the first cousin of Paul Stroganov. In Russia, Romme and Pavel Stroganov undertook several long journeys, which were considered the best method of education in Rousseau's educational system. Their first trip was to the Urals (1781) with Count Stroganov. Although Romme described it in his letters as a “trip to Siberia,” according to other sources, the easternmost point they reached was the city of Kungur in the Urals. Some stages of this journey are described in much more detail than others, for example, the routes from Saint Petersburg to Moscow and from Nizhny Novgorod to Kazan along the Volga (“Journey from Saint Petersburg to Moscow,” 30 p.; “Journey from Nizhny Novgorod to Kazan, via the Volga,” 24 p., RGADA, Moscow), while the rest is preserved only in fragments. In 1783, Romme and the young Stroganov traveled to the Karelian massif (see “Journey to Vyborg and Imatra in 1783,” 8 p., RGADA, Moscow), and in 1784, they traveled through Karelia to the islands of the White Sea (see “Journey to the White Sea,” 320 p., RGADA, Moscow). In 1785, Romme and his student went to Kiev, spent the winter there, and in the spring of 1786, they visited Crimea (see “Journey to Crimea,” 92 p., Institute of History of Saint Petersburg, SPBII RAN, Saint Petersburg). Everywhere, Romme and his student became acquainted with the curiosities of nature, cities, industry, and the local population. In July 1786, both left Russia accompanied by the Stroganov painter and future prominent architect Andrey Nikiforovich Voronikhin. They traveled to France through Germany, stopping in Paris and Riom, then continued to Switzerland, where they spent a year and a half. In Geneva, Romme and the young Stroganov met prominent Swiss scholars: Bonnet, Saussure, Senebier, Vernet. They attended lectures by Mallet, Pictet, and Tingry. In the summer of 1787, they took a hike from Geneva to Lucerne. They returned to France at the end of May 1788. Romme and his student spent the summer of 1788 in Auvergne, where Romme's niece, Miette Tailhand, described her uncle as follows: he was “not handsome and had a serious demeanor that was chilling”; “my uncle wears silk clothes of all colors, cuffs, and jabots of English lace. He takes great care of his hairstyle. He is curled and powdered white.” In the autumn of 1788, Romme and Stroganov traveled around France and arrived in Paris at the end of November. To protect his student from social distractions, Romme made him take the pseudonym Pavel Otcher. At the beginning of the Revolution, Romme took his student to the sessions of the National Assembly and revolutionary clubs. Upon receiving a request from the elder Count Stroganov to leave France, Romme, to annoy him, ensured that Pavel became a Jacobin. However, the young Stroganov was compelled to return to Russia under formal orders from the Russian government at the end of 1790. Romme was elected from Puy-de-Dôme to the Legislative Assembly in 1791, where he was a member of the Committee of Public Instruction and was re-elected to the Convention in 1792. Belonging to the Montagnard faction, he became president of the Committee of Public Instruction, and in November 1793, president of the Convention, where he voted for the death of the King. He was one of the authors of the revolutionary calendar adopted in September 1793, to which he dedicated his Annuaire du cultivateur. After the insurrection of Prairial Year III (May 1795), he was arrested and sentenced to death as one of its instigators, but committed suicide upon leaving the court.
Teaching institutions and families: Golovkin, Stroganov families.
Students and their social status:
Son of Count Alexandre Alexandrovich Golovkin;
Count Pavel Alexandrovich Stroganov.
Teaching methods and materials: Romme's pedagogical principles were influenced by the theories of Locke and Rousseau, as well as by the Rousseauist educational systems of Count Golovkin and Swiss physician Tissot. Romme wrote: “Three main points have been the subject of my studies: physics, morals, and instruction. It is from reading Tissot, Rousseau, and Locke and from the frequent discussions I had with an enlightened friend [Golovkin] that I have drawn the ideas I submit for your examination, for this is not at all a conception of education.” Since Rousseau's theory did not allow for “study by books” before the age of twelve, it was only from that age, which the boy [P.A. Stroganov] reached in 1784, that Romme began to give him regular lessons. Before that, his student had learned Russian and the basics of Orthodoxy with Russian teachers. Romme's mission was to be in constant contact with the child, to oversee his health and physical development. Free time was dedicated to the study of natural sciences. Following a meeting in August 1780, сhevalier de Corberon praised the tutor's scholarship. Romme conducted research on many scientific subjects, as evidenced by his correspondence with his Russian acquaintances, such as Academician P. S. Pallas, and with French individuals like James (or Jaunez), La Richardière, Blondot, Massenet, Cussy de Maratray, Charrette de La Colinière, and Dufresne, the physician Blondot. Nevertheless, his research did not surpass the level of a dilettante scholar. Grand Duke Paul, who was interested in sciences, commissioned him in 1784 to conduct the experiment of the Montgolfier balloon (see Mesnil), but this project did not come to fruition.

Personal records: (Brandenburg – 1737-07-28, Yekaterinburgsky Zavod, Russian Empire). When signing the contract (about working as a teacher in Yekaterinburg) in Moscow in 1735, he was referred to as a “foreigner of the Brandenburg nation”. Married to: Sophia Ivanovna, a German. Roze was the father of many children, including Asaph, who was 12 years old, when he was enrolled in the Yekaterinburg Latin school in November 1735 among the first students, children of foreigners. He arrived in Yekaterinburg with his wife Sophia Ivanovna, a German, who knew German reading and writing, and his children. His widow tried to leave Yekaterinburg in December 1737 with the children, but the Ural authorities denied paying her the journey to Moscow, because the contract with A. Roze did not stipulate providing his widow with a travelling allowance. Only after Tatishchev’s intervention, two carts were paid for and the family left Yekaterinburg in December 1739. Anton’s brother, Johann Roze, was hired as a translator by the head of factories V.N. Tatishchev in Moscow at the time of sending him to Yekaterinburg with his team. He worked as a translator at the chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters with a salary of 200 roubles a year, he translated documents submitted by foreign contractors to the Ural authorities from German into Russian and orders addressed to foreigners from Russian into German. On behalf of Tatishchev, he also performed translations from French. In June 1737, V.N. Tatishchev, having been appointed head of the Orenburg expedition instead of the deceased Ivan Kirilov, took Johann Roze with him to Samara, where he served as a translator at the Orenburg expedition until his death in 1739. Religion: Lutheran.
Career:
Before arriving in Yekaterinburg, Anton Roze served as a German teacher at the Moscow School of Navigation. He retired due to old age. When, in January 1735, the Yekaterinburg German school began to search for teachers, Johann Roze, who arrived in Yekaterinburg in October 1734 with the team of V.N. Tatishchev as a translator, recommended his brother Anton for the position of teacher. On behalf of Tatishchev, the Huttenverwalter of the Ural factories Andrey Poroshin, leaving for Moscow and Saint Petersburg with a number of orders, signed a contract with Anton Roze in Moscow concerning his service as a German teacher in Yekaterinburg.  Roze recommended to Poroshin a range of textbooks required for initial training in the German language – “books for each person: Азбука немецкая с латинским, Катехисмус, Новой Завет, Фестибулом, Орбис пиктус, Вакабула по-немецки, руски и латине, Грамматика» (German-Latin Alphabet, Catechism, New Testament, Vestibulum, Orbis pictus, Vocables in German, Russian and Latin, Grammar) but warned that a large number of textbooks could not be brought from Moscow due to the cost, so it was best to buy them in Saint Petersburg. 
Roze committed himself to serve for a year with a salary of 100 roubles. He was also assigned a state-owned flat, a travelling allowance for four carts, and a preliminary payment of half the salary. The contract terms were less favourable in comparison to contracts signed with teachers in the capital.  The money issued was not enough for the journey because of the large family that Roze was bringing to the Urals. In Kazan, he had to borrow 100 roubles from the merchant Inozemtsev until November 1735 (with a promissory note). Due to this, he asked the Ural authorities to give him the second half of his salary, but was refused. 
On 6 November 1735 he began teaching German in Yekaterinburg. In March 1736, he expressed a wish to sign a new contract for two years with a higher salary, expressing resentment about his hardship: “I have been absolutely ruined, and I have big debts now, because my journey here cost about two hundred roubles”. He requested an increase in salary of up to 250 roubles and an “especially bright room” for teaching. But the authorities only agreed to pay him 120 roubles. On 1 May 1736, Roze had to sign a contract on these terms, because he could not leave for Moscow due to his debts. Having worked at the German school in Yekaterinburg for 1 year and 9 months, Anton Roze died suddenly on 28 July 1737.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow School of Navigation (before 1735); Yekaterinburg German School (1735–1737).
Students and their social status:
Children of administration employees, clerks, factory workers, military men.
Children of a commissary, a protocol officer at the chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters, two junior office clerks, four craftsmen, a gunner.
From November 1736 onwards, Roze taught seven people in the second form, two more came in January and February of 1736. Among the nine people in 1737, there were two for each of the following ages: 12, 14, 16, and one person for each of the following ages: 15, 17 and 18.
Teaching methods and materials:
German reading and writing; grammar, translation of the New Testament and the Sacred Conversation.
According to the reports of the students’ progress, they first learned the German alphabet, and then moved on to studying vocables, writing words and reading the Sacred Conversation.

Personal records:
(Known as Marie-Claudine, born Germain) (†1784-01-20/02-01, Moscow). Married to: Benoît Rozet, Parisian bookseller. She had four children, including:
  • Marie-Françoise Rozet, Mme Dieudonné-Barthélemy Guibal.
And perhaps:
  • Alexandrine Rozet, Mme Philippe-Auguste Delesalle.
She lived around 1778 in Saint Petersburg with the governor Bousson de Mairet. She died in the house of Princess Varvara Shakhovskaya, on Tverskaya Street in Moscow; Bousson de Mairet took care of her orphaned children.
Career: Bookseller established in Moscow in the 1770s. Armed with a recommendation from the astronomer Joseph-Jérôme-François de Lalande, she first found a position as a governess while selling books. Research by Vladimir Somov shows that Mme Rozet was an important figure in the French book trade in Russia at that time. One of the first French booksellers in Russia and the only female bookseller, she distinguished herself by the quality of her merchandise as well as that of her clientele. In 1782, coming from France, she settled in Saint Petersburg in the house of private counselor Alexandre Talyzin. She notably sold subscriptions to Levesque's History of Russia. She corresponded with the secretary of the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg, Johann Albrecht Euler, and the academician Gerard-Friedrich Müller; she also knew Diderot and the sculptor Falconet. Among her clients were the Russian high nobility, the Noble Cadet Corps, and the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg. At the time of her death, her husband, a bookseller in Paris, was absent, and her belongings were gathered into three trunks on 6 February 1784. Mme Rozet left many unsold books, over two hundred titles. The inventory after her death, drawn up by the vice-consul of France in Moscow, Pierre Martin, includes the names of Mme Rozet's debtors, as well as those of her Parisian creditors, the booksellers Durand and Debure-fils. Her possessions were auctioned in 1785 at the Foreign Club in Moscow: the high nobility was very present among the buyers. In 1778, she was the godmother of Marie-Lucie Falconet (bapt. at Saint Catherine of Alexandria in Saint Petersburg), the daughter of the painter Pierre-Etienne Falconet and the sculptor Marie-Anne Collot; the godfather was the sculptor Étienne-Maurice Falconet.

Career: Governess to the children of Count Roman Illarionovich Vorontsov: Alexandre Vorontsov (1741–1805), future diplomat, ambassador of Russia to England and Holland, president of the College of Commerce, and under the reign of Alexander I, minister of Foreign Affairs and chancellor of the Empire, and Semion Vorontsov (1744–1832), future diplomat, plenipotentiary minister of Russia in Venice and London. Alexandre Vorontsov mentioned in his autobiography that he learned French "insensibly" thanks to Mmes Ruiveau and Berger.

Personal records: (or Rusiczewski; Titus) (*1709, The regiment town of Pryluky, Russian Empire). Tit Rusichevsky was born into a meschane (low-class urban inhabitants) family. Brother: Iust (Justus) Rusichevsky (Rusiczewski), hierodeacon, proof-reader at the printing house of the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Tit Rusichevsky studied first at the Pryluky regiment school and then, from 1724 until 1737, at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: It is known that in 1738 Tit Rusichevsky took monastic vows at the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. In the 1740–1741 school year, he taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, with the rank of hierodeacon. In the 1741–1742 school year, he taught the grammar class. Then he was sent to the Smolensk Seminary, where he taught the grammar class in the 1744–1745 school year and the rhetoric class later. Proceedings began against him for his unauthorised absence from the seminary (due to illness) and ended up with his appointment as a teacher at the Moscow Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy in 1747, which Tit Rusichevsky refused. From 1751 onwards, he served as hegumen at the Intercession (Pokrovsky) Monastery in Sennoy, from 1758 onwards, at the Holy Trinity Monastery in Kitaevo (Kyiv Metropolis).
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1740–1742); Smolensk Seminary (from 1744).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied at the grammar classes, which Titus Rusichevsky taught at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy and at the Smolensk Seminary. For example, in September 1741, there were 66 students in the grammar class taught by him. In total, 687 students were enrolled at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy at the time.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there. For example, in September 1741, out of the 66 students enrolled in the grammar class taught by Titus Rusichevsky, 40 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks). Most of the students at the Smolensk Seminary were from clergy families.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima and grammar class taught by Tit Rusichevsky, students studied grammar rules and grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Academy and at the Seminary at the time was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares. The surviving exercises intended for school and home work show that the students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the Academy at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. [Alvares E.] Emmanuelis Alvari. De Institutione Grammatica, Monachii [München]: apud Nicolaum Henricum, sumptibus Samuelis Maderi, 1625. [Knapski G.]. Thesauri Polono-Latino-Graeci Gregorii Cnapii... Т. 1–4. Cracoviae [Kraków]: sumptu et typis haerodum Francisci Caesarii, 1668.

Personal records: (or Rüttich, Rutticher) (Wilna, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth – 1727, Thorn, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Studied at the University of Halle.
Career: Theologian, preacher and pedagogue. Ruttich was one the pietist teachers of the Moscow Foreign Language School, who were sent there by August Hermann Francke at the request of Johann Ernst Glück, the founder of the school. Ruttich arrived in Archangelsk on 31 October, 1705 and reached Moscow in December 1705. At the Moscow Foreign Language School, he became teacher of Latin and German with an annual salary of 50 roubles and 23 roubles for maintenance and taught the lowest class. Two years later, according to E. Winter, he was also teaching Arabic. As a result of some conflicts between teachers, pupils, and parents, Ruttich was arrested in December 1707. Owing to the intervention of Pastor Johann Hennin from Wilna (now Vilnius), Ruttich was released soon afterwards and left Moscow in order to move to Wilna (now Vilnius), but there is no evidence that he really arrived there. In October 1710, Ruttich is registered as a student at the university of Königsberg (now Kaliningrad). In the period after 1710, Ruttich is a documented teacher, pastor and professor in Thorn, where he died in 1727.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow Foreign Language School (1705–1707).
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; soldiers, merchants, craftsmen.
At the beginning of the Moscow Foreign Language School, pupils came almost always from the higher nobility or the administration. They had to learn foreign languages for the diplomatic service or service in the administration and the ministries (collegia). Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was significantly extended and sons of soldiers and craftsmen also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: students in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To attract more pupils, in the first years of the existence of the school, students were exempted from military service.
The complete list of pupils, studying at the Moscow Foreign Language School between 1703 and 1715 was published by Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, pp. XXII-XL.
Teaching methods and materials:
Ruttich taught the third class (tertia) Latin and German.

Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. 
Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […].
Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […].
It is not quite sure which issues of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Foreign Language School. What is known is that J.E. Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis sensualium pictus” into Russian. “Vestibulum” was completed by end of 1703 and Glück applied to the Tsar with a petition to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, с. 47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished.

Other texts, used in the language classes at the Moscow Foreign Language school:
various nomenclatures (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (possibly the Latin-German dialogues of Johann Georg Seybold); Lutheran Bible; Lutheran catechism; German hymns
Language and other teaching books by the:
Translation of the Bible into Polish.
Translation of the Quran into German.

Personal records: (*Erlangen, Germany) Religion: Protestant. His father and two of his brothers lived in Berlin (one of the brothers died in 1735).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French, translation from French to German and from German to French.
Career: Professor of French at the Academy of Sciences in Saint Petersburg since 1735, he took the place of professor De Combles, who had just died. He was responsible for teaching translation from French to German and from German to French. He initially received an annual salary of 200 rubles, which was later increased to 400 rubles. In 1735, he had only two students in his class, certainly Germans. He was to give his lessons every afternoon. In 1739, he was dismissed from the Academy, and his duties were entrusted to Pierre-Louis Leroy.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Sciences (1735–1739; Saint Petersburg).
Teaching methods and materials: He explained his teaching method to the administration of the Academy of Sciences: “I had them write an abridged collection of the principles of Pepliers' grammar and other good authors; currently, the first is explaining the letters of Rabutin (this undoubtedly refers to the famous Lettres de messire Roger de Rabutin, comte de Bussy, Paris, vol. 1-4, 1666-1692), and is also translating German letters into French; the second is beginning to explain some stories from Pepliers' grammar. I humbly request that a dictionary be provided for my class.”
Sources and bibliography: Materialy dlia istorii Akademii nauk, t. II, p. 588, 589, 717, 718, 735-736; t. IV.

Personal records: (or Iakov Ivanovich de Sanglin) (1776, Moscow – 1864-04-01, Moscow) Father: Jean or Jean-Jacques de Saint-Glin. According to the legend reported by Iakov Ivanovich de Sanglin, his father left France due to a duel with the chevalier de la Payre to go to Russia. He is said to have married a demoiselle Brocas in Moscow and died around 1780.
Education: Educated first in private schools in Moscow, then in Reval, he began as a translator at the staff of vice-admiral Spiridov. He completed his education at German universities in Leipzig and Berlin.
Career:
Teacher, high official, literati. Upon his return in Russia in 1804, he was appointed as a lecturer in German at Moscow University. He simultaneously began teaching military sciences. In 1806, he became an assistant professor but left teaching in 1807 to join the staff of general aide-de-camp P.M. Volkonski. Around 1812, he took the position of director of the chancellery of the ministry of police and, in this capacity, participated with his chief, general Balashov, minister of the interior, in a cabal that hastened the fall of Speranski, secretary of State. In this matter, he communicated directly with the emperor.
After the war, Sanglin submitted his resignation and was transferred in 1816 to the heraldry department of the Senate, receiving a salary of 4,000 rubles, and retired to his estate in the Klin district near Moscow.
He was still highly regarded under Nicholas I: the emperor asked him in 1831 for his opinion on the writing of Prince A.B. Golitsyn denouncing the "Illuminati." De Sanglin severely criticized Golitsyn and was generously rewarded for it.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University (1804–1807).
Language and other teaching books by the: He published a monthly journal "Avrora" in 1805–1806. His literary output from the pre-war years was abundant (including treaties on military history, etc., published in Russian). In the 1830s, he resumed his literary creation, writing, among other things, a book titled Schiller, Voltaire, and Rousseau (in Russian, 1843). At the end of his life, he began writing his Memoirs, covering the period from 1776 to 1831 (published in Russian, Russkaya Starina, 1882, vol. 36, no. XII, p. 443-498; 1883, vol. 37, no. 1, pp. 1-46; no. 2, p. 374-394; no. 3, p. 538-578).

(*Mont-de-Marsan) Father: Jacques Saint-Glin, a merchant. Mother: Jeanne Lortal († before 1773). Personal records: Originally from Lyon. Father: Louis de Saint-Lubin de Villette. Mother: Catherine de Bajeau. Married to: Marie Laloyaux, daughter of Jean Laloyaux and Marguerite Varin (marriage concluded on 21 September 1793 at the Saint Louis of the French Church in Moscow; witnesses: Sergey Saltykov; Abraham Ludowille; Jacques Jourdain, merchant; Louis Méart, painter; Pierre Gromelin).
Career: Professor of French at the Méart educational boarding school in Moscow in 1792 and 1793. He was residing in the III district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793. In 1799, when the authorities' suspicion toward the French was at its peak, Saint-Lubin was arrested while heading to Baldon (?) because he did not have all his papers in order. He was expelled from the empire the same year.
Teaching institutions and families: Méart educational boarding school (1792–1793; Moscow).

SPbZ, 1793, no. 47; SPbV, 1793, no. 47.

Personal records:
Originally from Brussels.
Likely the brother of Nicolas de Saint-Nicolas.
Career:
Headmaster and professor of French. On 21 January 1766, Jean-Godefroi de Saint-Nicolas presented himself at Moscow University to take the exam required for tutors. However, since he did not have his passport with him, the exam was postponed to 4 February 1766. He ran an educational boarding school in Moscow. In 1773, he requested permission to examine his students at Moscow University, but this was denied. He was admitted as a lecturer at Moscow University after a visit to his boarding school by Mikhail Matveyevich Kheraskov, who attended the exam. He served as a French lecturer in the "syntax class" of the university from 1770 to 1772, following the lecturer Henri de Lavie. In 1771, he delivered a speech on the anniversary of Empress Catherine II: - Discours panegyrique pour le jour de naissance de Sa Majesté Impériale Catherine II, imperatrice et autocratrice de toutes les Russies mere de la Patrie prononcé par de St. Nicolas lecteur public et membre de l’Université Imperiale de Moscou, [Moscow], printed at the typography of the Imperial University of Moscow, 1771, 8 pages, in-4°. In 1772, he was replaced by Berland de La Bordelière, but he seems to have retained this position until 1773 (according to other information, until 1775) as he delivered another speech that year as a French lecturer at the university, composed on the occasion of the marriage of Grand Duke Paul with Princess Wilhelmina-Luisa, known as Natalia Alexeyevna in Russia:
  • Discorso di felicitazione per il giorno dell’illustri sponsali di Sua Altezza Imperiale Paulo Petrowich, gran duca di Russia etc. e di Natalia Alexiewna, gran duchessa di Russia. Pronunciato nell’Università Imperiale di Mosca, dal de St. Nicolas lettor publico della lingua francese et membro detta Universita. In: Actus solemnis, quo...Catharina Alexiewnae...Paulo Petridi...et Natalia Alexeidi...occasione augustarum nuptiarum... feliciter consummatarum Caesarea Moscvensis Universitas devotissime gratulatur..., Moscvae, 1773.
A Freemason, he was a member-speaker of the Clio lodge in Moscow in 1774. Several Russian nobles were part of it, as well as a few Frenchmen, Bérard de La Rozière and Pierre Dumoulin. He appears to have remained in Russia until the early 1790s.
Teaching institutions and families: An educational boarding school in Moscow; Moscow University (1770–1772/1773 or 1775).

This eulogy contains an Epître aux soldats russes, p. 59-66; this epistle was previously published in Moscow in French with a parallel translation in Russian by the Russian poet A. Sumarokov, the Russian title is: Эпистола российским ратникам, Moscow, printed at the Imperial University, 1775.

Personal records:
(ar. 1721, Saverne – before 1787). Antoine Sarlefin claimed to be the son of the chevalier de Lutzenbourg and a young lady who was not "of his rank." Married in 1746 a German Protestant widow born around 1706, with whom he had no children. He likely remarried around 1749 to Beate Grignon, widow of Adrian, and he had four children in 1761 and five in 1777, among whom were:
  • Beate-Marie-Anne Sarlefin (*1750-07-03, Saint Petersburg; godfather: Benoît Graven; godmother: Marie-Anne Perriard);
  • Catherine Sarlefin (*1752-02-28, Saint Petersburg; godfather: Jean Regli; godmother: Catherine Gibelli); godmother of Pierre Beaulieu on 19 March 1788, at the Catholic Church of Saints Peter and Paul, living in the VI district of Moscow when she took the oath in 1793;
  • Marie-Béate Sarlefin, Mme François Beaulieu.
  • Joseph Sarlefin, living in the IV district of Moscow when he took the oath in 1793.
Career: Wigmaker and then tutor. His mother is said to have taught him how to make wigs. Antoine Sarlefin reportedly traveled to Saxony to join "his uncle, general Count of Lutzenbourg." He spoke Latin, German, Italian, and Russian in addition to his native language, French. Settled in Saint Petersburg in 1746, he was found established in Moscow in 1761, where he was noted as a tutor and his wife as a French teacher. That same year, he represented Denis Berlire against Jean Michel, merchants in Saint Petersburg, in a commercial dispute.

Personal records: Originally from Marseille. Married to: Lucie Degand.
Career:
Colonist then tutor. He was recruited with his wife, likely in 1766, for Russia by Baron de Beauregard. On 28 September/9 October 1766, Saunier "pleaded" with the Chancellery for the guardianship of foreigners "to kindly accept and approve the receipt for the reimbursement of transport and subsistence costs that M. Baron de Beauregard, director of the Catherine-Lehn colony, has graciously granted them, given the illnesses that Lucie Degand has suffered in this country and the little hope for her recovery." Beauregard allowed them, after paying all their debts, to leave the colony; in October 1766, the Sauniers requested a passport to settle in Saint Petersburg.
In 1767, André-Claude Saunier was in Moscow. He presented himself at Moscow University to be examined and obtain a certificate as a tutor. He received it on 13 August 1767, for teaching French. He was then admitted on 17 April 1771, as "governor and writing master for the students of the second age" at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg, with a salary of 420 rubles per year.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (from 1771; Saint Petersburg).
Sources and bibliography: RGADA, fonds 283, inv. 1, dos. 79; RGIA, fonds 789, inv. 1, dos. 481, f° 68-69. Dokumenty i materialy, t. III, p. 55-56. Bartlett, 1979, p. 162; Gaponova.

Personal records: Religion: Catholic.
Career: Jesuit priest who lived in Spain and then in Russia. He taught in the Mamonov family, and later became the tutor of Prince Ivan Mikhailovich Dolgorukov (1764–1823, later a private counselor, brigadier, author of Memoirs), who appreciated him more than his other tutors. After spending seven years with the Dolgorukov family, Sauveré is said to have returned to France in the 1780s.
Teaching institutions and families: Mamonov, Dolgorukov families
Students and their social status: Prince Ivan Mikhailovich Dolgorukov.

Dolgorukov, 1997.
Gaponova.

Personal records: (1742-03-10, Magdeburg – 1790-05-10, Mitau, Courland).
Education: Studied at the University of Halle.
Career:
Schall started his professional life as a court councillor and counsellor at the superior Court of Justice in Berlin. Later, he worked as a private tutor in Halle and in Leipzig and also became teacher at the renowned Philanthropinum, a reformist, progressive school in Dessau founded in 1774.
In 1780, Schall moved to Russia. At frequent intervals he changed his jobs: teacher in Poltava, in Moscow, where he worked for a short period of time as honorary professor at the Moscow University, a tutor in Mahilyow, Pskov and Derpt (Dorpat, now Tartu). Finally, in 1785, he was engaged as supervisor and teacher of German and French at the First Noble Infantry Cadet Corps with an annual salary of 400 roubles. Sources report that Schall was quite a difficult character which may have been one of the reasons for his frequent change of jobs. In his position at the Cadet Corps, too, Schall stayed only for a few weeks. However, he remained at the Corps in an advisory function until 1789 and published three schoolbooks during this time. Later, he moved to Riga and finally to Mitau (now Jelgava), where he died in May 1790.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University; First Noble Infantry Cadet Corps (1785, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Nobility.
Teaching methods and materials:
According to Schall, the classes in the Infantry Cadet Corps did not have grammar books, so teachers had to dictate the whole content of the books to their pupils during lessons. Afterwards, the pupils had to learn the given rules by heart independently. Given these circumstances, Schall decided to produce a new German Grammar for the needs of his classes. In order to publish the Grammar as quickly as possible, he first published an extract which contained only the ‘etymology’ (which then meant morphology) and syntax parts. The complete grammar of 1789 was divided in two “main sections.” The first section consisted of three parts which were named 1. «On Pronunciation», 2. «On the Words, or on the Nature, the Transformations and the Properties of Words», and 3. «On the Conjunction of Words». The second part is equivalent to ‘etymology’ and the third part to syntax. The second section covered the spelling. Furthermore, there were five appendices. Three of them dealt with specific problems of morphology and two illustrated the syntactic rules by means of examples and exercises. The fifth appendix («Повторение правил Синтаксиса перенесением слов в нескольких примерах, которые учащимся для поправления преподавать надлежит») was taken from the popular German Grammar by Franz Hölterhof, published in 1770 (pp. 267-271).
Schall’s Grammar was of high quality and first introduced the grammatical model of the German linguist Johann Christoph Adelung to Russian students. Adelung’s German Grammar “Deutsche Sprachlehre”, published in 1781, was the best German Grammar of its time and was used in Prussian schools. Schall assessed this grammar as “the most exact, completest” and “best of all […] grammars written in German” (Schall, 1786, p. X). The composition of Schall’s grammar corresponded exactly to Adelung’s “Sprachlehre” but was far from being its direct translation. It deserves special attention that Schall was the first and only author of a German grammar in Russia in the 18th century who commented on the original grammar which he used as a sample, and reflected on its suitability for teaching German in Russia. As a result, he refrained from translating Adelung’s “Sprachlehre” directly, because “it was designed for German and not for Russian schools” and therefore, it was “on the one hand, not sufficiently detailed and on the other hand too extensive.” (Schall, 1786, p. X). 
In the preface to his grammar of 1786, Schall explained his ideas for language teaching. In particular, he accentuated the importance of teaching grammar and noticed that “without a well-considered use of grammar, language tuition […] would provide only a very poor knowledge of languages” (Schall, 1786, p. IV). This attitude is especially remarkable, since Schall called himself one of the “most cordial apologists” of Philantropism (Schall, 1779, p. 223), an educational reform movement in the German-speaking area which was opposed to teaching grammar and focused on oral fluency. This last point, however, was maintained by Schall, too. One of his basic principles was that oral skills were prior to writing skills. Following this principle and the criteria of progression, he selected the subjects of his grammar. Therefore, the first section of the grammar of 1789 covered pronunciation, morphology and syntax and the second section, spelling rules. 
Schall wrote his monolingual grammar in Russian: grammatical rules and grammatical terminology were presented only in Russian. In doing so, Schall followed a tendency in the second half of the 18th century, when already seven of the ten German grammars, published in Russia at the time, were written completely in Russian. This can be seen as an indication that Russian as medium of instruction in German lessons was already quite common. According to Schall, it was already common sense that foreign language tuition should also include the student’s native language. Justifying the choice of language in his grammar, he argued. “As much as teachers, who are not able to talk with their students, can deliver nothing but bad work, any grammar book which one would like to use, also needs to be written in the native language of the respective students. […] These principles are only questioned by non-experts.” (Schall, 1786, p. IVff.)
Contrary to the German grammars published in Russia until the early 1760s, Schall’s grammar exhibits a clear didactic and methodological concept. This was only the case in two other German grammars, namely the grammar of Franz Hölterhof (1770) and the grammars of M.G. Gavrilov (1782 and 1790). Furthermore, these three authors were the only ones to give explicit, methodical explanations, on how to work with the grammars. Schall militated against memorizing rules and their explanations. If the teacher would present them reasonably, grammatical rules and explanations could strongly contribute to forming the students’ minds and their reasoning powers (Schall, 1786, XII).
Schall’s grammar is much more practice-focused than previous grammars (apart from the grammars of Hölterhof and Gavrilov). Besides the theoretical rules, it provides exercises which are given in the appendixes. Furthermore, the language material itself has a distinct connection to real life. Sentences like: “Petersburg ist viel größer als Twer, Kasan ist auch nicht klein, aber Moskau ist die größte Stadt in Europa” [„Petersburg is much bigger than Twer, Kasan also is not small, but Moscow is the biggest town in Europe“] or „Die Kayserinn von Russland, der König von Preussen, der Bischof von Bamberg” [„The empress of Russia, the king of Prussia, the bishop of Bamberg“] (Schall, 1789, pp. 208, 225) refer to specific features of Russia or of the German lands. Exemplary sentences could also be used in real communication, like “Ich habe ein Buch gekauft. Was für eines? Ist kein Bediensteter da? Hier ist einer.”[„I bought a book. What kind of book? Is any servant there? Here is one.”] (Schall, 1789, p. 28). Everyday life and the experiences of the students themselves are also reflected: “Des Sonnabends gehen wir in die Badstube” [“On Saturdays we go to the bath.”] (Schall, 1789, p. 210).
In general, Schall supported new methodological tendencies which focused more on cognitive learning methods than on methods based on exercises. He is the only author who presents example sentences with detailed grammatical analyses of word forms («Примеры для грамматическаго разобрания слов в периоде» (Schall 1789 pp. 58-62). The appendix with example sentences, including mistakes which were to be corrected by the students, was taken from Hölterhof. However, it is also a good example of cognitive learning.

Personal records: (or Scharschmid) (1664, Quedlinburg, Electorate of Saxony – 1724, Halle, Prussia). In 1707, married to the daughter of the Russian major general Christoph K. Riegemann. Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Student of the universities of Halle and Leipzig; ordination to the priesthood in Magdeburg in 1700.
Career:
Theologian; preacher; tutor.
Scharschmidt belonged to the early followers of August Hermann Francke and Philip Jakob Spener, the leading theologians of German pietism. On Francke’s orders, he was sent to Königsberg to organize a Collegium pietatis, similar to the one existing in Halle. However, this mission was not very successful and Scharschmidt moved on to Livonia. In 1696, he received a new order from Francke and was sent on a mission to Moscow, where he arrived in September.
For two decades, Scharschmidt was the closest collaborator of August Hermann Francke in Russia. His correspondence with Francke which was maintained during the whole period, gives precise insights into his activities. Scharschmidt started his Russian career as tutor in the family of Laurenz Blumentrost, the personal physician of Tsar Peter I. Blumentrost was also a supporter of pietism. Scharschmidt also began to teach Russian children, primarily in German and Latin. Being a very strong supporter of the pietist movement, Scharschmidt got into conflict with the Lutheran Communities in Moscow with their rather negative attitude towards pietism. At the beginning of 1698, he therefore moved back to Narva, but got into trouble again and came back to Moscow in 1699. Supported by Blumentrost, he was finally engaged as preacher of the New Lutheran Community. According to Francke’s order, Scharschmidt’s task in Russia consisted not only of mission work but also of exploring new business opportunities. He therefore started active travel activities in the whole of Russia, amongst them two journeys to Astrakhan and the Volga region from 1701 to 1703 and from 1707 to 1712. Scharschmidt founded German schools in Astrakhan and possibly also in the German Lutheran communities along the Volga river. The pupils of the Astrakhan school were not exclusively German children, but children from different ethnic groups, namely seven Germans, one Armenian, one Greek, one Russian, two Bashkir, one Calmuc, one Finn plus seven girls whose nationality is not documented. Returning to Moscow in 1712, Scharschmidt again got into conflict with the New Lutheran Community and moved on to Kyiv and Smolensk, where he became diacon/preacher of General Weyde, one of several pietist generals in the Russian army. Later, Scharschmidt worked in the iron company of the German mercantilist Müller in Ugodka near Moscow. After his return to Halle in summer 1717, Scharschmidt became preacher in a hospital and advised Francke on Russian affairs.
Teaching institutions and families:
New Lutheran Community in Moscow; Lutheran Community in Astrakhan.
Family of Prince Romodanovsky; family of Pavel Veselovsky; family of Laurenz Blumentrost the older.
Students and their social status:
Nobility; children of members of the German communities.
Son of prince Romodanovsky; son of Pavel Veselovsky; pupils of German schools in German Lutheran Communities
The son of prince Romodanovsky lived in the household of Scharschmidt “in order to learn German perfectly via permanent exposure” (letter of Scharschmidt to August Hermann Francke from 4 November 1699, quoted in Winter, 1953, p. 58). The son of Pavel Veselovsky was taught Latin. In this family, conflicts arose because Scharschmidt tried to convert his student to pietism. The father interfered and limited the education strictly to learning Latin (see Winter, 1953, p. 80).
