Personal records: (or Schwanewitz, Schwanewiz) (1687 or earlier, Thorn, Poland – 1740-10-14, Saint Petersburg). According to a register of the local citizens of Thorn in the 17th century, Martin Schwanwitz was naturalised in Thorn by 1687. A list of non-local citizens of Thorn in the 17th century lists a Hans Schwanwitz, probably Martin’s father, who became naturalised in Thorn in 1649. Married to: 1.) Anna Catharina Hagen († 1737-11-15, Saint Petersburg); 2.) Christina Dorothea. Religion: Lutheran.
Education: Martin Schwanwitz attended the local grammar school in Thorn, where he probably learned Polish. His command of the Polish language is documented in a poem which he composed for his father in Polish at the end of his time at the Thorn grammar school.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; Russian; translation from Russian into German; history.
Career:
Based on his own records, from 1715 he was the director of the post office in Thorn and remained in this position for about two and a half years.
Schwanwitz came to Russia as the secretary of the Commissioner-General (“Generalkommissar”) Manteufel, whom he served for about eight months. From June 1718 onwards, he worked as a civil servant and translator at the Collegium of State Income (“Kamer-Kollegia”) in St. Petersburg. 
In 1725, he applied for a scholarship at the newly founded Academy of Sciences which was urgently looking for competent students – especially with some knowledge of Russian or other Slavonic languages. According to his contract dated 1 September 1725, Schwanwitz was engaged for five years with an annual salary of 200 roubles, and also received free lodging, firewood and candles. Being a student at the Academy, he worked simultaneously as a German teacher (“информатор немецкого языка“) at the Academy school. In October 1730 he was listed as a German teacher in class five, also known as the “lower” class or Quinta, with an annual salary of 300 roubles. From January 1728 onwards, he took over the task of translating the St. Petersburg newspaper (Sanktpetersburgische Zeitung) and its appendix from German into Russian. For this work, he received an additional remuneration of 72 roubles per annum. He also taught some of his own students translation; later on it helped him to translate the newspaper. 
In February 1732, Schwanwitz left the Academy in order to become the first “Hofmeister” (court official) of the Noble Cadet Corps which had just been founded. Since there was no German teacher, Schwanwitz offered additionally to teach German three hours a day, until another suitable teacher for German could be found. However, in his position as “Hofmeister”, he was not very successful and was discharged in January 1734. But being a good teacher of German and Russian, he stayed at the Corps and in September 1734 even received the title and position of a Professor of the Russian language. 
At the beginning of 1735, since Schwanwitz faced financial difficulties resulting from his activities as “Hofmeister”, he asked to be re-employed by the Academy and was accepted. From 1 March 1735, he became rector of the Academy School’s German Section (with an annual salary of 300 roubles) and also inspector for the boarding school which had recently been set up (with an annual salary of 200 roubles). In addition to his duties as rector and teacher, Schwanwitz was committed to translating “various documents coming up at the Academy in Russian and German languages” and was also to correct “the school manuals which will be published.” Furthermore, he was obliged to join the newly established “Russian Assembly”, a group of highly qualified translators, who met twice a week to discuss ongoing translations. The other individuals belonging to this group were V.K. Trediakovsky, V.E. Adodurov and J.J. Taubert. Even though Schwanwitz had a good and stable position at the Academy, he continued to have serious financial problems, because the Cadet Corps’ chancellery requested the paying-back of a financial loss which Schwanwitz incurred during his time as “Hofmeister.” However, these issues should not question his overall importance and overall contribution: given his great dedication to teaching and training pupils, producing textbooks, translating and – in general – improving the conditions of teaching, Schwanwitz is seen as one of Russia’s best language teachers of his time.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy School at the Academy of Science; Noble Infantry Cadet Corps, all in Saint Petersburg.
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
In the first half of the 18th century, both the Academy School and the Noble Cadet Corps were the most important schools in Russia. The Academy School’s pupil registers, published by Sukhomlinov in his “Материалы для истории Императорской Академии Наук“, list about 820 pupils attending the school during this period. At least two thirds of these pupils learned German in the higher classes, with Schwanwitz as their teacher. The names of a large number of these pupils, aged between 6 and 20, are known and listed in Sukhomlinov’s registers including information about their social backgrounds and learning interests. Examples are M.I. Alekseev and I.P. Iakhontov, who helped Schwanwitz to translate the newspapers and their appendices.
As for the Noble Cadet Corps, in 1732 the list of pupils indicates that 163 out of 223 Russian Cadets learned German. Consequently, one can conclude that Martin Schwanwitz, during his 15-years-long teaching career, had several hundreds of students.
In November 1736, Schwanwitz gave a detailed report of the number and social status of all students who were registered at the Academy school and learned German. In principle, there were two different categories of students, attending the Academy school: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. Schwanwitz’ report lists 78 independent pupils, among them 54 nobles and 24 non-nobles. 57 pupils received a scholarship, among them 42 children, whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy school, especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was very diverse, ranging from the higher nobility, army officers and officials such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia, to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even simple civil servants.
Teaching methods and materials:
At the Academy School, Schwanwitz started his career as a teacher in the beginners’ class which was class five, also called Quinta or lower (“нижний“) German class. In this class, pupils learned to read (e.g., the bible) and write in German and also studied German grammar. Later on, being already rector of the German Section at the Academy School, Schwanwitz instructed the advanced learners in the higher class and also gave some guidance to his colleagues (probably Johann Georg Oestermann and M. Potapsky) in the medium class and the lowest class. According to the curriculum of March 1735, published by Sukhomlinov, Schwanwitz had to teach the higher class to “write in German letters and translate clearly and with sense” and also gave lessons in history and geography (most likely in German too, since the textbooks were written in German). The timetables, belonging to the curriculum of March 1735, list the following subjects, taught by the rector: “various exercices, explanations, letters and epistles, history“.
In the medium class, Schwanwitz guided his colleagues in teaching “grammar [...] conversation and simple exercises to be translated from Russian into German.” The lowest class focused on learning “reading German and Latin books” and German etymology and also spelling and arithmetic.
In 1737, the Academy’s documents, published by Sukhomlinov, also mentioned Schwanwitz as a teacher of Russian. Most probably, Schwanwitz received this additional task after having returned from the Cadet Corps, where he had taught both languages – German and Russian.
Even though Martin Schwanwitz actively produced or translated textbooks for his own classes, he did not leave any written comments on his understanding of how to teach languages. Nonetheless, from some of his statements and also from his German Grammar we can see that Schwanwitz attached great importance to involving Russian when teaching German. Schwanwitz seems to have had quite a good knowledge of Russian himself. Furthermore, he consistently stipulated that teachers should know both German and Russian which very often was not the case, and offered to train his own pupils as bilingual teachers. The main textbook used in all German classes was Schwanwitz’ own German Grammar. This grammar book was bilingual, contrary to the German grammar by Charmyntes (Schwanwitz’ main source), written only in German. Each page was divided into two parallel columns, offering the whole text in a German and in a Russian version. The book was organized in four main chapters: “Orthographia”, “Etymologia”, “Syntaxis” and “Prosodia”. Therefore, it could be used not only to teach the theory of grammar, but also spelling and pronunciation. Schwanwitz also used Russian to compare some of the German grammatical structures to their equivalent in Russian, as for example the subjunctive, the future tense or the auxiliary verb “werden”. Thus, Schwanwitz’ grammar book constitutes the first German grammar book for Russians which compares the two languages in several places. Contrary to the German grammar of Charmyntes, Schwanwitz’ grammar book contained quite a lot of example sentences with an obvious link to Russian reality. Sentences like “Du mußt heute nach Peterhof reisen” or “Er pflegt alle Jahr nach Moscau zu reisen” were not only meant to illustrate the grammatical rules, but could also be used for pronunciation exercises, for being memorized or for translation exercises which were, in general, the most common type of exercises in the 18th century. For oral practice, Schwanwitz could have used the school dialogues, published in 1738. The German calendars, most likely, were used for reading and for translation exercises which were the predominant type of exercise in the advanced classes.

[Schwanwitz, Martin] Немецкая грамматика, из разных авторов собрана и российской юности в пользу издана от учителя немецкого языка при Санкт-Петербургской гимназии, St. Petersburg: Типография Академии Наук, 1730. Martin Schwanwitz is the author of the first grammar book for German, published in Russia for Russian students. This grammar book was a revised and supplemented version of Charmyntes’ German Grammar of (the real name of the author remains unknown, possibly it was Johann Leonhard Frisch), published in Berlin in 1713, also for Russian students. The Academy of Sciences charged Schwanwitz with writing a German grammar book, since there were no textbooks at all available for teaching. Presumably, Schwanwitz received this order relatively early, because already in 1728, the Academy’s Chancellery announced that the German grammar would soon be published. The first edition published in 1730, used in the Academy school and in the Noble Cadet Corps, was quickly out of stock, the same applied to the second edition of 1734, supplemented by V.E. Adodurov, Schwanwitz’ Russian colleague. It is well documented that Schwanwitz used his grammar book in his own classes. In February 1739, for example, he ordered three copies of the German grammar - that is one for each of the three German classes. The copy for the major class, the most advanced one, had to be interleaved with writing paper, so that mistakes could be corrected and amendments could be made. After Schwanwitz’ death in 1740, the third edition realized in 1745, was prepared by the Academy professor J. J. Stählin. This time, the number of copies issued amounted to 2400, which was extremely high for the time. This and the following editions of 1762, 1791, and 1802 were widely used for teaching German in Russian schools. As a result, Schwanwitz’ German Grammar became one of the most successful German grammar books in 18th century Russia in general. 
Compendium Grammaticae Russicae. Schwanwitz is also one of the authors of the Compendium Grammaticae Russicae, a Russian grammar book dating from 1731 which enabled Germans to learn Russian. Although it was ordered by the first president of the Academy of Science, L.L. Blumentrost, it remained unpublished at the time and was published only recently (the manuscript is kept in: the Library of the Russian Academy of sciences, f. 250). 
[Weissmann, Ehrenreich], Немецко-латинский и русский лексикон купно с первыми началами рускаго языка к общей полъзе при Имп. Академии науке, печатию издан, СПб.: Типогр. АН, 1731. Together with V.E. Adodurov and other translators of the Academy (namely I.I. Iliinsky, I.S. Gorlitsky and I.P. Satarov), Schwanwitz worked on translating Ehrenreich Weismann’s Lexicon Latino-Germanicum into Russian. The new trilingual version of the dictionary was issued in 1731.
[Lange, Joachim], Colloquia Scholastica, Школьные разговоры, Schul-Gespräche, Dialogues, СПб.: Типогр. АН, 1738. After having returned to the Academy of Science in 1735, Schwanwitz received the order to translate Joachim Lange’s popular “Colloquia Scholastica” into Russian, whereas his colleague Johann Eberhard Fischer, rector of the Academy School’s Latin Section, translated the Latin part into German. The new Latin-Russian-German-French version was published in 1738 at the Academy Press (reprints followed around 1748/49 [year, indicated on the title of this edition: 1738] in 1763 [number of copies published: 1200] and 1789). In Russian schools, the School Dialogues became highly popular and were used intensively until the end of the 18th century. They were indispensable in the lower German classes, where, according to the Academy school’s curricula of 1748 and 1758, their use was compulsory. Later, in 1776, Moscow University issued a version in five languages that also included a translation into Greek (further editions in 1785 and 1800). 
In 1737, Schwanwitz worked on translating the “schoolbook by Seybold” (Sukhomlinov, 1886, vol. 3, p. 580). The documents specify neither the exact book, nor the full name of the author, but most probably it was the Latin-German dialogues by the German philologist Johann Georg Seybold which were quite popular in German schools at the time. This assumption is supported by the fact that the Academy already disposed of a version of the Latin-German dialogues, translated into Russian by Johann Werner Paus, who also worked at the Academy as a translator. Therefore, we do not follow Lepekhin’s thesis, according to which the book was an “instruction for storing anatomic and taxidermic exhibits”, written by the German-Dutch pharmacist Albert Seba, whose collection was purchased for the Kunstkammer by Peter I.

Schwanwitz also composed a few poems. He translated some German poems into Russian, published in the Saint Petersburg newspaper, and also wrote his own lyrics in German, for example in 1727 a poem on the occasion of Peter II’s birthday (for details see the article by M.L. Lepekhin).

(*Saxony).
Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Teacher. Schwimmer had been principal in one of the German Lutheran schools in the German Quarter of Moscow, when he was recruited to become translator for Latin, German, Swedish and Dutch at the Posolsky prikaz (Foreign Office) in 1701. Furthermore, he was given the task of teaching six Russian students in these four languages. In fact, the pupils were taught only in Latin and German. They were all sons of secretaries (дьяк) of the Posolsky prikaz. Schwimmer’s school was part of a state-funded scheme and both teacher and pupils were financed by the government. Schwimmer received an annual salary of 120 roubles, the pupils a daily allowance of 4–10 kopecks. However, Schwimmer was not very successful in his teaching, probably because of his poor knowledge of Russian. Therefore, in February 1703, the pupils were transferred to another Lutheran teacher, Johann Ernst Glück, and thus formed the basis of Glück’s future grammar school. Schwimmer was sent to the Russian envoy A.A. Matveev in the Netherlands to work as secretary and translator. In 1707, he was dismissed due to drunkenness and poor knowledge of Russian and returned to Moscow in 1709. In March 1711, he was finally discharged and probably returned to his homeland.
Teaching institutions and families: German Lutheran school in the German Quarter; school at the Posolsky prikaz, all in Moscow.
Students and their social status:
Civil servants.
Schwimmer’s pupils were the sons of the secretaries (дьяк) who worked at the Posolsky prikaz. They were trained to become translators in the administration or to be sent abroad to work in the diplomatic service.

Semion Andreiev; Fyodor Bogdanov; Ivan Gramotin; Yakov Gramotin; Piotr Gubin; Samoilo Kopiev; Vasily Kurdevsky.
Teaching methods and materials:
After one year of instruction, in April 1702, Schwimmer gave a detailed report about the progress of his students. In Schwimmer’s class, students learned to read, write and talk in German and Latin. Furthermore, they used the German-Latin book «The Entrance of the Latin Language» (i.e. probably John Amos Comenius’ “Vestibulum linguae latinae”) from which they learned by heart German and Latin phrases and dialogues. For example, the pupil Ivan Gramotin learned 3000 Latin and German phrases from this book. Regarding Latin grammar, the pupils learnt by heart declension and conjugation forms of the Latin grammar book “Donatus latino-germanicus” by Johannes Rhenius.The most successful student, Vasily Kurdevsky, according to Schwimmer, acquired such a good knowledge of Latin “that he could already talk to a scientist in Latin” («что уже с ученым может по латыне розговоритца») (Белокуров/Зерцалов, 1907, p. 36f).

Вход латинского языка 
„Donat“ Latin grammar

The Latin book “Entrance of the Latin Language” («Вход латинского языкa») that was mentioned by Schwimmer in his reports was most probably one of John Amos Comenius’ schoolbooks, most likely his “Vestibulum” (Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]). The “Donat” was supposedly the Latin grammar by Johannes Rhenius (Rhenius, Johannes, Donatus latino-germanicus Seu Ratio Declinandi et Conjugendi. Pro Incipientes, Leipzig 1614). These books are mentioned by Schwimmers’ successor Johann Ernst Glück in his letter to August Hermann Francke dated 3 March 1704. Glück noted that he had found “many copies of Rhenii Donato” and that there was no shortage. In contrast, he had found only two copies of Comenius’ “Vestibulum” (Winter, 1953, p. 377).

Personal records: (*Holy Roman Empire).
Career: Schöning worked as a teacher of German calligraphy and arithmetic at the Noble Infantry Cadet Corps from 1742 onwards. In addition to his position at the Noble Cadet Corps, on 7 July 1748, Schöning was apparently also employed at the Academy School as a teacher of German calligraphy with an annual salary of 100 roubles. In March 1749, he was still working at both institutions. In January 1750, Schöning announced that his students at the Academy School had already completed their training in writing and that he could not teach them any new skills. Maybe as a result of this statement, Schöning does not appear on the Academy’s payroll of February 1750 in the function of a writing teacher, but only as a drawing teacher (with an annual salary of 100 roubles as well).
Teaching institutions and families: Infantry Noble Cadet Corps (from 1742); Academy School at the Academy of Sciences (1748–1750), all in Saint Petersburg)
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; merchants; soldiers; peasants.
Between 1748 and 1750, the number of pupils, attending the Academy School, fluctuated between 57 and 89 pupils. A significant part of them very probably joined the German class, because all students intending to study at the Academy University had to learn German and/or Latin. The names of a large number of these pupils, aged between 6 and 20, are known and listed in the school registers (see: Материалы для истории Академии наук) including information about the pupils’ social backgrounds and learning progress.
The Academy School was attended by two different categories of students. The first group were pupils in receipt of a government scholarship, the second group independent (self-funding) pupils. Among the group of independent pupils there were nobles and non-nobles and also quite a lot of non-Russian pupils. Scholarship students were often children whose fathers served in the admiralty or in the army and who were sent to the Academy School especially to learn German. Thus, the family background of the pupils was largely diversified from a wide spectrum of professions: from the higher nobility, army officers and civil servants such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary servants.
Teaching methods and materials: In a statement about Schöning dating from March 1749, it is written that “Schöning did not have a sound knowledge of the German language according to the grammatical rules.” Therefore, Schöning himself agreed that he should teach only reading and writing [«Шэнинг немецкаго языка знает не фундаментально и по грамматическим правилам, и того ради обучать ему студентов, по его мнению, только читанию и писанию». (Сухомлинов, 1897, т. 9, с. 692)].

Personal records: (or Semyonov Golovin) (Russia – 1716, Moscow). Married in 1695. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He was a student at the hieromonk Timofey’s Greek Slavic school, which was located at the Moscow Print Yard and functioned from 1681 onwards. The date of admission to the school could not be clarified. Documents concerning payment of allowances and distribution of boots and coats mentioned him as a student in the Greek department from 1683 onwards (RGADA (Russian State Archives of Ancient Documents), f. 235, op. 2, No. 111, No. 247v-248; ibid., No. 115, fol. 246). Such rapid progress in studying Greek shows that he could apparently read and write in Russian when he was accepted at the school. On 1 July 1685, together with the six best students (RGADA, f. 235, op. 2, d. 115, fol. 271v) he was transferred to Ioanniky and Sofrony Likhud in order to study at the newly formed Slavic Greek Latin Academy, located first in a specially constructed building in the Epiphany Monastery. From 1687 onwards, all the students had classes in stone chambers in the Holy Mandylion (Zaikonospassky) Monastery. Initially, the daily meal allowance that he was paid amounted to three dengas per day, that is the same amount paid during the last years of studies at the Greek Slavic School at the Moscow Print Yard. From 1 September 1685, he was paid four dengas per day (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 86, fol. 52), probably because he passed to the following level of studies. He studied at the Academy until the beginning of the 1690s. The documents for 1690–1691 mention him among the school starostas (elders) (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 92, fol. 51). One of his responsibilities was to assist the Likhud Brothers in teaching students at the Slavic department of the Academy. Some biographical facts show his achievements at the Academy. Account books of the Patriarchal Treasury Prikaz give information about good wishes expressed by students of the school for the patriarch and about blessings that the patriarch expressed for some of the students. Nikolay was mentioned among them. On 9 March 1688, “the patriarch blessed the Greek school student Nikolay Semenov with the Vladimir Icon of the Most Holy Mother of God, on paint, purchased in the year 195 (?), he came with a birthday cake” (RGADA, f. 235, op. 2, d. 128, fol. 90v); in 1691 “On 9 March , the holy patriarch blessed ... the Greek school student Nikolay Semenov with the icon of Saint Nicolas, on paint, purchased this year, he came with birthday cakes” (ibid., d. 139, fol. 94v); in December 1691, after the students “glorified Christ with the Greek chant” in the patriarchal chamber, as well as pronounced “many speeches about the Nativity of Christ” in Latin and Slavonic, Nikolay Semenov was given a golden ???.
Career:
From 1691 onwards, in parallel with his studies at the Slavic Greek Latin Academy, he was a reader at the Moscow Print Yard (decree dated 22 September 1691: “the school student Nikolay Semenov to be a reader at the Book Print Yard in the correction chamber” (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 67, p. 96). His salary was four rubles; besides this he had “meal allowances in addition to what he had, which were given to him for his school studies in the quantity of one denga per day”, and income from book publications (ibid., f. 1182, op. 1, d. 93, fol. 5v). 
In 1694, after the Likhud Brothers left teaching, he was appointed one of the main teachers at the Slavic Greek Latin Academy (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 67, fol. 99v). Following the decree of the patriarch dated 2 September 1694, he was given orders “to work in the school chambers behind the icon stand and to teach students”. He was supposed to teach the disciplines that “he, Nikolay, and Fedor (Fyodor) know themselves”. According to the same decree, the salary was supposed to be “twenty five roubles from September to March” (ibid.), or, in other words, fifty rubles a year. His salary was definitely lower than that of the Likhud Brothers prior to their dismissal. However, for a recent student of the Academy and an employee of the Print Yard, this was a great career promotion, because the highest-paid Moscow Print Yard workers received only 10 roubles more. 
On 11 December 1698, by decree of the patriarch, Nikolay Semenov was transferred back to the proof-reading room at the Moscow Print Yard, but then he was appointed book-corrector “in place of the deceased corrector hierodeacon Feofan" (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 99, fol. 30v). He remained in this position until his death in 1716. During his time at the Printing House at the beginning of the 18th century, Nikolay Semenov participated both in large events organised by the order of Peter I, such as the correction of the Bible, and in his routine work as an editor and corrector (proof-reader) of books translated and published at the time; a translation of Quintus Curtius is one of the examples of his work. 
He was a member of the commission for the correction of the Bible. The commission operated under the leadership of Feofilakt (Theophylactus) Lopatinsky (it also included Sofrony Likhud and Fedor (Fyodor) Polikarpov) from 1712 to 1720. He received 155 roubles for his work.
The Novgorod archbishop Iov (Job) asked “a certain Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov), who was at the Print Yard”, to be sent to Novgorod, but the sources do not contain information about his trip there. According to the documents, he spent all the time as a corrector at the Moscow Print Yard. Apparently, the metropolitan Iov (Job) was informed about Semenov by his teachers Ioanniky and Sofrony Likhud, who opened the Novgorod school in 1706.

According to the account books of the Book Printing Prikaz, only this list of Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov) and Fedor (Fyodor) Polikarpov’s students is available; the books mentioned mainly people who were responsible for receiving meal allowances for classmates. Most of Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov)’s students had been the Likhud Brothers’ students before. They continued their education in 1694–1698. The most famous of them was Moisey Ivanov (Arsenyev), a posad inhabitant, originally from Tula. He entered the Slavic Greek Latin Academy in 1691, when he was mentioned in documents as a 5th form student (RGADA, f. 1182, op. 1, d. 93, fol. 56). In 1695, he was listed among the poetics students, who “had studied grammar”, and was mentioned in December of the same year as a 1st class student (f. 1182, op. 1, d. 98, fol. 50). Then in 1698 he entered the Likhud Brothers’ Italian School, “by his own will” (f. 210, op. 9, col. 773, st. 3, fol. 152). In 1699, he was characterised as someone who had already learned to read and write in Italian and could speak well, and who was at the final level of the “grammatical syntax” (ibid., fol. 134). After finishing his education, he had changes in his career. On 26 July 1700, he was sent to the Ambassadorial Prikaz to work as an interpreter (translator) from Greek, Latin and Italian (ibid., fol. 152). In the Ambassadorial Prikaz, he participated in diplomatic missions to Poland (1701) with the envoy V.T. Pospelov and to Turkey (1702–1708) with P.A. Tolstoy. Then, in 1724, when archives were opened at the Collegium of Foreign Affairs, he became an archivist at the Moscow office of the CFA.
Teaching methods and materials:
Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov), along with his colleague, continued to use the teaching methods used by their teachers Ioanniky and Sofrony Likhud while they were students. Undoubtedly, studies were based on the Likhud Brothers’ manuscript textbooks, with the use of the same texts and the library that was collected for the Slavic Greek Latin Academy. 
Sources show that the educational process still included disputes over the topics covered, which students took part in, as well as presentations performed for the patriarch at Easter and Christmas. These educational components were traditional for the Academy.
Language and other teaching books by the: He was active in translating and book-writing, both within the framework of his official responsibilities and outside the walls of the Moscow Print Yard. In the late 1680s – early 1690s, together with Fedor Polikarpov and Alexey Kirillov, he translated the book “Акос” (“Akos”) by the Likhud Brothers and probably also participated in the translation of the “Мечец Духовный” (“Sword of the Spirit”). In addition, he translated the Enchiridion by the patriarch Dositheos. He probably participated in translations for the archimandrite of the Holy Sepulchre Chrysanthus Notaras, who was in Moscow from the end of 1692 till the beginning of 1694. Chrysanthus was actively interested in Russian writings and ordered their translations into Greek. One of the proofs of his work for Chrysanthus is the manuscript donated to Nikolay Semenov (Semyonov) in 1673 by way of a thank-you, with Chrysanthus’ note on his own gift (RNB (National Library of Russia), SPbDA (Saint Petersburg Theological Academy), B.II. 4, fol. 1, lower edge). He practiced composing his own works, mainly in the hymnographic genre. One of his surviving works written in the late 17th century is “Поучение на праздник святого великомученика Никиты” (“Teaching for the Feast of the Holy Great Martyr Nikita”) (draft autograph with correction in the manuscript RNB (National Library of Russia) OR (Manuscript Department), sof. 1315). In 1697–1698, he carried out orders for copying books for the Moscow patriarch Adrian: 1) he copied a Chronograph translated from Greek: “in the year 206, in different months and dates by decree ... of the patriarch, the school teacher Nikolay Semenov wrote to the patriarchal domestic treasury, the Chronograph, which was translated from the Greek language, in the form of a dest’. Fifty-three notebooks in total, quite skilfully. He was paid seven roubles for his work and one rouble for the paper and for the ink, so eight roubles in total from the domestic treasury” (RGADA, f. 235, op. 2., d. 170, fol. 200v); 2) he copied the “Толкования на все соборные послания” (“Interpretations for All the Cathedral Epistles”): “in the year 206, in different months and dates by decree ... of the patriarch, the school teacher Nikolay Semenov wrote to the patriarchal domestic treasury, on his paper, a book in the Interpretations for All the Cathedral Epistles, in the form of a poldest’, thirty three copybooks, and for the work done and for the correction, and for the paper he, Nikolay, should be paid two roubles...” (ibid., fol. 203-203v).

Personal records: (1722, Orzhitsya town in the Lubny Regiment, Russian Empire – 1827-01-27, Kyiv). Son of a priest from the Saviour-Transfiguration Church in Orzhitsya. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: From 1786 to 1798, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class.
Career:
In 1795–1797, while still a student, Stefan Semyanovsky taught Ancient Greek at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. After graduation in 1798 he continued teaching Ancient Greek. In 1799, he was a reader (sexton), later a priest at the Church of the Three Holy Hierarchs in Kyiv, in 1809–1814 a priest at Saint Sofia’s Monastery in Kyiv. At the same time, he continued teaching Ancient Greek at the Academy; from 1807 onwards, he also taught rhetoric and higher elocution. In 1817, he left teaching. In 1824–1827, he served as protoiereus at Saint Sofia’s Monastery in Kyiv.
Stefan Semyanovsky took an active part in the activities of the Russian Bible Society and was its reporter (correspondent) in Kyiv; from 1817 onwards, he was the secretary of one of the departments of the Society.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1795–1817).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes studied Ancient Greek as an option at the time; meanwhile the study of the Greek language was compulsory for students from clergy families.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The teaching of Ancient Greek was planned over three years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. One was supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies.
In the 1790s, the teaching of Ancient Greek at the Academy was based on well-established rules, which Stefan Semyanovsky also followed. At the same time, S. Semyanovsky influenced the teaching methods, because he had been teaching the language for more than 20 years without interruption. At the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, Ancient Greek grammar was taught using the book by Barlaam Lyaschevsky. The book was translated from Latin and was used at the Academy at the turn of the 18th – 19th centuries. After studying the first two parts of the book, which concerned declinations and conjugations, the teacher and his students were supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. The library of the Academy had a large number of lexicons, dictionaries and grammar books on Ancient Greek; they also were used for teaching. In addition, it was common practice to read extracts from works by various Greek authors as well as to do exercises on translation of extracts from various texts (most often by Aesop, Ephrem the Syrian, John Chrysostom).

Personal records:
(or Senyuta; Timothy) (Russian Empire – 1780, Russian Empire). Father: Mikhail (*Sosnytsia, Chernihiv area), a “pospolite”, which means that he held a “common rank”; he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, later took monastic vows with the name Mitrofan. Uncles (Timofey Senyutovich’s father’s brothers):
  • Ioaniky Senyutovich, famous for his many deeds as archimandrite at the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra;
  • Ioasaf (Joasaph), also studied at the Academy.
It is known that Timofey Senyutovich’s brothers, Dmitry and Lazar, studied at “Latin schools”. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Timofey Senyutovich studied at the Chernihiv Collegium, and then he went to study “different languages in foreign lands”, obviously, with the financial assistance of his uncle, Ioaniky Senyutovich.
Career: In 1737 (or in 1738), after his return from an educational trip to “foreign lands”, Timofey Senyutovich began teaching children “at school”. Then he was invited to be the tutor of Count Alexander Ivanovich Rumyantsev’s son Peter (Petr, Pyotr). In 1739, Timofey Senyutovich was appointed Chernihiv regimental judge. Alexander Ivanovich Rumyantsev is believed to have helped him in this. Subsequently, the general clerk Andrey Bezborodko received a complaint, in which he was accused of illegally appointing Timofey Senyutovich as a judge, since the latter was a son of a pospolite. In his explanation, Andrey Bezborodko wrote that the appointment of Timofey Senyutovich had taken place due to his knowledge of languages and previous translation activities. Timofey Senyutovich was a Chernihiv regimental judge until 1767. Then, until his death, he lived in an estate in the Chernihiv region.
Teaching institutions and families: We know precisely that Timofey Senyutovich served as a tutor in the family of Count Alexander Ivanovich Rumyantsev, who was “the ruler of Little Russia” in 1738–1740.
Students and their social status: Timofey Senyutovich’s student was Count Alexander Ivanovich Rumyantsev’s son Peter (Petr, Pyotr) Rumyantsev, later the field marshal general, who received an honourable addition to his name – Zadunaisky (“Transdanubian”). Researchers have noted that Timofey Senyutovich seems to have helped Peter Rumyantsev to develop a warm relationship to Ukraine and its people, which the commander manifested throughout his life.

Personal records: (or Szczerbacki; George; secular name: Grigory) (ar. 1725, Rogoziv village in the Pereyaslav Regiment, Russian Empire – 1754-08-18, Moscow). Georgy Shcherbatsky was the Kyiv Metropolitan Timofey Shcherbatsky’s nephew. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Georgy Shcherbatsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; Polish; Ancient Greek; rhetoric; philosophy; theology.
Career: In 1747, immediately after graduation, Georgy Shcherbatsky became a teacher in the syntax class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In 1749–1750, he taught the poetics class. He also taught Ancient Greek at the same time. Then he was a rhetoric teacher. In 1749, he took monastic vows at Saint Sofia’s Monastery in Kyiv. From 1751 onwards, he taught philosophy. In 1752, he was appointed prefect of the Academy. In summer 1753, he was summoned to Moscow and appointed theology professor and prefect at the Moscow Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1747–1752); Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy (1753–1754).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the syntax class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, which Georgy Shcherbatsky taught. At the time, students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes studied Ancient Greek as an option at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Georgy Shcherbatsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules; they also did translation exercises. Georgy Shcherbatsky continued the systematic teaching of Greek at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, initiated by Simon Todorsky and Barlaam Lyaschevsky. The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was planned over three years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. One was supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. In grammar classes, students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. The surviving exercises show the traditional “set” of tasks that students had to complete in the class. However, at the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Georgy Shcherbatsky taught Ancient Greek using the book written by Barlaam Lyaschevsky. Georgy Shcherbatsky is known to have added new information to the book. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading abstracts from works by various authors as well as through translating passages from various texts. When teaching Ancient Greek, Georgy Shcherbatsky used a number of grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Academy in Kyiv (for example, textbooks by Johann Scapula, Cornelius Schrevelius and Georg Pasor). Personal records: (or Shyshatsky; Barlaam; secular name: Grigory Stepanovich/Stefanovich) (1750-03-12, Krasylivka village in the Kozelets Uyezd (district) of the Chernihiv Province, Russian Empire – 1821-09, town of Novhorod-Siverskyi in the Chernihiv Province, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Varlaam Shishatsky studied first at the Pereyaslav Collegium, then at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the philosophy and theology classes; he also studied Greek and German. He spoke Polish. As one of the best students of the Academy, he was sent to continue his studies in Rome, but was forced to return to Kyiv because of military actions.
Career:
The existing biographical researches concerning Varlaam Shishatsky do not indicate the precise start of his teaching activities. The surviving lists of the Pereyaslav Collegium teachers show that Varlaam Shishatsky began teaching the analogy class in the 1770–1771 school year and that he was a grammar class teacher in the 1774–1775 school year. In 1776, he took monastic vows. In 1780, having the rank of hegumen, he managed the Moshnogorsky Ascension Monastery (Pereyaslav Diocese); in 1781, he was in charge of Saint Michael’s Monastery in Pereyaslav and was appointed its rector (without leaving his teaching activities). From 1781 onwards, he taught the philosophy and theology classes at the Pereyaslav Collegium, was its prefect and, later, rector (1783–1785). In 1785, due to the dissolution of the Pereyaslav Diocese, he was transferred as rector to the Novhorod-Siverskyi Seminary and was appointed rector at Saint Nicholas’ (Makoshinsky) Monastery. In 1787, he was appointed “the superior of the Vilna monasteries” and hegumen at the Vilna Monastery of the Holy Spirit and at Saints Peter and Paul Monastery in Minsk. In 1791, Varlaam Shishatsky received the rank of archimandrite and was appointed to the Vyazhishchsky Monastery near Novgorod and later was transferred to Saint Cyril’s Monastery. In 1792, Varlaam Shishatsky was appointed Prefect at the Novgorod Seminary. In 1794, Varlaam Shishatsky became the leading member of the Minsk consistory with the right to manage the Dyatlovitsky Saviour-Transfiguration Monastery. In 1795, he was ordained bishop of Zhytomyr and vicar of the Minsk Diocese. In 1796, he established a theological seminary in Ostroh. In 1799, due to the formation of the Volyn and Zhytomyr Diocese, he became the ruling bishop. From 20 December 1805 onwards, he served as bishop of Mogilev (Mahilyow) and Vitebsk (Vitsebsk), from 23 March 1808, as archbishop. In 1812, together with other clergymen, he swore an oath to Napoleon. In 1813, on the basis of a court decision, he was deprived of his rank and sent as a monk to the Novhorod-Siverskyi Saviour-Transfiguration Monastery. He remained in the monastery until his death.
We know of the great efforts that Varlaam Shishatsky put in to found the Volyn Seminary in the town of Ostroh in 1796, to find teachers and to organise the educational process. Thanks to his perseverance, a philosophy class was opened in the Seminary in 1797 and a theology class was introduced in 1799.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium; Novhorod-Siverskyi Seminary; Novgorod Seminary.
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
At the beginning of the 1770s, there were several dozen students in the grammar classes at the Pereyaslav Collegium. For example, 76 students were listed in the grammar class, where Varlaam Shishatsky taught Latin in the 1774–1775 school year. In total, 241 students were enrolled at the Collegium that year.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. Thus, in the 1774–1775 school year, out of the 76 students in the grammar class taught by Varlaam Shishatsky, 15 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the analogy (phara) taught by Varlaam Shishatsky. In contrast to the Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at the Orthodox collegiums. In the following years, Varlaam Shishatsky worked in grammar and syntax classes, where he taught grammar and syntax rules, grammar analysis and translation. When Varlaam Shishatsky worked at the Pereyaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Pereyaslav Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Personal records: (or Schvansky) (1738, Chernihiv, Russian Empire – 1790-07-12, Kharkiv, Russian Empire). Mikhail Shvansky was from a Ukrainian noble (szlachta) family. Married to: lieutenant Fedor (Fyodor) Anastasyevich Grekov’s daughter. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy from 1745 to 1760, including in the theology class.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Ancient Greek; German; rhetoric; philosophy; theology.
Career:
From 1760, Mikhail Shvansky taught Ancient Greek and German at the Kharkiv Collegium; from 1763, he taught rhetoric, from 1766, philosophy. In 1766, he was appointed prefect at the Collegium; from 1775 onwards, he was a theology professor. From 1764, he served as a priest at the Kharkiv Assumption Cathedral; in 1769, he received the rank of protoiereus. He functioned as prefect and a theology professor until the end of his life.
As protoiereus of the Assumption Cathedral in Kharkiv (which later became a metropolitan cathedral), Mikhail Shvansky played a very important role in the construction of its new building (1771–1778). Saint Clement’s Church in Moscow served as a model for the construction. Mikhail Shvansky’s contemporaries characterised him as an active organizer and also as a brilliant preacher.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1760–1790).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; nobility.
When Mikhail Shvansky was a language teacher, more than 400 students (472 students in the 1759–1760 school year) were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. At the time, from seven to ten students studied Ancient Greek; several dozen students attended German classes.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there. It is known that many sons of noblemen (szlachta) learned German.
Teaching methods and materials:
Mikhail Shvansky started teaching Ancient Greek with the basics of grammar; afterwards he taught syntax and translation. He also taught German grammar and syntax successively for three years.
As did other Kharkiv Collegium teachers, Mikhail Shvansky apparently used the book on Ancient Greek written by Barlaam Lyaschevsky (in Latin). He also used several Latin-Greek lexicons and grammar books, which were available in the library of the Collegium at the time. The surviving library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753) shows the range of lexicons that were at the disposal of the teacher. Most of the books were written in Latin. In addition, it was common practice to read short extracts from works of various Greek authors (by Agapetus and others) in order to consolidate grammar rules, as well as to do exercises on the translation of extracts from various texts (by Aesop, Ephrem the Syrian, John Chrysostom and others).
Little is known about his German teaching methods, but it is obvious that Mikhail Shvansky did not lack textbooks for students. He could use German grammar books and lexicons, which were available in the library of the Collegium. The surviving library catalogue (1753) shows that there were already a lot of French and German grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries at the Kharkiv Collegium at the time. These books had been transferred to the library by Belgorod bishops (who had once been teachers): Epiphanius (Epiphany) Tikhorsky (the founder of the Collegium), Dositheus (Dosifey) Bogdanovic-Lyubimsky, Joasaph (Ioasaf) Gorlenko and Mitrophanius (Mitrofan) Slotvinsky. Rather short book descriptions do not make it possible to identify the books accurately.

Personal records: (or Skyada, Skada, Skiyada, Skiadin, Schiada; Athanasius) (1691-06, Island of Cephalonia, Venetian Republic – 1796, Russian Empire). Son: Egor (Georgy) Afanasyevich Skiada (Skiadan) (1724–1803), he studied at the Flanginian School and the University of Padua to become a doctor and worked as a provincial doctor in Moscow. Nephew: Mikhail Skiada. According to Greek historiography, the date of the death of Afanasy Skiada is 1796 (Καραθανάθης Αθ.Ε. Η Φλαγγίνειος σχολή, σ. 268-271), although no Russian sources indicate this. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: In February 1708, Skiada entered the Flanginian School in Venice, created in 1665 with the money of Thomas Flanginis, a famous figure of the Greek fraternity in Venice. At school, his teacher was the Athenian professor Ioanis Patusas, who helped him to develop his interest for philological disciplines. He passed easily through all the levels at the Flanginian School and on 20 October 1710, he graduated together with the poet and compiler of the “Anthi Evlaveias” Lorenzo Venieris. In 1710, upon admission to one of the collegiums at the University of Padua, he was examined by Nikolaos Komnenos Papadopoulos, who advised to A. Skiada to enter the Cottunian (Kottounian) Collegium of the University. From 1711 until approximately the middle of 1714, he studied at the Faculty of Medicine and Philosophy of the University of Padua, but it is not known whether he received a diploma.
Career: Immediately after graduation, he went to Denmark, where he met Peter I in 1716. Publications mention this according to A. Skiada’s foreword to the book about Peter the Great, published in Venice in 1737 (publication: Legrand É. Bibliographie Hellénique, t. 1, p. 258). After the meeting, still according to Skiada himself, he went to Russia. In 1720, following the decision of the head of the Military Collegium A.D. Menshikov, he was appointed to serve as a dragoon with the rank of chief auditor. Referring to his poor health, he petitioned twice to the direction of the collegium to resign from military service, but did not receive any decision. So, on 7 March 1722, he appealed to the Synod with a request to take him into service at the synodal department, and his request was satisfied. On 9 May (according to other sources, on 3 May 1722), succeeding Sofrony Likhud, he was appointed “professor at the Hellenic Greek school”, located in Moscow at the Kazan Podvorye in the Vetoshny Row, with instructions to supervise students and to carry out the orders of the Holy Synod. This means that in addition to his teaching responsibilities, he was also supposed to work as a corrector (proof-reader) for the Synodal Printing House. Like Sofrony Likhud, he received a salary of 150 roubles per year for his teaching responsibilities (from the Kamor-bureau of the Synod) and 50 roubles for his corrections at the printing house. He also received 20 roubles as a monetary equivalent of ten sazhens of firewood. He unsuccessfully interceded with the Synod concerning an allowance for students who financed their studies themselves. There were about 20 of them out of the total number of 50 at the school, and they did not have enough money for food, ink and paper. In 1724 or in January 1725, he was dismissed from his teaching position, the main reason for which was the transfer of the Greek school to the control of the Moscow Slavic Latin Academy. Sources present various dates and reasons for the event. According to some of them, in 1724, the Synod supported the rector of the Moscow Academy, archimandrite of the Zaikonospassky Monastery (the Monastery of the Holy Mandylion) Gedeon (Vishnevsky) in his petition for transferring the Greek school to the monastery and uniting it with the Latin school that existed there, but Skiada “did not want to teach in that monastery” (Древняя российская вивлиофика, pt. XVI, Moscow, 1791, p. 305); according to others, on 16 January 1725, the Synod satisfied the petition of the protector of schools and printing houses, the prefect of the Academy archimandrite Gavriil (Gabriel) (Buzhinsky) over the transfer of the “Hellenic Greek” school to the Academy and the administrative subordination of the school to the rector of the Academy; but Skiada did not agree on such subordination, believing that “through this his honour was belittled without a fault” and asked for his passport in order to return to his homeland (RGIA (Russian State Historical Archives), f. 796, op. 9, 206, fol. 3-3v. ODDS (Description of Documents and Files Stored in the Archives of the Holy Governmental Synod), vol. 8 (1728), St. Petersburg, 1891, No. 206, col. 203). On 9 March of the same year, Alexey Barsov was appointed to Skiada’s position by decision of the Synod. Skiada stated that the Chancellery of the Moscow Printing House dismissed him from the Hellenic Greek School and from the rank of professor “without any fault or crime”. He also asked the Synod for the payment of his salaries, and his request was satisfied. On 10 November 1725, he was appointed Latin and Greek teacher for three years at the school founded in 1721 at Saint Alexander Nevsky’s Monastery (later the Slavic Greek Latin Seminary), with a salary of 400 roubles, 10 sazhens of firewood and one “varya’” of beer. Having left for Saint Petersburg, he fulfilled teaching responsibilities from 20 January 1726 to January 1729. In addition to his teaching, Skiada was responsible for arranging, describing and replenishing the monastery library (manuscripts of the description are not available). Afterwards he left teaching and returned home. Before doing this, he sold about 90 copies of books from his personal library to the school. He received 60 roubles for the books.
Teaching institutions and families:
Greek School in Moscow
School at the Alexander Nevsky Lavra
Students and their social status:
Clergy, raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks), posad inhabitants.
The “Hellenic Greek School” in Moscow: children of priests and servicemen; the school at the Alexander Nevsky Monastery in Saint Petersburg: children of priests, raznochintsy (people of miscellaneous ranks), craftsmen and peasants.
Nikita Sokolov, Anfinogen Romanov Efratov-Tigrovsky.
When Skiada taught at the Greek school (before it became included in the Slavic Greek Latin Academy), the school had about 30 students. Documents containing information about this period of the school are few in number.
Teaching methods and materials:
Presumably, he taught only Greek grammar at the Moscow Greek School, since the older students, who had entered the school in 1708, had already completed their studies, and the younger ones, who had entered in 1718, had not yet reached the highest levels of study.
Presumably, he used the Likhud Brothers’ grammar books in his teaching. The assumption can be confirmed by several direct and indirect facts. Firstly, as well as the Likhud Brothers, Skiada was from the same western Greek islands, having a certain tradition in teaching Greek; secondly, his education was almost the same as the Likhud Brothers’ education; thirdly, one of the surviving manuscript copies of the Greek grammar textbook by the Likhud Brothers came from the Alexander Nevsky Lavra’s collection, where Skiada could bring it from Moscow for teaching Greek.
Language and other teaching books by the: Schiada Ath. Catalogi duo codicum manuscriptorum qui in Bibliothecae Synodali Mosquensi asservantur. – Mosquae, 1723. Schiada Ath., Kappio I. Arcana Bibliothecae Synodalis et Typographicae Mosquensis Sacra, tribus catalogis codicum manuscriptorum Graecorum. – Lipsiae, 1724. Γένος,. Ήθος, Κίνδυνοι και Κατορθώματα Πέτρου του Πρώτου,. Πατρός Πατρίδος Αυτοκράτορος Πάσης Ρωσίας και εξής. Ενετίησιν, 1737. In 1722, by order of Peter I and by order of the Synod, he compiled the first printed catalogue of Greek manuscripts of the Moscow Synodal and Typographic (Printing House) Libraries, which consisted of three parts: 1) a list of 50 dated manuscripts from the Synodal Library; 2) a list of 304 manuscripts from the Synodal Library, of which Skiada determined the date; 3) a list of 93 manuscripts from the Typographic Library. According to a number of researchers (metropolitan Eugene (Bolkhovitinov), K.F. Kalaydovich, I.A. Chistovich, etc.), the Synod hurriedly commissioned the task to Skiada at the initiative of Afanasy (Athanasius) Condoidi (Kondoidi). This was due to the upcoming inspection of the Synodal Library rarities by the Duke of Holstein Karl Friedrich, the groom of the princess Anna Petrovna. According to the estimates of scholars (Matthaei, etc.), the catalogue contains quite a few errors both in dating and in the names of manuscripts, and it is clearly incomplete, since Skiada was not a paleographer and did not have the necessary experience. A total of 447 manuscripts are listed in the catalogue: 354 manuscripts from the Synodal Library and 93 from the Typographic Library; however (it is unknown whether it was the compiler’s or the publisher’s fault) the third part of the catalogue contains descriptions of only 87 manuscripts, and not of the declared 93. The catalogue was presented to Peter I on 4 January 1722, and then published in 1723 in Moscow in Russian and Latin with a circulation of 100 copies in octavo on 55 pages, 15 of which present a dedication to the emperor. Skiada received 50 rubles for his work. In 1724, the Latin text of the catalogue was reprinted in Leipzig. Then the catalogue was reprinted twice more. In 1776, it was published in the journal Nordische Nebenstunden and in 1803 it was published in Leipzig with a dedication to the memory of the publisher and theologian Johann Albert Fabricius (1668–1736). After Skiada finished his work on the catalogue of Greek manuscripts, the Synod entrusted him with the analysis and description of the Slavonic manuscripts of the Synodal and Typographic Libraries (the manuscript of the description is not known, and it was not published, but some of the Slavonic manuscripts contain Skiada’s notes in Latin. Skiada’s notes contain dates, and according to K.F. Kalaydovich, the dates were put “at random” (Калайдович К.Ф. Иоанн, ексарх болгарский, Moscow, 1824, p. 27). The Greek and Italian historiography presents some more facts about Skiada. In Russia, he married a princess from the Dolgoruky family. They had two daughters and a son whose name was George. He became a scholarship student at the Flanginian School in Venice. In 1737, Afanasy Skiada returned to Venice, where he wrote a book about Peter the Great “Γένος, ήθος κινδυνοι, και κατορθώματα Πέτρου του πρώτου...”, published in the same year at Antonio Bortoli’s publishing house. He cooperated with the same publishing house as an editor of translations of French writings. In addition, he became a member of the Greek fraternity in Venice.

Personal records: (Hryhoriy, Hryhorii, Grigori Savych/Savich, Savvich) (1722-11-22, Sotnia town of Chornukhy in the Lubny Regiment, Russian Empire – 1794-10-29, Pan-Ivanivka village, Sloboda-Ukrainian, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Grigory Skovoroda received his primary education from a sexton in a parochial school. From 1734 to 1741, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy up to the philosophy class. In 1744–1745, he continued his studies in the philosophy class at the Kyiv Academy, and in 1751–1753, he studied in the theology class (but he did not complete the full course). At the academy, he also studied Ancient Greek, German and Ancient Hebrew (his teacher was Simon Todorsky).
Career: From the autumn of 1742 to August 1744, Grigory Skovoroda was a chorister (alto or countertenor) at the Court Chapel. He left the chapel with the rank of court chorister (“regent”). In 1745, he went to Hungary as part of the so-called “Tokaj commission”, headed by major-general Fedor Vishnevsky, to purchase wines for the royal court. In the 1750–1751 school year, he taught poetics at the Pereiaslav Collegium. In 1753–1759, (with a short break), Grigory Skovoroda was tutor of Vasily Tomara, the son of the landlord Stepan Tomara in the village of Kovrai (near the town of Pereiaslav). From 1759 to 1764 (with a break), he was a teacher of poetics, Ancient Greek and Latin at the Kharkiv Collegium. In the 1768–1769 school year, he taught catechism in the so-called “additional classes” of the Kharkiv Collegium. After that Grigory Skovoroda took up the life of a wandering philosopher.
Teaching institutions and families:
Pereiaslav Collegium; Kharkiv Collegium.
Tomara, Stepan.
Landlord in the village of Kovrai (near the town of Pereiaslav).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
During the teaching career of Grigory Skovoroda, 15 to 20 students attended the poetics class of the Pereiaslav Collegium (for example, in the 1755–1756 school year, there were 15 students in the poetics class, and the total number of students enrolled at the Collegium was 127). At the same time, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium (there were 472 students in the 1759–1760 school year), 39 students attended the poetics school. In the 1763–1764 school year, Grigory Skovoroda taught Latin syntax to 96 students. Ancient Greek was studied by seven to ten students at that time. In 1753–1759, Vasily Tomara, the landlord Stepan Tomara’s son, was among his students.
Most of the students at the Pereiaslav Collegium and Kharkiv Collegium were from clerical families (although students coming from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). Grigory Skovoroda’s students were primarily children from the families of clergymen.
Teaching methods and materials:
Grigory Skovoroda started teaching Ancient Greek with the basics of grammar. He taught Latin in the syntax class. This class was supposed to finish the study of grammar and to start studying grammatical analysis and doing translation exercises.
As well as other teachers at the Kharkiv Collegium, he apparently used Varlaam Liaschevsky’s book on Ancient Greek (in Latin). He also used several Latin-Greek lexicons and grammar books which at the time were available in the library of the Collegium. The surviving library catalogue of Kharkiv Collegium (1753) revealed the range of lexicons that were at teachers’ disposal. Most books were written in Latin. It was common practice to read short extracts from works by various Greek authors (Agapetus and others) in order to consolidate grammar rules, as well as to do exercises on the translation of extracts from various texts (by Aesop, Ephrem the Syrian, John Chrysostom and others).
In the syntax class, students were also supposed to converse in Latin. The textbook used at the Kharkiv Collegium for Latin classes was at the time the book by Emmanuel Alvarez “De Institutione Grammatica libri tres” which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv Academy. A large number of books issued for Jesuit Collegiums of Rzeczpospolita were recorded in the library catalogue of Kharkiv Collegium (1753). The surviving school exercises used at the Collegium show that the students translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Cicero's letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for doing exercises. The rector of Saint Petersburg Academic Gymnasium Martin Schwanwitz participated in the translation of the book.

Language and other teaching books by the: Grigory Skovoroda is known as an outstanding Ukrainian philosopher, poet and musician. He began writing poetry while he was teaching in the family of the Pereiaslav landlord Stepan Tomara (“The Garden of Divine Songs”). Grigory Skovoroda’s Kharkiv time was quite fruitful (“Kharkiv Fables”, a course of lectures on ethics “The Initial Door to Christian Morality”, several songs etc). During his period of wandering which began in 1769 and lasted until his death, Grigory Skovoroda wrote his basic philosophical works: “Narcissus”, “Askhan”, “Alphabet”, “Silenus Alcibiadis”, “Archangel Michael's Dispute with Satan”, “Serpent’s Flood” and others. Grigory Skovoroda’s works were published posthumously (some of his works were written in Latin and Greek). Modern scholars believe Grigory Skovoroda to be the founder of Ukrainian classical philosophy.

Personal records: (or Snisarev) (1756-01-01, Levendalovka village, Valky Sotnia of Kharkiv regiment, Russian Empire – 1833-08-20, Valky, Sloboda-Ukrainian Governorate, Russian Empire). Snesarev was the son of the bell-ringer of the Church of the Transfiguration in Levendalovka village. Married to: Anna Sukhomlinova, daughter of a Valky landlord. He had four sons and a daughter. One of Snesarev’s sons was killed in the Battle of Borodino in 1812. All his sons studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, the eldest became a priest; the other two also studied at the Kharkiv University, later they chose a secular service. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Vasily Snesarev received his primary education from a sexton in a neighbouring village. From 1772 to 1782, he studied at the Kharkiv Collegium, including the theological class. He also learned Greek and German at the Collegium. After completing his studies, Vasily Snesarev went to the town of Nizhyn for teaching training. It was at the recommendation of the prefect of the Collegium, Mikhail Shvanskoi, that he went to that town, where there was a well-known Greek school in a Greek settlement. There it took him eight months to complete a two-year Modern Greek language course. Later, in 1783–1784, he attended lectures in the theological class at the Kyiv Academy and studied Ancient Greek.
Career: In 1784, he was ordained a priest. In 1784–1786, he taught Ancient Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1786, he was the protoiereus of the Cathedral of the Nativity of the Mother of God in the town of Valky. From 1787, he was a protopope of Valky district (uyezd). From 1807, he was a teacher of religion at the Valky district school. It is known that the first curator of the Kharkiv school district, Count Severin Pototsky, invited Vasily Snesarev to take the chair of theology at the Kharkiv University (which had just opened its doors), but he refused. Vasily Snesarev was the first among the clergy of Kharkiv to be awarded a kamelaukion by the Synod. In 1818, he was appointed a preacher of the Kharkiv Assumption Cathedral. In 1822, on a proposal by the university board, he was awarded a pectoral cross; in 1830, he received a gold pectoral cross.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1784–1786); district school in the town of Valky (Sloboda-Ukrainian Governorate).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
During the teaching career of Vasily Snesarev, more than 500 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium (for example, in the 1786/87 school year, there were 561 students). Vasily Snesarev taught Ancient Greek in the rhetoric class, but this language was not studied by all the students. Slightly more than twenty students learned it. In the following classes (philosophy and theology), a few students learned Ancient Greek at an advanced level.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clerical families (although students coming from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there). Vasily Snesarev’s students were primarily children from the families of clergymen.
Teaching methods and materials:
In the 1780s, the teaching of Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium was based on some established rules which were also followed by Vasily Snesarev. The Instructions on «How to Teach and What to Teach» at the Collegium (1769) as well as reports on teaching different subjects written by teachers give an idea of those rules. The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was planned for two years. In the second year it was assumed that the pupils would finish the study of Ancient Greek grammar and start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies.
Grammar rules were taught using the book on Ancient Greek written by Varlaam Liaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declinations and conjugations, the teacher was supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. The poems that were analysed by students and their teacher in a similar manner were later to be used by them as material for short speeches and translation exercises. At this stage, students were supposed to memorize short sentences from several lexicons that the teacher had. In the second year, the lexicon which was mentioned most often at the Kharkiv Collegium was that compiled by Cornelius Schrevelius. In the second half of the 1760s, thanks to the efforts of the direction of the Collegium, several grammar books, dictionaries and lexicons of the Greek language, compiled by well-known European authors (Jacob Gretser, Grzegorz Knapski and others) were purchased. Although those books were not the most modern, their total number in the Collegium library exceeded two dozen copies which made it possible for each student to use them. It was common practice to read short extracts from works of various Greek authors as well as to translate extracts from various texts (by Aesop, Ephrem the Syrian, John Chrysostom). In addition to teaching Ancient Greek, Vasily Snesarev performed liturgies in the Collegium temple. His liturgies were performed in Greek, with the participation of students and Greek merchants (in Kharkiv there was a Greek community). Vasily Snesarev was one of the first to preach in Greek in the Collegium temple. These methods of studying Greek were rare at schools at that time, but they were regularly used in the 1780s and subsequent years at the Kharkiv Collegium.

Personal records: (or Constantine; secular name: Kondrat Grigoryevich) (*1722, Town of Bohodukhiv in the Okhtyrka (Akhtyrka) Regiment, Russian Empire). He was born into a clerk’s (sexton) family. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Konstantin Sokolovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy from 1734 onwards, including in the theology class.
Career: We know that in 1748–1749 Konstantin Sokolovsky began teaching the analogy class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, while still a theology class student. In 1749, he became a teacher of grammar classes at the Smolensk Seminary; from 1755 onwards, he was a philosophy teacher, in 1760–1763, he taught theology. In 1764–1773, he served as archimandrite at the Nebin Holy Trinity Monastery in Toropets (Pskov Diocese). From 1773 onwards, he served as archimandrite at the Holy Trinity Convent in Smolensk, from 1755, at the Saviour-Transfiguration Saint Avraam (Avraamiev) Monastery in Smolensk. In 1778–1785, he was rector at the Smolensk Seminary.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1748–1749); Smolensk Seminary (from 1749).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the end of the 1740s, approximately two hundred students attended the analogy class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, which Konstantin Sokolovsky taught. In total, more than 1000 students were enrolled at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in those years.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there. The Smolensk Seminary was attended mainly by children of the clergy.
In the late 1740s – early 1750s, several dozen students attended the grammar classes at the Smolensk Seminary.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), which Konstantin Sokolovsky taught. The teacher also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. At the time, the textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (Sweden – 1752-04-11, Vyborg, Russian Empire). Married to: Anna Barck († 1746-04-19, Vyborg).
Career: Lawyer. Johann Mathias Solberg started his career as an assessor (auskultant = assessor without the right to vote) at the Svea Court of Appeal (Svea in Swedish), located in , which was one of six in the legal system. From 1719 onwards, he was a clerk in the Stockholm state chancellery. In 1734, Solberg was engaged at the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg as an adjunct for jurisprudence. He received a contract for two years with an annual salary of 300 roubles and was obliged to teach jurisprudence for four hours a day and “other political sciences” whenever required (Лузанов, 1907, p. 182). In 1737, his contract was extended for an additional three years on condition that he was also to teach history and geography (four days a week for four hours in the afternoon) as well as German style and spelling (four hours, once a week, 24 cadets). The salary remained at 300 rubles per annum. However, Solberg did not fulfill the contract completely, since he became Commissioner of Justice in Vyborg and Kexholm (now Priozersk) in June 1738.

Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know concerning Ivan Spodinsky is that he was a grammar class teacher at the Pereyaslav Collegium in the 1773–1774 school year.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (1773–1774).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
The grammar class taught by Ivan Spodinsky had 56 students at the time. In total, 232 students were enrolled at the Pereyaslav Collegium in the 1773–1774 school year.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So, in the 1773–1774 school year, out of the 56 students in the grammar class taught by Ivan Spodinsky, 14 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Ivan Spodinsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Ivan Spodinsky worked at the Pereyaslav Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the time show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Pereyaslav Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly).
