Personal records: (or Innocent; secular name: Ivan) (1761, Russian Empire – 1808, Kamianets-Podilskyi, Russian Empire). Innokenty Stavitsky was from the family of a Polish (szlachta) gentleman. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class (until 1786).
Languages and other subjects taught by t: Latin; Ancient Greek; German; history; geography; rhetoric; philosophy.
Career: He took monastic vows during his studies at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1780). Immediately after graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy he became a teacher at the Pereyaslav Collegium. He taught Latin, Greek, history and geography. In 1788, he returned to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy as a teacher. Until 1800, he taught the higher grammar class, the rhetoric class and the philosophy class (from 1795). He also taught German (1793–1795). From 1795 onwards, he also served as prefect. In 1800, he was appointed rector and theology professor at the Sharhorod Seminary (Podilia (Podolia) Province) and at the same time archimandrite at Saint Nicholas’ Monastery in Sharhorod. After the relocation of the Seminary to Kamianets-Podilskyi (1806), he was appointed rector at the Holy Trinity Monastery in Kamianets-Podilskyi. Due to illness, he left teaching and died soon after.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (from 1786); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (from 1788); Sharhorod Seminary (from 1800).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium and the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
When Innokenty Stavitsky worked as a teacher at the Pereyaslav Collegium, approximately 300 students were enrolled at the school. Stavitsky taught Latin in the grammar class; he also taught Ancient Greek. Most of the students who studied Ancient Greek were from the rhetoric class, a few were from the philosophy class. In total, he had approximately 20 students. At the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, he taught Latin and German to several dozen students from the higher grammar class.
Teaching methods and materials: Innokenty Stavitsky taught Latin in the grammar class at the Pereyaslav Collegium; later he taught Latin in the higher grammar class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In these classes, students studied grammar rules and grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. Innokenty Stavitsky was the first Ancient Greek teacher at the Pereyaslav Collegium (basically following the decree dated 27 August 1784 on the mandatory studying of Latin in the theological seminaries of the Russian Empire). Teaching Ancient Greek grammar was planned over two years. Syntax was apparently taught during the second year. In 1793–1795, Innokenty Stavitsky also taught German in the higher grammar class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Both at the Pereyaslav Collegium and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, his Latin grammar classes were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. There were a great number of books by Cellarius, published in different years, so that each student had a book. It is known that the direction of the Pereyaslav Collegium bought more than 100 copies of these books several times. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students show that they also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. There were also a great number of copies of this book, published in different years. Grammar rules were taught using the book on Ancient Greek written by Barlaam Lyaschevsky. After studying the first two parts of the book that concerned declinations and conjugations, the teacher and his students were supposed to read the Gospel and the Epistles and to practise their grammatical analysis. During the second year of studies, students were supposed to memorise short sentences from the lexicons that were available for the teacher. There were several lexicons, dictionaries and grammar books on Ancient Greek at the Pereyaslav Collegium. Some of them entered the library of the Collegium from the personal collection of the Pereyaslav bishop Job Bazilevich (who had once taught Ancient Greek at the Kharkiv Collegium). Innokenty Stavitsky used textbooks by Franz Holterhof and Johann Christoph Gottsched for teaching German grammar and syntax. Гёльтергоф Ф. Personal records: (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know concerning Kondrat Strekha is that he was a teacher in the analogy and infima classes at the Pereyaslav Collegium in 1760–1761. In the 1764-1765 school year, he still taught these classes. In 1765, he became a priest. In the following years, he was no longer on the list of the teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (1760–1765).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. Thus, in the 1760–1761 school year, out of the 35 students enrolled in the analogy and infima classes taught by Kondrat Strekha, 15 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks). In the 1764–1765 school year, there were 21 “raznochintsy” among the 50 students of the Collegium.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the analogy (phara), which Kondrat Strekha taught. In contrast to the Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory class at the Orthodox collegiums. Kondrat Strekha taught grammar rules and grammar analysis in the lower grammar class, in the so-called “infima” class. When Kondrat Strekha worked at the Pereyaslav Collegium, Latin grammar was still taught using the book by Emmanuel Alvares “De institutione Grammatica”. However, the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange were already in use at the time. The library of the Collegium had several books by these authors as well as lexicons compiled by different authors. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Pereyaslav Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Personal records: (or Suchodolski; Sylvester; secular name: Roman Markovich/Markowicz) (1773, Malyutinets village of Yabluneve sotnia in the Lubny Regiment, Poltava Province, Russian Empire – 1820 (?), Poltava, Russian Empire). Father: Mark Pavlovich Sukhodolsky, the protoiereus of the Church of Saint John the Baptist in the village of Malyutinets; he is known to have studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: In 1784–1798, Silvestre Sukhodolsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. He also studied French, German, Greek and Polish.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: German; Polish; French; poetics; rhetoric; theology.
Career: Immediately after graduation from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, from September 1798 onwards, Silvestre Sukhodolsky worked as a German and Polish teacher at the Pereyaslav Collegium. In 1800, he took monastic vows. From 1800 onwards, he also taught French. In 1801, as a good connoisseur of German and French, he was summoned to the Alexander Nevsky Seminary (Saint Petersburg). He taught French, German, poetics and rhetoric. He also served as prefect. At the same time, he was appointed cathedral hieromonk at the Alexander Nevsky Lavra. From March 1804 onwards, he served as hegumen at the White Lake Saint Cyril’s (Kirillo-Belozersky) Monastery (Novgorod Diocese), and in June of the same year he was appointed rector of the Smolensk Seminary and theology professor and also archimandrite at Saint Avraam’s (Avraamiev) Monastery in Smolensk. From the beginning of 1812 onwards, he was a theology professor at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy; in 1813–1817, at the Poltava Seminary (although it bore the name of “Poltava”, the seminary was located in Pereyaslav at the time). From 1820 onwards, he was a teacher of religion at the Poltava Institute of Noble Maidens and a priest at the Institute’s Elizabethan Church.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (from 1798); Alexander Nevsky Seminary (from 1801; Saint Petersburg); Smolensk Seminary (from 1804); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (from 1812); Poltava Seminary (1813–1817; Pereyaslav); Poltava Institute of Noble Maidens (from 1820?).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; nobility.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there. It is known that many sons of noblemen studied languages.
When Silvestre Sukhodolsky taught at the Pereyaslav Collegium, more than 400 students (443 students in the 1798–1799 school year) were enrolled at the school. Several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few from the philosophy and theology classes) studied German, Polish and French.
Teaching methods and materials: At the end of the 1790s, the Pereyaslav Collegium had well-established standards of teaching all the foreign languages. Polish had been taught from the foundation of the Collegium in 1738, German from 1763, and French from the beginning of the 1780s onwards. As before, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the Pereyaslav Collegium at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Textbooks by Franz Holterhof and Johann Christoph Gottsched are known to have been used for studying German at the Pereyaslav Collegium. The grammar book by Pierre Restaut was used for studying French. When studying foreign languages, books with varying content available in the library of the Collegium were used for translation exercises. Гёльтергоф Ф. Personal records: (Also known as Surion de Chevannes) (*1744, Chevannes-Changy, Nivernais).
Career:
Military man and then tutor. Surion de Chevannes joined the French army at the age of fourteen and served for thirteen years. In October 1771, he was in Lübeck and spent four days there while traveling to Saint Petersburg. He received a passport that described him as follows: “with black hair, a healthy face, he wears a green coat.” He continued his journey by boat to Saint Petersburg.
In 1772, he wanted to enter the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg. He sent a letter to the Academy's administration: “Monsieur de Chevane, French by nationality, a man of conduct, with irreproachable life and morals, offers his services to fill a position of governor at the Academy of Fine Arts: if the directors of this body find it appropriate to accept him, he will inspire in his students 1° Humanity, justice, benevolence, pure sentiments, honor, conduct, gentle and honest morals, the good example which is the best of all teachers, politeness, decency, honesty, benevolence, and finally all the virtues that characterize man, that form the good citizen, that distinguish him from the noise of others by making his own happiness and cooperating to that of humankind, to which all men are equally interested. 2° Declamation, if required. 3° Epistolary Science, which is the one by which the adolescent should begin to compose, to accustom his little genius to create easily. 5° Geography. 6° History. 7° A touch of Heraldry. 8° To walk nobly, to have an honest bearing, to greet according to the circumstances and the people, to present oneself with the graces and manners required in decent assemblies. He will also conform to the Methods and regulations of the Council and his Superiors. In Saint Petersburg, 12 June 1772. Chevane.” He only held this position for a few months and, upon leaving, he was able to present the certificate issued by the inspector of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg, Burdin de Saint-Martin, which stated: “I, the undersigned, certify in my capacity as inspector of the Imperial Academy of Fine Arts, that M. Surion de Chevanes has held the position of governor for nine months, that he has successfully taught the French language to some of the students, and that he has always behaved with honor and distinction, for which I have given him this certificate to serve and be useful where needed. 20 February 1773.” In February 1773, he also requested to take an exam at the Academy of Sciences of Saint Petersburg in order to obtain the certificate of tutor. The examiner Charpentier found that de Chevanes spoke and wrote French correctly.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Fine Arts (1772; Saint Petersburg).

Personal records: (*German lands – † 1796-12).
Career: As far as is known, Johann Friedrich Surlander started his teaching career at the Naval Cadet Corps. In the early 1781, he applied for the position of German teacher in the higher German class at the Academy school which was announced in the “Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti.” To be hired, Surlander had to prove his teaching abilities by a) giving a demonstration lesson and b) writing an essay about his ideas on teaching. Having read the essay, Member of the Academy of Sciences Leonhard Euler attested that Surlander had an “easy,” “unsophisticated,” and “comprehensible” style of writing, and “an adequate knowledge of German,” so that he was "able to teach it thoroughly." On account of his good command of German and his teaching skills, Surlander was recruited as teacher for the higher German class (March to May 1781) and also became supervisor of classes (надзиратель, смотритель). He kept this position until his death in December 1796.
Teaching institutions and families: Naval Cadet Corps, Academy School.
Students and their social status:
The Academy School was attended by two different categories of students. The first group were pupils in receipt of a government scholarship, the second group independent (self-funding) pupils. Among the group of independent pupils there were nobles and non-nobles. Scholarship students were often children from poor families, who were sent to the Academy school not only to learn arithmetic, reading, writing and foreign languages but also to ensure their upkeep. Sometimes the parents had to guarantee that they would not claim back their child, which was important for the Academy that needed well-educated staff members.
The family background of the pupils was very diverse, their parents’ occupations ranging from the higher nobility, army officers and officials such as staff members of the Academy’s chancellery or the Collegia to merchants, craftsmen, soldiers, farmers and even ordinary civil servants.
Teaching methods and materials:
Surlander’s essay about his method of teaching (written in German) presents the author as an enlightened educator influenced by the philanthropical ideas of his time. Surlander strongly advocated a student-oriented tuition and intended to involve the students in the selection of the learning content: “One way to get the affection and trust of one’s subordinates is to try to let them organize their pleasure – as far as possible – according to their own way of thinking and to let them decide. Thereby, you get the confidence and respect which give the required weight to all of your presentations and reprimands. One should often exchange with them and should avoid keeping them at bay by stiff behaviour. One should give them the opportunity to ask questions and should not get tired to answer them, but avoid those questions which are just asked for the sake of asking a question.” (SPF ARAN, f. 3, op. 9, No. 417, f. 10f).
Surlander recommended that the teacher should develop the curriculum and – if it proved useful – inform his students of it. The teacher should indicate “the benefits which they [the students] will have, and demonstrate the disadvantages which they will have when they act against it. One should often talk with them about their intentions which are the basis of acquiring the skills in one or the other scientific field, their satisfaction stemming from these studies, their benefits resulting from the studies for them and for their mother country as well as the honour they will receive from these studies.” (Ibid.)
One of Surlander's principal concerns was “to inspire the students with human kindness [philanthropy] towards everybody.” Furthermore, the pupils should be raised to be reflective and to become individuals with a critical mind-set: “To sharpen the mind of young people, it will not be sufficient to give them well-written books. You should let them tell you what they have read, why they liked it and which parts they did not appreciate.” (Ibid.)

Personal records: (1753, Clamecy, diocese of Auxerre – 1812-11, Moscow). Religion: Catholic.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: He received a doctorate from the Sorbonne.
Career:
Priest. Ordained as a priest in 1778, abbot Adrien Surrugues served as headmaster at the Royal College of Toulouse before emigrating with the onset of the Revolution. He is said to have taught for a time at the Institute of abbot Nicolle in Saint Petersburg. He withdrew to Moscow in the mid-1790s, where the family of Count Aleksey Ivanovich Musin-Pushkin (president of the Holy Synod, discoverer of "The Tale of Igor's Host") engaged him as a tutor. He raised the young counts Ivan and Alexandre for over ten years; the family wanted to keep him when he decided to resume his pastoral duties; he later maintained very friendly relations with the Musin-Pushkin family.
Elected as the pastor of the French Church of Saint Louis in Moscow in 1807, he was appointed to this position on 17 October of the same year (see Pesme de Matignicourt). He is also credited with playing a decisive role in the conversion to Catholicism of Countess Fiodor Rostopchin: it was said that he brought her a host at the ball in a gold bonbonnière. The entire family of the famous general governor of Moscow attended Saint Louis Church. In his letters to abbot Billy, Surrugues expressed how pleased he was that Count Rostopchin had been appointed governor of Moscow, given the relations he had with the Countess.
In 1812, abbot Surrugues reportedly declined the French authorities' offer to return to France. Concerned about the image of the French community in Moscow, of which he felt he was one of the representatives, abbot Surrugues also refused, during the occupation of Moscow in 1812, to stop mentioning the name of emperor Alexander I during religious services.
Teaching institutions and families: Institute of abbot Nicolle in Saint Petersburg (?); Musin-Pushkin family.
Students and their social status: Ivan Alekseyevich Musin-Pushkin, Alexandre Alekseyevich Musin-Pushkin.

Personal records: (or Serville).
Career:
Professor of French at the Noble Cadet Corps of the Land, he also started giving private reading lessons since May 1792. He lived on the Moika River embankment, in the Skavronski house, in the apartment of Armand-Louis Dictus-Chevalier, a steward at the court.
Author of the dialogue recited by the cadets in 1791 in front of the bust of Catherine II, he was likely in Saint Petersburg at that time and was probably in the service of the Noble Cadet Corps of the Land.

The ballet was composed by Mr. Neudin (French?). The title page briefly recalled the content of the performance: “The stage represents Parnassus. The young cadets, dressed in white, with a white apron edged in red, and holding a hammer, working on the bust of Her Majesty. - Filial offering. Our hearts are dedicated to her. – She deigns to take care of our childhood; we raise a monument in gratitude.”
Teaching institutions and families: Noble Cadet Corps of the Land; private lessons (Saint Petersburg).
Teaching methods and materials: He committed to introducing his students to the best dramatic authors (tragedies, dramas, comedies). He held his classes three times a week (on Mondays, Thursdays, and Saturdays). Each reading cost one ruble.

Personal records: (or Pyotr, Peter) (*1768, Russian Empire). Petr Sushinsky was born in the family of a priest. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Chernihiv Collegium, including in the theology class.
Career: We know that after graduation Petr Sushinsky taught the lower and then the higher grammar class at the Chernihiv Collegium from 1792 to 1795. From 1796 until 1798, he taught the poetics class. All these years he also taught German.
Teaching institutions and families: Chernihiv Collegium (1792–1798).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1793–1794 school year, the lower grammar class taught by Petr Sushinsky had 93 students. In total, 440 students were enrolled at the Chernihiv Collegium in that school year. Several dozen students from the grammar and rhetoric classes (and a few from the philosophy and theology classes) studied German.
Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there. So, in the 1793–1794 school year, there were 25 “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks) children among the 93 students of the lower grammar class, which Petr Sushinsky taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Petr Sushinsky, students studied Latin grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. By the beginning of the 1790s, the Chernihiv Collegium had well-defined traditions of teaching the new languages. German had been taught at the Collegium from 1766 onwards. When Petr Sushinsky worked at the Chernihiv Collegium, Latin grammar classes at the school were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated through reading the “School Dialogues” by Johann Joachim Lange. At the time, the Collegium had well-defined traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. School exercises of the Collegium students of the end of the 18th century show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated. As evidenced by memoirs of the Chernihiv Collegium students, all of them had the Latin grammar book and the “School Dialogues” (the Collegium purchased these books regularly). Textbooks by Franz Holterhof and Johann Christoph Gottsched are known to have been used for studying German at the Chernihiv Collegium. Гёльтергоф Ф. Personal records: (Marburg, Prussia – after 1758, Yekaterinburg, Russian Empire). Religion: Lutheran.
Career:
On arrival in Saint Petersburg in June 1735, Söechting appeared at the Academy of Sciences. It took just three months after the Academy received a note [“promemoria”] from the Chancellery (office) of the headquarters of the Siberia and Kazan factories on finding a Latin language teacher for the Yekaterinburg Latin school, who could also serve as a pastor for the foreigners who worked in the factories.  The academic authorities offered the position to Söechting, and he accepted it. The preliminary contract conditions were agreed with the Cabinet of His Imperial Majesty; the contract was signed in July 1735 at the Academy of Sciences.
According to the contract, Söechting was supposed to have 300 roubles per year as his salary, a free state-owned flat, firewood and candles; and 100 roubles for travelling in addition to his salary. In case Söechting did not wish to continue his service, he would have to announce his decision to the Ural authorities one year before. The period of the contract was not specified, which means that in fact it was an open-ended contract.
On 24 October 1735 Söechting arrived in Yekaterinburg and on 6 November he began teaching in the first, the highest class of the Latin school.  Since he did not know the Russian language, he could not teach local children, so he only taught children of the foreigners living in Yekaterinburg. They were only six in the school. The number of his students varied; some of them left Yekaterinburg with their relatives. By December 1738, Söechting had three students. By 1740, his teaching was over.
On 30 April 1740 Söechting was ordered by the Ural authorities to supervise the German school and the teacher Müsset. On 7 May, after supervising classes, he organised a presentation for the Chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters about changing the teaching order at the school and introducing work with the whole class, which indicated his possession of an advanced teaching methodology, applied apparently in the Marburg schools.
On 13 September 1740 the Ural authorities asked the General mining directory (“General-berg-direktorium”) for the first time, whether it was necessary to continue paying Söechting such a high salary in Yekaterinburg, just for foreigners.
On 10 April 1741 due to the reluctance of the German school teacher Müsset to sign a new contract (because the authorities refused to increase his salary to 200 roubles per year), Söechting was ordered to take Müsset’s job; so on 20 April, he took the position of a German school teacher. But as Müsset decided to stay in Yekaterinburg until the General mining directory (“General-berg-direktorium”) came to a decision about increasing his salary, on 29 April 1741 the Ural authorities reappointed Söechting to supervise the German school. The decree of the General mining directory (“General-berg-direktorium”) dated 31 July 1741 presented the same decision.
Therefore, in October 1741, Söechting re-addressed the authorities with the question of the introduction of a new order of education at the German school and giving him the “Uchrezhdeniye” by Tatishchev (dated 1736 and addressed to teachers of the Ural schools), which standardised their activities; he also asked them to specify his responsibilities.
Only on 9 July 1742 did the authorities reply to the idea: Söechting received the “Uchrezhdeniye” and was ordered to “act according to this one, and to those of its subdivisions, which are useful and can work for a better order”, i.e. he was given the task of introducing the new study organisation methods to the German school. He also received a school training schedule, attached to the “Uchrezhdeniye”, a form for reporting on students’ progress, and a list of their names.
Due to the dismissal of the teacher Müsset at his request from 1 November 1745 and his departure to Moscow, Söechting took over his responsibilities, instructional books, and students and began teaching at the German school. But in November 1746, he left for Nerchinsky Zavod (Nerchinsky plant or factory) for his pastoral affairs. He did not find anyone to replace him as a German teacher and continued to travel until November 1747. After Müsset returned with his new contract signed at the Mining collegium, on 1 October 1747 he began teaching at the German school. As soon as Söechting arrived from Nerchinsk, on 20 November 1747, he was ordered by the Ural authorities to “do the same business”, although they did not specify what exact business they meant. Therefore, in March 1748, the supervisor of Yekaterinburg schools Fedor Sannikov put the following question to the authorities:  what students should Söechting teach and what subject should he teach them?
Only on 20 June 1749 did the members of the Chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters decide, “so that he would not be idle”, to assign eight German school students to Söechting for Latin language studies. So, from 9 July 1749 the activities of the Latin school in Yekaterinburg were restored, but came to an end in October 1755, when the last of its students left the school to work.
Along with teaching Latin and German and supervising the German school, Söechting fulfilled pastoral duties for the Protestants who lived on the vast territory dependent on the Chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters, from Kazan in the West to Nerchinsk in the East. He went at their request for communion and confession, accompanied by a soldier assigned by the authorities.  In Yekaterinburg, he administered oaths to foreigners, who signed contracts to join or prolong the service.  He served as a magistrate, arbiter and executor among foreigners, and as an attorney of the German community at state factories.
Söechting also performed the role of first librarian of Yekaterinburg. He was in charge of books that were sent on the initiative of V.N. Tatishchev from the Academy of Sciences; he described the books, listed them in the catalogue, and gave them to readers.
It should be noted that the Ural authorities addressed the question of Söechting’s dismissal to the central governing body of the mining plants several times. In April 1741, due to the dismissal of all the children of clergy from the Latin school according to the decree of the Synod and the General mining directory (“General-berg-direktorium”) and because Söechting did not work with foreigners’ children anymore, the directory was asked whether it was necessary to keep him as a teacher for the factories. In September 1742, Söechting was described as someone who was not necessary at the German school, and the Ural authorities asked the following question: would it not be wrong for the foreign Protestants to be the ones who pay the pastor? In January 1745, another request was sent to the Mining collegium. It questioned what to do with the pastor who “until now is paid by the State”. In October 1745, when Müsset left for Moscow and Söechting began to teach at the German school, the authorities put forward the question of closing the German school and reported to the centre that Söechting was not needed, again.
According to the decree of the Mining Collegium dated 13 February 1754 and issued after the latest submission of the Ural authorities, Söechting was supposed to teach Latin to children on the same terms and to sign a contract stipulating these terms. With Söechting’s consent, the contract was drawn up in two copies. According to the contract, he was supposed to work as a Latin teacher for five years and, at the same time, serve as a pastor for Protestants on the same terms (a salary of 300 roubles per year, a state-owned flat, firewood and candles) plus the provision of three carts for departure from Yekaterinburg at the end of the contract. The members of the Chancellery (office) signed the contract, but Söechting refused to do so. He wanted to be noted as a pastor while the teacher’s title would be mentioned in the same way as it was in the old contract. Moreover, he requested that a clause about granting him 100 roubles from the treasury, for his return journey, be added to the contract.
Therefore, at the meeting of the Chancellery (office) of the factory headquarters that took place on 25 October 1754, its members expressed bewilderment: the positions were indicated just as in the contract dated 1735, but money given by the state for departure from Yekaterinburg was not mentioned in the contract. It was stated that no students had been taught perfect Latin by Söechting in the 19 years given to him. At that time, he was only responsible for one student. That is why Söechting “has nothing to do at the school and is not needed, because he does not know the Russian language enough and can not teach children who do not speak German yet”. The Russian students who had been transferred to him were behind in other disciplines necessary for the factories. Besides that, the period of their education became longer, and the treasury suffered from excessive expenses.
It was decided to report to the Mining collegium that Söechting did not sign the contract and was “not needed there, and should be dismissed”. In March 1758, the Ural authorities sent their comments about the factories' staff to the Mining collegium and mentioned the uselessness of German and Latin schools in Yekaterinburg, again. Söechting continued to serve as a pastor at the state factories of the Urals and Siberia until his death in the late 1750s.

Simultaneously with teaching, Söechting served as a pastor for Lutheran foreigners who held contracts with the Chancellery (office) of the headquarters of the Siberia and Kazan factories. The territory controlled by the Chancellery stretched from Kazan in the West to Nerchinsk in the East.
At the request of the Saxon foremen, Söechting visited Kushvinsky Zavod in December 1739 and March 1741, and the plants of Perm mining authorities in March and December 1745, which employed about 30 Saxons.  According to the decree of the Mining collegium dated 25 July 1746, he went to Nerchinsky Zavod (Nerchinsky plant or factory) in November 1746 and returned a year later, in November 1747. In February 1750, he went to Perm at the request of a foreigner; he also went there in the winter of 1751. On his return he was sent to the Kolyvano-Voskresenskiye plants, which belonged to the Cabinet of His Imperial Majesty, for confession and communion of the local foreigners, at the request of the lieutenant-general, staff officers and company officers, who promised that he would be paid for travel and for work. In winter 1754, he travelled to Nerchinsky Zavod (Nerchinsky plant or factory) again.
During his trips to the nearby factories, Söechting was supposed to be replaced by one of his best students, or by the supervisor of the Yekaterinburg schools, the German school teacher Heinrich Müsset, who did not know Latin. During his trips to the Siberian factories, the teaching stopped for many months.
In addition to his pastoral service, probably immediately upon his arrival in Yekaterinburg, Söechting was assigned control of foreign books at the Department of Mines Library in Yekaterinburg (V.N. Tatishchev, the head of the state-owned factories in the Urals and Siberia, initiated the formation of the library back in 1734). The library was enriched with books ordered at the Academy of Sciences in 1735, 1736 and 1737, and with a large consignment of foreign books that Tatishchev sent from Samara in December 1737 at the request of the teachers Kondratovich and Störmer.
According to Söechting's records of book borrowing, Tatishchev’s personal library was also integrated into his supervision. The library was officially transferred to the state-owned property on 25 June 1737, on the eve of Tatishchev’s departure from Yekaterinburg to Samara.
Söechting became the first official librarian in Yekaterinburg. He compiled a catalogue of Tatishchev’s personal library when it was transferred for the benefit of the factories. In doing so, he showed an ability to catalogue and describe books, indicating the author, the book title, the place and year of publication in most cases.  It was Söechting who officially received the books from the Book Chamber of the Academy of Sciences, and the large consignment of books from Samara in 1738, as well as the books that were delivered later. In 1739, at the request of the General mining directory (“General-berg-direktorium”), Söechting described the entire composition of the Yekaterinburg library stock, including Tatishchev’s collection.
He had the keys to the library and gave books to readers. In 1740, Söechting made a report on the books that had been taken by readers from 1737 to 1739 and were still not returned, despite his demands. There were 25 readers and 145 books on the list.  Teachers borrowed some of the books for their own use as well as for lessons with their students (for example, Kondratovich used 55 books).
Teaching institutions and families:
Yekaterinburg Latin School; Yekaterinburg German School.
At the Latin school (in 1735–1739), Söechting taught exclusively foreign children, who knew German.
At the German school (from November 1745 to November 1746, only a year, due to his subsequent departure to Nerchinsky Zavod {Nerchinsky plant or factory} for his pastoral affairs) and at the newly opened Latin school (from July 1749 to October 1755), Söechting taught Russian children, who had a basic knowledge of German thanks to their studies at the Yekaterinburg German school.
It is possible that Söechting, who had plenty of spare time, could teach German, Latin, arithmetic, history and geography to foreign children at home in Yekaterinburg, because, according to the documents, foreign children received their education at their own expense, which means that they paid for it.
Söechting was probably the best candidate as a home teacher (tutor).
Students and their social status:
From 1735 onwards, in the 1st class of the Latin school there were: sons of a doctor; of a merchant; of a teacher; of factory foremen; of a chief of police.
In 1749–1755, at the Latin school there were: children of the factory administration workers, of a sergeant, of an assayer.
It is impossible to determine the social composition of the German school students taught by Söechting in 1745–1746.

From November 1735 onwards, he taught in the first class of the Latin school. His students were children of foreigners living in Yekaterinburg – Germans, an Englishman, and a Swede. They were few in number and became increasingly fewer over time, due to a change of residence in the Urals, or to the departure of the family from the Urals after the death of the head of the family.
When the school was opened, Söechting had six students: Carl Sprintzell, son of a headquarters physician; Carl Moreley, son of a merchant, who arrived from Moscow with the Englishman Dr. Grefe; Asaph Rose, son of a teacher at the German school, Peter Trumler and Andrew Bellunin, children of hammersmiths, and Matthew Somma, son of a “dismissed” Swede. The age of the students: 12, 13, 15 (two of them), 19 years old.
In April 1736, Sprintzell left the school (due to the death of his father and to the departure of his family), Moreley left the school in June 1737 (Grefe left for Samara with Tatishchev), Trumler left in November.
In August 1737, the children of the former captive Swede, Captain Karl Brandt, the chief of police in Yekaterinburg, Karl and Wilhelm joined the class. In September, Peter Gele joined the class, but left in February 1738. At the end of 1738, Söechting had only three students (Rose and Brandt’s children); in December 1739, Rose left Yekaterinburg with his mother.
In July 1749, when the Latin school resumed its activities, Söechting had eight 11–17-year-old Russian students, who learned the basics of the German language at the German school. At the end of 1751, they continued studying. Gradually they began to leave to work. In the first half of 1753, Söechting had four students, in May 1754, they were three, one of them left to work in assaying, another became a teacher at the Yekaterinburg verbal school.  In 1755, the last student, who was often ill and absent from school, was sent to work in mining.
Among his last group of students, there was Nikita Yartsev, son of a berg-geschvoren, who was the first among the natives of Yekaterinburg to continue his studies at Moscow University. Later, he was the head of the Ural factories in 1797–1802.
In November 1745, Müsset transferred 17 German school students to Söechting. The latter taught them before his departure to Nerchinsk for pastoral affairs until October 1746.
Teaching methods and materials:
Latin and German (reading, writing, spelling, syntax), the New Testament, history, geography, arithmetic.
Söechting taught these subjects (except German) to children of foreigners at the Latin school from 1735 onwards.
He only taught German (reading, writing, spelling, syntax) at the German school in 1745–1746.
He only taught Latin (reading, writing, spelling, syntax) at the Latin school in 1749–1755; his students went to the arithmetic school at specific hours.
According to Söechting’s reports about the success of his first students, three of the six children of foreigners in Yekaterinburg began studying Latin at home, in the family. They learned grammar and syntax; two students had the time to review them during the year. Other students started with learning to read and to write, they read the Vocables and Donate. Then they moved on to grammar and learned the rules of orthography as well as etymology and syntax. Then they reviewed them. They also learned the basics of the German language in their families or with their home teachers (tutors) before entering the Latin school.
After studying the rules of Latin grammar, they read “Lange’s Conversations” and translated and analyzed the text from the point of view of grammar rules. Since J. Lange's textbooks only appeared in the state-owned Yekaterinburg library in 1738 (they were sent by V.N. Tatishchev from Samara), it is clear that the students had those textbooks in their homes and used them in class. The same applies to the geography textbooks by Hübner (their first chapter talked about the globe and images of parts of the world; the book also gave information about countries, as indicated in Söechting’s reports about the success of his students).  The students not only learned geography themselves, but they also “listened” to the reading of their teacher, or perhaps read aloud in turns.
The reading and explanation of the book by Cornelius Nepos “De Vita Excellentium Imperatorum” helped consolidate their knowledge of the Latin language. The reading of the New Testament and the Catechism by M. Luther (“The Moral Book”) strengthened their knowledge of the German language.
Since Söechting did not know Russian and thus could not use a Russian textbook while German textbooks on arithmetic were not bought for schools in 1735, his own textbooks published in German were used for studying arithmetic.
During the supervision of the German school as a curator (1740–1745), in May 1740, Söechting proposed to change the teaching order at the school, he set up a schedule of classes by days of the week and times. The teacher had to follow the schedule. On Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday mornings, the students were supposed to read, in turns, the New Testament in German and to answer the teacher's questions. In the afternoon, their task was to do the same, but without explaining the text. On Wednesday mornings, they were to take turns to read the Apostle and to answer the teacher's questions. Their task for Saturday was to read and explain the Gospel, the learning of Gospel verses was given as a home task.
On Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, the 2nd and 3rd hour of the morning classes were devoted to listening to the homework, performed by the students (at the same time the teacher gave home tasks for the next few days, and the students began to do those tasks in order to save time); then the students translated texts from Russian into German and from German into Russian, interpreted them and explained the grammar rules using those texts. On Monday and Tuesday, the texts were from the Bible or the Sacred Conversation, on Thursday and Friday – from “Aesop’s fables”.
On Wednesday, the 2nd and 3rd hours were devoted to the study of grammar. The teacher dictated a task, which one of the students performed on the blackboard, and identified the mistakes that he made. The other students wrote the exercise down in their notebooks, listened to the teacher’s explanations of complicated words, and wrote the words down in their notebooks. If the teacher had enough time, he was supposed to check the exercises in their notebooks and explain his students’ mistakes, applying the appropriate syntax rules, and then ask his students about declinations with an explanation of the rules.  The two days before Saturday were devoted to homework on grammar that the students did in their notebooks. On Saturday, the 2nd and 3rd hours were again devoted to grammar exercises according to the Wednesday arrangements. The teacher was also supposed to “listen” to the verbs and to ask his students about them.
German grammar was supposed to be studied during the afternoon classes (after lunch on Wednesdays and Saturdays, the students were allowed to go home). Söechting suggested that after reading the Gospel, on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday, students should write in Latin and German in their copy-books, pre-filled by their teacher, and the teacher should check and correct their spelling mistakes.
On Friday, after the reading of the New Testament, the teacher was supposed to explain spelling rules: one of the students filled in a table on the blackboard, the teacher corrected his mistakes and explained why the word had this or that letter, and the other students listened to the teacher's explanations.
The reading of the “Vedomosti” and the “Primechaniya” (a supplement to the newspaper) for an hour on Friday afternoon would certainly help consolidate the knowledge of the German language. A set of the newspapers “Sankt-Peterburgskie Vedomosti” and “Primechaniya”, the first popular science magazine published by the Academy of Sciences as a supplement to the newspaper, was available at the school (from 1728 until the end of the 1730s).
The teaching methods that Söechting proposed for the German school were authorized for use in July 1742 (they could be used according to Söechting’s discretion), but the decision was delivered to him only on November 20 together with a list of students indicating their success in their studies. Unfortunately, no known documents that would reveal the extent of implementation of these methods at the German school in Yekaterinburg are available.

Personal records:
(or This)
Originally from Metz.
He married in Saint Petersburg Rose, known as Marie Grandjean (*Paris), who remarried in Moscow in 1790 to Jean-Ignace Vanderheyden, believing him to be dead.
Career:
Governor of the 3rd age at the College of the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg since the late 1760s. In 1772, Jean Thys sent a letter to the Academy Council in which he complained about the attitude of the Academy's deputy inspector, Godfrin: “Godfrin was dragging my downfall, inspiring aversion towards me in everyone, as if my company were pernicious. I wanted to believe nothing since at the same time he showed all kinds of consideration for me, but shortly thereafter, two governesses and a governor who left the Academy at the same time spoke the same way to me. […] M. Godfrin had told him [to a governor, apparently] that I was right to stay at the Academy, as if I left, it would be impossible for me to find employment elsewhere.” Godfrin was dismissed on 20 November 1772, and on 22 December, following the proposal of the interim inspector Burdin de Saint-Martin, Thys was appointed deputy inspector, with an annual salary of 370 rubles. Another governor, Gillot, took his place. In 1776, Thys's salary was increased again: salary, bonus, meal expenses, and an additional amount for the German class, totaling 596 rubles. However, on 25 May 1776, Thys reported to the Council that “since my last illness, having been unable to recover my health despite all possible care, I am forced, given the great decline I am experiencing, to ask for permission to retire.” He requested a retirement pension for his seven years of service, but since the statutes did not grant him this right, he only received a bonus of 300 rubles.
In April 1777, he was admitted to the Academy of Sciences to teach French in the "lower class" with a salary of 250 rubles. But on 8 June 1778, he was dismissed because the Academy no longer needed his services, also due to his "absences." He disappeared and was thought to be dead. He was in the government of Kiev when he took the oath in 1793. In 1794, he reappeared in Kazan.
Teaching institutions and families: College of the Academy of Fine Arts (late 1760s – 1776); Academy of Sciences (1777–1778), all in Saint Petersburg.

Personal records: (or Tichorski; Epiphanius) (†1731-07-02, Belgorod, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Epiphany Tikhorsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career:
We know that Epiphany Tikhorsky taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the 1710–1711 school year. In 1711, he was in charge of economy at the Academy. He remained at Saint Peter and Paul’s Monastery near Hlukhiv for some time; from 1719 onwards, he served as archimandrite at the Annunciation Monastery of Nyzhin (Chernihiv Diocese). From 9 July 1711 until his death, he served as bishop of Belgorod and Oboyan. Epiphany Tikhorsky is known as the founder of the Kharkiv Collegium.
As the bishop of Belgorod and Oboyan, Epiphany Tikhorsky opened a school at Saint Nicholas’ Monastery in Belgorod in 1722; in 1726, the school was transferred to Kharkiv. The school was given the name of “collegium”. Epiphany Tikhorsky put in great efforts to organise every aspect of the collegium’s activity. He obtained permission from the Synod to use the Ozeryany, Chuhuiv and Arkadiev Monasteries in support of the new school as well as to unite the Parish Church of Intercession with the school, laying the foundation for the School’s Monastery of Intercession in Kharkiv. He invited graduates and teachers from the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy to take up positions as teachers at the Kharkiv Collegium. In 1731, a charter followed Epiphany Tikhorsky’s appeal, according to which the status of a collegium was assigned to the school together with the corresponding privileges. The arch-priest bequeathed his personal library and all his savings to the Collegium. For several decades, the Collegium was also known under the name of the “Tikhoretsianskaya” Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1710–1711).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the infima class, which Epiphany Tikhorsky taught.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Epiphany Tikhorsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (Secular name: Simeon Fedorovich/Fyodorovich) (1701-09-01, Sotnia town of Zolotonosha in the Pereyaslav Regiment, Russian Empire – 1754-02-21, Pskov, Russian Empire). Simon Todorsky’s father was a Cossack of the Zolotonosha sotnia in the Pereyaslav Regiment. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: In 1718–1727, he studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class. He left for Saint Petersburg and afterwards for Germany to continue his studies. From 1730 onwards, he studied at the University of Halle. He studied theology, Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew and other languages with the help of John-Heinrich Michaelis, a Hebraist well-known in Europe.
Career:
While a student at the University of Halle and after graduation, Simon Todorsky was actively engaged in translation activities. He translated from German “The Book on True Christianity” by Johann Arndt and “The Teaching on the Beginning of the Christian Life” by Anastasius the Preacher, as well as the “Catechism” by August Hermann Francke. Most of his translations were in the Ukrainian edition of the Church Slavonic language. On his way back from Germany, Simon Todorsky taught Greek at an Orthodox school in Belgrade for more than a year.
Returning to the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in 1738, Simon Todorsky began to teach Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew and German. In 1740, he took monastic vows. He taught the languages until 1742. In May 1742, he was summoned to Moscow to teach the law of God to the heir to the throne, Peter (Petr, Pyotr) Fedorovich (Fyodorovich) and to his wife Ekaterina (Catherine) Alekseevna. On 12 September 1743 he received the rank of archimandrite at the Ipatiev Monastery in Kostroma. In 1744, he took part in the revision of the text of the Slavonic Bible. From 31 March 1745 he served as bishop of Kostroma, from 18 August 1745 as bishop of Pskov. From 1748 until his death, he served as archbishop of Pskov.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1738–1742).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
At the time, students from the rhetoric, philosophy and theology classes studied Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew and German as an option at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching methods and materials:
The name of Simon Todorsky is associated with the systematic teaching of Greek, Hebrew and German at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. Researchers believe that he brought to the Academy the teaching norms and methods common in German universities (primarily the University of Halle). The teaching of Ancient Greek grammar was planned over three years. Grammar was the first subject to be learned. One was supposed to finish grammar studies and to start learning the syntax of the language in the second year of studies. A similar “plan” was used for teaching Ancient Hebrew. The teaching of German was planned over two years.
Simon Todorsky used books which he had brought from Germany. He used grammar books written by John-Heinrich Michaelis for teaching Ancient Greek and Ancient Hebrew. It is known that grammar rules were consolidated through reading abstracts from works by various Greek authors as well as through translating passages from various texts. Probably, Simon Todorsky also used several Latin-Greek lexicons and grammar books, which he had brought from Germany and which were registered in his personal library (for example, the textbooks by Johann Scapula, Cornelius Schrevelius and Georg Pasor). The library of the Academy also had many of these books. This is also true for books on Ancient Hebrew and German, a large number of which were registered in Simon Todorsky’s library (for example, books by Heinrich Opitz, Johannes Buxtorf, Johann König, Joahnn Georg Seybold and François-Antoine Pomey). These books were also available in the library of the Academy. Rather short descriptions do not make it possible to identify accurately all the lexicons, grammar books and dictionaries, mentioned in the catalogues of Simon Todorsky’s book collections and those held at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
The surviving manuscript records of grammar and syntax courses and the “school dialogues” in Ancient Greek, Ancient Hebrew and German show the teaching methods applied by Simon Todorsky at the Academy. The manuscript collections of the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra (No. 338), the Kyiv Theological Seminary (No. 279), the Church-Archaeological Museum affiliated with the Kyiv Theological Academy (No. 67) and the libraries of the Chernihiv Theological Seminary (No. 195) include students’ notes and exercises, which show the structure of the courses and make it possible to reconstruct the traditional “set” of exercises that Simon Todorsky’s students performed. Since the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the time, these manuscripts are an essential part of the evidence for specific educational practices. The methods of teaching Ancient Greek used by Simon Todorsky are also demonstrated by the grammar book, published by his student Varlaam Lyashchevsky (Łaszczewski) (Łaszczewski W. Institutional Linguae Graecae Liber, Wratislaviae, 1746). Varlaam Lyashchevsky is known to have used Simon Todorsky’s notes for his grammar book.

Personal records: (or Fyodor, Theodore) (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know about Fedor Tripolsky is that he was a teacher in the lower Latin grammar class at the Pereyaslav Collegium in the 1797–1798 school year. In the following years, Fedor Tripolsky was no longer on the list of the teachers.
Teaching institutions and families: Pereyaslav Collegium (1797–1798).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
At the end of the 1790s, several dozen students studied Latin in the grammar classes of the Pereyaslav Collegium. In the 1797–1798 school year, there were 405 students at the Collegium.
Most of the students at the Pereyaslav Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meshchane (low-class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: Fedor Tripolsky taught Latin grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. Fedor Tripolsky’s Latin grammar classes were based on the book by Christoph Cellarius. The Collegium had a great number of books by Cellarius, published in different years, so that each student had a book. It is known that the direction of the Pereyaslav Collegium bought more than 100 copies of these books several times. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students show that they also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel as well as from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero’s letters, and books by the Roman historian Cornelius Nepos. The book by Johann Joachim Lange “Colloquia scholastica” – “School Dialogues” was also used for exercises. There were also a great number of copies of this book, published in different years. Personal records: (Trofimowicz; Theophanes; secular name: Fedor/Fyodor) (†1736, Regiment town of Lubny, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: We know that Feofan Trofimovich studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theology class (until 1725). During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Career: Feofan Trofimovich is known to have taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the 1727–1728 school year and the poetics class in 1728–1729. From 1730 onwards, he was a member of the Kyiv consistory. From 1733 until his death, he served as hegumen at the Saviour-Transfiguration Mhar Monastery near Lubny (Poltava Diocese).
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1727–1729).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the infima class taught by Feofan Trofimovich.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Feofan Trofimovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums. The surviving exercises intended for school and home work show that the students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (1762-08-05 – 1828-04-22, Tuchów, Austrian Empire). Religion: Catholic.
Education: Wincenty Tywankiewicz entered the Society of Jesus in August 1781 and received a religious education at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. He spent the 1781–1782 academic year at the novitiate, in 1782–1784, he studied philosophy, in 1791–1795, he studied theology.
Languages and other subjects taught by t: French; Latin; rhetoric, poetics; systematic theology; moral theology.
Career:
Priest. Wincenty Tywankiewicz began teaching at the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium, where he was a French teacher (1784–1786) and a teacher of Latin grammar (1784–1787). At the Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium, he taught Latin grammar, rhetoric, poetics and French (1788–1791, 1795–1798) and was a boarding school regent from 1795 to 1798. During the first two years of study in the theology class, Tywankiewicz taught French and later systematic theology (1798–1803, 1806–1808) and moral theology (1808–1809) at the Polatsk Jesuit Collegium. In 1803, he was appointed Rector of the Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium and worked in this position for three years. From 1810 to 1814, he was the rector of the college in Mstsislaw. In 1814, he was elected Provincial of the Society of Jesus in Belarus. Tywankiewicz retired from this responsibility in 1817 and became a preacher in Orsha, where he heard of the dissolution of the Society of Jesus in Russia.
After the expulsion of Jesuits from Russia, W. Tywankiewicz moved to Galicia, where he was the rector of the Lviv mission of the Order for a year (1820–1821), the instructor of the house of the third probation (tertianship) in the village of Stara Wieś for two years (1821–1823) and finally the head of the Mission in Tuchów from March 1823 until his death in April 1828.
Teaching institutions and families: Mahilyow Jesuit Collegium (1784–1787); Mstsislaw Jesuit Collegium (1788–1791, 1795–1798); Polatsk Jesuit Collegium (1798–1803, 1806–1809).
Students and their social status: Clergy; urban lower and middle class; nobility.

Personal records: (or Ivan Petrov) (*Paris) From a family of Champagne origin, consisting of notaries and attorneys in the bailiwick of Arc-en-Barrois. Father: Pierre de Varennes, seigneur des Carrières (†1781), squire, quartermaster, former bodyguard of the mercery, and councilor of Paris in 1772. Mother: Catherine de Longchamps (1719–1797). Grandfathers: Pierre de Varennes (†1727), clerk of the buildings of Paris, on one side; Jean-Baptiste de Longchamps, master brewer, on the other. Married to: Rose-Jeanne-Louise Brina, widow of Pierre-Robert Leplé, daughter of Jacques Brina and Christine Varcio, from Turin (marriage concluded on 20 September 1792 at the Church of Saint Louis of the French in Moscow; witnesses: Louis Annoni, merchant; François Brochet, merchant; Alexandre Deudon, merchant; Paul Palouze, doctor of medicine; marriage contract was registered on 14 June 1792, at the French vice-consulate in Moscow).
Career: Tutor and traveler. Enrolled at the age of twelve as a naval cadet in Toulon, Jean-Pierre de Varennes des Carrières held this rank for sixteen years, then “he sank into debauchery,” went into debt, and was discharged. He traveled to Italy, Spain, and England but did not dare return to France even though his father had paid his debts. He went to Hamburg, met the French ambassador, a relative, and confessed his debauchery and extreme poverty. The ambassador advised him to go to Russia, where the young man, having some knowledge of the sciences, could find a favorable position. Varennes des Carrières obtained a passport from the Russian minister and went to Saint Petersburg, passing through Lübeck in 1778 or 1779. However, he only stayed fifteen days in Saint Petersburg and continued his journey to Moscow. There, he worked as a tutor in the family of general Isakov and in other families before taking a position at the gymnasium in Kazan (probably the gymnasium affiliated with Moscow University). He then learned through a letter from his mother of his father's death (in 1781); his mother wished to pay off all his debts (nearly £130000!) to allow for his return to France. Varennes des Carrières stayed in Kazan for three years before returning to Moscow. He then worked for M. Lunin and taught in his estate near Viazma. Already having a certain capital, Varennes des Carrières decided to temporarily abandon his tutoring activities to travel around Russia. He passed through Orel, Baturin, Glukhov, Voronezh, Kharkov, Kherson, Kizliar, and Astrakhan, then along the Volga to Saratov. This first journey lasted a year and ten days: Varennes des Carrières was pleased to have observed “rarities” in these remote corners of the Russian Empire. A new stay in Moscow lasted only six months because he had enough money again to undertake another trip: this time he was able to see the old Russian cities of Rostov, Yaroslavl, Vologda, Veliki Ustyug, and Viatka, and returned once more to Kazan where he had taught, then to Perm, Yekaterinburg, Tobolsk, and in towns of his province where he searched for minerals to build a collection. In Yekaterinburg, he met an Italian woman living with the manufacturer Turchaninov. Her name was Louise Leplé, born Brina. He had time to fall in love and persuaded her to marry him. He returned to Moscow and made another trip to Siberia to visit the Kolyvan and Nerchinsk factories and briefly reunite with his beloved. She agreed to go to Moscow ahead of him to wait for his return. The lovers met again in Moscow in 1792, at the house of the wife of brigadier Sokorev, and married on 20 September of the same year. However, the newlyweds were without resources: all of Varennes des Carrières' money had gone on travels, and he had only his mineral collection left. He quickly found a buyer, major general knight Stepan Stepanovich Apraksin (†1827, son of the president of the War College and field marshal), who paid 5000 rubles for half of his collection, but only 500 rubles in cash, the rest in promissory notes. Apraksin soon left for Saint Petersburg with his wife, born Princess Golitsyna. Mme de Varennes des Carrières, likely tired of their relative poverty, stole a promissory note for 2000 rubles and exchanged it with Apraksin's steward for 1500 rubles. The couple quarreled, and Mme de Varennes left her husband. She found a job as a children's governess near Saratov with the landowner Abalduyev. Meanwhile, Varennes des Carrières was in Tver near Moscow when he took the oath in 1793. He then imagined writing letters that he signed with the name La Mariner (?), a military commander in the revolutionary army in Germany, in which he invited himself to France, a means for him to bring his wife back. These letters were fabricated by chevalier Didier de Morancourt, a friend of Varennes des Carrières, who was to bring them to the attention of his wife. The French in the colony, upon learning this news, alerted the governor of Moscow: suspicion was rampant at that time, and it was not uncommon to see foreigners denouncing their compatriots for fear of being denounced themselves. Varennes des Carrières was then living in Moscow with the Italian Campodi, in the 5th part of the city. He assured the authorities that the whole story with the false letters was merely a "mischief" and that he intended to live and die in Russia, which had become his new homeland. Nevertheless, Morancourt and Varennes des Carrières were imprisoned, and the empress ordered their expulsion from the Empire.
Teaching institutions and families: Isakov family; gymnasium in Kazan (probably the gymnasium affiliated with Moscow University).

Personal records: (1737-09-24, Paris – 1801-07-23, Saint Petersburg) Father: Jean Vauvilliers (1698, Noyers, Yonne – 1766-07-20), holder of the chair of rhetoric at the University of Paris. Unmarried.
Career:
Professor. Under his father's guidance, he learned Latin and Greek at a very young age and was initially appointed to the king's library. In 1766, he was appointed lecturer and professor of Greek at the Royal College of France. Thanks to his Essai sur Pindare (Paris, 1772, in-12°) and Examen du gouvernement de Sparte (Paris, 1769, in-12°), he was admitted to the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres in 1782. He notably published:
  • Extraits des divers auteurs grecs, à l’usage de l’école militaire, 6 vol. in-12°, 1768;
  • Lettre sur Horace, adressée aux auteurs du Journal des savants, 1767, in-12°;
  • notes for the edition of Plutarch by Amyot, published by Cussac;
  • Oraisons funèbres, Panégyriques, and Discours, etc.
Appointed president of the Sainte-Geneviève district, then an elector and first alternate deputy from Paris to the Estates-General, he was called to the presidency of the Commune and then to the position of lieutenant mayor. In July 1789, he was responsible for supplies and managed to restore the flow of provisions. He resigned from his position as a member of the Paris municipality at the time of the adoption of the Civil Constitution of the Clergy and published a Témoignage de la raison et de la foi contre la constitution civile du clergé, 1791, in-8°. He retired to Corbeil after 10 August 1792, was elected to the Council of Five Hundred, was included in the deportation list of 18 Fructidor, and had to take refuge in Switzerland before joining Russia. He visited Louis XVIII in Mitau. He was received with great honors in Saint Petersburg by Paul I (who had met him during his trip to France when he was the heir grand duke; Vauvilliers offered Paul his translation of Pindar). He arrived in Saint Petersburg in 1798. He was elected to the Saint Petersburg Academy and appointed professor of literature and director of studies at the Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg in 1799. There, he reunited with old acquaintances, abbot Nicolle and Count de Choiseul-Gouffier, and had time to learn Russian before dying a few months later.
Teaching institutions and families: Academy of Sciences; Academy of Fine Arts (1799–1801), all in Saint Petersburg.
Language and other teaching books by the:
He was the author of:
  • Essai sur Pindare (Paris, 1772, in-12°);
  • Examen du gouvernement de Sparte (Paris, 1769, in-12°);
He published: - Extraits des divers auteurs grecs, à l’usage de l’école militaire, 6 vol. in-12°, 1768;
  • Lettre sur Horace, adressée aux auteurs du Journal des savants, 1767, in-12°;
  • notes for the edition of Plutarch by Amyot, published by Cussac;
  • Oraisons funèbres, Panégyriques, and Discours, etc.;
- Témoignage de la raison et de la foi contre la constitution civile du clergé, 1791, in-8°. He is the author of an edition of engravings representing memorable events in history, published in Russian in Saint Petersburg in 1798:
  • Сокращенная всеобщая история или Собрание эстампов изображающих достопамятнейшия произшествия в истории, как священной, так и светской с принадлежащими к оным историческими изъяснениями / [Translated from French and published by Nikolay Boltin]. Moscow, Унив. тип., у Ридигера и Клаудия, 1798. 8°, 4°. There was a subscription, but it seems that only the first two parts were published, likely due to censorship.

Personal records: (or Velichko, or Weliczkowski/Weliczko) (* Russian Empire – † 1737). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Yakov Velichkovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including the in theological class (until 1727).
Career: After graduation, Yakov Velichkovsky was a protopope (archpriest) in Poltava. In 1728–1734, he was a member of the Codification Commission, as a result of which “Laws by which the People of Little Russia Are Judged...”, a monumental work of Ukrainian legal thought, was created. In the 1736–1737 school year, he taught in the analogy class of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1736–1737).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
The analogy class, taught by Yakov Velichkovsky, had 58 students in the 1736–1737 school year.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), in which Yakov Velichkovsky taught. The teacher also taught grammar rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students.
The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes at the time was the book by Emmanuel Alvarez “De Institutione Grammatica” which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and which was published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely.

Personal records: (or Weneracki, Ioaniki) (*Poltava, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All that is known about Ioaniky Veneratsky is that he took monastic vows in the Vydubychi Monastery in Kyiv in 1740. In the 1743–1744 school year, he taught in the analogy class at Kiev-Mohyla Academy, then in the infima (1744–1745), grammar (1746–1747) and syntax (1747) classes.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1743–1747).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
The grammar classes taught by Ioaniky Veneratsky had more than one hundred students. For example, the analogy class had 202 students. In total, that school year, 902 students were enrolled at the Academy. A year later, Ioaniky Veneratsky taught 175 people in the infima class.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), in which Ioaniky Veneratsky taught. The teacher also taught grammar and syntax rules, grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, the book by Emmanuel Alvarez “De Institutione Grammatica” which was widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and which was published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek) which were intended for Jesuit schools and were printed in Kraków, Poznań, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (Known as Baron de Villedieu or Torcykoff) (1770–1864). Parents: Vivant-Mathias-Raphaël Villedieu de Torcy (1729-03-29, Montcenis, Notre-Dame – 1795-01-19, Louisburg, Germany), counselor to the Parliament and the Court of Aids of Burgundy (8 March 1748), the last dean of the Parliament of Dijon, who emigrated in 1791; Nicole Seguin de La Motte (1745-11-18, Dijon – 1836-09-03, Dijon), married on 14 and 16 March 1767. He first married N. Mergot de Montergon, with whom he had no children. He remarried Amélie Carlet de La Rozière, daughter of Jean Carlet, 2nd Marquis de La Rozière, from Réthelois, chevalier de Saint-Louis, former colonel of cavalry in the service of Portugal in emigration, then marshal of camp in the service of France (1814) and commander of the department of Haute-Vienne (1815). Religion: Catholic.
Career:
Tutor and then civil servant in Russia. A Catholic, parishioner of the church of Saint Louis of the French in Moscow in 1798, he was initially a tutor with a general practitioner. Employed at the Imperial Library from 5 October 1800, he became a college counselor on 7 January 1800, in Russia, and upon his return to France in 1821, he was attached to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the translation office.
Knight of Malta and Knight of the Legion of Honor.
