Personal records: (Known as Fiodor de) (1770, Boulay, Moselle, Lorraine – 1825, Dresden). Married to: Louise Bassenge, originally from Dresden, with whom he had several children. He seems to have remarried.
Career: Tutor. Threatened with legal action, Frédéric de Villers emigrated to Germany during the Revolution and served as a second lieutenant in the army of Condé until June 1785. He passed through the corps of Prince Hohenlohe and Löwenstern before coming to Russia. He taught French in Estonia to the children of Baron Ungern and appeared in Saint Petersburg in 1797, where he met General Ketler, who was at the head of the Naval Cadet Corps. Villers received a teaching position in this institution. In 1799, he accompanied to Dresden a student from this Corps who happened to be the son of Ivan Glukhov, the governor of Saint Petersburg. Upon his return, he submitted his resignation and took a position as a tutor with the Glukhov family, and then with the Princes Meshcherski in Moscow. During another trip to Dresden, this time with a Meshcherski in 1804, he married Louise Bassenge. He was a professor and lecturer (magister) of French at Moscow University since 1806, the year he defended his philosophy thesis. He also ran an educational boarding school in Moscow from 1803 and served as the scientific secretary of the Society for Experimental Studies of Nature (Obshchestvo ispytatelei prirody) at Moscow University. He became a Russian subject, likely since 1806 when the authorities forced the French to adopt Russian nationality. During the occupation of Moscow by Napoleon's troops, he agreed to head the police of Moscow. Several French residents of Moscow (Lassan, Palange, Fabre or Faber) claimed, after the liberation of Moscow, that they had joined the police only under Villers' pressure. He presented to the commander of Moscow a list of individuals capable of fulfilling roles in the occupying municipality. Upon the departure of the French troops from Moscow, Villers received money to leave the city. He went to Warsaw but turned back. In 1814, he was with a landowner in Belarus, in Shklov. He was arrested there, sent to Saint Petersburg for interrogation, tried, and sentenced to exile in Siberia. During the amnesty of 1815, this sentence was commuted to expulsion from the Russian Empire. He left Russia permanently in 1815 to go to Leipzig, then to Dresden, where he taught philosophy and French. The best biographical study on Villers is by D. Gutnov. Could he be one of the editors of the Spectateur du Nord, one of the influential periodicals of the emigration, founded in Hamburg in 1797?
Teaching institutions and families: Ungern, Glukhov, Meshcherski families; Naval Cadet Corps (late 1790s; Saint Petersburg); an educational boarding school in Moscow (from 1803); Moscow University (from 1806).
Students and their social status: Children of Baron Ungern.

Personal records: (*1771, Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Education: He studied at the Kharkiv Collegium from 1785 to 1792.
Career: Concerning Roman Viroslavsky, it is only known that he taught Latin at the Kharkiv Collegium in 1792–1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1792–1793).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In 1792–1793, 455 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. The grammar class taught by Roman Viroslavsky had 37 students. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families (although, students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there). So, in 1792–1793 there were seven “secular” students among the 48 students of the grammar class, in which Roman Viroslavsky taught.
Teaching methods and materials: In the grammar class taught by Roman Viroslavsky, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. When Roman Viroslavsky worked as a Latin teacher at the Kharkiv Collegium, the Instructions on “How to Teach and What to Teach”, that were written by Bishop of Belgorod Samuel Mislavsky in 1769 and addressed to the rector, the prefect and the teachers, were in use at the Collegium. Latin grammar classes were based on Johann Matthias Gesner’s version of the book by Christoph Cellarius. Grammar rules were consolidated by reading Johann Joachim Lange’s “School Dialogues”. At the time, the Collegium had certain traditions concerning the sections and paragraphs of the books that were supposed to be studied at different stages of learning. The surviving school exercises intended for the Collegium students at the time enable us to say that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Students also translated excerpts from Sebastian Castellio’s dialogues, Cicero's letters, sententiae by Epictetus, Aesop, Thales, Conversations of Socrates, and excerpts from secular novels of Western European origin. Extracts from works by Cornelius Nepos were very often translated too. The library of Kharkiv Collegium had copies of these books. The library also had a number of modern dictionaries and lexicons by different authors. Most of the students at the Chernihiv Collegium were from clergy families (although, students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle-class urban inhabitants) also studied there). Personal records: Nephew: Ivan Iakovlevich Wegner, pupil of the Moscow University Grammar School since 23 April 1765. Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Johann Friedrich Wegner taught German at the grammar school of the Moscow University for about 30 years and thus was the teacher with the longest lasting engagement. He was engaged on 10 August 1762 as teacher of the lower German class («нижный немецкий») with an annual salary of 80 roubles. In September 1765 he had a pay rise and henceforth received 110 roubles. The same year, he also taught the German class of eloquence. In the following years, Wegner continued to teach the lower German class. He is listed in the reports on the student’s yearly examination, which always took place in June, until 1770 (documented in Пенчко, 1960–1963). The schedules of lessons, given in the grammar school, document Wegner as teacher of the German class of “etymology” (which in fact means morphology) until June 1791.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school attached to the Moscow University (1762–1791).
Students and their social status:
Nobles; non-nobles.
The grammar school at the Moscow University, which was founded in 1755 on Mikhail Lomonosov’s initiative with the aim of educating students for Moscow University, was divided into two departments: One department for noble students and one for non-nobles. Both departments consisted of four different sections (so-called “schools”): one for Latin, one for Russian, one for European Languages (that is German and French) and one for the “foundations of sciences” (“Anfänge der Wissenschaften”). The school was attended by two different categories of students: those, in receipt of a governmental scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. At the start, there were 50 scholarship students (amongst them nobles and non-nobles) in each section, but this number increased quite quickly. The highest number of students – 1010 – was achieved in 1787 (Koch, 2002, p. 110).
Teaching methods and materials:
The timetables of the grammar school contain information about the subjects taught at individual lessons. According to the schedules of 1775, Wegner taught German reading and writing from 7 to 11 a.m. and also explained “friendly and domestic conversation with the translation thereof” [«дружеские и домашные разговоры с переводом оных»] (Объявление, 1775, without pagination). The timetables of 1783 and 1784 give the same information, adding that «Этимологическия таблицы» (that is ‘morphological schemes’) would be taught repeatedly (Объявление, 1783 and 1784, p. 2). According to the timetables of 1787 and 1790, Wegner instructed the class of etymology every morning from 8 to 12 a.m. He would “teach his pupils the etymology of the German language and explain the German chrestomathy, analyzing each word according to grammatical rules, and give his pupils the best parts for learning by heart” [«обучать учеников своих Этимологии Немецкаго языка, и изъяснять Хрестоматию Немецкую, разбирая в ней каждое слово по правилам Грамматическим, и лучшия места будуть задавать ученикам своим для выучения наизусть»] (Объявление, 1787, p. 10; 1790, p. 15).
Apparently, there were major problems in the teaching of languages at the grammar school of Moscow University, so that the professors of the Moscow University felt compelled to draw attention to the issue in their conference in May 1767. They made the following decision:
“It has been observed that students at the grammar school, especially in the lower classes, get very tired because of studying grammar rules that they do not understand and that are not explained in practice; whereby the Conference demands: 1) That teachers writing on the blackboard examples subject to grammatical analysis should immediately translate them into Russian or from Russian into French, German (or Latin and Italian) and that they should do so every day. This is particularly important for practicing conversation (dialogues). Dialogues, words and phrases explained in such a way should be learned by heart. Grammatical rules that have passed through multiple explanations during the analysis and been read about in grammar books, and thus are comprehended without much difficulty, should be studied in advance. One day a week should be used completely to practice free conversation consisting of questions and answers. 2) That they force their students to do exercises given in the classroom and for homework three times a week, and that in the following morning teachers should sign the revised work and note the day when the hometask was assigned and corrected. Similar exercises should be introduced by teachers in other classes, too, for example, in the mathematics, as well as in the geography and history classes. These exercises, showing the diligence of both teachers and students, should be supervised by the inspector and the rector; they should be the first to be paid attention to by the examiners in the public examinations.” (Minutes of the conference of the professors of Moscow University from 12 May 1767, printed in Пенчко, 1963, p. 41).
Thus, the main focus was on the translation of example sentences. Contrary to prior practices, the student’s mother tongue, Russian, was now incorporated into the process of teaching in order to increase the student’s understanding. Oral skills should be build up by memorizing sample dialogues, which were presented in the so called “dialogue books.” Next to grammar books, these dialogue books represented the main basis for language instruction.
Some years after this first attempt to improve methods of language teaching at the grammar school, in 1771, the professors’ conference published their first official guidelines for teaching languages, the so-called «способ учения» (for the complete version see Сычев-Михайлов, 1960, app. 8, pp. 160-165). It had been developed by the professors of Moscow University under the guidance of the teacher Franz Hölterhof and described in detail the contents, structure and textbooks of language teaching at the grammar school. Furthermore, it provided the language teachers with detailed methodical instructions. It is not definitely proved whether the requirements of this guideline were in fact implemented. However, some evidence shows that this was the case. The schedules of the grammar school classes confirm not only the use of the required textbooks, they also emphasize that lessons followed the published instructions as to method. The fact that the «способ учения» underwent a second edition in 1790, too, indicates that the guidelines proved their worth in practice (for the 2nd edition see Сычев-Михайлов, 1960, app. 9, pp. 166-172).
The «способ учения» clearly focused on the practical use of the language to be learned and was opposed to the  method of memorizing. Practical exercises were to be a main element in each stage of the learning process. Right from the beginning, the instruction of the alphabet, reading and writing had to be linked with exercises of frequent words and phrases. Practicing dialogues and correct pronunciation were very important. In the second class, the so-called “etymological”, declension and conjugation were learned by drilling patterns, whereupon examples had always to be presented within a linguistic context (e.g., phrases and sayings), in order to demonstrate to pupils how to use the words. Phrases were also used for morphological analysis and translation exercises. The next step in progression was the work on simple texts, such as Aesop’s fables for example. These texts were to be read and afterwards translated into Russian. In translating the text, clausal elements and familiar words were to be analysed according to already known morphological rules. These rules were also to be looked up again in the grammar book. This way, the rules would be learned by frequent reading and repeating as well as by practical analysis. After the translation into Russian, the texts were to be translated back into the original language. Additionally, the teacher had to continue to practice dialogues and generally speak as much as possible in the language to be learned. The instruction in the syntax class followed the same methods of analysing and translating texts and practicing dialogues. In particular, the «способ учения» underlined that teachers always should correct the student’s translations and works. If possible, students should assist the teacher in finding the mistakes themselves. In the most advanced class, the class of German style, the teacher dealt with the rules of rhetoric and poetry, which again were to be demonstrated on the basis of selected examples. Following these examples, students were to compose their own letters and speeches.

As for the grammar school attached to the Moscow University, the books used there for learning foreign languages are quite well documented. Initially, the regulations of the school, published with its foundation in 1755, prescribed the use of some standard works, for example Joachim Lange’s “School dialogues” of 1738 which were used in the lower German classes (Регламент Московской Гимназии, in: Белявский, 1955, p.298). In the following years, the professors’ conference, which was one of the administrating institutions of the university, chose and ordered books to be used in classes. Minutes of the conferences and other documents such as book catalogues, book orders etc. were published by Пенчко (1960, 1962 & 1963). Additionally, the «Method of Teaching» prescribed the use of specific textbooks.
For grammar, there were two German grammars which were used in the early 1760s at the grammar school. The school regulation composed by Mikhail Lomonosov in 1758 imposed J.Ch. Gottsched’s German grammar “Grundlegung einer Deutschen Sprachkunst“ for German classes (Ломоносов, 1955, p. 459). From 1762 onwards, the grammar school used the German grammar by М. Agentov, teacher of the German syntax class at the grammar school itself, who had received the order to compose a new grammar for the school probably in 1761 (Koch, 2002, p. 238).
Hölterhof’s “Немецкой Целлариус” was used intensively at the grammar school. Only one year after its publication in 1765, the professors’ conference acknowledged it as the best dictionary of its time and officially enforced its use in German classes. In later years, it was continually purchased for the grammar school. For use in the class of German morphology, the “Немецкой Целлариус”, Hölterhof’s German grammar, Formey’s “Kurzer Inbegriff aller Wissenschaften” and Aesop’s fables were prescribed by the «Method of Teaching». Gottsched’s textbook “Vorübungen der Beredsamkeit“ might have been used at the start of Wegener’s teaching career. This is indicated by the fact that pupils for Wegener’s class were rewarded with Gottsched’s «Краткий [учебник] красноречия» (Пенчко, 1962, p. 131), for excellent achievements at the exams in June 1765.

Personal records: (*Valenciennes) Married to: Barbe (or Varvara Ivanovna) N., widow of Jean-Baptiste Parat (*Paris).
Career: Pensionmaster. “Magistre of Arts from the Imperial University of Moscow.” The Wille couple opened a “noble” educational boarding school for girls in 1792, with the intention of educating a maximum of 25 students, and teaching them: French, Russian according to the rules of grammar, the “purity of writing” in both languages, the “Divine Law,” history, geography, arithmetic, drawing, dancing, and harpsichord. During their leisure hours, the girls were to engage in “handicrafts suitable for noble young ladies.” Mme Wille committed to personally supervise the students and employ all means to elevate their hearts and “adorn their minds with useful and pleasant knowledge.” This boarding school was located in the house they owned, which they had purchased from general Kar, on Pokrovka Street near the church of Kosma and Damian, at No. 110. The Wille family resided in the 5th district of Moscow when they took the oath in 1793.
Teaching institutions and families: Moscow University; a “noble” educational boarding school for girls (from 1792; Moscow).

Personal records: (German lands – 1740-05-28, Saint Petersburg). Married to: 1.) Gottliebe Knoll (1695-09-02—1734-07-14); 2.) Metta Westergarten († 1740-05-02). Religion: Lutheran.
Career: Johann Gottlieb Windorf was adjunct professor and “Обер-Учитель” for German at the Infantry Noble Cadet Corps in Saint Petersburg. He is recorded in the staff lists of 1737 and 1738 and continued to work at the Cadet Corps until his death in 1740. According to the time-table of 1737, Windorf taught German three or four hours a day to a total of 74 students. After he had worked at the Cadet Corps for two years, he asked for a salary increase saying that otherwise he would leave the Cadet Corps. As a result, he had a new contract for another three years, with an increased salary of 300 roubles per year. In addition to his previous duties, he had to translate documents from the Cadet Corps administration, which were usually written in German, into Russian.
Teaching institutions and families: Infantry Noble Cadet Corps (1737–1740, Saint Petersburg).
Students and their social status: Nobility.
Teaching methods and materials:
The main method of language teaching at the time was learning by heart. Thus, the students learned declension and conjugation forms from the grammar book and also memorized vocabulary and dialogues. These studies were completed by translation, one of the “principal means of teaching foreign languages in the Cadet Corps” (Rjéoutski, 2013). “The cadets were trained to translate from German into French and from French into German and later, at least from the beginning of the reign of Catherine, from and into Russian as well” (Rjéoutski, 2013).

Personal records: (1684-07-22, Serben (now Dzērbene), Swedish Livonia – 1729/1731, Riga?, Russian Empire). Father: Nikolaus Wurm, a pastor. Mother: Katharina Wurm, née Burbach. Married to: Maria Wurm († 1731-11-05). Religion: Lutheran.
Education: University studies.
Career:
Tutor.
Johann Gustav Wurm was employed as tutor in the household of a parish priest named Johann Ernst Glück in Marienburg, Swedish Livonia, to teach Glückʼs children. In 1702, during the Great Northern War, Glück and his family were captured by the Russians and brought to Moscow. Wurm followed them into captivity.
After his arrival in Moscow, Wurm began to teach Russian children in the German Quarter. Furthermore, he was one of the first teachers at the Moscow Foreign Language School, which was run by J.E. Glück from March 1703 onwards. In a letter of March 1704, Glück reported to August Hermann Francke (university professor and pietist in Halle and supporter of Glück’s school) the presence of about five teachers, who were already working at his school. One of those was Wurm, who possibly started to teach Latin at the school in the course of the year 1703. In Glück’s conception of the school, Wurm was to be a teacher of German and Latin grammar. De facto – as the payrolls prove – he taught German only. In 1706, Wurm was teaching German six hours per day to the medium class. His salary was 40 roubles, plus 28 roubles for subsistence. In the period between 1706 and 1710, the school experienced its most successful period: up to 12 teachers were teaching more than 100 students. Wurm continued to teach German in the medium class. Other teachers of German and Latin were Otto Berghahn and Michael Ruttich in the lower class and Peter Daniel Brettschneider and Christian Büttner in the upper class. The deсline of the school, which was now called “German school”, began in early 1711. Due to declining student numbers, the staff was reduced to four teachers: Wurm, Brettschneider (both German), Johann Nordgren (Swedish) and Joseph Hagen (French). The curriculum was restricted to languages, namely Latin, German, French, Swedish and Italian. From August 1712 until the closure of the school in September 1715, Wurm remained the only teacher of German with a small group of students. In the following year, Wurm and Hagen were ordered to move to St. Petersburg. According to M. Schmücker-Breloer, they both received a contract to teach at the Maritime Academy (морская академия). In 1718, Wurm became a translator at the Collegium of Justice. Later he is documented as co-rector of the “Stadttöchterschule” (city school for girls) in Vyborg. From 1728 onwards, Wurm lived in Riga and apparently fell on hard times.
Teaching institutions and families:
Moscow Foreign Language School; Maritime Academy (?); “Stadttöchterschule” (city school for girls) in Vyborg.
Family of parish priest Johann Ernst Glück.
Students and their social status:
Nobility; civil servants; soldiers, merchants, craftsmen.
At the beginning, pupils of the Moscow Foreign Language School came almost exclusively from the higher nobility or the officialdom. They had to learn foreign languages for their future diplomatic service or service in the administration and the ministries (collegia). Quite soon, the social background of the pupils was significantly extended, with sons of soldiers and craftsmen being also enrolled. There were two different categories of students: students in receipt of a government scholarship and independent (self-funding) pupils. To attract more pupils, students were exempt from military service during the first years of the school’s existence.

Aleksei Zenzerov; Semion Pavlov; Andrei Gorlov; Galation Chizhev; Piotr Kopiev; Mikhailo Fonarnikov
Other pupils of Wurm’s class in 1711 are named in Белокуров/Зерцалов, 1907, p. 113f. The complete list of pupils studying at the Moscow Foreign Language School between 1703 and 1715 was published by Белокуров/Зерцалов, 1907, pp. XXII-XL.
Teaching methods and materials:
In July 1712, Wurm reported on the results of six of the students in his German class. Most of them were learning German in the second year, namely Aleksei Zenzerov, Semion Pavlov, Andrei Gorlov, and Galation Chizhev. They could read and write in German, had learned the declensions and conjugation and some of them could also hold a conversation in German. After two months of learning, Piotr Kopiev «выучил азбуку и начал писать по немецки» [“has learned the alphabet and begun to write in German”] (Белокуров/Зерцалов, 1907, p. XVII). Four months later (in July 1712) the same student could read and write in German and also «выучил разныя вокабула и разговоры» [“has learned various vocables and conversations”]. The sixth student, Mikhailo Fonarnikov, after five months of learning, could read and write single words and had learned some dialogues by heart (Белокуров/Зерцалов, 1907, p. 179).
In November 1712, the advanced pupils Aleksei Zenzerov, Semion Pavlov, Andrei Gorlov, and Galation Chizhev practised translating “exercitia”. About Piotr Kopiev, Wurm reported «учится фестибулум и разговоры, яко и грамматику» [“is learning ‘Vestibulum’ and conversations, as well as grammar”] (Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. 181).
In May 1715, Wurm reported that his student Mitrofan Vasiliev «выучился по немецки читать и писать, твердить грамматику и зачал учиться Орбис Пиктус и разныя разговоры» [“has learned to read and write in German, to recite grammar by heart, and has begun to learn ‘Orbis Pictus’ and various conversations”] (Белокуров/ Зерцалов, 1907, p. 198).
Wurm’s report gives precise information about the progression of language learning at that time. In the early stages, pupils first learned to read single words. For this purpose, they could use German primers (азбука). Next, pupils learned to write in German and enlarged their vocabulary. To acquire oral skills, students learned dialogues by heart. Therefore, they may have used compilations such as the popular Latin-German dialogues of the German philologist Johann Georg Seybold, which had been translated into Russian by Johann W. Paus. Books were usually learnt by heart page by page. The most popular books for language learning were John Amos Comenius’ “Vestibulum”, “Janua” and “Orbis sensualium pictus”, all dating from the 17th century. Johann Ernst Glück and Johann W. Paus both completed these bi- or multilingual books (for example Latin-German or Latin-German-French versions) with Russian equivalents for the needs of their Russian students. “Vestibulum” was used at the end of the first year of learning, the “Orbis Pictus” in the second year. In the second year, students were also exposed to grammar, probably by learning declensions and conjugation forms by heart. Furthermore, they practised translations. In addition, pupils worked with German texts from the New Testament and hymns, which had been also translated into Russian by Glück and Paus.

Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Vestibulum linguae latinae […]. 
Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Januae linguarum reseratae […],
Comenius, Ioannes Amos, Orbis sensualium pictus […] Die sichtbare Welt […] (possibly: Nürnberg, 1698).
It is not quite sure which issues of Comeniusʼ books were used at the Moscow Foreign Language School. What we do know is that Johann Ernst Glück translated Comeniusʼ “Vestibulum”, “Januae” and “Orbis pictus” into Russian. The “Vestibulum” was completed by end of 1703 and Glück applied to the tsar with the petition to publish it as “Преддверие к познанию русскаго, немецкаго, латинскаго и францускаго языков” (Белокуров 1907, p. 47). However, all the manuscripts remained unpublished.
Other texts used in language classes at the Moscow Foreign Language school:
various nomenclatores (primer, азбука) in German; proverbs; compilations of dialogues (possibly the Latin-German dialogues of Johann Georg Seybold); Lutheran Bible; Lutheran catechism; German hymns.

Personal records: (or Janowicz; Parthenius) (†1728). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: Concerning Parfeny Yanovich, we know that he was an infima class teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the 1719–1720 school year. At the time, he was a hierodeacon. Several months after the beginning of the school year, he became a preacher and examiner at the “Metropolitan’s House” in Kyiv. In 1724, he was summoned to the Slavic-Greek-Latin Academy in Moscow, where he worked as a poetics teacher. He retired due to illness in 1727 and died in 1728.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1719–1720); Moscow Slavic Greek Latin Academy (1724–1727).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
There were several dozen students in the infima class taught by Parfeny Yanovich.
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima class taught by Parfeny Yanovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules as well as grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. At the time, the textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (or Jasnikowski; Athanasius; secular name: Andrey) (*1710, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth). Son of a (szlachta) gentleman. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Afanasy Yasnikovsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (he has been mentioned in documents as a philosophy class student). During his studies, he took monastic vows.
Career: Afanasy Yasnikovsky taught the infima class at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in the first half of the 1742–1743 school year, the grammar class in the second part of the 1742–1743 school year and in the 1743–1744 school year, and the syntax class in the 1744–1745 school year (having the rank of hieromonk). Afanasy Yasnikovsky was appointed namestnik (vicar) at one of the monasteries assigned to Saint Nicholas’s Poustinia Monastery in Kyiv in 1745 and at Saint Nicholas’s Poustinia Monastery in 1751. He retired in 1758.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1742–1745).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
Several dozen people studied in the grammar classes which Afanasy Yasnikovsky taught at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. For example, in September 1743, there were 127 students in the grammar class taught by Afanasy Yasnikovsky.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there. For example, in September 1743, out of the 127 students enrolled in the grammar class taught by Afanasy Yasnikovsky, 75 were “raznochintsy” (people of miscellaneous ranks).
Teaching methods and materials: In the infima and grammar class taught by Afanasy Yasnikovsky, students studied grammar rules and grammar analysis; they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Academy and at the Seminary at the time was “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares. The surviving exercises intended for school and home work show that the students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were used for teaching Polish at the Academy at the time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (or Johann) (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: All we know concerning Ioann Yuzefovich is that he taught Latin in the syntax class at the Kharkiv Collegium in 1751.
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1751).
Students and their social status:
Clergy.
In the 1750s, more than 400 students were enrolled at the Kharkiv Collegium. There were several dozen students in the syntax class, which Ioann Yuzefovich taught.
Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: In the syntax class taught by Ioann Yuzefovich, students studied grammar and syntax rules, they also did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Kharkiv Collegium from the first years of its existence and at the beginning of the 1750s was still the book “De institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvares, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. A large number of Latin textbooks published for the Jesuit collegiums of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) were mentioned in the library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753). The “purchase of the Alvares” was a common expense at the Kharkiv Collegium at the time. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Kharkiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Personal records: (or Zarudinsky) (*Russian Empire). Religion: Orthodox.
Career: Concerning Gavriil Zarudnitsky, we know that he taught Latin in the analogy and infima classes at the Kharkiv Collegium in 1737–1739. Then apparently he worked in the subsequent (grammar and syntax) classes. In 1741 he was a rhetoric teacher. By this time, he had taken monastic vows: he was mentioned as “hieromonk” in the documents, and not as “magister” (as in the 1730s). In 1744, he taught philosophy. Gavriil Zarudnitsky was also the Prefect of the Collegium (1741–1742).
Teaching institutions and families: Kharkiv Collegium (1737–1744).
Students and their social status: Clergy. In 1737–1738, there were 522 students at the Kharkiv Collegium. In those years, the analogy and infima classes had several dozen students in each of them. Most of the students at the Kharkiv Collegium were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, merchants and meschane (low and middle class urban inhabitants) also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the analogy, in which Gavriil Zarudnitsky taught. In contrast to Jesuit collegiums, there was a preparatory analogy (phara) class in Orthodox collegiums. In the infima class, students studied the rules of grammar and grammar analysis, and did translation exercises. The Latin textbook used at the Kharkiv Collegium from the first years of its existence and in the 1730s was the “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used in Jesuit schools and at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. A large number of textbooks published for the Jesuit collegiums of Rzeczpospolita (the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth) were recorded in the library catalogue of the Kharkiv Collegium (1753). At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely at the Kharkiv Collegium. The surviving school exercises of the Collegium students of those years show that they translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. Personal records: (or Nicolas) (France – 1771, Kyiv, Russian Empire).
Education: It is unknown where exactly Margast de Zeemilière studied, but the correspondence between the Moscow archbishop Amvrosy Zertis-Kamensky and the Kyiv metropolitan Arseny Mogiliansky shows that they were searching for a candidate with a sufficiently good education for the position of French teacher at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Career: Margast Zeemilière announced the opening of his private boarding school in Moscow in 1766. Students of different social origins were admitted to his school, but it was mostly focused on the children of merchants because, according to his statements, they had limited opportunities to study religion, and their opportunities for learning foreign languages and "liberal sciences" were even more limited. He planned to teach French, German, history and geography at his school. The boarding school was located in Bersenevka, across the Moskva River, in the house of Peter Alekseev, a dyachok (clerk) at the Ascension Church and a catechist at the Moscow University. On 10 May 1770, he signed a contract for four years to teach French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. In 1771, Margast de Zeemilière died of the plague during an epidemic in Kyiv.
Teaching institutions and families: Private boarding school in Moscow (1766); Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (1770–1771).
Students and their social status:
Merchants; clergy; Cossacks.
At the time, several dozen students from the syntax and rhetoric classes (and a few students from the philosophy and theology classes) studied French at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the terms of the contract, Zeemilière could give private French lessons not only to students of the Academy, but also to other interested persons (for an additional fee).
Zeemilière’s boarding school was primarily open for children from merchants' families. Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials:
The contract that was signed with Margast de Zeemilière stated that he was supposed to teach reading, writing, speaking and also rules for composing conversations and letters in French.
The contract signed with Zeemilière stated that he would use the textbook compiled by Martyn Sokolovsky for his teaching. The textbook was available at the Academy library. It is obvious that Zeemilière did not lack textbooks for students. He could use other French grammar books and lexicons, which were available at the library of the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy. According to the library catalogue, it contained a significant number of grammar books, lexicons and dictionaries (by Pierre Restaut, Giovanni Veneroni and François-Antoine Pomey) at the time. Rather short book descriptions in the catalogue don’t make it possible to identify all the books accurately.

Personal records: (or Zełenecki; secular name: Fiodor) (* ab. 1717, Sotnia town of Budischa in the Poltava Regiment, Russian Empire). Son of a merchant. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: It is known that Feofan Zelenetsky studied at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, including in the theological class. During his studies, he took monastic vows at the Brotherhood Monastery in Kyiv.
Career: In 1742–1747, Feofan Zelenetsky taught in the analogy class, and then in the subsequent grammar classes at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy.
Teaching institutions and families: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (from 1742).
Students and their social status:
Clergy; Cossacks.
There were several dozen students in the grammar classes in which Feofan Zelenetsky taught. For example, in the infima class, taught by Feofan Zelenetsky, there were 149 students; in the 1744–1745 school year, 121 students attended grammar classes given by the teacher.
Most of the students at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy were from clergy families, although students from families of the Cossack elite, ordinary Cossacks, and merchants also studied there.
Teaching methods and materials: The basics of Latin and Polish were studied in the first (preparatory) class of the phara (analogy class), in which Feofan Zelenetsky taught. He also taught grammar and syntax rules and grammar analysis and did translation exercises with his students. The textbook used at the Academy for Latin classes was, at the time, “De Institutione Grammatica” by Emmanuel Alvarez, widely used both in Jesuit schools and at Orthodox collegiums and published in different European cities. Students also translated prayers, troparia, kontakia, Latin proverbs, and excerpts from the Gospel. At the time, the amount of educational material for each of the classes was not defined precisely. In all likelihood, the so-called “Knapiusz lexicons” were also used for teaching Polish at that time. These were textbooks by Grzegorz Knapski, a well-known compiler of dictionaries and lexicons (Polish-Latin, Polish-Latin-Greek), which were intended for Jesuit schools and printed in Kraków, Poznan, and Lwów (Lviv) in the 17th century. Personal records: (or Zolotnickij) (1741, Kyiv Governorate, Russian Empire – after 1796, Russian Empire). Zolotnitsky was born into the family of a village priest in the Kyiv Regiment. Married to: 1.) Uliana Lazarevna Serezlieva; 2.) Ulita Ivanovna Troinitskaia. From the 1st marriage he had nine children; from the 2nd – three children. Religion: Orthodox.
Education: Zolotnitsky began his studies at the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in Kyiv. In spring 1755, he was part of a group of students who were sent from the Kyiv Academy to Moscow in order to continue their studies at the recently-founded Moscow University.
Career:
Lawyer. In 1760, being still a student, Zolotnitsky began to teach German at the grammar school which was attached to the Moscow University. In May 1762, he became teacher of the German class, replacing teacher Iurovsky, who was transferred to the grammar school at the University of Kazan. Shortly after that, Zolotnitsky was moved to Saint Petersburg, where he joined the Land Noble Cadet Corps also to teach German. In June 1764, he left the Cadet Corps to become a translator at the Chamber Collegium («Камер-коллегия»).
Over the years, Zolotnitsky rose through the ranks in various juridical functions. Starting as a secretary in the staff of senator «генерал-аншеф» [general-in-chief] Piotr I. Panin, he later became member of the « от шляхетства Малороссийской губернии» [“Little Russia nobility commission for drafting a new legal code”] chief accountant, head of the chancellery in Crimea, procurator at the chancellery of the New Russia Governorate in  and procurator of the governorate in . At the end of his career, in 1795, he was head of the civil court in Ekaterinoslav. Zolotnitsky published a great many books about jurisprudence, philosophy and theology, among these both translations from German and Latin and his own works.
Teaching institutions and families: Grammar school at the Moscow University (1760–1762); Infantry Noble Cadet Corps (1762–1764).
